description:
I was very impressed and pleased with my dinner at Barbacco. The food was tasty, creative, and impeccably plated. The burrata with squash and pomegranate was an explosion of different flavors and textures that melted in your mouth. The pasta dishes were delicious (stuck with a traditional bolognese - I love my bolognese - and it didn't disappoint). The carrot cake dessert was a perfect ending to the meal. 

To add to this, the service was friendly and food came out at a well-timed moment. The restaurant itself is sleek and welcoming. I will definitely be returning!
author: Philippe D.

description:
Widely considered the cheaper version of its next-door neighbor, Perbacco. Although the vibe inside the restaurant is nice, the food doesn't quite deliver. 

For the main course, I ordered the Fusilli dish with pomegranates. It was rich and creamy, but it was extremely bland. I ordered it because I was curious how pomegranates would go with pasta, but it was not great. It was too tangy for the subtle taste of the pasta. The fusili was also pretty undercooked. I thought maybe it was just my pasta but I had similar feelings about the mushroom pasta as well althought it was a bit better. The Brussel sprouts that we got for the appetizer, however, were fantastic. They were extremely crispy and full of flavor - could've honestly made an entire meal out of those brussel sprouts.
author: Sampath D.

description:
I have yet to find a delicious pasta place in the Bay and this place has not stopped my search. 
We had dinner here on a Saturday night with reservations. We were seated promptly and service was great the whole night. 

Decent fare:
-Arancini: I've had better but this wasn't bad. Really thick balls of risotto deep fried with cheese in the middle, so what's not to love. 
- Meatballs: Juicy pork meatballs with pine nuts and raisins in tomato sauce. I would get this dish if you come here. 

What took this down to 3 stars:
-Orecchiette: The pasta itself was decent; cooked well with a great texture. What threw me off was the hard chunks of broccoli scattered throughout. I've had broccoli orechiette before that was executed well and I can't say the same for this. 
-Bruschetta: Wow, the saddest bruschetta I've ever had. The bread was tiny and ridiculously hard. There was some sad flavorless balsamic sauce on top and then sprinkled with some pink pickled thing and shaved Parmesan. They really need to change this dish up. 

Overall, not impressed with this spot and the search for good Italian food continues.
author: Jenny L.

description:
For a FiDi lunch spot, Barbacco is 5*. The prices are reasonable, the location is convenient, and the food is tasty. What more could you ask for?

As the casual younger sister of Perbacco, Barbacco is one of my go-to spots when having lunch with coworkers on our own dime. Reservations are a must and you can usually get one during prime lunch hour if you plan a few days in advance.

The pastas are what Barbacco is known for and are generally in the $17 range. The sandwiches are a steal. On my last visit, I ordered a Roasted Porchetta Sandwich that came with provolone, arugula, and delicious onion jam. It was huge and it ended up being lunch for 2 days. The meat was tender, juicy, and a little fatty (in a good way). The spiciness of the arugula paired with the sweetness of the onion jam was heavenly. At $14 for the sandwich, that's basically the same price you'd pay at a take-out place.
author: Yi Z.

description:
Great meal. Came for Saturday dinner and it was really full and lively. Ordered the Bruschetta, Orecchiette, Polpette & One more dish that I can't recall the name of. Personally did not care for the Bruschetta. 

-B
author: Brandon G.

description:
We had a decent dinner experience at Barbacco. 8pm on a Thursday evening, the place was quite busy - definitely best to make a reservation for dinner. They said it would be a 45 minute wait, but we got lucky with a small corner table, just big enough for three. It was cozy, but doable for a last minute dinner, although there was a cold draft throughout most of our meal. The restaurant seating is a little crowded, with the tables a little too close together and wobbly contemporary chairs that aren't very comfortable to sit on. We could very easily hear the conversations of the two tables next to us.

We ordered a Burrata appetizer, Vegetarian Meatballs, Corn Fusilli, the Fettuccine, and the Chocolate Nemesis Cake for dessert. The Burrata was great, definitely an appetizer you can't go wrong with.

Of the entire meal, my favorite was the Corn Fusilli - the pesto seemed to lack salt, but the texture of the dish was what really got me. The sweet corn kernels added a great "crunch" to contrast with the al dente pasta. I added a little bit of salt and I have a tendency to put chili flakes on everything, so those added a little extra flavor for me too, but even without those, the dish really stood out.

The Fettuccine was alright - while the pasta was well-made, I wanted the dish to be a little creamier. Instead, it came across a little watery and didn't really come together for me.

The Vegetarian "Meatballs" are made with Impossible brand meat, and it's great to see a prominent upscale restaurant offering these options. The texture of the meatballs is soft and every bite bursts with flavor. As a vegetarian who isn't used to meaty textures, this dish is a little bit of an adjustment, and it's definitely geared towards meat-eaters trying to incorporate vegetarian meals into their diet. Nonetheless, it's a well-made dish that deserves 4 stars for both effort and execution.

Finally, we ended our evening with the Chocolate Nemesis Cake. The slice was very dense, more like a solidified mousse than a cake. It was good we shared the slice between three people as a couple of bites was more than enough for all of us. I didn't care too much for the candied hazelnuts - the smokey flavor was too overpowering. The presentation also left much to be desired. The other dishes came out neatly plated, but it seemed the the cream and hazelnuts on the cake were just thrown onto the plate.

Our waiter was very friendly and service was solid. We really appreciated them making space for us on a busy night. The food is so-so, but I can see how the atmosphere makes for a nice evening out.
author: Apoorva A.

description:
This place is conveniently located near the Embaradero, which was perfect for a Saturday night as we were going to a show at the Punchline.

I had a pasta dish that has wine infused in the pasta.  That sounded awesome, except it was cooked really al dente.  The waitress was nice enough to replace it with one that was cooked.  I rarely send food back but that pasta was really chewy (and I recognize that even though my dad is 100% italian-american, I am not a big fan of tough pasta).  The second version was much better, but not sure that I would have that again.

My wife had the Orecchiette, which was pretty good (and was properly cooked).

We finished off the meal with an Affagato with olive oil gelato which was pretty nice.

While that dinner was just okay, the Vegetarian Meatballs (made with "impossible meat) sounds pretty interesting.  i may be back.
author: Bob F.

description: One of the best Italian restaurants I've dined at recently. All dishes hit the spot. chicken liver dish was superb...we ordered 2. The fried cheese or risotto balls were so good, the rigatoni bolognese was amazing, and meatballs were good...we ordered seconds in both as well. We also had the butternut squash risotto, however, it was just OK. My friends liked the squid ink octopus but squid ink just wasn't for me. Service was good. Wine was good. Will definitely come back!
author: Lorie N.

description:
Yummy pasta and cute atmosphere. We enjoyed everything we tried: buratta, red wine pasta, meatballs and Brussels sprouts. We ate at the bar and service was quick and friendly. 

Side note there is a large tv behind the bar so if you're going to a nice dinner during a big game there's that option.
author: Daniela J.

description:
The vegetarian meatballs were delicious but I felt like it would have been perfection to leave it in the microwave or oven for that perfect crispy exterior and softer interior hence I will take off two stars. For 20$ a plate on average you don't have room for error 

Their beer and wine selections are very good. Good place to eat on a Saturday night when everything else in FiDi is closed
author: Vikas J.

description: The bruschetta was incredible. I didn't think I'd like it (the ingredients separately are all suspicious to me) but I had it over a month ago and I'm still thinking about it. The fettucine was good too (as everything on the menu likely is- Barbacco was packed on a Friday lunch) but not as memorable as the bruschetta.
author: Alice Z.

description:
Ever since moving to San Francisco I have been told by friends and colleagues to try Barbacco. It's the first place everyone rambles off when you ask about where to go in the Financial District, and they're not wrong. What a treat this place is! First of all, the restaurant and bar area is enormous - they can really fit a lot of people inside, but boy does it fill up quickly at happy hour and dinner time. We made reservations in advance and I'm so glad we did because we probably would have had to wait awhile had we not. We even got there a little early and they were able to immediately seat us, which was nice. 

The interior was sleek. The staff all matched and looked very professional, and we were talked to by several people before our server reached the table, to fill up our waters, hand us menus, etc. - everyone really worked together.

We ordered a bottle of red wine, two pasta dishes and carrot cake for dessert. Let's start with the pasta! I ordered the shrimp linguine which was so good and surprisingly filling. However, I was a little disappointed in the amount and size of the shrimp though - there were only 3-4 pieces of shrimp and they were truly tiny. The white sauce was yummy - with garlic and chili to give it a little kick, but it did not overwhelm the other ingredients, and the pasta was cooked perfectly. The second pasta dish was the rigatoni alla bolognese with beef and pork ragu. The pasta was infused with the sauce which made for an interesting look and a different but good tasting noodle. There was also additional sauce with the meat, so it was not lacking in the sauce department! The portions for both were large enough for the price at a fancy yet affordable Italian restaurant and we were not disappointed at all. We then ordered the carrot cake for dessert which came with a scoop of ice cream on top. Yum! It was a little on the dry side, but if you ate it with the ice cream it tasted really good.

Our bill totaled to right below $120 with tip - not bad. The service throughout our meal was so great and we really felt well taken care of.
author: Bri T.

description: Kind of a go to place for business meetings since it's so easy to make reservations.  Usually always a spot available last minute.  Items that stuck out to me was the bruschetta and fried brussel sprouts.
author: Jeffrey H.

description:
Barbacco is a busy place for lunch in financial district, but it provides the excellence of food and service. 

I tried salad. Pretty simple and stylish. Great place for business lunch.
author: Shell J.

description:
so, it was a beautiful sunny day and I had visitors.
some of my visitors were hungry and they wanted Italian.
but the problem was ..
we were in little Italy!
you know that if you're from or live in San Francisco, you don't go to little Italy for Italian food!
you just don't.

so I took them to Barbacco for some hearty pastas and they liked it!
7 of us were ordering different things.
mine was "Spalla di Maiale Arrosto" (Braised Pork Neck w/Salad).
the pork was succulent, great cut, and delicious.
came with side small salad w/vinaigrette and it was pretty satisfying.
everyone in my party seems to enjoyed their orders as well.

will I come back here?
most definitely.
author: Rudy H.

description:
Came here for Valentine's Day 2018 and the food was good, customer service was great! 

Favorites were the Brussels sprouts and risotto, especially mixing them together! Meatballs were good too, but the fettuccine was a little underwhelming. 

Customer service was amazing. We were running late, which I thought would be a big deal especially for Valentine's Day, but they were very accommodating. Took great pics for us ladies too. 

And last but not least, price was very affordable. Definitely recommend Barbacco!
author: Raquel Y.

description: Excellent restaurant! Five star service and food was cooked to perfection! Only issue was it's a smaller (very narrow) restaurant, making a tight fit so you may end up sitting shoulder to shoulder with someone you don't know. But it was worth the lack of boundaries. Excellent place!
author: Raean P.

description:
I am surprised I have not reviewed Barbacco yet. Big fan of them and their sister restaurant Perbacco.

Both serve awesome Northern Italian food. Never had a bad meal or service at either over the years. I consistently refer friends here when they ask for a Italian recommendation.
author: Sunil R.

description:
So so place in the financial district. Lots of suits and ties. 

Burrata - yes
Aracinni - small and unmemorable
Shrimp linguini - I would probably order this again. Simple dish and good sized portion.
author: Song C.

description:
This is a really great budget friendly authentic Italian restaurant! A sister restaurant to perbac
I've been three times now, once for lunch with a girlfriend, with my parents & husband & with girlfriends! Their menu stays th same but is very good. 
They have an excellent selection of pastas, cheeses, salumi, & wine that will knock your socks off!
It usually not too hard to get a reservation here either
author: Ashley G.

description:
My friend was able to make a reservation right at opening time just 2 hours prior.  

The deep and narrow restaurant seems to be divided into 2 sections: a more well lit area for diners more than 2, and a more dim area for diners 2 or less.  Actually there also the counter seating I though looked nice. My friend and I were seated right at the divide, where he sat next to a column awkwardly.  All the tables were parabola shaped which at first felt weird but you kind of forgot about it afterwards.

Let's talk food!

Here's what my friend and I shared:

PEAR & ENDIVE SALAD - $14 - Gorgonzola Crema, Toasted Hazelnut, Mosto Cotto
This salad had a nice balance of many textures and flavors.  It has the nice crunch of the salad, the creaminess is the Gorgonzola that's not too strong in taste, the nuttiness of the hazelnuts and the sweetness of the ripe pears.  I really enjoyed this salad.  Good to share as a starter.

ORRECHIETTE - $17 - "Little Ears", Broccoli di Ciccio, Fennel Sausage, Pecorino.
I made this choice because of the Yelp recommendations and photos--it looked good! But it was disappointing. It felt like something was missing. Perhaps an olive oil base  or butter topping because it tasted so dry, a lot of the "littler ears were stuck together. There was hardly any fennel sausage. It honestly didn't feel or taste like pasta. 

POLPETTE - $16 - Sicilian Meatballs w/Pine Nuts, Raisins, Spicy Tomato Sugo
Ordered this because it came up a lot on Yelp. It was good. It was not special but it was good.  You get 3 huge meatballs that was salty and flavorful enough in chunky tomato sauce.  I don't recall seeing or tasting any raisins.

FRIED BRUSSELS SPROUTS - $6
Capers, Anchovy Vinaigrette
This came out last and it smelled so good! Some had a nice crisp to it and I'm glad t didn't have that usual weird Brussels sprouts taste.  This was probably my favorite out of everything.  Maybe if everything else was fried I would have enjoyed them more :P

NEMESIS (Chocolate Flourless Cake) - $6 - w/Vanilla Bean Crema, White Chocolate Crunch, Preserved Dark Cherries
Our server recommended this and I went for it. It is SUPER rich and pretty good. But I don't rec this if you rather have something lighter for dessert. I liked the thin white chocolate crunch a lot.  Boy was this rich.  

The service was the stellar, the restaurant felt fancy and the food was just ok. It was still nice to try a place I never been to before.
author: Tu-Anh N.

description:
The seating was horrendous. The tables are put too close to each other. I saw three women falling or struggling to get in  or crawling on the floor to get out.  And the chairs can barely support your butt. They barely qualify to be bar stools. 
At this point I hoped the food will turn around the story.  But no.  Food was "OK".  I ordered the fish and my family ordered the homemade pasta.  It was just "OK". 
Back in my room.  Sitting on a real chair with back support.
author: Thiroo T.

description:
Came here for a workday lunch.  Got seated at the counter.  The place filled out quickly.  Server was professional, swift, and just the right attentiveness.  He seemed to know exactly when I need service and when I don't want to be bothered.

The special was white trout and I went for it.  Was delicious, only a bit small in portion.  I asked for bread and they soaked up the sauce very nicely.

Of course it is pricy.
author: Sin-Yaw W.

description:
Worth trying:

Not your typical authentic Italian restaurant but fresh and well put together..Nice a bit different, clean fresh flavors not as heavy and robust as your typical Italian food..

Favorite: Octopus, Brussel sprouts, Beef stew
author: Head Chef F.

description: Finally got to try Perbacco's more fun sister restaurant or so I've been told. We didn't have a reservation on a Friday night but were able to be promptly seated at the long bar. I immediately loved the ambiance. It's much more casual, fun and trendy compared to perbaccos white tablecloths. I started with a spritz and we moved on to apps - burrata and chefs selection of salmi. Delicious. I couldn't wait for the rest of the meal. For mains, we ordered 2 very different pasta dishes. Orecchiette with broccoli and rigatoni bolognese. The orecchiette was light and the fennel sausage was a good balance to the broccoli. The rigatoni was more traditional and very hearty. This is seriously my new favorite Italian restaurant.
author: Yin H.

description: My friend and I came in the afternoon for a late lunch, and the decoration is quite cozy yet modern. They have a small menu for the afternoon, we ordered the bolognese and orecchiette (which were the only options). They were really good! I especially enjoyed the bolognese spaghetti
author: Jin Y.

description: Visiting from Boston for a conference and was having a hard time finding a dinner place that would be decently "friendly" to our 3 year old.  That's the tough part of staying in the financial district.  Took a chance on Barbacco--I figured the little one would share some pasta with me.  Although seating was tight (I did manage to fold my stroller up under the table), they were so, sooo good to my kid!  Waiter immediately offered to make her any pasta she wanted in a smaller size and found her a plastic cup with straw.  Food was great - husband got sirloin tips, I had the pesto fusilli which was delicious, and kiddo happily chowed her orecchiette pasta.  That and a nice pour of wine and it's a wonderful Sat night dinner!
author: Shari J.

description:
I broke up with Barbacco tonight. We've had some highs. We've had some lows. Tonight was the last straw. Made the reservation through open table saying we were celebrating two birthdays. Not until we signed our checks did our server acknowledge them. 

More importantly, it's stupidly loud, they have pared down the menu, they have increased their prices and they flat out refused to serve a single meatball even though they have it as a main. They used to serve 1 or 2 if you requested it. Nope, no more people.

I ordered the carbonara and had been told it was cooked in salt from the pancetta (?) but it was so ridiculously salty that I had to send it back. Felt like I had eaten a salt lick. It was terrible and not like any delicious creamy carbonara I have had before.

Our server was great about replacing my meal which I really appreciate. I ordered the orecchiette. It was only meh. Not worth the price of admission. I can doctor up my leftovers but in the past, I wouldn't have had to say that about any of their food. 

Bottom line, there are plenty of other restaurants in the city. I will be checking them out. Sad but true.  Barbacco used to be my go to place.
author: Tera K.

description: Excellent food. Super service. Fish is very fresh. Love the homemade pasta. It takes reservation during busy lunch hour otherwise the wait line is very long.
author: Chi-Li T.

description: Last minute ressie cause I needed some fresh pasta. They didn't disappoint. Great fresh saffron fettuccine with mushroom sauce. Brussels were missing flavor and adding lemon didn't help. Maybe salt? Pepper? Something. Service was fine, the real star was the pasta.
author: Roxanna A.

description:
A colleague and I visited Barbacco for dinner last week. We made prior reservations so got seated immediately. Our server was extremely helpful and helped us select the right wines and food for the evening. 

I got the gluten free CORN FUSILLI PASTA WITH WILD MUSHROOMS - a nice al dente, creamy pasta with subtle but delicious flavors. And my colleague got the SQID INK RISOTTO with leeks and tobiko caviar. I tried a couple spoons and loved it. This dish was packed with flavor and will definitely be ordering this one for myself on my next visit.
But the showstopper for the evening was the SALTED CARAMEL MOUSSE with a chocolate cake base, puff kamut, poached peaches and whipped cream on the side. The presentation was elegant and all of these individual elements worked really well together.

A solid choice for lunch or dinner if you are in the vicinity.
author: Ishani S.

description: Before catching a show up the street at 42nd st Moon, we stopped in for a quick bite. We were seated and our order was taken in under 10 minutes. The food came out just as fast and was perfectly cooked. I ordered the Bolognese and the pasta was some of the best cooked I've had in a while, not to mention the sauce. Also the suggested wine pairing was perfect. Everything came out so quickly and so deliciously that we even decided to squeeze in dessert, which I'd also recommend. This is the perfect pre-show restaurant.
author: Steve A.

description:
We got our food to go. Tried the spinach rigatoni with lamb and little ears. 

3/5 Spinach rigatoni with lamb - had shreds of orange zest and lamb that was slow cooked and pull apart. 

2/5 little ears - fennel sausage made it extra salty

Maybe I need to try other dishes but the ones I tried didn't leave me craving more.
author: Susan C.

description:
Made a lunch reservation for two about a week ago with no problem, getting the noon slot I wanted.  The hostess seated us side-by-side at the bar, which wasn't exactly what I was expecting but worked out fine.  You might ask specifically for a table if you're a twosome and would prefer a table.

I ordered the meatballs and my companion had the chicken thighs, which I think was the better dish...though both were excellent.  The pork meatballs were firm and yet very moist, in a tomato sauce with one or two mushrooms and pearl onions.  The onions, or something near them, had a little fennel/licorice flavor which was just right amidst the sauce.

Totally agree with other Yelpers that the fried brussels sprouts are a menu highlight.  Crispy, savory and with just the right amount of anchovy sauce to make 'em memorable.  Its the kind of dish that sticks in your mind and keeps a place atop your mental bookmarks for next time you need a good spot downtown.

The decor is nothing super-special, but it is comfortable.  The tables are well spaced, so there's some intimacy for a business or personal meal.
author: Lanny B.

description:
Their menu is seasonal so if you're looking through pictures make sure that you either look at recent ones or call them to double-check it is on the menu. 

I went there for dinner with a friend on a Wednesday night. It got packed really quickly. Midway through our dinner they sat another pair next to us and we looked like we were one party. We could hear everything they were saying and vice-versa. It was too crammed for comfort. Also if my friend wasn't tiny, they would need to move a table into the walkway for her to leave. 

We got the corn fusilli, Brussels sprouts, and squid ink risotto. I am glad I did not get the risotto because it looked like black water with solid grains. It tasted like someone who didn't know what risotto was supposed to look or taste like made it. The Brussels sprouts were fried and would have been delicious had it not tasted like it was doused in vinaigrette and left standing there. The corn fusili tasted like corn and pasta. Overall, the only experience that saved it was the waiters who made sure our glasses always had water. 

Once we paid, it definitely felt like we were being kicked out. After clearing the table, they took over items that came with it (ie the salt and pepper salter). I really wanted to like this restaurant but I would tell others to stay clear.
author: Michele L.

description: Katina and I sat at the bar - had a bottle of Lamarca and two dishes: the deviled eggs and steak tartare. All was delicious. Great atmosphere and friendly staff. We sat next to the owner/owner's wife for the second half of our visit who was great company.
author: Lauren E.

description: The corn fusilli pasta will always be my favorite but the lasagna is also amazinG, as are the meatballs. Honestly, there is nothing I don't love here.
author: Tara K.

description:
Barbacco is okay. It's kind of cramped and loud, though the food is good. Feels like half club lounge, half airport lounge. It's only a destination restaurant in-so-far as if you head to Barbacco, it is--by definition--your destination. Yet Barbacco still serves a purpose without being great. It is good food in the Financial District. And good food is better than bad food nine times out of ten. 

As a side note, our waiter had such a strong Italian accent it bordered on absurd. Think an Italian Borat. Like, I didn't actually think it was real until the second time he came over to our table. I kept expecting him to break out of it and he just refused to do so. I can still hear his voice in my head and it's been weeks since I was at the restaurant. This was the best part of the meal.  

In terms of food, we had the marinated olives, charcuterie board, little gem salad and fried Brussels sprouts. The b'sprouts were on the tastier side of the spectrum. For my main I had the orecchiette with broccoli de ciccio, fennel sausage and pecorino. For me a dish like that has to be a home run, yet this one pulled a hamstring rounding second base.
author: Oliver S.

description:
Having been a regular lunch customer at their sister restaurant Perbacco next door, I finally had the opportunity to try Barbacco for a recent business lunch.  My lunch partner suggested this as a convenient Financial District quick bite spot.  I was a bit early so I nursed my strawberry lemonade (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=N5FlPJcVmyIGq7p1_NvhFg&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) while studying the menu.  Seated at an end counter seat, I observed the bartender work his magic and scanned my surroundings.  There are a number of tables on the right as you enter while the bar sits to the left.  All tables were occupied as were the counter stools except for my companion's seat.

When my lunch partner arrived, he gave me several recommendations, mainly the meatballs, Brussels sprouts, lasagna, and oreccheiette.  My eyes were glued on the lasagna so that's what I ordered while he had the oreccheiette.  My lasagna was good, just not mama-gimme-some-more good.  My friend's dish looked light and clean, consistent with California cuisine.  We shared the Brussel sprouts which met expectations with hearty flavor without being oily.  Service was efficient and prompt as we were able to complete our lunch within the normal work allotted hour timeframe.  

Atmosphere wise, it is certainly festive and bustling with loud conversations throughout the restaurant, at least when we were there.  I would recommend this for a casual lunch but business lunches are a bit tougher given the room volume.  A friend of mine actually used to operate a deli at this location and they've done a great job of renovating it into a hip eat and drink spot.

Yes, I'll be back and hope to try their other dishes that are often mentioned.
Definitely a solid lunch choice in the Financial District.
author: Mike C.

description:
For our office lunch last Friday, June 30th, I decided to try Barbacco. Our delivery order arrived via Caviar around 12 noon.

*Chef's Selection of Salumi: Chef's choice ($12.65 small)
*Crushed Peas: Ricotta salata and radishes ($3.45)
*Roasted Hen of the Woods Mushrooms: Parmigiano ($3.45)

I love a good salumi platter, so I had to try Barbacco's. It's a good size and had a variety of meats. Also came with slices of bread and olives which were tasty. I did wish the dish came with cornichons and mustard, but maybe that's more of a charcuterie thing? Since we only have $20 to spend on lunch, I decided to get some sides. (I actually wanted cheese, but that would have put me over budget.) This is probably Caviar's bad more than Barbacco's, but I had no idea I was ordering bruschette. If I did, I probably would have ordered the Tuscan Chicken Liver Pate: Balsamic braised onion ($3.45). I ended up just eating the toppings of the bruschetta and discarding the bread.

I've been to Perbacco and had a nice dinner. I think due to the budget and delivery menu, I didn't enjoy Barbacco as much as I should have. I probably would have had a better experience if I had gone into the restaurant and had a meal.
author: Elena N.

description:
It is hard to choose between Barbacco and Perbacco.

We have dined at Barbacco and Perbacco for years and have never had a bad dish. Barbacco is the more casual and a little more energetic where Perbacco is little more upscale. Both serve outstanding Northern Italian cuisine.

We like to sit at the counter at Barbacco. On a recent dinner, we shared the octopus, a wonderful pasta -- they usually have four -- a specialty of both restaurants, and a steak. Barbacco has a nice wine program, including carafes. We had a 500 ml Sicilian red for $32 -- excellent. The whole bill, tax and 20% tip was $120.00 -- what a bargain.

Perbacco is more of a celebratory experience. A little more upscale, the preparations are a little more involved, and the choices a little wider. I am a sucker for the quail if its on the menu and always a pasta or two. Like Barbacco, they have a great wine program, but being a local, I often bring a bottle from my cellar for a nominal $25 corkage.
author: John C.

description: The food was good, and the service was decent, but the bruschetta they brought for the appetizer tasted like a left over dish sponge. Get the halibut if it's on the menu, it's one of the better dishes we had as a group, but we won't be dining there again.
author: Bill C.

description:
Having been to Perbacco and loving their pastas, I was excited to come to Barbacco for lunch with a friend. 

Service & atmosphere: the space is narrow and a little dark, kind of like an underground sushi restaurant, but the space was packed and the energy was electric. We sat at the long bar and the bartender/server was extremely attentive and courteous. 

Food: for starters we ordered the mushroom, pate, and prosciutto bruschette. The page was definitely my favorite and the balsamic braised onion added a nice sweet tartness. My friend and I ordered the fusilli and orecchiette. The fusilli was tasty, but be aware they definitely mean walnut pesto- it was super nutty. The orecchiette was well-cooked, savory, salty, with generous chunks of flavorful sausage. We also ordered the chocolate mousse for dessert. The combination of textures was interesting, though I wasn't fan of how the flavors combined.
author: Marissa F.

description: Really great service but sat at the counter during a busy time and it was very tight, quite uncomfortable, might've been a good idea to take out one or two seats and just give people a little bit more room, I just wanted to get out of there because I didn't know where to put my elbows. I didn't really like the pate pate brussels sprouts were nice. Pasta  was also on the average side.
author: Tiff W.

description:
Came here for a quick bite during lunch. The service was great and a walk in party of 2 was accommodated despite most people having reservations. 

The food was fairly good! Was hoping the pasta would have had more flavor, but adding some extra Parmesan helped. 

Also the seasonal sorbet was phenomenal.
author: Kimberly B.

description:
Aside from having water spilled on me (it was a complete accident), the experience was good. I met up with an old coworker and picked this place since it was nearby and right off Montgomery station.

For a weekday after work, it was pretty crowded and we ended up sitting at the bar. I got a tap beer and ordered the radicchio salad to start. Salad is salad so I'll spare the details. Next came the lasagna with spinach pasta! Now this one is a must try because it was awesome. Pasta was done correctly and the meat and cheese melted so well together. My only wish was that they gave a bigger portion! I also got to try the meatballs and those came in 3 an order. I'm not a fan of meat balls but these were really good. The tartness of the tomato sauce helps diversify the flavors a bit. 

I have to commend the people working here. After having my water knocked over on me by the bartender, the staff around noticed quickly and came by to help with towels. They also moved us to another area and offered me a complimentary beer sample. Small gesture and I'm sure others are of the opinion that it was the least they could have done, but I was impressed.
author: Quoc N.

description: This is a great place and it has even here for years. Every time I am in the city I try to visit this wonderful restaurant. Service is great, the food is fantastic and the wine selection is fabulous.  The atmosphere of the restaurant is special.
author: Pedro R.

description:
I was not impressed with Barbacco. Parbacco, their sister restaurant, is definitely the better choice. 
We ordered the Corn Fusilli pasta & the Fettuccine w/ Rabbit Sugo. Both were very bland & flavorless. I had to add a ton of salt to my dish. 
I think I will stick to Parbacco from now on.
author: Nari M.

description: Amazing! Amazing! Amazing! Very delicious homemade Italian food! All I can say is that we both loved it! You Can tell that the pasta is fresh and homemade. The halibut is very delicious as well. We look forward to going back
author: Deborah P.

description:
The brussels sprouts were the highlight of our meal! They were crispy, savory and super flavorful - highly recommend. I ordered the Bolognese which came out piping hot.

I really liked the service here. For a nice sit down restaurant, service was friendly and quick. I'd be back again to fulfill my Italian food cravings!
author: Jen P.

description: Had dinner here last night. Sat at the bar. The bartender/waiter was fine. He was attentive and quick. The food on the other hand could be better; considering the price. I had the little gem salad and asked for light dressing. The salad is small considering it's $13 and was swimming in dressing. Why?  Someone in the kitchen hasn't been taught how much dressing to put on a salad. Fix this please. I also had the halibut main course which was almost perfect except the fish was over cooked. Since overcooking fish is a meal killer, why can't they learn not to overlook it. I will return for another try but if another meal doesn't live up to the price point there are plenty of other options.
author: Joe T.

description:
Solid, quick Italian spot in FiDi that's reasonably priced.

My friend and I came here with a last minute reservation on a Monday night.  They have booth seats but we sat at the bar counter, which we don't mind.  Note that it does get a bit crowded at the 6:30-7:30 dinner rush so might not be good if you are claustrophobic.

Servers were relatively quick even with the dinner rush.  They did forget our order of the fried brussels sprouts but they were kind enough to make it on the house and get it to us quickly.

Portions were on the bigger side- we shared one appetizer and then I was full after another appetizer and side (maybe I just have a smaller stomach).  Even so, my friend ordered a pasta dish and even though he was super hungry coming in, he noted it was a huge portion and barely finished.  

Crostone (chicken liver pate, pear, balsamico)($12) - my friend and I shared this (they serve 4 pieces).  I love the smooth salty pate- it almost was like foie gras and thankfully wasn't too mushy.  The pear added a nice texture to the smooth pate, though it would have been great too if it were thicker so that its sweetness could balance out the slightly salty pate.  The crostini didn't get soggy either.

Roasted octopus (with crushed potatoes and salsa verde)($12) - portion was perfect for me.  Octopus was cooked well and had a nice subtle flavor (not too fishy or overcooked).  Love the texture of the crushed potatoes (since they weren't fully mashed) and the crunchy salsa.

Fried brussels sprouts (w/ capers, anchovy and red wine vinaigrette)($6) - the brussels sprouts themselves were fried well, but unfortunately mine were way overdressed and unevenly so.  Some bites were fine but then after taking some bits, my mouth would pucker so much from the amount of vinaigrette they used.  Shame, considering I LOVE brussels sprouts.

My friend had the rigatoni all' amatriciana (tomato sugo, pancetta, onion, chilli, pecorino)($17)- I didn't eat it but it smelled amazing!  He enjoyed it and finished the dish (see note above) and loved how it had enough cheese to bring the smoky pecorino flavor into the dish but not so much that it became heavy.

Splitting the bill down the center (including a beer and wine), we both paid a little over $40.  

Definitely will come back to try their Meatball Mondays and pastas- I think I'd bring coworkers and/or colleagues back here again.
author: Audrey H.

description:
I have been wanting to try this place for awhile. I first went on the day they launched their new Meatballs Monday menu. Every Monday, the menu will feature three different meatballs and spaghetti alla marinara for $16. You can get one flavor or mix-and-match. 

The meatballs were cooked well, moist and tender. Their signature polpette di manzo alla bolognese meatballs (beef) were flavorful; loved the bechamel sauce. I was really surprised by how much I liked their polpette di pollo meatballs (chicken). They were light and full of citrus flavor. 

I would definitely come back for their meatballs. I'd also love to try their other dishes. I hear their arancini are delicious!
author: Rose A.

description:
For the longest time I had assumed that Barbacco specialized in barbacoa, so I was pleasantly surprised to find a trendy Italian restaurant with craft pasta and bar bites. 

In my opinion the menu is just right, not overwhelmingly huge but not overly minimalist. It offers a sufficient variety to cater to your preferences. They even have corn-based gluten-free fusilli! Although I often scoff at the pointlessness of the gluten-free hype, corn pasta sounds like a creative and delicious idea :P

We started with BRANDACUJUN (don't ask me how to pronounce it) aka salt cod fritters. It was comparable to salt cod fish cakes at most places, consisting of meatball-shaped cod surrounded by a golden panko coating. Each of the 3 accompanying aioli tasted distinctly different, though I don't remember the descriptions the server introduced to us. At $11 for 3 fritters it's a bit pricey (and difficult to share because it crumbles when you cut it in half), but noteworthy and appetizing indeed.

At first it bothered me that the FRIED BRUSSELS SPROUTS ($6) were so inconsistent, with some pieces dry and plain while other pieces were doused to a pungent tangyness in the red wine vinaigrette. The texture was similarly heterogeneous, ranging from thin, crisp, almost flash-fried single leaflets to chunks with more resistance to the bite. I quickly came to appreciate how the dish showcases the fascinating diversity in something as simple as fried Brussels sprouts. (Just like how SF adores the variation of basic avo toasts)

The risotto was the reason we came to visit (I had been on something of a risotto quest for boo's cravings). While it was not the absolute best risotto I've ever had, it was memorable and exemplified the same culinary finesse of creating a signature dish from simple ingredients. Named the FARROTTO ($15), the "risotto" was farro-based for a heartier, grainier texture and a more complex, earthier flavor profile. The farro was more chewy and fell short of the intriguingly al dente firmness of traditional risotto, but the savory parmigiano reggiano, roasted mushrooms, and spinach gave a nice oomph. Overall I liked the spin and the healthier approach in contrast to the typically creamy, rich composition.

I didn't know what to expect of the LUMACHE ($17; featuring green "snail-shaped" pasta), and it turned out to be another interesting and unique pasta creation. The lamb sugo was braised melty soft (and came in a surprisingly generous portion) blended with a bold arrabiata-like spicy tomato sauce, a garnish of cool mint leaves, and sharp pecorino cheese. The pasta was notably al dente, and the snail shape was excellent for scooping up sauce. 

The dining experience at Barbacco has its share of class and stellar Italian cuisine, yet it remains casual and comfortable. (The nearby Perbacco is its fancier sibling.) True to its name, Barbacco includes a long row of bar seating (with extremely comfortable bar stools) along one side of the restaurant.

The verdict? Reasonably priced (for SF) and outstandingly delicious (for SF) (which is saying a lot.)
author: Edna C.

description: We didn't plan on eating here and so I didn't know we had to make a reservation but luckily the staff were able to sit us at the bar (big shoutout to them). The food is great and it's really beautiful on the inside. I definitely recommend getting the desserts--they were amazing!
author: Irene T.

description:
I came in assuming it would be a more casual place, but it's actually quite upscale. The ambience is beautiful though, and the servers were very, very attentive.

I couldn't help it and started with the Chicken Liver Mantecato (I had to look up the menu to remember what it was called) and was pleasantly surprised by the portion size. It was a lot & definitely meant to be a shared appetizer. It was also delicious. If you're a pâté lover, you'll absolutely love this.

For my main dish, I ordered the Polpette (pork meatballs) and was very pleased with the sophistication of the dish. They took something simple and made it feel special simply by adding fancy mushrooms, and I appreciate that.
author: Sao B.

description:
PSA this restaurant stores your credit information and charges you without your consent. We came in for dinner on a Saturday evening and dinner was okay. Risotto was atrocious and rest of the meal was subpar. 

Regardless, we were enjoying our night, we finished our meal and we were on our way out, we signed our check and one of friends left to use the bathroom. As we were about to get up to leave, the waiter came over to us and handed us another bill and stated that apparently he had given us the wrong bill the first time. This new bill was $70 more than the bill originally given to us. We were all shocked due to not realizing the discrepancy and were ready to head out. My friend asked how his card was charged again for this bill that he hadn't given his card for, and the waiter said they still had it on file and just ran it again. ARE YOU SERIOUS? How is this possible, isn't this illegal? The receipt that was given to us was in essence a contract and we agreed to it. By handing it to us, the restaurant agreed to it as well.  What would have happened if we had left? 

I promptly requested to speak to the manager. Upon the managers arrival, she attempted to downplay the situation and state that she wouldn't need our card for the new charge and we would be okay. Instead of offering her apologies and maybe offering up something for the inconvenience, she treated us like we were the ones who had done the wrongdoing. Any self respecting entity would offer up a free round of beers (which I requested)  or desert on the house for their mistake, but instead she chose to be stubborn and not properly respond to the situation and offered us nothing.  My friends and I felt cheated and violated.  I told the manager this wasn't the proper way to be dealing with the situation and that I would be writing a negative review for this poor service. She seemed unphased and had an overall very rude demeanor.  

We did not think the situation was handled professionally at all and we do not have any intention of going back the restaurant. We will also be sharing our negative experience to others and we will not be recommending this restaurant to our friends. It's a shame the manager didn't know how to properly respond to the situation and make amends.
author: Eric L.

description: I ordered the fettuccine and my partner ordered the bolognese. Both had no flavor and tasted as if they had been microwaved to order. Our food came out literally five minutes after we ordered with a packed restaurant. Which is never a good sign. The waiter forgot our water three times. Overall if you're looking for a nice Italian spot in the city I would steer clear of this location.
author: Mike S.

description:
4.5 stars!
The Financial District has some good dining options, but usually they're a bit overpriced and not that impressive. However, that's NOT the case with Barbacco--the ambiance here was modern, clean, and chic (though a little bit loud and crowded), and the food was absolutely delicious, and a surprisingly great value for the price! I came on a Friday night for dinner and was really impressed with their offerings. 

There are a bunch of small plates on the menu, which were great for sharing. Surprisingly, the "small" plates actually had pretty substantial portion sizes--definitely bigger than the appetizers you get at most restaurants! We started with the grilled octopus with mashed potato and watermelon radish--the octopus pieces were so delicious and tender but still had a nice bite. The Brussels sprouts were unbelievably tasty and fried to tender perfection. The arugula and radicchio salad with parmesan was nice and simple--absolutely nothing fancy, but a great vegetal addition to the meal!

And then came our entrees--the lumache (snail-shaped) pasta came with a divine tomato/lamb ragu--the meat was so moist and tender, and the pasta was dressed with an unctuous blend of herbs and cheese. The "peposo" was a Tuscan beef stew--it came with three hearty chunks of beef braised in a tomato and red wine sauce and served over a creamy and chunky polenta. So delicious and tender--and again, the portion sizes of both entrees were extremely generous, and I finished the meal feeling very satisfied. My only complaint was that the entrees were just a bit salty, but there's nothing like a cool dessert to finish off!

Given how good everything else was, the dessert was probably the least impressive part of the meal. Nevertheless, the cannoli with ricotta, pistachio, and orange peel was decent, and the housemade orange/lemon oil gelato was light and refreshing. Overall, an absolutely delicious meal for a great value (especially given the location of this restaurant in downtown SF). The service was extremely helpful in giving us delicious suggestions, and everything we had was simply fantastic!
author: David K.

description:
We arrived at Barbacco around 12:45PM as a group of 3, and as expected for most FiDi restaurants, the place was packed with people. The greeter gave us a choice of waiting 15 minutes for stool seats, or 30 minutes for a table. We chose the former, as this lunch was between work hours for my group. We were seated after standing and waiting 20 minutes. After being seated, we waited 25 minutes with no one paying attention to us...finally, we had to ask the same greeter if our server was coming or not. This was disappointing as the restaurant wasn't as busy at that point, and we weren't even served water. 

To start off we ordered a platter of crostini and various sauces. The server stated it was good for sharing and would come with six pieces of bread (so two for each of us) but only came with four. We asked for additional bread to finish the rest of the each ordered one of their $17 pastas, which were quite filling and tasty (but we were also starving). Their fried Brussel sprouts were also a nice snack in between, and have a similar taste to vegetable tempura. 

Tl;dr - Uncomfortable seating, poor service, long wait times, but food was decent.
author: Vivian L.

description: I was very disappointed with this restaurant. I read so many good reviews. The bruschetta was so hard I couldn't even chew it. My risotto had a nice flavor to it but it wasn't cooked right. I understand it's supposed to be al dente but it was hard and tasted raw.
author: Glorimar A.

description:
If you're seeking high-quality Italian food at incredibly reasonable unpretentious FiDi SF prices, Barbacco has you covered. A friend and I dined here and split a cheese platter, a starter, a main pasta dish, and a half bottle of wine, and our bill didn't surpass the $70 mark. Where can you get a super generous helping of citrus roasted brussels sprouts for a mere $6? This place. You can select from a variety of cheeses to make up your own board. Helpings are generous and are served with a plate of fruit and nut toasts. If you order a "half bottle" of wine, you actually get about 3+ glasses in the carafe, so it's more than worth it if you prefer to get a little more than a single glass with your experience. Pasta is phenomenal. Cooked perfectly, it chewy without being sticky and mushy, or underdone. We sat at the bar, and the view of the prep kitchen was amazing. A great venue for meetings of all sorts, from personal to business. 

All service from the hostess with the mostess to our waiter were amazing. Everyone is attentive and friendly. Acoustics are amazing. Noise levels remain average and manageable despite a full house and partially open kitchen. 

Pro-tip: reservations are a must for this quaint, super popular venue in the FiDi on a weekday night.
author: Alison A.

description:
Ate here on a Friday evening after reserving through OpenTable. This is the more casual version of Perbacco (a few doors down). We had the rigatoni bolognase and the roasted butternut squash, both of which were good. If there are two of you, my recommendation is to share an app and to each order your own entree. 

One disappointment was that we were seated at a bar counter even though we had reservations (restaurant has a large bar counter as well as two top tables). The restaurant has modern decor but the chairs are rather uncomfortable. Ladies, my short girlfriend advises don't wear a short dress if you are sitting at the bar...the backed counter stools are shallow and covered in a slippery fabric.

Overall, this is a solid choice for your next date night in the financial district.
author: Gabe G.

description: The Tagliata main plate and the brussels sprouts side dish were the best things I have ever put in my face hole in San Francisco. Not to mention that the croutons in the salad were soaked in the vinaigrette. So. Much. Yum!
author: Stacey L.

description: Delicious food, great atmosphere, polite and knowledgble wait staff.   Highly recomended.
author: Gary B.

description:
great food, great ambience, great service.
Do get the Sicilian meatballs, they are amazing! 
Pastas here are safe options too. 

However, I gave the dessert a few tries, and they are not on the same level as their appetizers and mains. I think you can give it a pass unless you are craving sweets.
author: Julia C.

description:
My cousin and I came here for lunch last Thursday. She made reservation through their site for 11:30. I was there by 11:20 and waited in the lobby area. By opening time, there were a dozen of us waiting to be seated. The hostesses promptly sat customers at 11:30 (only if everyone in your reservation party was there already). 

What an excellent choice for lunch! Food exceeded their fine reputation. I took a star out because of our server, but more on that later. We opted to share everything and I had my cousin do the ordering since she knew the menu quite well. We started with melt-in-your-mouth Burrata cheese and quickly went to salad, which was Hearts of Romaine with anchovy dressing. If you are a fan of anchovy, this is a definite must. It's too bad there wasn't an option to add grilled shrimp to the salad. That would've been a great lunch entree. However, we did have a perfect entree to share: Orecchiette pasta with fennel sausage. Perfectly cooked with loads of flavor. I savored every bite of it and will definitely go back for more. 

Now for the minus one star, our server. He rushed us from the moment we sat down and I really wanted to smack this kid. Of course I would never do such a thing, but you get the idea. I know he wanted turn-over on tables, especially during the lunch hour, but he was so aggressive to the point he almost ruined our lunch. We saw him doing the same to the table next to us. My cousin works just around the corner and we went during her lunch break. I mean it's not as if we were going to be there all afternoon long. An hour max, buddy, go away and leave us alone, I thought. Stop popping in on us, and no you cannot take away that half eaten salad....are you insane? Anyway, hence the minus star. 

Reservation is a must, especially during the weekdays lunch hour. This place was hopping from the moment they opened the door. By 12:30, the lobby was filled with hungry business folks and a little crowd was standing outside to be seated as well. I'd like to come here again the next time I am in town and if my cousin can't make it, I will ask to sit at the bar. At least I've never been rushed by a bartender......not yet anyway :-)
author: Mariani D.

description:
Not sure if they thought we were tourists and they could get away with it but, the pear salad had just 2 slices of fresh pear and big humps of soft tasteless, mushy blobs either fished out of a dumpster or from a can!  If this is SF, the Mecca of farm to table dining and the salad is priced at well over 10$ where was the rest of the fresh pear?

Never going back.
author: Chitra J.

description: Yummy burrata, pasta and lamb shank! I had the olive oil and vanilla gelato and chocolate cake as well. One of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco
author: S L.

description:
Food earns 5 stars in my opinion. Must haves: Bruschetta and Stracciatella Gelato.
We had reservations, yet initially tried to seat us at the "counter". We had to ask the waiter for specials & the soup of the day.  He was very pleasant and prompt in responding to us flagging him down, with questions & for more water. I realize this is a very busy and popular spot, so we very much appreciated him explaining the details of the dishes and honestly giving us his opinions.
The spinach rigatoni a bit salty, but very good. The endive salad w/pears & gorgonzola was really fresh & tasty.
I look forward to eating here again soon!
author: Kelley K.

description:
Fantastic spot for a nice dinner.
One of the best octopus plates I have had in a long time. ( it was an appetizer and it was just perfect) Must have again soon!
Very attentive service
Great drinks
Interesting menu
ambience is perfect for a relaxed time ( not too noisy) they would have earned a fifth star if my risotto had been better. ( it wasn't bad, but compared to my appetizer it seemed a little bland.
Planning to go back ASAP
author: Ivonne V.

description: This place is good. Young, hip ambiance and good wine list. The Fettucini Ragu was excellent... the steak was just ok. Enjoyed sitting at the bar and watching the food be made.
author: Andy R.

description: I really liked the food the service was slacking tho. Its a little pricy but totally worth it. We showed up without a reservation but they were able to get the 3 of us in. I ordered the orecchiette and it was on point. Great sauce and sausage bits. My coworkers had the meatballs and the farroto mushroom risotto which they both liked. Having shared bites I liked those dishes as well. We ordered a huge soup of the day some minestrone varient and my favorite cali cheese humbolt fog which went over well as well. Im super laid back so I didnt really mind to the lack of any service but it pissed off both of my coworkers to the point that I still get jokes about taking them there so im factoring that into my rating.
author: Sean G.

description:
I went to this place with my friend on a Saturday evening.
This place definitely provides some amazing fine dining experience through it's upscale interiors and a townie look.
This place is a should-go for couples but does not prove it's worth for groups of friends and vegetarian people.
There are very few options on the menu for Vegetarian people and the worst part is that the quantity of food which they server per portion is very less compared to almost all other places in the bay area.
We had the following items:
1) Mushroom Appetizer
Mushrooms were combined with wine and were giving out a nice decent flavor
The quantity served was very very less

2) Corn Fusilli Pasta
The Pasta was only half cooked so we had to forcibly chew the entire dish which was a little weird as we have never had such Pasta before
The quantity was less too for this dish as well

Overall I would not be going to this place again unless they get a makeover and provide more options.
author: Pratham V.

description: I don't understand why people love this place so much... I feel like the service is slightly below average at night, and the portion is tiny for its price..
author: Tai C.

description: Fantastic food. Delicious pasta and BURRATA DI STEFANIO.  Had the Rigatoni and Farrotto pasta.  Domenico is pleasant and charming. Great food. The service picked up big time after we asked for some attention and hence the 4 stars, otherwise 5 easily.  Lunch is a little crowded but recommend reservations in advance. Will definitely go back and ask for Mr. Domenico.
author: John M.

description:
This review is based on the service rather than meal - I made reservations for Vday a week in advance. I get a call a few days later and was told that I may have to sit at the bar due to the number of people who  also reserved... well isn't the point of reserving to hold a table? and why was my reservation taken in the first place if that doesn't "guarantee" a table?

I decided to spend valentines else where that knows how to take a reservation.
author: Allan M.

description: It's nice to start the Barbacco experience with a trio of bruschette because you know, TOASTED BREAD. Skipping the salad is totally fine (trust me, crap will eventually come out). Proceed directly to the tubular paccheri pasta with lamb ragu and beef stew with creamy polenta. Knock back a couple of glasses of wine with that amazing meal and roll back home to nap until dinnertime. Repeat.
author: Suany W.

description:
Rainy Wednesday night yet this joint was still packed. A party of four hungry girls, we were ready to order and chow down. Did not have to wait long to get our orders in. Beets, Brussels sprouts(a bit too burnt), kale and roasted squash salad, mussels(cooked perfectly), roasted octopus over bed of arugula, cauliflowers, beef stew(melts in your mouth), and lasagna. Perfect portions divided by four. Top it all off with panna cotta and chocolate mouse. 

Was told I must try next door next...=P
author: Vee V.

description: Met our favorite couple there for dinner at 5.45 p.m. on a Thursday. It was superb. Friendly, professional, stylish. I didn't take the tasting menu, but I drink a couple of the pairing wines from the Piccon southern Italian vineyard by the 6oz glass with the pappardelle, then the duck. That duck dish was outstanding. Pink grilled breast, with the croquette of duck confit  with a delicious grilled peach and arugula salad. And the bill was not at all outrageous for such a classy place. Noise level was tolerable.
author: Robert O.

description: Great Bolognese and steak! Friendly staff who were very accommodating to us and our infant.
author: Hannah W.

description:
Decent prices and tasty flat iron steak.  Wish the portion was slightly bigger though.  Steak paired nicely with the cherry tomatoes and argula w/ balsamic.   Ordered the side of brussel sprouts and it was really oily and salty.  

My friend said his order of pasta was just ok.  I didn't try it, but the portion looked big.  

I will be back to try the rest of the stuff on the menu!
author: Jenny L.

description:
me and my boyfriend were exploring San Francisco and we came across this restaurant.Great place! 
I loved the service, our server younger guy but he was so professional and kind. 
Food was great, we had the chefs special 3 course meal. My boyfriend looveed the pasta dishes. Personally, I loved the wine list. 
Definatelly recomend it!
author: Simba M.

description:
A few coworkers and I came here for a team dinner after work. I was initially apprehensive about the limited menu and the lack of dairy-free options (since I am lactose intolerant). 

I ordered the seafood item of the day, which was a seared Halibut over a polenta cake, a butternut squash crema (I decided to have a lactase tablet and suck it up) and a some sort of kale thing (forgot what the waiter said). The Halibut was well made. It had the perfect sear and was super flaky. The polenta cake was also a really nice balance to the fish. The cream over did it in my opinion, but I also don't like super rich foods. The greens did balance it well though. Overall, the dish was well-balanced and satisfying. 

For appetizers, we ordered the salami platter which came with a variety of meats, olives, pâté, and some bread. We also ordered the octopus, olives and two cheeses. I didn't have the salami or the octopus, but the cheese was pretty nice! 

I finished  the meal with a nice, smooth espresso. My overall experience of this place was pretty nice. Nothing too spectacular or eye-catching though. It's just a standard, nice dinner/lunch place!
author: Sitara R.

description: Chicken liver crustini is a must get.  They give you a big jar of it and not enough bread so get an extra order of free bread to use the rest of the Chicken liver don't waste it.  Had the Lamb Shank it had good lamb gamey flavor but it wasn't braised long enough so still had to chew quite a bit.  Had the fish of the day Alaska Halibut which was suprisingly good since it can be a dry fish but still had alot of juice.  Meatballs were good too you can tell they didn't fill it up with breadcrumbs but wasn't hot enough only lukewarm.
author: Stevezee C.

description: A great little spot for lunch or dinner. Whatever you do, order the brussel sprouts as a side. They are fabulous. I went with a salad at lunch, the pear endive salad to be exact. Loads of flavor and interesting textures. I added shrimp but wish I wouldn't have as the shrimp lacked any extra flavoring. Brussels were a much better call. Plenty of seating and also some "bar" seating options where you can watch them prepare the food in front of you. This place is probably a pasta lovers dream but if you don't love pasta (like me) you can still get away with a great meal.
author: Kara N.

description:
Solid Italian food! My party and I ordered a Humbolt Fog cheese platter and Burrata starter to share. Everyone enjoyed the cheese (atmosphere helped it feel more fancy too) and I really liked the meats from the burrata starter. The place also offers bread if you ask, and the butter it comes with was so soft, like a cloud. 

The table got the corn fusilli, a rice squid ink dish, orecchiette, and chicken thighs. I thought the chicken thighs were wonderfully cooked, and the sauce was a nice surprise as it was slightly think and paired well with the squash. I had bites of the orecchiette and squid ink dish, and I thought they were solid choices too. 

Overall, good atmosphere and good food.
author: Serena W.

description:
After a couple of drinks at the Royal Exchange, we slid around the corner and established ourselves at Barbacco's bar.  Barbacco is a comfortable spot, and both the food and the drink are better than A-OK.  I drank an Italian sauvignon blanc as well as the unique orange wine on the menu that we saw -- this was again an Italian wine.  Both wines were excellent, and the pours are on the generous side.  (In fact, I drank two half-pours.)  My appetizer was the roasted octopus; for my main dish, I chose a pasta with sugo.  Hey, what's not to like?  We felt slightly "managed" by the staff -- everything is a production, and we were part of the production.

Maybe I'm being slightly harsh; we should return without an initial stop at the Royal Exchange.  One thing in Barbacco's favor is that it's only steps away from an Embarcadero BART exit.  It's easy to come from elsewhere on the BART map, have an indulgent lunch or dinner at Barbacco and then return to the world of public transportation.
author: Kenneth R.

description: Excellent food and service. Our waiter Damon was attentive and made great recommendations. I got the fettuccini with gluten free pasta which was delicious! My sister got the lamb shank in which we all ate off of. The husbands both got the bolognese which was slurped down in a matter of minutes. I highly recommend this place. Oh yeah and we also got the antipasto appetizer. See photo.
author: D A.

description: I hit Barbacco every couple weeks for dinner and have yet to be disappointed, it's outstanding!! Don't miss the octopus!  The Burrata cheese appetizer is amazing and if steak is on the menu make sure you grab it! The menu changes regularly and never fails to have excellent choices of fish, beef or fowl. Tonight I had lamb shank and it was great!! Cheers!!
author: Dusty W.

description:
Randomly decided to go here today and was glad I was able to snag a reservation for prime time lunch rush at 11:45. 

I love the vibe of this place especially since I wasn't in the mood to try its sister/more expensive restaurant, Perbacco. The place has a modern design and is clean. 

Service was alright for me. We weren't really greeted with great service upon arrival and when I put in a reservation I thought we would be getting a table but instead were seated at the bar.

***The place can also get very loud. At some points I found it hard to have a conversation. It does gets really busy here so I don't recommend walking in during lunch. Use opentable to make a reservation ahead of time. 

My friend and I both ended up getting the orecchiette dish. At first we thought it wouldn't be enough since the portions looked small but it was actually very filling. The pasta was perfectly cooked al dente but similar to other reviews I thought the sauce was a little lackluster. It definitely had way too much kale and not enough sausage. The fennel sausage they added to the dish was delicious and definitely made it better.
author: Keizzel C.

description: Came here with work on a Monday night.  The highlight of the meal was the flourless chocolate cake. We shared some salads and burrata. Beet and pear salad were the salads that don't have too much in the way of greens.  Nice presentation and very tasty. I got the fish which was good but I was slightly disappointed. It tasted good for sure but I try to get fish as the healthy option and this was not there. It was served with mostly starchy beans and very few green beans. It also had a HUGE lump of butter. It was not needed at all. I would have spooned it out immediately but our bread plates disappeared or were never there. Would have been odd to put a huge dollop of butter on the table, amiright?
author: Danielle B.

description: Everything was exquisite!! The ambiance is very light and inviting, really good vibes. They said we could only have a seat at the counter because it was only just two of us but they accommodated with a table after asking. It's a smaller space and a little crowded but still deserves five stars because the food was 100% perfect and the intimacy was part of the experience! Dig in and enjoy!!
author: Edward C.

description:
Pros:
- Great vegetarian entree. Ordered the farrotto (risotto + mushrooms) which was delicious. It had the appropriate amount of cheese and the mushrooms were very fresh! Highly recommend. 
- Takes reservations through yelp. A must if you're having lunch on a weekday...place gets packed! 
- The Brussel sprouts are a popular appetizer here. Order them if you're ok with a garlic & sour taste. 
Cons:
- The seating space within the restaurant is very limited. Each table is literally 6 inches away from the next. This makes it a little uncomfortable and provides limited privacy.
author: Abhi M.

description: Superb!!!  What a great meal of delicious flavors!!!  Love the pasta dishes we ordered in this lively financial district place.  Spaghetti was cooked to perfection-the layers of flavor charmed this Italian Girl.  Brussel sprouts-top notch!!!  My husband enjoyed his spinach rigatoni spinach pasta with lamb Ragu.  Bread was yummy-will be back to enjoy this wonderful place.  If you have a chance to grab a meal here, you will not be disappointed!!
author: Nancy M.

description:
Not sure how this restaurant has so many reviews and is able to maintain a high rating.

Ear pasta w/ fennel sausage: edible but nothing I couldn't cook myself at home. Also the proportion was that of an appetizer.

Rissoto: How can you screw up rissoto? It was hard, bland and I believe they used oats. Worst rissoto evar.

Pro tip: Don't come here.
author: Tom P.

description:
My friend Eugene and I were looking for place to eat lunch on a weekday and have our regular catch-up session. Barbacco seemed like a good cross between classy and affordable, so we gave it a try. I always get nervous when we walk into a restaurant and the first question is whether or not we have a reservation. Fortunately there was seating available at the bar, so we sat there and ordered through the bartender. This would be a fantastic place for a date night or an evening get-together with a friend!

I wasn't feeling too hungry for a heavy entree, so I decided on polenta squares and Brussel sprouts. This was a good amount of food, and not really a balanced meal, though I will say I ate way more Brussel sprouts than polenta squares. The staff was very friendly, and Barbacco had an overall lively atmosphere. We sat next to the TV which unfortunately had some bloody cowboy scene that I kept getting distracted by, but I enjoyed my time here regardless.

If possible, make a reservation (especially for dinner) either for a small group or an intimate rendezvous. Would love to get dressed up, order some wine, and try some of their meat or pasta dishes one evening. If you're coming here for lunch, get here right when they open at 11:30 AM to snatch a seat. Otherwise you may be waiting for awhile. And go for the bar area! But then again I'm biased because I like to sit at the bar.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
Absolutely incredible food, superb service, and a wonderful vibe. I will be returning next time I'm
in San Francisco.
author: Adam F.

description:
I allotted myself an hour to drive from San Jose to here because there would probably be a little traffic but I forgot to factor in looking for parking! :( The restaurant is located in the Financial District so going here for lunch is definitely very crowded and busy. 

We drove around for a bit looking for parking. We finally decided to park at the parking garage on Clay St and Front St. It's very close to the restaurant, only about two blocks away!

We ended up being over 30mins late but the hostess was still kind enough to let us be the next table seated. The restaurant itself had low ceilings, dim lighting and was a little narrow. Definitely a loud restaurant with music playing and people talking. It's extremely busy during lunch hour so I suggest making reservations first! We walked into the waiting area and it was completely filled with people waiting around to be seated. There was bar seating available as well.

During the lunch hour there's only half bar available so they only offer beer or wine. I opted for an IPA which was extremely cold and refreshing- $8. 

For food we ordered..

4 Piece Bruschetta 2/$3: 
Tuscan Chicken Liver Pate with balsamic braised onion-delicious! 
Roasted Hen of the Woods Mushroom with parmesan- good, had a strong vinegar note. 

Orecchiette $15: "Little ears" pasta, cavolo nero, fennel sausage and pecorino cheese. -al dente pasta, the sausage was flavorful but the sauce itself was a little plain...

Corn Fusilli $16: (gluten free) Corn crema, pancetta, nettles and ricotta salata. -al dente pasta, creamy sauce, sweet corn bits and savory pancetta. (which tasted like creamy bacon pasta! Yum.) 

Fried Polenta $5: Parmigiano and rosemary. -fried into little cubes, slightly dense but had a light rosemary fragrance and dusted parmesan like it was salt seasoning. Mmmm! 

Fried Brussels Sprouts $6: Capers, anchovy and red wine vinaigrette. -omg get this!! Soo good, especially if you like a prominent vinegar taste that's been cooked down. 

Everything came to be around $80 which is pretty pricey for lunch but there were leftovers and definitely enough food for 3 people! 

(The pate bruschetta was so good that I ordered another 3 piece togo..lol)
author: Truc T.

description:
Food: Although the food remains to be consistent I'd say that the portion size has been cut drastically from when I once came.  I used to be able to take some to go but this time I came out a little bit hungry.

Orchiette - definitely my favorite dish when I'm in the mood for pasta.  Love this dish and it's always consistent.
Panna cotta - the flavors change every season but always good.

Service:  very nice wait staff

Ambiance: kind of like an after work joint since its in fidi.  Make a res as this place gets packed.

Overall: I'll be back but I'm definitely more less likely to come now that the portion size is smaller.
author: Spencer Q.

description: Came here for lunch with coworkers. I ordered the oriechette pasta and it was very underwhelming (even though the waiter strongly recommended it, which leaves much to be desired for the rest of the pasta options). The brussel sprouts were good. Everyone else at the table seemed content with their choices but for an italian place I would expect better pasta dishes.
author: Laura D.

description:
It says on Yelp you're open till 10pm but your kitchen stops serving at 9pm? Shouldn't that be noted somewhere? It's misleading and was a total waste of my time trying to get across the city to get there. Then, it was topped off by being greeted by an unapologetic, dismissive, matter of fact host. You ain't that good and I won't be doing that again. 

Eh, later.
author: Betty V.

description:
Pros:

Food tastes pretty good, nice sized portion, no issues with service.

Cons:

Too loud, limited seating (ended up sitting at bar), pricey (although it is SF).

Probably a better spot for an after-work drink rather than dinner to catch up with friends.
author: Greg S.

description:
Tasty but not quite worth the price!

Swung by around 7 without a reservation. It only took about 10 minutes to be seated in a very crowded restaurant. The menu is quite small so making a choice didn't take long. However, our server didn't come by to check on us for roughly 15 minutes and when I tried to grab him real quick, he walked by without stopping while brusquely responding "One second, thank you." That experience non-withstanding, the rest of the service was fine.

We ordered the nduja as well as the lasagna and meatballs. The nduja was packed full of flavor (although a bit salty for my taste) but still a good starter. When the dishes arrived, we were surprised by how stingy the portions were. However, the flavors were quite good! The meatballs were nice and light while still remaining juicy and flavorful. The lasagna is definitely not traditional. The layers were made with spinach-flavored pasta and there was very little tomato sauce involved; instead, Barbacco opted for bechamel. 

With a recent visit to a restaurant like Vega which was the same price for much more generous portions that also tasted better, I thought Barbacco was fine but not really a place I'd return to given the value and service.
author: Jason W.

description: Lunch with my new colleague here today! LOVED my Sausage Orecchiette!!! Delish! Huge portion too! YES! I was starving and ate the entire dish!!! :0) YUMMY!!!
author: Aaa T.

description:
Carb load!!! We came here since it was within walking distance from our hotel in Union Square and it was a moderately priced Italian restaurant with good reviews. We made reservations since we heard this place gets packed. We made an early res online before 6p and when we arrived, we were promptly seated in a booth in the back. 

We were greeted, offered menus and given comp bread and olive oil/ balsamic vinegar. I opted to order the lasagna bolognese ($15) as our waiter mentioned that this is one of the more popular dishes. My husband ordered the paccheri because of braised lamb shoulder ($16). I like a lot of sauce with my pasta dishes and the lasagna lacked in sauce. I should have asked for a side of meat sauce. The paccheri dish was divine. The braised lamb shoulder was tender with good flavor!

For dessert we got coffee and a scoop of the house made gelato -coffee stracciatella. OMG so delicious!!! Made my splurge in pasta totally worthwhile. They make their gelato in house and has tons of flavor.

Within an hour the restaurant was packed! Every seat in the restaurant was filled, even the bar area. Make reservations if you're planning on dining here.
author: Maria C.

description: Last minute choice for dinner as it was near our hotel. We got a reservation on open table and were seated when we arrived. Seating is a bit awkward as restaurant is long and narrow. We had a high top table for 2 near a post so there was a bit more space from the table next to us. It did get loud and it was hard to hear the server at times. TV's over the bar had the baseball game on. We ordered the rigatoni and the chicken dish. We enjoyed both and felt prices were reasonable compared to other places in the area. Service was friendly and prompt. A nice dining experience.
author: Donna B.

description: Super busy Saturday night(s)! Our wait was less then 30 minutes. The moment I walked in and sat down I felt I was in NYC.
