-{GET} FOCACCIA BREAD - 4.5/5
[rosemary, sea salt]
YUM. A little heavy with the olive oil, but incredibly soft and yummy

-BRUSCHETTA - 3.5/5
[spring onion, ricotta, toasted almonds]
The bread was nowhere near crunchy. Also very, very oily (which is probably why the bread ended up being chewy). I let one piece sit on a napkin and when I lifted it up, the oil had seeped through. The flavors of the toppings were good though.

-BUTTERNUT SQUASH - 3.5/5
Greasy like everything else. Honestly pretty standard but it was a well cooked side. I enjoyed it the most out of all the sides.

-ROASTED CAULIFLOWER - 3/5
Sometimes it's okay and then sometimes it's unnecessarily greasy

-BRAISED BROCCOLI RABE - 3/5
[garlic, chili, olive oil]
Nice chili flavor, but greasy

-FRIED BRUSSELS SPROUTS - 2.5/5
[duck fat, anchovy vinaigrette]
I LOVE brussels sprouts and these aren't thaat bad. They're a little on the sour side, but unfortunately too greasy for me to enjoy fully

====================

*** PASTAS & ENTREES ***
-{GET GET GET} POLPETTE / SICILIAN MEATBALLS - 4.5/5
[raisins, pine nuts, braised chard, tomato sugo]
On 7x7's list of things to eat for good reason! These meatballs are HUGE and SUPER FILLING. Pretty greasy, but you can dab off some of that oil if you're like me... Meat had pretty good flavor! I liked the addition of the raisins for some sweetness and the pine nuts for some texture. The sauce is delicious and has some sort of unique spice/kick to it. Definitely recommend this! 

-BRAISED CHICKEN THIGHS - 3/5
[caponata, pine nuts, basil, chicken jus]
The chicken was somewhat on the dry side (especially for thighs) and there was nothing really unique about it, but still okay. Incredibly greasy though.

-FARROTTO - 2.5/5
[farro "risotto", roasted mushrooms, spinach parmigiano reggiano]
Pretty heavy, creamy and rich, but decent flavor

-ORRECCHIETTE - 3/5
["little ears", kale, house made fennel sausage]
Probably my favorite of the pastas I've tried because of the sausage, but even the sausage wasn't particularly special

-PACCHERI - 3/5
[large pasta tubes, pancetta, cauliflower, tomato sugo, parmigiano reggiano]
Nothing special, but it didn't feel as heavy or creamy as some of the other pastas, so I personally enjoyed it a little more. The addition of cauliflower was nice too
author: Jessie L.

description:
Food was amazing, we had the steak, eggplant rigatoni, arugula salad and the waiter was nice enough to let us order just one meatball ($5) because we were too curious to try it. The meatball was very moist and soaked up great flavors, paired well with the chard and pine nuts. Steak was cooked perfectly well and the rigatoni was simple but great balance with the rest of our meal. The baked beans with sage on the side was nice and hot with a crispy top, one of my favorites of the night.

We also ordered one scoop of butterscotch chocolate crisp gelato, super delicious.

Easily one of my favorite places for Italian food.
author: Angela L.

description:
I love the ambiance here. Great service and great food! The portions are a bit small but you're paying for the quality. Ingredients are fresh! 

First ordered the seared squid appetizer (tomato/orange/chili). The squid had a nice kick to it. This was super flavorful! Got the orecchiette pasta - "little ears" - (fennel sausage/pecorino cheese). This was a pesto based pasta and they did not skimp on the fennel sausage. I thought this dish was also good, but just a tad bit  too salty. Lastly, had the braised ox tail (red wine/celery/onion/garlic/chili). Again, a ton of flavor. The ox tail was soo moist and tender. The meat just fell off the bone.

A delicious meal! I would come back!
author: Kimberly H.

description:
I LOVED this place. Period!

I come to San Francisco for work a lot and always have trouble finding a good place to grab food. I work in the Financial District and most restaurants are extremely overpriced for the quality. It's also frustrating when you are trying to have a great meal on a company budget and can't find a decent place to do so.

After extensive research, I stumbled upon Barbacco. I made a reservation and when I checked in, the hostess was extremely friendly.

The decor was amazing. I loved the ambiance. It is rustic/romantic/modern. It's not too fancy but not super casual either.

The hostess seated us at a table that was apparently reserved for a bigger party and apologized for seating us there. She brought a complimentary class of prosecco for the "trouble" (literally us sliding 5 inches down to another table). I'm kidding people. No trouble here! It was definitely a great way to start the night.

I had the mussels to start which were heavenly. They were accompanied by bread which was warm and delicious! I can't remember which pasta I had because I kept going back and forth between the two on which to order (the FARROTTO faro "risotto" / roasted mushrooms spinach / parmigiano reggiano
or the CORN FUSILLI (GLUTEN FREE)corn creme / pancetta / nettles / ricotta salata) but I do remember whichever one I ate was very good as well.

The waiter was ON POINT. He wasn't one of those people that would interrupt your conversation every literally 4 minutes to ask about something, but wasn't one of those waiters who you would see once a night and wonder where the water was. I constantly noticed my water glass being replenished without noticing anyone at the table replenishing it which was great.

All & all, I had an AWESOME time here and will absolutely be returning the next time that I am in SF.
author: Melanie A.

description:
ORDER THE BRUSSEL SPROUTS!

- Classy, nice interior and atmosphere. I went in dressed casually, and I felt under dressed surrounded by the guests wearing business clothes. 
- DELICIOUS brussel sprouts (highly recommended... GET IT!). 
- Respectful and attentive service. My friend's pasta (Orecchiette) came out too salty, so she ended up getting another Orecchiette with the salty cheese on the side which she enjoyed more. You get a lottt of pasta if you order the Orecchiette, so she took half of it to go, and she said the pasta tasted even better the next day

ORDER THE BRUSSEL SPROUTS!
author: Annie S.

description:
We came here after the 3 adjacent restaurants were not able to accommodate our party of 2 on a Tuesday evening (strange, I know).

Although they made us wait for 10-15 minutes, and allowed a few people to be seated ahead of us despite them arriving much later, we weren't miserable.  We sat at a booth, and I must say the tables are a bit small.  For the entire night, our waiter struggled with arranging the plates to get the variable dishes in order and silver-wear and salt shakers were dropped (is that bad luck?).

Since this was a light dinner, we ordered the vegetable dishes (you get to pick up to 5 for $20). What a steal! We got the Carrots (delish), beets (hella delish), roasted Cauliflowers (yum), Olives (a little too salty for my taste), and sun-dried tomatoes (rate PG, aka pretty good).

I got an additional side salad to go with that while my friend got the soup of the day which she really enjoyed.  Overall the staff was very nice, attentive and it was a nice ambience. I didn't get to dive deeper in the menu as I was trying to stay on the healthy side, and the bill was very reasonable. 

Not a destination place, but if you're in the FiDi, give it a try.
author: Arman J.

description:
Location and environment was good
Host and service was also good
I had daily special which was seafood fish and it was cooked well and it was tasty 
Reason for 3 stars is simple pasta and butter was not good, very much over cooked
author: Pauline P.

description: Don't understand what the hype is about here.  Came here because of the great reviews on yelp. Ordered the Brussels sprouts people are raving about here which were burnt, bitter, and sour. Also had the orecchiette which was bland.. the restaurant ambience is nice but that was about it. Could have had much better Italian food for half the price..
author: Ree'Ay I.

description: Terrible service. They said we would wait 20 minutes for a table ended up waiting for ONE hour! And they didn't even sit us on a table but at the bar!!
author: Maria O.

description:
I haven't been seated and I'm already taking a star  off for service as I wait to get seated. I have reservations, however, the hostess decided it was ok to walk off after I told her my reservation info, come back to seat me after she seated a couple of other walk-ins. 

Food is good. Regular portions. Reasonable pricing for the area. I would eat here again.
author: Gloria T.

description: Food is good but way overpriced. I was a huge fan of the appetizers and salads. 4 appetizers put me at $50..
author: Jackie W.

description:
Wanting to try an Italian restaurant, my friends and I came to Barbacco for lunch. Walking in, they asked us if we had reservations. (We didn't.) This place must be pretty crackin' if people make reservations for lunch! Next door is Perbacco, which is the more formal/fine dining/expensive version of Barbacco. Instead of regular tables, they have communal seating! Wanting to try more things, we each ordered something different.

- Brussels Sprouts ($5): fried in duck fat with capers, anchovy, and red wine vinagrette. It sounds delicious (and Yelpers love this appetizer), but it was a little too  salty and cooked for my taste. It was good, but nothing so amazing that I would go back for.
- Paccheri ($13): large pasta tubes with pork ragu. When they say large, they mean large! The sauce was pretty flavorful.
- Lasagna ($14): spinach pasta (whoa!), bolognese, mozzarella, and parmigiano. This dish was pretty good too. There was a perfect balance of pasta and cheese.
- Farrotto ($14): risotto with mushrooms, spinach, and parmigano reggiano. AH-MAZING! Ever since watching Gordon Ramsey cook risotto on most of his shows, I've been wanting to order risotto whenever I go out to eat. I'm glad the risotto here is so delicious. I loved the texture of the risotto, and the dish had the perfect amount of mushroom flavor.

Lunch came out to be around $20/person. My wallet tells me I can't frequent Barbacco all the time, but I definitely would be back if me or my friends are craving Italian food. I'd imagine this place is perfect for a date! ;)
author: Christine S.

description: We've come here a few times for lunch during work hours, and I'm still trying to figure out why this place is always packed. Everything is beyond salty, you're packed in like sardines, and it's so loud you can't have a convo.
author: Nancy R.

description:
What a disappointment. I'd eaten here quite a few years ago, and had really enjoyed my meal. I don't know if they were having an off night or if the place has just started to slip, but it was kind of just bad all across the board. 
We ordered a variety of things and they forgot two of our items. It was just as well because the food we did get was completely uninspired, and lacked balance. They also included meat in our vegetarians   friends pasta after she had requested it be made without. She didn't bother to say anything because, in her words, "she didn't realize that she was ordering glorified mac and cheese". 
Our server seemed overwhelmed and never bothered to check on us after we received our food. 
I am however giving them 2 stars for the great cocktails. Won't be coming back.
author: Becca B.

description:
Randomly stopped to have late dinner at Barbacco on a Monday night.  Their space is nice and swanky.  Clean, low lights with a bit of a sexy feel.  All of a sudden I felt like I wasn't in SF.  My first thought was it would be a perfect place to bring a date or go on date night.  

I'm a fan of brussel sprouts so I ordered the brussels sprouts fried in duck fat, capers anchovy, red wine vinaigrette.  This side dish was good but more on the salty side so I recommend ordering it to accompany something with a little less flavor.  We also ordered the roasted eggplant which was good, but lacked flavor.  For the main dish, I ordered the Farrotto which was risotto with roasted mushrooms spinach, and parmigiano reggiano.  The Farrotto was pretty tasty.  The risotto was cooked perfectly and the chunks of mushroom that was mixed within the dish added to the flavor.  I ordered the strawberry mint limonata to drink which was sweet and refreshing.  

The service was great.  Our waiter was very attentive and came by our table without being overwhelming.  Althought we came late night, we didn't feel rushed out.  I would definitely return again.
author: Christine D.

description:
What?  What did you say?  Ohhhh.... If you are here on a typical evening, it will take some lip reading and shouting in order to converse.  No there isn't a band or a DJ it's just that loud.  That being said we had a very nice meal and this is definitely a spot to try if you haven't been here yet.

It's Italian fare, but not your typical red sauce kind of place, which in my book makes it fun as the menu is creative and well executed.  Décor is hip, and tables are a bit close so if you are from Manhattan you will feel right at home.  

Starters were the seared squid with beans, parmesan and pesto - very good.  Had to ask for more bread to soak up the buttery sauce.  Heirloom tomato and mozzarella salad was on point, but wouldn't be my choice next time only because there are more interesting things available to start.

The fish of the day was a perfectly grilled fillet of Petrale Sole with a creamy burrata topping served on a bed of arugula, sweet peppers and cherry tomatoes.  The mushroom farro (think risotto only it's a sort of wheat) was creamy and deeply flavorful.

Extensive wine list with a variety of price points allowed us to try two selections that were new to our palates.  

Desserts modestly priced, the shared angel cake with gelato and pine (yes, pine as in pine tree - can't remember which species) was wonderful.  

Service was excellent, and I have seem some others complain about being seated at the bar with a reservation, however when I called I was asked if I had a preference but told they couldn't guarantee a table for two.  No issue for me and we did get a table.

Overall excellent value and a fun spot.
author: Jerry P.

description:
Nice italian restaurant, the food is very good and the ambient is quite. The price of the food is decent ($15-$20 aprox per dish). The wines are expensive but good. I had the draft beer: good!
The lasagna is great!!
author: Ana L.

description:
The last few times I was there I loved it, but this time around, I think I actually prefer Perbacco.

Services issues were a bit of a turn off this time around...
- One of our wine glasses that was brought to us still had someone else's residual wine at the bottom
- Waters didn't get refilled
- I asked for bread 3 times, and it never came
- Our server disappeared for much of the meal
- We asked for sharing utensils but didn't get more; our appetizer plates also never got changed out for larger plates for sharing the food
- Two people didn't get dinner napkins 

Wines:
Their mark ups are actually pretty reasonable.  We went with two bottles, and I really liked the sangiovese. I think all the bottles were under $100, and many come in glass or carafe sizes, too.

Starters:
- Octopus: nice char, good crusted potatoes in the center (almost like a potato salad)
- Squid: crushed peas and sliced radishes were nice for the summer; the squid was cooked well and wasn't rubbery

Sides:
- Cauliflower: get it without the anchovies; we had one and one without, and the one with anchovies was too fishy; otherwise, this dish is great 
- Summer squash: with ricotta salata, well seasoned, great for summer
- Brussels sprouts: I know they're fried, but they're too oily

Pastas:
- Farroto: good texture, but it's a bit single dimensioned. It has roasted mushrooms, but it was mostly farro 
- Orecchiette: good texture, and the sausage adds a lot of flavor, but without it, the pesto is a bit under salted. This is usually one of my favorites.  Since they were out of one of the other pastas we wanted, we doubled up on this one
- Lumache: the ragu was good, but again - without the actual meat, it was under seasoned 

Mains: 
- Steak: wonderful seasoning, perfectly medium rare 

I used to love all of their pastas, but now I would say the highlights were the steak, cauliflower side (without anchovies), and orecchiette. 

I know it was a busy night, but even after the place cleared out, service was pretty lacking.
author: Marilyn H.

description:
Impeccable service and flavorful food. 

I've been here once for lunch and once for dinner. The food is solid--not amazing, but the great service bumps this up to a 5 in my book! 

My waiter for dinner gave us four tasting pours of wine before we chose a bottle. He also was personable and made good recommendations. It was a good bottle of wine...that's about all I remember from that dinner. 

Lunch was much more affordable with 10-15 dollar mains. The chicken thighs were perfectly cooked and the brussel sprouts were crispy just the way I like it. A bit heavy on the vinegar but nothing I couldn't handle. Again, service was on point. 

Good place to go for lunch or dinner with solid food choices and great service. Will be back again!
author: Kat T.

description:
I ordered the farrotto via Order Ahead for pickup at lunch and only had to wait about 15-20 minutes before my food was ready! The risotto was rich, but I felt the portion was a little small for $14. Luckily, it's super filling so I didn't feel like I was getting ripped off.

It's not what you would think of traditional risotto though, with smaller grains of rice. The risotto is made with farro, which is larger and rounder. I really enjoyed it, but I also wish it had meat in it instead of just veggies (but that's just a personal gripe).

Overall a decent spot for lunch, albeit a little on the pricier side of FiDi lunch dining, and I would like to eventually try them for dinner one night.
author: Anna W.

description:
Great Italian spot in the financial district if you're craving homemade pasta and well executed meat dishes. Prices are very decent for the area and quality of food.

The decor was very nice - a mix of trendy, chic, and rustic with brick wall accents. I made a reservation and was seated promptly. The restaurant was busy but not too packed (this was on a Tuesday night - for weekends I'm assuming it's busier so I would make a reservation)

I ordered their signature paccheri pasta ($13) which really hit the spot. The large pasta tubes were cooked perfectly - al dente and chewy which is how I like my pastas. The sauce was good - fresh tomatoes stewed into a pork ragu which was seasoned nicely. It could have been a little more flavorful but overall pretty good. 

My bf got the braciole pork cutlets ($18) and this was outstanding. Perfectly pan roasted and seasoned. It was juicy, tender, full of flavor, the field greens and parmigiano paired amazingly well with this dish. Everything on this dish paired well together. I would say it's one of the best pork dishes I've ever had and would definitely come back for this. 

The brussel sprouts ($5) also did not disappoint. Saw the words, fried in duck fat and I was sold. Came out hot off the fryer - crispy shell and tender inside. Flavorful with a nice tang from the vinaigrette and smokey aftertaste from the char - well done.
author: Brenda L.

description:
Food 5++  I love this place so much. their tapas, pasta, entree are always so good. 
Drink 3 Wine list was okay for me
Ambience 4 
Service 4 
Price 5
author: Tory T.

description:
After having some time to mull over my overall experience having lunch at this place, I must say that I was not impressed.

Normally I would only review the food, but this deserves some more elaboration on my part.

Our party of 7 arrived at 11:24 for our reservation at 11:30. The hostess lets us in and tells us that they're not fully ready to open, which is understandable. However, she starts to seat other smaller parties anyway, not us. 

A few minutes later, after the restaurant officially opens and a few people get seated, she informs us that the maximum amount of people for the online reservation is 6, that they had tried to call us about it, and failed to do so. In spite of that, they managed to accommodate us anyway. Even though it was quite a tight spot, at least we were seated. I wish she was upfront with us about the reservation issue from the start, but I do appreciate the effort to get us seated anyway. 

Now, on to the food. My friend had informed me their polpette (Sicilian meatballs with pine nuts and raisins, braised chard, and spicy tomato lugo, aka tomato sauce, $15) was well-received on Yelp, so I went ahead with that choice. The 3 meatballs were definitely well cooked as they were all consistent in texture and didn't fall apart. However, take a look at all of the components of this dish (pine nuts, raisins, braised chard, and spicy tomato sauce). The pine nuts were non existent, as well as the raisins. The "spicy" tomato sauce did not have a hint of spice to it. In essence, all I got were 3 meatballs drenched with tomato sauce and chard. I don't know what the other reviewers got, but I didn't get what was advertised. 

One of my coworkers also tried the lasagna bolognese, and thought it tasted quite bland, AND she got a stomachache afterwards. Tsk tsk tsk. 

I expected a lot more out of this place, and I'm disappointed that wasn't the case.
author: Viet N.

description:
Went here with a group of 7. Their tables usually only hold a max of 6, but we called ahead for a reservation and they let us pull up a chair. 

Brussel Sprouts (4/5) - Nice and crispy with a good flavor.

Crostini (3/5) - I love pate, but there was wayyy too much pate per piece of bread for me. I stole some bread from my friend's appetizer and put about half the pate on those pieces. That proportion was nicer for me.

I also ordered another pasta that I can't remember the name of...It was on the temporary menu and had wild boar. It was super tasty, and had lots of meat!
author: Cynthia M.

description:
Great food. We ordered Burrata salad appetizer, two lasagna and the salmon special. Very fresh food. Very tasty. Good service. Berry attentive!
Nice wine and drinks list.
author: Sabine M.

description:
Great food! The prices are great, the atmosphere is casual, and be ready for communal seating!.

We ordered the orecchiette (I wish this was a bit more separated as huge chunks were stuck together). The spaghetti was really good! The pastas overall were pretty big portions even though I thought it would be a lot less food. We also got the hamachi crudo and the fried brussel sprouts in duck fat. This is a great spot for catching up with friends.

Note: there is no hard liquor. We thought we could get cocktails but instead we got some wine and a chimay.
author: Lily P.

description: Must try the Flank Steak!!! It was simply amazing! Better than most high end steak houses. Super friendly staff! Oh and the chocolate mousse dessert was thick and balanced! So dam good!!! Great price, great staff, great food! I highly recommend it!!!
author: Matthew B.

description: I took a group of clients to lunch at Barbacco and it was wonderful.  We had a reservation and everything flowed smoothly, we quickly had drinks and appetizers sitting in front of us.  Everyone ordered a different entre and had wonderful things to say.  I wasn't hungry and ordered an off-menu salad with chicken and it was delicious.
author: Lauren H.

description:
I came here for an early dinner before going to a retirement party for a friend. 

I had heard about Perbacco but not about this place until my friend set up the reservation. When I arrived on the early side, the hostess set me up with a drink and a got a good look of the interior. It's well-lighted in the front and the back was a bit dark but not overly so. We ended up seated in the back and it did feel a bit cramp back there though - maybe because I'm a bit claustrophobic

We decided to make it simple and shared an grilled octopus salad and we each got an entree. I ended getting an excellent beef stew (can't remember the name of it now on the menu). The portions were huge and the beef was super tender while the sauce was rich and earthy - again excellent!

The service was just ok. I felt they could've stopped by and asked me for another drink but oh well.

Definitely a spot to hit up if you're in the FiDi.
author: Art O.

description:
I knew I would love Barbacco given my amazing experience at their sister restaurant, Perbacco. As expected the pasta was perfectly al dente - you know a good pasta the instant you sink your teeth into it. 

* Bruschetta with Burrata - 5 STARS ($12): Arugula, corn, burratta, and some type of crack. This bruschetta unlike the others is served on a larger piece of bread, and topped generously with a phenomenal, delicate burrata cheese and a variety of corn, arugula, and other vegetables. From the soft, fresh grilled bread, to the burrata and the corn this was one of the highlights of my meal.

* Paccheri Pasta with Pork Sugo - 3.5 STARS ($13): The paccheri is one of Barbacco's most popular entrees. In pictures the noodles look long and flat, but they're actually huge cylindrical shaped pastas, with a nice thickness and bite to it. The sauce was a bit tart and pretty tasty but overall flavor wise needed more cheese, cream or something. 

* Orecchiette - 4 STARS ($12): Cavolo nero fennel sausage,  pecorino cheese. This was quite a hefty portion of pasta, topped generously with oil and green sauce. The flavors were delicious and satisfying, I just wish they cooked the pasta more al dente.

* Local squid - 4 STARS ($10): With piastra / capers / chili / olive oil crushed potatoes. I loved the combination of the textures and flavors. The olive tapenade was quite salty but complemented the potatoes and delicate chopped fresh calamari. It was heavier than I expected, but filling and reminded me of homemade food. 

Overall prices were affordable - they don't inflate prices for dinner, food was high quality; I would definitely come back but not for a business lunch as they don't take reservations at noon (they are on Opentable!) and it gets very loud inside. 

Pro-tip: they serve complimentary sparkling water!
Pro-tip: the complimentary bread is pretty terrible.
author: Jess C.

description:
I'm typing this as I'm finishing the last morsels of the take out I just finished from Barbacco tonight, and I'll start by saying that it was more of a 3.5 star experience than a 3 star.

Oddly, you can't order take out online after 3 Monday through Friday (presumably due to the fact that they seem to always be busy during the evenings), so I called in my order and got a very friendly person on the other end who took my order, answered the few questions I had very nicely, and was told my food would be ready in 20 minutes. I ordered the corn rigatoni with roasted peppers, asparagus, prosciutto, all in a meyer lemon butter sauce.

I picked my food up about 35 minutes after I placed my order, but when I got it back to the office, it seemed as though my food had been done more quickly and sitting longer than the 20 minutes I was quoted. It wasn't cold, but it was a bit tepid and had that I've-been-sitting-on-the-counter-for-a-while look about it. The veggies were deliciously cooked, the meyer lemon butter sauce was such a light, fresh accompaniment to the dish, but the biggest disappointment - and I mean biggest, because pasta is sort of my life - was the corn rigatoni. I don't know if it was because it's made of corn, if it was a combo of the pasta being made of corn and cooked al dente, or if it was a tri-fold combo of being made of corn, al dente, and having been sitting for a while, but it was hard and dry.

Hard, dry pasta. No, guys. No.

The pasta that was sitting in more of the sauce than the other rigatoni was softer, but ultimately it reminded me of when I make a pot of pasta at home, try a noodle or macaroni to see if the pasta is done, and when I find that it's too undercooked I keep boiling the noodles - but it seems like the chef preparing this dish thought the pasta was ready to go at hard and granular. 

Something tells me, by the quality and taste of the rest of the dish, that if I were to get any other pasta dish at Barbacco (this is the only dish with corn pasta), it would be delicious. I had originally intended to order the paccheri, but when I found out it was no longer served in a pork ragu but in a tomato cauliflower sugo I changed my mind. I probably shouldn't have. But I'd like to go back to try something else. This experience, however, wasn't what it should've been, and wasn't totally what I was hoping for.
author: Angela M.

description:
Walked in on a weekday lunch without a reservation for a party of 3.  Was seated almost immediately and did not realize that they do communal seating here!  It actually surprised me a bit, as this was the first time I've ever shared a table at an Italian restaurant... actually at any restaurant in California.  I think I'm more used to it in Asia where the spaces of restaurants are much more cramped, haha.  

That day I had a huge craving for pasta, so I was hoping this place would fulfill my craving ... which it did.  I had the Orechiette, which had cavolo nero, fennel sausage, and pecorino cheese.  Served generously with plenty of pasta, oil, and green sauce!  The sausage really complimented the pasta well and I felt like there was a good sausage to pasta ratio between the two.

My other coworker had the Farrotto, which was farro "risotto", roasted mushrooms, spinach, and parmigiano reggiano.  I had a bite of his pasta, and found it quite creamy and almost a bit too heavy to eat the entire dish by yourself.  Even though this pasta had all the ingredients that I liked, I was actually quite glad I didn't end up with this dish because like I had thought, my coworker actually didn't even end up finishing his pasta cause it was too heavy.

Overrall, I wasn't too impressed for how upscale looking it was.  Now, the prices are quite reasonable and the service is great, but like another Yelper on here, I think I expected a little more.  I'll have to come back and give their dinner menu a try though!
author: Carena N.

description: Good but not great Italian food. The menu is pretty simple and I ordered the lasagna. It was huge. The place was packed and even with a reservation we got a place at the bar right in front of the kitchen. Good, if forgettable dinner.
author: Cameron R.

description:
Really pleasantly surprised with how affordable the food was here - looks super fancy inside! We felt a bit underdressed, kind of a nicer place, but really enjoyed the food here.

- roasted brussel sprouts 5/5
- chicken breast 4/5
- risotto 5/5

Got the moscato and wine mojito with my friend and they were both good :) overall great experience!
author: Beatriz G.

description:
Barbacco is such a perfect combination of quality, portion, and price and the service was excellent! Barbacco provides an upscale enough ambience to have a formal dinner while also casual enough to watch sports with a group. My family really wanted to watch a specific basketball team on TV that night and the waitress switched the channels for us right away.

For appetizers, we ordered the Brussel Sprouts ($6) because I'm a huge fan of them. The were slightly charred and crispified just how I like it and had rich flavor with a hint of citrus. Very worth it considering the time it would take to cook brussel sprouts at home and that raw brussel sprouts are about $4 a bag in store. Definitely a deal.

For the entrees, my group shared the Orecchiette ($16), which were pasta shaped like little ears. The pasta was chewy and dense, a little too dense, and was well flavored with kale, sausage, and pesto. This entree could have been shared by two medium sized people.

We also shared the Lamb Flank with Fava Beans ($22). It was just soo delicious and tender, and I love it when the meat falls off the bone. The portion was also enough for 2 medium sized people, in my opinion. 

The last was the Sicilian Meatballs ($16), which was slightly sweet with chard, raisin, and tomato sauce. This was tasty but not spectacular because the tomato sauce actually overwhelmed the flavor of the meat.
author: Shelley C.

description:
Barbacco is dear to my heart, as I came here almost weekly after work when I was still in FiDi. I would say this is one of the few places that serves the most delicious Italian food you could scour the city for. The gem salad they had last summer was my absolute favorite, with diced stone fruits (i.e., peaches, apricots) and perfectly whipped ricotta. I am currently writing a very belated review, because I ate somewhere else tonight that had ricotta in its salad, and it just does not compare -- somehow, Barbacco is capable of making an extremely light, fluffy ricotta that makes the whole salad come together. Thank you for always making my day with that salad.

For entrees, a must-have is the orecchiette. It's on the saltier side, but if you can appreciate freshly-ground pesto, handmade pasta, and generous portions, get this dish. I'm glad to see that this is still on the menu.

Barbacco's atmosphere is sleek, dimly lit, and loud. They are also slightly pretentious, but what's new with that in FiDi? I did not appreciate being temporarily turned away once when the restaurant was nearly empty, because the friend I brought with me happened to look, say, in a more rugged attire. Otherwise, I am usually seated right away at the bar. It gets crowded, so reservations are recommended if you are going to be more than a party of one. 

Last thing: the wine on tap is underrated -- it is delicious, and I order it every time.
author: Letitia L.

description:
I don't have to elaborate on how fabulous this place is, whether for a quick catch up lunch at the bar or dinner at their communal tables.

The food is solid, entrees are usually a perfect serving for one (or shared by two if ordering multiple dishes) the salumi plate is great, pastas are a no brainer and always a crowd pleaser. If you want meat, the MEATBALLS are flavorful with a slight kick in the back of the throat. Aherm. ;) 

Dare I say, best Italian lunch spot in the Fidi!
author: Janice C.

description: This is my favorite Italian restaurant in the city! My boyfriend and I first came here a few years ago and I have been hooked since. We have been back for birthdays, celebrations and random Tuesday nights because this is "our restaurant" now. The food is always SO GOOD. I usually get the orecchiette, the "little ears" pasta. They make it with kale, but the other night it was with broccoli and sausage. I'm never disappointed. The pasta is so fresh, not sure if they make it here or not, but it's delicious. My bf usually gets the lasagna (highly recommend) but he tried the special that night and it was wonderful as well. The service is always great, I never feel rushed and can linger once we're done. Their desserts and coffee are fantastic as well. Highly recommend the almond cake and sorbet. Their lattes are great too, they use Me Espresso coffee and I swear it's the best tasting coffee. Overall, love this place and will continue to come back over and over again!
author: Jasmine M.

description:
Nice gem in the financial district. Given so many reviews, I was surprised 4 of us were able to get a seat with minimal waiting on a Saturday night (granted it was 9PM).

The ambiance is cute- well decorated but not too pretentious. Modern but still cozy.

All the food was solid. Tasted very fresh and portion sizes were good. We shared:
- Starters: Brussel Sprouts, Calamari, Mussels
- Main Course: Ziti and Beef Stew
- Wine: We got a bottle of Italian red. They let you taste some before you pick one as long as they're bottles that are sold by the glass.

Fits a versatile crowd- from date night to family outings.
author: Ruth H.

description:
Decent Italian food with an ok selection of alcohol (wine and beer only, no cocktail options), we came here for a work lunch to wind down a bit. We were able to get seats despite a semi-large group and no reservation and our order was taken quickly. 

Food was good, prices were decent for the area and quality, atmosphere is definitely loud and busy and packed so be prepared if this isn't quite the scene you prefer (we had some difficulties with conversation with people sitting next to us). 

Definitely a place to return to for lunches again, although I'd like more options on the drink menu!
author: Cassandra J.

description: Slightly below average food. Had the chicken thighs and it was just ok. The lasagna was a small portion and dry. They wanted to sit us at the bar when it was half empty and we had a reservation. Skip this place and go to something better.
author: Brian B.

description:
Complimentary sparkling water that they make in house!  Nice way to start the evening.  Also the extensive wine list (including wines on tap) did not hurt.  We started with the brussel sprouts, upon recommendation of the waitress.  They were roasted perfectly and had a nice flavor but were slightly too tart for my taste buds.

Then came the entrees.  I ordered the farrotto which is farro "risotto".  It was really lovely because I love risotto but this one was made with a rice more similar to brown rice so it had a nice texture and was deliciously flavorful and creamy without being too heavy.  Definitely a winner and I would totally order it again.  My husband ordered the chitarra which was also wonderful--hand cut pasta with spicy tomato sauce and meatballs.

Overall, for the price, I thought their service and food was excellent.  A great deal for good Italian food.  I would definitely visit again.
author: Jess Y.

description:
Came here a while back for a Christmas dinner with 4 other friends. We had reservation and sat near the back. I felt that the service could have been better due to the unfriendly waiter. Although he didn't put give us attitude, his face barely had a happy expression making it seem like he wasn't friendly.

As for the food, I didn't think anything exceptional. We tried the bruschettas which had only 4 pieces for all of us to split. It was not satisfying because we had to cut small pieces into 5 so we could all have a taste of it, but we barely tasted much of it. Our waiter could have suggested to order more, but he didn't even seeing that there were more of us than the dish. The brussels sprouts were my favorite of the evening - very flavorful with a strong vinegar taste. I had the lasagna bolognese and it wasn't as tasty as I expected and the "little ears" pasta was bland - so bland my friend had to request chili pepper. Nothing special about pasta and I probably expected too much coming here. Probably won't be back since I didn't think it was that worth it.
author: Amanda C.

description: Just like its sister restaurant next door, Perbacco, this place lives up to the bougie Italian food hype. Perbacco is one of my faborite restaurants in the city. Barbacco is for smaller groups. I tried to book a company lunch for 9 people and they can't seat that many people to a table. BUt I came back with 2 friends, and ordered a bunch ofthings. Favorites include the brussels sprouts, the salad, and my beautiful melt in your mouth Lasagna Bolognese. I work close to here so I am always coming back.
author: Annie K.

description:
After the disappointment of hearing "the wait is eternity" from 2 other places during SF Restaurant Week, the reassurance received from the hostess at Barbacco that she could fit us in ignited the tastebuds in my mouth like fireflies! My friend and I walked in, put our name on the list but didn't even have enough time to finish our glass of wine at Michael Mina next door. That's what I call fitting in. 

Our host sat us at the end of the bar, where the scene was busy, busy, hustle, hustle! The momentum of the staffs precision and attentiveness showed they run a tight nit operation here. At one point I think we had three people attending us.  

We starting off with the fried Brussel sprouts, Burrata salad and Chicken liver pâté as our appetizers to share. The brussel sprouts were tangy from the capers with a, slightly crisp outer layer finished off by a plump, tender inside. I could have passed on the burrata salad. It came with a side of whole garlic. I don't know about you but I'm not one for chowing down on whole pieces of garlic in a salad.. or any other dish for that matter. The cheese was creamy, easy to spread but reminded me of a watered down manchego. Pass. The chicken liver pâté on the other hand was amazing! Spread out on a slightly toasted slice of bread and topped with caramelized onions. It was a mix of sweet and meat and it was divine. 

By now we were on glass 2 of the '05 Claret, which mind you, each new pour came with a fresh new glass. Class! This complimented our main dish - the Lasagna Bolognese. I will admit I was a little skeptical with the spinach pasta. My doubts were settled with the first bite of melted cheese, creamy béchamel and soft pasta sans all the usual oil in most lasagna meat dishes. I was stuffed at this point so I literally had 3 bites. Those 3 had me wanting more, I just couldn't! We packed it up. We were then offered a final glass of wine while the staff closed shop. Although we were the last customers in the restaurant, not at any point did the staff say 'hey! uh we want to go home'. They allowed us to enjoy our time and enjoy their space. I will return!
author: Jaylena P.

description: This is the second time I have been here and still the customer service is incredible!  I made an open table reservation 15 min before arriving and fwe got there early and the hostess seated us right away I a busy dinner service.  I must say the Bruschetta Burrata  appetizer was incredible, the best I ever had period!!  My 11 yr old son loved it. We moved on to the entrees, my son had the flank steak and I had the polpette veal meatballs we both tried each other's food and both were equally great! I must give kudos to the waitress, she saw my son struggling with his knife so without any indication she brought him another knife that was much better for cutting his steak. The customer service was above and beyond. Then it was time for dessert, we had different homemade Gelato the honeycomb gelato was awesome!!  This place earned another 5 stars!!!
author: Dr. Scott C.

description: Loved the beets bruschetta and corn rigatoni pasta. Quick service and delicious food on a Wednesday lunch hour. My friend had the lasagna and loved it too.
author: Joyeta S.

description: Amazing lasagna and Brussels. Went here for lunch and the place was packed. The waitress was also very helpful. Great atmosphere.
author: Danny F.

description:
Came here for a girl's night dinner on a Friday night with 3 other friends and the meal was delicious! We ordered a small salumi plate, 4 bruschettes, 3 pastas (corn rigatoni, squid ink penne and chitarra), brussels sprouts and 2 desserts (chocolate cake and warm maple cake). It was a good amount for us and our favs were the appetizers and squid ink pasta. The brussells sprouts was a bit salty but we were told it was good and cooked with garlic and duck fat, so don't be alarmed and say you weren't warned. 

Overall Portions: not too big/not too small - just right
The staff is really friendly too and checked on us periodically. 
Making a reservation is a must (open table is awesome!)
author: Eva O.

description:
Delicious, everything we ordered. Busy on a Friday night but the hostess got us a spot at the bar (fairly quickly) since we had no reservations, and the service there was fast.

Everything was delightful, even the wine and Italian bubbly water. We had the fried lemon brussels, yellow beets w horseradish, pomadoro soup, and the Italian beef stew. Simple yet astounding flavors. Would go again. 

Only complaint is the place is a little narrow, but the decor helps quite a bit.
author: Tony B.

description:
I came here to lunch with some coworkers and I loved the food here, especially desert! it's a great place to come, it's not overly fancy and it's not too loud or busy. 
I had to try the Brussels sprouts and they were delicious! Just thinking about them now is making my mouth water. I also had the meatballs and those were delicious too, the plate comes with 3 and they're a good size so you are not left hungry or overly full. 
I can't exactly remember what we had for desert because we ordered 3 gelato's and 2 different deserts. Everything was so good, i would definitely come back here again.
author: Irma R.

description: Love Barbacco!! Whenever I'm in Sfo I get the fried brussel sprouts!! To die for!!! Easy order ahead and pick up!! Always nice and accommodating!! Cool place!!
author: Julie E.

description:
I have been here twice so far. Both times customer service was top notch.

First time I stopped for a glass of bubbles and a variety cheese/spread plate , while waiting on a friend early evening. It was very pretty arranged and very tasty, the sparkling wine was good (it was not the cheapest one so it better be good :) ) 

Second time I went was for lunch with co workers. I ordered bruschetta with the chicken liver pate and vinaigrette caramelized onions. Texture was not well balanced and so weren't the flavors - seemed like the liver was deluded  with something watery, so you did not get the thick creamy liver texture and the taste was lost in the sweet taste of the onions. Main course was the eggplant sandwich. Insanely delicious , well balanced textures and taste, and not soggy as many places make it. Perfect bite! For desert I ordered the Coffee Panna Cotta .... I was very confused - it was made with mascarpone cheese, it had very soft consistency and the coffee lady fingers on top - pretty large size, beautifully looking dessert arrangement , delicious tiramisu... They don't have tiramisu on the menu, so I know they did not bring me the wrong desert. Still good to try, just don't expect Pana Cotta, haha 

Tables are way too close to each other, I am a little curvy and had hard time going between the tables to sit on the bench. The TV across was playing some reality TV show , and even if you are not watching it was not pleasant at all to pick up your head from the plate and see scarred people in hospital, or homeless drunks on the street. Not a restaurant appropriate channel.
author: Gergana N.

description:
Came for a late happy hour on a friday and it was dead at 7. Got more crowded as we left at 8PM for the dinner crowd. Good ambiance, not a great wine list (very overpriced), and food we meh at best. 

We got the asparagus $5, squid $12 and roasted carrots $5 and all we actually pretty bad. The pasta main was worth the price. I would avoid all three of those small plates. 

The meatball, and pasta dishes looked good from seeing the orders at adjoining tables.
author: Matt D.

description: This restaurant was a bit of a letdown. The food was so-so...my mom got the lasagna and it was stone cold, but they were quick to reheat and did not charge for it. Overall, the staff seemed kind of frantic and out of sorts, and the food was less than stellar. The one redeeming dish was the celery root soup of the day, which was awesome!
author: Laura H.

description:
Came here for lunch with some co-workers. The atmosphere was good -- lively, but not too loud or busy for lunchtime conversation. 

The bruschetta and nduja were a great start, and for me, the highlight of the meal. I tried the the shrimp and squid sandwich. It was good, and the ingredients were fresh. However I found it just a little dry and it could have used a bit more flavor.

However, the pasta dishes all look great and I regret not getting one now! Will definitely have to come back again for dinner for some pasta and wine!
author: Greg J.

description: MEH. Had all this hype from yelp and trip advisor, had bloggers chatting about it. So I go. I'm a very picky Italian food eater. When someone says it's Italian it better be ITALY Italian and not AMERICAN Italian. However this place left me confused. It said it was hand made pasta, not so sure, it said it was tradition with modern flare, kinda. Small menu. Very small inside seating. Very loud. I wouldn't go out of my way to go there again I did try 5 dishes and all were okay.
author: Lacey S.

description: Fun atmosphere and good food at a solid price point. Big fan of the Brussel Sprouts :)
author: Michael J.

description: Every time I come to San Francisco we eat at these "amazing" restaurants. I've noticed a pattern. The service is horrible and dinner takes forever. I've been to the Caribbean numerous times and get "carribean time" but this is beyond. We tried to order drinks 4 times before our server actually took our drink order. When we were finally able to order our wine it took 20 minutes for our server to tell us they were out of that wine and asked us to order another. 15 minutes later we finally got our wine. Portions are underwhelming and not that good. I had the rigatoni. Meh. Not overwhelming flavor. The taste was mediocre. Service was not good throughout and the dinner took way longer than it needed to. I've heard Perbacco us better. Wish we went there.
author: M S.

description: The food here had a horrible aftertaste. We ordered the fried Brussels sprouts and Orecchiette, both popular dishes on yelp. While the first few bites were enjoyable, the flavors became flat and stuck around in my mouth. I walked out of there feeling queasy from the amount of grease I had consumed and the pungent flavors lingering in my mouth.
author: Tim V.

description:
prefer it over perbacco and still making rocking the hits.
POLPETTE sicilian meat balls with pine nuts and raisins braised chard / spicy tomato sugo 
excellent flavor, texture, best testing.
ORECCHIETTE "little ears" / cavolo nero fennel sausage / pecorino cheese -- lots of ground meat, filling pasta dish.
ROASTED OCTOPUS celery / potatoes / ink aioli -- probably would have been better grilled.
FRIED BRUSSELS SPROUTS capers / anchovy red wine vinaigrette -- excellent flavor, perfect contrast and vinaigrette tang
author: Rob C.

description: I love eating here with my coworkers for special occasions. I've never had a single complaint until lunch on 01/23. Two of us ordered ribollita, both of us have lived in Tuscany and that was not even close to ribollita. Beans, broth, some kale and a piece of bread the size of my thumb in it. I want to try again!
author: Drew P.

description:
Pros:
*Totally affordable
*Quick
*The 'Njuda--soft salame spread from Boccalone.  They need to give more crostinis though!  
*Good portions

The So-So:
*Porchetta was moist and thought the bell peppers was a different but nice addition. However, don't think I can say it's in my top 3 porchettas.  No crispy skin!
*The espresso panna cotta, was super light, but didn't have a bold enough espresso flavor.  It may as well have been the standard vanilla panna cotta.

Cons:
*Our orchiette with broccoli rabe and fennel sausage was so bland, some pepper didn't even help.
*We did make a reservation, and got a table; but tables are close together, so not ideal for holding a conversation well.

It wasn't horrible, but there's better Italian restaurants in SF for sure.  In terms of the Fidi, it's hard finding a good Italian restaurant, especially at this price point!
author: Cat C.

description:
Wearing a shirt and a hoodie with jeans and sneakers does not fly at Perbacco. I mistakenly walked into the wrong restaurant during a busy lunch hour. "I have a reservation for lunch." Hostess: "I think you mean at Barbacco next door." How pretentious. It's confusing enough that you open two like-named restaurants adjacent to one another. Brushing off a case of mistaken restaurant identity, I had a great lunch at the real Barbacco.

My one must-try dish is the roasted peaches, prosciutto di parma bruschette. I never knew this flavor combination could work, but it did and it was delicious. The rest of the menu had classic Italian dishes like the lasagna bolognese and the orecchiette with fennel sausage, both of which were done well. 

For sides, we had the fried polenta and the brussel sprouts fried in duck fat. I'm not much of a polenta fan due to its mushy consistency, but this side was interesting enough to pique my curiosity. It's a mix between a hash brown and polenta. How do you get kids to eat more brussel sprouts? Fry them in duck fat. I liked the crispy texture of the brussel sprouts, but they were too salty for my liking. Capers and anchovy tend to do that to a dish. It was also overdressed with the red wine vinaigrette. The prices were quite reasonable for all the food we had for lunch. All in all, a very complete Italian meal minus the wine!
author: Bailey Z.

description:
- Relaxed, cozy ambience, spacious and close to Market St/Bart - easy accessibility
- Great for post work meet up with friends, but not a food heaven
- Excellent appetizers. Personal favorites: roasted octopus, fried Brussel sprouts, crostini with chicken liver pate and bruschetta with prosciutto and burrata
- Entrees were average, really large portions
- The butterscotch gelato was delicious
- The Pinot by the glass was really nice for the price
author: Coastgirl H.

description: I love this place. Decent menu selection, generous portions at a reasonable price. It is modern, upscale but at the same time casual. Perfect for business lunch/dinner or a fun outing with friends and co-workers.
author: May N.

description:
**This is just for their take-out, primarily the fried Brussels Sprouts!

Take-out is so easy here. you can order online, type in what time you want to pick up, walk right in and avoid the crowd. I'm assuming it's better to make reservations and have a lot of time if you want to eat here because it gets really crowded during lunch time. It looks really nice though!

I was craving Brussells sprouts one day and searched around Yelp for them and found this place, only 2 blocks from work WOOT. Omg they are AMAZING. Fried in duck fat, red wine balsamic, anchovies and capers (you can't taste either of these). I have to mix them with plain lettuce or chicken because the flavor is VERY potent, but they are delicious. I get them every couple of weeks when the mood hits. 

*Side cautionary note: Your coworkers may complain of the smell, but just enjoy them anyway because it's worth it!! lol
author: Lindsey P.

description:
Lasagna is killer. 
Surprisingly non business hip atmosphere at dinner time, even in middle of financial district (take note visitors in downtown hotels).

Lunch may be different.

Will return.

Minus a star for incredibly surly hostess, almost compensated by incredibly nice waitperson.
author: E F.

description: Great spot in the FiDi for a delicious Italian meal with interesting modern and flavorful variations. I mean I had the meatballs. Meatballs. What can you do with them? Well, quite a lot when you include pine nuts, and raisins, and serve them over braised chard and sauce them with a tangy tomato sugo! Delicious! Prompt, attentive, and friendly service. I can't wait to try some of their other offerings! Bravo, Barbacco!
author: Lou S.

description:
Pleasantly surprised with my boyfriend's pick to go to Barbacco! The ambience is perfect for a date night, service was great, food was delicious and was all reasonably priced.

It's definitely a place where you want to order a variety of dishes to share. We started off with a cup of Minestra and cauliflower purée, which was the soup of the day, both delicious! We also shared the Chitarra, fish of the day - seared coho salmon served with a refreshing arugula, baby tomato and green bean salad (my favorite of the night!), and sides of fried polenta and brussel sprouts. Psst.. pick the polenta over the sprouts, which were a bit soggy. 

If this was anywhere else, I would say that I regret ordering so much food. However, since everything was so delicious - I don't regret anything except not saving enough room for dessert.
author: Laverne N.

description:
This is my new favorite spot in the FiDi. Delicious southern Italian menu. The Orechiette and Farotto are my favorite pasta dishes. Their brussel sprout side is tasty and very popular. Even non-brussel sprout lovers will like this dish. The squid appetizer is amazing with potatoes and capers. It may not sound like these ingredients would taste great together, but this is definitely a winner. Def one of my standys there. If you're looking for dessert, you won't go wrong with the gelato or sorbet options. Service is friendly and helpful though for a business lunch crowd, service sometimes runs a touch slow -- my ONLY gripe. 

Other than that, will dine here whenever I get the opportunity!
One of my new favorite places to dine in.
author: Anna R.

description:
Came here around 10 minutes before opening to meet my dad for lunch.  It was cold outside and they wouldn't let us wait inside.  It was understandable since their entrance way was small, but it was off putting and uncomfortable. 

Walking inside, the restaurant looks bigger than it is from all the mirrors.  I liked the modern decorations and feel to the place.  It seems like it would be a great place to grab drinks or for a nice dinner.  The food was good with portions on the smaller side.  The beef stew I ordered was great for the cold weather outside.  It was good, but not fantastic. 

Probably wouldn't come back here.  Had an OK experience and the food was only alright. 

Ambiance: 5/5
Food: 3.5/5
Service: 3/5
Overall Experience: 3/5
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
Came here for a weekday lunch - good for casual business or catching up for a pair.  You'll feel a bit like a sardine, but if you forget to make reservations there always seems to be an open seat or two along the bar.  They have a TV too, so makes for a nice solo meal as well.

All the food was solid and nothing I wouldn't eat again.  But the one must-have-next-time would be the POLPETTE meat balls - nice, moist with a bit of sweetness which really went well with everything else.

Here's what else went into the tummy:

bruschette PROSCIUTTO / TUSCAN CHICKEN LIVER PATE / ROASTED HEN OF THE WOODS MUSHROOMS: the bread was nice and toasted, but felt more like a hindrance to the topping flavors. high quality meat, could've used a smidge more pate/onion, but they were all hearty little bites

ORECCHIETTE: nice little kick to this, enjoyed the fennel sausage, would've preferred more al dente and less salty

FRIED BRUSSELS SPROUTS: loved the vinegar tang, a tad salty but fried sprouts usually are
author: Lil L.

description:
Loved Barbacco!  Since we all ordered the same meal I can't attest to very much on the menu, but everything we had was perfect.  

We shared the bruschetta appetizer and all of us ordered the Peposo (the beef stew w/polenta).  Everything was delicious!  I will definitely be back.
author: Elise C.

description: I couldn't believe how loud this restaurants was at lunch! It didn't help that the tables were almost on top of each other. The bruschetta were quite tasty and the fried Brussels sprouts were delicious, but everything was way too salty. The limonata had good flavor but was excessively sweet.
author: Lisa K.

description:
We stopped by one afternoon to grab a quick late lunch. Luckily we made it in before they reduced the menu down at 3pm.  The place was nicely decorated with bar seating and small half booths (bench on one side) along the wall.  The tables were parallelogram shaped - more for aesthetics than function.

We went with a few recommended dishes (from the Yelp reviews) - Porchetta sandwich, Orecchiette pasta, and brussel sprouts.

The Porchetta came with a side salad of leafy greens.  The sandwich was tasty - slow roasted pork topped with arugula and red onions (sweet).  

The Orechhiette was cooked perfectly and combined with sausage (not a lot of it) and kale.  Actually, I did not know it was kale until later - it did not taste earthy.  Both were ample portions.  

I was impressed with the preparation of the brussel sprouts - crispy on the outside and tender in the middle.  But the flavored bored me after a while as it was just vinaigrette.  

The service was great - attentive but not overly so.

Definitely good food and service at SF prices.  However, I am deducting a star since they pass along the extra heath tax/surcharge - IMHO this should be covered by the restaurant/management and calculated in their pricing just like every other operating expense.  I personally do not like being surprised with extra line items on the bill.
author: Roy L.

description: My bf and I really liked this place. The food was good and the prices are reasonable. I love the atmosphere and I would definitely try this place again. The service was great too. Good place to take a date. It's a fun and romantic environment.
author: Hong V.

description: Fuck this place!  We arrive with a reservation and you attempt to pass off bunk bar seats to us?!?  After we've walked past two open tables.  Not gonna happen.  Out the door we went.  But, thanks for calling a few minutes later to say that you've had a cancellation and now have an open table for us.  Yeah, give that to someone else and let them deal with your bullshit.  We've had enough of it!
author: Dan G.

description:
More casual take on Perbacco. I think the food is very similar quality and definitely cheaper. 

If you want a fancy/high end experience, go to Perbacco. If you want excellent food in a casual (but not too casual) setting, go to barbacco.
author: JM H.

description:
Good ambiance and  good service.
The brussel sprouts are obviously a no brainer here, per the other reviews (and they are fried, so how can you go wrong?). We also ordered the little ears for the table, very tasty. Our waitress was Morgan, very pleasant, and very attentive to our needs during the lunchtime rush.

I ordered the meatballs as my main course, they were OK, but nothing special. Perhaps what killed it was the LONG STRAND OF HAIR that I found in the meatball upon my first cut into the dish. What an appetite killer. Given that it was a work lunch, I didn't have the heart to kill the whole mood and make a scene, but I find this totally unacceptable. The hair was wedged into the meat, so this definitely happened during the meatball making process. There are 101 things wrong with this, no matter how good your fried brussel sprouts are...
Totally gross, really really foul.
author: Nikki R.

description: I ordered the ziti pasta and it was so bland.  It's about equal to Kraft.  However, the paté appetizer was good -- but 2 crackers amongst 4 people was a little sad.  The service was terribly pushy and I kept asking them to leave my plate in front of me.  They never asked me if I wanted another glass of wine so I drank the water.  Tables are incredibly close to each other and the bench-side of the table people sit too low and the chair-side of the table sits too high.  It was a peculiar place.
author: Jenny F.

description: Super psyched that I just paid $50 to have a place to stand and drink a glass of wine while I waited for my lasagna and olives to go and then got to my hotel room to discover not one piece of plastic ware, or napkin and BURNT nasty lasagna with ZERO FLAVOR.  Awesome.  Thanks.  Never again.
author: Amie C.

description:
Outstanding.  I've eaten at Perbacco, but this was the first time at Barbacco.  
Three of us had dinner on a busy Saturday night.  Reservation at 7:00 and they seated us immediately upon arrival.  
We had:
Fettuccine Verde in ragu Bolognese sauce
Chitarra pasta with spicy meatballs (a thicker strand of spaghetti)
Roasted Chicken
Pork cutlet 
and Brussel Sprouts.
The pork was a bit dry, but everything else was very good.  Both pastas had that nice texture you get from properly cooked fresh pasta.  The spicy meatballs were awesome. The roasted chicken came with a grilled lemon half - squeezing that over the chicken was a great touch.
Plenty more items on the menu to try when we return.  
Service was impeccable - very attentive without hovering.  
It was a very enjoyable dinner.
author: Lewis C.

description:
Must get: Brussels sprouts & roasted octopus (dinner menu only).

I've tried my fair share of brussels sprouts here in the city, but I honestly have to say that Barbacco's are my favorite! They're fried perfectly, and tossed with a bit of balsamic vinegar to add some tang to the dish. They do have a bit too much oil, so if you're not a fan of that, I'd ask them upfront to go easy on that front. They're really accommodating. 

The octopus dish is also cooked really well - the edges of the octopus are quite crispy, but the rest of the meat is really tender. It's cooked with celery, which adds a nice refreshing crunch. 

In addition to the two above, I've had the lamb shoulder pasta and roasted chicken. Both were good as well, but not as great as the octopus or the sprouts (in my opinion). 

Service is a bit slow, but friendly overall.
author: Jennie Z.

description:
Fun spot to go after work! My friend and I are a little bit meatball obsessed and we had heard good things about Barbacco meatballs, they did not disappoint! We came here after work on a Friday, we got there around 5:45 and it was pretty empty but it was packed by 6:30. 

We split the meatballs, burrata and the corn rigatoni. The meatballs and burrata were amazing!! The corn rigatoni was good but not great. Side note, the meatballs by themselves are not on the menu for dinner but if you ask the waiter for the meatballs off the lunch menu they'll give you the three meatballs without the pasta :) They also have a lot of wine on tap which is cool but wine prices weren't any cheaper even though they were on tap. 

I'll definitely be coming back, great spot downtown for wine and apps!
author: Lizzy U.

description: Me and two other friends waited 50 minutes for a table while people after us were seated - perhaps because we weren't wearing suits. After 50 minutes, the greeter told us because we were three she was going to sit us at the bar instead of a table that had just left. All of this after she said wait would be 25 minutes on a Thursday night.
author: Camilo O.

description:
There was a strange odor when I walked in that was somewhat reminiscent of a sewer or public restroom.  There's no bar where you can wait - everyone was just standing around - so we went next door for a glass of wine at their sister restaurant, Perbacco.  

I met a friend here for dinner; we had a reservation, but were nonetheless seated at their odd bar area (it's not an actual bar with a bartender, but rather a strange sushi-bar-type area with some food behind it).  My friend's chair had some old food stuck to the back of the seat when we sat down - not appetizing.  We shared the chicken liver toasts, brussels sprouts, octopus, and orecchiette.  I was not impressed with any of the food.  Prices were reasonable, but I would not come back.  There are much better options in the area.
author: Colleen K.

description:
First thing I thought when walking in here, This place is way too cool for me. Better be a 20-something working at a startup, yo. Waiter was very nice though.

The brussel sprouts were way too salty. Orechiette was awesome. I ate all the pasta before the sausage. XD honey-lemon cake was pretty decent, but the butterscotch chocolate gelato tasted like coffee. (I hate coffee.)
author: Lady V.

description: Highly recommend bruschetta, fried Brussel sprouts and lasagna. Recommend ALL! Their wine is also great pairing with the food. I finished my food so fast and still wanted more... Can't get enough of the food
author: Yuhuan T.

description:
If there's a style of food I can eat every night of the week, it's Italian. Blame the dago blood that runs in my veins, maybe, but, for me, I could eat an entire meal consisting of a cold cut and olive spread and be content. Luckily, Barbacco has all that and more. 

My family, gf and I wanted to end our last night in SF with a nice dinner, and although my parents had initially booked themselves at Perbacco next door, once they popped in here to meet us for a drink they decided to just stay and eat. It's got a contemporary decor, modern but not overdone, although I will say the chairs used here and awkward and not very comfortable. If I'm sitting down for a meal, I want a back to my chair. I need my moments of sitting back to wallow in my own crapulence. 

Everyone was hungry, so we ordered up a mini feast before ordering up a bigger one. Wine arrived, followed by a bowl of marinated olives (a nice variety, too), salami, breads, toasted almonds, and various cheeses. This was my kind of spread. They've got a decent selection of local brews on tap, so I got a refreshing beer that paired well with the meal. 

I ordered the flat iron steak, which looked absolutely delicious but keep in mind it comes with nothing but a bed of arugula. Thank to a Yelp tip, I knew the brussels sprouts were the thing to get, and GOOD LORD were they right. My steak, good as it was, almost became second banana to these little savory vegetable treats. The sprouts are fried in duck fat, with anchovy and a red wine vinaigrette. Out-effing-standing. Everyone at the table couldn't stop eating them, and I almost thought we had to order another plate. 

I sampled everyone's food, and it was all fantastic. All, that is, except my brother's pork chop, which was a fatty mess. To make up for it, the waiter sent us over a couple of desserts. I was in full fatty mode scarfing down these sweet treats after I'd just eaten a mountain of appetizers and an entree. And other people's entrees. Don't judge me. 

This was an exquisite meal and if you're in the area, you've got to stop in for a bite. Make reservations; the waiting area fills up quickly.
author: Anthony A.

description:
Super good. Food was excellent, service was good, and options were plentiful.

Atmosphere: trendy, a bit fancy, but comfortable. 

Service: my best friend and I sat at the bar and it was actually nice (minus the wobbly chairs). We were served quickly which we both appreciated.

Food: After struggling with which option to pick because they all looked so good, I settled on the corn rigatoni and was not disappointed at all. The corn tasted crisp and fresh and the pasta was filling without being heavy. My friend got the burrata salad and she also liked it!

No complaints-I'd definitely come back!
author: Salma R.

description:
To start, this is Barbacco not to be confused with its sister restaurant Perbacco which is next door. Fortunately I only felt mildly stupid when I got the two mixed up. So pay attention, because an egg is a terrible thing to waste.

I have to say that the service was barely polite though very professional. Our server didn't seem to care if we were there or not and we had to flag him down a few times in order to get basics like drink refills and bread. Considering we were in a larger group he wasn't particularly helpful when it came to selecting dishes for our dining party to share. I just wish he was more engaged with us as I think it would have made our evening far more memorable. 

Being in a large party, who were all into sharing family style, gave us the ability to try a large swath of the menu. However the online menu is different than the menu you will actually order from. We were really there for the beef cheeks so imagine our horror when we noticed that they weren't present. Certainly not a deal killer but very disappointing. We did manage to order a ton of food and for writings sake Im going to feature my favorites. To be fair, there wasn't a single dish we didn't like. 

chickpeas - Scented with the robust smell of rosemary, these were cooked so well that they literally smeared into the ACME bread we were served, little did we know we should have rationed the bread out.

orecchiette - The pasta here is dynamite! Big chunks of sausage in a sauce made from cavolo nero, a type of leafy green related to kale, that reminded me of pesto. Lots of delicious green oil pooled at the bottom of the bowl, just wished we would have had more bread to sop it up with. 

chitarra - Thick al dente noodle awesomeness! This was the most favorite dish on the table. In fact the rich sauce and meaty balls had us almost ordering another one. Hearty, comforting and delicious.  

brussels sprouts fried in duck fat - What's not to love here except they were cold when they were brought out. But we were so enamored with the chitarra we just let it slide. If we visit again we will be sure to make sure they're piping hot when they hit the table. Anyways, the red wine vinegar added a nice pop of flavor that cut through some of the fatty rich flavor of the brussels, I love that kind of balance. 

As you can see I had a lot of love for the food here. The kitchen just rocked the dishes, 5 stars! I just wished our service experience matched the fantastic cookery.
author: Alexander C.

description: We ended up here late on the Wednesday before Xmas. Glad it's open until 10pm. Had nice decor and a lot of white people. Usually a foolproof sign the place is tight. Had the roasted octopus, lamb shank and orrechiete pasta. All were full of flavor and well-portioned. The vibe was chill and imitate at the same time. Prices were very reasonable for a nice place like this in the financial district. I would definitely return to try some of their other dishes or get the same dishes.
author: Gabe L.

description: Bruschetta apps followed by the risotto was to die for!
author: Shaun R.

description: Do you want to know what heaven in your mouth tastes like? Try the Lasagna at Barbacco in San Francisco! I was there a couple of weeks ago traveling for work and me and a few of my co-workers were starving and found this place! I was staying at Le Meridien and it was only a couple of blocks walking distance away so we went over! We walked in, sat at the bar (cute place) and were greeted by a very sweet woman with an Italian accent.  We all ordered separated dishes and shared appetizers. Seriously people, this was the BEST Italian food I've ever had! I usually don't like to go out for Italian because I feel like I make pretty good Italian at home but nothing I can make or have had at any other Italian restaurant compares to their Lasagna! SO GOOD!! The Brussel Sprouts were amazing too!! Me and my co-workers were still talking about how good our dinner was the next day! The next time I'm in San Francisco, I'm definitely going back to Barbacco!
author: Toia C.

description:
We went to Barbacco on a Thursday night at about 8pm and it was packed! We were told there would be a 45 minute wait and that they'd call us, but after an hour and a half without a call, we headed back and saw the line had cleared out. It was strange that they never gave us a call but we were quickly taken to the bar.

We ordered liver pate, brussel sprouts orecchiette and chittara with meatballs. The liver pate was great, I'm no connoisseur but the texture was great and there was a good balance with the bread. The brussel sprouts were so tasty! I usually hate brussel sprouts and I think these are the only kind I will eat! The balsamic glaze and duck fat makes them melt in your mouth. Too big for 2 people though since they are so rich you can't eat a whole lot. The chittara stole the show! The pasta was so tender and the meatballs were huge. Would highly recommend. We didn't even finish half of the orecchiette. It didn't have much flavor and the kale didn't help.

We finished the night with vanilla gelato and honeycomb which was just divine. We were pretty full so we split one scoop but the portion was generous and the honeycomb added just the right amount of crunch.

Would return and get the pate, chittara and gelato again!
author: Jane H.

description: Nice service and cannoli bean soup delicious! Fair corkage fee of $20. Roasted carrots good, good fish
author: B J.

description:
Pro tip: sit at the bar. I've been here many times, and have yet to sit anywhere else. For one bars are fun in general whether you're at a diner or a fancy after work happy hour. For two, while lovely, the tables at Barbacco are a little close together. You have less of a chance that someone else will overhear you spilling secrets to your BFF at the bar. 

I have yet to meet a small plate here I didn't like. The brussel sprouts - yum! The cheeses - great. The farro risotto - oh my. All the bruschette - holy crap yes. The polenta, the kale salad, the chick peas...I could go on and on, seeing as how I've tried everything vegetarian on their menu. 

Yes, they have wine, no, I know nothing about it other than there is sparkly rose which makes me quite happy. 

Service has always been nothing blow-my-mind-shout-from-the-roof-tops in either direction, which means kind and good in my book. 

Will be back.
author: Alicia O.

description:
Best. Customer. Service. Ever. Tried this and sister restaurant Perbacco. This was hands down the winner. Affordable tasty food, great staff, clean, approachable. Perbacco, although tasty, was too snobby for my taste. 

And the manager even came up to me and asked if I'd like to have my phone charged when he saw me holding my charger! Then I forgot my CC at the restaurant, he (Chad) emailed me to let me know that same night! I was already on my way back to LA and they mailed it to me with a cute note! Next time I'm in San Fran, going back for sure- they nailed gold ol' Italian 'everyone is family' hospitality.
author: Natalia R.

description:
Came here for dinner a couple weeks ago with my boyfriend.

The staff here are very nice and the restaurant was very trendy. The interior looked like it was supposed to be on that show "Bay Area Restaurants" or whatever it is.

I took a quick look at the menu and saw risotto and instantly knew what I wanted to order. Babe ordered the lasagna and the fingerling potatoes.

My risotto was extremely dry and unappetizing while babe's lasagna was okay. The fingerling potatoes were also okay.
author: Mabel Y.

description: So a buddy of mine totally raved about this place. I was thinking of a place to take a girl out to dinner and I came across here and he raved about how amazing it is. He basically made the decision for me. He couldn't stop talking about the meatballs for 2 days straight. So the girl I took ordered the meatballs and I tried it. Yeah I mean they were good, but I guess he hyped it so much I was waiting to have my mind blown. But again, they were really good. I ordered the fish special and it was not bad, kinda too lemony and tart. We also shared the Brussels sprouts, absolutely rich but good. Finally for dessert we had the warm maple cake. It wasn't very warm at all and it was ok. I enjoyed the mascarpone cream on the side. All in all our waitress's was awesome and the food was good.
author: Heather S.

description: Yesterday Perbacco and today Barbcacco! I enjoy Barbacco so much better for their excellent food! I love their Brussel Sprouts cooked in duck fat and Polpette meatballs in spicy tomato sauce - perfectly cooked, moist and full of flavor! Their Braised Chicken Thigh is also very juicy and tasty. Add a side salad for some healthy greens and you'll be pleasantly surprised to find it's made with kale, pomegranate seeds and some sort of grilled squash with a very light dressing.
