The only compliant I have about this place is their service both during take outs and when I eat there. The woman who confirms our order on the phone is usually rude and continues to be rude when we arrive. Yes, I know you're restaurant is busy for lunch and yes, we know our order is big and yes, we know you might not have everything in stock and yes, we know it works better if we order the day before but we don't work that way so either obligingly take our order or send us somewhere else because we do submit the order before your lunch crowd just as we do daily at other restaurants in the area. This is the only restaurant that complains about our orders. When dining there, the service isn't as attentive as I'd like but it's not horrible. I'm really glad they remodeled the place awhile back as the seating is much better now.
author: Jen L.

description:
Barbacco is one of my favorite places to go for a nice lunch with friends or a work lunch. Also a great place for dinner but have mostly been here for lunch. The food is SO good. Whenever I have come for lunch, I have shared dishes with the folks I am with and I think that's the best way to get the most out of this place. And it's very reasonable for the quality and quantity of food!

I am listing my favorites:
Bruschetta - have had all of them and all of them are DELICIOUS
Hearts of Romaine - absolutely delicious salad!
Arugula and Radicchio - YUM
Porchetta sandwich is great to share!
Lasagna is amazing - again, great to share
Paccheri is very good - very filling and great portions
Orchiette is interesting and delicious
Polpette - wonderful!
Fried Brussels Sprouts - get two, heck get three orders   SO good!
Roasted cauliflower - SO, SO good!

One downside - when the restaurant is full, it is rather loud (as is the case with a lot of place these days...or am I just getting old?  )
author: P M.

description:
Food was okay here...wasn't fabulous and wasn't terrible.  Most of it lacked flavor and some of it had to be reheated.  Farrotto, meatballs, meat & cheese plates, burrata salad, squid and brussel sprouts filled our table.  Cheese selections were so tasty.  Meat selections were chefs choice and mediocre.  The rest of the dishes were good but nothing outstanding.  

Service was good.  At first, our server was on it but as the restaurant filled up he became less and less a tune to our needs.  Sometimes it's mgmt who doesn't want to hire more servers but it might be helpful.  Who knows, perhaps someone didn't show for work.  

I don't know that I would return.  Too many other places to go try that might be better.  

Happy eating!
author: Bojangles O.

description: I'd heard great things about this place so decided to stop in while visiting SF for work. We arrived at around 6:00pm on Wednesday and immediately found two seats at the counter. Really cool atmosphere, hip, loud I liked it. We started with a great bottle of wine and the octopus which was served with radishes and cilantro. The octopus was meaty and tender and cooked really well. For our meals I had the bucatini upon recommendation from the waitress, my boss had the lasagna and we split the meatballs. Bucatini was definitely good, noodles were cooked well but didn't blow me away. My boss really enjoyed his lasagna but the absolute hit were the meatballs. Three incredibly large, tender amazing meatballs. I highly recommend getting these with your meals at least once. If you're in the financial district for dinner I highly recommend Barbacco for a tasty Italian meal and I'll be back to check out some other pastas.
author: Aryn C.

description:
Half a year since my first visit to Barbacco, I'm still loving the food here. Great atmosphere and great food. Their Brussel Sprouts Fried in Duck Fat is still a dish I order each time. However, the last few visits has been a bit less than perfect. At least, I felt like there's something more to work on in terms of service. Perhaps the restaurant is THAT busy, I find the wait time between ordering the food and food delivery to have lengthened by quite a bit. Perhaps it may be the food we order for appetizers that take longer than usual to prepare, I seem to find my eyes wandering to the kitchen more often than before.

Nonetheless, their menu still calls me back every so often. I've tried quite a few of their dishes. I missed their little jars of mixed mushrooms, but I found a new favorite appetizer: suppli. These croquettes are extremely hot when they were served. Fresh out of the fryer, its outer layer is very crispy and not burnt, creamy mushroom risotto to balance out the crunchy texture, and with a good sized of mozzarella cheese melted in the center. I can tell you, one is not enough. You can definitely share it with your table, but I guarantee that you will want more.

If you're a fan of sashimi, perhaps you can try their Pesce Crudo. It's a small dish with marinated raw fish and other fruit pieces. I would say it's pretty standard. It's nothing too exciting, but this dish is a little beauty.

If you're coming with a party of 4 or more, think about splitting their chef's choice of salumi. There's a little bit of everything. It's a great finger food plate that doesn't have a long wait time.

In my last visit, I've tried their daily special of a Ciopinno, a seafood stew with mussels, shrimps, fish, and squids. It's very rich in flavor, but not extremely thick in texture. Be assure that the stew does not mask the flavors of the seafood, but does the opposite. Compared to my swordfish, I love how soft and sweet the fish was in the stew. And by sweet, I mean that unique seafood sweetness, not your white sugar sweetness. I'd love to see this on their regular menu.

As for dessert, their Espresso Panna Cotta is a decently sized dessert for $5. It's not extremely sweet. Something you cannot go wrong with especially if you can't decide on a coffee or a dessert. Why not both? If you're not a fan of pudding, you can always opt for their gelato. I've had their Vanilla Gelato with Valhrona Chocolate Sauce. You can't go wrong with vanilla, it's not extremely sweet, but you can smell the vanilla essence seeping into the roof of your mouth. With a bit of salted chocolate syrup that is more of the dark and bitter side, the sweetness of vanilla is not too overwhelming. 

If you're a big chocolate lover, you should try their Chocolate Nemesis Cake. I do recommend you to share. It is quite... chocolately...
author: Connie C.

description:
We came as a party of 4. My cousins were in town, so we decided to give this place a try. As we waited for our table, we enjoyed a bottle of red that was recommended by the hostess. Shortly after having a few sips of our wine, our table was ready. The dishes that we ordered:

1. Brussel sprouts fried in duck fat-this was surprisingly a bit too salty, less salt please!
2. Duck liver pate with basalmic marmellata-yum! 
3. Crosotone with burrata cheese and marinated artichokes-loved the the crosotone
4. Ravioli and peas with tomato sauce (special)-this pasta was a bit bland for us
5. Mussels with garlic, lemon, leeks with white wine sauce-great flavors, loved it
6. Flat iron steak tagliata on top of cabbage-great taste and flavors, perfectly cooked
7. Suppli-mushroo risotto croquettes with truffled mozzarella-loved the texture and taste of this!
8. Gelato in torrone-great taste, can't say no to gelato
9. Gelato in butter-scotch chocolate crunch-can't say no to gelato
10. Expresso panna cotta-absolutely loved

We enjoyed the meal very much! The staff and service was very friendly and provided great service!
author: Jennifer G.H. W.

description:
Perbacco is one of my favorite restaurants in the city but we were looking for something more casual and less expensive so tried Barbacco. I had a reservation so was surprised to see my friend at the counter when I got there. He said that's it even with a rez. I thought a table would be quieter to catch up with my friend. But frankly the restaurant is so loud, it probably didn't matter.It's definitely a scene here!

We shared a few plates. The octopus was amazing. Just a great combo of tastes with the squid ink. My friend had the cod fritters. I'm not a big fan of cod but he said they were really good. The crust was crunchy and not greasy at all. The beef stew was very rich and again really good although a little spicier than I thought it would be. I'd order again if they could tone it down a little. The orecchiette was very tasty although I would have liked a little bigger pieces of sausage. Pasta was cooked perfectly.  Clearly both Perbacco and Barbacco know how to do pasta right.

Was a  little disappointed they didn't have rose' by the glass. It would have been really nice with the warm weather. Food came out fast and service was good. As others mentioned, very difficult to carry on a conversation though.  I'd deal with it though for the food at decent prices.

Street parking was easy with free meters after 6pm. Financial District pretty much closes down after work.
author: Stacey R.

description: Great unique Italian dishes! Not the same boring stuff.. would have received 5 stars if they had another bathroom for men and a little better service.
author: V R.

description:
Great ambiance, nice wine list, attentive service, fantastic prices. What's not to like about Barbacco?

A friend and I came by for dinner recently. Started off with the burrata cheese on a bed of greens and crostinis which did not disappoint. I immediately wanted more. We also had the Brussels sprouts which were also another good starter dish. I had the corn rigatoni with butternut squash which wasn't lacking in the taste department, and surprisingly is gluten free. 

Being in the location it's in, their menu was fairly economically priced. If my office was closer I'd definitely be a regular here for lunch.
author: Esther A.

description:
Small bites, great ambiance, and wine tastes to take for a really nice night out with light yet tasty meals. Really good dishes with a great mood to be in for a nice date or catch up with an old friend. 

Great dishes to share across the board. I especially remember the brussels sprout chips and a dish of salumi. 

A fabulous place to visit and highly recommended.
author: Joseph L.

description:
3 1/2 

I had no reservation as I did not know what time my SF meeting would be done. Although a weeknight and (still) raining, they fond me a seat. Yes, in a corner, but under the circumstances can't complain; it was packed. 

Restaurant is more shaped like a bar, long and narrow. I almost walked into the mirror before realizing it was not a really really long room.

OK, started with Barbacco Punch, pomegranate, apple, orange, lime, prosecco. Mild and sweet (unlike me!) and the kale/roasted squash salad. Salad also had apples and pomegranate so they matched, which is why I picked the drink. Salad fresh, good dressing, perhaps could have used a bit more of the squash. Asked for Acme bread with salad, but I was nearly done with salad when it arrived. Small demerit.

Then got rigatoni with lamb sugo. Pasta correctly al dente, nice tasty sauce, portion good size as in enough to fill but not stuff. For dessert had the milk chocolate concoction - not on the on-line menu so not sure what it's called. A mousse-like (but more solid than most mousse) square with whipped cream, a chocolate crunch "crust" surrounding it. All good. They added, however, candied rye berries and kumquat syrup which did not add anything. The syrup was too sweet. The berries a distraction. But the chocolate part was really good. 

Summary: Good but not stupendous food, reasonable price for SF, noisy high energy place. Good for a convivial outing, not a place to hold a meeting or to unwind. Not a knock, just a fact. Considering how packed it was service pretty good, quick at least. 

I might return although not on my priority list.
author: Carol S.

description:
What's up with all the hype?? Food quality and taste at this place are embarrassingly average. We ordered a bunch of appetizers and several different entrees - so incredibly underwhelming that I think the chief had to try hard to cook up something so bland.

All is all, not worth spending your hard earned money on (honestly not even on company's money)
author: Alan N.

description:
Been back here a few times, about 2 or so years ago they seems to have discontinued their lasagna which was to die for and NOW it's BACK! And they redesigned the place (I guess I haven't been since about 2 years ago)...

Either way, I love this place again! It feels a lot more comfortable at the regular tables to me. Lasagna is back. Services is excellent. We went there last week for a team celebration lunch for my anniversary with my company and the waitress even got us/me a treat at the end of our meal! IT was so nice of them to do that (flour less chocolate cake, OMG, I'm def getting that next time I'm there)

If you havent been in a while, I suggest you go back! If you have never been, now it's the time to go and try them!

Everything we ate was delicious! No one complained at my table that's for sure.
author: Denise V.

description:
I really liked this place! the ambiance is trendy, our waitress was fun and helpful, and food was delicious! 

fried brussel sprouts (5/5) - if there's one thing on the menu you have to get, it's definitely this!! I mean how could anything fried in duck fat not be good? I normally hate brussel sprouts, so if you do too, don't worry - they don't taste anything like them. they're crispy and tender with a saltiness that isn't too overpowering. 

minestra soup (3/5) - was just ok. it wasn't bad, but not really worth the $6 in my opinion.

pork ragu (4/5) - I liked this, but I thought the pasta itself was a bit undercooked. the sauce was delicious though!

mushroom farro risotto (5/5) - loved this! so much mushroom flavor and the texture of the farro was perfect! 

bruschette (5/5) - omg how could I almost forget about this! these were so good. my favorite was chicken liver pate, but the pear & prosciutto and anchovy & hummus (didn't taste like anchovy at all) were amazing too. they don't skimp you on the amount of spread/meat on the bread either!

fudge hazelnut gelato (2/5) - I don't know what happened with this one, but the ice cream didn't have much flavor and the texture was icy. it wasn't even creamy enough to be "ice cream". meh. 

butterscotch gelato (5/5) - on the other hand, this gelato was rich and creamy as it should be and the butterscotch flavor was really yummy.
author: Stephanie G.

description: Excellent food and service. Had very good beef tartare, a delicious, perfectly prepared pasta dish with pasta stuffed with beef rib meat, and very good cabernet. Good service too. However, it was very loud and crowded, and exceedingly expensive. I'm not sure I would go back if I were paying.
author: Josh Y.

description:
This review is based on our experience at the bar only:

Showed up around 7 PM before our dinner reservation at Michael Mina, which is a few doors up.

My friend, Ryan, is a big basketball fan so throughout our drive into SF, he kept eyeing every bar that had a visible TV to check out the scores of the Warriors vs. Cavaliers game.  Although he was visiting from Oahu, at least he was rooting for the Warriors!

So, being the wonderful friend that I am, I told him we could watch the game at a bar before our dinner.  That's how we ended up at Barbacco.  Upon entering, we were greeted by two hostesses, one was a younger girl who was probably new or on training because she seemed to have to ask the other lady (she might be the manager since she was pretty much everywhere) for clarifications on quite a few things.

We were told that we couldn't sit at the bar if we weren't ordering any food...but we already had dinner reservation so it wouldn't make any sense for us to eat right before our meal.  But the "manager" told us that she would make an exception just for us, which was very sweet of her.

Ryan had a glass of red wine while I had my delicious Sprite.  The bartender asked us if we wanted to order any food, but we told him we were fine with just our drinks so he didn't seem very happy with us at all.

Honestly, this place has a really nice feel to it.  The bar looked clean and immaculate.  Loved the way they have all the wine glasses nicely laid out.  If you're a beer or wine drinker, you're in great hands because that's all they serve at the bar.  If you're a cocktail drinker, you'll have to look elsewhere...

But now that we both know what the food at Michael Mina tastes like, we should've just stayed and had dinner at Barbacco instead.  We would've been able to watch the remainder of the game instead of just half time.  I'm sure Ryan would love to the beat the crap out of me, if he were reading this review.  LOL
author: Sivilay T.

description:
Barbacco is a modern and trendy restaurant located in the FiDi.  If you come during lunch, make sure you have reservations or arrive early cause by 12:00 p.m., you'll be waiting a while.  

We ordered:

Chicken Salad Sandwich ($11) - Poached chicken salad drizzled with lemon vinaigrette served on ACME bread.  The portion was generous and tasty according to one of my team member's. 

Farrotto ($13) - farro "risotto" / roasted mushrooms / spinach / parmigiano reggiano - I asked the waiter to skip the parmesan since I'm not big on cheese.  IMO, the risotto was delicious even though the pamesan was omitted. It was less creamy, but the texture was still good.  Plus, I didn't leave feeling sick to my stomach as the cheese usually makes it very rich.

Paccheri ($13) / rustic pork ragu / parmigiano reggiano - Two of my colleagues ordered this and they both seemed to enjoy it as their plate was spotless.  

Corn Rigatoni ($14) (gluten free) / cannellini beans / radicchio / bacon / parmigiano reggiano - My co-worker who is even pickier than I am when it comes to eating enjoyed this dish.  I asked if he was able to taste the radicchio and he said the bacon overpowered it, which was a plus in his book!

Dessert

Espresso panna cotta / chocolate toffee ($5) - Very strong espresso taste and creamy, which I like.  My only grip is it was a bit too sweet. 

Coffee ($2) - My manager ordered the coffee and said it was really good. 

I've only visited Barbacco for lunch, but the food has consistently been on par each time. The only complaint one of my co-worker's and I had was the service was super slow the day we visited. The food took forever to come out.  Had their service been quicker, they wouldn't have had to turn away customers.
author: Candice H.

description:
This experience was just OK - nothing special at all for a nice sit-down restaurant in the financial district. 

Forget the food, the service we received was way below-par. To start out, my friend and I had a couple questions about the vegetarian dishes on the menu and the waiter gave us less than ideal answers to any of our questions; instead, he sounded very uninterested and annoyed. Finally after about 10 minutes of asking questions that we weren't getting proper responses to, we ended up ordering some food and drinks. 

Our drinks came out and one of them was wrong so we told the waiter and in the meanest tone, he exclaimed to us that we had said the wrong drink to him so it wasn't his fault. I was shocked! In a semi-formal restaurant setting like this, I have never been treated like this. 

All these experiences in the beginning definitely put off the experience for me but when the food came out, I was willing to give it a try!

We ordered the asparagus bruschetta, brussel sprouts, arugula and radicchio salad, and the soup of the day which was a cauliflower cream soup. My favorites were the bruschetta and brussel sprouts but they were also just ok - nothing was extremely special. The salad had wayyy too much salt and the soup was wayy too heavy and didn't have enough salt! One of my friends got the meatballs and he said they were pretty good so maybe this place is better for their meat?

Food: 3 stars
Service: -1 star

I will probably not be back again unfortunately :(
author: Malika R.

description:
Are you telling me that it's not always necessary to feast on an entire menu when I go to a restaurant? That I could just fast forward to dessert and wine, skipping the protein and vegetables? 

To quote Elaine Benes, "get out!"

Having eaten alright sushi at a joint nearby that didn't have any desserts, my friend and I just beat the buzzer and got to Barbacco before they closed at 10pm. The idea of using a restaurant for a dessert felt a little risque and naughty, but I was intrigued, wondering if this is what adults do. Am I an adult now? Ugh. I entered Barbacco timidly and was upfront with the host that I only wanted a sweet nothing and a glass of wine. I closed my eyes in suspense and when I opened them I was sitting at the bar in front of an iPad wine menu. Phew-that didn''t hurt a bit. 

My pal had been raving about the espresso panna cotta, and she was right to do so. It was perfectly light, with just a hint of java, and a dollop of feather weight whipped cream. On the richer and lascivious end of the spectrum, we ordered the butterscotch-chocolate crunch gelato, which was so good that I thought I might need a safe word. In the spirit of Portlandia, I would suggest screaming 'cacao' when you taste this, even if you have never seen it. Everyone will think that you're just crazy for the chocolate.

The adult drink menu is digitized on a very adult toy-the iPad. Even though my fingers were covered in sugar they let me use it. The wine is obviously Euro-centric, but I kept scrolling down for a California Zin from Poco a Poco. Pours are generous, especially at the end of the night. Cacao.

The cost of this tryst was so reasonable-I'd say just above the cheap thrill threshold, but far more tasteful and tasty.  I'm savoring my memories of this delightful dessert, but I can't wait to return for a full meal-no restraints.
author: Joanna M.

description: Good place for California cuisine at lunch time for financial district area.  Good serving portion and prices.
author: Bennie B.

description: I went to Barbacco with a group of 4. We made a reservation, but they couldn't seat us on time. They apologized multiple times, but I don't think we waited more than 20 minutes after our reservation time. We ordered the bruschetta, roasted eggplant, fried brussel sprouts, orecchiette, farrotto, and the Tuscan beef stew. Our least favorite was the stew because the beef was a bit tough, but it was still flavorful. Everything else was delicious. I highly recommend this restaurant.
author: Kyla K.

description:
Hey paisan!... The secret to eating great Italian food in San Francisco is making sure you dine with a true Italian who knows the food of her roots. I was already a fan of Barbacco from my previous visit, but I really enjoyed the food this time thanks to my Italiano friend Linda who joined me for lunch there over the holidays. Since Barbacco is still very communal in approach given its rural Ligurian inspiration, we were seated in the busy counter area in the middle and had three dishes - all stellar and probably none I would have ordered on my own due to my own ignorance.

We started with the $10 Local Squid with 'nduja. Yeah, I didn't know what 'nduja was either until Linda explained that it's a special smoked pork salami from Calabria, the boot tip of Italy that looks like it's kicking Sicily. The salami is spicy with red peppers minced with shoulder and belly parts, sorta like an Italian version of an Andouille, and it's stuffed into the calamari pieces, then sauteed in bread crumbs (grattato) and accompanied by rucola greens (see photo). Delicioso! This was followed by a smashing pasta called Paccheri.

Yeah, I've never heard of paccheri either but it immediately became one of my favorites because it's the large, tube-shaped pasta that's much bigger than rigatoni and prepared al dente. The consistency was just right to take in the rustic pork ragu sauce and parmigiano reggiano shavings (see photo). So tasty and a fair bargain for $12  for the quality despite its simplicity. We wanted to see how full our bellies were before plowing into the third dish, a lovely $14 entree of Braised Chicken Thighs served with Creamy Polenta, Braised Broccoli Rabe and Garlic Confit (see photo).

I bake thighs at home all the time but never this tender and certainly not with such luxuriant polenta on the side. The broccoli rabe and garlic provides just the right textural contrast to the meltiness of the chicken and polenta. We were three for three and most pleased with ourselves. Best of all, I've made a fan out of Linda who had never been to Barbacco before. Once again, the friendly servers at Barbacco never make you feel rushed. Just watch out for the flying elbows that may come your way from the Nob Hill matron seated next to you as she reshuffles her purse. Hey lady!

FOOD - 5 stars...a move up to the five-star echelon due to insider insight on the art of rustic Italian food
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...still a-bustling thanks to all the great, reasonably priced menu
SERVICE - 4.5 stars...the servers have always been top-notch here
TOTAL - 5 stars...just call me paisan!
author: Ed U.

description:
the Paccheri is soooo on point! 

if you order the bruschette that comes with 3, you can get 3 diff ones. The roasted pepper and anchovy one was good! 

Lunch prices were really reasonable! $15 for the Paccheri pasta (the best! al dente pasta) Also tried the lasagna (was good, different with spinach noodles), the orecchiette (a little salty) and got a butcher salad (it's ok), the bruschette (good), and pro tip! ask for acme bread! Comes with olive oil and balsamic vinegar. YUM! So satisfied.
author: Joanna S.

description:
I had a perfect meal tonight here. Ambiance is both casual and trendy. The server was highly knowledgeable with the dishes and wine which was a ++++! 

Every dish was impeccable and I loved the Brussels sprouts
author: Sarah K.

description:
June 2013 - When I first starting working in SF, my new boss and the man who was leaving the position I was about to take over to head to law school, took me here for lunch.  They both had been to Barbacco numerous times before and, consequently, already knew what they wanted to order the moment we were seated.  As the new recruit, I perused the menu with TWO criteria in mind:

1) It had to be something I could pronounce properly - I did NOT wanna look like a complete fool on my VERY FIRST DAY

2) I know that dishes can vary from restaurant to restaurant, so I had to get something fairly standard, something that nobody could put too many fancy schmancy (read: ultimately gross/unpalatable) spins on without creating something new altogether.  Again, I'm was the new girl on the block, and would likely have to sit and finish most of what was on my plate with a SMILE on my face.  Didn't want to make that a more Herculean task than it could already potentially be.

And so I went for the "lasagna bolognese - spinach pasta meat ragu / bescimella sauce," but of course, I just told our waitress that I wanted "lasagna" because "bolognese" was about 75% and, well, they completely lost me at "bescimella."

My boss ordered a salad and my coworker ordered the porchetta sandwich.  (Side note - Funny enough, the porchetta sandwich became my "go-to" order.  I got it when I went to lunch with my dad a few months later, and with my friend at the beginning of this year.  SOLID!).  But before our waitress left, they looked at one another and nodded.  I was *just a little* jelly that they seemed to have, like, ESPN or something (Mean Girls!), but I was struck with actual terror when my boss added on an order of brussels sprouts.  

What the what?

My dad loves brussels sprouts and while my mom doesn't LOVE them, she's the kind of Asian mom that enjoys eating bitter melon so the little green veggies are nothing to her.  But for me... dear, sweet, merciful Lord in Heaven whyyy would you create something that not only tastes bitter, but SMELLS bitter while cooking, too?  

I was all smiles on the outside, but on the inside, I began to try and calm my nerves by telling myself that I only had to take maybe one or two of them to be polite.  Chew and swallow.  Chew and swallow.  Chew and swallow.  Oh gosh, my water glass is only 1/3 full!

When the waitress came around with the brussels sprouts, I tried my best not to stare at them the way a woman will normally stare at her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend up in da club.  But I couldn't help it.

They, of course, offered some to me first and stared expectantly, completely unaware of allthefeeeeelings inside of me.

I cut the little sprout in two and raised it tentatively to my lips.  I slowly began to chew it, put my fork down and began to reach for water to wash down the bloom of bitterness, but...

Nothing.  

I finished chewing the half and then popped a second one in with much less hesitation.  Were these specially raised or something?  

My boss asked me if I liked it and I nodded my head, still pondering how different this experience with brussels sprouts was from any I had had before it.  "Isn't it great the way they fry it in DUCK FAT."

O_O!

The only poem I can recite from memory is Robert Frost's "The Road Not Taken."  My 6th grade CORE teacher would be so proud.  Props to you, Ms. Anthony!

Anyway, in the final stanza he talks about how taking the road less traveled by made all the difference.  Well, i'd like to say yes to that, and to DUCK FAT.  

I now wonder how many other things duck fat can make the difference with.  ;)
author: Iona C.

description:
I'm kind of torn.  The restaurant and decor is cute, sleek, and modern.  Service was great and very helpful.  Food was cheaper than I thought it would be.  Apps were great.  However, pasta entrees were sub par to me.  A group of 5 ordered 2 of each of the below apps:

Daily Special Pesce Crudo - ours was hamachi, which I love.  Super good and no complaints.

Crostone w/ Burrata - love burrata and they give you a ton.  Delicious and a must-try.

Kale Salad - fresh and no complaints.  It's a kale salad though so doesn't pop out to me.

I ordered the popular orecchiette.  Other people ordered the lasagna, pacheri, and mussels.  Everyone agreed that their pasta was average but I heard the mussels were good.  Maybe if I go again, I'll stick to just their apps or try their meat/seafood entrees.
author: Jane N.

description:
I love the bruchettas here. The pastas have also been consistently unique and tasty. 

and OH YES you have to get the brussel sprouts. brussel sprouts fried in duck fat.. definitely defeats the purpose of ordering such a healthy vegetable but it tastes amazing! My boyfriend normally loves brussel sprouts, and he was the only one not too happy with these. They no longer taste much like brussel sprouts =P Oh well, the rest of the world loves them!
author: Annie Z.

description:
Barbacco is one of my all-time favorite southern Italian restaurants in San Francisco.  The atmosphere is lively and hip without being too scene-y and the food and wine are great values.  They are also done family-style, so you're able to try a number of dishes on the menu without ending up too full.  I have been coming here since 2010 and have always had a good experience.  

Last night I went with a few coworkers, and we were wowed once again.  We ordered the roasted beets, sweet summer corn, marinated olives, roasted peaches bruschette, tuscan chicken liver pate bruschette, roasted hen of the woods mushroom bruschette, burratta cheese salad, paccheri pork ragu, chitarra, flat iron steak and brussels sprouts, along with a bottle each of the Nebbiolo and the Grifola (two Italian reds).

My personal favorite is the pork ragu.  The pasta tubes are expertly done, chewy and eggy, and the ragu complements the dish well.  The surprise at the table was the brussels sprouts, which are fried to a crisp in duck fat then seasoned with red wine vinegar.  I order both of these dishes every time I go and am always impressed.  

The bruschette are also worth mentioning.  The bread was chewy and crunchy without being too hard to eat with each of the toppings.  My favorite were the roasted hen of the woods mushrooms, which were earthy, chewy, and plentifully stacked on top of the bread.  The tuscan chicken liver was also delicious.

Overall, this is an awesome place to bring people in San Francisco.  Be sure to call ahead to book a reservation to avoid having to wait a long time.
author: Gen W.

description:
Barbacco, for me, was definitely in the 3-star zone. It wasn't spectacular yet it wasn't a disastrous meal or experience. We recently went in on a Saturday night for a late-ish dinner: around 9ish. It was nearly full, but it wasn't unpleasantly busy. The hostess was friendly and told us our table was almost ready. We waited a couple minutes and she escorted us toward the back of this narrow restaurant. As my friends and I walked to our table, I noticed an expansive and long bar area. The overall decor was fine; nothing was particularly outstanding. The choice of music throughout the night was "interesting" to say the least. It was a mishmash of disco, R&B, pop, and then the "Game of Thrones" theme song played... (My friend: "Wait is this...?" *listening* "It's the 'Game of Thrones' theme song!" Me: "Ohhh..." *shrugs*) 

Anyway, it took several minutes until our server greeted us and then it took awhile until he came back to take our order. I'm not sure if he was the only server in that section (which didn't look too busy), but he seemed to be MIA at times. On to the food: the kale salad is highly recommended. I loved the golden raisins and almonds added in for texture and bite ($8). We also ordered an antipasti plate of marinated asparagus ($5). My friends said they enjoyed that; it was fresh and bright thanks to the meyer lemon. I ordered the chitarra ($14) which was good, but some flavors didn't seem to pair well together. The pasta had meat balls, pine nuts, raisins, chard, and a spicy tomato sugo. The spiciness, for some reason, wasn't doing it for me. The heat didn't seem to fit with the other components and while I still enjoyed it overall, I probably wouldn't order it again. My friend ordered farrotto ($14) which was a farro "risotto" (so instead of Arborio rice, they used farro). It had spinach, parmigiano reggiano, and roasted mushrooms. This is a very filling dish and between my two friends (a couple), they couldn't finish it. We also ordered a side of brussels sprouts ($5) which were pretty good. It was fried in duck fat and had capers, anchovy, and red wine vinaigrette. I personally liked them a little charred as did one of my friends. Another friend with us didn't care for the preparation. My friends ordered dessert which was a chocolate polenta cake ($6). Flavor-wise, they liked it. In terms of the texture, my friend noted it was moist on one side and then dry on the other side. I'm not sure if they spoon syrup over the batter to keep it moist -- so perhaps that was an underprepared area... or was it over- or unevenly baked? Who knows? In either case, they were a little disappointed, but not repulsed. 

Overall, our experience at Barbacco was decent. I was hoping for something a bit more inspiring or memorable, but luckily, this wasn't a bad experience either.
author: James Z.

description: I don't know how this restaurant was rated 4 star. Food was below average, service was mediocre, and the ambiance was awful.
author: Nick Z.

description: Impeccable service. Menu is 4 star. We all had a different pasta. I had the 5-hour pork sauce. It was amazing.
author: Early L.

description: Every dish was delicious! But, the best dish by far was the Lumache. It's red wine pasta with braised lamb shoulder and castelvetrano olives. Oh my!
author: Alexandra S.

description:
This place is solid.  The service was impeccable and efficient.  Many people helped us with water, wine, food, clearing plates, getting the bill, etc.  There is a real team effort here!  The service is really outstanding.

We had the chicken liver and anchovy bruschette.  Both were ok.  The brussel sprouts were amazing - better than most.  The orecchiette was just ok - I'd stick to the pork ragu next time (the pork was so tasty and cooked perfectly!).  The chocolate polenta cake replaced the nemesis cake and it was not that great but I'm glad it was priced correctly at $5.  

We had the cab on tap, the Nebuchadnezzar, and it was pretty good.  I would definitely recommend this place to anyone and will come back soon!
author: Chris L.

description:
FiDi is an odd area on the weekend. It feels pretty ghost-town-ish around 6 pm, even though there's plenty going on. And of course, there are nice restaurant gems like Barbacco that make it worth your while to come in on a Saturday.

Came here as a party of six for a friend's birthday. It's a chic but casual setting, perfect for a get-together with a few friends. 

And the food is very delicious. As an appetizer, we shared the roasted octopus (delicious), brussels sprouts (again, delicious), and an artichoke that I believe was on the special regional menu (which, on our visit, was dedicated to Lazio, which encompasses Rome). 

But dinner was where it was really happening. Everything was fully enjoyable -- and felt like you got your money's worth. I had the arrabbiatta, which was on the special menu, and I loved it. I had a very hearty portion. I tried a bit of my friend's corn rigatoni -- and while I liked it, I was glad i ordered the arrabbiata. Other friends ordered the steak, the meatballs, and the fish of the day, and had only great things to say. 

After "carbing up," I wasn't ready for dessert, so I stuck with a cup of coffee (which was good). Other friends enjoyed the gelato and affogatos. And, they came out with a very nice birthday dessert for my friend - nice touch :)

Other notes:

Servers were well informed, attentive, and very willing to answer questions.

The valets are friendly, and IIRC it wasn't all that expensive (but it's worth your while).

I really liked coming here. I will definitely keep this spot in mind if and when I find myself in the  Financial District in the future.
author: Tami S.

description:
Barbacco offers a lot on their menu from vegetarian options to pastas to meat dishes.  Since we had a varied group of diners with different needs, we ordered some veggie friendly options like the risotto croquettes and non meat bruschetta along with some meat dishes like the orechiette with the fennel sausage in there.  This place almost implies that your group shares family style.  I don't know any Italian place that doesn't do family style except maybe the Olive Garden.  

The service was great first of all although our food did take a bit longer than I liked.  The server was attentive and took our appetizer and main dish orders in a staggered fashion thus the delay.  When choosing and ordering things in a group, sometimes it takes extreme measures to get everyone to have an opinion and agree on a few things as they sip their wine and drink from their pint of beer.

Despite us having a very late reservation, the staff did not give us the subtle hints for us to skee-daddle out of there.  Other than being a restaurant without a bar, Barbacco definitely satisfied all of my Italian food needs.  The food wasn't exactly bargain priced but it was worth the price to pay.  I definitely wouldn't mind coming back.
author: Ben H L.

description:
Really good food. 

We popped in here right after work with low expectations - but let me tell you, the buratta appetizer wow-ed us. It was SUPER delicious. My pasta was simple and predictable, but that appetizer pleased our most difficult critics.

We sat sort of at the bar (?) and it was fine service / atmosphere. Decent for colleagues.
author: Stephanie M.

description: Stumbled upon Barbacco on a business trip and it's my best dinner in SF yet! Enjoyed the Tometta Cremosa di Pecora Carletta to start which was perfect with its touches of honey. Followed up by the Farrotto which was recommended by the waiter and also delicious! This place was packed on a Tuesday night so make sure you have reservations.
author: Becky M.

description:
A great place to grab dinner while in the financial district on a weeknight. Was able to snag a 5:45pm reservation an hour before via opentable. Ambiance is nice and it's not too dark. There is no bar here, just FYI.

Food is good and very reasonably priced given the location. Bowl of pasta for dinner, which is dinner portion, ranges from $12-$15 which isn't bad at all. Doesn't Olive Garden charge more?

The meat dishes are a little pricier, and definitely would not fill someone up on that dish alone.

Got the burrata salad which was phenomenal. The burrata was fresh and sad on a bed of arugla. Came with four pieces of bread which were decently sized. Also came with olive tapenade (I don't like olives in general); sun dried tomato mixture and confit garlic. It was all delicious. 

The spaghetti with mussels and nduja was GREAT. There was a good amount of mussels and it was spicy. We also asked for some bread so we can slop up the sauce afterwards. There was a good amount of savory-umami-ness to the pasta bowl, and the mussels were fresh and cooked perfect.

Spicy spaghetti and meatballs, it really is spicy! If you need a kick, it's here. Although my friend did say "oh it's spicy?" It comes with two giant meatballs which was cooked perfectly and had good dimension of flavors.
author: Vanessa K.

description:
Ate here for a work lunch. We chose to eat at the bar because my coworkers previous experience was that the tables were to spacious and since the restaurant was busy during lunch it was also loud. You ended up having to inch over the long table to try to hear each other during the meal. 
But the food was good. Waiters were attentive. Kale salad here is d'bomb!
author: Julianna I.

description:
Overall good experience with this hip place in the Financial District.  I've been here a couple of times on weeknights; it's always busy.  Reservation is highly recommended.

I had the ox tail stew for entree and bruschetta for appetizer.  I liked both dishes for the portion and flavor.  On another visit, I had the meatball and grilled vegetable.  The meatball and sauce were tasty, but the grilled vegetable (optional side order) was pre-grilled and a bit wilted.
 
The service very attentive; the atmosphere was lively....a little difficult to carry on a conversation. If you are driving there, try to get a 6pm or 7pm reservation as the commute lanes become available for evening parking within one block of the restaurant.
author: Jean T.

description:
I was looking for a good restaurant for our party of four to indulge in before our comedy show at the Punchline nearby without breaking the bank.  Barbacco fit the bill perfectly.  All four of us shared samples of our dishes with each other.

We ordered a full carafe of wine they had on tap.  It was a grenache of some sort- fruity but not sweet.  It had a unique and refreshing finish in addition to being reasonably priced at $42.  It comes room temperature, but they gladly brought an ice bucket to our table to chill it.

For dinner we ordered:

Petrale Sole Special - lightly seasoned, fresh and healthy

(2) lasagnas -  This was full of fresh Italian flavors, delectable and bittersweet taking the last bite.

Roasted Cauliflower - Yummy, yummy...simple and tasty

Roasted Sprouts - This was quite a hit with the duck fat it was cooked with.  I made sure there was no leaf left on the plate!

Butternut Squash - The balsamic was a nice accent to the sweetness-very soft and savory.

Potato Leek was soup of the day.  It was creamy with a hint of sweet- very tasty.

The Cannelli Bean Maestra soup was similar to one that I make minus the carrots and celery.  This one was hearty with nuances of fresh flavors.  I will add carrots and celery to my soup from now on!

For dessert, we shared the butterscotch chocolate crunch which had heavy chocolate and butterscotch flavors.  It was heaven in a bowl and not too rich.   The egg nog panna cotta was my choice and totally satisfying.  I prefer desserts more on the light side.  This did not disappoint with some blueberries sprinkled on top.

Of course, I have to mention the excellent service.   Our server was on point, friendly and a great attitude.  Other restaurant staff was attentive to us as well in clearing our plates and pouring our wine.  Everyone here was so kind and polite.  The atmosphere couldn't have been better in this beautifully sleek modern designed restaurant with comfortable ambient lighting.  

We will definitely be back if not try the sister restaurant Perbacco for a fine dining experience!
author: Elizabeth S.

description: Great vibe, generous portions for the pasta, friendly service. I had the orrichiette with pesto, which was delightful. Without a reservation, we were seated at the bar, and could speak easily without screaming to each other like some other bars. The dessert Panna cotta was just as delightful, with loads of flavour and lovely toppings sprinkled to add the crunch to the soft texture.
author: Rosaline O.

description: I had lunch here today, it is really my go to lunch meet up place for friends who work downtown. My favorite is the meatballs, brussels and gelato. Today I made reservations but my table was not ready and we waited for 15 mins, they were every apologetic which I appreciated. It was not okay but I understand. In the end they comp our dessert to make up for the wait time. I think that was a classy move.
author: Michelle F.

description:
There was a lot to like about Barbacco - it was stylish and sexy-looking, yet still warm and inviting. We were seated promptly and had a great server (who incidentally happened to sound exactly like Kathy Griffin...interesting!). I didn't love our two-top, which was shoved up next to a pole. And the food had some good moments, but wasn't quite as exciting as I had expected. We had the stuffed dates and roasted pear bruschetta as an appetizer - the dates were pretty yummy, but I think they might have been even better without the tomato sauce. I liked the combination of the roasted pear and prosciutto, but I think it could have been amped up had the pears been warm.

For our entrees, my friend and I shared the paccheri pasta with pork ragu and the polpette. I feel like this is where things kind of fell down. The pasta was so al dente as to actually be a little hard to chew, and the pork ragu was alright, but not as meltingly tender as I had hoped. The polpette, meatballs, had kind of a weird texture - firm but kind of chewy. But they had a nice taste, and the chard that accompanied it was good.

Maybe I just got an off day?
author: Deb G.

description:
Want great Italian food without the stuffy atmosphere and crazy wait for reservations? Choose Barbacco over its more stuffy sister restaurant, Perbacco.

Barbacco has a great formal bar atmosphere- think great furniture, loud chatter, and friendly casualness. The seats are a bit close together but I like peering over my neighbor's food so this worked out well for me. Plus, the menu is pretty good, especially at this price point in the Financial District.

I went with the Farrotto- a risotto made with farro, fancy pants mushrooms, and a solid helping of cheese. This dish is comfort in a bowl and best of all, it's healthier than a traditional rice-based risotto (or so I tell myself). I also got the much hyped brussels sprouts cooked in duck fat, capers, and anchovies but thought they were a bit too salty? And that's coming from a man who loves his salt. If you peeled away the top layer of the brussels and got rid of the overwhelming coating, they were quite good but really, with all that effort, you might as well make your brussels sprouts at home. 

All in all though, it was a good lunch with a fun vibe and I'll be back.
author: Nadeem A.

description:
I only came here briefly for appetizers, but I loved it!

The atmosphere was excellent; sharing tables in an intimate upscale restaurant. This is the sort of place for a hot date; its romantic and cozy. What's more it is near Embarcadero Center, one of the best movie theaters in town with the screening lounge recliner seats. Paired with Italian makes an excellent night out! 

To eat we had:
- Bruschetta (3 for $8) - we tried all 5 flavors
- Fried Polenta ($4)
- Bread with oil and balsamic (free)
- Smoky Sausage paste thing (I forget the name) (???$)

The bruschetta was fantastic, freshly cooked bread with a garlic olive oil brushing that just melted in your mouth. My favorite was the one with the grilled peaches, and secondly the onion one. All were excellent though, as as was the polentia. I didn't like the smoked sausage paste and the server was kind enough to strike it off the bill without asking. I didn't get a chance to try the pasta but I definitely will be back, others beside me had it and it looked (and smelled) amazing. 

A was also really impressed with the fast service, Open Table Reservations, and prices. I can't wait to come back and I will update this review accordingly.
author: Chris S.

description:
I am upgrading my review to 5 stars for two reasons:

1.  They have substantially expanded their wine-by-the-glass selection into a lot of the more interesting Italian wines.

2. Their service is just awesome.  We showed up for our reservation with an extra, 5th person, and despite being an underdressed bunch of computer geeks were treated royally by the staff.  I really can't say enough about the great service here.
author: Josh B.

description: Excellent pasta but the service was lacking. Fun atmosphere. I would recommend it, for great pasta and the pate appetizer was yummy.
author: Garry H.

description:
We knew we'd be back! Went for dinner this time and it was BUSY for a Wednesday night. No problem, the maître d sat us in a tiny bar seat near the door just right for the 2 of us. It had the added bonus of seeing nearly every person open the front door wrong. Lol. The bartender provided great service and the kitchen made even better food! 

We creates our own kind of sampler from all their delicious "small things" and sides. We especially loved the ascolane-fried olives stuffed with short rib filling (what?!) and the suppli-mushroom risotto croquettes! Yum. The 'nduja-spicy soft salame and the gremolata-roasted cauliflower were not our favorites but were still good. Oh and the parmigiano reggiano-fried polenta was awesome!
author: Jen C.

description:
Had a craving for a porchetta sandwich so called in a couple sandwich boxes to go from their takeout menu. Ready in 10, you can save time by going strait to the bar to pickup and pay instead of their hostess. 

Basically, if you do not know about Porchetta, you don't know shit.  

For $11 the porchetta came with a warm arugula/fennel side salad and some pickled vegetables (celery, cucumber, etc). The flavor on the pickled items was intense like biting into a lemon type of way. 

The porchetta was pretty good, I'm a fan - 4 stars. Thick slices of tender and savory roasted pork wrapped in a foccacia like roll. I would have liked a little more texture and bite to the roll's crust since it was soft all around. The sweetness from the peach and red onion offset the arugula. I found myself missing the crunch from the pork skin and herb flavor from Roli Roti's version though. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Wd5ho0_FKk9n7uV8pSCYIg?select=5ddq5mLBqk6F-8W9WobF-Q)

Barbacco's better sandwich imo is their roasted lamb - 4.5 stars. Tender lamb shoulder with garlic confit, mustard greens and fennel. The lamb had intense lamb flavor without being excessively gamey. My coworker who isn't a real fan of lamb liked it. Everything worked to create a sandwich I'd come back for. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Wd5ho0_FKk9n7uV8pSCYIg?select=2D2foHGOLp6w8pL-U43trA)

The ipad menu and cool industrial decor would make this spot cool for a date night. 4.5 stars.
author: Earl G.

description:
I came here with my coworker for dinner.

We got the little ear and the mushroom risotto and had it family style.  Both were really good and generous in portion size.  The service was quite nice, but she forgot that we wanted bread?  Do you get bread for free?  I can't tell.

The atmosphere is great for a place in FiDi.  Classy yet comfortable.  My coworker and I sat facing the bar (I think?)  and there were hooks below us for our purses so it didn't feel awkward or cramped at all like some bar seating does.
author: Esther S.

description: Came here for lunch with a friend....we had the roasted beets, strawberries and fennel, and orrechiette (i don't think this was housemade pasta though). We shared everything and the flavors in each dish were well-balanced.  Though the food was fine for Italian, the service was not. The restaurant is in the middle of downtown, so I'm sure the servers are aware of the time crunch for guests during the lunch hour and are also very busy during those few hours/quick table turnovers. I think we got lost in the shuffle, as our waiter did not greet us until 20 minutes after we sat. He was definitely in a rush and not too courteous as a result. Our food come out at random times and it took another chunk of time before we could flag him down for the check. A bit underwhelming, but glad to have tried it once.
author: Zara S.

description: Very fresh and fragrant, vegetables in the gnocchi were soft, cheese was well dispersed and mild (not too salty) the only thing that was a bit disappointing was the gnocchi dough itself. Not as fragrant and tasted of regular potatoes. Maybe that's what it ought to be and my east coast taste buds have long been overwhelmed? Overall very beautiful setting and good food.
author: Jenny L.

description: The food is delicious. We started with the Polpette and Gnocco Frito. Both were amazing. For our entrees I had the Lumache, my partner had the Tagliata, and we shared the Fried Brussel Sprouts. I would definitely recommend everything we tried. My only critique would be that the service was lacking. They were understaffed, which I can totally understand but it took away from the overall experience.
author: Rachelle Anne J.

description: I had swordfish, Brussels sprouts, orecchiette with fennel sausage, seared local squid , and trig point Cabernet to drink.  Everything is AMAZING!! Full of flavor!
author: Melanie E.

description:
Seated immediately at the bar as opposed to a 45 minute wait for a walk-in table.

The bar seating was just as comfortable and perhaps even more intimate than the table seating.  I got the vegetable risotto and my guest a similar pasta dish.  These were both very tasty but the winner was the side/starter brussels sprouts.

I was really hoping there was a full bar but unfortunately just beer and wine.  

Overall a good experience.
author: Anthony L.

description:
Barbacco has been on my radar for what seems like forever. When my brother and his wife visited from SoCal, I felt it was the perfect opportunity to finally scratch this place off my list... and it didn't disappoint. 

SERVICE: Excellent all the way around. It all started the day before when they called to confirm our reservation. Margo (I think that was her name) was so professional over the phone, but not uptight. She also gave us a HUGE heads up about the Chinese New Year parade that would close down a large portion of Market Street. Gotta give her props because it was a nightmare to get around that night. Our server (forgot her name) was awesome. Very personable, not stiff and gave us the full rundown of the menu and specials. She was fantastic all the way to the end. 

Here's what we got, my favorite starting from the top (FYI, our party of four shared everything):

TUSCAN CHICKEN LIVER PATE w/ GRILLED ONIONS BRUSCHETTE ~ 5 stars

CHITARRA (Hand cut pasta w/ Sicilian meatballs) ~ 5 stars

ROASTED PEAR, ARUGULA & PROSCIUTTO BRUSCHETTE ~ 4 stars

POLLO AL MATTONE ~ 3.5 stars

CRUDO DEL GIORNO ~ 3.5 stars

BROCCOLI RABE, MOZZARELLA & CALABRIA CHILI PEPPER BRUSCHEETE - 3.5 stars

TAGLIATA (Roasted sliced flat iron steak) ~ 3 stars

ORECCHIETTE (pasta w/ fennel sausage) ~ 2.5 stars

The Tuscan Chicken Liver Pate Bruschette is a MUST HAVE. The creamy pate combined with the sweetness of the grilled onions was amazing. If you're in the mood for pasta while at Barbacco, go with the Chitarra. The pasta and sauce are excellent but the  star of the dish were the meatballs. Some of the best I've ever had. 

Everything else ranged from average to good, but they can't compare with the pate and chitarra. I have to mention that their chicken (Pollo al Mattone) was cooked very well - moist and tender. But it lacked flavor. I think that dish can absolutely be elevated a little more with the right flavors/seasoning. 

I would also stay clear of the Tagliata and Orecchiette. Both sound amazing but had no wow factor. In fact, the Orecchiette was a big disappointment. Instead, we should have went with the Farrotto or even the Lasagna Bolognese. Next time, for sure. 

Barbacco is located right next to their, I guess, parent restaurant Perbacco. I plan on going some time in the future since that's also been on my radar. 

Although Barbacco came up short on a few things, their top dishes more than made up for them. They gave me an excellent idea and sample of how the rest of the menu tastes. I will absolutely go back.
author: Bruce C.

description: I went here a few weeks ago and had the orecchiette and it was divine. I decided to introduce my coworkers to this place today and got the orechiette as take-out and was sorely disappointed. Instead of giving us orechiette, they replaced the pasta with rigatoni. Not once did they give us notice, but because we trusted their business practices we were already long gone. I wish we had checked our order before leaving the restaurant. But that was just really messed up guys.
author: Binh P.

description:
It's a shame I have to write this review, as their food (and, typically, service) is quite good. However, I had a truly terrible service experience today that makes unlikely to revisit.

I went to Barbacco last night with my sister for a late dinner - which was lovely. Today upon ordering lunch, I realized I may have left my card in the billfold. I immediately called the restaurant - as I work nearby, I figured a quick trip to pick it up at some point in the afternoon would save me a visit to my bank - and reassure me that no one had picked up my card on the street for nefarious purposes.

When I called, I was put on hold twice - and then told that "they are too busy, and can't look right now, but would call me if they found it." I'm sorry...first of all - you'll call me IF you find it?

I politely mentioned that I'd like to call my bank and cancel the card for security purposes if they didn't have it, and would be happy to quickly stop by the restaurant if that would be helpful. They replied "it's the lunch rush right now, we cannot look for you" (for reference - it was around 2, so conceivably busy but not exactly prime time).

I understand that they're busy - but seriously, not one staff member can spare 3 minutes to look in the safe, if I come in, to spare me potential fraudulent charges? No thanks, Barbacco.
author: Laurel K.

description: Walked here from AT&T Park. Our waiter was so patient with requests and knowledgeable. Food(salmon, flat iron steak and lasagna) was delicious   I especially enjoyed my citrus & fennel salad. Highly recommend this restaurant
author: Dede M.

description:
I feel like I should be more impressed. We were seated by the bar, and while service was very attentive and friendly, I think I just personally prefer sitting at a table or booth for dinner. But, the bar was pretty to look at, they have a great display.

Great prices for a place that appears so upscale. I got the farrotto - it was good, just the right amount of creamy and it had a distinct taste (maybe the mushroom) that permeated through the whole dish. It was a big serving, I definitely could not finish it.

Now I wish I tried more from the menu, for a more complete experience. It did get loud in there but I would recommend for a date or small group.
author: Pamela S.

description:
I ordered a lasagna and corn rigatoni via their online ordering system.  It was pretty easy to use.  I went to pick up my order at the restaurant.  It wasn't ready at the time but I waited until it was done.  The staff was busy serving the dine in customers but they were friendly and didn't forget that I was waiting for my food.  They even threw in a free cookie for my wait (really a 5 minute delay).

Dh said his lasagna was good.  I loved the corn rigatoni.  It came with spinich, bits of bacon (not fat but real bacon meat) with a hint of meyer lemon.  This is as good as Perbacco but slightly cheaper.

I would definitely come back and eat in next time.
author: Wendy H.

description:
I was delighted with my visit last Thursday night.  The place was full however, as a single diner, in no time I was accommodated at the bar dining area where I quickly made friends with a very nice couple from Vallejo.  We shared samples and recipes and laughs, all adding to the charm of Barbacco.  The staff is wonderful, with everyone checking on you, not just one. Very well in sink as a team and you can sense a good vibe about the whole place.  

I had checked out reviews and the menu before coming and knew what I wanted to try.  

The beets were amazing as other reviewers also say, with surprise pieces of plum complementing the sweetness of the beets and a fluffy creamy white accent sauce slightly hinting of horseradish...sooo surprisingly good with the beets!  Feisty dish in flavor!  Not over stated, and an amazing party in my mouth!

I tried the pate next which came with a zesty complementing relish...honestly, it was so good I almost ordered another plate!  I decided to save room for one more dish and man...it did not disappoint!  The cauliflower florets came evenly browned all around, yet keeping its fresh firm texture with slight hints of garlic browned butter.  Delicious    

The reason for the 4-star is confusion of location. (sister restaurant)  I had accidentally walked into their "Sister Restaurant" 2 doors down called "Perbacco" I think.  When I walked there was a lot of confusion and unhappy staff faces... 3 staff members were having a business discussion at the front counter that seemed to be one that should be in the kitchen, one looked up after several minutes and asked if I had a reservation...I didn't so they sat me at the bar and after glancing at the menu I realized I was in the wrong place. THANK GOD!  Beware, and don't make the same mistake I did.  Since they're so close, step into each one and you'll see what I mean.
author: Lynne B.

description: Great drink menu with a wide variety of wines. Food was very good however portion size was very small. The seasonal gelato was fabulous. Would recommend however don't come starving.
author: Chris B.

description:
It's funny how one can just walk next door and receive a much better dining experience. I had previously dined at Perbacco (see review here: http://www.yelp.com/biz/perbacco-san-francisco?hrid=jPO9xG59LztZzjxJX8hPxA), and had a less than amazing experience. I wanted to try Barbacco, just to compare, so some friends and I ventured there for my birthday lunch. 

WHAT A DIFFERENCE! 

Not only was the staff 10x friendlier, the food was 100x better! I had the braised chicken thighs, which were scrumptious and juicy, amazingly well seasoned, with a crispy skin on top. Just remarkable.

On top of that, they offered my entire party a complimentary dessert, in celebration of my birthday. We'll definitely be back to Barbacco.
author: Dom J.

description: Brussel sprouts in duck fat...AMAZING. Moscato is good too. ummm, the sashimi fish the waitress called small, should have been more specific by saying "you get three small pieces of cheap fish that are as thin as rice paper." A whole dish of cherashi at a faboosh Japanese restaurant cost the same price for those THREE PIECES OF FISH. Because of this trick they pulled on me, I give three stars. Did I want to order more food? why? I already spent over $50 for a dinner for two. We went to a comedy show after and destroyed a basket of garlic fries bc I was starving!
author: J. W.

description:
This is a great spot! I met a friend here after work and generally shy away from FiDi spots b/c they aren't my style. This place definitely has more of a FiDi feel and is a bit pricy but I felt like the value was there for the money. Really nice wine and the portions were generous for SF. We got a salami plate, cheese plate the brussel sprouts and cauliflower. All were excellent.

I did knock off a star because my friend needed to get out and catch a flight. We didn't want to be too demanding so we ordered virtually no-cook food and asked they not wait to bring anything out. This worked well and the food came fast. That said it was much too difficult to get anyones attention when we needed the bill. We asked for it a good 15 min before we needed it and it took every second of that and more to finally get it from someone.
author: Hanna L.

description:
I love this place! I've been there 4 times in the past year and I have never had a bad experience. This last time I brought two girlfriends who have never been there and I had made reservations. Unfortunately we were more than 45 min late because of Uber and they still took us.

My favorite dish is the lasagna but honestly I love everything there. I have also had the flank steak, meatballs, and risotto and I enjoyed these as well. For appetizers I love the brussels sprouts and beets. I was disappointed when they stopped cooking the brussels sprouts in duck fat but the fried versions are great too. 

Not that far from Bart. Great staff. Cozy environment. If you don't like to sit close to other dinners the seating arrangement may bother you but otherwise great spot!
author: Lisa M.

description:
The "B" in Barbacco should stand for "Bang for your Buck" with mouth-watering fare at 1/3 the cost of its more upscale cousin restaurant, Perbacco...

Personally, I think Perbacco is over-hyped (thanks to the 7x7 list) and the food was very mediocre and lacking in flavor. Link to my review: http://www.yelp.com/biz/perbacco-san-francisco#hrid:nwb3HCMlaCKgTEr34l9L7Q However, after my co-worker told me how much she loved Barbacco and after seeing all the rave reviews, I thought it would be a great place to take my friend for a belated birthday dinner after some HH drinks.

On Thursday, 3.24.11, my friend and I arrived promptly for 9 PM reservations and were immediately seated. 

F O O D:
~~~MUST ORDERS~~~
*ARACINI - RISOTTO CROQUETTES w/ Braised Short Rib & Mozzarella ($3/ea.): http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Wd5ho0_FKk9n7uV8pSCYIg?select=hRcdRsOTCUf1F9ETGNYXYg

Like little balls of heaven, the aracinis were fried to a crisp golden brown and generously filled with short rib and mozzarella cheese. The combo of the crisp and creamy risotto, tender and savory short rib and ooey gooey cheese made me savor each decadent bite and left me wanting more.

*DUCK LIVER PATE w/ Balsamic Onion Marmalade Bruschette ($3 ea.): http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Wd5ho0_FKk9n7uV8pSCYIg?select=2f5fKFbVbhsfvlXuQkRUng 

The velvety smooth pate was slathered atop a toasted bruschette and then topped with a tangy and sweet balsamic onions which created the perfect balance of savory and sweet flavors. 

*RUSTIC PORK RAGU ($11): http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Wd5ho0_FKk9n7uV8pSCYIg?select=JitWsHBccuGUiT0r3v1k5w

The al-dente paccheri (large, hollow, tube-shaped pasta) was interwoven with the thick, savory, and tangy pork ragu. The pork ragu was packed with bold flavors and the sprinkle of Parmigiano-Reggiano added a subtle rich tang. (I must note that the pasta was very al-dente and if you like your pasta on the softer side, you may think the pasta is undercooked.)

*FRIED BRUSSELS SPROUTS w/ Capers, Anchovy and Red Wine Vinaigrette ($4): http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Wd5ho0_FKk9n7uV8pSCYIg?select=roeTvwXjT1tQmj3G2DLFaw 

Tossed in a tangy red wine vinaigrette, the fried brussels sprouts remained crispy on the outside and was tender in the inside. The capers and anchovy added a layer of saltiness that complemented the subtle flavor of the brussels sprouts without being overwhelming. 

~~~GOOD~~~
*MOZZERELLA DI BUFALA w/ Asparagus & Fried Capers ($12): http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Wd5ho0_FKk9n7uV8pSCYIg?select=Ya0HbDrm6bII0fqjVtPdYg 

The huge asparagus spears were crisp and tender and the fresh mozzarella was rich, light, and creamy. The fried capers paired with the mozzarella and asparagus by adding layer of crispness, as well as, a burst of subtle saltiness.

*SPICY BRAISED TRIPE w/ Tomato & Sage Over Grilled Filon ($8): http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Wd5ho0_FKk9n7uV8pSCYIg?select=ikGA6ljKkvlWqa7jobloew 

Although the tripe was perfectly braised to a soft and rich tenderness, it lacked heat and the accompanying filon (Italian bread) became a complete soggy mush after sitting underneath the tripe stew. 

*HOUSEMADE DUCK SAUSAGE w/ Cannelli Beans, Balsamico & Onion Marmelleta ($12): http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Wd5ho0_FKk9n7uV8pSCYIg?select=FFUx5Ng4LMAS39XqzpVneg 

An Italian take on bratwurst and sauerkraut, the duck sausage had a snap to it upon biting into it. It was tender, juicy and flavorful with a hint of gaminess. The cannelli beans were rich and creamy while onion marmelleta gave the dish a fresh burst of sweetness and tanginess.

S E R V I C E:
Down-to-earth, friendly and attentive. Our first 2 dishes came out within minutes of ordering, however there was a 25 minute lag before getting our other dishes. 

A M B I A N C E / D É C O R:
Compared to its upscale cousin restaurant, Barbacco is very hip and casual with contemporary furnishings, exposed brick walls and iPad wine menus.

Barbacco is not really meant for an intimate dinner as the tables are in close proximity and the noise level can get very high.

P A R K I N G:
Relatively easy street parking on weekdays before 6 PM. Valet parking is available during dinnertime for $10.

After a disappointing experience at Perbacco, I was pleasantly surprised at all the dishes at Barbacco which were mouth-watering and packed with bold flavors. While the food at Barbacco is a solid 4 Stars, the Recession-Friendly prices make it 5 STAR worthy!
author: Cherylynn N.

description: Really enjoyed the food. Got the burrata starter (gnoccho frito) as the starter, farroto and poplette as the main course. Everything was perfect! Would love to go back.
author: Louisa D.

description:
Let me make this clear for all the people that LOVE the brussel sprouts here, they SUCKED SO BADLY.  

For $5 you get oily, over lemon-ed burnt palm size serving of CRAP. I love brussel sprouts, but these were horrible. I think all the people that "LOVE" them either like alot of oil or have no taste buds. 

My entire party of 3 all though it was crap and did not finish them.

Starters:

Tuscan chicken liver pate and grape conserve bruschette. The only good thing from the night.

Chef's Selection of Salumi: Not worth it, rather go to Boccalone in the Ferry Plaza, it would taste so much better. 


Entrees(SO NOT WORTH IT): 

Cornish Game hen was cooked, but hard to cut. The "braised broccli rabe" was so soft that an old person with no teeth would love it. Braised does not mean overcooked till it turns to mush.

Tuscan Beef Stew: Can you say soup? It was soo watery and the meat was tender but so tender that it was a meat sauce. Plus,"Creamy Polenta" my ass, it was not mixed well, as one part tasted like grainy gruel and the other like salty cheese and still grainy.


Grand Total: $106 for shitty food, over priced wine and I'm not even getting into the server and his lack of attention. Would I go back for the pate, not really, I can get the same if not better in other places.
author: Mei L.

description:
A great place to try some great food that is prepared in front of you (if you are lucky to get a seat in front of the prep area)!

Had dinner reservations and got there early. We checked in and waitress told us should would call us when table was ready and directed us next door (their sister restaurant) to get drinks. She did call us soon afterwards but we didn't hear it. 

My cousin is a vegetarian and I am not. This place had a great selection for both. We ordered a few small plates and were satisfied. This is what we got:
Suppli- a risotto ball deep fried. Had nice crunch and flavor. A different way to eat risotto. 
Bruschetta- You get to pick 3 different ones off of the menu, not just your standard tomato/garlic/basil. We got the prosciutto/pear (decent, something seemed missing though), beans/duck (great flavor and texture), squash/kale (my cousin liked it). 
Burrata- byt far my favorite dish on the menu. So creamy, so amazing. I am salivating writing this. 
We shared a mezzo of the barbera/bonarda blend. It was a little over 3 glasses and was a great selection. A red wine with a little sparkle.
author: Sarika S.

description: Based on other reviews we were led to believe the food at this place was good... sad surprise. We ordered the ziti, beets salad, sole (fish of the day), and the octopus. The only decent dish was the octopus. The rest left a lot to be desired. The ziti was absolutely overcooked, it was breaking apart. The beets were bland. And the sole had "artichoke chips" that were inedible... could not even chew them
author: Pau Y Monica C.

description: Great restaurant! Good for family. Foods delicious. We got pasta, beef stew and chicken thigh. Everything was amazing.
author: Kiran P.

description:
This review is for Pandora in the catering department. 

Today, I contacted Barbacco via telephone to inquire about offsite catering for a dinner party of 30 at a private venue 1/2 mile away from Barbacco. I was referred to Pandora. I was having trouble hearing what she was saying because of the background noise in the restaurant. When I asked her to speak up over the noise, I still experienced significant difficulty in comprehending what she was saying. I then asked if she could step away to somewhere within the restaurant that was a little less noisy so we could hear each other and she said in a very rude tone, "No, I work in a restaurant." 

Clearly, she could hear me and that's all that mattered to her. I have worked in a restaurant and I understand the madness of the lunch rush. Often times, it is difficult to hear customers over the telephone but I always made an effort to walk away to a more quiet corner or at the very least, take down the customer's phone number and return the phone call after the lunch rush or maybe during the afternoon slump. 

I have dined at Barbacco several times and this one employee's attitude has left a lasting bad taste in my mouth about the restaurant. 

When you're spending $2,000 on catering, especially from a restaurant like Barbacco, you expect a much higher caliber level of customer service. Taking my business elsewhere and never coming back. Impressions are everything.
author: Monelle A.

description:
Great food & great service!

This is why I love this place and its sister restaurant, Perbacco!

Came here to celebrate my friend's birthday and sat at the bar, and loved it! 

From the moment we walked and was greeted by the friendly hostess, knew it was going to be a solid night at Barbacco!

We had:

+++Seared Local Squid+++
This was super tender and what made the dish were the cannelloni beans. The basil-pine nut pesto was secondary, but the squid shined.

+++Roasted Three Mushroom en Papillote+++
Once the food runner cut open that parchment package, a beautiful citrus aroma released and the subtle earthiness of the mushrooms only added to the enjoyment of the dish.

+++Fried Polenta Cubes+++
Melt. In. Your. Mouth. Crispy exterior which perfectly contrast the creamy interior. Delightful!

+++Paccheri Pasta+++
I was intrigued by this dish more because of the braised lamb, and the protein didn't disappoint. However, my friend noticed that the consistency of the pasta was off with some noodles being al dente and some undercooked.

+++Butter Scotch-Chocolate Crunch+++
They had me at gelato! It was rich and delicious. You could taste a bit of caffeine, which was much needed at the end of a meal.

+++Service+++
Our server was friendly and very knowledgeable. Checked on us multiple times during the meal. Only delta is attentiveness to refill water glasses, which lacked. It was my friend's birthday and they brought her out the dessert with a birthday wish written in chocolate. When the manager dropped the checked, he even wished my friend Happy Birthday. 

Overall, I'm still a fan of the Perbacco/Barbacco Restaurants! Can't wait for my next visit!
Thank you for a great dinner!
author: J L.

description:
Good service and fantastic food. Bucatini was perfectly cooked with a rich flavor where many pastas are simply sauce delivery mechanisms. Tomato sauce was light and fresh and perfectly seasoned. 

The real star of the show for us though was the Italian stew. Much like a pot roast, but the red wine braised beef had a deep and complex flavor, served over heavenly creamy polenta. Definitely recommended.
author: Chris B.

description:
lunch review...

upscale but not in a stuffy, pretentious way. the atmosphere is an updated version of traditional Italian service. at 11:30am there are already people lined up waiting for the doors to open. the table are a bit close together, so if you're looking to have a more private conversation, sitting at the counter (with bar stools) might be a better idea

they have some interesting bruschettas, we started with a asparagus and lemon ricotta which was amazing. also a butcher salad which could have used a little more salami and mozzarella, but for lunch, maybe it didn't need to be so heavy. the meatballs were the fantastic! served with braised char and tomato sauce. oh man. I could have spent all afternoon eating them and dipping that sauce in a whole loaf of sliced bread. 

the price is surprisingly reasonable too. I'll be back, next time for dinner
author: Bob U.

description:
This is a solid bet.

Good menu selection.  Food very good (the brussel sprouts are reeeaaaallly good).

Staff is pretty responsive and friendly and food delivered fairly quick.  Price not bad considering the competition in the Financial District (a few doors down from Michael Minna, for example).  

Usually packed - both a good sign and a challenge if you don't plan ahead.

Good choice for clients or professionals meeting for lunch.
author: Dennis R.

description:
London Buddy was in town & Barbacco was his choice of spots to celebrate a wonderful New Year & catch up on events that occurred over the holidays

I *really* liked the fact they seated Sis & me w/out our 3rd party being there!  Allowed us to peruse the menu & pick out the veggie options

London Buddy got the Mushroom Farro Risotto - ginormous portion of extremely mushroomy & delicate farro - I totally want to come back for this dish alone!!

Sis & I opted for the Butternut Squash Pasta - this was a squash puree on top of flat sheet-like pasta & while it was good, it was pretty bland.  Good thing I had also ordered the Roasted Butternut Squash as a side dish & could mix the 2 together
