That Roasted Squash was ALL KINDS OF GOOD!  Pomegranate seeds & pumpkin seeds were paired up w/ this goodness & the flavors & textures were a definite winner

And what New Year wouldn't be perfectly kicked off w/out dessert?!  Sis & I chose the Bread Pudding; London Buddy chose the Chocolate Torte

Bread Pudding was somewhat mushy (which is a good thing!) but had an abundance of fruit (which isn't a good thing) & there was some kind of anise-like / xmas fruitcake fruit in there that totally hit my yuck factor.  Luckily there wasn't a lot in there & I could pick around it.  While it was okay, this Bread Pudding was no comparison to Esin's BP (in Danville)

The Torte was like a piece of chocolate fudge it was so creamy & rich & all kinds of delish - this was the winner in the dessert round - looked like London Buddy scored in every category!

Homemade (lip puckering) Lemonades to wash it all down & we've got a delish start to the New Year!
author: Adrienne G.

description:
My friend HIGHLY recommended the sandwich at this place, so I brought a friend and made a reservation at 1:15PM. When we walked in, there's actually a line of people waiting to be seated (so make the reservation if you don't want to wait). However, we got seated at the bar, which has limited space (I seriously bumped into the guy next to me 3 times before I decided to move my chair infinitely closer to my friend's side).

The decoration of the restaurant is pretty modern, clean and classy. There are mirrors on the far side that made the restaurant look twice as big as it actually is. 

Now let's talk about the food. I would NOT say that the food here is to-die-for, but it was definitely different from any other sandwiches that I've had before. We ordered the lamb shoulder sandwich with broccoli leafs and the chicken salad sandwich with almond and a lemony/orangy dressing. I don't want to describe the taste too much because I simply cannot put it into proper words, but both sandwiches tasted more Asian-Fusion than Modern Italian to me. The lamb one has a minty/wasabi taste, and it's kinda bitter. The chicken salad one had tender chicken and crispy almond, combined with the dressing was light and sweet. However, the bread was so HARD and the sandwich fell apart after the first bite.

My friend ordered the lemonata, and she thought all the different flavors (classic, mint, cucumber, ginger, strawberry) were put into one drink. The waiter was super nice that he actually put every flavor into one lemonade for my friend. The cucumber was really strong, much stronger than the other flavors. Give it a try if you like adventures!
author: Maggie L.

description:
I had a wonderful lunch with yelper Ken G., who graciously took the reigns and made the reservations.  

I'm sure glad we ended up at this cool and modern trattoria, as I discovered one of my favorite lunch spots in the FiDi.  I've passed by Barbacco several times and read positive reviews, but for some reason I have always ended up elsewhere for lunch.  While their next door neighbor Perbacco emphasizes a more elegant feel, Barbacco has a more casual, down to earth atmosphere, without compromising quality.

The place was busy, but not chaotic; classy, but not pretentious.  And, best of all, sophisticated, but not expensive.  It's the type of place you can take a client for a business lunch or just ham it up with friends.  Service is also very good, plus you can place your drink order on Ipads, how cool is that?

Anyway, I tried the Slow Roasted Porchetta Sandwich.  While not quite as juicy and meaty as Roli Roti, the sandwich was very very good.  The meat was tender.  It had a hint of saltiness, that when mixed in with the sweetness of the roasted grapes and red onion, results in a fascinating medley of flavors.  This sandwich was a bargain at $10, well worth it.  Even the side salad, which was not drenched in dressing, was delightful.  

I'll find my way back here for sure.  It's just a comfortable place to have lunch whether for business or pleasure, plus the food is pretty good.
author: Angel S.

description:
A nice yet affordable sit down type of lunch spot can be hard to find in the Financial District, but Barbacco met and exceeded my expectations! My manager treated me out for lunch here on a Thursday. Call in ahead of time to make a reservation because the place can get pretty busy! The seating is split between tables/booths and bar seating with a view into the prep area. 

To start off our lunch we ordered the marinated olives. I was a little bummed out I didn't get to try the brussel sprouts, but they are cooked with duck fat, so vegetarians take note. Tip: Acme bread upon request which comes with olive oil and balsamic vinegar. When our pasta arrived, they came in boat-shaped bowls, and was a much larger portion than I was expecting. I highly recommend the orecchiette pasta - spinach and Italian sausage yummm. My manager decided to try the butternut squash rigatoni, which was made with corn (gluten free), but wasn't really a big fan of it. Their salads looked really delicious too.

Shoutout to our waitress (forgot her name!) for providing great service :) I look forward to returning and indulging in more pasta!
author: Michelle C.

description: Went here for dinner with a friend. Was surprised they only serve beer and wine but you can grab a cocktail next door at Perbacco if you're jonesing. On to the food... I had the Lumache- a red wine pasta, pork ragu and parmigiano; it was divine!  My friend ordered the Agnello- braised lamb shank and it was pretty tasty as well. Great price points, large portions and okay service. I will definitely return.
author: Michelle S.

description:
(In reality, this place is more like 3.5 stars)

Had a reservation at 8pm on a Friday night and were seated immediately. Decent service throughout the night, but nothing exceptionally great or noteworthy.

I ordered the Orecchiette, which was described as: "little ears" cavolo nero fennel sausage pecorino cheese. So maybe I don't eat Italian food enough, but I had no idea what this was after reading the description (other than that it had cheese), so I googled this. A search on cavolo nero came up with kale. And well fennel sausage seemed like just sausage and same with the cheese. Then when my dish came, I realized it seemed like some sort of pesto sauce. (Which was a little disconcerting because I'm allergic to nuts, and pesto can sometimes have nuts). Basically after waiting maybe 15 minutes, I was finally able to flag down our waitress and ask if the pasta contained nuts. (Meanwhile my friend was just devouring the meal -_____- ) And when I finally asked our waitress, the restaurant was loud so I misheard her and thought she said YES there are nuts, which quickly turned my face pale. But luckily when I clarified, she said (yes) they are aware that people have nut allergies, so they make their kale pesto without any nuts. 

Just to clarify, the Orecchiette with the kale pesto sauce is nut free!

But my actual orecchiette was very dense and filling. I liked the kale, since it was different and nice to be eating some veggies. However, I did not find the dish to be the most flavorful.

Overall dining experience was decent. A nice cozy restaurant in FIDI.
author: Julie L.

description: Trendy post-work spot in the Financial District, with an excellent wine list. Unfortunately, for the price, the food was mediocre. Under seasoned (but large) serving of orechiette and a skimpy "large" serving of Chef's choice salami. We enjoyed our time because the atmosphere is relaxed and the wine list is extensive, but we were disappointed with the food compared to other, less pricey options in the city.
author: Convict T.

description:
I stumbled upon this place as I wrapped my last meeting and had time to kill before heading back to SFO.
Attentive staff and very friendly. 
I started with the Octopus salad $12 and it was delicious. 
For the main I had the Paccheri  $16 (homemade tube pasta with braised lamb, olives and ricotta salata). It was fresh, delicious and was served piping hot! 

I also ordered a side of fried brussel sprouts as suggested by the woman who took my order. A little heavy on the red wine vinaigrette but tasty. 

To drink I had a limonata with ginger. (Non alcoholic beverage.) It was A bit tart and too sweet, but was much better after adding some ice water to it.

Bread is served upon request. 

All in all great place, great ambience, very good food.
author: Mark A.

description:
I've been to Barbacco a few times and I've really enjoyed everything at this spot.  I've tried a few different appetizers like the Fried Polenta and the Duck Fat Fried Brussel Sprouts all is amazing!  I've had a couple of different versions of Beef/Short Rib Stew Over Creamy Polenta as well as Spaghetti Carbonara and those were all fantastic as well.  They have an excellent wine list and the décor and ambiance are perfect for a fun evening.  The atmosphere during the week is really energetic while weekends are bit more calm.

This place is an excellent choice!
author: Ken G.

description: Last night my wife and our friends had our New Years Dinner. The appetizers came out quick. The wait staff was exceptional. Our main courses were delicious.                                                  Now the BAD.. At the end of our dinner what could have been the manager was rude, short and not at all courteous. He came to our table stated he let our waiter go. He basically was rushing us out. We just spent a large amount money on a nice dinner. The worse was after we had dessert I ordered the panforte. It is a very small fruit bar (very good). My wife went back to order another one from that (manager?). After we had spent a size able amount on dinner he had the audacity to bring us a $2.00 bill for it!! He (manager?)was a portly, caucasian, bearded middle aged man with glasses. What was a wonderful dinner was marred by manager.
author: Ricardo H.

description:
SHE LIKED:

1)  The Counter

It runs all the way down the restaurant and is a much better option than the communal tables for cozying up to your date. 

2)  The Bruschette

The braised greens / garlic / crescenza cheese one was my favorite.  I wished the lonza / roasted grapes / saba one had more pork and the grapes rolled off so it was awkward to eat.  The truffled lardo was too much.  (Yes, there is such a thing as being too rich!)  (3 for $8)

3)  The Fried Brussels Sprouts

They were perfectly cooked inside with nice crispy leaves on the outside.  The red wine vinaigrette that they were tossed in was amazingly salty and tangy.  I could have eaten a bowl of these!  ($4)

4)  The Duck Sausage

Nicely portioned and grilled, it was even better with the sweetened bits of red onion on top.  The pretty plate was sprinkled with arugula and also had a slab of grilled polenta that was creamy and cheesy inside.  Loved it!  ($14) 

5)  The Vibe

The Hostess was gracious and welcoming, our Server rocked, and the feel was nice and casual despite the high quality of food and service. 

6)  The Prices

We had all the above plus the Orecchiette pasta ($12), the Espresso Panna Cotta ($5), and drinks.  We were stuffed but our bill was only around $60 (+tax & tip).  These plates are meant to be shared but they aren't small.  Perfect date night food for people who like to eat!

HE LIKED:

1)  The iPad

Barbacco has solidified its wine nerd street cred by putting their wine list on iPads.  Techie BF liked this very much.  Non-techie me thought it would be gimmicky but actually it worked well.  It was organized by types of wines and regions.  Once you made your selection, you could learn more than you ever wanted to know about the wine and then order by the taste, glass, quarto, mezzo, or bottle.  My taste of Prosecco was lacking in the bubbles department ($5.50) but BF liked his glass of Cabernet Sauvignon blend just fine ($9). 

2)  The Company

(Good save BF!)

Note:  I've also ordered takeout from Barbacco for lunch and it's a nice treat from the usual FiDi routine.  I love the Porchetta Sandwich (no Roli Roti line - holla!) and the Mozzarella di bufala and Roasted Beets salad.
author: Amy C.

description: Food was good, but service was subpar
author: Vicky G.

description:
I decided to check out this place over the weekend and catch up with a friend from college. Overall, it was a great experience and I would give the restaurant another visit if I'm in the area. Here are the details:

APPETIZERS
They have a diverse selection of appetizers (vegetables, seafood, salami, bruschette) and I went for the ROASTED CAULIFLOWER, which included a combination of tomato, garlic, chili, and arugula. The dish was more like a salad with the amount of arugula. Cauliflower was awesome; my only complaint was the small portion size for $5.

My friend had the CREAM OF MUSHROOM soup...which was good....but nothing special. It did the job.

PASTA/MAIN
I went with the ORECCCHIETTE "little ears" pasta with fennel sausage, cavolo nero (kale) and pecorino cheese for $13. I didn't really expect anything amazing, but I was presently surprised by the flavor and combination of simple ingredients. I can admit I've joined the kale band-wagon and there was plenty of it....so if you're not into the green veggy, don't try this dish. The fennel sausage added a little kick every couple bites, the pasta was cooked perfectly, and I had a very satisfying meal.

My friend had the POLLO AL MATTONE (chicken "under a brick") with salsa verde and grilled lemon for $18. First thing we realized was the portion size was pretty healthy and satisfying for one person. The chicken was done well and it was a very simple dish...literally just chicken, salsa, and a lemon. So if you're looking to be a little more adventurous I'd stray away. If you're looking for a simple and hearty dish, go for it!

CONCLUSION
I'd recommend BARBACCO to my friends. It was a clean restaurant, had a pleasant (not too loud, not too quiet) atmosphere, and the staff was responsive and efficient. We went on a Saturday night and it got pretty crowded by 7pm, so I'd recommend booking reservations in advance to be safe.

Until my next review...HAPPY EATING!

Tyler
author: Tyler J.

description:
I love tapas. And I love Italian food. So I was ecstatic when Alex P. and Jess H. suggest Barbacoo for dinner. They are seasoned vets -- they recognize servers, basically know the menu by heart, are prepared for the wait, and know parking regulations for the area.

We ordered:

SM Chef Selection Salumi 
Suppli - mushroom risotto croquettes filled with truffled mozzarella
Bruschette -- tuscan chicken liver pate / onion marmellata, roasted pear/prosciutto di parma, roasted mushrooms/artichoke crema
Crostone with burrata cheese roasted beets/rucola
Orecchiette - "little ears" / cavolo nero fennel sausage / pecorino cheese
Spaghetti Alla Carbonara - guanciale, pecorino romano, egg, black pepper

Each dish including the pasta was easy to share and absolutely delicious. The hostess was even nice enough to provide free seasoned almonds to snack on during our wait. A few of my favorite dishes were the bruschette (all of them) and the orecchiette. Thank you A & J for sharing Barbacco. 

What I recommend:

-- bruschette
-- orecchiette
author: Andrew W.

description:
It's very rare that my wife and I will both love every dish we ordered. This place did just that. We've been here a couple times and it's one of our local's favorite. Full bodied, rich dishes at every turn. 
Braised tripe, salumi, anchovy devil eggs, even the more common pasta bolognese offered fantastic flavors.
Good selection of Italian wines to compliment a great meal. 
Service and ambiance are always excellent.
author: James W.

description:
i love barbacco for a business lunch because it is super centrally located. and it's also one of my most recommended lunch places whenever friends need a suggestion. but seriously be sure to make a reservation because it gets PACKED! and make sure you're okay with communal tables or bar seating, because it's all they have!

a few of my to-go items: roasted pear bruschette, kale and farro salad, orecchiette with fennel sausage and pecorino cheese, chicken thighs, meatballs, fried brussel sprouts, and polenta fries! seriously cannot go wrong with any of those items - and they're always consistently done well!  i enjoy barbacco more so that perbacco because of its relaxed atmosphere, and more reasonably-priced but more delicious fare!
author: Christina L.

description:
Stopped by here for a Monday night dinner and we were seated almost immediately. We at first had a hard time figuring out what the point of the ipad was. Basically a glorified drink menu, and don't be afraid to click on anything... even though there's a "shopping cart" you don't actually get charged unless you order straight from the waiter. Interesting overhead cost.

Anyway, service was slightly slow and food slightly overpriced, but overall was decent. I ordered a honey ale and the cornish game hen. The hen was well seasoned, but the mustard green salad that came with it was a bit too tart. All washed down nicely with the ale. Also note, if you are looking for a private affair, this is not the place. Four of us shared a table of 6 with 2 others. Totally fine since we were all friendly.
author: Veronica C.

description:
If you have time to have a nice lunch in the FiDi, this is the place to be.  A nice modern + sophisticated restaurant filled with your normal FiDi lunch crowd.  It's the perfect spot to conduct a business lunch or catch up with old friend.  Staff was very attentive and knowledable. Definitely seeing a crowd during lunch time is normally a good sign already.

For starters, my friend and I picked a trio of bruschette that consisted of the duck liver pate (my fav out of the 3), smoked lonza, and the house cured sardines.  I'm personally not a sardine person, but my friend insisted that I give it a try.  To my surprise, it was rather yummy, perfect seasoning, not too salty or disgustingly fishy.  Per the recommendation of our server, we also had their soup of the day, which was cream asparagus and truffle oil. What a great starter, we should have definitely gone for the bowl instead of a cup! 

Having such great starters, we had high expectations for our entrees. Without a doubt, we went for the slow roasted shoulder porchetta (to see how it compares to their Ferry Building competitor) and the orecchiette "little ears" pasta w/ homemade sausage.  Sadly, we were unimpressed by both dishes - bland and boring with too much going on in the sandwich.  

With some room left, we ended the meal with the butterscotch chocolate crunch gelato recommended by our server.  A great choice indeed, I loved the rich butterscotch flavor and the texture the crunch in each bite gave. 

Although we did not opt for any alcohol, another thing worth mentioning is their wine menu.  It was a nice touch that they've incorporated their drink list onto an ipad, very forward thinking and innovative.  

All and all, a nice meal with great company.
author: Janetto L.

description:
Overall, a very solid three-star Italian restaurant with fantastic service and great ambiance in SF's financial district.  As an added bonus, stays open a bit later than most places in FiDi (10pm).  

But I've been here twice now, and both times was relatively underwhelmed by the food.  I loved the bruschetta, especially the (a) crushed borlotti beans and duck conserva and (b) roasted pear and prosciutto di parma selections.  The pasta, however, was over cooked (so couldn't even tell if it was homemade or not), and the sauce lacked any memorable flavor.  I was very pleased with my wine selection, courtesy of an iPad sommelier - the 2011 Gold Hill Chardonnay from El Dorado County, CA.
author: Greg B.

description:
Having eaten at Perbacco a number of years ago and really enjoying it, we decided to check the kid sibling out after getting a 30% off deal. A small hallway of  a space is lined with sleek booths in the back, a long bar area and a number of tables up front. I dig the IPad wine ordering system. Unfortunately it doesn't sync with the waiter's wireless notepad or syncs over wireless to the main ordering system. the server had to physically pick it up and then enter the orders...still it's a cool way to save on paper and be able to update an ever changing list. I understand the French Laundry is translating their massive wine list to IPads too, so if it's good enough for Thomas Keller....

Of the food we had:

-arancini - risotto croquettes filled with braised pork, mozzarella and peas
-nduja - smoked Calabrian salame spicy, soft served with grilled crostini
-finocchiona - fennel seed and fennel pollen
-nostrano - warm spices
-mortadella
-ciccioli with mostarda and crostini
-gorgonzola / chestnut honey 
-taleggio / housemade fruit mostarda
-cypress grove - humbolt fog / almonds
-heirloom tomatoes / cucumber / red onion
-orecchiette - "little ears" / fennel sausage/cavolo nero / garlic / pecorino cheese
-polpette - Sicilian meatballs with raisins and pine nuts / braised chard / tomato sugo
-paccheri / rustic pork ragu/parmigiano reggiano
-torrone gelato
-espresso panna cotta

it certainly was a tasty small plates feast. You can eat as much or as little as you want, and there's a huge selection of things to eat. Our server was super cool and the whole staff kept us taken care of. At the end of the night the 30 off was a super bonus. Even without it, I'd make this a lite bites, communal, hang out if I were in the area more often.
author: Kim N.

description:
Came back today and had a much better experience! I had reservations, still waited a few minutes but nothing too bad. Today I got a table instead of the communal seating and it wasn't as loud, and we had more privacy. I was much happier this time around.

Items
Pear bruschetta was good
Polenta- side dish, fried cubes pretty good!
Brussel sprouts- crispy and always good
Kale salad with faro- loved it- vinaigrette was awesome too!
Orecchiette- pasta dish is popular and hearty portion
Chicken entree dish I did not try but the person in my party did and it looked pretty good, it came with couscous- looked flavorful and hearty.
author: Azizi A.

description: Overpriced and trendy. It works for some but not me. It can get loud since you're packed pretty tight. My suggestion is to come here when it's less busy. At least you'd feel you got to enjoy the environment for the price you pay.
author: Joseph T.

description:
This place is pretty freaking bomb. The only thing I would advise against is the risotto. Despite all of their claims of "rustic" pasta and hand made, this is not what you think risotto actually is! 

I felt like they just threw a bunch of ... oatmeal or barley or something in there and called it risotto. Did not like.

However, everything else including the awesome iPad drinks menu, was great! 

I made a hastily reservation here for dinner on Saturday as we were in a cab from a long day of drinking at a spirits festival. I guess I got lucky because right when we walked in, they said no more walk in's for the night! Sheesh. Crazy. 

I loved their salumi plate, their version of a bruschetta was also really delicious and we got the famed duck fat brussels sprouts which were definitely very, very good and lived up to the hype. I guess if you come here, make a reservation! I will want to come back to try one of their other "rustic pastas" since I was not a big fan of the risotto at all as it is not traditional and didn't even come in a traditional portion.
author: Lorrie M.

description: Delicious! Had a Caesar salad, fried brussel sprouts, and farrosotto (which is a farro risotto). Enjoyed it all. There are two Barbaccos side by side. This is the more casual of the two.
author: Melanie M.

description:
Food is great, service is great. Went with a party of four and ordered family-style and everyone loved everything. 

- The meatballs were amazing. 
- Suppli was amazing, very similar to deep-fried mac-n-cheese balls. 
- The squid with chili was excellent too; just the right amount of spice. 
- The braised chicken thighs were also really good, but I probably wouldn't order them again because, well, it's chicken and there are so many other good things on the menu to try. 
- The duck-fried brussels sprouts were all excellent.

We weren't able to finish everything and passed on dessert because we were so stuffed. 

Only thing I didn't like was the wine selection. We all ordered different wines, and I tasted them all, and none of them impressed me in the least. I didn't even finish my glass.
author: Evelyn C.

description:
Had an excellent meal here with family celebrating a special occasion. Everything we ordered was mouth watering delicious. Service was on point. And the prices for what you get are very very reasonable. Our fourth visit and we look forward to the next!!

Tips: the lasagna and gnocchi are to die for. Their ice creams are amazing. And their Brussels sprouts and bruschetta won't disappoint!
author: Heather K.

description:
I had low expectations since I've been to Perbacco.  

Jump right to the food:

- Jar. Corn and bell pepper jar was great. 
- Bruschetta.  Duck liver pâté bruschetta and anchovies bruschetta were average. 
- Pasta. I had the orecchiette (broccoli rabe, fennel sausage, and pecorino cheese) but swapped out the pasta for maccheroni. The pasta texture was great but it was a bit dry and under seasoned; probably why I shouldn't have swapped out.  Possibly.  Also had the miaccheroni alla chi, which seemed popular and was decent.
- Sides. Fried polenta was delicious. Brussels sprouts were too oily and burnt. 
- Dessert. Espresso panda cotta was just ok.

I would definitely come back and try the other dishes; even the ones that weren't great were at least interesting.  Great value and location.  Also need to try them for lunch.
author: Erika C.

description:
I usually end up regretting my last minute decisions, but this last minute decision was one I'm glad I took!

Called in on Saturday around 5:15pm before the place opened for dinner and asked them if I could make a reservation asap. The woman booked me for a 7:15pm reservation. I had a 8pm comedy show to attend around Nob Hill and 7:15pm was cutting it close but I went with my gut (and my growling stomach) and took the reservation anyways.

Went in around 6:45pm and luckily got seated at the bar around 7pm. Aside from the casual but modern ambiance, the food was deeeeelissshhh! I'm so bummed I didn't take pictures, but I cannot forget how delectable the dishes tasted on my palette.

My friend and I ordered the brussel sprouts, seared ahi tuna (fish of the day), mussels, and the tagliata. We told our waiter we were kind of in a rush and seriously, all our food came out within 15min!

BRUSSEL SPROUTS ($5)= my fellow yelpers were not joking when it came to these veggies cooked in duck fat. Super rich, almost tooooo rich, but definitely a must try!

SEARED AHI TUNA ($24) = it was like two sticks of butter. The knife cut through the meat like butter and it melted in my mouth like butter. Uhm, YUM. The sauteed bell peppers paired well with the fish too.

MUSSELS ($12) = I took forever to decide if I wanted this or not and I'm so glad I went for it. The mussels sank in a beautiful garlic and wine sauce. Super light yet very tasty. The toasted bread on the side was not enough for me to soak up all that leftover juice that I looooooved. I'm definitely ordering two bowls the next time I come back.

TAGLIATA ($19)= my friend ordered this and I only took a bite of the perfectly cooked medium rare steak. Even though I barely ate it, the keywords: perfect, medium rare, and steak should say enough about this dish

Aside from me dropping my menu, napkin, and utensils several times, my overall first experience at Barbacco was four-stars-fantastic (5 stars if i had enough time for dessert) and for those who are wondering... yes, I made it to show on time to see the opening act :)
author: Margaret W.

description:
This place is fine. The service was strange and we felt like more of an imposition. 

The lasagna was excellent. The starters were good. The rest of the pasta dishes our table had were good, but nothing that we would rave about. The prices are very reasonable.
author: Nicole R.

description: Apparently Barbacco's menu changes, but there are some dishes that are there consistently. We tried the beef stew, octopus, the seasonal stonefruit salad, & their famous orecchiette pasta. Everything was really good, but the two dishes that really stood out to me were the stonefruit salad & the octopus. I'd definitely order them both again. However, fair warning, the  stonefruit salad doesn't contain many greens. It does offer an abundance of summer fruit though.
author: Cici A.

description:
The meatballs are absolutely disgusting! I went with 7 coworkers and 3 of us ordered the meatballs after the server's recommendation. None of us (who had meatballs) finished our dishes because we thought it was terrible. 

The meatballs: 4 giant, fatty, rubbery and disgusting hunks of meat with some tomato sauce glopped on top.
author: Laurence S.

description: This place is awesome.  I really enjoy the food here and the ambience.
author: David S.

description:
LOVE this place! 
Yes it's a treat for lunch, medium price. 
Get yo sugar daddy to take you here. 

*delicious bruschetta 
*BEST LASAGNA ever 
*brussel sprouts  rule 
*great small plates 
*great wine list 
*always busy, make a reservation! 

Minus one star because they should make their lasagna year round. Also hostesses are hit or miss, sometimes snotty.
author: Amy P.

description:
This. Meal. Was. Redic.
Here it is laid out dish by dish (with commentary of course!)

Starters:
-Spreadable salami (!!!! So good. Who knew something that looked like cat food could be that delicious)
-Chef's selection of house made salumi (Cured meats are always a winner)

2 Salads:
-duck conserva / baby spinach / onion
     stone fruit / ricotta salata  (Duck salad actually works! Great mix)
-rucola / radicchio / parmigiano reggiano (simple salad)

Main Men:
-farrotto - farro "risotto" / roasted mushrooms
spinach / parmigiano reggiano ('Take more than you should when it gets passed around, even when people are looking' would be a good way to put it)

-polpette - Sicilian meatballs with raisins and
pine nuts / braised chard / tomato sugo (Great meatball! This might have been my first meatball made with lots of Italian sausage. Sicilian meatball...I think you have a new best friend)

-orecchiette -  broccoli rabe
fennel sausage / pecorino cheese (solid)

-brussels sprouts fried in duck fat / capers
anchovy / red wine vinaigrette (whaaaaaat. Let's just say there were conversations for days about how good these were.)

Seriously good meal. The service was spot on and the ambiance was trendy/cool. Would go back tonight if I could. Get here.
author: Drew A.

description:
Make sure to make reservations. It makes everything easier.

This place is always buzzing as it's in the financial district and is located to the fancier sister restaurant, Perbacco. The seating situation is always a bit cramped, but their food is good! And prices are reasonable.

They have a Tuscan menu going on and we ordered off that. I had the Pinci and my SO had the cod. The Pinci was really good. I'm a sucker for homemade pasta and the meat was very tender. The cod... Well, my bf destroyed it. Careful for some bones, but the fish was so well cooked, everything just fell apart. It was flaky but juicy and so so good. The potatoes that came with the fish were also soft and well flavored.

I'll be coming here more often :)
author: Mina Y.

description: Tried three different bruschette (tomato, prosciutto, and pate), and all three were great.  For my main, I got the chitarra with Sicilian meatballs.  The pasta had the perfect texture, the sauce was spicy and flavorful, and the meatballs were juicy.  And the portions were very big.  Considering the availability on a Saturday night, the delicious food, and the incredibly reasonable prices, we'll definitely be coming back here in the future.
author: Simon L.

description:
I had a bad experience at Barbacco.  I was all set for my girlfriends birthday party. I had flowers delivered, a cake delivered and reservations in advance.  I expressly told Michael that our party was for 10-12.   He assured me I would have the table by the window up front, that way there would be additional seating to accomodate our entire party.  When we all arrived at 9pm, he switched me for another table (not the one I was promised) and told me "Sorry" ... I said the new table was too small and only holds 8, he said, again "sorry" and I said well, Sorry is not going to work .. I need to seat all 12 of our guests who have driven a long way to come here on my very important night .. and he just would not budge.  We ended up having to leave and go to another restaurant.  It was a disaster.  

Bottom line, be careful when making a dinner reservation here.  You might get burned like I did.
author: Paul R.

description:
Went here for dinner during a business trip.
Trendy little place with mostly what appeared to be mostly office friends grabbing a bite to eat after work.
I went in extremely under dressed but still received exceptional service.
I had some type of past dish with shredded pork, and it was one of the best Italian dished I have ever had.  The ice cream is great too.
Great service, pricing, and food. 
You can't go wrong with that.
author: Andrew L.

description:
I really enjoyed my meal here! My friend and I shared 3 bruschettes, our own plates, and brussel sprouts.

3 Bruschette
- Roasted peaches/ Prosciutto = the best one, the perfect mix of salty/sweet to pair off with creamy and crunchy. I would definitely get 3 of these
- CHicken liver Pate/Balsamic Braised Onions = this was okay, second best
- Charred Spring Onion, Ricotta, Toasted Almonds = By this time, we basically wished we got 3 peach ones..

Brussel Sprouts in duck fat - delicious and smelled oh-so-good

I got the Pancherri - love the sauce and thought the portion was just right! 

My friend got the Tagliata - flat iron steak, this was quite tasty

Portions are a bit small but I would still go back again.
author: Joyce M.

description:
I came here with a friend of mine to celebrate my birthday (although we didn't tell them that).
Arriving to the restaurant, he and I were seated immediately.
We ordered an appetizer (the roasted octopus and the prosciutti *don't remember which one*) and our waiter was very nice to us.
The appetizer came on time for us and it was delicious. We weren't rushed to order our entrees while dining.
It was slightly busy while we were there but not cramped or loud (which was nice) because I was able to enjoy the conversation we were having.

After ordering our dinner, it came to us in a timely manner. 
The waiter didn't come up to us while we ate to see how everything was (I hate when you have a mouth full of food and they ask that), so that was refreshing.

After dinner we had dessert.
I remember my friend had the vanilla ice cream with honeycomb and I had their seasonal sorbet (I think it was grapefruit with lavender. I remember the lavender and it being citrusy) and we loved it.

It was after closing when we had our desserts but we were so busy in conversation, that we didn't realize that we were the only ones left.
It was very relaxing that we didn't have to be forced out or told that they were closing. They let us enjoy our night and that's why I give this place 5 stars. Not just for the delicious food, but for the people that served us.
author: Marilynn S.

description: Business Trip - Very inexpensive Italian food! I got the lasagna and I was super impressed. However, customer service was not the best.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
Great spot for the location and price. Used to go here all the time for work lunches / dinners. Some really good options at a very reasonable price, but can get busy in the evenings so make sure to make a res.

Highlights:
 - Orecchiette pasta (especially when done with the pesto sauce)
 - Pork Ragu noodle dish
 - The Buschetta
 - The Sicilian meatballs

Note: they used to do the Mussels in a delicious red sauce, but have since redone the dish and removed the tomato from the sauce, making it less tasty than before (but still decent).
author: Eli B.

description:
Excellent lunch spot with creative menu and friendly service.

Stopped in at the height of lunch rush on a Friday afternoon and was seated quickly at their sushi bar style bar, despite a packed crowd. First thing I noticed when I opened the menu was brussel sprouts cooked in duck fat, anchovies, capers, and vinaigrette. WOW. 

Team service was quick and very friendly. Porchetta sandwich was excellent. It's served with greens, which pair well with the hefty sandwich.

I really enjoyed the food, service, and the hip room that makes great use of the smallish space.

Highly recommend.
author: Evan F.

description: Had the orecchiette (nice portion, btw) and a Prohibition beer. Outstanding. With the cost of a decent lunch around FiDi (including take-out places) costing between $10 and $20 nowadays, why not at least get a nice, excellent, hot meal?
author: Maximillian M.

description:
Hip and modern set-up.  Located in the FiDi, it was buzzing w/work suits even though it was a Sat nite and the crowd seemed a bit older.  We were brought all the way to the back of the restaurant and seated at the bar.  We think this is where the delinquents are seated.  Just an observation.  iPads are used for drink orders.  Boy what a mistake on their end.  We hit the "home" button and looked at what else their iPad had to offer.  We clicked on "Notepad" and proceeded to leave unnecessary profane notes. Totally necessary now that I think about it.

Gonna cut the bullsht and just tell you what you MUST get should you come here.

brussels sprouts fried in duck fat/capers/anchovy/red wine vinaigrette - This.  THIS!!  Growing up I didn't eat brussels sprouts cuz I thought they were yucky poo-poo and a waste of plate.  I now know that it's because they were never fried in duck fat.  Geez, mom.  Get it together.  I mean really.

Another restaurant crossed off my non-bucket list.  Glad I got my priorities straight.

Peace brethren
author: Rho T.

description:
Came here for a business dinner with the colleagues and oh boy, did we close the establishment.
After maybe 8 bottles of wine, one bottle of very expensive champagne, The Maitre' D had to open it for us, most of us were so drunk, we don't know how we all got home.
We ordered their appetizers that came in jar which were delicious. Tried the brussel sprouts cooked in duck fat and that was superb. I ordered the chicken thighs with eggplant and it was perrrrfeccctt! Just what I wanted for dinner. Their steak was very good as well.
My friends ordered dessert but I skipped it. They looked good though.
Friendly service, very attentive. Ofcourse after spending about $1500 who wouldn't right?????
author: Claudine V.

description:
While I've heard a lot of good things about the food at both Perbacco and Barbacco, I never knew that Barbacco was such a good deal!  Great food at fair prices?  Can't argue with that!

After my friend and I both decided on trying the "Italy vs. France" flight of wine (their wine menu is on an iPad!), we decided to order a bunch of things to share:

- "Italy vs. France" wine flight (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Wd5ho0_FKk9n7uV8pSCYIg?select=lTathI4o7runei-ak0acqA) - a red and white from each Italy and France
- Ascolane (fried olives stuffed with pork) (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Wd5ho0_FKk9n7uV8pSCYIg?select=MYTa5TN7IDsZx23ma5S-UQ) - I'm not a huge fan of olives, but these were pretty good.  The pork wasn't dry, and I liked how the taste of olives was kept mild since it was stuffed with meat and fried.
- Cured Sardine Bruschette (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Wd5ho0_FKk9n7uV8pSCYIg?select=oXMLDQyuCfBMv8exljb-SQ) - the best overall of the bruschette we tried.  I generally like pate more, but this one had more to it.  It was done well, the combination of flavors was more unique, and I liked how everything came together.
- House Cured Lardo Bruschette (see above) - meh.  Lardo can be hit and miss for me, and I felt like the flavor needed to be a little more assertive and distinct.  It just tasted fatty, and it was hard to get past that.
- Duck Liver Pate Bruschette (see above) - maybe it's because I have an affinity for pate, but I thought it tasted great and there was a generous amount.  The caramelized balsamic onions added a nice touch to the pate's richness.
- Orecchiette ("Little Ear" pasta with Broccoli Rabe and fennel sausage) (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Wd5ho0_FKk9n7uV8pSCYIg?select=8kF7Z475Pe_jWti2kGVYPA) - simple (my friend and I both wondered if we could make it at home), but I liked it.  For me, the sausage and broccoli rabe were a great combination, and the dish gave me that "comfort food" feel.
- Polpette (Sicilian meatballs with raisins and pine nuts) (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Wd5ho0_FKk9n7uV8pSCYIg?select=O83LT8sD3woPclwvCQQHHQ) - the waiter described them as "fluffy" and I can see what he meant.  Definitely more light than hearty.  They were just okay to me, but the pine nuts and raisins were a little different. 
- Espresso Panna Cotta (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Wd5ho0_FKk9n7uV8pSCYIg?select=YpFddV16TJTEp7tQVLSZQg) - pretty good.  The espresso flavor was strong enough to know it's there, but subtle enough where it wasn't overpowering.  Not bad to me, but I don't get panna cotta that often either.
- Spiced Pear Cake (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Wd5ho0_FKk9n7uV8pSCYIg?select=Ox847whjO-CCc57dO1iRTw) - only tried a bite of it and I thought it was just okay.  The cake wasn't as spiced as I had hoped.

Even though our bill came out to about $120 after tax and tip, the food is actually a really good value.  Half of our total was made up of the flights of wine ($28 each), and so the food portion came out to only about $25 each.  Definitely will keep it in mind for future dinners, and if Barbacco is any indication of what Perbacco is like, I'll be there a lot sooner than later.
author: Mike L.

description:
Two words: Brussels sprouts.

The worst part about Barbacco is that the secret is out. I met a friend for dinner and, because of its popularity, we had to share a table with another party (it's so crowded!) - even with reservations. Also, it was really loud and I often found it hard to hear her. WHAT? 

I had the bruschette with olives and tomatoes - it was delicious. Be warned that you only get one slice, so if you're dining with a friend, or are particularly hungry, order more!

For my entree, I chose the paccheri. Delicious! And because we split a side dish, I couldn't finish it all. 

Speaking of that side dish, go there now and order the brussels sprouts. I don't even like them and I could.not.stop eating those suckers! It's been over a month and I'm still dreaming about them.

My friend and I split the chocolate polenta cake and it was yummy.
author: Melissa C.

description:
After reading all the great reviews on yelp decided to give this place a try, we were very disappointed with the place. The only thing good about the experience was the bar tender. 

We did a walk in, the hostess said 20 mins for a table so we waited turns out they seated us at bar without even asking us if it was ok, since we were hungry we decided to just go with it. 

We orded cauliflower as appetizer and 2 main entrees.  We got our entrees before the appetizers, and the flavors were very disappointing as well. It's an Italian restaurant, but have no Ceaser salad on the menu and won't serve even upon request. 

Overall, we will defiantly avoid this restaurant in future. There was a lot of people to be Wednesday, but most of them seem to just come to hangout at the bar after work.
author: Rehnish P.

description: I have come here before and have come back several years later. Food is mediocre. Using COD as fish and some specials that are mushy and lacking good flavor. Brussels sprouts were great but other thank not that not really worth the wait. Manager changed our reservations without telling us which was odd.
author: Matt S.

description: I just wanted to say "thank you" to the staff at this place. As usual, the food was great but the service was awesome. We walked in without a reservation on a Thursday night with two kids and they sat us at the bar with room for a stroller and high chair. The hostess also brought our 3 y/o paper and pens (without us asking) as well as water in a plastic cup without any trouble. We had a nice dinner overall and it was refreshing to see a downtown restaurant that was so easy-going and classy at the same time.
author: Nina L.

description:
The food at Barbacco is overly laden with fat and grease.  It seems to be the case in every dish.  I had the worst stomach ache after having dinner here.  In addition to the fat concentration, salt was in excess.  While the restaurant is well designed, it is packed. The waiters interrupt your conversation in order to push you out as quickly as possible.  

Food - no go.
Service - no go.
Atmosphere - no go.

So sad that Barbacco failed.  I was really looking forward to enjoying a meal here :(
author: Ali B.

description:
Make a reservation. Tell them specifically you don't want a bar seat or else you'll be seated close to a stranger and bump elbows with them constantly.

Everything I've tried on the menu is literally delicious. I don't think you can go wrong with this place. It's an upscale place with reasonable prices. During my two times here I had the bruschetta, orrecchiete pasta, brussel sprouts, risotto, and various white wines.

I would recommend getting bruschette as an appetizer. I had the Duck Liver Pate, Balsamic Onion Marmellata, proscuitto & peaches, and a fresh tomato one which I don't see on the menu anymore. They were all delcious!!

Anyways, go here and try anything that sounds good. Most likely it will be superb!
author: Jenann P.

description:
We were looking for a place to celebrate my husband's birthday last Saturday (06/04/16). Our very dear friend, who is a chef in SF, gave us a list of places he would recommend trying out. Of a list of 10 places, I picked Barbacco and was very excited to try the food! We had reservations for 9:30pm and the place was full. Service was nice, but the food was very disappointing. Between me, my husband, and two friends we had: the CHEF'S SELECTION OF SALUMI - our table enjoyed it, BRUSCHETTA - fava beans were overcooked to me and it was melting in my mouth (didn't like it), ARUGULA AND RADICCHIO salad - it was under seasoned and not much flavor at all, 
BEAN MINESTRA - it was good, LASAGNA BOLOGNESE - my husband really liked it, ORECCHIETTE - not much flavor AT ALL (this dish was the one that got my attention when picking the place to have dinner and it was very disappointing. It was super bland in good flavors but it was over salted! Pasta was undercooked too), FARROTTO - delicious!, ZITI - disappointing! (Pasta was undercooked too, it was SUPER salty (couldn't finish it), if it had 2 pieces of eggplant it was already a lot (wanted more), and didn't had much flavor besides being over salted, "PEPOSO" - delicious! , CAULIFLOWER - it was good, BABY FAVA BEANS - horrible :(  (it had no salt at all, overcooked, not much flavor!), and CHOCOLATE NEMESIS CAKE - AMAZING!!!! (Would definitely go back for it!)
Overall, my experience wasn't good going to Barbacco that day. Oversalted dishes and not much flavor was what I got. I really want to go back and try it again another day and hopefully, it will be much better.
author: Flavia S.

description:
Man oh man I wanna come back here for dinner! 

My coworker suggested we try this place for lunch because she said all her friends had good reviews for this place. It was around 1 when we went so it wasn't overly packed. We ordered this spinach? pasta with bolognese sauce and 3 bruschetta along with brussle sprouts cooked with duck fat. Lets start with the bruschetta. I got the chicken liver pate and it was really good, but super heavy. Something that I could share with someone but my coworker ordered the same thing with a peach and prosciutto bruschetta. I didn't get to try that one but it's ok. Hah.

The pasta verde...oh my was that delicious! I'm still dreaming about it now. I think it's one of the best pastas I've had and I've been to Italy! (maybe cause in Italy...we were being cheap college students..hah) It was heavy but it was so good that I couldn't stop picking at it!

I can't wait to go back for lunch AND dinner because I wanna try everything. Amazing!
author: Denise L.

description: It's been a couple years since I have been here. I mainly didn't come back because of the communal seating which I found inconsistent with the goals of a business lunch. But a colleague last week made a reservation here for us, and I was pleasantly surprised to see they had changed the seating such that two (or more) people can have a functional business lunch. Food was quite good. Atmosphere is a bit noisier and less upscale than its nearby sister, Perbacco, but prices are friendlier, and I guess that is the point -- to offer two different types of restaurants in the financial district. I will happily go back, particularly for a lunch with co-workers. To impress a client, will still lean toward Perbacco.
author: Fred E.

description: My friend wanted to go for dinner..I was not thrilled over the pasta selections and couldn't decide. The waitress raved about the spaghetti with mussels, ok fine I'll get that. My friend ordered the homemade pasta with meatballs dish. The meatball pasta dish was the best thing we ate! Spaghetti total failure. Waitress said it would be spicy she said a 7 out of 10. Scared me I said take out the chilli leave the spicy meat...It was a zero in spicy and flavor. She said the meatball dish was a 5 out of 10 in spicy...It say it was a 1 or 2 ha! Bruschettas: prosciutto with peach best one, mushrooms 2nd best and 3rd was ricotta and almonds.  They were all good and layered with flavor. Fried polenta was perfection must get.
author: Karen T.

description:
This place was great! Loved the iPads for each table, would have loved if it was more interactive though.

The burrata appetizer was to die for, super tasty! The pasta dishes were very flavorful and fresh, but nothing beat the appetizer. 

The special martini drink that they had that night was also good, very fruity. 

This is a good place for a nice weekend dinner.
author: Molly S.

description:
Amazing Brussels sprouts!

Came here and decided to get food to go after a long day at work. I'm glad I decided to try their food! I had the Fried Brussels Sprouts which was amazing! For one, it's fried in duck fat! It's also served in a tangy vinegary dressing.

What a perfect start before digging into Roasted Mushrooms Pasta- it was delicious, creamy but not too overwhelming. The mushrooms were tasty and perfectly cooked.

Service was friendly and helpful. They even gave a cookie to take with me. Score!
author: Roehl A.

description:
Ordered oxtail and a pasta dish, chicken liver pate and cheese plate.

everything was good but not spectacular. given the price, i'd say its fair, but not exceptional in SF.

very nice staff though.
author: Danielle A.

description:
Food: 3
Decor: 4
Service: 4

Came here for dinner and got the table right next to the door.

1. sweet summer corn / cherry tomatoes / basil 5
~Okay. I really liked the individual ingredients, but the presentation was rather disappointing, and I was hoping it'd be more interesting.

2. orecchiette - "little ears" / cavolo nero 13
fennel sausage / pecorino cheese
~Pretty good. Pasta was cooked al dente, and the sausage was quite tasty.

3. brown butter "shortcake" 6
whipped house-made ricotta, seasonal berries,
~Pretty good. Ricotta was quite tasty (thought it was ice cream), and all the components worked well together.

Service was good, although I had to ask for an extra pair of spoons.
author: David L.

description: Had no reservation. Very friendly and helpful with the selection of an evening red wine. The hostess is great. The feel of this modern dinning experience is welcoming. Visiting San Francisco for what feels like the first time. This place will be one to come to. My comments on our food experience is to come
author: Elizabeth F.

description:
I've been a fan of Perbacco for quite a while now, so I was thrilled to learn that Perbacco would be opening a more streamlined concept called Barbacco, just 2 doors down. I've now been to Barbacco at least 5 times since it opened in early 2010. 

I like to think that Barbacco is the more casual, hip, and trendy younger sibling to Perbacco, where you can get similarly inspired, highly refreshing Italian cuisine at far lower prices, and at portions that, while smaller, are still big enough to share with others.

Indeed, Barbacco's more affordable menu encourages you to try many different things and share them with others. The casual layout - a long bar area as well as plenty of communal high tables - further promotes an open, social vibe. I've really enjoyed the duck liver pate and summer squash bruschetta, the gorgonzola with chestnut honey, the fried brussels sprouts, the flat iron steak, and even the Silician meatballs.

I agree that the wine list on the iPads feels like more of a gimmick, if only because the service here is truly warm, engaging, and helpful - so you can get a far better suggestion from your server than you would slowly fumbling through the iPad menus.

All in all, highly satisfying food that's inspired by the far pricier Perbacco next door, but at far more reasonable portions and prices, plus a lively, casual, and engaging atmsophere. You can't go wrong either here or at older sibling Perbacco.
author: Vincent L.

description: I came here with my husband on xmas eve night. Was seated right away without any reservation was a plus but it took good 5 + min for our waiter to come by... Food was ok... nothing spectacular. We had cream of mushroom (soup of the day) , faro risotto, Brussel sprouts, flat iron steak and the chicken then shared butterscotch gelato. I thought the flavor here is very mild, I always needed pinch on salt... except for the steak, it was tender and very tasty. I'm little judgmental when it comes to restaurants that leave salt & pepper shakers on the table and complimentary cold bread with side of cold hard butter is a turn off...
author: Kaori T.

description:
Barbacco was on my bookmarks for a bit and I finally got to try it! My coworker had also tried Barbacco before and she recommended it. Barbacco is extremely busy during lunch time. My coworker had made reservations for 11:30AM right when it opened. We were the first ones there and within five minutes, half the restaurant was already packed! Another ten minutes, the restaurant was all packed and there was already a line waiting outside! So glad, we had made reservations! 

What I thought was really cool was that their drinks list was presented on an Ipad. I had the Orecchiette ($12) and my coworker had the lasagna bolognese ($13). The Orecchiette came with fennel sausage . It was a yummy pasta dish and it was not too heavy. I got to try a bit of my coworker's lasagna and it was so delicious and tasty. 

Service was great and we were both satisfied with our dishes.
author: Philana C.

description:
Ughs. I want to believe we just mis-ordered. I was excited to try Barbacco.  

We made reservations and were seated right away, love when that happens.  One issue with this - they sat us at the bar.  I feel that when you have made a res in advance, you should be seated at an actual table. Love the open kitchen concept, but I'd rather comfortably sit and talk with my company. 

We tried the beets, shrimp, brussels, and three of the bruschetta. The beets were a little ho-hum, tasty, but something I could have made at home.  The shrimp had a very peculiar texture, almost mushy, which was a little off-putting.  I did really enjoy the brussels, hard not to when cooked in duck fat :) The bruschetta was also tasty too - the  bread was perfectly cooked and you could taste every ingredient.

We had great service and I loved the vibe, but would have preferred a table. Happy to try this place again and explore more of the menu.
author: Brianna M.

description: not great service and OK food... we sat there for 10 minutes before flagging someone down for water and a menu, they were impatient with that and questions about the menu, then was disappointed in my dish (I had the ziti al forno)
author: Valerie B.

description: Went here for lunch. Had a reservation and were told our "table"  was two seats at the counter.  They did seat us at a table, but got a bit of attitude like of course you reserve space at a counter.  Service was very strange. Immediately brought water without asking (a non-no in a drought).    Told server we were sharing a salad, brings us one plate. Salad came and my companion and I were not even sure if it was dressed. Incredibly salty and don't think it was from the anchovies that were supposed to be in it as there didn't seem to be any.  Brought unsweetened iced tea, had to ask for sweet and low. Brings me a dispenser with two packets in it. Did enjoy my pasta with lamb. however.  Better casual, lower priced places downtown.
author: Dennis N.

description:
Realistically a 3.5 because most of the times I've been I actually enjoy it quite a lot, but the one time I ordered the corn rigatoni was a huge bust. Avoid that dish like the plague if you aren't a fan of cheese. Even my friend who doesn't mind cheese found the dish to be completely overpowered by it. Despite that blemish, the menu as a whole boasts many worthy options.

In terms of appetizers:
+ 'nduja stuffed dates / bacon spicy tomato sugo
+ roasted pear / prosciutto di parma bruschette

For entrees:
+ paccheri / rustic pork ragu : the al dente tube noodles are infused with flavor from the ragu
+ "angry mussels" / 'nduja / potatoes / garlic / chili : just enough of a spicy kick to give the dish more heartiness
+ flat iron steak tagliata / roasted sunchokes / onion / green garlic: not an extremely large portion, but the quality of the meat is good 

Finally dessert:
+espresso panna cotta: the right amount of creamy sweetness to end a meal

The restaurant is modern and trendy without becoming snobbish. Service here was prompt and attentive and they offer "orange" as a category of wine on their wine list. I suggest giving it a try if you're adventurous.
author: Charlotte Z.

description: The food is unbelievably salty... and I'm a person who loves sprinkling salt on bread, butter, veggies. I was really looking forward to the brussel sprouts but they're fried and came out leafy-edge charred and dripping with oil. Really wasn't what I was expecting. It's unfortunate as Barbacco has a great night-out vibe.
author: Christina J.

description:
Barbacco has reminded me that Solid Italian Food still exists out West. 

First time here and I was lucky enough to taste a super diverse spread since it was a dinner set up for a large group. I actually had no idea that the menu had been pre-set so I was pleasantly surprised when the starters came out.

Surprise Starter(s):
First a variety of house made Salumi, ranging from mild to spicy, were brought out, followed by a spreadable salumi served in a jar and accompanied by toasted bread. I'm not sure, but I think it was raw or it looked raw, but DELICIOUS and Spicy! A first for me, and I devoured it. We also munched on grilled veggies and a variety of cheese. A solid starter it was! 

Next Up: Insalata
First salad was duck served with greens and fruit. It was excellent and super flavorful, my favorite of the two. Salad number 2 was Rucola and Radicchio, a super traditional choice and served authentically with Parmigiano and Olive Oil. 
    
Mains: We had three to to choose from!
1.Risotto made with farro (instead of Arborio rice), with mushrooms, parmigiano cheese and greens, maybe spinach or kale. Superb.

2. Orecchiete pasta with broccoli rabe and pecorino cheese. I was officially wow'd with this dish, because this is a Barese dish from the South of Italy and it was served to perfection, so perfect, that I think even my boyfriends Nonna would approve. I was transported back to Italy in one bite. 

3. Polpette: Which are meatballs. These were good, but not the winners for me. They were a little dense for my taste. 

Side dish was brussel sprouts. Everyone loved these, but these were not the highlight of the evening for me. I Found them on the salty side.

Dessert: Gelato. Pretty good.

In conclusion, Barbacco was excellent. It is officially on my list of favorite Italian restaurants, offering up some solid traditional and authentic fare from a variety of regions in Italy. The service was top notch, friendly and attentive. Oh, I forgot to mention the red and white wine that was poured all evening. Both were perfectly paired with the food. 

Tutto era buonissimo e saporissimo! Grazie Barbacco. Bravo!
author: Isabella J.

description:
My son who lives in SF took me here for lunch, which in itself is so special! We ordered the Chicories salad,  Brussels sprouts, and Moliterno cheese as appetizers. All were very good. We had them replace the Gorgonzola on the salad with goat cheese and it worked great. I'd have preferred the Brussel sprouts to be roasted vs fried but ... The Moliterno cheese was of good quality and I loved the wafer thin toasted bread it came with. We had some house bread with olive oil. I tend to judge the quality of the restaurant by the olive oil they serve, and this one got an 'A' grade!!

We split the Orecchiette "little ears" pasta for a main. We found it extremely salty and asked for it to be remade, which they very happily did. They said they would make it without salt and it was just perfect, as I guess the salt from the cheese and the meat was plenty enough. 

Service was excellent and seems like all the wait staff worked well together. The young lady who greeted us as we entered the restaurant seemed to be a bit stressed out, but then it was peak lunch time so understandable. Overall a great dining experience and I'd definitely go back.
author: Smita S.

description:
I have always enjoyed every visit I have made to Barbacco, fun little place whether on a date or with friends.  My favorite spot is sitting at the bar, I've always gotten great beer/wine suggestions, but this is not a full bar... you need to go next door to their sister restaurant for that cocktail while you wait.  

I love small plates, I love the opportunity to share so I can try a little bit of everything.  The bruschette is always a great place to start with some nuts or a cheese/salumi plate.  I usually ask for the latest suggestions, and can't recall ever being disappointed with my meal and I do specifically recall a couple phenomenal lamb dishes in the past.  And I always get the brussels sprouts.
author: Nivita S.

description:
I made a reservation here for Valentine's Day around 7-7:30 PM. We were seated promptly and the water ran through the specials. The restaurant has a nice ambience with semi-dim lighting and asymmetrical tables. 
The staff was very attentive and courteous but did rub me the wrong way when I asked for bread. They stated that I needed to order first before I could ask for it.

Anyway on to the food!
We ordered Brussel Sprouts fried in duck fat. 9/10 ( i wish it was a bit crispier)
A squid ink penne 9/10, great seafood flavor and pasta texture
My girlfriend had the Handcut pasta they are known for, which had a great texture 8/10 but was overpowered with cheese.
Pickled cauliflower 10/10. I kid you not, I wanted to order 6 of these things so I could have it with each part of my meal. It was so flavorful and light.
author: Michael W.

description: A good value Italian restaurant. The pasta (orrichiete) was a little thick for my liking, but the portions were mountainous and well priced. Will probably drop by again at some point.
author: Fi M.

description:
We had a great meal here.  We started with the burrata and some bruschette.  Both were good and the serving of burrata was generous.  I had the beef cheek with polenta and my GF had the chitarra.  Both were good, but I thought the Chitarra was very good.  Again, the serving of chitarra was generous and the meatballs were great.  

Even though we sat at the long counter, the dinner and experience were great.
author: Larry L.

description:
this place was fantastic! i ate my birthday dinner here with my guy and we were both impressed by the quality of the food. the fifth star is missing because the service was a little slow and our server wasn't the most attentive for that style of restaurant; but overall everything was really great.

we were seated right away (on a busy friday night) and the style of the restaurant is really fresh and modern with a cozy italian feel. the tables are close together but it doesn't feel uncomfortably crowded. 

i started with the soup on special: a vegetarian roasted tomato soup with fennel and a pesto drizzle. it was definitely no ordinary tomato soup; it had a very smokey and hearty flavor that left me very satisfied. for my entree i ordered the orecchiette without the meat. it came with a very hearty kale pesto and was very filling for a basic pasta dish. my guy ordered the roasted octopus and shared my pasta. we were both stuffed by the end of the meal and he was satisfied with the octopus' flavor/texture. 

i would recommend this restaurant to anyone in SF looking for a special date night or just an especially delicious italian meal in general.
author: Rachele A.

description:
Yes, I am a fan of this simple yet sophisticated eatery that prepares and plates hearty Italian cuisine.

Dishes I like and recommend: beets or roasted cauliflower; arugula and radicchio or endive salads; paccheri, orecchiette pastas, or farro risotto; as mains pollo al mattone or braciole; don't forget the sides of fried brussels sprouts; and any dessert on offer.

Yeah, I'm a fan.
author: Jay D.

description:
Barbacco is definitely one of my favorite places in the city to have dinner with friends or even for a date night. It has a chill, casual and relaxed atmosphere, but nice enough where people still dress up and it's not exceedingly loud. 

I've been here a few times now, and always get the below:

- Brussel sprouts: definitely one of the best I've had ever. Sooo flavorful and not overly bitter (the way some brussel sprouts are). The flavor just pops in your mouth! 
- 'nduja: this is a great appetizer for folks to share. They're generous with the crostini and it has a really spice/kick to it that I enjoy.
- Pasta: I always get one of their pasta dishes because I love pasta and I think they cook it really well. The sauces are always tasty and the pasta is al dente - just how I like it. The portions aren't huge, so if you're a small eater like me, it's just right. If you're in a group I recommend ordering a few so you eat to your heart's content. 

Definitely a must go! Parking is also convenient - never had issues for dinner.
author: Kimberly F.

description: I found a hair in my food!!! .... What they said?? Oh! Sorry, we will let know to the people from the kitchen!!!... Never again, only when I am bald!
author: Andrea A.

description:
The interior is nice, service is pretty fair. But I do not like communal tables, especially when you're trying to have a business lunch. I think it missed the point of a private meeting to discuss w/e it is you came there to discuss. Also its pretty packed inside so get there early or make a reservation.

No full bar - so that's too bad.

The sandwiches have good meet and bread. but they're too dry. Detrimental to any true sandwich lover. They need some type of dipping sauce or an aioli option. We asked for sauces and all they were able to provide was chili infused olive oil... not what I want on a sliced pork sandwich...

I have heard the meatballs are good.

FINALLY THIS IS IMPORTANT they have 8oz, yes 8oz, not 12 oz, but 8OZ diet coke bottles for $3 each. that is a rip off and to any true DC lover - completely unacceptable.

In conclusion - decent spot, but I would go elsewhere if you want a more private meeting or you are with a client.
author: Dakin G.

description:
Of all the restaurants in San Francisco this is my favorite place to celebrate my birthday! 
The mushroom risotto is something I crave. I believe I can eat it almost every day. I would have taken a photograph to show you the dish but I already started eating it the second it appeared on the table! The service is fabulous and the owner Umberto is the BEST. He comes by our table to check on us.

When I have a quiet moment I think of the delicious food here and when I'm planning to come back!
author: BJ S.

description: Went here with my friend from back home on a busy Friday night. Our waiter was incredibly attentive, and always asked if we needed anything. He also made some pretty good suggestions. We tried the lasagna bolognese (?) and the octopus thing... damn forgot what it's called but good stuff.
author: Fam A.

description:
Once again I'm having an incredible meal at Barbacco. The prices are so reasonable given the quality of the food. Where in SF can you get an amazing orecchiette with kale pesto and fennel sausage for $13? My roasted beet with hazel nuts and goat cheese was $5. Crazy low prices for a financial district resto.

Every time I eat here I sit at the bar and someone remembers me and greets me warmly. So unusual in SF. 

This is one of the best casual restaurants in SF!
author: R D.

description: Nice cheeses, and fish of the day. Great chocolate cake
author: Natalia D.

description:
Been a while since I had been at Barbacco.  Wifey, kids and I were wrapping up our visit to the Exploratorium and since we parked around here, thought we could grab an early dinner.  Was easily able to grab a 5:30 Saturday RSVP (yes, that is when we eat dinner now!).  First minor knock... the seats of the dining table areas (not the booths, but the chairs on the outside)... they had very low backs and were 'bouncy' due to the design (You'll understand when you see them).  Weren't very comfortable, and I had the sensation that I was going to tumble backward the whole time.

Anyhow, we ordered a medley of small apps, pasta mains.  Brussel sprout chips were delicious....as was the meatballs (the item that my wife always remembers to order there).  There was a spinach tortenelli type pasta dish (green pasta, as my girl called it!) which was also super tasty.  The tagiatelle (wide flat noodle) I believe in a ragu sauce was good... .although my little one couldn't eat it cause it had a slight spice kick to it.  And the pasta was a bit too al dente for me.  The burrata app was also a delight (We normally order burrata sides wherever we see them on the menu, and this one did not disappoint).

We ordered a small carafe of their cheapest white from their tap... which they were out of ... so ordered the cousin red.  Can't remember the exact name... something like 'Donkey and Goat'.  It was mediocre at best.

I won't go out of my way to go back to Barbacco.  But if I'm nearby, can easily see myself making a cameo dinner appointment there.
author: Dale K.

description:
We dined here again recently, and I'm holding at four stars--which actually reflects quite well on Barbacco!

They had changed up the menu (I'm suspecting seasonally, which is very cool) and had removed both the bruschetta and the stew that I so enjoyed last time, replacing them with... nothing even kind of vegan. However, our server went above and beyond the call of duty in not only pointing out what things could be changed to be vegan, but which menu items she would recommend as being still a satisfying flavor AND suggesting wine pairings.

They got rid of the iPad for wine ordering that I mildly teased in my last review, and I think that was good. Our server was incredibly knowledgeable about the wine and was a joy to speak with, something that we probably would have missed out on had we stayed with an iPad. She gave us a few samples to help us make our selection, and we ended up choosing a Valpolicella--something I basically never drink--that was perfect for both of our meals.

I really love Barbacco because with their location and sufficient reputation, I think they could coast, but I've never had anything less than a really delightful experience there, and this is coming from one of the most loathed dining demographics (vegan). I will happily go out of my way to eat here because there's just so much that I really enjoy about it.

**It's also a great choice for bringing out of towners and family because it's uniquely San Francisco, but not too "weird" and not too expensive. Try it, you'll like it!
author: Vivienne P.

description:
Made a weekday night reservation to celebrate a belated birthday and the host was very welcoming. They promptly seated us at the bar.

All items we ordered were delicious (brussell sprouts, orecchiette, bruschetta, and halibut).

When making the reservation, I requested if we ordered a dessert to add "Happy Birthday". While we did not order a dessert, the wait staff had already prepared a dessert on the house for us. This really topped off the night and shows great service.

I highly recommend Barbacco for its food, service, and atmosphere.
author: Brad T.

description:
When I think back to the incredible meal I had at Barbacco, my mouth still waters!

*Burrata on Crostini*
One bite of the Burrata cheese on the toasted French bread and I was in LOVE! Seriously, I can't recommend this enough if you haven't had the pleasure of trying Burrata cheese before! Burrata has a rich, buttery yet creamy flavor and soft texture which made for a perfect pairing with the crunchy crostini, arrugula and olive oil. 

*Paccheri Pasta with Rustic Pork Ragu*
Paccheri is a large-tube pasta and I enjoyed the light texture of the pasta, which wasn't as starchy or heavy as lasagna or penne. The serving sizes were quite generous and even though I was famished after missing lunch, I left the restaurant with half of the pasta dish that I could enjoy the next day. 

Barbacco offers some unique items, including house-cured salumi and 2-week-old olive oil imported directly from Italy.

Interestingly, Barbacco is a sister restaurant to Perbacco next door. The owners describe on their website that they wanted to create a "place with high energy and a convivial atmosphere, where our guests could share a table with friends as well as new acquaintances" and I believe they succeeded in doing just that!
author: Meghan L.

description:
It's Feb. 18th. Need a place for a cute date? Have a small birthday dinner to plan? Want to eat somewhere fabulous with a couple of your girl/guy friends? If you're looking for a great Italian place that's affordable and doesn't cost $20 a dish, look no further.

Delicious food with a hipster-y chill ambiance that seems to have perfuse in certain parts of SF.

My girlfriends and I got the infamous Brussell Sprouts that were infamous for a reason. Crunchy, oh-so-slightly fried with that hint of guilty pleasurable golden brown sheen.

I wasn't very hungry that night, so unfortunately, I was only able to finish a small entree, the local squid alla piastra. Chewy, flavorful, more please! Had I know that I was going to go to such a delicious restaurant (shame on me, should have checked Yelp beforehand!), I would have gladly ran some extra laps on the treadmill or ate very little throughout the day.

The menu is slightly overwhelming though - the uncultured me faced a lot of fancy words on that small piece of paper, I wanted to ask the waitress for the definition of all the plates, but she began to explain the menu as if we were five, so I opted out.
author: Mandy C.

description: We sat at the bar, which still felt cozy and intimate. Had 3 vegetables to start: the beets were not that spicy and cooked very well. Included white and red beets. The mushrooms had a little cheese on it with made them very savory. And the olives- there were so many olives, all types, mostly small ones, but some on stems and some big ones. If you're a fan of olives you'll love this plate, it's like a tour of olives. The brussel sprouts were excellent. The lasagna and meatballs were excellent. I haven't had meatballs that good since I was at the north end in Boston. The portion sizes were appropriate. Enough to get full without being too much. I'll definitely be back.
author: Stephen G.

description:
I had the tuscan chicken liver pate / balsamic braised onion and the orecchiette - "little ears" / cavolo nero fennel sausage / pecorino cheese.

The food was okay and the prices were fair but it just wasn't memorable for a 20 dollar meal.

For the bruchetta, the balsamic onion overtook the chicken live pasta.

The same issue occurred with the orechiette, the intense spinach flavors of the pasta sauce over took the the whole pasta dish. The sausage though evident, had not enough flavor to make it's presence on the dish.
author: Jackson P.

description:
I've come here many times over the last 3 years, largely for business lunches. I'm a fan of their food and have tried several of their salads, with my favorite go-tos being the brussels sprouts and the meatballs. Most recently, I tried the meat stew with polenta, which seemed more like a ragu on top of polenta than a stew, but no complaints here as it tasted rather good! 

Overall a good place for a business lunch, with prompt service and solid food.
author: Maria G.

description:
So many reviews; what more is there to say?  

Barbacco is the "affordable" priced meals so that's where my coworkers took me for lunch! Modern restaurant with IPADs as your menu list. So fetch! 

All I have to say is...DUCK SALAD and ROASTED BRUSSELS SPROUTS are a must try!

FYI - make reservations...even for lunch.
author: Diana M.

description:
3.5 stars!


I was really impressed by this place. It has a very sleek, classy interior. Everyone who worked there was very friendly and seemed to enjoy working there. 

One cool thing about this place was that they have part of the menu -- drinks, appetizers etc. -- on an iPad. I wish they would allow you to order from the iPad, that'd be a nice bonus. 

I ended up ordering a fish dish along with some tea. I really wanted to get a cocktail but unfortunately they didn't have that as a option. My fish was divine. My only complaint is that the fish was served with some really good green vegetable (I believe it was spinach) which when I took a bite of one particular piece I had to literally chew it for 2-3 minutes and I still couldn't get it small enough for me to swallow. So I had to resort to finding an old receipt in my purse to spit it into. But other than that, I didn't have any problems with that dish and was more than satisfied with my meal.  My friend ordered the Flank Steak which I took a bite of -- that was also delicious. 

For dessert, I had vanilla gelato with some chocolate sauce. They give you one scoop but it only costs $3 so I can't complain. I highly recommend it. I would go there just for that gelato. 



On a side note: For some reason the way that their paper menu was designed made it difficult for me to read. I found it to be aesthetically busy.
