author: Abena O.

description:
I'd give 3.5 to the food alone, but bump it up to 4 including service.  I came here last Friday for a nice(r) dinner and booked this place based on a friend's recommendation for 8 p.m.  The reservation was relatively easy to make.

When we came, there was a small gathering of people waiting in the lobby area, but we briskly walked past them and were seated at the bar area.  Our waiter greeted us quickly and based on his recommendations, we ordered the meatballs, lasagna, roasted cauliflower, and a set of three crostini (chicken pate, butternut squash, and roasted duck).  

Meatballs - you get three huge ones.  The waiter said that they're majority ground pork, but also ground shortrib.  I couldn't really taste the short rib, but regardless, they were pretty good.  

Lasagna - I was a little disappointed by this dish.  Although the entire thing screamed homemade, it just didn't comport with my expectations of lasagna.  It was a little flat, not very cheesy, and green.  Granted there was some cheese off to the side that I probably should've mixed in, but I'm not sure if that could've saved it.  The whole dish was a bit of a let down.

Roasted cauliflower - although this was only a side dish, it was one of my favorites.  I appreciated the sharp lemony zest, and how soft the cauliflower was.  I've long been a fan of roasted veggies, but I didn't know cauliflower could be this good!

Crostini - these stood out as some of the best of the meal.  I loved the chicken pate - it was spread on pretty thick onto the bread, and the ratio was a bit more pate than bread.  The duck and roasted squash were good too, but I do remember the squash was a bit salty.  I realize pate isn't everyone's thing, but if you do fancy it (or simply want to try!) I'd order it here.

Service:  Like I alluded to earlier, this service is dang good!  Our waiter was very knowledgable.  I was so impressed when we asked for recommendations, not only did he introduce us to his top 5 dishes, he also was able to describe them in greater detail than the menu.  He was great about getting us our prosecco and making sure our water pitcher wasn't empty as well as checking up on us during the meal, too.  Five out of five for service here!

Another random note is that there seemed to be a lot of people on dates here.  Yes, it's one of those places.

Bottom line:  Some of the food, like most restaurants, is hit or miss. I'd stick to the crostini and go with some sides, too.  Other people's pastas looked pretty good as well.
author: Denny C.

description: I have been dinning at different restaurants where Humberto (the current owner) was the manager. He always figures out how to get the top menu. One of the things I like here is that Barbacco has complimentary sparkling water. Their menu is great, including excellent pasta dishes and some appetizers such as olives, almonds, etc. For main course my favorite is Risotto, although the chicken tights are great as well. This place is located by the bart station, making it very convenient and easy to get there. The only time I had a bad experience at Barbacco was when the bartender gave me attitude over something minor.
author: Leslie R.

description:
Do NOT roll up in here at 11:30 and request a table, because it ain't happening!!

We made an opentable reservation via Yelp 1 hour prior and I am so thankful we did.

This place was packed and super high tech. Something about a resto that lets you order via ipad screams high-end and pricey. BUT it wasn't that bad. For lunch a lot of the items were between $11-$13 dollars!

We ordered:
1. Bruschette - Peach/Goat Cheese/Mint...IT WAS SO GOOD!! At $3 each, it was like..really/? but yes, really! Yes, get it..omg that was the perfect starter to wet my appetite.

2.Ferro Risotto - This wasn't as creamy as I thought it'd be, but I definitely appreciated that for a lighter lunch.

3. The orecchiette "Little ears" - SO GOOD! I really liked it, it was pasta tossed with small pieces of sausage and broccoli...not too heavy and great spices/flavoring. omnomnom!! ~

Love this place!! might be my new spot for business lunches!! YES!!
author: Jennifer S.

description: This was our first time here, and it definitely didn't disappoint! The tables are seated quite close together (our only minor complaint) but our waiter, Jose, was absolutely wonderful. We were celebrating my boyfriend's birthday and he made sure that we got a complimentary dessert, with "happy birthday" written on the plate. Dinner was absolutely delicious. We got the bruschetta (AMAZING!) to start, the Lumache (on Jose's recommendation - so delicious...every bite had delicious lamb flavor), the Pollo al Mattone (so tender and salsa verde was so fresh!) and fried brussels sprouts on the side. Must finish the meal with a chocolate nemesis cake! From the food to our awesome waiter Jose, Barbacco was great and we'll definitely be back.
author: Kasey T.

description:
Ambiance: Casual, but hip/trendy.  These much-raved-about iPad menus are now gone.  I guess they were getting stolen too often.  Likely you'll end up having to share a table with someone.  This seems like a good place for a large group to gather.  Not so noisy inside that you could still have a nice conversation with friends.

Service:  Very good (around 5:30pm on a Friday).  Attentive.  Our server was very knowledgable about the menu.

Food:  Overall delicious.  My favorite appetizers were the croquettes, which had very good texture.  The nduja was so savory and had a very nice mild kick to it.  We had to ask for more toasted bread because of the hearty portion.  All of the pasta was nicely al dente, and not too heavy, but my favorite out of these was the Paccheri.  The serving sizes of the pasta were on the small-moderate side.  (Definitely order appetizers.)  Here's everything we ordered for 3 people. (We were nicely satisfied at the end of our meal.)

Appetizers:
# Suppli - mushroom risotto croquettes filled with truffled mozzarella / $4 ea
# 'Nduja - spicy, smoked Calabrian soft salame / $6/ $9
# Pesco crudo 
# Antipasto of seasonal vegetables / $10

Pastas:
# Lasagna Bolognese - spinach pasta / meat ragu / besciamella sauce / $13
# Paccheri / rustic pork ragu / parmigiano reggiano / $13
# Orecchiette - "little ears" / cavolo nero / fennel sausage / pecorino cheese / $12
author: Jeanne L.

description: Fried brussels sprouts with anchovies, capers and red wine vinaigrette shine, I could eat every day. The piastra seared asparagus with egg, lemon aioli and house made bottarga was delightful. However, one of my all time favorites, the 'nduja, failed miserably. First it was served chilled, impossible to spread and eventually breaking the bread. I brought it to the attention of our server who agreed the container it was in was cold. Five minutes later the server returns with what looked like chopped meat, almost beef tartare like in appearance. It was lifeless, flaky and, once again, impossible to spread. It was so dry that I had to add the olive oil that was served with the bread. Disappointed they would even serve a dish in that condition.
author: Charlene L.

description: The flat iron steak was excellent. The lasagna was ok. The squash soup was ok. Service was excellent.
author: Malcolm M.

description:
I've heard good things about this place, but it doesn't quite live up to the hype.  The food is simple yet creative at times.  However, something isn't right whether it's the tough texture of the Sicilian meatballs, the ecclectic flavors of a mushroom risotto croquette, or the seasoning of potatoes.  Desserts, such as the sorbet and bread pudding, were a treat to end the meal.

Service is fast and friendly with customers ordering using tablets.  The ambiance is simple, dimly lit and cozy for shared tables.  Parking is tough on the street, but there are garages within a few blocks.
author: Jenny L.

description:
*Love the atmosphere
*Dig the decor
*Staff is friendly
*Ordered chicpeas, corn and spiced almonds as part of the 3 combo antipasti
*Ordered the burrata "salad" which was super delicious - it came with olive tapenade, garlic, arugula and 4 slices of toast... Highly recommend this dish

Friend and I were in the mood for simple food so we ordered spaghetti with a simple white wine sauce, garlic, shallots,  finely chopped parsley and of course lots of butter! ;)

We ended our meals with a touch of sweetness - we ordered the Panforte and butterscotch gelato.

We went home with yummy in our tummy and smiles on our face...
author: Kinjal S.

description:
Good, solid food (solid as it well executed, not texture or weight gain ratio).

I ordered a pasta dish and it was done very nicely with just a touch of chewiness (the way I like it).  Overall dish was well seasoned and very good.  Portion was large-ish.

Desserts are a really good deal with gelato at only $3.

Service was friendly without being pushy.

Nice touch bonus: they leave everyone a little carafe of water so I can refill my own water glass without having to wait.

Decor is modern and cozy at the same time.  Bar stool I was on was comfortable.

Good food, good value ... I'll be back.
author: Winnie C.

description:
Ambiance of the place is awesome, very simple but elegant. We started off with duck liver pate bruschette, and the 'nduja jars. The nduja jar was just okay, it was abit to spicy for me so i didnt really enjoy it. But the duck liver pate bruschette was DA BOMB! its so good that i had to order another serving of the duck liver pate bruschette. Then we got the rustic pork ragu pasta and the orechiette. They taste just okay i wasnt really impressed. Also got the strawberry lemonade, they are so good, like you can actually taste the strawberries and you can tell that its not made out of some flavorings. We finished with the butter scotch chocolate crunch gelato and they were SO SO GOOD! 

Hilight of Barbacco: Duck liver pate bruschette and the butter scotch chocolate crumb!
author: Valerie H.

description:
Food and ambianceawesome. LOVED the crostone with burrata cheese. We shared a bunch of plates so just a few tiny bites of the crostone with burrata cheese had me longing for more. The maccheroni alla chitarra and the polpette are two favorites of mine and are great comfort foods. The chocolate cake was wonderful but definitely a dish to be shared.
Serviceleft something to be desired. Our waiter seemed to have some attitude which really dampens the mood even if the food is great. This was my second time here and the first time the service was great.
suppli  mushroom risotto croquettes filled with truffled mozzarella
roasted peach / goat cheese / mint bruschette
crostone with burrata cheese, cherry tomato / basil / rucola
roasted beets / fennel / rucola / thyme, goat cheese / fresh horseradish
gorgonzola / chestnut honey
maccheroni alla chitarra / rustic pork ragu, parmigiano reggiano
braised chicken thighs / caponata / basil toasted pine nuts 
polpette  Sicilian meatballs with raisins and pine nuts / braised chard / tomato sugo
brussels sprouts fried in duck fat / capers anchovy / red wine vinaigrette 
roasted eggplant / pan grattato / balsamico
gelato and sorbetto, scoop butter scotch-chocolate crunch
chocolate nemesis cake
author: Schelly Y.

description:
Make sure to get the house-made gelato! Yum!!

I'm vegetarian, so I was a little sad when I saw that everyone on Yelp raved about the Brussels sprouts cooked in duck fat. But when I brought it up to the waitress, she offered me a vegetarian version of them! I obviously can't compare to the duck fat sprouts, but my goodness were these things delicious. I loved how accommodating they were!

My other favorites here were the suppli (mushroom risotto and truffle mozzarella croquettes) and the crostone with burrata cheese.

The farro risotto was tasty, but a little on the heavy side as risottos often are. I think next time I go, I'd be happy just to make a meal out of all the small plates!

Oh, and seriously, get the house-made gelato. You won't regret it.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
I took my boyfriend here because he worked right around the corner at the time. 

We were excited about the iPad drink menus. Apparently all they did was tell you what the drinks were though. So excitement died down. It would be cool if in the future they connected to a bartender so you could just send your drink order in directly.

If you get nothing else, get the brussel sprouts fried in duck fat and dressed with a balsamic vinaigrette. I could toss back bucketfuls of these babies only I don't want to have a heart attack this year. 

I've since been back with other friends and I care about nothing but those brussel sprouts.

Go here, get the brussel sprouts. For $5, heaven's never tasted so delicious nor been so cheap.
author: Emily R.

description:
Dishes are encouraged to be shared, and if done that way, it's somewhat like Italian tapas with an American twist. Great suggestions from the staff and I had a great meal. Fantastic brussel sprouts too.

There is limited seating and you will likely eat at the bar if your group is just 2 people.
author: Andrew H.

description:
I adore barbacco. Quick good italian food, their soup if the day has consistently been fantastic, and the duck fat Brussels sprouts are to die for.

If you want a table during peak hours, you're going to have to book.

It's rather loud, so possibly not the best place for a business meeting, by great for a lovely night out.

All around an excellent stop.
author: Chloe A.

description:
This place offers a phenomenal value in SF. Like, seriously. 

Ruth C. and I came early as a pre-theater dinner before going to see Book of Mormon at the Orpheum.

We had: 

- one suppli (mushroom risotto croquette, with truffled mozzarella), $4 -  it was excellent, and probably my favorite thing of the night. This might not bode well, but...

- three bruschette (chanterelle mushrooms in balsamic, pear and prosciutto, and Tuscan chicken liver pate), 3 for $8 - the mushroom one was my least favorite, as it was so overwhelming of vinegar; the chicken liver was my favorite, and I liked the fruit compote they added 

- orecchiette pasta with spinach and fennel sausage, $14ish? -  the pasta was well-cooked, but there was so much green that it almost killed any flavor

- polpette (meatballs), $don'tremember - I thought there was a disjointed spice to this, but I liked the texture. Not my favorite meatballs (I think the ones at Piccino are better, but these are a better deal, considering the portion size)

- brussels sprouts in duck fat, balsamic - good, but not great. Some of the sprouts were little vinegar bombs. I approached each with a little trepidation. 

- Nemesis cake, $5 - Yeah, it was only $5 for dessert! And we couldn't finish (not with our scoop of gelato for $3, either). It was such a good, chocolatey cake. Very tasty, indeed! 

Now, you might be wondering why this is still a four-star experience for me. Well, everything was super well-executed, and our server was stellar (she told us about a guy she dated that was covered in zombie tattoos), but I honestly feel that  my not 100% enjoying all the food was that I ordered incorrectly for me. I think that if I could do it all over and order different things, I would LOVE this place. But I already love the value! All this PLUS two glasses of wine was $100, including tip!
author: Ingrid C.

description: This one of the Best restaurants I ever try in sf. Great food and an excellent service. The first time I had the CHICKEN THIGHS and it was good tender and testy. Last night we went back again and we had the brussel sprouts, Lasagne Bolognese which was pretty light and very delicious. The desserts is just another level you must try them out. We had different flavors of GELATO, our fav was the honey crumb and the butterscotch MUST HAVE. Both times we had the Chocolate Nemesis Cake and its amazing. The manager was such a sweetheart. Definitely we going back
author: Emanula M.

description: Had a work lunch here last week - was good! I had the spinach salad with duck and it was quite tasty. We also shared a selection of bruschetta and they were all delicious. It's pretty small inside, so I would recommend making a reservation. We had a reservation and were seated right away - but it looked like they were taking walk-ins to sit at the bar area only. The only thing I didn't like was that the tables are very close together - reminded me of a Paris Bistro.
author: Allie H.

description: Just tried this restaurant for the first time. The food was delicious and our waiter, Scott was great. We went with his recommendations for wine and food. We weren't disappointed. Definitely going on our list for a return visit.
author: Peggy K.

description:
I had extended my SF stay 1 more night with my two boy 5 and 7 (see omni hotel review GREAT place)... for whatever reason I ignored the guy at the desk and chose something within walking distance, I yelped and saw this places menu.... first, the menu listed here is not at all what they have on their menu. As for the rest of the complaints, well I thought it would be ok with kids given that menu and our omni experience... nope, it's ALL pretentiousness... frankly it just wasn't good, we ordered three different entries and planned to family style it sharing all three, the acted put out I asked to do that and my boys, ok hardly refined palates... hated it, frankly it was hard to argue with them, oh and the $$ it has listed, yeah
... no.... dropped 150 on a crappy meal, thank goodness for the Omni... with or without my boys I love fine dining, this place just had that feel of trying to fake it till they made it..... sooooo not making it.
author: Matt W.

description: Service at thid place was Great, the bartender awesome good knowledge of wines, we tried 8-10 till we found the ones we liked, sit at bar( always better and easier to get their attention, came from eating at Coqueta( review to fallow) tried the sardines, great texture on the meat superb flavor, nice presentation,  grilled couliflowers, really good, definitly coming bavk to this place next i am in town
author: Larry L.

description:
Well priced for the quality and variety of food + the classy atmosphere.
Quiet enough to hear the people at your table and converse.

Suggest: brussels sprouts, lasagna.
author: Gee H.

description:
Pretty good tapas, and love that it's the casual cousin of Perbacco next door, but felt just a wee bit overpriced for what you got - though it is smack in downtown SF, so pretty much par for the course. 

We tried a mushroom risotto croquetted with truffled mozzarella - just delicious, and not overly cheesy. I loved that the earthiness of the truffle came through just enough but didn't overwhelm. 

The tuscan chicken liver pate bruschetta was umami in 3 bites for me - you say "pate" I say "ahhhh" ~ 

The only disappointment of the night was probably the pesce crudo - hamachi with olive oil, dash of lemon, and supremed wedges of blood orange. The flavor combination was refreshing, but the servinfg is 3 small slices (sashimi sized) for $12 - just not worth it. I've had crudo at other SF tapas-style eateries at the same price point with more generous sharing portions. 

The entrees were comfort food hits - I tired the spinach pasta lasagne and it just hit the spot, and my dining companion had the Tuscan beef stew over a creamy bed of polenta which was rich but not fatty/heavy. 

All in all, a good meal to end a long workday.
author: Rachel M.

description: Special lamb dish is really good... but then I tasted my friend's just regular old spaghetti and Sicilian meatballs with home made pasta and it was awesome!
author: Justin H.

description: On a scale of 1-5(5 being the best) Barbacco rates a 6 in every category for my wife and I.  We often travel to SF and after having enjoyed several dinners at the big brother (Perbacco) next door, we have wanted to try Barbacco since it opened -- it was well worth the wait.  Our server, Harold, was one of the best we have ever had (we are both seniors) and knew everything about each dish and also nailed the wine.  My wife deemed the Gnocco the finest she has ever eaten and I highly recommend the chef's selection of salumi.  The atmosphere and friendliness' of the entire staff made this dinner something very special - it doesn't get much better.
author: MC B.

description:
Personally, I just  tapas. My little heart just flutters when I get to try a myriad of dishes as I gaze over a menu that makes my mouth water. I'm that person that has eyes way bigger than my stomach. But how can anyone resist?

I came with some gf's and we ordered everything that caught our eye.

Brussel sprouts - if you like brussels sprouts, you have to try these. If you don't like brussel sprouts, you have to try these to see how great they can taste. Cooked in a balsamic vinaigrette with duck fat, and capers... it was sublime.

Spicy Braised Tripe - cooked in a tomato (and saffron?) broth. Tasted awesome, the tripe was cooked perfectly.

Nduja - spicy smoked Calabrian soft salami, basically a salami spread that is to die for.

Mushroom Risotto Croquettes - meh. The mushrooms were overpowering. 

Mussels - pretty tasty but I was not a fan of the abundant corona beans.

We also started with some anti-pasto which had endive, kale, and some other greens that were just perfection.

If I still lived in the city, I would be all over Barbacco on the daily.
author: Grace L.

description:
Came in on a Monday and really enjoy the environment.  Pretty mellow with an open kitchen and nice red brick interior.  The seating is good, with some private and shared tables, but the shared tables have a good enough spread to keep the privacy.
The Octopus is delicious, seared perfect with a tender meat.  Brussel sprouts were roasted and a delightful addition to the octopus.  The real show stealer is the burrata cheese and the toast served with it.  Absolutely savory and delicious.  The mussel pasta had a very good amount of mussels and a tasty broth, a bit on the spicy side to fully enjoy because of the sausage used.  I chose the fish option, which was tasty in a red marinara sauce served in a baked dish.  A wonderful experience and lovely wait staff.
author: Christopher K.

description:
I came here for dinner with some friends after work on a Monday. We came in around 5:30 without a reservation, and because it will still pretty empty they were able to seat us. The place really filled up by 630, so if you're coming around that time be sure to have a reservation or you might end up eating at the bar!

Service was attentive in the beginning while there were no people, but flagged later on. We had trouble getting the check when we needed to leave. 

Finally, we had the "oriechette" little-ears pasta with kale, "polette" the Sicilian meatballs, and "peposo" the beef stew. All were delicious! The pasta was a little too oily which offset the healthy taste of kale. It could use with some more variation in it. The Sicilian meatballs were flavorful, but it doesn't come with anything else. I liked the peposo the most, as there was beef, tomatoes, and polenta to mix it up! 

Also, try the duck liver bruschetta!!! 

All in all, a good place to eat dinner and good for groups, just a little more than I'd like to pay for dinner and one drink.
author: Sandy L.

description: Very busy lunch service between Xmas and New Year. Service a bit slow/uncoordinated but not too bad considering how busy it was. Stools are lions if weird at table because that side of the table will sit higher. Bruschetta appetizers (caponata and prosciutto) were bland. Main dishes - squash soup, orecchiette, fusilli- were excellent. Tried the ice cream for dessert - not spectacular.
author: N C.

description:
A light lunch this was not, but delicious? Quite. A coworker of mine chose this place for a work team lunch and I thought it was the perfect selection. It was easy to make a reservation online through Yelp, and we were glad we did because it was bustling inside. 

The decor isn't anything mind-blowing, but it's classy and clean - a long narrow space with exposed brick and sleek tables and chairs. I have to say I thought the iPad drink menu concept was a tad hokey, but I do see how it could really speed things up if the orders go straight to the bar. 

I was honestly more interested in the food menu, which was filed with enticing options. Because I was feeling indecisive, I ended up with the small watermelon salad and 2 bruschettes - the egg and anchovy and the duck liver pate. All were absolutely delish although perhaps the watermelon wasn't the best choice on the cold, blustery day. I could see it being a great meal in a heat wave though! The pate was so rich that I was really glad I only had one small piece of it. I also insisted on ordering the brussels sprouts with duck fat for the table, though I think I was the only one who ended up enjoying it. They were seriously some of the best brussels sprouts I've ever had, though I suppose anything described as being fried in duck fat can no longer be considered even remotely healthy. 

We also ordered foccacia for the table, which was $1 for 2 big pieces, so we ended up having to get 3 orders. I tend to have a problem with places that charge for bread, though it was very yummy. 

I have to say that this lunch experience was very very close to a five star as I thought all of the flavors were excellent and so was the service, I suppose a few small things (the bread, how heavy the meal felt after going back to the office) keep me from giving it those coveted five stars, but I'd definitely recommend it and would love to return for dinner!
author: Christina P.

description:
The last time we tried to get in Barbacco, we ended up next door to its higher end sister Perbacco and had a fantastic dinner.  

This time around, we were determined to give this place a try.  We were told it'll be a 20 minute wait so we checked out the menu while waiting.  Before we knew it, we got our table in the back.

What we had:
Gordon Biersch and Thirsty Bear wheat - $7 each
Sangria - $6 - tastes like blackcurrant juice
taste of SanLazzaro Pecorino $6 - not cold enough but nice flavor
lardo bruschetta - $3 - very flavorful and rich
Suppli - $4 - like aranchini - outer layer crust was a bit hard 
small chef selection of salumi - $11 - pretty good but quite salty, pickled veggies helped, the breadsticks were good
tripe stew - $8 - comes w/ 2 grilled slices of bread, piping hot, very tender and flavorful - best dish of the night
squid - $9 - ok
side brussel sprouts fried in duck fat w/ capers - $5 - on the salty side for me.  i removed the outer layer and ate the inside
gelato - bittersweet chocolate - $3
panforte - $1, two thin slices
biscotti - $0.50

Maybe we didn't order the right items but nothing really impressed me much except for the beef tripe, which I'll definitely order if I return.
author: Gloria H.

description:
I can say only good things about our Barbacco business lunch. The one downside is that they don't have a place for you to nap after you've stuffed yourself with their robust, stick-to-your-ribs Italian indulgences. Though, they do have plenty of soups, salads, and bruscetta options, if you want to avoid the post-lunch coma. 

We went all out and ordered up a parade of enticing dishes: my personal favorites being the tender Olive Oil Poached Albacore Salad (Nicoise style), the fluffy Foccacia (soaked in olive oil, of course) and the soup of the day (Sweet Pea + Mint, if I remember correctly). I was impressed with the variety of dishes they offer, for every eater and appetite. The portions were quite large, and most everything was served in a boat-shaped bowl - a nice rustic touch. 

While lunch was fabulous, Barbacco seems ideal for dinner when you can linger and indulge a little longer (and explore that wine list everyone is talking about!)
author: Nique F.

description:
Great meal and experience all the way around.  We made a dinner reservation here just a few hours before we ate and when we arrived my wife and I were going to be seated at a table with four others but we decided to sit at the bar and we're glad we did.  Kevin was our waiter and he was really nice and knowledgeable.

We both had glasses of wine and it was cool to see the selections on the ipads on each of the tables.  We started with the spreadable salumi which if we stopped there would have made our night.  It had a smoky flavor and a bit of spice which was really nice.  We also tried a bruschette with pear Gorgonzola and honey as well as suppli and all were very tasty.  For our main meal we shared the meatballs which had a nice lemon zest as well as the orecchiett which was great.  

The greatest part of the meal though was the brussel sprouts.  Hands down the greatest sprouts we've ever had and I could have ordered a second dish as a dessert they were so good.

We did order some gelato for dessert and both were very tasty as well.

I can't believe that I haven't been here before but will guaranteed be back here time and time again.
author: Blake B.

description:
Don't be fooled by the modern decor... this place is not as expensive as it looks!

The service is warm and friendly like someone else mentioned.  They have iPads set up so that you can look at beer / wine, but it contrasts with the personal service you actually get.  iPads seem a bit detached?  Anyway, food was great.  

I ordered the Duck Liver Pate Bruschette, which was DELICIOUS!  $3.  I suppose it's quite a bit for a sliver of bread + spread, but well worth it.  

I also ordered the Summer Squash Bruschette, which was also good, but definitely not as good as the Duck Liver.  They both went well together, though.

Finally, I ordered the soup of the day, which was also a squash related soup.  Creamy and satiating.  The people sitting next to us had ordered some orzo / pasta-looking dish, which looked hearty and smelled SOOO good as well.

In total, my meal was $10... oh also, I only have a 30 minute lunch break so I actually was seated + served in under 30 minutes.

I can't wait to come back and try the rest of the stuff on the menu!!  Orrrr order Duck Liver Pate again. and again.
author: Jennifer L.

description: As I live in the Financial District, there aren't a ton of evening options for take out that aren't super expensive. Barbacco is a totally bang for your buck type place. You get amazing food and the staff there is always friendly and inviting, especially the hostess Alex. I probably average one meal here a week, whether it's take out or sitting down. One small criticism: the food tends to get "awesomer" as the week goes on (i.e. Thursday night is typically more delicious than Monday night.) Highly recommend going here and if you do try the meatballs (which used to come with three and now come with two on top of pasta, although they accommodate me when I ask for three meatballs, no pasta) and the fried brussel sprouts. Yummyyy...
author: Alexander C.

description: Great place to take a first date for dinner, just in case there is no love connection, you can still enjoy the atmosphere and excellent food. Try grabbing a seat at the bar for dining.
author: Omar A.

description:
Barbacco was a great place to come and catch up with my best friend. After work, we met up here and it was actually closer to work than I had though. Anyways, it was great a place to have a casual catch up about anything and everything. 

We ordered our wines off their iPad which I thought was cool...but kind of unnecessary. Sparkling for me, and white for her.

We ordered a plate of the vegetables and I ordered the pork ragu and she ordered the risotto. Mine was really good. The pasta was a bit hard to cut and eat to be honest, so I wished the pasta was like smaller or something. 

Dessert was really good too. She ordered the panna cotta. I ordered the chocolate nemesis and it was so good. It was just like a chocolate cake, but oh so chocolately. (I'm really thinking I should stay away from chocolate for a while...)

Definitely a great place to go and eat. Love the place. Definitely a great place to eat and hang out, but also for a date.
author: Nina Y.

description:
Barbacco was wonderful, lively place, nice wine selection, delicious food, tastefully prepared. Very reasonable prices and great service.
Great for a get to know date night!
author: Brian R.

description:
My parents and I had just gotten to our hotel after traveling the entire day.. we were starving, tired, and cranky. All we needed was food. I found this place on yelp and I am so glad that I did. The décor of the restaurant is amazing, the servers are so nice, and the food is fantastic. 
We started with the fried Brussel sprouts.. SO GOOD 
The kale salad was amazing too
There olives were great, not too salty. 

I got the porchetta sandwich with grilled peaches.. OMG AMAZING !!!
My dad got the BLT..... ok ya I could eat this everyday 
My mom got the chicken salad sandwich.. It was so yummy it had no mayo and it was fresh ! 

My parents got a great bottle of white wine. 

love this place, wish it was in orange county because I would be there everyday.
author: Niloo S.

description:
Barbacco is a casual Italian place in FiDi, with decently priced pastas for lunch.  We had the maccheroni alla chitarra, a rustic pork ragu pasta, orecchiette with broccoli rabe fennel sausage, nduja (spreadable salami) with crostini, and brussels sprouts fried in duck fat with capers, anchovy, red wine vinaigrette.  

The maccheroni alla chitarra was an excellent tomoto based pasta, al dente, very hearty and really well seasoned.  The orechiette was surprisingly good, I don't care for brocoli rabe as it tends to be to bitter, but it was chopped up very finely so it worked well.  The brussel sprouts were delish!  I tend to avoid items fried in fat, but this dish was tasty and I tried not to think about the duck fat!  

They do communal seating, so you don't get your own table unless you have at least 6 people.
author: Wendy S.

description:
Holy cannoli this place is DELICIOUS.  I'm always hesitant about Italian food.  It is done terribly at most restaurants and usually tastes like you are eating Chef Boyardee.  Barbacco totally blew me away.  I will 100% come back for another visit, it is worth it just to explore their extensive menu.

SO, what did I have:
-Lemonade: Best lemonade I have ever had.  Truly tasted fresh squeezed and it was the perfect amount of tart.  
-Minestrone Soup: Usually, I would never order a soup like this, but after creepily glancing at other people's tables, I shifted my expectations around food quality and ordered it.  Amazing.  So many fresh vegetables packed with so much flavor.  I have never had vegetables taste so good in a soup. 
-Lasagna Bolognese: Again, I usually never order lasagna since it typically tastes like someone dumped prego and cheese into a platter and baked it.  This was the best lasagna I have EVER eaten.  I can even describe the flavor profiles, but there was a perfect balance of flavor, texture.  I could eat this every day and be perfectly happy for the rest of my life. 

The ONLY negative that I can think of for this place was their host was pretty darn snooty - We had 4 people in our lunch reservation and one of them (a VP of a company) couldn't join the lunch until halfway through since he had a meeting.  We had his order ready to place it when the waitress came around, explained this to the host, and STILL got a considerable amount of pushback to let us be seated.  I understand not wanting people to hold a table for an unreasonable amount of time just so they can wait for party members who may never appear, but we had even explained that this wasn't the case so I was a little baffled by his logic.  Eventually he gave up and let us sit down, but it was more of a struggle than I would have expected from a nice restaurant.  He also spent every time that he passed our table glaring at us since our 4th member arrived 20 minutes late right as the food arrived (as we explained).  

Anyway, I've said my peace about that, but aside from that minor setback, this is a 5-star experience.  The food speaks for itself.
author: Alyx F.

description: Went here for dinner and loved it.  Got seated at the bar, which we did not exactly care for, but the food was great and the service was good.  Had the octopus, which was fantastic, plus a few pasta dishes (the little ears, the beef stew and a tube pasta with lamb...I think it was lamb), as well as a salumi plate.  Everything we had was excellent and more filling than we expected.  The pasta was cooked well, and everything tasted fresh and was a good size portion.  Overall, a great meal.  Total was about $127 including tip for 2, which was 3 appetizers, and 3 main type dishes, plus 2 desserts.
author: A. L.

description: Was in SF for the night and a friend suggested we meet at Barbacco for some Italian fare. I'm usually allergic to dining in the Financial District, but this place was wonderful. The octopus starter, along with the beets appetizer, was succulent. The house red wine was great and chicken breast cooked under a brick, served over arugula, was wonderfully presented, super moist and delicious, as was the risotto. The only reason I didn't give this place 5 stars was because I felt the hostess was less than welcoming when we arrived. I know it's sometimes customary not to seat a party until everyone in the party is present but our friends were slightly late and we were slightly early for our reservation and had to stand by the door for about 15 minutes. The restaurant was otherwise empty when we got there and I think we should have been seated right away. Oh well, it was still a good experience overall. Food and wine excellent at a reasonable price for SF.
author: Chris D.

description: I always imagine Italian restaurants to have that homey feel, this place not so much. Hosts and waiters were friendly for sure. And the food was just okay, okay portion size. Just kinda left feeling something to be desired. I was hungry about a hour later. Seating was not great, tables were too close together and high chairs not very comfortable.
author: Luz H.

description:
4 stars for this sandwich spot

I was in search of the perfect porchetta I was told this place would possibly have it haha. I have little to go on since I have not yet tired the roli roti pork porchetta sandwich which everyone has been raving about before it was featured on food network. My friend suggested we come down and give this place a try. We sampled two sandwiches, one lamb the other the porchetta.

The roasted lamb was exceptionally good even for folks that don't like lamb they stated it was subpar since it was not to gamey. For me it was just right, tender with full punch taste of lamb but not super gamey, also in the sandwich was greens dont recall which veggies since I am anti veggies haha, I would come back for this sandwich

The porchetta was decent for what I was able to sample thick slices of meat that was tender and favorful, there was greens also in this sandwich dont recall their names again since I rarely eat veggies, from what I am told Roli Roti's is better, for me this being one of my first I would have to give it 4 solid stars, I have had other porchetta sandwiches recently and I would still hold this one at a solid 4

If you can dine in do so, it is fancy inside, place for first date, snazzy haha

food **** both lamb and porchetta I recommend a try
price $$
service **** ordered to go, friendly staff
ambiance ***** upscale, modern, looks expensive inside
author: Clarence A.

description: The waitstaff is great! Attentive & nice. The food was a little disappointing, but I have really high expectations of Italian food.
author: Cris B.

description:
My friend and I couldn't find each other because one of us went to Perbaccco and the other went to Barbacco, but we eventually regrouped and jumped back and forth because they both had wait times. I am really glad we decided to wait the 20-30 minutes for a table at Barbacco (Wednesday around 7:30PM) - food was tasty and prices were extremely reasonable for high quality food (we paid $22 each after tax/tip). There is bar and table seating, but the space is not as large as it looks (the back wall is a very deceptive mirror). I would suggest making a reservation to avoid the wait. I also really enjoyed sharing everything we ate, even though this isn't necessarily a tapas restaurant. 

- Peach & proscuitto bruschette ($3 each, $8/three): Ok, just imagine this. Are you salivating yet? I'm pretty sure I have a Pavlov's dog response to savory sweet menu options. Peaches were succulent and proscuitto was fresh, and oh, I could eat this forever. You can mix and match the different bruschette varieties for the $8/three deal.

- Brussels sprouts ($5): I'm a brussels sprouts fanatic, and I don't even like vegetables. These aren't the best I've ever had, but they get the job done. My main quip is that they don't have that crispy outer crunch.

- Fried polenta ($4): Much like the brussels sprouts, these are what you expect, no surprises. The portion sizes for these sides are quite large, so I would suggest sharing or else you'll be drowning in sprouts and polenta.

- Paccheri ($13): The pasta comes with a generous helping of pork ragu, which is tender and flavorful. The tomato sauce and pork is proportioned well with the pasta tubes, which are cooked just right.

- Brown butter "shortcake" ($6): The whipped ricotta on the side sold this for me. It's not too sweet, but just sweet enough that it wraps up a savory meal. The plating is bold and the berries are a refreshing pop of color and juice. 

They have a wide selection of wine (did you know orange wine is a thing?), but it didn't feel like a Wasted Wednesday, so we settled with pedestrian water. Service was also very attentive and patient, even when we were waiting for a table.
author: Jessica F.

description:
There's not much worse than working in your office on a Saturday, looking down from the 38th floor at the city enjoying an unusually warm SF summer day below. There is one thing worse though, and that's when an announcement comes on informing you that the elevators are out of service. 

A bunch of us had just ordered dinner at Barbacco for take out. Since no one wanted to climb back up 38 flights of stairs, we decided to leave for the night and try to eat at the restaurant. We were super late to pick up our food, thanks to our trek down the (many flights of) stairs. We explained our predicament when we got to Barbacco, and despite being very busy they squeezed us in at the bar. They then plated our food that had been packaged to-go, and served us like we had ordered in the restaraunt. Everything was delicious, but more importantly we really appreciated the flexibility and the great service. 

Like an idiot, I forgot to take my receipt which I needed for expensing. They were able to look up our meal after the fact and provide me with a receipt a couple days later. 

Great service makes me loyal, and for that reason I'll be back to Barbacco.
author: Audrey B.

description:
Went to Barbacco to meet up with my roommate after work (he works in the Financial District). We made reservations beforehand, and it's a good thing we did. The place got crowded soon after we were seated at the bar. The place itself was quite small.

I enjoyed the bruschette I ordered (roasted hen of the woods mushroom with parmigiano) and thought that all the bruschettes on the menu were really unique. My roommate ordered the tometta cremosa di pecora carletta (cheese) with honey almonds, which was delicious! Our mains were well put together and my flat iron steak was cooked to perfection. The menu may not be very big, but each dish was done very well.

I did not get any alcoholic beverage, but they had big selection of beers and an even bigger selection of wines.

Due to the small amount of space, I would not recommend this place for large groups. I do recommend reservations, especially if you're going for an early dinner or right after work on a weekday, since you'll get the large crowd of people that work in the Financial District flowing in around that time.
author: Nirel R.

description: It was 9:30pm and we were looking for a place nearby to eat. I found this place through yelp, and we got there in time before the kitchen closed. I shared a dish of spaghetti and mussels. I was totally taken by surprise by the wonderful mix of flavors in what I expected to be a typical dish. It had some spice that added a nice kick. The others in our party of 5 all enjoyed their meals as well. Five stars for great food at reasonable prices.
author: Susanna C.

description:
I wish I had read more about this place before I made reservations to meet a old friend I hadn't seen in a while.

Barbacco is one of those restaurants that have the odd practice of seating you *literally* right next to strangers.  My friend and I were sat a long table with six seats.  There were 4 diners (strangers) already present at the table and we were sat on the end, practically bumping elbows with our new tablemates!  

On top of that, the 4 people at the table weren't really talking that much so my friend and my conversation served as entertainment for them.  Very strange and I would not go to this restaurant again based solely on this practice.

The food was tasty.  Stuffed dates were out of this world.   Bruschetta was fresh and creative. I ordered a pasta dish which was, well, pretty much a standard mediocre pasta dish such as one would receive at Pasta Pomodoro.  Not as inspired as the small plates.

The kick in the face was the outrageous prices for beers: $8-10 for your standard selection of IPA, wheat beer, lager, etc.  The prices of the food were reasonable but how they can justify these crazy beer prices, I have no idea.  $10 for a glass of beer?  

Lastly, the tables and chairs were uncomfortable.  It seems someone mismatched the height when picking these out.  I found myself hunching over on my elbows a lot.  It was as if the chairs/stools were too high and the table was too low.  I am an average-sized person so not sure where the disconnect happened with the designer when this restaurant was conceived.  The stools have no back so you can either sit up perfectly straight or do the hunch.  My elbows were sore after the hour and half dinner.

Service was decent and the restaurant wasn't too loud (in this case I had wished it was a little louder considering the seating arrangements).
author: Jeff M.

description:
What an amazing meal :)
I had the Prosecco, lasagna, butter scotch gelato, choc fudge cake and the maple cake.

The meal felt like a Parisian experience.

Will be back for sure. They offer take outs too, will try it.

Wish they had a ravioli on the menu..
author: P D.

description:
Unfortunately Barbacco, has fallen quite far into Perbacco's shadow. Two weeks prior, I had tried Perbacco and the experience was wonderful. I have not written a review, but believe me the in house made pasta was wonderful. Walking into the restaurant it is fairly dim and intimate which is nice. At times it does get quite loud as you are sitting fairly close with fellow diners. I liked the glossy wood tables, but did not like the tile floors as much. I do understand that wood floors and wood tables would like a little funny together. 

Let me first start by saying that prices are very good considering that the restaurant is in a prime location in the financial district. Like every Italian meal, we were some Acme bread with butter and olive oil+vinegar. The Acme bread itself tasted good, but I wish it was warm, because the butter was incredibly difficult to spread as a result. As an appetizer my family ordered three brushettes. The three included, the tuscan chicken liver pate, mango and prosciutto, and the wild mushrooms. Of the three the tuscan chicken liver pate was miles away in taste and it was very smooth as well. The mushroom bruschette was unfortunately very eccentric because it tasted rather vinegary for some odd reason. The mango and prosciutto was all wrong because the mango overpowered the prosciutto so I didn't get the saltiness for balance. Next up came our entrees. My mother ordered chitarra, I ordered the farroto, and my brother ordered the orecchiette. First off I will say that the pasta themselves were excellent, each being a little chewy which I love in my pasta. To start the chitarra was somewhat pedestrian, as the sauce seemed a little bland and might have come out of a can. The meatball/sausage it came with however was very tasty. The farroto was extremely dissapointing because the mushrooms taste did not come through at all and the risotto itself was fairly bland. Salt and pepper next time please? The best was by far the orecchiette; by no means was it stellar, but the sausage was very good and the pesto was light and tasty. We shared two sides between the three of us, we shared the fried brussel sprouts and polenta. The polenta was nothing special and was just a filler. The brussel sprouts were definitely the highlight of the meal without a doubt. I could eat these little green, bashed on vegetables all night long. The leaves were nice and crispy and I am sure anything fried in duck fat is amazing. Brussel sprouts and chicken liver pate are two things not to be missed, while the rest was rather ordinary. 

Service was unfortunately not a shining point either at Barbacco. They probably only checked up on us once throughout the meal which was strange considering this is an Italian restaurant. They did fill our water often, but I was saddened by the inability of our waiter to recognize our table more often. 

Scores:
Ambiance 3.5/5 Entrance is nice and the rest is modern confusion
Food: 3.5/5 The .5 is added due to those terribly addicting brussel sprouts
Service: 2/5 I would expect the service we received at a Chinese Restaurant!
author: Mitchell L.

description: Atmosphere, food, wine, service was pleasant. Tables are usually booked on friday nights.
author: Lee-Hong L.

description:
I am so annoyed with this place.  I'll "second" all the reviews that basically say "good food, but get your s#*t together."  There's simply too much competition of equivalent quality food in the market.  Service completely sucks.  A 12:30 lunch reservation gets you seated at 12:50 and at a cozy side-by-side counter table.  Really cozy for a business lunch with a stranger.  Hope he didn't mind my hand resting on his knee.

Oh, and when they tried to placate us for waiting even though we had a "reservation" they said they'd comp us an app.  Perhaps, if we had to time to fight and tell the server that the bill didn't reflect the comp.   But we were too late from the delayed seating.  Suck it, Barbacco.  And Perbacco to boot.
author: James S.

description:
To begin, it was a saturday night, so busy everywhere.  we were told 20 minutes to wait and sat down in ten. the hostess was perfect ..warm, down to earth good eye contact and smile...and explained some menu items to us plus offered some suggestions.  we were seated at a table occupied by two other couples.  the place is small, and seating with strangers was customary.  the chairs were small and uncomfortable ..felt like i was falling forward the whole time and much too close to each other. .. like an airplane coach section. the two star rating reflects the uncomfortable cramped seating and  the average tasting food.

 kate, our waitress, was quick to greet us and get our order, and we told her we had an event planned right after, so she made sure we got everything quickly including a birthday gelato on the house.  we thought kate was one of the best parts of our night there. 

 the food was obviously prepared by an experienced chef.  portions were average size and a la carte, so if you ordered lasagna like i did, that is all you got. it was good but not memorable. my husband had pork ragu pasta ..also good, not great. you can request bread, but no garlic bread was available, i ordered a glass of milk which was about 4 oz...smallest millk i,ve ever been served. i was afraid to check the price.

  we liked everything ok but would not make an effort to go back because there are so many good p laces to eat around there, and nothing was special about the food really.  i didn't reflect on my dinner with desire for a repeat.  but it was nice to have a healthy meal after a day in the city of no public bathrooms.
author: Marcia M.

description:
Tapas, tapas, tapas. After moving back to Norcal from Socal, I've been dying to find a tapas restaurant that could replace that empty hole in my stomach that was previously filled by Bacaro LA near USC. Thankfully, my best friend, Erica J., shares my love for tapas and took me to this little gem that she kept raving about. Originally, we had a reservation at Chapeau but since we were stuffed from eating at Waterbar earlier in the day we opted for a later reservation at Barbacco so we could share a few bites of different dishes. Upon arriving to the restaurant, we were promptly seated at two seats at the bar. Keep in mind the restaurant is quite narrow but quite reminiscent of what I'm used to at Bacaro LA. Now, because the age group is slightly higher, the noise volume is a little better and more subdued than the chaotic screaming matches that seems to exist inside the few walls of Bacaro LA. From the bartenders to the waiters and coupled with the ipad drink order menus, the service here is impeccable and it helped me stay excited for every tapas dish that came through. 

Onto the food & drinks!

1. Ginger Lemonade & Strawberry Lavender Lemonade: As much as I enjoyed the lovely pairing of the lavender notes of the puree that neutralized the harsher sweet tones of the strawberry, I think I would have to side with the Ginger Lemonade between the two. The ginger not only brings in a refreshing spicy kick but also a refreshing mint-like chill in the back of your throat after every sip. Especially with the heavier food we were eating the whole night, the Ginger Lemonade would have been a better choice.

2. Mushroom & Chicken Liver Pate Bruschette: It's saying a lot when a mushroom fiend like myself could easily say that the chicken liver pate bruschette stole the show. At first I was a little worried that the abundance of chicken liver may be overwhelming but the onion marmellata provides a sweetness that cuts through the creaminess. 

3. Cauliflower: I wish I could say more about this dish, but as it is I'm not a big cauliflower fan and to me it was just cauliflower in a sauce.

4. Polpette: These sicilian meatballs were to die for. On the menu it says it's made with raisins and pine nuts, which would seem strange but I definitely did not notice as it was masked my delightful notes of spice, acidity from the tomato sugo, and paired with the chard on the bottom. However, these meatballs are huge so we did not even come close to finishing them.

5. Mushroom Risotto: This dish came in a heaping portion of mushroom deliciousness. The risotto was a little harder than I would have preferred but I've never had such a satisfying amount of mushrooms in a mushroom risotto. A MUST for mushroom fiends like me!!

6. Local Squid with Crushed Potatoes: This dish was such a delight since the squid was perfectly done with the rustic olive oil crushed potatoes. There is some kind of crack in the sauce of this dish because we cleaned this plate like it just went through the dishwasher. 

7. Lemon Buttermilk Panna Cotta: My first words to my friend when dessert came to the table? "I hate when panna cotta comes in a bowl or dish and not on a plate." Why? It usually means a few things...it's usually mindblowingly amazing and trying to get the remaining bits from the corners is a complete pain. I was correct on both points. The lemon buttermilk panna cotta with its few pieces of strawberry and brown sugar sauce is to die for and had the airiness that we needed after the otherwise heavy meal. 

Usually, I'm really hesitant to believe a 4-star rating of a restaurant in SF because the sheer amount of reviewers usually tips the average and causes a higher rating than usual....but I totally believe it for Barbacco!! Perbacco, I'm coming for you next.
author: Christine K.

description: Not sure what happened to Barbacco? Did they change chef? The dishes all came out missing the marks.  Ordered two of the same dishes, risotto and meat balls but they just didn't taste right.  The risotto main ingredient changed from arborio rice to barley.  The texture just didn't taste right.  The meat ball and sauce were extremely spicy.  The heat remained in my mouth for a good 5 mins. even after drinking lots of water.  As opposed to another yelper, I was lucky that our waitstaff was accommodating and willing to take another  order for me (I replaced with the orecchiette dish.). Two stars for great service but not unless the kitchen fixes the menu, sadly, its one less lunch place option for me.
author: Shirley H.

description:
I love Barbacco! It may just be one of my new go-to places in FiDi. It's more upscale than a lot of nearby lunch spots, and it's also slightly pricier. However, I have yet to find an Italian restaurant in downtown SF that offers the same quality food at such low prices, so I'm definitely not complaining.

The atmosphere is somewhat dark but classy at the same time. It's quite versatile in that it would be suitable for business lunches, dates, or just a casual dining experience. There doesn't seem to be a lot of individual tables in the restaurants, as I mostly saw communal and bar seating. So it probably wouldn't be the best place to go if you're looking for a lot of privacy.

Now for the food - I love everything I've tried from their "Pasta etc." section. In particular, the farrotto (essentially risotto with mushrooms, spinach, and parmesan) was so delicious I'm developing a huge craving just thinking about it right now. The mushrooms and spinach were extremely fresh and the risotto had just the right amount of richness. If you're looking for something less cheese-heavy and light, I would also highly recommend the orecchiette. I've never had kale pesto before and Barbacco nailed it with this one. 

The only reason why I'm not giving it five stars is because service wasn't as attentive as I would have liked. It gets busy around lunchtime, and it can get difficult getting a waiter's attention and they seem to be in a hurry to rush people out. Regardless, I love their menu selection and will be back many times in the future :)
author: Sunny H.

description:
It was 9pm on the third night of my interviews in SF, and my options for (relatively) cheap, tasty restaurants in the area were limited. Barbacco was near the top of this list, and fortunately, turned out to be an awesome find. Again, going against the voice of reason, I went for a full three course meal, late night indigestion be damned, getting a shaved asparagus salad, rustic pork ragu, and panforte, for a grand total of ~$25 after tax and tip.

The salad, served with spring onions and parmigiano reggiano, was a light, tasty, and surprisingly filling salad - the citrus flavors went a long way towards making it a great dish. The ragu, served with al dente paccheri (a fat tubular pasta), was also equally awesome, with an incredibly soft and flavorful pork. The panforte, a spiced fruit and chocolate bar, was probably the least interesting of the three, but was still good - not overly sweet, and reminded me of a fancy KIND bar.

Great food, excellent service, reasonable prices, and generous portions make Barbacco one of my list-toppers. I just hope I can ask the chef for softer pasta the next time around - I don't care much for anything prepared al dente, traditional or not.
author: Johnny W.

description: I have to say, the first time I dined at Barbacco was years ago when I still lived in SF and back then I thought it was a little heavy and greasy for my taste. I have recently been back twice in the past few months though and I have to say I'm impressed with their dishes and the value you receive for them. This last time I went, we were a group of 3 and shared a few of the bruschettas, the nduja, the brussel sprouts and the orechiette. The brussel sprouts here are always good and the orechiette is one of my favorites. I did really enjoy the nduja as well. The bruschetta was just bruschetta. No big deal. I was really surprised that our bill was only about $43 with tip though. That's a pretty decent deal for a nice lunch in SF for 3 people. I would definitely bring clients back here.
author: Kerry K.

description:
Came here for lunch and thought it was a very modern looking restaurant. We got seated at the bar-ish area which was kind of difficult to have conversation. 

But I got the special corn soup and Brussel sprouts. I would not order the soup again but omgosh the sprouts!

I'm sure everything else here is good as well but the service was outstanding here.
author: Elizabeth N.

description:
I actually CRAVE Barbacco. 

Recommend:
- bottle of wine (they have a great selection that are super affordable)
- Meatballs - they' phenomenal
- Lasagna - Best lasagna I've ever had. 

Great Services too!

I always made reservations, and it's always packed inside. If you go in without a reservation, expect a wait
author: Valerie Y.

description:
Awesome, awesome lunch place. The vibe is slightly upscale/business, yet very approachable. Service is great. 

Highly recommend the brussel sprouts and olive oil poached tuna salad.
author: Nadine H.

description:
The service was exquisite!  Starting from the host, the general manager Andelino to our waitress behind the bar Chrissie, all provided us excellent service!  I had to change my earlier dinner reservation to a later time.  GM Andelino did his best to accommodate and kindly informed me that there might be a little wait for the new time.  When we showed up, he kindly provided us an estimate of the wait and an update on our reserved table.  Then a few minutes later apologize for possibly longer wait for the table and explained the reason.  He offered an option to dine at the bar.  We accepted.  Chrissie behind the bar was our waitress.  She was attentive, professional and patient with our questions.  In addition to that, big smile!  We had a lovely time at Barbacco!   I highly recommend this restaurant and will continue to dine here!

Here are what we ordered this time:

1. Bruschette
    Tuscan chicken liver pate - excellent flavor, not too heavy due to the right portion
    Roasted pears - the flavor is good but very difficult to consume with all the toppings
                              staying together on the bread
    Braised Chichories - delicious, complex flavor, highly recommend

2. Kale salad - excellent combination of the kale, apple, raisins, and almonds, 
                        simple, refreshing and surprisingly flavorful

3. Pacherri - rustic pork ragu/parmiggiano reggiano, constantly good!  Has been on
                     their menu since they opened I think, LOVE their "aldanteness"!  

4. Local Squid - good, but don't remember much about it now

5. Almond Cake - good but reminds me of madeleine, no surprises


They are serving a particular menu by region right now.  I forgot which region.  I order the wine from that region as well served for limited time only.  Very good!
author: Gina W.

description:
I took one of my best friends here for dinner as a treat for her birthday. First off, I really liked the atmosphere of place; it is a little bit on the dark side in terms of lighting, but it's still cozy yet chic. The staff were all really accomodating and friendly. 

We ordered the chef selection of salumi to share as a starter, I ordered the oriccheitte, and my friend ordered the corn rigatoni. All the food was delicious, with pretty generous portions with the pasta. 

Our bill came out to about $50, which is a pretty good deal for two in the financial district, but speaking as a college students, it was still a little bit pricey for us, yet completely worth it.
author: Hanling C.

description:
The food is amazing, and I usually never go out for Italian! It seems like most Italian or Italian-inspired food can be made at home, but Perbacco is so good and perfect for afterwork dinner and drinks or date night.

Salami in a jar, it's spicy and delicious, just don't be afraid of it's appearance!
author: Sonya S.

description:
The meatballs at lunch are amazing. The service is excellent and the price is right.
I also love the rotating crostini they have.
author: Adrienne G.

description:
I understand why this place gets such great reviews: Location, trendy interior and it tries really hard.  But the food is just ok.  The menu isn't all that creative--you can get the same dishes, but better, at a dozen other places that are not as hyped up or nearly as pricey.

And why does it always feel crowded, even when it is not?  Was this a design decision to make it feel like it is always jamming in there?  After too many visits, I have never been able to get over the nagging feeling of being crowded in and that I am actually dining with the people at the tables on either side of me.

Staff and service are always friendly and attentive.

Great if you are looking for a scene or place to impress whomever you are with.
author: Jen Y.

description:
Great ambiance for both lunch & dinner, great service, great food

Pros:
-Really great service. They are extremely polite and in the rare case they get something wrong, they will apologize many times over and make it up to you. I'm always thoroughly impressed.
-Some really excellent items. I especially love their selection of bruschettas, and their brussel sprout side (fried in duck fat, no less!)
-Good wine selection

Cons:
-Some not-as-excellent dishes... a couple of pasta dishes I've had were a miss

I really like this place, and find it a great option for both business and leisure meals. This is supposed to be a more casual version of Perbacco, I think, but it has it's separate charm, and I often prefer it to Perbacco. I'd absolutely recommend this place.
author: Heidi K.

description:
My friends and I were looking for a place after a fairly unsuccessful happy hour and found Barbacco on Yelp. We walked in at about 8:45 on a Tuesday night, the place was still busy , but we were seated right away. 

The food was excellent, reasonably priced and came out fast! I had the Ocrecchiette as did two other people at the table, we were all very pleased.
author: Lisa E.

description: Great visit right from the get go. Was greeted right away, by who I found out to be later the owners wife - love that! Food was spectacular and the server was spot on with his recommendations. Had the corn rigatoni and fried Brussel sprouts (amazing!)They even accommodated my girlfriends birthday and brought her a dessert on the house. Thank you for a wonderful evening!
author: Gabi B.

description:
The biggest bang for the buck in the heart of SF. Prices very reasonable. Food and service are spot on. I go here for lunch, however, I took my family here for dinner this week. I actually like it better than Perbacco (also an excellent choice) as the staff is consistently excellent. The Sicilian meatballs are the best! The owners, chef Staffan Terje and owner Umberto Gibin nail it. Umberto walks both spaces almost every day and makes you feel like your his best customer!

Why can't other restaurants emulate this simple formula?!
author: Miles H.

description: Great place, but you will need a reservation on the weekends. The service is on point and the food is priced well! The muscles and brussel sprouts are always must!
author: Kyle R.

description:
Nice place, nice ambiance and good food. Shared a risotto and the soup of the day with my cousin, and they were both excellent. 
The ipad additional menu was a bit confusing though.
author: Asieh G.

description:
I came in for weekday lunch with co-workers and surprised by the well priced sandwich options for lunch. We were seated and the food came out fast (less than 5 minutes) and was delicious.

I had the pacherri pasta which was large pasta tubes with their rustic pork ragu. The pork ragu was flavorful and reminded me of their pork sugo at their sister restaurant Perbacco next door. The pasta was slightly undercooked and could have used another half minute to get to the perfect "al dente" state.

My co-workers had the salad and the Porchetta sandwich and both were satisfied. The Porchetta sandwich was quite generously portioned and came with salad on the side. We also ordered some olives to share and those were marinated well which brought out the fresh grassy notes of spring.
author: Roger W.

description:
This place was recommended by a friend who spend a lot of time in the city. He told me I would ove this place, and he was right! 

It had a cozy, comforting atmosphere. You do sit pretty close to everyone (its a small place but they make the most out of it with the big mirrors and smart seating), but you don't feel crowded or like everyone can hear your conversation. 

Their drink menu is on an iPad. Unnecessary, in my opinion, but totally cool and fun to play with while you're waiting. The service was awesome, very polite and efficient service. 

The food was AMAZING! I had the duck pate and a pasta dish with lamb (I cannot remember the names, even if I did would be unable to pronounce). Plenty of food and it was so delicious. 

I went with a friend of mine on a girl's night out, but this would be perfect for a date night. Very romantic but not too fancy shmancy. The price was what I thought appropriate for a nice night out. Highly recommended!!!
author: Brenda G.

description:
Food was delicious and well priced. Brussels sprouts were awesome. 

 My only negative would is the general attitude of the place...it seemed like I was doing them a favor by dining there.
author: Sarah S.

description:
They take reservations and the food is delicious.  Service can be hit or miss (during a weekday lunch, we sat at our table for at least 10  minutes before anyone talked to us).

Delicious menu items: the pork shoulder sandwich (fresh bread, tender meat, complete with arugula!);  also, love their brussel sprouts (fried in duck fat!) and the bruschetta (the peas and ricotta were fantastic, but I didn't love the peaches and prosciutto option as much).  The gelato dessert options are good too (the hazelnut flavor is a fancy version of Nutella - who can really complain!) 

The only menu item I didn't love was the burrata with beets appetizer; while the burrata was good, the beets were not fresh (the texture was stringy, nothing like what beets should taste like). 

Lunch and dinner prices are very reasonable. Tables are communal, so note you might end up sitting next strangers and making friends.  

All around, Barbacco is great place to have a casual lunch or dinner in the Financial District.
author: Kimya P.

description:
With the considerable amount of great reviews, my girlfriend and I were influenced into trying out Barbacco.
We had a reservation for a late Tuesday evening, being seated was not a problem. Sparkling or still water was offered... the sparkling water was solid and we thought that we made a great choice of venue. It seemed like we were off to a good start.

- Roasted Octopus was ordered, it was soft and tender, yet flavor was not fully present, it was decent but it lacked punch. When done, we didn't miss it.

- House Cured Sardines; very bland taste, we really would not have known we were eating sardines if we hadn't specifically ordered.

- We proceeded with our final dinner plate (pasta), Paccheri. The pasta tubes were not al dente, of hard texture and of mellow flavor; the pork was lacking in savory taste and a bit rough to chew.

- Accompanying our meal were Brussels Sprouts fried in duck fat. After eating a few, the taste was just overwhelming and not in a satisfactory way. Our taste buds got tired of it quickly.

Dessert was also ordered, Gelato was good for the price and the Olive Oil Panna Cotta, nothing to write home about.

All in all, we will cross this establishment off of our list, it really should not be rated as high. If a place like this is getting good reviews, I would think that all of their dishes should be superb...
Plain food at near fair prices.

However, I will not discredit the service there. It was very professional (though a bit dry); our server was very attentive and helpful.
author: Aaron C.

description:
Great Italian place in the Financial District. 

Very warm atmosphere. The restaurant has a great design, and they show old italian movies on the TV with Italian subtitles :) I felt home! Friendly staff and very helpful!

Food is very good. I would recommend the olives and 'nduja as a starter. Haven't tried the bruschettas though.
The Chitarra pasta dish I had was delicious: the meat balls sauce was perfection! Worth getting! 

Don't wanna even talk about wine: the selection is HUGE!!

Reasonable price for a great restaurant! :)
author: Cecilia D.

description:
Craving some homemade pasta?  Definitely make a trip to Barbacco, you will not be disappointed. I had the chitarra with Sicilian meatballs, chard, raisins and spicy tomato sugo, it was absolutely delicious and the portion was great for sharing. 

The seared squid with chilies, fennel, and lemon was one of my favorite dishes. It had the perfect amount of spice and the squid was cooked perfectly. The brussel sprouts were good but salty; we weren't able to finish the entire portion. We also had three bruschetta, charred spring onion, hen of the wood mushrooms, and chicken liver pate, all fantastic, and again a good size. 

The wine list was good and had the option to order by the glass, half bottle or 3 oz taste. Would come back for some more pasta!
author: Elisa P.

description:
Barbacco is my all time favorite restaurant for business lunch or a casual date and I have been there at a minimum 30 times for both lunch and dinner. The atmosphere always welcoming and the food has always been solid, I have never had a bad dish there, though my favorite is the Braised Chicken Thighs on the lunch menu and any fish of the day on the dinner menu. Everyone I introduced the chicken thighs to loved it and one of them mentioned it tasted like grandma's chicken and you know that's a tall order. I always start all my meals with the bruschette, you really can't beat the value of 3 for $8 deal. and end all of my meals with the nemesis chocolate cake. (They do change their menu seasonally, so please check for updates)

My favorite seating in the restaurant is at the bar because it offers better intimacy since the rest of the restaurant has communal style tables, and you get very attentive service at the bar. They employ very knowledgable bar tenders/waiters and they all seem to love their job, which is an extremely important factor for my dining experience. Do you remember the last time you went to a restaurant and the serving staff looked like they hate their lives? and how it ruined your meal? well. I do.. 

For those of you who do not like to plan ahead and make reservations. The restaurant gets a little busy during weekday lunches because of the proximity of many downtown business buildings, but you shouldn't have a problem getting a table (walking) for dinner with a 15 wait maximum, which is another reason why I love the place because sometimes you feel like being spontaneous.. enough with the one hour+ wait for some over hyped restaurant in SF. 

For those of you who drives, you can valet in front of the restaurant for $10.

I have not found another restaurant in the city that offers the same value for the same caliber of food with such consistency in the city. You owe it to yourselves to come check this place out.
author: Linya X.

description:
The girlfriend's last job sucked. Fortunately, her services are very much in demand, so she quit. To celebrate her self-proclaimed emancipation, we had dinner at Barbacco.

Barbacco is a well appointed, modern, trendy & hip take on traditional, casual Italian dining. We had reservations which did insure we would have seating, but not at our own table as the seating is either at 1 of a row of long communal tables or along the bar. Service was mostly attentive, considering it was very busy. Our server was deadpan, but the rest of the staff was warm with lots of smiles.

While the food menu was on long, narrow paper stock, the beverages were listed on iPads located on each table & on the bar. Like many things Apple, this approach was entertainingly novel but didn't provide any true functional enhancement. The food selection is very faithful to authentic Italian, meaning if you don't read or otherwise know Italian you may not know what a dish is. Lucky for me, the girlfriend lived in Italy a while & more or less translated the menu.

Instead of offering composed meals, everything is a la carte. The girlfriend & I picked out our own combinations of starter/ entree/ side. She got Spicy Braised Tripe, Paccheri w/ Rustic Pork Ragu & Parmigiano Reggiano, Fried Brussels Sprouts. I got Duck Cotechino Sausage, Orecchiette or "little ears" in Cavolo Nero w/ Fennel Sausage & Pecorino Cheese, Roasted Squash. The food took a while, so we had a couple beers & chomped on bread (which was good) while waiting.

When the dishes started coming out, I was reminded of the oxymoron "jumbo shrimp." All 6 of our dishes were like giant tapas. Trying all 6, all were well-made & delicious but 3 of the dishes had bigger, bolder flavors than the other 3. The Spicy Braised Tripe, Orecchiette & Fried Brussels Sprouts were sensational with huge flavor. The flavors of these 3 dishes also complemented each other extremely well, making this a fantastic trio to order together. The Duck Cotechino Sausage, Paccheri & Roasted Squash were still nice, but paled in comparison. Though less intensely flavorful, these 3 dishes also complemented each other well & would be a good trio.

After polishing off so many big little plates of food, we still found room for a piece of Chocolate Nemesis Cake. OK, it's true. The name alone was a significant factor in my wanting this dessert. Though it had an abundance of deep, rich chocolate & a substantial cookie-like crust, this chocolate cake wasn't overly intimidating in any particular way. So, despite the name, the Chocolate Nemesis Cake was easily vanquished. Scrumptiously & gratifyingly, but easily.

Barbacco is an interesting & somewhat quirky new take on Italian dining. Some things are a real big hit. Some things come closer to a miss. Either way, Barbacco is far from boring. What really makes Barbacco worth trying (& trying again) is that even some of the things that are more of a miss are still pretty good.
author: John M.

description: Food was underwhelming. Very loud inside. Appetizers served with our entrées.  I didn't like anything about it. But it was clean.
author: Bryan T.

description:
Barbacco is my (yes, I am going to commit to this) FAVORITE restaurant in the SF.  The restaurant is beautifully decorated and spacious, always plays the giants game, always has friendly employees, is quick with their take out and table seating, has delicious food, and is reasonably priced - all in a prime spot in the city. 

I've dined at Barbacco numerous times and they are always consistent with the quality of their food. I always leave happily full and pleased with my dining experience.
