Some of my favorite small dishes are the ascolane (fried olives stuffed with park, they are SO good), roasted beets/fennel/rucola/thyme dish, all the bruschetta's, and of course, the brussel sprouts fried in duck fat. 

The prizes for favorite entrees go to the maccheroni, orecchiette, summer bean stew, and braised chicken. 

Barbacco is outstanding every time and is aways my go to restaurant that I recommend to others.
author: Michele P.

description:
Completely different atmosphere from Perbacco, the fine dining restaurant next door, which is also very good. Sit at the bar at Barbacco, and you will get perfect service, at least we did. Much more casual than Perbacco, with food more like modern Americanized Italian tapas.  Americanized because, for example, everyone's favorite tapa there is the deep fried Brussel Sprouts. They are terrific, guaranteed, but unlike anything I've ever seen in Italy. Not that Italians don't do deep frying....I'm just saying.

All the dishes were excellent but my favorite was the spinach pasta with Bolognese sauce. That was genuinely Italian and genuinely excellent. Definitely a primo place. No TV at the bar is a plus.
author: Susan B.

description:
My review is for Lunch.

This place is definitely in my top 10. Not just because it's a block from work, but I love everything else about this place too.  Everything except the tight seating arrangements, if you are a party of 4 or less, and you don't want to sit at the counter, and its during lunch hour, you are more than likely going to have to share an already small table with another party. I wouldn't recommend this place for large parties either. Party of 6 max. 

On the bright side... The ambiance is great! It's hip enough for a casual meal, a work lunch, and even a casual date. I wouldn't call it romantic. If you want romantic or a white table cloth setting, go next door to their sister restaurant Perbacco. 

Their menu is pretty delicious. Granted I always get the same thing, I've tried many other dishes ordered by others. I'll only mention the ones I really like and dislike to make this review shorter. 

Their bruschette - the only one I didn't really like was the anchovy one. All the rest are pretty darn good. My all time favorite that I always order is the chicken liver pate, served with some sauce and grilled onions on top. Yum!

Their salads - I've tried the the tuna salad. I did NOT like it. Something extremely acidic about it that just didn't sit right with me.

Their pastas - I've had the lasagna, the orecchiette, and the pork ragu. All good but the Pork Ragu, my all time favorite. Get it every time. 

Finally, saved the best for last, the Brussels Sprouts. This place turned me onto Brussels Sprouts. I used to never touch them, now I crave them. I've even tried many times to duplicate the recipe at home, which I've come close, but not close enough to satisfy my craving.

They have a pretty substantial wine menu as well. They did away with the iPad wine menu at every table. Maybe too many were getting stolen/broken?

All in all, I could probably safely say I go to Barbacco once every month or so. Service is fast, they've definitely mastered the serve-the-full-meal-in-under-a-hour thing.

Last thought. Make a reservation.
I've only been there twice for dinner so I can't comment on the crowds.
author: Ping N.

description: Made a reservation for 2 at 12pm. Arrived 5m early. Waited 25 minutes. Multiple 2 person groups who arrived after me without reservations were seated ahead of me. Terrible service by host. Eventually canceled my reservation and walked out. I work 2 doors down the street. Won't be returning.
author: James D.

description:
This has become one of my favorite restaurants and apparently I'm a regular via Yelp check-in. Excellent food at decent prices, great ambiance-casual yet chic, friendly service, great wine selections, good for lunch or dinner! Make a reservation if possible because this place gets busy. Once you dine here, you'll understand why.

- Duck Liver Pate Brushette: one of my favorites. rich pate, soft caramelized onions, on a slice of olive oil grilled bread
- Braised Chicken Thighs: tender, delicious flavor, saucy
- Spicy Braised Tripe: good and soft, tasty tomato sauce and slightly spicy
- Pesce Crudo: like a sashimi salad, nothing special
- Angry Mussels: excellent flavor! spicy, garlicy, fresh mussels
- Paccheri Pork Ragu: heavenly pork ragu with fresh soft pasta, can't go wrong with this 
- Fried Brussel Sprouts: if you like brussel sprouts, you'll love this. if you don't like brussel sprouts, try it because it might change your perception of them! crispy on the outside and soft flavorful goodness on the inside

Highly recommend everything listed above except maybe the pesce crudo. I think 90% of everything I've had at Barbacco has been amazing. Also, don't get intimated if you can't understand the menu, the staff is more than willing to translate it into plain English. =)
author: Linda C.

description:
Lively, hip, fresh ingredients, and good service.  A must in this neighborhood!  

Been twice so far and both were good experiences.  Sat at counter and shared a table.  I don't think the tight communal dining is just a philosophical choice--in SF, it's a practical one as well.  Browsing the wine via iPad is a fun twist.  

Dishes are on the smaller side and not cheap (this IS the San Francisco Financial District, people), but are made with good quality ingredients and taste delicious!  Try ordering several courses and wines, and proceed at a more leisurely pace, if you can.  

Service was the right amount of attentiveness and friendliness both nights.  A whimsical touch was the 80's movie Cinema Paradiso playing on the flatscreen as we ate.
author: Stephen F.

description: All I have to say is WOW. I never thought I would find such a great fine dining restaurant. The atmosphere was inviting. The food was out of this world. Full of flavor, cooked just right, and good size portions. Service was first class. I would recommend this restaurant to everyone.
author: S H.

description: Ate here for lunch and it was such a culinary treat. Had the farrotto, brussel sprouts, and a glass of wine - everything was delicious!! Simple flavors yet well seasoned...so good!
author: Stacie S.

description:
Excellente....!

From the second you walk in to the end of your meai, the service is so wonderful and friendly. Hostess- and service-with-a-smile and beyond. Perfect place for after work business or social drinks-n-dinner. We were lucky to get a table vs. a communal table, so if that's your thing, it's worth noting to them upon making a resv (we didn't).

The menu is outstanding, especially if you enjoy salumi/salami/prociutto/cheese and the like. You can share or do your own thing - they have a nice selection of entrees in addition to "tapas" style extras from vegetarian bruchettas to salads to soups. Super impressive. I had the meat balls and fried brussels sprouts in addition to a salumi and bruchetta, all incredible.

It's fun to play around with the drinks menu on the iPad, nice touch, and a reminder of what an awesome town SF is. I liked that our server wasn't notably disappointed when we turned down actually ordering alcohol - big plus. Just wasn't that kinda of night.

Yay for Barbacco, great story to boot (to be read on the back of their menu, worth it), mission accomplished.
author: Meredith R.

description:
4.5 Star.  I had the shrimp and squid sandwich and the porchetta sandwich.  I would recommend the porchetta sandwich.  Both are roughly the same size and came with same side salad but the porchetta was done so that it just melted in my mouth.  

PS. I did not have the sandwiches on the same day. :p
author: Jessica P.

description: Love this place. Busy lunch spot. Good to come for business or social lunches (not sure about dinner, haven't gone). The sides are all so excellent. Brussels sprouts and polenta are delicious. Five stars for lunch. I have no idea how it's like in the evening but I would try it out then as well. Minus one star as I had some orrechiete with fennel that everyone seems to rave about that I thought was awful. Strong garlic and too much oil; not much other flavor.  Could not finish, and I am not one to leave an empty plate if I can help it. That said, it was one bad dish out of about six we recently ordered on our last visit, so that's still good odds.
author: Gigi K.

description: Went for lunch and had a great time!  Food was good and prices were relatively reasonable, for downtown SF.  Service was good too, though we felt rushed... no doubt about that.  Pretty noisy, so not ideal for business lunch meeting or anything like that.
author: Maui ..

description:
Two words: Salumi 'Nduja - YUM. Great ambiance, good food and good wine.

Main dishes are not as strong as the appetizers though.
author: Michelle C.

description:
Food and service are very good.  

The space could be better -- not a fan of the communal-dining tables. (up to 6 at each)

Can't-miss dish:  Brussel sprouts. That's right. Brussel sprouts.  They're sautéed in duck fat and balsamic.  I'm hyper-salivating thinking about them now.

Recommended dishes:  baratta appetizer (only if heirloom tomatoes are in season), caesar salad, lasagna, meatballs with a side of fried polenta.

So so items:  the wines and desserts.

The staff are great and really helpful.

Some things that I would change:
1. For some reason, the wine list, which really isn't that extensive, is only available by browsing these iPads that they have at every table.  That would be fine, I guess, if the rest of the menu was on there too, but it's not.  So you end up using an iPad for wine (it's a really bad UI for browsing, btw), and then a regular paper menu for your meal.  Just make the whole thing paper and call it a day.

2. There is one really absurd "table" for two.  It's possibly the most absurd restaurant seat I've ever seen.  It's two seats that sit side by side facing a glass wall.  Unfortunately, that glass wall is the wall of the entrance, which means that, if you're seated in these unfortunate seats, you're either looking at the backsides of waiting customers whose butts are literally inches away from your food, or those customers are standing staring at you through a glass wall while you eat -- you feel a bit like Clarice Starling interviewing Hannibal Lecter.  If you do end up in these seats, I recommend ordering a side of fava beens and a nice Chianti!
author: David L.

description: The lasagna was in fact "better than my mom's" (our waiter). Get it, you won't be sorry. Also, the meatballs were incredible, as were the beets.
author: Mischa S.

description:
we may have just hit an off night here, but below is why i'm only giving it two stars:

- we got there 10 minutes before our reservation and a table was open but we had to wait for our third party member  to be seated. when she arrived 5 min later, we had to wait another 15 minutes to get a table as the table that was open was sat during the 5 min we were waiting. 

- service was poor. we waited 45 min between our apps (bruschetta, brussel sprouts and soup) for our entrees. 

- food was okay. the brussel sprouts were extremely salty and my pasta was just ok, nothing worth coming back for.
author: Dana B.

description: Fast service, good food. Great client lunch spot.
author: Katherine L.

description:
What I Ate
- Bruschette
   - asparagus / meyer lemon / capers / red onion
   - roasted pear / prosciutto di parma
   - braised chicories / gorgonzola / balsamico
- orecchiette - "little ears" / cavolo nero / fennel sausage / pecorino cheese

Would I Go Again?
Barbacco was packed during lunch, and I can see why--I enjoyed everything I ate, and it was all at a very reasonable price.  The bruschette was awesome; each one I tried was packed with flavor, but each was very unique.  I would highly recommend the bruschette to anyone.  The orecchiette was fantastic.  The sausage, spinach, pesto, etc. all came together to make each bite delicious.  I must say that I would vote for a little less pasta and a little more of everything else, but now I'm getting nit picky.  The lunch was wonderful and it's a great place for work lunches in the FiDi.
author: Ben M.

description: The food is worth 3.5 stars. It's above average, pretty good food full of flavor. However a restaurant is not just about good food. The atmosphere is very loud. The service is horrible. Not worth going to this place.
author: Dean O.

description:
Came here for dinner with a couple friends after work at 7pm. There was a wait since a lot of people work around the area and get off around this time.

We ordered a bottle of white wine we thought was $27 but was actually $40 and did not live up to the cost.

Our waitress wasn't very friendly and gave very short answers to our questions. I ordered the lasagna that she recommended and it was just mediocre. It had a white sauce, not red like tomato sauce that I was expecting. Nice after work atmosphere but food wasn't anything special.
author: Christine C.

description: Starving at lunch and wanting good italian, which in the past has been my experience at Barbacco, I decided to order takeout - lasagna and arugula salad. I get back to the office open the salad and its mostly bitter radicchio with a few leaves of arugula and the dressing was so bland, definitely not enough to mask the bitterness. The lasagna was swimming in oil and fairly tasteless. Overall really disappointing (and expensive) lunch experience. I won't be back.
author: Ajj J.

description: Tight seating and the food was OK. I really liked Perbacco but Barbacco just didn't tickle my fancy.
author: parisa e.

description: Truly excellent, unique Brussels sprouts (hints of anchovy and vinegar, crispy on the outside and sumptuous on the inside). Massively sized meatballs, dripping with moisture. Casual, unpretentious, very high deliciousness per dollar.
author: Wiley W.

description:
Decent looking wine/dinner place in the FiDi. Convenient location I suppose if you work around the area. Maybe I'm not used to SF pricing, but I thought this place was grossly overpriced.

The food was moderate at best. I had a table of 5 and out of all the appetizers and entrees we ordered, none of us seemed particularly happy with any of them.

Giving 3 stars for convenience/proximity to FiDi, decent service, and clean looking interior. Not happy with prices or food though so probably will never come back.
author: Kevin S.

description: For all the hype I heard about this restaurant I was pretty disappointed. The interior was nice but the tables were REALLY close together. It was a Friday evening so it was crowded and a little loud. The food was nothing special but the wine selection was nice. Good thing for me the night got better than this meal. I got engaged after dinner which definitely made up for a average meal.
author: Jillian C.

description:
This is a place I can see myself at every week if I lived in SF. 

The portions are small and the prices can be a bit steep for what you get, but everything we had was just delicious. 

Suppli (risotto croquettes) were really delicious but REALLY TINY for the price. I tormented myself for the rest of the meal because they were really delicious but the price just made me feel so guilty for ordering it. 

Bruschette was amazing. My favorite was the chicken liver pate. The roasted pear with Prosciutto was a close second followed closely by the roasted mushroom and artichoke. 

The Orechiette was delicious but the portion was rather small. 

Brussel sprouts were amazing. Definitely not your typical spin on brussel sprouts. It's very flavorful because of the duck fat. The red wine vinaigrette is a nice touch to the dish helping to tie all the flavors together. 

Lamb chops were one of the specials the night we went and they were pretty amazing. Very tender and simple, they paired well with the very robust brussel sprouts. 

Definitely make reservations. They have very little available for walk-ins, especially during peak dinner hours.
author: Chantelle T.

description:
I was VERY surprised with Barbacco. I knew I was in for a glass of wine and some Italian, but little did I know that my taste buds would be dancing like a drunken 20-something at Coachella.

I have to admit, I'm pretty turned off with their "communal" tables. I'm a very social person, and I've sat in communal seating arrangements at restaurants before (i.e. Don Pisto's) and it hasn't been an issue--but the other party was just so in our face! You can't help but look right into the other party. We sat at a table of six, and it was just very awkward, but nothing that a glass of wine and a plate of heaven couldn't solve.

I had the Orecchiette, and I was completely blown away. It's like a very delicate pesto on little ears pasta with fennel sausage, pecorino cheese and garlic. The perfect amount of spice, cut with the right amount of cheese. There was a little blend of everything in each bite. I'm going to have a lot of trouble migrating away from this dish to try something else.

If you do come here, for the love of god ,GET THE MEATBALLS.
author: Tyler H.

description:
Came here for a little Friday night get together with a few friends. Unfortunately, the place does not have any happy hour specials (sad face). I got myself a sangria. It was tasty, but almost like juice. After two glasses, I felt absolute no effect from the alcohol. Either my tolerance improved leaps and bounds or, well, it's mostly juice.

We shared the cheese plate and salume plate. We choose a hard cheese and a a bleu cheese. The salume plate had a pretty wide variety of offerings, I especially enjoyed the head cheese. The true stand-out of the night was the focaccia. The bread had a rich flavor, very olive oil-y, and a crispy crust. 

I liked that the place isn't overly loud and it's great that they have a large bar so it's good for walk-in's, but it could be much better with some happy hour specials.
author: Alice W.

description:
Tapas! Everyone loves tapas. They're great and Barbacco knows it. Prosciutto di parm, burrata with broccoli rabe, spinach lasagne, grilled calamari, pork ragu, cauliflower, brussel sprouts, we literally ate it all. The portions are great, the pacing is excellent, the Grant Family wine is a winner. There are multiple ways to make this place a home run. 

Two things to be aware of: its casual and not the most intimate of spots but good for date night or a party of friends. The only bad dish, the farro "risotto." Be warned if you don't know what farro is, it is not risotto. Its basically kashi and its awful. 

Other than that, nothing but good times here. Even sitting at the counter is fun.
author: Z P.

description:
Been here a few times to pick up lunch and dine in. Social atmoshphere; love the decor. Food is unique. Love the Fregola Salad the time I tried it. Keep the dessert portion away from me cuz I might eat it ALL :o)
Would visit again!
author: Joanna V.

description:
LOVE. 

barbacco is one of my new favorites...

reasonable. italian small plates. not heavy. really good food. great for groups or date night - little tastes of everything

bruschette - super reasonable for $3, but not my favorite. 

'nduja -  

spicy braised tripe ::love::

orecchiette with fennel sausage

polpette - Sicilian meatballs

fried brussel sprouts - in rendered duck fat ::love::

roasted squash with pumpkin seeds
author: Jessica S.

description:
I just had a pretty delicious meal at Barbacco.

I recommend all of the things we ate:

-Duck salad. Amazingly delicious. Confit meat can often be dry, this was perfect. The frisse part of the salad wasn't overly crispy (I have that)
-Orecchiette- split for two was perfect. Nice deep bowls, rich food, nicely shared. 
-Bruschetta- The top three that are ordered, mushroom, asparagus and white bean did not disappoint. 

Friendly service, nice atmosphere, (suits! something I miss out on working in SOMA) and well timed. Complimentary still OR sparkling water. I like that.
author: Danielle V.

description:
We walked in on a Saturday night with no reservation and were able to sit at bar. Which I  highly recommend vs. Sitting at their tables, so close to your neighbors or table with strangers 

We had the fish crudo, while delicious., is a total rip off at $12. You get three tiny pieces of fish (at other places, for example, you get a mound of ceviche for six bucks)

We had the bacon(  ok) and the pear prosciutto (our favorite dish) bruschetta 

The mushroom farro was very good.  The side of roasted cauliflower had weird sauce

I like this restaurant a lot, so four stars. The hubby would have given it three
author: Foodlover B.

description:
Foodie Lunch Date: October 2010 @ 12:30 PM

What a difference two hours make when you are sharing them with a good friend. 

Once again, my beautiful foodie friend Heather Z and I made it to another blissful monthly foodie lunch date despite our very busy lives as modern gals.

Once a month we pick a new "cool" restaurant, take 2 hour lunches and just do our girl-bonding thing.  Believe me, these lunch dates are effective in restoring our sanity. The restaurant of our pick this time is Barbacco.

So, let me get this out of the way. Barbacco uses an iPad as a drink menu instead of the traditional printed menu on paper.  Each table gets one iPad. Very 21st century and very cool. After looking at it like kid who found an interesting toy and pushing the "buttons," I abandoned it.  Call me old-fashioned but I was at lunch, don't want to be hooked up to cyber and just want some good old fashioned meal with my friend. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Wd5ho0_FKk9n7uV8pSCYIg?select=5s7kiomhQfe0x2qzw4abzw

SOCIAL SCENE: Having said all of the above, Barbacco's exterior is almost non-descript. It looked like an ordinary but neat storefront. Inside is contemporary loft with brick walls. The lunch hour was patronized by the "cool and beautiful" or those hoping they looked the part.

DECOR/AMBIANCE: The loft decor starts with high ceiling at the reception area then drops to a low modern white plastic ceiling at the dining area. I wish they kept the high-ceilings since the place was tight, packed and loud! The noise level was so high that at one point I was listening to people screaming to be heard! http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Wd5ho0_FKk9n7uV8pSCYIg?select=fmltN_xSMyqlKGM7tlV4qg

SERVICE: Despite the well-heeled lunch crowd and image of the place, the service was friendly and unpretentious.

APPETIZERS: Heather and I started off with samplings of Italian small plates: 
1. Quick-braised squid in tomato, chili and pan grattato (breadcrumbs) $8:  The squid was fresh but this dish was just okay and nothing really stood out flavor-wise. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Wd5ho0_FKk9n7uV8pSCYIg?select=XrsixfKw4rYS7kKbOkqEgA

2. Grilled Sardine Bruschette $3 or 3 for $8:  I love sardines and I could have eaten half a dozen of these.  Once again the sardines were obviously fresh. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Wd5ho0_FKk9n7uV8pSCYIg?select=X0S_o1pQL79CLdjkkuHKZw

SALAD: We ordered an Heirloom Tomato Salad with cucumber, red onion, basil and olive crostini in red wine vinaigrette. We ordered the bigger serving for $9. This dish was so simple yet so fresh and so delicious! The tomatoes were sweet. Heather and I could not believe that they were only charging $9 for this hefty bowl of organic heirloom tomatoes when one good-sized heirloom tomato already cost at least $5 at the farmer's market! http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Wd5ho0_FKk9n7uV8pSCYIg?select=zXOsph3gHUq8YdNOqrwReQ
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Wd5ho0_FKk9n7uV8pSCYIg?select=Llmq-offuLJWfXp1nyHVKA

SANDWICH: For our main entree, Heather and I shared a Caponata Sandwich  ($9) which was made with grilled eggplant, agrodolce (Italian sweet and sour sauce), almonds, currants and rucola (arugula).  This also came with a simple green salad. This dish was sweet yet savory at the same time. It's like eating salad in a bread. So delicious! http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Wd5ho0_FKk9n7uV8pSCYIg?select=omi3Oj9zt4exWCkMDpDWJw

Heather and I shared everything. In the end we were comfortably full, feeling guilty-free and proud of ourselves for indulging yet eating healthy. We are starting to discover that it is indeed possible to be a foodie and watch your diet.

Tab: $40 ($20 per gal including one non-alc drink, tax and 20% tip.)

Barbacco is a winner! Good service, good food, sophisticated ambiance and affordable prices.
author: Leah E.

description: Food was excellent and a different take on things. Wife loved the seafood pasta except it was a bit spicy for her tastes. She's not one to complain and she ate 2/3rds of it before the spice was too much. Steak entree and roasted squid app were quite good. They do nickle you with the 8oz sodas though. Overall pretty good.
author: Giraffo G.

description:
I'd say this was just OK.  I'd probably go back again at some point if i'm ever in San Fran again, but it wouldn't be my first choice.

See the issue here for me is that it is labeled Italian but you will not find your traditional Italian fare.  They have meatballs on the menu but no pasta and meat balls option.  They have lasagna but it's spinach noodles.  It just doesn't seem right to me...

I ordered the lasagna which cam out pretty quick.  I was there around 5 and sat at the bar...  The bread appetizer was good with the oil and vinegar, the lasagna was just ok.  When I spoke with my wife later that evening I compared it to something from the freezer chest at your favorite grocery store.

This part is not really a strike but an observation I found odd...  From the time I sat down to the time I left I had 6 people assist me.  From seating me, taking my food order, drink order, checking on me, check, etc...  I usually tip based on service of the wait staff, this made it difficult to gauge the tip amount.  I was never without service so i left my standard 20% and left.

I'll give it one more shot and try something else next time.
author: Matt W.

description:
Food Was Great.
We had lunch here the other day started with the Arugula Salad, had brussel sprouts + polenta for a mid-course, then the broccoli rabe orchiette for entree. Everything was very flavorful and chock-full-of-cheese and oil which is yummy!
Wine was good, and I was happy they had complimentary sparkling water.
The reason I gave 4 rather than 5 stars is because the service was lacking. They were not bad, but they were not attentive and more than once the server went to the tables next to us before us when we had been waiting longer.

So food was good, service was fine, and I definitely would go back!
author: Nelli S.

description:
This might be nice for a lunchtime meal, but I probably wouldn't come back for dinner.  The food was good, service was fine, but the inside is just way over lit at night with an ambience that's somewhere between the clean look of a new sushi restaurant and a diner.

It's just not my idea of a cozy sit down meal.  The noise level is pretty bad too, and they weren't even close to capacity.

You can also tell when the employees just really do not enjoy where they work.  Not a genuinely smiley face the entire time we were there.

I had the "Angry Mussels" which were tasty, but I guess I didn't know what 'nduja was.  I'm a pescatarian, and was a little alarmed when they showed up with spicy sausage sprinkled on top and in the sauce underneath.  I'm ok with meat broths, so I was OK with just picking around it and getting to the mussels & potatoes.  It was nice and spicy, a little too greasy, but I'd recommend it if you're into that sorta thing.

We also had the petrale sole fish, which was decent for the setting.

If you're looking for a really nice sit down meal at a genuine setting, you won't find it here.  But if you're in the FiDi looking for something inexpensive, decent and satisfying.  It's not a bad decision.
author: Jonathan B.

description: Came here last night with two girlfriends and shared a table with 3 strangers (communal dining).  We got olives, salumi, Burrata, potato croquettes, pork ragu, meatballs, and Brussel sprouts.  Plus 3 types of gelato and the flour less chocolate cake.  Everything we ate was fantastic and would definitely come back.
author: Madhuri K.

description:
Both my husband and I happened to be working in the city one Friday last month so we decided to meet up and have dinner before we headed home.

Barbacco is very cool. Very modern and trendy, without being overdone. 

The iPads with the wine list while cool, was a little much for me, but cool.

The food was AMAZING! Portions that left you satisfied without making you feel bloated. Delicious and perfectly cooked. The spinach lasagna and pallela were both to die for.

I would definitely come back and appreciate the more casual experience as opposed to their sister restaurant Perbacco.
author: Alexis M.

description: I love this place is affordable, service is excellent, food tastes very good. They also have a tasty gluten free pasta dish. That is an achievement in my books. I love their bruschetta
author: Balu V.

description: Yay, I'm a fan. Great place for lunch; there's something on the menu for everyone. I had the poached tuna salad and my friend had braised chicken.  They were both delicious!  The service was excellent as well.  Be sure to make reservations. They were packed.
author: Rita A.

description: Cool spot.  Kinda low key.  The tables are communal, so they'll still small groups together.  They have a long bar area where ppl also sit.  The pasta's were great.  We bumped into some locals that love the place.  They gave us some excellent recommendations.
author: Sam C.

description:
I didn't like how close the tables were to each other, but that was the only negative during my lunch here.  We had the small duck salad, brussel sprouts, shrimp and squid sandwich, macheroni with pork ragu, a scoop of butterscotch crunch gelato and panna cotta.

Everything was delicious, but after tasting my friend's macheroni, I wished I had gotten a pasta.  The seafood in my sandwich was perfectly cooked and you can't go wrong with Acme bread, but the pasta dish was so good.  The panna cotta was also outstanding.

The bill was really reasonable, and our server was pleasant. I'll definitely be back.
author: Seong P.

description:
Although the food was really more like a 3, the company and wine made me believe in Barbacco's four-star capabilities, and I felt generous this morning so here we are with a "yay! I'm a fan".

Prior to dishing on the food -- I have to mention that the hostess and the sommelier are completely lovely -- majorly high marks for fitting in our party of 6 when I called for a reservation on a Saturday night...two hours before we wanted to show  up.

Each of us ordered 3ish things and there was plenty of food to go around -- highlights included the arancini (short rib filled fried crack), broccoli rabe orrichette (sp?), farrotto, and the chicken thighs.  Squid was mediocre, apple salad was crunchy to the point of unwieldiness (yes, I went for all sorts of scrabble craziness on that one), and the focaccia was cold.  Most things just needed salt -- and while I don't think that I gorged myself, I left feeling kind of greasy...?

I should also note that it has so much secret meat!  The brussels are fried in duck fat (which is  awesome, just not for the PETA crew), etc etc , leaving a few salads, a pasta, a risotto,  brushchetta, and well, okay, it sounds like a lot, but there are about 230948 meat things for every one veg, so if that's you're thing, then Barbacco probs isn't where I would send you.

We were a crew in the golden years of our twenties and were the youngest by a few years, that said, the service was still lovely and it was a great way to spend a few hours.

Din for 6 with two bottles of wine was $235 pre tip -- I should note that the wine list is really reasonable, and playing with the iPad wine list is amazing.  Except when you're drunk.  DISASTER.
author: Rachel N.

description:
I hate hate hate to do this.  
   
But I have to.  
  
Barbacco changed chefs, and slightly altered the menu.  The old chef was a mad genius.  A food god.  Chef of Chefs.  
  
The new chef is simply good.  And that means the food there is now "good"  
  
But not 5 stars/over the top/have to go there  like it was before.  
  
**tear**
author: Adam P.

description:
Busy, busy.
We went in a few minutes before they opened and there were already people there waiting..

Tables and counter space (with hooks underneath!).
Beer and wine only. The drink list is available on an iPad where there was also an icon to push to order your beverage.. Didn't try it, though.

The food, on the other hand, was pretty good. They probably have the best Brussels Sprouts I've ever had. It's so good that it would be hard not to order it every time I go to Barbacco.

That good.
author: O M G.

description: Love the atmosphere. Service is great. Up top :) my girl really enjoy the service. I had the Chitarra. The meatball? It was so good!!! I guess the only thing I didn't like it was the starter roasted cauliflower. It wasn't that great, but the kale salad was awesome :)
author: Jenny Y.

description:
I wanted to try this place because I really enjoyed Perbacco a couple years ago. 

Made reservations on OpenTable - easy 

1st star - they have valet and it was pouring when we got there - excellent 

2nd star - the wine list is on a iPad - so cool 

3rd star - server was patient and didn't rush us and was informative because the menu was half in Italian and explained/ recommended dishes 

4th star - food was great. we had their homemade nduja cured meat. It was a bit spicy but really good. The apple fennel salad was refreshing and light. they changed the dressing to accommodate my friend's allergy. soup of the day was celery root and was good. homemade little ears pasta was good and straight forward without lots of sauce and meat to mask the al dente pasta. A-mazing mussels, they were big, juicy and were elevated with the nduja sausage. i think i drank all the liquid goodness. Yummy brussel sprouts. All the dishes were tapas sharing style so I was able to taste a bit of everything. i can come back next time to try the other half of the menu. 

1/2 star - communal dining. it was weird having other people sitting with us because they were couples. If it were 3-4 other people, maybe we would have struck up a conversation, but us 5 ladies talking to a couple seemed intrusive. I like the idea and thought the tables were bigger and would fit 10-20 people.
author: Debbie N.

description: Amazing squid dishes, delicious cheese selection, affordable Italian wines by the glass!
author: Erin W.

description:
So this is a ok for lunch I hear - but our dinner experience was not great! Perbacco is much better for the buck and quality of food.

Not that we worry about spending $$$ for good food or drinks. 

But the wine I purchased here was not great - small glasses and was $16.00 per glass! Half the price of our meals combined! For just three glasses of wine! 

I will ask the price if there is a next time? The wine did not even seem to have any alcohol in it as well. :(

Then the 'Gelato' ? 'Butterscotch' had a fake, fake after taste! Yuck! And the other 'Gelato' was very flat and the texture was like that old 'iced' ice cream - not even gelato like. Come on guys!

We probably won't choose Barbacco again... Perbacco is fine though. We are local and there are so many better choices here.... sorry Barbacco! :(
author: Kirk M.

description:
God I'm so sad I found out about this place during my last week working in the city!

I came here with out brokers for my going away lunch. Since it was my goodbye lunch, they let me order anything and everything on the menu!

Between three people, we ordered:

Bruschetta: (2 of each)
crushed borlotti beans / duck conserva
tuscan chicken liver pate /onion marmellata
roasted peaches / prosciutto di parma

Tomato and mozzarella salad
Paccheri / rustic pork ragu
Brussel Sprouts fried in duck fat

Gelatos
Almond Cake
Buttermilk Panna Cotta

Holy deliciousness!
The bruschettas are big! Each is like two big bites. My favorite ones out of the three we ordered were the beans and chicken livers. The pasta was amazing too. It's definitely more of a one person size...maybe share between two. But sharing between three was really stretching it. Brussel sprouts are definitely a must order. For dessert, the almond cake was great. Not too sweet and great almond flavor.
author: Janny N.

description: I went here for my birthday with my roommates and mother. It was great! A really cool atmosphere with a good wine list. The food was incredible too. Pricey, but exactly what I was expecting. I like that it was busy, but the service wasn't lacking. I'll definitely be back!
author: Kristina B.

description:
I visited Barbacco for dinner a little while back on a business trip with some co-workers; the place isn't bad, but it isn't outstanding either.  Maybe it's just when we were visiting, but the restaurant is pretty small, and it took us a good half hour to 45 minutes (there were two of us) to find a place, and that was at the bar of all things.  Service was decent after that, but we were attended to by what seemed everyone at once, and multiple times we had to ask the bartender instead of the wait staff for refills or other things.

The food however was quite good, just a bit small portions for the price.  I had the Polpette along with the Fried Polenta, which were both pretty good (however the Polenta was a bit greasy, I feel it could have been fried at a higher temp so it didn't absorb so much of the oil), and my coworker had the Paccheri, which I tasted and thought was the better of the entrees.

While the food was good, the atmosphere was a bit too crowded and busy for a casual dinner.
author: Michael R.

description:
The wait can be long, even when you have made and arrived on time on your reservation. Judging from how busy this place can get, even on a regular weekday evening, it must be superb. The wine list is listed on an iPad, and they have quite a decent selection of wine. Note that they only serve wine and beer here in Barbacco, so if you're in need of a slingshot of a cocktail, scoot over to their big brother, Perbacco, which is just about 10 steps up the block. 

One of my favorite and outstanding dessert is their Espresso Panna Cotta. Perhaps people have made enough rave about it, but my friends and I actually made a come-back because of it. Service is friendly and efficient, and food arrived somewhat swiftly. We also enjoyed their broccoli rabe orecchiette; very tasty.
author: Rika P.

description:
Sister restaurant to Perbacco, this is really one of the finest bargain restaurants you can find in the financial district.  

You really get a quality meal at a bargain (most dishes are under $20), and the wine menu here really is not half bad.  All of the pastas here are worth to be ordered, and they really do a fine job given how little you are paying them.

The service can be a little better (at least more enthusiastic), but the decor, ambiance, and buzz here really is terrific.  This is a great place to grab a bite with some friends or for a 8th or 9th date.
author: Mark M.

description:
What can I say? Simply fantastic! When arriving without a reservation we got a glass of wine and after waiting 20 minutes we got seated, and from then on the experience was pure pleasure. The Flat Iron Steak Tagliata was the best steak I have had for a very long time, so tender and tasteful... My companion had the Cornish Game Hen Al Mattone and it was delicious too. The Almond Cake for dessert, also very good. 

The service? Smiling people, doing a good job all the way. No wonder, because the atmosphere of the place is very pleasant. The only negative thing was the old Italian movie that was shown (with no sound :-D) on a 40" screen behind the counter, it was a bit distracting, but that's a minor detail.

It makes me happy to go to a place like this, and I really recommend it! 

This is a place where nice people do a superb job in giving their customers the best Italian food experience possible. I love it!
author: Jo Petter K.

description:
Another day, another fancy lunch.
Maybe I had the best BLT of my life at Barbacco because I can't think of one better. Nope, I really can't. it consisted of heirloom tomato, bacon, romaine, basil, black pepper aioli and a cheese that may have been Roquefort but was definitely blue. I didn't ask the waiter nor did it specify on the menu which is pretty odd.
I opened the lunch with a roasted beet salad that was very predictable but enjoyable as it had fennel and goat cheese. The menu stated it had horseradish but I tasted no kick. I kinda' wanted the kick! I kinda' wanted to be kicked all over the joint!
With my sandwich I had some roasted fingerlings that claimed it would be served with a garlic confit. Maybe I don't know what confit is but the potatoes were served with roasted portions of garlic.
The mint lemonade I drank with the meal was as advertised and delicious.

So it was a really good meal but I'm either very confused or the menu is a bit of a suggestion rather than a rule. I will be back to try more but I will have to make sure I know what I'm getting before I confirm my order.


In case it matters the clientele was business lunch and tourist trending.  I do love a power lunching table of business suit wearing ladies but that's besides the point.
author: Alexander R.

description:
The food itself deserved two stars but an extra star was for the sservice.

This was my third time here.  The service was still great but the food was just so so this time.  

My friend and I shared the Tuna Sandwich and the Pork Paccheri Pasta (large, hollow, tube-shaped pasta).  I used to love the Tuna Sandwich but today the sandwich was kinda flavorless.  The bread had too much butter spread.  

The portion of the pasta was too little.  There were only couple tiny pieces of pork there.  The pasta was little under cooked.  

Due to the selection of the lunch menu was kinda limited, I don't think I will return here in a short time.
author: Liza T.

description: Love this place for cozy, Italian comfort food and a great wine list. Just wish they'd get rid of the annoying giant TVs
author: Vivian B.

description: Dropped in on a Saturday for dinner, so we weren't expecting to be seated right away. We were happy to take the seating by the bar for our party of three. Problems came after that. We were not offered a drink menu. We were not courteously told about hooks to hang bags under the bar, even though we were a party of three women who all had bags (didn't see those until we were leaving when the hostess told another party). Food wise, I ordered the Orrechiette, and it was much too salty. Not even sure what it would taste like otherwise because of how overpowering the saltiness was. Maybe it wouldn't have been as much of a problem if I had been offered some wine!! Overall, disappointing to be let down by this well reviewed restaurant after a long day in San Francisco (a day I was kind of looking forward to ending with some boozing, but oh well).
author: Christine C.

description: The wine was good, but the fennel salad was tasteless and the pasta needed some seasoning as well.
author: Ashley M.

description:
Great Service. The waitress was really attentive and I liked their IPAD wine list. Although we never did end up ordering through it. 

Food was average. I can't think of a single item that really stood out in my mind. Pretty pricey, but understandable given how close to the financial district it is. There's no other great food around here. 

One redeeming dish was the artichokes.
author: Winny F.

description: As far as Italian food, this place was alright. I do think it was way overpriced for the quality of the food. I had the lasagna and was disappointed with it. Also, it should be noted that even if you make a reservation, you can still be seated at the bar. So if that's not your desire, make sure to specify.
author: Gianna A.

description:
Our group received great customer service here. I certainly owe Barbacco a 5-star review. Changes in start time, waiting for others in our party to arrive...despite this, the everyone was cordial and provided great service at the table.

Fried Brussels sprouts were a big hit. One of the group said, "I'd come back (from Oakland) just for this." Of course, what food wouldn't be improved by being fried in duck fat?

My orechiette was very satisfying and an excellent combination of flavors to go along with the pasta: broccoli rabe, pecorino cheese, and sausage. Very highly recommended

We liked the cured sardine bruschetta for its saltiness, of course, and the version with roasted pears as well. 

Beer and wine are listed on an iPad. We read up on it but  placed the order with our server, at her request.
author: Mike H.

description: I am a fan of the meatballs and brussel sprouts. The prices here are great especially for a restaurant in the financial district.
author: Korissa S.

description:
Decent Italian food at a reasonable price. I've been a couple of times and have been quite impressed by the pork ragu with paccheri -- the ragu is flavorful and the pasta is cooked just right.

The brussels sprouts are good when cooked right. (I had to send the first batch back as they were overly vinegary, but they happily cooked a second batch which were much better.)
author: Glen G.

description: Service was good but I can't say the same about the food. I'm from San Diego and we have a ton of amazing restaurants, this one would not last long with the menu that they offer along with the food itself. If your in the mood for drinks, I'd say go for it! But if your wanting a meal there are plenty other options nearby. (Side note, there is no music, so listening to people in the background gets old after a while)
author: Evan G.

description:
4 1/2 stars. Everything was so yummy. Like it better the Perbacco. 

Bruscheete:

Chicken liver pate-yummy
Roasted pear-refreshing
Roasted Mushroom-best one

Small Chef Salumi-they give you alot. Delish

Pork Ragu pasta-Very good

Brussel Sprouts-One of the best I ever had.
author: Karen H.

description: My review is solely on the idiot I just spoke on the phone with. Wouldn't even let me finish my sentence that we had 9 with our party. Whatever! I had a budget of $350 to spend, will take it else where.
author: Tom L.

description:
This was a pleasant surprise...I didn't expect it to be really good b/c it was in the Financial District, but the food was delicious!  Although the quantities are small, everything was very well-cooked and flavorful.  The suppli (mushroom risotto croquettes filled w/ truffled mozzarella) is a must try if you loved risotto and fried foods.  For the main dishes, I had the angry mussels and flat iron steak tagliata - both were amazing, but only enough for a light dinner (or maybe I'm just an oink oink).  I really liked the sauce the angry mussels came in and wished I had bread to go w/ it...so one star off b/c the restaurant didn't offer free bread!  I feel like it's a must if you're starving and need some carbs to fill up the light fare.  

I also liked the hip iPad ordering style for the drinks.  Barbacco offers wine to go w/ your meal in all different sizes (glass, quarter, half, and full bottles), which is perfect b/c lightweights like me can only take so much...
author: Chinh T.

description: I came here with my future MIL on a Tuesday night, and we had a fantastic time. The atmosphere is great, the staff are very friendly and make great suggestions, and there are tons of options on the menu. We split two veggie dishes and an entree and were incredibly full. I also had their panna cotta for dessert and it was KILLER. By far one of the best desserts I've had in a long time, and I would go back for it alone!
author: Rachel A.

description:
For such a nice restaurant, my group was surprised the meal could be so cheap. We ordered several items off the menu tapas style and paid no more than about $15 per person. Pretty sweet.

However, the standout part of my experience comes from the service. We did walk-in seating for 8 people at around 6pm, and the hostess managed to squeeze us in even though there were already some reservations in queue. She said we just had to open up the table in an hour and half because of another reservation. No problem.

We sat down, mingled, ate our meal and realized that time was passing faster than expected. The manager came over and just mentioned that they'd be able to move around some tables, so we didn't have to rush. Awesome. It's small things like this which make me appreciate great restaurant service. 

Service was good. Food was good. Ambiance was good. I will definitely be back.
author: Paul B.

description:
I have eaten here many times, and the food and service are incredible (especially for the price!) Here's a note I just emailed to them: 

Hi Barbacco team,

I moved to the Bay Area a year ago, and since then have been to Barbacco a number of times. Eating out in general is stressful for me because I have Celiac Disease and as such am highly sensitive to gluten. The servers at Barbacco have always been helpful when I bring this up (and in general, I'm incredibly impressed with the service at Barbacco - Barbacco staff seems to be very excited about the food and wine and gives great recommendations). I've never gotten sick after dining at Barbacco, and always enjoy my food. 

Today I ate lunch at Barbacco and was blown away. Before I even said anything to Jason, who was helping me, he (somehow??) already knew that I was gluten free. He offered to have the chef start boiling a pot of water in the off-chance that I might like a gluten free pasta dish. I didn't even know you did that! The fact that I didn't even have to say anything and that you all know enough about gluten intolerances that you boil a separate pot of water was above and beyond. 

One of the most difficult parts about having a sever gluten sensitivity is trying to navigate meals at restaurants that don't have a dedicated gluten free kitchen. It's rare that I can have a meal where I'm not overly anxious about being "glutened" and actually enjoy my meal. I know that you can't ever guarantee that there is no cross-contamination, but I wanted to thank you for being proactive and making me feel safe and happy about the food I'm eating. It's often tiresome to have to pull a server aside and explain the ins-and-outs of my diet and gluten and see if I can be accommodated. To just sit down, order, and eat is such a treat. And seriously, give Jason a high five or something, because he made my day. He even when and got me the box for the pasta so I could look at the ingredients. 

Also, the pasta was delicious. I asked for no cheese because I'm somewhat lactose intolerant, and didn't have to ask twice. That just makes me feel even better about your staff's ability to communicate to the kitchen - something that is really integral to my health and the health of people with diet-related illness! 

I don't expect restaurants to cater to my food intolerances, but it's incredible when I'm actually able to eat out. I'm also always embarrassed when I have to be high maintenance and ask a million questions, and you made me feel like a "normal" customer today. Thank you.
author: Michelle V.

description:
Is it still called "Tapas" if it's not a Spanish restaurant? In any case, this Italian "small plates" restaurant was great! 

We had a variety of bruschettes. My favorite was the duck live pate. Delicious! The balsamic onions really added to the flavor! The lardo was interesting... the first time I had this tripe-like-but-melts-in-your-mouth substance. 

We also had a variety of other dishes such as the braised squid, flat iron steak, soft polenta, fried brussel sprouts, and pork ragu. Every dish was great, especially the fried brussel sprouts, which we ended up ordering seconds of.

Desserts were all good, as well. 

The staff is very knowledgeable about their wines, , and our waitress was able to pick us out a bottle according to our preference and we really enjoyed it!

I'm definitely coming back!

By the way.. wine lists on iPads? The geek in me approves. 8-)
author: Kazu O.

description:
Go for the entrees and ambiance, but not for the appetizers or dessert.  Bathrooms are eh.

Appetizer:  
Steamed Mussels: we both felt it was lacking in flavor.  the mussels were fresh enough, but they were literally steamed, placed in a light butter sauce and that was about it.  The parsley and garlic was nearly non-existent, and I frankly had to add black pepper to it to make it "interesting".  
Buschette: We had the Persimmon Prosciutto one.  the prosciutto definitely overpowered the persimmon, so all you got was a small hint of sweetness.

Entree: we had the Chitarra (Hand Cut Pasta with Sicilian Meat Balls) and Pollo al Mattone (Rotisserie-style Chicken)  She loved the chicken and I loved the Chitarra.  Even better for me was to move between the two; the tastes were completely different.  Moist chicken and super flavorful, the meatball had pine nuts in it and was moist as well.  just plain amazing.

Dessert: we had the Panna Cotta, and when it came out, it was in a jar.  Didn't seem to match the ambiance of the room/restaurant, so we thought it was odd.  The lemon curd was way too strong, but I liked the pomegranate and puffed rice crunch (she didn't care for that).  All in all, the panna cotta was too soft and the taste was all over the place

The ambiance was nice, definitely date-worthy.  In fact, the couple next to us was on a date for sure.  So yes, the tables are close together; we could hear everything the next table over was talking about.

Bathroom was nice, but only one per gender, so you had to wait if anyone was in front of you.  As a guy, any line is unacceptable, and at one point, there were two others in front of me.
author: Keiske S.

description:
Came here the first time because my previous boss treated me for my last day of internship. 
I fell in love with the mushroom rissotto and have been coming back ever since! 

First of all, I would like to compliment their amazing service. All the servers are so friendly and nice. Also, they have ipads for their menus on each table. I decided to bring a few friends for a christmas eve dinner and it was great! they have a reasonable price, nice ambiance.

I definitely recommend this place to go with a few friends and try their different appetizers.
author: Tessa A.

description: Happy to squeeze in at the bar on a recent busy Thursday night. The burrata and prosciutto appetizer was delicious and served with a puffy, airy, homemade cracker. Brick chicken was the only so-s0 dish. Peposa was a hearty braised stew with a spice to it served over polenta. Probably should have 2.5 dollar signs but other than that go and enjoy...
author: Joseph C.

description:
We were looking for a casual restaurant we could stroll to from our hotel along the Embarcadero and found this spot via Yelp. 

We had calamari (stuffed with Pecorino and bread crumbs, then grilled) and the corn and bacon soup to start. The calamari was perfect - juicy, just cooked, and seasoned well. For mains, I had the maccheroni alla chitarra, a rustic pork ragu pasta, while my husband had the steak, and we shared a side of their infamous fried brussels sprouts. Truth be told neither of us were particularly blown away by our mains, but the sprouts were moarish and extraordinarily tasty.
The service was delightful -attentive, casual, and very welcoming. 
Whist not a place you'd go to for a special night out, we'll definitely be back when we're next looking for a quick, affordable and  civilized meal in FiDi.
author: Eugenie Y.

description:
I sent out a request to my friends via facebook looking for a great Italian restaurant for Christmas Eve in SF.. Some of my first choices were closed. I got lots of great ideas, we crossed referenced all of them on Yelp.  A sommelier friend recommended Barbacco. I figured it would be delightful. The wine list WAS delightful. Highlight of the restaurant. 

This is one of those trendy places that tries too hard.  We ordered Bruschetta, 3 different types (which is a nice option) All of them had too many ingredients, which made the bread mushy and hid the flavors of any of the ingredients.  The salads were simply average. The entrees (fennel pasta and pork ragu) were actually quite nice and saved the evening from being a huge disappointment. 

There was nothing special about the service nor the atmosphere.  So many better options in San Francisco if you are looking for Italian.
author: Tricia S.

description:
(See pics)

More of 3.5 stars.

Flour-less chocolate cake was divine! 

Okay, the best part was written. Now comes the story.

Came for a small farewell with a friend who was embarking a long Europe trip, a new exciting life. I did not make reservations as the night before I saw all tables were still available. When we arrived they would not seat anyone since it was after 6pm and we were told they usually seat people on the hour or if at that hour reservations were canceled. At this point all bar seating was empty and so were a couple tables. They then told us to come back at 7pm. I now speculated maybe there were people who made 7pm reservations and they hoped us to come back in case people canceled.

As I started calling another restaurant for a few minutes, the server came to us saying they would seat us at the bar seating area. I am glad they decided to do so or I doubt if I would go back.

Food wise, the appetizers beet salad was refreshing. The brushette and lardo were a bit hard and chewy, but the duck liver pate and smoked lonza were good.

I had the special- albacore tuna with arugula and peas which was pretty good.

Cherries with gelato (I think it's actually ice-cream and not Italian gelato) was good.

We also had  Vigneti Massa Barbera which was a light and great pairing especially for an early evening.

Service was fast as the server ordered on her little electronic pad as we were browsing through the wine list on the iPad. By the time we finished ordering, the appetizers were already in the works.

One thing, though, was the actual serving of the main course showed up when I was still enjoying the appetizers. The server did come by and checked as she realized it.

Also, the bar seats were on the heavy side and a bit hard to adjust and sit comfortably. Maybe the tables would be slightly better.
author: T L.

description: Not only do I know them for their consistently delicious office catering, but they have even better goodies for lunch. I was impressed by how addictive their brussel sprouts were! It was decadent! Also, kale salad can be pretty lame, but they juge it up right with flavor. I had a nibble of duck confit salad too and was pleased with its tantalizing taste. Great for business lunches, but leave cocktail hour to Perbacco :)
author: Brianna S.

description:
I'm a fan! Especially since this is situated right in the heart of financial district. It's extremely affordable and I would highly recommend it if you want to go to a decent place around work. 

I like the idea of the menu - everything comes in tapas style and it's easily shared with friends. 

My favorite dishes: brussel sprouts cooked in duck fat, cheese plates, lasagna, fried polenta balls, pork belly sandwich (serve with acme bread!) for lunch.

I wish I can give some bonus points for the ipad menu!
author: Keara C.

description:
I do not understand the reviews for this place.  It was barely ok.  They were out of the first 2 wines I ordered and the vegetarian options were few and far between (even though we called first to make sure there were plenty).

It looks a little empty behind the bar to me, like they keep meaning to restock and haven't.  Beer and wine only BTW.  The restaurant was well put together and the staff were attentive.

We had a cheese plate, the bacon-wrapped figs for the meat eaters, brussel sprouts,  risotto balls (they call them something else), and grilled veggies for appetizers.  The brussel sprouts were off the hook and of course the cheese platter was fine.  Everything else was decent.

For dinner I had the butternut squash pasta.  It was mushy and tasteless.
author: Stacey C.

description: Solid food here, got the food to go.  Got some food based on recommendations by the staff, pasta with 3 huge meatballs, beef stew over polenta, salumi sample plate, and a grilled chicken breast.  All were solid even though we got it to go and ate it a little bit later.  Really terrific atmosphere in the restaurant, pretty low key and casual.  Will definitely return again next time I am in town!
author: Vinh T.

description:
I like this place.
The food is really good, the service is prompty and the location is very convenient.
Great for a business lunch at the Financial District or to just catch up with a friend.
Their menu have enough options and at this time I went with the lasagna, and it was 100% delicious! No cpmplaints at all. I actually like Barbacco much better than the "rich brother" Perbacco, where the service is absolutely awesome, but the food I didn't really love, and it is very overpriced. Barbacco is the right choice for italian food, for sure.

Will definitely be back.
author: Paula C.

description: 3.5 stars.  We had dinner here and thank you for putting on the Giants during the postseason.  The apps were great, but entrees were oily and needed salt.  Definitely would come back, but plan on ordering a lot of small plates and apps.  Another patron next to us obliviously asked if they could change the channel to a college football game since "no one was watching the Giants" on the path to creating a dynasty.  Thank goodness for good food and common sense at Barbacco.
author: Tim L.

description: Located next door to its sister restaurant, Perbacco, BARBACCO is like the younger, hipper sister.  The food is, unsurprisingly, delicious and is a popular lunch spot for the FiDi/Downtown scene.  Service is impeccable.  I'd recommend the kale salad with tuna or the pork sandwich for lunch.  Come early and definitely make a reservation as it will fill up at noon.  Happy hour is equally fun and lively.  A definite must in the FiDi!
author: Angela R.

description:
Ah the days when I used to work in the area, I'd look forward to Thursdays and Fridays after work where we'll gather at Barbacco for a glass (or 3 glasses) of wine and some delicious food. Service is extremely attentive here and makes up for the fact that it's a popular place with tight seating. Sometimes the bar is a good option too for smaller groups.

Check out the wine menu on the ipad on the table and you're ready to go. The servers are also very good at recommending wines depending on your preference and are good about letting you try a few before making a decision. Miss you Barbacco ---- as I am trying to schedule a happy hour there now.
author: Angela S.

description:
iPad wine list- so cool. Ambiance & friendly Italian servers- excellent! We ordered:

- Duck liver pate, caramelized onions bruschetta: OMG, party in my mouth!
- Vegetable soup: veggies still had a crunch, yum.
- Romaine salad w anchovie dressing: salty & tangy, yum.
- Mussels: Huge! Oh so good.
- Pork ragu: hell yeah, that's what I call aldente! Amazing!
- Mushroom risotto: not too creamy, I can taste the flavor in every grain, best risotto I've ever had.

Next time, I need to save room for dessert!
author: Ennie L.

description: I used to get take out here frequently, but the staff ignored my orders so often that I will never go back.  Pandora would normally take my order and I would arrange to pick it up at a specific time.  On countless occasions, the food was not ready at the specified time and the staff were in no way apologetic about making me wait or ignoring my order.  If you value your time, spend your money elsewhere.
author: Lester B.

description:
The four of us came here for dinner. We were seated at a narrow table with six chairs. The table/wall is angled..making the seats agains the wall a bit awkward. We decided to spread out. However, we were asked to move against the wall, in case they need to seat two additional people at the table. WTH?? It's not one of those spacious communal tables, nor can the tables be seperated. I couldn't imagine having another party of two seated so close to us and be subject to our obnoxious conversation... Being the smallest of the group..I was crammed against the wall during the entire dinner. Of course..the two extra seats were never used...

Okay..now that I've vented--The food and service were decent. The highlight were the fennel rub pork, the squid, the mushroom risotto, and the cheese plates. I didn't care for the pasta with Tuna..tasted bland and boring. The heirloom tomoato was a bit too watery..

I did enjoy nagivating through the wine list on the iPad..but the overall experience doesn't leave me with much excitement to return anytime soon.
author: Mimi T.

description: Maybe eating Barbacco out of take-out containers at my desk takes away from the experience, but I found the food to be mediocre with nothing particularly memorable about it. I had the chicken under a brick, which was essentially two chicken thighs with herbs and lemon juice served with broccoli rabe. I found the chicken to be too greasy, although once you peeled back the slightly soggy skin, the chicken was tender inside. I also had the sweet corn appetizer, which was mixed with cherry tomatoes and basil. I loved this little salad particularly with the fragrant basil flavor that made the dish bright and refreshing. Overall, the highlight of the meal was the appetizer, while the chicken left me wanting more particularly for the price that I paid.
author: Ashley T.

description:
A friend of ours had a coupon for this place, and having wanted to try it at some point, my hubby and I joined him and another friend.

Good thing we had a reservation, because they were slammed, (even though it was a Monday night.)

Service started off slow, but definitely improved after we ordered.

Since we decided to share everything, we each picked a few dishes. I think this was the best way to go, the portion sizes are perfect for sharing, and I like being able to try a few bites of a variety of dishes:)

Everything we had was pretty good, although my one complaint was the amount of olive oil used. It was a little much on the fish special, and in one of the pastas. I definitely think cutting back on the oil would have improved both dishes, and my enjoyment of them.

We ended with some shared desserts, and those were AMAZING.
The chocolate "nemesis" cake was perfect for sharing since it was so rich, and I'm not usually a  fan of panna cotta, but theirs was delicious.

All in all, a very enjoyable meal. If i was in the area more often I would return.
author: Amanda G.

description:
I take back what I said in my previous review. The food at Barbacco is not overly salty when you don't order the brussel sprouts. In fact, it is extremely delicious. 

First of all, service at the bar is way better than the tables. The folks are really attentive to your needs and it's a much more personal experience there. 

Now on to the food... the salads here are some of the best things I've put in my mouth recently. The roast beet salad was just divine. The wonderful sweetness of the beets paired nicely with the gorgonzola and the herb dressing gave it a nice light and savory touch. 

Lovers of fresh cheese have to get the burrata cheese that is served with fresh arugula and grilled filone bread. It's a wonderful paring of creamy cheese with the bitter aromatic greens. It was just a fantastic start to a meal. 

I had the fennel rubbed pork ribs as my main and it was very well executed with a nice char. A simple presentation with very good flavor. Just squirt the juice from the roasted lemon over the perfectly roasted ribs and you've got some bright flavor in your mouth. Pair this with the fennel salad and you've got some nice acid to balance out the meat and fat. 

Finish off the meal with a scoop of spiced chocolate gelato plus a biscotti and you're set. Not too sweet, it's a great way to have a little dessert without leaving painfully full. 

Barbacco is a real gem for dinner and my new favorite place for good rustic cooking, served in a contemporary space, yet really well priced at the same time. I'll be back soon I'm sure.
author: Jon L.

description:
Inner Cheapskate says: SUCH A DEAL! $25 for dinner in the FiDi with slick bar/communal table seating and decent service is hard to beat.

Stomach says: I'm full, but what was it that you filled me with again? 

- Bruchetta: Mushroom/artichocke - tasty, chicken liver pate - heavy and not very smooth, pear/prosciutto - bland, all the  bread was too thick a tad stale.
- Paccheri/pork ragu: Well cooked pasta, OK ragu
- Pollpettes - A shade undercooked which is a bit scary for a meatball, but decent flavor
- Angry Mussels: More like Sleepy Mussels. 

Not bad but forgettable. zzzzzzzz...
author: Snuffles B.

description:
---LOCATION---
2 Stars
Near the market street in the area of the financial district. I wouldn't even know it was there if I didn't walk in front of the place. The only reason I found out about this place was through Yelp. Maybe they should have a sign somewhere to advertise they are out there.

---ATMOSPHERE---
2 Stars
Interesting place. The front of the place have a beautiful open ceiling area. Then when you go to the back, the ceiling goes down and makes the place feel small and cramped. The back of the wall had a mirror to try to make the place feel better, but it just looks weird. I loved the idea of lights on the floors. 

You don't get your own table. You have to squeeze in and have to sit next to another party. That would be odd for me. I would want at least a couple inches away from someone else. I think they got so busy it would be smarter to push the tables together and hope to get people out quicker.

I had a HUGE feeling that thing place use to be a dinner maybe. A huge place to sit down and have you coffee and the table area use to be booths. The brick wall behind should be exposed to give the place a nice look to the place. Like a classic open light Italian restaurant, not a covered up dark cold place. 

BIG downside of the crapped area is it can get loud. The waiter barely heard our orders and my boyfriend could barely hear me and he was RIGHT next to me!

---WAITING---
4 Stars
I would highly suggest a reservation. You can do that via the website or Yelp. BART had issues this day so it was pretty empty. It can get really busy and you may wait a while if you don't.

---STAFF---
5 Stars
We were sat at the bar instead of a table for some reason. The bartender was basically our waiter for the day. He was really nice. We even had a nice conversation about going from East Bay to SF. 

---FOOD / PRICES---
3 Stars

SODA
$3
Seriously?! I got a coke metal bottle. It was really small to. Like one that would be less than a $1 at a store.

BRUSCHETTE 
They are normally $3 for each OR 3 for $8. 

We decided to try three: 
- Asparagus / meyer lemon/ capers / red onion
It was OK. Not super delicious. It seems like something I would have on a salad not on a piece of bread.

- Tuscan chicken liver pate / onion marmellate
DELICIOUS. I have never had chicken liver so it was a new experience for me. With the onion is amplified the flavor of the liver. I would love to have this again.

- Roasted mushrooms / artichoke crema.
It was kinda messy for me. I would have diced the mushrooms a little smaller. I took one bite and all the mushrooms feel off. The sauce on the bottom was good but I couldn't tell you if it tasted good with the mushrooms since they ended up on my plate. When I was able to get one mushroom with the sauce, they kinda blended to well that it was kinda bland.

ORCCHIETTE
$12
I was good. IT was little pasta 'pillows' drenched in olive oil with spinach really. At the bottom of the bowl was a little lake of green stained oil. Barely any fennel sausage. I was afraid that it may stain my teeth green... yea that is how GREEN it was. I will admit the spinach in the did taste great.

BRAISED CHICKEN THIGHS
$14
Delicious! My boyfriend ordered this but we traded bites. The chicken was baked but was still moist and delicious. Baked it perfectly. Wish there was a little more spices added to it. Maybe more pepper and cumin to match the earthy taste of polenta. Never had polenta either. Wish I had ordered his dish instead. 

APRICOT SORBETTO
$3
Wow, just apricot puree, sugar, and water. Defiantly tasted like apricot. Really sweet but good overall. Wish they added something to the scoop. Maybe mint or a drizzle of chocolate. Not just a single scoop into a tiny cup.


I loved the waiter and some of the foods, but I don't think I'll be coming back. Everyone is different but it's defiantly worth a try!
author: Jolene M.

description:
Tasty, but forgettable small plates. A fair selection of wine. Nothing to write home about.

Gripe: The iPads are not used for ordering. They are there for you to peruse their drink menu and you still have to order through a server. I call that a failure in connecting trendy tech with your business operations. If it did, they would have a schtick interesting enough to bring up in conversation.
author: Linda T.

description: Way better than Perbacco. Or more accurately, way better than my experience at Perbacco. Food is good--great for sharing with groups. Honestly, one dish MAY not be enough for one person but it's good for groups to go and share a few different dishes. Some of the seating is communal seating so as long as you don't care about that, you are good to go.
author: Diana Y.

description: Average food, poor service. We complained about our salad and still had to pay for it. Will not come back again.
author: Guillaume L.

description: No point to the ipad because you don't actually order through it. So it's just a distraction. The food is average for the price, and in this city I expect exceptional.
author: Mark S.

description: I didn't used to be a huge fan of Italian food, but after a recent trip to Italy, I've been pretty obsessed. Barbacco was an amazing place to satisfy that craving. I was leaving the Bay for grad school, and my best friend and I came here for our "Last Supper." We were sat at the bar, which was actually really nice, although the chairs didn't seem terribly stable (mind you, we're not large people). It took us a while to decide on what to order, but I ended up choosing the Burrata on arugula and crostini, with black olive, roast tomato, and garlic confit spreads. I love these fresh cheeses, and the burrata did not disappoint. My best friend had the corn rigatoni and from the bite I had, it was very flavorful and fresh. Service was great; the restaurant was trendy and fit right in with neighborhood.
author: Jennifer J.

description:
So part of me thinks I should be rating this place 3 stars. Another part of me wants to give it 4 or 5 stars. I'm going to just say 3. But I'm torn. Just know that. And also know that I hope to go back.

Arrived at Barbacco at 5:50pm on a Saturday, early as usual for my dinner date. I asked to use the restroom. When I got back and was lingering by the door, evidently giving off crazy person vibes, the hostess kind of barked at me, "HELLO! CAN I HELP YOU?" I told her I was waiting for someone. She had me check in for us but didn't seat me. Helpful! Also not representative of the service, which was overall very nice.

Other party arrived; we were seated at the bar. The bartender was insanely polite and attentive. One of the loveliest servers I've ever encountered. Go, you! We ordered drinks using the iPad they presented to us. The only actual use I saw out of the iPad presentation was you could sort your wine by grape/vintage/what have you at the click of a button. I ordered beer.

The food menu was printed on actual paper (I know, right?). For dinner, we got the jar with mushrooms and mascarpone. Truffle something or other was involved. The jars are "make your own bruschetta". It was cute, and tasty. My entree was the orecchiette with fennel sausage and broccoli rabe, which I will be dreaming about for weeks to come. Incredible, perfect, wonderful pasta dish. 

My date got the lasagna. Oh, the lasagna. We each take a few bites of our respective dishes. He tries mine and admits that it's more delicious than his lasagna, which is still good. Then he spots something shiny in his dish. He fishes it out. It's... a big ol' piece of saran wrap, warming itself between blankets of pasta and a meat sauce. How sweet. 

Not wanting to be jerks or anything but acknowledging that this is the kind of thing you should send your food back over, we sent it back. Profuse apologies were issued by both the bartender and a snazzily dressed gentleman who seemed to be a manager? Sommelier? Something. 

A few minutes passed, my orecchiette was shared, and the second piece of lasanga arrived. A few bites were eaten, and then, there it was again, gleaming in the light. Another piece of saran wrap, easily twice as big as the first.

The lasanga was ditched for a farro risotto with mushrooms, quite good but not as amazing as my orecchiette. The failed lasanga(s) and risotto were comped, and we were served complimentary ice cream.

I would be happy to eat here again, but you gotta wonder about that saran wrap. Also, we were told my food would be comped, too, which was a nice gesture, except that it wasn't. Awkward.
author: Kristina C.

description:
I love Barbacco! I don't normally care for tapas-type places, but Barbacco is the exception. The food is great, location is nice and modern, and the prices are really reasonable. 

I would recommend trying: 
* Focaccia - slightly salted and homemade
* 'nduja - spicy, smoked Calabrian soft salame - a surprisingly spicy little jar of soft salame and enough for 2 to 3 people.
* Chef's selection of house made salumi  - small platter is enough for 3 people
* Orecchiette pasta - great flavor and a favorite! 
* Brussels sprouts fried in duck fat - tasty and sometimes on the crispy side, which I don't mind. 
* Slow roasted Porchetta sandwich - Awesome. I prefer this one over the Roli Roti's but is missing the crispy skin pieces (bummer!). Unfortunately, this is only served during lunch. 

Their menu changes, but the items above seem to be staples. The wait staff is very knowledgeable about the menu and can offer suggestions as well. Unfortunately, it's not a large place so reservations are definitely recommended. Another plus is that parking is pretty easy in that area at night. Be careful not to mix this location up with Perbacco, which is their sister restaurant, 2 doors down.
author: Rachelle T.

description:
I absolutely love this restaurant. I've walked by quite a few times and it has always caught my eye. I finally decided to stop in with a friend last week hoping to grab a table.

The hostess was nice enough to squeeze us into a corner spot (lucky for us we're small!), which was great because the place was packed. There is no bar or bar seating.

1) I have to agree with others that the iPad menu serves no purpose and is quite distracting. Fun toy, but I don't need it at dinner time.
