2) Food was pretty outstanding; the only gripe I have is that I was given the wrong salad and finished it without realizing until the end of the meal. 

- Brussel Sprouts Fried in Duck Fat .... pretty amazing
- Burrata on Crostini - seems like burrata is on everyone's menu these days! Very good but nothing I haven't had before.  
- Chicken Thighs on Creamy Polenta - warm and savory at its best! Exceptionally delicious.

Definitely coming back to try the rest of the menu - make a reservation!
author: Vivi T.

description:
Random wonderful lunch experience here.

After the Giants Parade (Go Giants!) we were hungry and were looking for a quick bite to eat. First we ended up at Schroeders, but for some reason they had only staffed 1 server... yes it was a Wednesday, but it also was the Giants Parade and Halloween, please allow proper staffing on such festive days. 

Anyway, being hungry and not willing to wait, we decided to yelp, call, leave and give Barbacco a shot (I had heard great things from my Concierge-staff at the InterContinental Hotel San Francisco). 

There was no wait for Barbacco and our server (Aglianico) took immediate care of us. He was quick, friendly and had awesome recommendations. 

We ordered the Beets Bruschetta, which was DELICIOUS. Then I had the Mushroom Risotto, which was very tasty. 
My friend order the BLT (with Heirloom tomatoes and gorgonzola cheese) sandwich which she really enjoyed as well.

Along with this we had some Italian wine based on the recommendation of our server. 

I will be back for a full on meal, with more tasty bruschetta soon! And I will definitely recommend this place and ask our Concierge to continue recommending this place.
author: Helen D.

description:
Service is great and selecting wine and specials on an I-Pad is cool and all, but after trying Perbacco first, I have to day, it is far better than Barbacco.  The salumi platter was nothing to rave about, however, the one at Perbacco is a like heaven on a platter!

The gnocci special was tasty but overly oily and uninventive.  

Perbacco is definitely worth the extra $!
author: LeAndra M.

description:
I came here for "fancy friday" lunch with my coworkers. We were all intrigued by the iPad wine menu, but in the end left a little disappointed by it. Personally I'm about 0 for 3 in finding an iPad based drink menu worth something over a paper menu  - in fact I always seem to think it's not as useful in the end, since it ends up splitting things in ways that might not seem intuitive - and makes it hard to see al your choices in one place.  This being said, the service  was great and when I ended up wasting about 5 minutes clicking around on the iPad, a good wine suggestion was made by the waiter. 

The food was very very good.  I started with a simple hearts of romaine salad, which was crunchy, tangy delicious. The main portion of my lunch was the maccheroni alla chitarra with a rich pork ragu. While the portion seemed small at first glance, the dish was rich and filling, and it ended up being a perfect portion size. My coworkers all seemed to enjoy their lunches, and gave high marks to seafood sandwich and the lentil stew. We'll be back!
author: neil c.

description:
So after moving to SF early last year, Barbacco has been one of my solid business lunch spots in the city. I was lucky to be taken by a yelp elite and man was I not disappointed. Definitely packed always so make sure you show up with a reservation otherwise you will be waiting for a while. The place is definitely a nice joint to go for a business lunch and the ambiance is simple but classy making it perfect for a nice lunch with clients or coworkers without being over the top flashy. 
We were seated promptly and the waiter came over to get our order. We were both a bit hungry but the person I was with wanted to make sure that I got a few of the key highlights so don't judge us for the order we placed. Ready?
Alright so we ordered the slow roasted pork sandwich, the pork ragu, and the polpette. I told you it was an aggressive order for two people but don't hate just because you are jealous at the order we placed. So the sandwich was great and it comes with a pickled red cabbage on the side. It had a nice flavor to it but I found that I was a bit bored of the flavor after a few bites out of it. The polpette is delicious and tender. My co worker swears by it and I was not disappointed by any means with this choice. The pork ragu was hearty and light at the same time which I did not expect as most park ragu plates are very heavy. The service was also quick which I appreciated since we were on a schedule.
Overall definitely a great place for lunch and will definitely be coming back to try other items on the menu.
author: Dan M.

description: Best rabbit cresti de gallo pasta of my life. Can still think about it and make my mouth water
author: Jane B.

description:
05.04.10

Came here for a late lunch with Tan T.  Decor is simple and modern.  Bar stools are quite comfy.

Lunch prices are extremely reasonable, and the portions are bigger than expected.  We had the porchetta sandwich and the farro risotto - both delicious.  The risotto smelled fabulous!

Ended with an espresso and a coffee - perfect cap to subdue the food coma that is forthcoming.
author: Jenny L.

description:
I had reservations yesterday at 630PM (via OpenTable) with my girlfriend to celebrate a personal milestone. I had kept it a surprise from her the whole day and just before we left, she guessed the restaurant based of the address. Needless to say, she was very excited as she loves Italian food and heard good things about Barbacco.

We left our apartment in a cab at 615PM, and at 625PM while in the cab, I received a call from an employee at the restaurant informing me that she is canceling our reservation due to some type of flooding in the restaurant. It's not clear if that was a result of the rain the day before or if it was a plumbing issue. She said that they had fixed it in the morning, served people for lunch, and then something happened again. She said that they started serving dinner and since something happened again, they decided to no longer take patrons. This implies some folks were already eating dinner, and we missed the "cutoff". I also asked if we could get a reservation at the sister restaurant, Perbacco, and she couldn't help there either. I was very frustrated at this given that we made reservations a week ago and I ended up getting the cancellation 5 minutes prior to our dinner, when we were already in a cab on the way over.

5 minutes notice after I've already hopped in a cab is pretty frustrating, as I ended up sinking money into the cab. We then had to find another quality restaurant (we couldn't use OpenTable since our reservation at 630 was still active and couldn't be canceled), that could seat us. The first opening we could find was 8PM, at which point we had to cab there. We were starving. All of this, because Barbacco decided to give us really no heads up or support in accommodating the inconvenience.

I'm sure the food is delicious  and service is excellent, but I'm disappointed in how this cancellation was handled. I was put in a difficult and frustrating position because of the last minute cancelation. Lucky for me, my girlfriend is a trooper.
author: Cristobal L.

description:
Obcessed. Good lunch place with friends or coworkers. a Little crowded/loud because sometimes you get sat a communal table. However, prices really are reasonable (lunch 10-17 per lunch entree) or you can just get a bunch of small things (small salad, bruchettas, cheese/meats etc)

Wine is ok, seriously I've never had a GREAT wine here which makes me sad cause they specialize in wine. However, I like California wines the best, despite my Italian heritage and they only have a few on the menu.

BRUSSEL SPROUTS
BRUCHETTAS
or just go with a big CHEESE/MEAT Platter and wine :)
author: Katie D.

description:
Huge fan of Perbacco, so I decided to take a friend here the other night to sample. We split:

Focaccia
Pear and Prosciutto Bruschetta
Citrus Salad
"Angry" Mussels
Roman Style Gnocchi
Duck Fat Fried Brussel Sprouts
Bottle of red

Gnocchi on a bed of greens was the standout. Great texture and seasoning. One oddity: Charging $1 for the two pieces of focaccia. I'm not arguing that's expensive, but why even charge at that point? Looks funny on the menu: "Focaccia / Fresh Herbs and Sea Salt         1". Do they really need that dollar?
author: Anthony R.

description: Incredible all around. Fried Brussels, cab on tap, and chitara are to die for. Excellent date spot. I would go back again and again!
author: Devin E.

description:
To me, this is California cuisine, not Italian, by the way.

Anyway, its good! Sit at the (comfortable) "bar" and order drinks and stuff to share. The portions aren't huge (or overpriced) so you can get a few things and split them up.

The octopus (squid?) and mashed potatoes are good. So is the panna cotta.

I liked that the wine was organized by type via the ipad. It made it easy to pick out a bottle. Plus they have you taste a few before committing. Nice!
author: Catt G.

description: Farotto was creative and rich with flavors. Didn't care too much for the type of grain they used but the sauce was superb. Fried brussel sprouts were good though! Get these! And the giant tube pasta with proscuitto was just excellent. Loved the dining experience with chic interior. Will come back with girlfriends!
author: Stefanie C.

description: Service was solid; depending on the dish, food was anywhere from ok to very good; space felt a little cramped and unwelcoming. Overall, not a disappointment but I wouldn't head back. Even the best food felt kind of average, for moderately priced, small plate, Spanish-influenced fare.
author: zach b.

description:
The brilliance of Team Gibin and Terje shines brightly again at the younger, more casual sibling of Perbacco.  

Co-owner Umberto Gibin, who dresses impeccably and would blend in perfectly Front Row at every Fashion Week event carries his fastidious attention to delicious details and uncompromising  excellence to Barbacco.  

Of course, there are accommodations for the Hungry Hipster & Tech Types, like iPads from which to order your drinks  and a single [muted] high-resolution TV that manages to remain unobtrusive yet still entertain those who come in groups or are flying solo.  

The atmosphere is slick, welcoming and less formal than Perbacco -  that's just fine with me.  The lights are low; the tone: comfortable, and permissive... not unlike having an open door policy at a dear friend or relative's house who happens to be a kick-ass chef.  

Yes, I am am an ethical omnivore and a jubilant carnivore - traits my beloved Cadet inherited.  However, on this most recent foray, I asked between the two venues which he preferred -  his emphatic response:  "Barbacco - they have the BEST brussel sprouts!  Can I get an order for here and one to take home?"

Contorni are vegetable platters "side dishes" to the rest of us - and not so common in the traditional format of Italian fare, but here, one can order tremendous portions for $4 a serving that beg to be shared by two or three.    

Unless you want the World's Sexiest Fried Brussel Sprouts Fried in Duck Fat and finished with capers, anchovy and a perfectly acidic snap of red wine vinaigrette.  That'll be $5 for a giant heap.  

Every time I order them, I am transported to my 34th birthday, when I was stranded and falling-down starving, alone.  After a last-minute business meeting that lasted for HOURS, I surely would have passed out if I'd taken one more step.  Barbacco existed only in the minds of Umberto and Staffan, and I literally stumbled into Perbacco, dehydrated and faint.  It was PACKED to the gills, as a private event had overtaken the entire upper level.  

I almost wept.  I told the Hostess I needed to eat a dinner - a big one - and that I'd be sitting at the bar, which is first come, first served.  Somehow, my dilemma was discreetly relayed to Umberto, who welcomed me back and gave his oath: he would certainly find a place for me.  Maybe it was wishful thinking, part hallucination, or the totally appropriate reassurance that only a Born and Fed Italian Man can convey - I [choose to] recall that his hand rested on my mid-back for just a beat.

He made a second round, maybe 15 minutes later, and *whispered in my ear*  "There ees a spot that I weel make, just fora' you, bella... Don' worry - eet weel be just a moment, please."  The lapel of his impeccable cashmere suit grazed against my shoulder and I thought:  I can die now.  My life is complete; what more is there to experience?

That, Childrens, is how Barbacco elevates humble food to the level of La Perla lingerie.  There is nothing pretentious about their offerings, but it's gorgeous food that a passionate lover would make for you before taking you to the bedroom.  It's all love, sensuality and wisdom that will make your eyes roll back into your head: deliciousness, ecstasy, revelation, laughter, incredulity, pleasure, exploration, sincerity... again and again and again. 

And again...!

*cough*cough*  

I TOTALLY digress!!!

We ordered:

* Cucumber limonata for me
* Minted limonata followed by cucumber version for Cadet
* Pork rillette w/ mostarda di frutta in vasetto
* roasted mushrooms trifolati w/ herbs & truffled marscapone in vasetto
* cured sarde bruschetta w/ radish, fennel & salsa verde
* 2x duck liver pate bruschette garnished w/ galsamic onion marmellata
* crushed cannellini beans & radicchio bruschetta
* roasted butternut squash bruschetta with crushed hazelnuts and comegranate condimento
* house cured lard bruschetta w/ rosemary & frisee
* piave vecchio w/ mosto cotto
* humbolt fog w/ red wine poached dry cherries
* toma trifulera w/ Christmas bush honey
* brescianella w/ mostarda di frutta
* 2 orders of the incomparable Baby-Making Brussel Sprouts
* 2 orders of watermelon radishes dressed in olive oil, salt and herbs

All told, this abbondanza was a mere $82 before tip; the significant leftovers will be Cadet's lunch (or breakfast) and a snacks for me, easily.  

Special thanks to our server, KEVIN & "Young Man"  who were consummate hosts - carrying on the fine tradition and exemplary standards set forth by Umberto and Staffan.

Chow here; belli - your belly will thank you.

Pane intended.  ; D

Grazzie mille!
author: Kim D.

description: I really like Barbacco, especially in comparison to its stuffier and pricier sister restaurant, Perbacco. Barbacco has great starters to share (i.e. the brussel sprouts, the crostini) and awesome fresh-made pasta. Usually really easy to get a last minute reservation as well.
author: Shirley L.

description: Much needed dinner after the Women's March. The place was packed! We had a reservation at 8:15, but got there early. We couldn't be seated yet, but the very patient, calm, and friendly hostess suggested we go to Perbacco for drinks to wait. I felt badly for Perbacco, because all of us wet and hungry patrons were waiting in their small bar area for a table either there or at Barbacco, and the servers had to navigate around our many bodies. We eventually got seated (right at our rez. time) and enjoyed a delicious meal! Our appetizer with burrata, prosciutto, and arugula was a great way to start the meal. We picked two glasses of red to enjoy, and boy, did we enjoy them! We had a farro dish with mushrooms and a crispy brussels sprouts dish that were both so full of flavor and very well prepared. We shared an almond cake for dessert that was a nice way to end the meal. We thought the staff was very professional and flexible with what Mother Nature did to all the patrons.
author: Robin A.

description:
I found this restaurant on yelp and this restaurant to be expensive for no reason. The price of the food on the menu seems priced ok but the portions were so small. Each table had ipad but the ipad didn't help with the decision making. I didn't know what to order. I wish there was pictures of each dish on the menu but the ipad was not useful but for show on the table. I figured that the iPad would be more useful if knew what I was ordering. The waitress was not helpful. My friend order one of the specials and its was $12 and the waitress told her that it was small but for $12 it was not worth $12. 

I order the mushroom risotto which was not what expected. I was ok and was able to finish most of it. 

I wouldn't come back again. The four order $126 worth of study and not one of this us was full.  

The atmosphere was really nice at Barbacco
author: Ashley G.

description:
Food was good, but the service was awkward. I didn't realize it was open, shared seating, which isn't a big deal, but the waiter had a hard time getting in between the tables to drop things off. Maybe it was just our table and the way it was angled? 

My biggest issue: The wine iPad app they seem to be big on also makes absolutely no sense to me and is a clunky experience. It just adds a really lengthy ordering and selection process, the app's UI/UX is horrible - slow, buttons take several pushes to get them to work, getting back to the menu once you add something to your cart isn't obvious and you can't just see all the wines at once, they're divided into categories (and let's be honest, not everyone knows their wines so for one of my party members it was really difficult for her to figure out what was what). But the worst part of it is, you have this really fancy, digital wine menu....and you HAND the iPad to the waiter to complete your transaction. Basically, they glance at your cart and then go walk over to the register and put in your order manually. Now, tell me, how exactly is that efficient? As someone who works in tech, you'd think that it could be a cart check out that sends it to the bar computer register or another iPad the bartender has handy to fulfill and then your waiter comes over with your drinks right away. Or, you can ping a flag on the app, saying you have a question about wines and your waiter can come over with samplings and walk you through their selections. But the fact that you guys went through this whole song and dance to make a cool, nifty menu that doesn't have a digital checkout/order process is just a waste of my time and your money. 

They also forgot most of the requests that one person in my party made, which had her a bit frustrated. 

I'll come back because the food is great, but if you're going to go high-tech and modern in your restaurant service just make sure it's a completely seamless and impeccable experience.
author: Alita M.

description:
four of us came here on a monday night and i really enjoyed the food.  they have wine and beer.

we started with the:
suppli - mushroom risotto croquettes filled with truffled mozzarella
nduja stuffed dates / bacon spicy tomato sugo
bruschette tuscan chicken liver pate / onion marmellata
roasted pear / prosciutto di parma
balsamico roasted mushrooms / artichoke crema

then we had
paccheri / rustic pork ragu parmigiano reggiano 
orecchiette - "little ears" / cavolo nero fennel sausage / pecorino cheese
local squid alla piastra / capers / chili olive oil crushed potatoes
brussels sprouts fried in duck fat / capers anchovy / red wine vinaigrette 
cauliflower / parmigiano balsamella sauce 
roasted butternut squash / pan grattato balsamico / pomegranate seeds

and we finished with apple polenta cake / citrus marmalade crème fraiche

everything was really good.  pasta was perfectly cooked aldente.  service was attentive.
author: claudia y.

description:
The food was delicious, beautifully presented and very reasonably priced. 
The sand dabs were the best I ever had.
author: Francisco M.

description:
Returned for a business lunch and amazed by how packed it gets.  By noon, the place is kicking and there will be a wait (go when it opens at 11:30am or better yet, make resos).  

Had the 'nduja (spreadable salami not unlike pate) ,which was quite good and had a lingering spiciness.  We got the large which is too much (better to stick with the small ... more than plenty for 2, or even 4 ppl).  Also had the focaccia, which is pretty standard.

I had the polpette for my main.  These are three large meatballs with raisins and pine nuts in them.  Really good.  Served in a sauce of tomato sugo and braised chard which added a pleasant juiciness.

Didn't look back at my previous review, which would have been useful because I ordered the fried Brussel Sprouts in duck fat (two things I love).  I liked it but found it to be too salty (basically my exact impression three years ago when I was first here!).

Very reasonable prices.  No wonder it's still a hit years later.
author: F. P.

description: Mediocre food and worse; rude service. Even though we had reservations the so called table was adjacent to a different group's. Basically we were asked to sit next to strangers because they had a few empty chairs at their table.
author: Mohammad S.

description: What happened? Previously one of our favorites, we were disappointed tonight. The first thing served was bruschetta & while the toppings were good (we got pate, asparagus with mint, and mushroom toppings), the toast was burnt. We were in Oregon last week where they mock our SF affectation of serving toast and when it comes to this restaurant rendition, Oregonians have a point. We also had brussels sprouts previously crisply resplendent, deep-fried in duck oil with just a touch of counter-acting balsamic, now fried in canola oil (another SF PC move? / PETA on the move?) & sodden with too much vinegar. The polenta previously crisp on the outside and pillow soft on the inside was granular with way, way too much rosemary. Finally, the artichoke soup although visually appealing tasted soapy.
author: Phillip L.

description: Last Friday I was scrambling to find a chill early-ish dinner place in/ near Soma for the same evening. Everything that had 4 stars and above on Yelp did not have any tables available before 9pm. After at least 30 mins of frantically searching, I scored a table for 2 at Barbacco. I was so glad I came! The restaurant is spacious, not too loud, has decent food, good service, and most importantly, very reasonably priced. Will definitely come back again!
author: Mel L.

description: During my 2 trips to San Fran, I was in the downtown area looking for a nice restaurant on Yelp, and interestingly enough, both times I end up in this place and do not get disappointed. Very good ambiance, great for happy hour or late night drink with friends or coworkers. Great wine selection as well. Food was as good as it gets too!
author: George I.

description: Came here during lunch a couple of months ago. I had the Fried Brussels Sprouts and Corn Rigatoni. Both dishes were delighful - the Rigatoni was a bit too salty for my taste buds, however, I highly recommend the Brussels Sprouts!
author: Kumalah J.

description: Barbacco is the ticket.   Better food, nicer buzz, than Perbacco.  I like Perbacco too, but Barbacco is just more fun and immediate.  Sit at the counter.  The help looks scrumptions.
author: Rob B.

description:
Yep, best Italian food we've found in SF so far.  

The have 6 or 7 amazing kinds of bruschetta.  Try the anchovy & eggplant one.  It's amazing.

We also had the roasted eggplant side dish.  It just melts.
For main dishes, the meat balls were large and filled with apple(?) and spices.  
The thick flat spaghetti with pork ragu was excellent as well.

Looking forward to going back soon!
author: Hui C.

description:
My wife and I went to Barbacco on a Friday night for our 26th anniversary.  When I made our reservation, I had told them about our occasion. When we arrived, the hostess seated us and we were treated to glasses of Spumante by the owner to celebrate our occasion.  That was a very nice touch - totally unexpected.  
 
We started with a cheese plate along with a variety of bruschette.  Both were outstanding with our wine.  For our main dish, I had the farro risotto and my wife had the fettuccine verde.  Both were fresh, and vibrant with flavors.  Again, all I can say is  outstanding! 

The waitress was outstanding throughout the meal, attentive and engaging, and it was also great to be seated next to two gentlemen who were obviously 'regular' patrons to the establishment - very engaging and friendly conversation.

The final touch was when the waitress brought out specially plated desserts as a recognition of our anniversary.  Fresh melon gelato/sorbetto with 'congratulations' written in frozen chocolate.   Such a nice touch, unexpected, and a perfect way to end a very memorable dinner.

All I have to say is don't miss out.  The vibe is unpretentious, the food is great, and the service is friendly and helpful.  We loved it!
author: Marc M.

description:
What's not to love at Barbacco? That's a rhetorical question. But seriously, how can you hate on a place that celebrates salted pig? The food was amazing, the space proper and the staff engaging despite our numerous nerdy questions.

Food highlights included a diversity of salumi that would make even the best Italian balk, perfectly braised squid, tasty burrata and fried artichoke hearts. My goodness. For salted pig, the chef's choice salumi plate and 'nduja spicy calabrian chili sausage spread were remarkable. Did I mention the squid was cooked perfectly? Try a few of the bruschetta - they are divine. 

The space is well-designed and sleek without being too euro. The staff was knowledgeable about food ingredients and drink options. Our server's suggestions were all spot on and she was gracious despite our neverending barrage of questions.
author: Corey F.

description:
I wished I had reviewed this place right after I had eaten here, but better late than never. 

Had reservations for a Saturday night and the place was packed.  Valet parking was necessary and we didn't have to wait for our table.  We chose to sit in a shared table versus the bar.  Made it nice to see what good eats were available.  Wine list comes out on the iPad, something I also saw in Argentina!  

Food: Bravo! I don't think I have any complaints over the food.  So choose wisely since you might end up with too much food like we did, since we wanted to try everything! 

Service: Attentive. That's all I ask and they delivered.  

Overall: Great spot.  Worth checking it out again.
author: Meshell C.

description:
Barbacco is the little brother to Perbacco located next door, but I think it holds its own.  The majority of the food is good, however, I had a couple of items that weren't the greatest.  On subsequent trips I asked the server about what was good and that really helped in getting a great dish.

The decor of the restaurant is very modern with iPads on each table.  The iPads only contain the beer and wine selection.  The only down side is that Barbacco gets extremely loud, and if crowded, might lead to yelling at your dinner partner(s) just to speak to them.
author: Dipesh G.

description:
Such a fun, relaxing place. Lots of little dishes to share, great wine list. Our server, Kevin was friendly and knowledgable. We just let him pick the wines to bring with the dishes and he was spot on everytime.

Some highlights from the menu:
ascolane - fried olives stuffed with pork - still craving these weeks later.
bruschette - they have many offerings depending on what's fresh - delicious all - the one with house cured sardines though so yumma
fried brussels sprouts with capers and anchovy -if your a brussel sprout person, must have
author: James Y.

description:
Wow - pretty shocked this place isn't reviewed better.  I'm a fan and I'm a picky bitch when it comes to food and service.  

Overall, I was really impressed with this place.  If you're a cheese lover like me, please try the burrata cheese plate.  It was delicious and I liked how the paired it with argula (my favorite green) and toasted acme bread.  How could you go wrong?!?!

I also got the muscles, fried brussel sprouts, rissoto croquettes and some eggplant on toast thing.  The muscles were okay (I mean I ate them all but I wasn't blown away), fried brussel sprouts great (you can't really go wrong deep frying anything) croquettes good and unique and the other thing was kinda blah.

We ordered a few bottles of wine, and the wine list was pretty extensive with a variety of reasonably priced bottles and more pricer bottles.  

Negatives, I'm sorry but my server creeped me out within the first minute there.  Please don't call honey or hun.. I'm not a pet.  Besides that, he was great.  He did a really good job providing reasonable recommendations and explained the food well.  I do wish the muscles were better though; looking forward to coming back and getting to try some other dishes!
author: Laura H.

description: Yum.  Classic SF fidi restaurant with great food.  I've been there twice and left a happy camper both times!  The lasagna is hands down the best thing I've tried on the menu. Simple yet so right!  The service has also always been on point.
author: Gohar J.

description: Nice ambiance but food was overlooked, overseasoned and overpriced. I wouldn't go back.
author: Blair S.

description:
I had a wonderful dinner here! The mushroom croquettes were absolutely delicious.  But I think my favorite part of the meal was dessert. Wonderfully done. The lemon buttermilk panna cotta, chocolate nemesis cake, stone fruit sorbetto and a piece of the spiced fruit and chocolate bar. I was rotating my bites bc it was all so good. 
Minus one star bc the waiter, how ever nice, his recommendation for wine was no good. After explaining what I like, he made a recommendation that was exactly what I said I didn't like (Chardonnay, buttery sweet wine). But otherwise wonderful time!
author: Kat H.

description: Called to make reservation. Hung up after being placed on hold for 10 minutes. Oh well.
author: Martin F.

description:
Now dont get this place mixed up with Perbacco next door!

Barbacco is waaaaayyyy better.  I come here for lunch and each time it is an amazing experience.  

To start, I normally order the Bruschette.  It satisfies your palette while you wait for the main course.  For the main dish, I order the Porchetta which normally most places dont have this on their menu.  The Porchetta is sooo good!   The meat is cooked to perfection and is really tasty.  I usually stick to this unless I feel like having pasta or risotto or the lighter fare salads.  Each dish is good.  Just make sure you get reservations in advance since there could be a long wait for lunch.

And each time I leave, not only do I feel satisfied, but I also dont feel like that gross "ate too much food" feeling after lunch especially since I have to go back to work.

I would also come back here for dinner.  Good for a romantic night out (and drinks are great too) or lunch with some friends.

Service is outstanding!  Highly recommend!!!!!
author: Cliff H.

description:
How very SF!  Wine lists on an ipad.

This place was cute and quaint.  The food was pretty good. The long tables are good for large groups, but a bit awkward for a small group.  You end up hob nobbing with people you may not want to be hob nobbing with.

- Maccheroni alla chitarra: This nice ragu dish was warm and soulful. It was sophisticated  with its ingredients, but a nice seasoned overal flavor.
- Braised Chicken Thighs: A definite crowd pleaser.  It's not the most attractive dish, but there is love there.
- Flat Iron Steak: This was alright.  With the other dishes being wonderful, this was a bit just a miss.
- Fried Polenta: Polenta is one of my favorite dishes, but this was a miss. It had a fish stick quality to it, and packed little flavor. We added a side of marinara, because it was just missing something.

All in all, this is a great spot.  A couple misses, but definitely would make this a spot again.
author: Natalie G.

description: I had a wonderful lunch with a friend last week.  The cauliflower soup was so tasty and really special.  The Tuscan Beef Stew and Braised Chicken Thighs were absolutely delicious.  The chicken thighs were juicy, tender and succulent.  The beef stew flavor and sauce were really out of this world.  (Be sure to have lunch earlier than later, as these popular dishes could run out.)  I can't wait to go back just to enjoy these again!  Staff was super friendly and attentive.
author: Deborah C.

description: Great casual lunch place. A bit chaotic during lunch even with reservations. Had the gluten free corn pasta. Quite tasty but would be even better with sausage or some other protein. Looking forward to trying some of their other dishes.
author: Mai C.

description: The service and food was perfect! I highly recommend this restaurant to experience the San Francisco ambiance.
author: Nathan S.

description: So delightfully yummy!  It gets really busy at lunch time, so I was glad we had a reservation.  The staff was super friendly and helpful!  Everyone at the table thoroughly enjoyed everything we ordered (there was a  lot of sharing!).  I have food allergies and our waiter was extra helpful in guiding me towards dishes I could eat.  I ended up bringing food home and it was super yummy the next day!
author: Shay M.

description:
So happy I was finally able to try Barbacco.  As a big fan of Perbacco, I was hoping that the experience would be just as good and indeed it was.  The space is long and narrow, with the bar taking up one half of the room.  The decor and vibe remind me a lot of the restaurants in NYC.  The crowd was diverse - young and old, couples, groups, locals and out of towners.  Most of the seats are left open for walk-ins - seating at the bar or seating at one of their communal tables.  Service was attentive and our waiter did a great job of helping us figure out not only what to order but also the appropriate number of dishes to order.  The food is also available for take out.  If only I lived/worked nearby!  

Now onto the food.  The arancini were rich and creamy on the inside, crispy on the outside.  One of my favorites.  The chef's selection salumi platter was ok (I enjoyed the selection at Perbacco and Beretta more).  The farm eggs,  recommended by our waiter, was so good!  The eggs were on the runny side and went perfectly with the 'nduja and greens.  Absolute comfort food.  We had a trio of brushette - duck liver pate (my favorite!) with balsamic vinegar and onion jam, cannellini beans  and house cured sardines.  Definitely worth a try.  The polpette were light, fluffy and full of flavor and I love a good meatball.  The braised pork ribs were tender and fell right off the bone.  Lastly, the spring peas were farm fresh and cooked just right - not a mushy pea in sight.  Yes, this sounds like a lot of food, but the dishes are small and meant to be shared.  

I love that wine can be ordered by the half glass (3 oz) which makes it easier to sample a variety of choices from their wine list.  

Seven dishes + 3 half glasses of wine + 2 cappuccinos = $90 for two people (I was mildy hungry, he was starving).  A definite bargain given the quality and quantity of the food.  Why not five stars?  I'm not a fan of the big tv screens at the bar unless I'm dining at a pub or sports bar and and we wished they had paced the dishes out a wee bit better, as the food came out in two waves.  Minor annoyances.  As for the food and overall service, I have no complaints.  I definitely recommend this restaurant.
author: Melissa L.

description:
Came to Barbacco a couple times for lunch so want to summarize the experiences and food of course.

Fried brussels sprouts: Delicious ! I would suggest give it a try even if you normally don't like brussels sprouts - it would change your opinion about brussels sprouts. 

Polpette (meatball): Very flavorful with tomato sauce. Juicy also. 

Orecchiette (little ear pasta): There's kale in the paste but did not taste bitter (like a pesto sauce). The paste is well cooked and has a chew to it. There is sausage in this pasta. This pasta dish is a bit on the heavier side - I can never finish in one sitting. 

Paccheri (large paste tubes): The paste is cooked well and still has the chew to it. The sauce is nice with pancetta. Could season it a little more but I still enjoyed it. 

Tips: 
- Make sure you make a reservation; otherwise, show up right when it opens to secure a table. 
- Remember to ask for bread. Just don't eat too much and save some room for the actual meal. 

Overall, good Italian food and service.
author: Xtina L.

description: Crostone with burrata cheese was amazing.  It tasted like the lovechild of mozzarella cheese with a poached egg - light, springy and generally egg-white-y.  The pasta dishes were so-so though (I tried the risotto and the curly pasta with tuna).
author: Letitia L.

description:
Everything was enjoyable overall.  Our server's recommendations were right on.  Hubby enjoyed the focaccia.  The beets in the roasted beet salad were a bit over done for my taste.

I had the meatballs and they were perfect with just a little heat along with the fried brussels sprouts.  Hubby ate all of his flat iron steak and half my meatballs.  He had the potatoes as his side which had a nice smoky flavor to them.

I had the market fruit for dessert  - grilled nectarines with vanilla gelato drizzled with honey.  The nectarines were cold and didn't have the fresh from the grill aroma.  Very disappointed as the Food & Wine section in the Chronical had an article on grilling fruit that got me thinking...Hubby had the flourless chocolate cake and the chocolate something or other gelato.  I'd recommend the cake and gelato for dessert the next time you are there!
author: Marisa I.

description: Nice place. Good people. I got kale salad and the steak. Salad was missing a little balsamic dressing but the steak was very tasteful even though small on potion.
author: Omid A.

description: For all the varied reviews of Barbacco, I was totally blown away. For an affordable cost Barbacco offers incredible food! Haters gonna hate, but the brussel sprouts were ridiculously good. (As were the fried risotto bites and all of the bruchettas we tried.) I can't WAIT to come back here :)
author: Eliza D.

description:
*This review is based on my experience placing a lunch order on Seamless*  

My company placed an order via Seamless at 10:30am, I contacted the restaurant at 11am to confirm they received it. I was informed  that the order was received and confirmed for delivery at noon. At 11:30am (while in a meeting) I get a call from Nathan at the restaurant saying "Sorry, we won't be able to deliver your order. Sorry for the inconvenience.  Feel free to come pick it up yourself". Are you Kidding Me? Mind you, this was a group order for 8 people. How in the world would I be able to carry all of this food back to the office. Nathan never explained the reason for the cancellation other than telling me it was out of his control and nothing he could do. I even offered to cover the cost of a cab ride for someone to deliver it to me, he refused.
The fact that they pulled this move during peak lunch time is beyond me and shows their lack of customer service!
author: Krystal C.

description:
I will admit - I was a wee bit skeptical when I came upon this place. I had read the Yelp reviews but didn't plan on eating here tonight for dinner. Alas, we were faced with the ever annoying task of deciding where to eat. We decided to walk and find some place. We came upon Barbacco a few minutes later. I remembered the reviews and my friend wanted to check out the menu. After a few minutes, we decided to try the place. For a walk in, we were seated pretty quickly. 

I'm so glad that they have a menu glossary because this mid-west born gal gets lost easy on them big city menus n' such. We ordered our drinks and I was bummed that they were out of the Thirsty Bear Wheat. For appetizers, we opted for the slightly spicy ricotta and eggplant bruschette. It was not too shabby! I will jump to the juicy part by saying that the main courses were the clincher for me! I had the swiss chard, ricotta pasta topped with the sage browned butter. HOLY MOTHER! You know how every once in a while (like once every couple of years)...you take a bit of something so good, it leaves you speechless? Well, this takes the cake! The pasta was so fresh and the sage butter coated my mouth like the heavens. 

My partner in crime opted for the polenta and mushrooms, which was also amazingly tasty. We shared the cauliflower/pancetta and the potatoes that were sauteed in either bacon or pancetta grease. All I can say is WOW! We finished off the meal with a scoop of butterscotch toffee crunch gelato and a piece of chocolate cake. Divinity. I will absolutely recommend this place to my friends and will continue to frequent this establishment until A. My pants no longer fit B. My wallet is nothing but a Safeway club card and a Mcdonalds gift certificate from my Grammy or C. All of the above. 

Cheers to Barbacco - keep up the good work!
author: Autumn Y.

description: The food was awful and the silverware was dirty. We ordered the chef's salami tasting and it was slimy, the bread was hard and it only came with a few, sad olives. We barely touched it. We also tried the polpette and it was even worse. When I stuck my fork in it, it was almost rock solid. It reminded me of eating meatballs out of a can as a child. Not good as an adult. And they could clearly see that we barely touched our meal and still charged us $50. Overall lousy experience.
author: M C.

description: Everything is great here. The Burrata Cheese and marinated eggplant app is delicious. Try  the quail, duck and rabbity dishes - absolutely succulent!
author: Michael G.

description:
3.5 stars!

Barbacco is decent, and the atmosphere (though busy and semi-clustery) makes for a great date night spot! The prices are very reasonable (surprisingly) and the service, splendid. However, Barbacco doesn't get 4 stars because I don't think it was omg-so-amazing, but just slightly better than your average pasta. I opted for the Pork Ragu, where the maccheroni was perfectly cooked to its chewy consistency, but I wasn't really feeling the ragu. I can't really pinpoint it, but I didn't enjoy it as much as I would have liked. However, I would still come back and try their other dishes. I was disappointed when I didn't see the risotto croquettes on the menu! I was looking forward to having those! :(
author: Michelle L.

description:
Barbacco, sister restaurant to Perbacco next door, opened just a few months ago.  I came here for an early dinner and welcomed the opportunity to order various small plates.  I liked the fact that there are quite a few menu offerings that can be ordered in different portion sizes depending on one's mood.  For example, the bruschetta can come as a single, or as a plate of three and the fried olives can come in a small or a large serving.  Barbacco also offers three ounce pours of wines allowing for more opportunity to pair the perfect wine with each dish. 
 
The food was both a hit and a miss with me.  The arancini, because of the amount of tomato sauce used in it, is like Spanish rice rolled into a ball with cheese and then fried.   It was okay, but I have had better.  The polpette (meatballs) were underwhelming.  Even though they came in a tomato sauce on a bed of braised chard, I didn't find the meatball itself had enough flavor and it was not as moist as I expected.  The best dish of the evening was the day's special, fried anchovies caught that very morning.  They were tender and delicate, not at all fishy or greasy.   The other highlight was the nduja , a salami paste which is then spread on grilled crostini.   The creamy texture and the spiciness made for an interesting dish.

Service was very attentive.  My only complaint is the noise level in the restaurant.  It got so loud that it was hard to carry on a conversation and my ears were practically ringing by the time we left.  I think next time, I will drop in for a couple of snacks instead of trying to eat a full dinner.
author: Jeannette W.

description:
The food is a solid 4 stars. Everything tasted wonderful.  Especially the mushroom croquettes and butternut squash bruschetta.  But there were a couple of odd quirks about the overall experience that lost a star.  

First, the ipad wine & beer list. This could be awesome, but the way Barbacco is using it is just awkward.  They've essentially spent $400+ on what can be accomplished with a .15 cent pamphlet.  I'm not hating for the sake of it; I think the ipad menu could be really cool if you could place your drink order directly to the bar tender with it, or basically do anything with it besides merely browse their wines and beers...you know, like you do with a menu.  Especially since after fiddling with the ipad for about 15 minutes, the waiter asked me if I was really sure about my order, and proceeded to repeat what I just read about it. It was a very man vs. machine moment, the ipad and the waiter competing to prove their utility.  Meanwhile, all I wanted was a glass of sauvignon blanc.  The experience was really confusing.  

Second, I give the restaurant kudos for efficient space utilization.  There's long rows of booths, a bar, and then another bar for seating in front of the restaurant.  If the mini-bar in the front of the restaurant faced the street, it would be really cool to watch pedestrians.  But it faces the lobby, and it feels just like you're sitting in the lobby, which gets awkward as you watch other patrons get turned away. Not the most romantic setting.  If you're making reservations, I recommend specifically asking not to be sat at the table by the front door. 

I don't think I've ever used the word "awkward" so much in a review before, but it captures my Barbacco dining experience.  Which is unfortunate, because the food and wine itself was divine.
author: Lynn M.

description:
Had about 45 minutes to grab lunch during work, the place was close and had good reviews so i decided to give it a try.
I got there at around noon and didnt have to wait to be seated ( sat at the bar and there were still a few tables available for bigger groups. However, when i looked up at around 12:30 there was already a line waiting to be sitted.... so don't get there too late)
The guy at the bar was very nice and explaine dthe menue and suggested a few items. I Ordered the soup of the day (Which tasted sooooooooooooooooo good!!!!) and the Tuna salad which also was very tasty.

So the food is Just Yum!!!!! 
The place itseld is nice as well, and the prices are very reasonable.

Enjoy :)
author: Ella B.

description:
This is one of those places in SF that you will frequent once you find it.  AMAZING value and very consistent quality.  Nice atmosphere as well.  The food here is very very good and the prices are very reasonable for the city.   

The seating is mostly communal tables which is sorta cool so you meet new people in the city.  I have been here more than 12 times and the food is always great.

The service is good, very efficient and sometimes very friendly.   The sommeliers here are very good as well.
author: Robert T.

description: I'd actually give it a 3.5/5. We sat down as a party of 2 and we had the paccheri and the shrimp and squid sandwich as our main dishes, and the coffee stracciatella gelato and a cup of coffee for dessert. The sandwich was pretty good and flavored well and the paccheri was delicious as well. The only unfortunate part of the paccheri was how the cauliflower was overcooked. But besides that, I'd say it was satisfactory. The gelato was amazing and I'd definitely recommend getting that.
author: Celina N.

description:
First step make a booking.
When I booked there was only a few choices for available times and after looking at the menu I could see why, they were turning people away at about 7.00pm, so busy and when we left there where people waiting for tables.
The menu choices were very extensive and very very good, we all had the scallop starter followed by rabbit for myself and big boss had ravioli with truffle butter which she said was devine and mini boss had the pork, her plate looked liked it had just come out of the dishwasher when she finished.
We had panna cotta to finish and it was probably the best we have ever had.
Our waiter Sal was great, he knew all the answers to any questions and was attentive without being intrusive.
Highly recommended.
author: Robert H.

description:
Quite pricey but the food was delicious.  We ordered a lot of things to share between seven rather hungry girls.  This is a list of everything we ordered:

Roasted mushrooms trifolati/herbs truffled mascarpone - DELICIOUS!  I'm not a huge fan of mushrooms, but this was so good on the toasted hard bread bites that came with it.  We asked for more bread too.
Antipasto of seasonal vegetables - pretty good, nothing amazing
Roasted beets with goat cheese, fennel, etc - also pretty good, I'm a fan of both beets and goat cheese, so I liked this dish.
Suppli - mushroom risotto croquettes filled with truffled mozzarella - also very very yummy!!
Lasagna Bolognese - pretty good, standard lasagna
Orecchiette - this was good, but after we got chili flakes for the top of it, it got a LOT better, felt like it was missing something and the chili flakes filled that gap
Mussels - also pretty good
Flat iron steak with asparagus - I really liked this dish a lot, the steak was tender and the asparagus was cooked well and was flavorful.

BUT.. my FAVORITE of the night (oddly enough) - Brussels sprouts fried in duck fat.. oh wow.  I still think about this dish and it's already been a week.  I want more.  Please someone bring me more brussel sprouts fried in duck fat... please!

Of course.. there was always room for dessert.  We all shared the bittersweet chocolate, butter scotch-chocolate crunch gelatos and tutti frutti sorbet (the last two were the best).

The chocolate nemesis cake is a must for anyone who loves chocolate dessert, it paired well with the gelato and sorbet.

The espresso panna cotta was disappointing, too thick and not really like panna cotta as much as it was like pudding/jello.

Overall it was a great night, with good food, wine and company!
author: Victoria Y.

description:
Waiter was great.  Atmosphere great.  I really liked sitting at the counter facing the chefs and prep cooks.

Not really jazzed about the IPad menu.  Would rather have a conversation with our waiter about the list and the specials.  Meat plate was average and underwhelming for the money.  Fried Olives with Pork sounded promising but tasted like nothing but fried blah.  Meatballs - specialty of the house.  Raisins, pine nuts, and pork.  No meat, no veal, non va bene.  I am more of a traditionalist when it comes to meatballs.  I want meat in them or tell me they are Lamb or Pork or whatever.  I get that this is the Neapolitan style but a little warning would be cool.

Will stay with Perbacco if down in the area.  Did I mention our waiter was great?
author: Doreen D.

description: The best Italian good I've had in the city, and I studied in Florence for three months! Seriously, this place is amazing. I also LOVE that they do family style! Super classy family style. The best is the orecchiette with pesto and sausage. I also love the brussels sprouts... I love brussels sprouts but these were the best I've ever had!
author: Roz M.

description:
This review was for a dinner visit that my girlfriend and I decided to stop by to try to catch up with life. 

We had the chef's choice house made salumi and the ndjua to share 
There were about 4-5 selections of salumi we were able to try with bread and the ndjua was basically a paste of soft salme in a jar that was similar to a pate. It was tasteful with a little kick of spice. For both of the appetitizer we try to share, the ndjua was the best. 

We then went to the entree selection, the menu was a bit hard to read, beacuse it was in Italian. I dont blame that I cant understand or read what it says until the waiter came by and explained to us what was what, which was very helpful.

The waiter recommended the Lentil Stew and she had the Farrotto. The Lentil stew was basically similar to a rissotto but indeed a healthy dish on the Pasta part of the menu. Her Farrotto was a mushroom risotto, she didnt seem to like it, but I had a taste of it and it basically just tasted like a mushroom risotto and nothing special. 

Another perk to the restaurant was that they were have drinks/wine menus off of ipad that the waiter would bring to your table to pick. It would only be better if the menu was too, because I kept scrolling on there and couldnt find the menu till the waiter came in and says oh no the menu is on the side which was a long 5 inches paper.
author: Linh D.

description:
Our experience at Barbacco was fantastic. Not only the food was great, but the service too. Our waiter was attentive without being annoying, gave really good explanations of food/drink items, and was very friendly.

First we ordered drinks. My bf had a craft beer and I ordered this super girly fruity wine concoction. I'm blanking on the name, but it was white wine, pureed strawberries, and lime and it was absolutely delicious. I could have had 10 more!

We only had 3 food items between me and my boyfriend, but all three were absolutely delicious. We ordered the Nduja, which is the spreadable house-made salami. It sounds (and looks) a little weird! But you cannot leave this restaurant without getting it. It is SO yum! The perfect amount salty and spicy... We also ordered a few cheeses to go with it- one was a gorgonzola, one was a sharp asiago, and one I think one more. Then we shared the spinach lasagna which was great also. Very filling, so perfect to share after some apps.

If we head back to San Fran, we'll definitely visit here again.
author: Melinda M.

description:
The duck liver pate was SO TINY! :( For $7, I did not expect to get 1 tiny piece of french bread toast with a bit of pate spread across the top. 

Our other appetizer came in a jar with layers of mushroom and mascarpone, like a parfait. Maybe because I was expecting something warm and truffle-y, I was really disappointed--cold, kinda flavorless, NO TRUFFLE flavor.

The entrees, however, were delicious! The squid, steak, and brussel sprouts were all extremely flavorful.
author: Sophia C.

description:
Great vibe like an upscale sports bar with  Italian food.  Bar had a very good selection of local beers.  

I had an appetizer of the chickpea soup and that was just wonderful

For dinner I had the lasagna and a side of brussel sprouts.  The pasta was great, very well done but the star was the sprouts.   I love sprouts but these are some of the best I've ever had.

Best customer service I've seen in a long time
author: Dave L.

description:
Came with coworker for lunch.
The shrimp and squid sandwich was a delight~~!!
The shrimp and squid are cooked rare with refreshing sauces.
The warm fluffy ciabatta bread makes this a fulfilling meal.
Highly recommend call before hand for take-out to avoid the lunch crowds.
There are plenty of nice sunny outdoor area near by to enjoy this yummy sandwich......
author: YC L.

description:
Some industry colleagues and I went to Barbacco tonight. Two of us were early, but, much to our surprise, we were unable to hang out at the bar. Every seat at the bar has a full place setting. Awkward. But no worries, they seated us early. Cool. 

About halfway through our meal, they seated strangers AT OUR TABLE. Some people love communal dining. Not me. And it was really weird because it wasn't a big giant table where you'd expect communal dining. This was a six-top and we were a foursome. So it was just weird to me. Invasive. 

The appetizers were great. We had the chickory bruschetta and the sardine bruschetta. The entree was a pasta dish with pork. I kid you not: two cups of pasta, one tablespoon of pork. Basically no sauce or flavor. Huge disappointment. The brussels sprouts were perfection. Lastly, we had butterscotch gelato and biscotti, which was wonderful. The service was attentive enough, but there were several mistakes. And if you serve entrees in a bowl, and there are shared side dishes, let us have side plates! 

So, would I go back? No, because the entree was...well, sad.

Bummer! This place had been on my to-do list for a long time!
author: Karen Z.

description:
I was there today and tried the arancini (flavor ok but didn't like the texture), the fennel rubbed pork ribs (nice texture but it was not flavorful enough, needed more salt or seasoning) and the same happened with the flat iron steak. As side I got the fried brussels sprouts that had a lot more flavor but nothing out of this world.
The best part was by far dessert. Would highly recommend the spiced chocolate and terreno ice cream.
Service and ambience excellent. Out waiter was very helpful and attentive. I liked the decor and the fact that they are tech avant garde with menus in Ipads and waiters using hand helds.
author: Guillermo M.

description: I recently took my mum for dinner here. I had left my cell phone at home and I wasn't able to make a reservation beforehand. I figured I'd give it a shot because it was around 6pm, pretty early for dinner. The hostess was very accommodating and after a short wait, we were seated at a communal table. As usual, the food was amazing, the best Brussels sprouts ever! (The secret is duck fat.) The service is so professional, you feel taken care of. If you haven't been here yet for some bizarre reason, go! But make a reservation..
author: Rita F.

description:
If I could give it 3.5 stars I would.  The place was good.  I enjoyed my food (shared lasagna, meat balls, large salad, and croquettes) and service was ok.

The lasagna was a very good lasagna.  The meat balls were great but was a little surprised that they were a tad spicy (fine by me but not what I was expecting).  THe salad was underwhelming.  The croquettes were really good but not as good as the waiter or other people made them out to be.

The one thing I really dislike about this place are the mirrors in the back.  I think it is so ghetto and tacky when a restaurant installs mirrors at the end just to make it seem like the restaurant is twice as big as it actually is.  Just own the fact that you are a small restaurant in the financial district.

Also (ok maybe I lied and there are two things I dislike) the ipads.  You know, they are a great and fun idea for customers.  Unfortunately, these are like HELLA old, they must be first gen, so they are all thick.  Also, they definitely look worn and used.  I understand obviously that they are used but if you're gonna try and make yourself look nicer by having a fancy hi-tech gadget, you can't let it go out of date or let it look all worn out.  Yes, I realize this is expensive but that's why you probably shouldn't go there in the first place.

As far as the service, it was ok.  Not amazing but certainly not bad.  It was a little unnerving that when someone in my party asked one of the employees what a particular dish was, we were unable to understand what he was saying.  Not a huge deal but not necessarily what you want to have happen when you see an amazing dish you want to order :)
author: Banana S.

description:
The bruschetta with duck conserva is suuuuper good. Ma e buonissimo! the pastas were decent, a little above average. They have a very traditional Calabrese dish called Nduja which I was very surprised by. If your into spicy meats I recommend having a taste of the tip of the boot of Italy.
Apple Crostada is a nice choice for dessert, and I WILL be coming back.....alone if I have too.
author: Devin S.

description: In my honest opinion, the food at Barbacco is on par with their sister location, Perbacco, but it's significantly less expensive. In fact, the only difference I would cite between the two is the ambiance. Barbacco seems a bit more hip, and fresh, where Perbacco seems more prestigious. All in all, I would highly recommend Barbacco if you're looking for great food, with a cool decor and great service.
author: Devon L.

description: Really good food. Like everyone else said, the Brussels Sprouts are superb. Also, don't be afraid of ordering your own thing - the staff is very accomidating.
author: Emily G.

description:
Excellent and convenient place to eat. Casual, not too formal. Good wine selection (on an iPad, works well for younger generation but navigation would be difficult for some of the older crowd). Menu is printed on a piece of paper right in front of you, I would say it made dinner feel a bit too casual. Possibly could integrate into the iPad. Great selection of small plates, can order a bunch and get a good variety of food. 

Def recommend the chef selection of salami, sliced right in front of you and you can ask the chef about the meats if you are sitting at the counter.
author: Daniel K.

description:
Not a fan of sitting at a "bar" to dine on expensive (though very tasty) Italian food!
We arrived late for our 6pm reservation and the place was packed.  The food was tasty but I had finished my wine and my friend her appetizer and we had a 20 minute wait for our entrees!  Our waitress was apologetic and did take the appetizer and side off the price of our meal but it was awkward.
author: Jill B.

description:
Appetizer: Focaccia, Humbolt Fog cheese with Red Wine Poached Dry Cherries.
Mains: Duck Conserva Salad, Roasted Lamb Shoulder Sandwich
Drinks: Ginger Lemonade & Mint Lemonade

The food was amazing, and the server was fantastic.  As a couple of foodies, we were impressed.
author: Suzanne C.

description:
Oh how i love thee!! I've been here twice now and I can't wait to go back. 

The brussel sprouts cooked in duck fat are AMAZE!! What more could you want in life??

I've had probably 15 or 20 different things on the menu and loved all of them. You just can't go wrong. The service is impeccable and Sommelier is very knowledgeable and super friendly. 

Keep in mind this is only a restaurant. You won't be able to walk in and have some appetizers at the bar. If you want that go next door to the sister restaurant Perbacco which is equally delicious.
author: Brenna S.

description:
I've been twice now and really like this place! It's the more casual version of Perbacco. They serve small plates so it's fun to go in a group and share. Just keep in mind that depending on your size you might be seated at a communal table.

Here are a few things I enjoyed:

Duck liver pate bruschette - This had a great flavor and texture, and was topped with onions in a balsamic glaze.

Fried brussel sprouts - Fried in duck fat need I say more? They were delicious; crispy around the edges and had a wonderful salty flavor.

Angry mussels - These were really interesting as I'm used to mussels being served in a white wine broth. This broth had potatoes and chili, which gave it a unique flavor and a nice spicy kick.

Pork ragu - Although the sauce was nothing special, the pasta was cooked really well.
author: Alice J.

description: Tried their sandwiches, and I wasn't too impressed.  Their bread is HARD, which I completely dislike because I feel like I can't enjoy the food.  I also had the lemonata, which the waiter specially combined ALL flavors for me-- I don't recommend this either!!  Trendy spot, but I wouldn't come back for sandwiches.
author: Lily N.

description:
Came in here for my first time to have lunch with a colleague.  The ambiance was very nice and the food was truly superb.  My colleague had the Arugula and Radicchio salad along with the Lasagne Bolognese.  He's a regular here and swears by it; the presentation was very nice.  I started with the Heart of Romaine Salad and my lunch entree was the "Peposo" (tuscan beef stew braised with creamy polenta).  Yes the lunch was great and the food alone is worth 5 stars.  So where is the miss?  Barbacco is definitely an upscale trattoria.  There are plenty of small hole in the wall restaurants and dives with superb food out there too (but they are missing the ambiance and service and are priced accordingly).  And on a place like that I would have only reviewed the food.  But when I go to any upscale place, I look for more than just the food.  It's about the total experience (and the meals in upscale places are priced to reflect that total experience).  That experience is comprised of 1. the meal itself, 2. the atmosphere/ambiance of the restaurant, and 3. the service.

The miss for me was the service.  This was my first time in this place and we did have reservations.  As soon as gave them our name, they walked us to the counter.  We asked if we could instead be seated at a table; the host seamed very bothered by this request but walked us to a table.  The server came by to take our order.  We both ordered an Arnold Palmer and our meals.  Drinks came out promptly and shortly followed with our meals.  However my drink ran dry early during my meal and I definitely needed another drink (or a glass of water).  I kept looking for our server but never saw him during our meal.  We didn't see our server again until the end of our meal when he asked us if we wanted desert; then quietly dropped off our check at the table.  I expect our server to stop by at least once during the meal to check on us (make sure everything was ok), and to also occasionally glance at the table to see if anything needs attention, such as empty glasses.  I understand lunchtime is busy, but this lack of attention to your guests is a total turn off for me.

Although I thoroughly enjoyed my lunch (it definitely was great), as a first timer in this place, I was turned off by the service (or lack there of).  If they would have had the service element down, this would have been 5 starts instead of 4.  It's unlikely I'll come back as there are too many great options in a city like San Francisco.  And although the food is great and the place is packed, these things catch up with restaurants once the word gets out.

Again:
Food = 5 stars
Ambiance = 5 stars
Service = 2 stars
----------------
Overall Average = 4 stars
----------------
author: Nick K.

description:
This is definitely an overdue review for Barbacco... 

can i say that i LOVE this place!!!

Here are my reasons:
- GREAT wine list!
- awesome menu at reasonable prices!
- super nice waiters
- and it's hip and cool atmosphere!!

My favorites:
- mussels in spicy 'nduja: last time i had it... the mussels were FAT and delish!!! 
- 'nduja - spreadable salami!! it's spicy and freaking good!
- duck liver pate YES PLEASE!!! 
- The pork ragu paccheri (pasta dish) deeeelish! 
- flat iron steak: cooked to my perfection.. med rare
- Brussel sprouts... its a MUST!!! it's cooked in duck fat!!! of course it's good!
- Braised tripe: soft, tender, VERY flavorful!!

I love Barbacco!  The food quality is fresh and top notch.  I think it's better than what I had in italy... and I definitely seeked out good food in italy!  So... instead of spending euro prices... i can have just as good if not better italian small plates here!!! whoo hoo!!!
author: Kelly H.

description: The kale salad is so gooood! I met for lunch with an old friend who was in town for a conference. I chose Barbacco on the advice of a foodie friend, since I wasn't familiar with the area. This was a great choice for a more casual dining experience, without sacrificing quality of food. My only suggestion is to offer more vegetarian options on the menu. Also, don't forget to make a reservation!
author: Ania M.

description:
Wow wow wow. What an excellent place. Not to mention the nice decor to compliment to great food.

We were there with a party of 8.  There is something for everyone - one of us don't eat pork, one of us don't eat chicken, and there is me who is a vegetarian.  Everyone who got their polpette (Sicilian meatballs with raisins and pine nuts / braised chard / tomato sugo) loved it. 

My risotto with roasted mushrooms spinach and parmigiano reggianto was excellent.  The vegetarian brachette plate was very yummy as well.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
This restaurant is an amazing deal both for the quality of the food and the location.  Enjoy tasty pasta and meat dishes with shockingly low prices.

The wine list is on an iPad which may have been cool when they first dreamt it up, but now it just feels tacky.  The seating is largely communal but the diners don't seem to want much to do with socializing with neighbors.

Everything I've tried here has been amazing, and I'll continue to go here when I've got friends from out of town.  The food is dope, but it's got enough quirks to knock off a star.
author: Meow S.

description:
The food here is excellent. Tasty, unique, fresh and flavorful.  If you like these dishes, order them and you will love them: mushroom bruschetta, grilled octopus with fennel and broiled potatoes, spaghetti with spicy meatballs and a delicious fresh tomato sauce. 
I'd give it a 5 star except for two things: 1. Service- it is good but not great. It is impersonal, like many trendy places. A different person brings the food  (not the waiter) and essentially plops it in front of you. A third clears up. There is no relationship here with the people who serve you. It is not bad or rude, just disconnected. I rate it a 15% tip class- did the job, but nothing memorable. 2. Cutlery management - sounds strange, but it was a problem here. You get one set for the whole meal, so you have to manage it. But how? They don't give side plates or little stands to hold your dirty cutlery between courses, so you have to plop it on the place mat. Yuk. Even during some courses it's hard to manage because the pasta comes in bowls and so there is nowhere to lay the cutlery except on the side where it points to the ceiling, slips off and eventually drops again on that place mat. That's the same place mat the last people ate at and the next will. They may not even be aware of this problem but come on guys, a simple side plate would do a lot. Or else change the cutlery.
author: Mickey C.

description: Ordered way too much food and happily rolled out having eaten every delicious bite of it. I highly recommend the brussel sprouts (cooked in duck fat - yum!), paccheri, and the spaghetti with mussels. Will definitely go back!
author: Victoria L.

description: I've been once.  There were parts that were good and parts that weren't resulting in the overall medium score of 3.  The wait, even with a reservation, was crazy.  We stood in the doorway for over an hour and watched as countless people walked in and were seated.  I can only assume the issue was with our odd sized party of three, because they eventually gave us the tiny window seat that would make four people hate it.  The service was good once we finally got seated.  The pricing and portion size were the slightly pricey stuff you'd expect in this area of San Francisco.  The food was really good, all three of us finished every bite.  The waiter offered up some suggestions on multiple servings of wine once he found out two of us were ordering the same thing, which was appreciated.  I like trying new places, so I don't mind having the experience; but with the plethora of outstanding choices available in this area, I am not likely to pick it again on my own, but wouldn't veto it if suggested by others either.
author: Jaime F.

description:
The brussel sprouts are no joke. You must try them!

You need a reservation because its a small place and can get crowded on key days (Thurs/Fri night). The menu is simple with lots of small plate options that can be shared with a group. We had many seafood dishes and all were good but small.

They use an ipad for their daily specials and drink menu. It's pretty cool. Note that they only have beer/wine and the wait staff is super helpful with wine recommendations.
author: Lynee L.

description:
Went here with my girlfriend after work before going to a concert. Definitely have the bruschetta (they have like 10 different kinds!). 

I had the Canneroni pasta with lamb sugo, and it was great! 

The iPad ordering concept is really cool, and i'm certain will get better over time
author: Nicolas M.

description: If you like to share a table on an uncomfortable bar stool and want to listen to people at your table, this is the perfect restaurant. There is not a lot of choice on the menu. Definitely a no go
author: Vincent V.

description: This place is awesome! Great food if you love trying your not so typical Italian. By far the best brussels sprouts. They are tangy and fried to perfection in duck fat. Second is the asparagus bruschetta!!!! OMG I took some girls here for a lunch and we all were fighting to get the last bite. I've tried almost all the pasta and by far the lasagna is wonderful with a little kick of spice. I definitely will be coming here for more lunch meetings and ordering it to go for my friends and family!
author: Stephanie N.

description: The manager Stephanie, an elegant beauty, allowed a friend of mine and I to come in as they were closing to have a couple glasses of wine. Their menu was terrific with wonderful descriptions of each wine and beer offering. Not to mention, the ambiance was stunning with beautiful lighting in an intimate setting. Thank you Barbocca
author: Nathan S.

description:
I have to admit that when I walked into Barbacco, my first reaction was not a positive one. The place, while not tiny, is so packed-to-the-rafters full of people that is has the spaciousness of an airport lounge for a delayed, overbooked flight. 

I personally can't stand communal seating. It's one of those fake "trends" restaurants created to flexibly pack in more people then they should. And Barbacco takes this to its zenith; the counter seating--used egregiously for walk-ins and reservations alike--is half the restaurant and ridiculously cramped. (They don't even have hooks for bags under the counter--lame.) To continue the airplane analogy: imagine having a $50 dinner in the middle seat in coach.

So, when I was seated--with a reservation--in the back of the restaurant at the counter, I was visibly and vocally unhappy. The hostess said, politely, that nothing else was available and I begrudgingly said I'd make the best of it.

So why four stars? (Well, really 3.5, but I'll round up instead of down here.) Service and food.

After I told our server that I wasn't pleased with the counter arrangement--of course it wasn't her fault, but she could tell I wasn't happy--one of the managers came over and asked me about it. I was really impressed by how each member of the staff was genuinely concerned with wanting me to enjoy my experience. He bought me a glass of wine (after we found something on the ridiculously gimmicky iPad-based wine list) and said we could have the next available two top table. Well done.

Our server was also super attentive and nice. In fact, it was really just striking how these two people really CARED, even though they were terribly busy. Truly a model of how to treat customers well.

As for the food, there were a couple so-so items (fried olives stuffed with pork), but most others were really quite good. The olive oil poached tuna could have been a meal itself; delicious and well seasoned. The pasta in sugo was rich, hearty, and flavorful. The pork sugo was earthy and perfectly cooked. Desserts were also enjoyable.

So would I go back to Barbacco... yes, probably. But until they perhaps "remove a few seats in coach," you won't be finding me at the counter. Ever.
author: Aaron L.

description:
Oh good, good, good.

Barbacco's ambience is kind of weird because of the loooong bar with patrons sitting shoulder to shoulder in a line... but the tables were cozy and just the right length for carrying on conversation. The iPad wine list was an interesting if actually somewhat superfluous touch - it was more "look at how hip and techy we are" than useful, to be honest. It actually made us MORE indecisive about our wine because there was an overload of information for each one. And frankly, I like talking to the sommelier or server about what we're in the mood for that night.

The food is DAMN good. The duck salad was amazing, I don't think I've ever had duck that savory and not "oily." The pastas were also spot on - we had the orecchiette with a beautiful light green sauce and the pork ragu that was, oh my god, so incredible. Comforting, yet light, absolutely delicious yet well balanced.
author: Lisa P.

description:
I came here tonight with two of my old friends. As locals, they gave me about five different options and we settled on this one. What a good decision. 

First, they find a way to pack in everyone despite the space being quite small which makes for a cozy atmosphere. In fact, it appears to be quite common for there to be multiple cross conversations which end up going on, and I am all for this. Second is the extremely creative method of having iPads at every table which display the drink menu. This has to be a west coast/San Francisco thing, but it is pure genius, at least until the back button stops working for me! 

I started with the soup of the day which had lentils, chicken and who knows what other deliciousness in it. I followed this up by getting the Orrecchiete pasta, which much like the starter proved to be another excellent dish. The mix of the spicy fennel sausage combined with broccoli rabe and the sauce (I think it was pesto, but I could be wrong) hit the spot dead on. When you combine it all with a glass of red wine, it is impossible to go wrong. To close out the evening I ended with the lemon olive oil cake/strawberries which much like the previous choices left me a very content person.

Great place, good service although it is a tad on the pricey side. My only complaint is that one of my friends ordered two of the "jars," but ended up only receiving one, and that the portions are perhaps a tad on the small side. However, these are minor issues and I'm definitely a fan of Barbacco!
author: Hikaru N.

description:
Came here for a birthday dinner, and everything here was delicious.

-suppli
-roasted mushroom trifolati
-duck liver fegatini
-cured sardine bruschette
-fried polenta
-spicy braised tripe
-rustic pork ragu

I'm sure there were a few other items and there was a bottle of white wine from which I can't remember the name of...

Overall the food was very good, and I loved the fact that most of these dishes are small shared dishes. Kind of like tapas, and the best thing about that is you get to get a taste of everything.

Service was great and attentive while not over bearing and watching over your shoulder in a strange way. It was also neat to see the drink list on an Ipad...different.

Definitely will come back for more next time.
author: phillip w.

description: Good service, a little bit on the loud side, but otherwise a solid choice, and the food was quite tasty. I was a little disappointed with my entrée the last time I was there though.
author: Soo S.

description: These guys are racist. As they rejected our group. When we walked in the restaurant at 9:13 pm. The receptionist said that she cannot accommodate party of 7. The kitchen closes at 10 pm... Guys beware about this place. Also if you have similar experiences please do let other guys know.....
author: Pankaj A.

description:
Four of us went to Perbacco next door a few months ago, and we were a bit disappointed.  The food was good, but not spectacular, and the tab was quite pricey.
