So we decided to try the more casual and less pricey (yet also highly recommended) Barbacco this time.  And we were all thrilled with the experience.

The atmosphere is highly inviting.  Very energetic, contemporary, attractive.  It was really busy inside, but our server took great care of us.  

Admittedly, we're all suckers for a fine burrata starter, and Barbacco doesn't disappoint in the slightest, with a rich, creamy and liberal serving with crostoni.

All of Barbacco's plates are between $5 and $18.  They're on the small side, but not too small.  This isn't a tapas place.  You'll be well fed.  We loved the pork ragu and the hanger steak, and can't wait to go back.
author: Ruben G.

description: My boss simply loves this place for work lunches, the service is top-notch and the food is always a hit with her guests. Today she had a particularly good experience, walking in for a work lunch without a reservation around 11:45AM on Friday. She asked if there was any way they could squeeze her in. The hostess, Brittany, was extremely helpful and made every effort to find them a spot right away. I really appreciate the staffs' efforts to  make this lunch meeting work on short notice. Barbacco will definitely stay on our list of go-to places for lunch in the FiDi.
author: Karin L.

description:
Cute, little restaurant with very good service.
Recommend making a reservation just for ease of entry.

Food and wine was tasty but definitely not an inexpensive meal.
Highly recommend this starter we had that was a mushroom type spread on crostinis, super YUM!
author: Rachel R.

description: Great dinner!  I still prefer Perbacco, next door.  But this place is just as good!
author: L T.

description:
My favorite financial district lunch spot! Great food and great service. 

Try the duck bruchette. Trust me.
author: Fiona F.

description: This place was simply amazing! We stopped based on yelp reviews, put our name on the list, but lost track of time. They had to give away our table, entirely our fault, but the hostess was so nice when we finally showed up. They got us in as soon as they could and boy am I glad they did!  We started with the prosciutto sampler and a sampling of cheese, both of which were amazing. We had a great bottle of Pinot Noir, California of course, then the recommendation from our waiter for the fat spaghetti with meatballs. (it had a much more sophisticated name of course) We had the brussels sprouts and the fried polenta as sides and finished it with some wonderful caramel gelato.  We were never rushed or hurried, great staff kept our glasses filled, and the management was evident in making sure we were happy. Highly recommended.
author: David S.

description:
I want to like Barbacco and I have been here many times.  I like the ambiance, the waiter was very nice, but we did feel rushed, during lunch hour, to leave and vacate the seats as quickly as we could.

I got the ragu pasta and it was nice but NOT very filling at all.  We got no bread to start with.

We got complimentary regular or sparkling water.  

For the price and for the small quantity of food is not worth it.
author: Sailing A.

description: What a hip, modern restaurant.  We tried Bruschette with Cannellini Beans, Sweet Peas, and Roasted Summer Squash, vegetables I normally wouldn't go for, but they taste oh so good.  Mushroom Risotto was equally delicious.  This lovely meal did not disappoint and ended with Torrone Gelato.
author: Ross W.

description:
Really a 3.5, but I'm going to round up. Not as great as the place is hyped up to be, but I'm not saying that its bad! 
It was about a 30 min wait around 6:30pm weekday without a reservation. 
My friend and I tried 4 of their bruscetta (out of 6) on their menu, all of which were really good! They each had their own unique taste so I'm going to have to recommend all of them while trusting that the other two that we didn't try to be just as good. 
For entree, we had the Chitarra since we had to try their famous meatballs. I'm going to say this dish was good all around! Great meatballs, great pasta, and just the right amount of flavor! The pasta was definitely handmade with quality you can taste. 
Lastly, we also tried their fried brussel sprouts. In my opinion, it was good, but too salty for my asian tastebuds. I had to eat it between the pasta or else I would've had to down some water between every 2 or so. This was the only dish we (2 people) did not finish. Some of them probably fried a little too long resulting in pitch black parts. 

Service was mediocre. When we needed the waiter, he wasn't close to us, or when our water bottle needed refilling, we had to specifically point it out to him. 
I would come back to try some of their other dishes.
author: Sharon L.

description:
This place, WOW!

This review will certainly not do it justice, because it is by far, one of the best meals I have had in some time. 

Start your meal with any (maybe all) the bruschettas that are offered. They offer several different bruschettas but all I have tried are absoultely amazing. 

Also order the brussel sprouts.  Just wow. So good. I could go on and on about these. 

I always order the Canneroni pasta with slow roasted lamb as my entree. It is fantastic. 

What I also find amazing and unique about this place is their "orange" wine. It technically is a white wine but is made with the skin of the grapes left on, giving an orange hue. I can't remember the name of the wine, but you must try their "orange" wine selection. Very good. 

In any case, I can't imagine this place would fail you. Their diner and wine menus are devine. When I have the chance, I love to spend evenings eating here.
author: Christina C.

description: Went here for dinner with 3 of my friends and used the open table to make a reservation. Very convenient using the online reservation and there was no wait! The restaurant itself is very classy and modern. The lighting is nice (slightly dim) and the service was great! We asked for wine recommendations and entree recommendations. She also convinced us to order two orders of fried brussels sprouts which were delicious! I got the orecchiette and loved it. The portions are fairly large and the whole dinner experience was lovely!
author: Krista L.

description: Had to fight to get a seat at the bar because the restaurant was fully booked but totally worth it!  Lamb skewers were tasty, as were the zucchini patties and rotisserie goose. Finished the meal off with the flourless chocolate cake.
author: Nick A.

description: The wine list is terrific and reasonable. I had the Kale salad and the meatball pasta, both were really tasty. Service was spot on giving us time when we wanted but continuing the meal in a timely manner. Definitely try this place if you are nearby.
author: Adam P.

description: Despite being crowded and loud, I'd go back for their pork on orecchiette and side of fried brussel sprouts.  Reasonably priced relative to all the other fine dining establishments in FiDi.
author: Linus W.

description:
I came here expecting a full dinner, but realized this is more like a tapas bar. The brussels sprouts that everybody else is raving about disappointed me--they were too salty and overly charred. You should probably share them with somebody else, because they come in a large portion (in fact, it turned out to be the largest plate we ordered, despite being a side) and the taste eventually becomes too overpowering.

I loved the polpette, meatballs served on a bed of chard, but $13 for three meatballs? Yeesh. The squid with 'nduja was similarly delicious, but they were buried under arugula, which ultimately composed most of that plate. I also enjoyed our cheese, Humboldt Fog with wine-poached cherries. I was fine with the amount of cheese they gave us, but couldn't we have gotten more than three cherries? They were tiny! It seems like three is a recurring theme at Barbacco.

I really wish I could like Barbacco. The interior is hip and lovely (the iPad drink menus are a fun if useless novelty). The food, when it was good, was very good, and scores more points for uniqueness. But the fact remains that I spent $50 here for two people and we left feeling like we still needed to eat a full meal.
author: Angela X.

description:
I was ready for a great night of dining and came back disappointed. I liked the atmosphere but the food in the other hand was bland.

We ordered:
the pesce crudo- flavorless 
brussels sprouts- good 
Duck liver pâté bruschetta- average 
orecchiette- nothing special
apple crostada- delicious! along with the bottle of Prosecco was the best of the night. 

Will not be coming back.
author: Andreia G.

description:
came here with the boyfriend and thought this was a unique spot with a nice ambiance.  the problem was the lines were RIDICULOUSLY long and we had an Open Table reservation.  Even with the reservation we waited almost 45 minutes.  YUCK.  

They have a unique menu ordering system on an Ipad and an extensive wine list.  The food is very reasonably priced and an overall good experience.  They have a bunch of small plates for the small eater but can accommodate for full dinners.  I love the versatility of this spot to accommodate the bar hopper as well as diner.

I would recommend this as a great spot for girls night out after a long week at work.  Definitely for the more loud crowd.  =)  Actually if I remember correctly a set of 5-6 girls were our neighbors and they were definitely full of gossip... haha
author: Sandy L.

description:
On that rare occassion that both my wife and I were working in the City on Monday, we opted to grab a drink and bite to eat before trekking back across the bridge to Oakland.

Barbacco is close to my office and we were able to walk over.  We were promptly (and politely) greeted by the Hostess.  Without a reservation, she asked if we minded sitting at the bar - which was great for us.

One of the guys behind the bar saw us eyeing the wine list.  He came over and asked my wife what she liked.  He spun around and pulled 3 red bottles and let her taste each.  After each pour, he spent the time asking my wife what she was tasting and did she notice....(the hint of berry, or the zest, or the pepper).  We opted for one of the wines based on his recommendation (never actually got the name of it).

We ordered a few dishes to share as we recapped our day.  The grilled peaches with proscuitto on brueshetta were amazing!  We also ordered the lasagna and the mushroom risotta.  We shared all the dishes and both of us enjoyed the mix of flavors and fresh ingredients.

We passed on dessert but we'll be back.....
author: Todd S.

description: Had dinner reservations, but they seated us at the bar. Otherwise, staff was very friendly. We had orecchiette with kale and sausage and farrotto with spinach and mushrooms. Both were flavorful but also very heavy; the pasta was drenched in oil. Our side of roasted cauliflower was the highlight: a hit of citrus, lots of flavor, and just the right kind of crunchy.
author: Alex L.

description:
I was in San Francisco in early October attending the big Oracle OpenWorld Conference along with 45,000 attendees, and Barbacco was highly recommended by several of my SFO friends.

It was a perfect place for a group dinner with enough of us to fill a table. The table tried several of the appetizers to split and they were all very good, particularly the mushroom risotto croquettes--cooked to perfection. For dinner I had the rustic pork ragu, cooked el dente and did not disappoint. 

I also realized as I walked into this establishment that it was conveniently located next to another San Francisco favorite, Perbacco, which I had been to four years ago and learned they were sister restaurants. 

The more casual Barbacco is definitely great for large groups, but a good alternative to the fancier Perbacco, which I look forward to returning to again. Props to all the SFO peeps who recommended this place. Now I know why you return again and again ...
author: ellen e.

description: Very nice ambience restaurant, the service was very attentive and friendly. They also provide valet parking for our convinience as finding parking spot is really hard in financial district area. I ordered the burrata as an appetizer, the taste was great, the texture of cheese and bread was perfect. On the other hand, the little ears pasta tasted bland and greasy. My friend ordered pork chop,it was well-cooked and taste good but nothing special. But, fortunately the wine that we ordered was pretty good. But, for the taste and the price I will not come back again.
author: Aldora Z.

description: The brussel sprouts fried in duck fat was indeed delish but the rest of the dishes were ok. My friends and I came here for our annual Xmas dinner and to be honest. I wasn't that impressed. The food is tasty, don't get me wrong but I wasn't wow'd by anything aside from the sprouts. I'd totally come back still if the occasion called for it by if I don't know if I'd personally crave to come back.
author: edward k.

description: Great for a light dinner.  Pretty standard kale salad, halibut was a little too plain and had too much oil, but their mushroom bruschetta was delicious! I took a seat at the bar and the girl who was serving me was great! She made good recommendations and cheered up the evening.
author: Anna Z.

description:
This is my favorite restaurant in the city and my go to spot when I want to have a "me" night. The wine is amazing, the food is wonderful and well proportioned to mixing and matching for tasting, and the service is top notch.

Better yet, the prices are mindblowingly cheap. I went to Barbacco recently with a friend of mine and picked up a bottle of great pinot and something like 6 small plates for less than $120. 

If you don't mind sitting next to a lot of people, you're in for a treat at Barbacco.
author: Andrew M.

description:
Knowing this restaurant's full name, Barbacco Eno Trattoria, will help prepare those who may venture here looking for mixed drinks and cocktails. Owing to the "Eno" part, you'll find a decent selection of wines (as well as some draft and bottled beers) here, but the only two cocktails on the menu both contain prosecco - you can have a Bellini or the bubbly with a splash of blackberry liqueur. In addition, Barbacco closes at 10 p.m.

But don't let that prevent you from dining here or enjoying a post-work glass of wine. The narrow space is furnished with a long, black marble bar, exposed brick walls leather stools and plenty of stainless steel, giving it a fun, casually elegant feel that attracts attorneys and hipsters alike ... and, inevitably, the oblivious few. At the bar to my left, a boisterous gentleman, who claims high rank at a nearby financial-advising firm, ostentatiously declared to his co-worker that he had much better Barolos in his cellar, while to my right a pair of pretty girls didn't know what peperonata was.

Once my wine arrived, courtesy of the cheery, courteous bartender, I was able to tune both sides out and savor what was before me. I fell in love with the light-amber 2008 Donati Il Mio Malvasia after one sip, its fruit and tannin surprisingly direct for a sparkling wine, yet not unpleasantly so. It is perhaps the perfect bubbly for the season and was a great start to the rest of my autumnal meal. 

The wine truly amplified the rich woodsiness of my starter of minced mushrooms cooked trifolati-style in olive oil with garlic and parsley and layered in a tiny jar with truffled mascarpone. The baguette croûtes with which it came were incredibly crunchy, so avoid ordering this on a date, unless your companion relishes the sound of a lion chomping on a freshly caught gazelle.

Something softer and sexier to eat: perfectly al dente orecchiette, whose mini-bowl shapes captured a mildly spicy sauce laced with tomato and tossed with slow-cooked lamb and braised Swiss chard. The chunks of lamb were sparse, but for $12 it was a massive bowl of pasta and managed to be a warming, delicious dish.

I absolutely adore bass and thus proceeded to order the night's branzino special. A few bites into the crispy-skinned filets, set atop a luscious cauliflower puree and adorned with golden raisins and bits of charred cauliflower and Romanesco broccoli, I silently lamented that I couldn't get a plate anywhere like this in Honolulu, my current place of residence. Most of the food there is either incredibly salty or flavorless, and adulterated with Asian and Polynesian flavors; I cannot stand it anymore. The streets of San Francisco will one day permanently become the pavement I pound.

Pensive chewing through an almond-anise biscotti, dunked into espresso, eased my nerves. My last dinner in the city was largely successful, and as I stepped out into the chilly night, I was very glad to have places like Boulevard, the Four Seasons and Barbacco to remind me that my days of living in the land of bland and Panda Express are waning.
author: Tadd T.

description: I have been here a few times and it has always been pretty good.  Today there were 3 of us, and we each ordered the "Chicken Salad Sandwich."  I have to say that it was the worst thing that I have ever eaten in a restaurant.  I know that those are strong words, but trust me, those harsh words are warranted.  The chicken is mixed with a hideous citrus blend which tasted like orange marmalade.  So imagine this:  chicken, orange marmalade, and some kind of mustard sauce.  We each took one bite and said, "Why would they make a chicken salad sandwich so off-puttingly SWEET with this overpowering taste of orange marmalade?"  It was absolutely AWFUL.  Not just bad, we're talking AWFUL AWFUL AWFUL.  You have to wonder, did anyone actually TASTE this when they decided to "reinvent" the Chicken Salad Sandwich and serve it to unsuspecting customers?  It took me all day to get that vile taste out of my mouth.  I like this place, but trust me, do not order that oddball Chicken Salad Sandwich.
author: Thomas M.

description: Good food, well priced, great service. Solid.
author: Mark K.

description:
Thank-you fellow Yelpers for directing me to this great restaurant.  We really enjoyed our meal here and would definitely come back to try some of the other menu offerings.  We ordered the brussel sprouts and they were definitely the highlight of the meal.  Give them a try, even if you're not normally a fan.  I found our waiter to be a little snooty and really not helpful with their extensive wine list, but luckily the food made up for all that.  We ended up ordering the red wine that is made especially for the restaurant and it was really good!

It was super busy on a Tuesday night so make sure to reserve in advance.  We'll definitely check this place out again the next time we're in SF!
author: Jennifer B.

description:
Last Friday I went back to Barbacco with two girlfriends to celebrate a birthday. This time around, didn't get any appetizers, just entrees. All three of us got the Rustic Pork Ragu, and once again, what a DELICIOUS dish. I think I could come back time and time again for that one. We also split a bottle of Prosecco, which I enjoyed the version that they have here.

I love Barbacco's food, environment, and price points - but the service is still very meh. We had 8PM reservations, but still had to wait 15 minutes upon arrival. The entire time we were waiting, I saw a completely open table - then finally 15 minutes later, they sat us at the open space. Not sure why they didn't just seat us from the get go. Service through the meal is fine, but just not very attentive. But for the positive things, I'll definitely return.
author: Tiffany K.

description:
It's the least Italian food I've ever had at an Italian restaurant.  I loved it!

We stopped by one early Saturday evening without a reservation.  It was already all booked on opentable.com but we decided to try our luck anyway.  Although we had to wait 20min and the hostess told us that she'd need the table back in 1hr, we were grateful that she could squeeze us in.

My mother-in-law was treating my husband and I for our birthdays.  I wanted some place nice but not too expensive.  Tapas style worked out great for the wallet and our small appetites.  My favourites of the night were the mushroom risotto croquettes and the squid alla piastra.  Mmm mm.
author: Bertilla M.

description:
You should have seen my face when I heard Perbacco had a brother. You see, Perbacco and I have been dating for a quite a while now so I didn't know why his brother's name was never mentioned. Perbacco even told me they live on the same block! If he was just as good looking as Perbacco was, I had to know him. It became a mission of mine to meet this person I've become so interested in. I started hanging out with Barbacco during lunch and then have dinner with Perbacco after work. I kept all of  our lunch rendezvous from Perbacco because I felt he didn't need to know. After all, it is only an innocent lunch. Or two. 

There is no question in my mind how I feel about Perbacco. Whenever we're together we have the most amazing time. It's grown to be a comfortable, natural relationship and I love him. I can introduce him to all my friends and he is always so accepting and warm. They think the food he cooked at our last dinner party was unbelievable and they said it was some of the best Italian food they've eaten in a while. They tell me I'm the luckiest girl on the planet to have him and deep down I truly feel that we're meant to be together, but something about Barbacco intrigues me in such a way that makes me want to learn more and more about him. 

I stare at Perbacco sometimes and watch him get ready for work. He is always so handsome and put together. I never have to tell him to wear this or wear that because he looks good in everything. He is so composed under pressure and has this ability to make anyone feel special, especially me. Barbacco is different, but in a good way. There's no doubt they're brothers. They may have grown up together but they've walked through their adult lives on different paths. Barbacco's gentle swag is what I find attractive. He knows he's sexy but carries himself in a humble sort of way. And I like that. 

Perbacco recently found out I've been having, as he says, "One too many lunch dates," with his brother. It bothers him and he thinks there's something going on between us. I assured him there isn't and that Barbacco's nothing more than a new friend and a person I respect as his brother. 

Things are finally good now between Perbacco and I but I have to be honest with myself and admit that there are feelings for Barbacco that I will always have. I've never cheated on anyone and I'm proud of that, but there's nothing wrong with two friends getting together once in a while to catch up, is there? ;)
author: Jen Y.

description:
This was definitely one of our favorite and most memorable meals in San Francisco. We were looking for something nice-ish, but still close and convenient, and Yelp led us here. Thanks, Yelp!

Keeping in mind that we were already big fans of the "modern Italian tapas" concept, I have to say that we loved everything about this place. The stylish decor, the bar seats overlooking the food preparation, the iPad wine list, and of course the food. (Okay, I kept wishing the iPad did a bit more, but my boyfriend loved being able to browse the wines and learn more about them.) The only downside was that it was pretty crowded/loud.

The food was simple but superb. We got the chef's selection of salumi, along with 3 cheeses we selected, which were then paired (very well) with various breads and fruits. ALL of it was delicious. If I recall correctly, that was all we had for lunch, because the portions were surprisingly generous and filled us up.

Oh, we did get dessert! Two different flavors of gelato, each with a gourmet twist. Both of them were excellent.

I also recommend the mint limonata, which was quite refreshing and delicious!
author: Kristan H.

description:
How have I never written a review for Barbacco? We have been coming here for the last two years and it has always been a great experience. 

The menu changes often which allows us to try lots of new things. One thing we are always sure to order if the salumi plate. All of the pasta is made in house (of course!) so you can't go wrong with any those dishes. The pork ragu was a stand-out dish during our last dish so order it if it's still on there!

We have never had an issue with service here, actually quite the opposite. Everyone from the hostess to the bus boys is friendly and constantly striking up conversations.

Perfect date night spot.
author: Seema M.

description:
I have to say this is the first restaurant I came to that is using iPads for their wine list...COOL!  But they dont have a huge selection of wines.  I have to say that our waitress was very patient with us at choosing a wine.  That I'm pleased by. 

Ordered the brussel sprouts, spicy marinated tripe, sicilian meatballs, and the roasted chicken.  Everything was good....BUT (yes here it comes) the brussel sprouts were on the salty side, the tripe was tasty but it didnt have a pinch of spiciness but it was nice and tender, the meatballs were a bit salty especially its just 3 meatballs with sauce (it needed to be served with a light pasta or some kind fo carb), and the chicken was nothing special.

I'm curious to try the brother restaurant which is right next door, Perbacco. Its more fine dining and Barbacco is more brasserie like.
author: Gina S.

description:
Tasty good lunch. The soup today was a chickpea based one and it had a great spicy flavor. The salad was also really good - all of the salads looked great. They did forget my companions soup, but then brought it later and removed it from the bill. 
Very nice folks, not too loud.
author: Charlie H.

description:
I wanted to try this place after going to its sister restaurant next door. I knew this was more informal so I was curious to see how it compared. Admittedly the iPad wine list in front of you definitely raises the cool/hip factor. The flow of the dishes that come to you can be a little off -- something I think they should work on. 

If you're not a fan of close dining quarters, then this is not the place for you. My friend and I were seated at the bar area, which I didn't mind really, although you will have a stiff neck by the end of the night after having to turn to one side to have a conversation the whole night. Other tables that were away from the bar were packed as well.

That said ... on to the food. I had the summer squash bruschette, which was pretty good, although it felt like it could have used some more seasoning. The taste was a little light. 

I couldn't tell you what the watermelon salad tasted like that I ordered, because the waiter forgot to bring it. So ... I'm dinging them a star for messing that up. (At least it didn't show up on our bill.)

My mushroom risotto was quite tasty. I was also impressed with the portion size -- it was much bigger than I would have expected. Enough for a full dinner portion the next night!

We got an order of the brussels sprouts that everyone raves about but they had too much of a balsamic taste to them. It overpowered the overall flavor. A similar dish at Park Tavern does brussels sprouts much better. 

I ended the meal with the chocolate nemesis cake. It was divine!

Overall, a great experience with just a few tweaks that can easily be done.
author: Lori M.

description:
I prefer Barbacco to Perbacco.  More buzz at Barbacco. 
The butterscotch chocolate gelato is more delicious than the salted caramel at Bi-Rite.
author: Wakako U.

description:
My favorite restaurant in the city. 
Great Italian food that strikes me as incredibly authentic. The menu focuses on small plate (something I really like)-- and the fried brussels sprouts are absolutely incredible. They have a great salumi plate too that I think I've ordered every time. 
Great ambience, more low key than Perbacco but just as delicious.

The wine list is on an iPad, and our waiter was incredibly helpful when it came to picking a bottle for our price range and taste preferences. He suggested a few and even let us try two before we decided on a bottle-- that kind of service in a restaurant of this price level is really impressive.
author: Will A.

description:
Really wanted to give four stars but I'll have to settle for a 3.5 stars.

We wanted to take out our lovely assistant for Admin Appreciate Week lunch last week and we chose Barbacco. Was able to secure a seat for 4 on a Friday the morning of so we started out on the right foot. 

This whole iPad ordering concept... I'm torn really. In theory, excellent. I used it at Chevy's for happy hour last weekend and it went well (though not on an iPad but another touchscreen) but Barbacco just doesn't seem like the right venue for it. It is a little more intimate and upscale and its nice to have an excellent service touch when it comes to places like these.

Anyways, the lemonades are fun, particularly the strawberry that they recenetly rolled out. Mmm delicious. The bruchettas are definitely overpriced and a little overrated in my book. I had the peas with goat cheese variety and while good, definitely needed some salt and pepper to add some flava. Everyone in my group seemed a little meh about them. The portion sizes are perfect for lunch in my opinion, not too small or big. I ordered the asparagus pasta and it was very tasty. Everyone seemed pretty happy with their mains (others had the pork shoulder sandwich, lasagna, and the meatballs).

The service was a little underwhelming but a nice FiDi lunch spot nonetheless. Would probably only go back if I had to for work but wouldn't go out of my way otherwise.
author: Raina B.

description:
I love this place.

Get all the Brushhette. ALL OF THEM! Especially the Anchovy.

Fried Brussel Sprouts, Lamb sugo pasta(DAMN), meat tasting plate.

Use open table via Yelp because it gets busy M-F especially around 11-1:30pm.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
Meh. Not worth it. Walk 5 minutes and go to Wexler's instead.

It wasn't bad at all, it just wasn't worth the price.

We had the peach/prosciutto bruschetta (which is admittedly large), the lamb 'nduja bruschetta, the burrata cheese, the chef's selection of house made salumi, the tripe, the brussel sprouts, the pesce crudo (which I think was hamachi and peach), and the gorgonzola / honey appetizer (for 5 of us). The only thing that was really good was the pesce crudo. The brussel sprouts and the bruschetta weren't bad, but not extremely noteworthy. Everything else was kinda ok.

The wines (pinot noir and zinfandel) were really not good. My B said "The zin tasted like a wine that Jagermeister would make".

Overall - not worth the $50 / person. If you have to eat in that area of town, I'd recommend Wexler's (5 minutes away).
author: Helen D.

description:
Went here the other day to try somewhere new.  It was pretty good but not great.  We liked the atmosphere and decor.  Our waiter was super nice and attentive BUT we had to ask for our beer after one person's drink came and one appetizer (about 15 min after we had ordered it).  Then we had to ask where our focaccia was when our entrees had come and we still hadn't received it. And then it was horrible anyway.  Cardboard-y.  

We tried the asparagus egg bruschetta and the arancini.  Both were good but small. 

We had the lasagna (didn't like it at all), and we tried the pork ragu with wide tubes (that were very good), and a steak with arugula and parmesan (which was also very good).

I'd go back but only if it was convenient.  I wouldn't go out of my way.  There are too many really excellent Italian restaurants that I like much better.
author: Karen N.

description:
I was directed to Barbacco with the help of a local food blogger friend of mine. I'm so glad I took her advice, because Barbacco is dynamite!

What first stood out to me about this place was the ubiquitous iPads on every table, containing only the restaurant's wine list. We can argue either way whether this is really necessary or an overindulgence, but I'm sure it's bound to be the way of the future for San Francisco dining. The drawback of having an iPad on every table, of course, was in noticing that there was a hostess whose sole job, it seemed, was to stop people from stealing the iPads and walking right out the door. I felt bad for her.

Barbacco does a great variety of simple, well-executed Italian food at very reasonable prices ($10-18 per entree). My favorite pairing was of the meatballs with the brussels sprouts cooked in duck fat. Excellent service all around, especially if you are gluten-free. One of our friends had no problem with her dietary restrictions being accommodated.
author: David P.

description:
Came here with a friend for drinks and some food after work. We weren't particularly into the communal seating, but we were lucky to set seats at our own table.

-We got one of each of the bruschetta. All delicious. Highly recommended.
-Meat balls were perfection. Certainly worth getting.
-My friend got the Paccheri and it was good

I would come here again for this type of outing. It exceeded my expectations and was reasonable from a price standpoint.
author: Anne K.

description: Nothing was bad, the service, food, or wine. Nothing was amazing, exciting, or anything I felt I couldn't get somewhere else. My date thought it was very good.
author: Lauren S.

description: I'm not a giant fan of Italian food, but food was pretty standard.  The hand made noodles were the best part of the entire meal, while the sauce was average. Worth the one time try.
author: Sinan W.

description: Zero tables, although it was empty! And it was 5:30! Losers, its just italian, lots more places to go anyhow!
author: Tiwi M.

description:
Jumbacco! Jumbacco! lol, That's what the name makes me think of..

FOOD:
1.) croquette - o yum... a lil cheese in the center
2.) sulami spread - with a lil chili pepper to put on top, n spread on a crunchy piece of bruschetta... tasted just like a salami ;} with a nice perfect kick of spiciness to open up the palate mm
3.) brussel sprouts - mm yum, w a lil hint of citrus zest... reminds me of bstar's brussel sprouts minus the crispy rice on top
4.) duck liver patte bruschetta - oo not banh mi tasting as i expected... lol.. more rich
5.) butternut squash bruschetta - mm sweet yum

*everything here was tasty with interesting flavors not overbearing, but in a perfect balance..  mm .. definitely worth experiencing 


SERVICE:
Attentive, knowledgeable

ATMOSPHERE:
Reminds me of an old school diner, cept madeover to be a fine dining/lounge ;P straight away walkway down the restaurant with tables to the right and a long bar seating to the right exposing some behind the scenes...
author: Angela L.

description:
We were here for a biz dinner and thoroughtly enjoyed ourselves. Food was delish...here're some highlights:

LOVED:
Roasted Mushroom Trifolat (fave of the night)i, Rustic Pork Ragu, Lasagne, Artichoke Spread in Jar, Butterscotch Gelato

Liked:
Aranchinis, Cheese & Salumi Platter, Roasted Beet Salad, Duck Confit Salad

We also had the LIttle Ear Pasta (it was OK), Tuna Salad (i'm not a tuna fan but others seemed to like it), Duck Liver pate on bruschetta, burrata (it was ok; not my fave), Torrone (nougart gelato), Spiced Pear Cake, Choc Nemisis Cake, Panna Cotta (skip; too watery) 

Service was great; our servers were attentive and friendly. I had a few glasses of  prosecco (yummy). It was packed/ really busy all night. 

Will be back for tapas
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
Amazing. I ate here on a weds. Night and highly recommend making reservations because Barbacco fills up. 

I'm generally not a huge fan of Italian food as the stuff I've had has usually been mediocre food buried in insane amounts of sauce. Barbacco has really good reviews and it's close by so my friend and I decided to give it a shot. 

The menu looks confusing at first because the headings are in Italian. But fear not, there is dictionary on the back.

I started with the suppli - mushroom risotto croquettes filled with truffled mozzarella. This was definitely the best thing to wet my appetite. I followed it with the roasted mushroom trifolati with herbs and truffled mascarpone (do you sense a pattern of what I like?). It was like a savory parfait paired with crostinis.

Moving on, I had the asian pear, garganzola and honey bruschette. I have a newfound love for garganzola or blue cheese paired with something sweet. 

My friend really wanted to try the crostone with burrata cheese, roasted beets and rucola - I generally don't like beets, because to me they tend to taste like dirt and they're rarely ever prepared a way I like. I highly recommend this dish because the beets a roasted and have a touch of sweetness to them making them extremely delicious. 

We finished with the chef's selection of salumi and were surprisingly stuffed. 

 I'm currently looking at their lunch menu and debating if I should pay them a visit today.
author: Analisa S.

description:
Tried a bunch of "orange" wines from the White?! menu, and they were incredible. I'm not much of a wine snob, but these were a really nice change from my usual glass of white, and the bartender was extremely patient and knowledgeable in explaining them. 

And I love how the menu really does have something for everyone. I stuck with a light dinner of farro salad, a veggie plate and the green pea bruschette, but the guy next to me had some sort of jarred pate and a cheesy hunk of lasagna...and both of us couldn't be happier with our meal.
author: Eeeeestar T.

description: Omg. The food is so good I feel like I'm high (I'm not). The gluten-free bread feels like Mandela's first breath of freedom. The service team makes me feel like Madonna in a gay bar.
author: Stella K.

description:
Directions:
1. Forget the iPad, sit at the bar and ask the bartender about wine!      (they are like vino Jedi/ninjas)
2. Order the Bruschetta dishes!(all of them)
3. I think I had rigatoni something... It doesn't matter! Just go and eat!
author: Nathan B.

description:
It was fine, nada mas.  The flavors of the bruschetta were very good, but the bread was so soft, it was difficult to cut (in half) or even take a bite from without making a mess.   

I had the squid ink pasta with squid an shrimp in a "spicy" tomatoe sauce.  I found the flavor to be bland.  My friend had the kale an sausage - she liked it.  And, I will say that the pasta portions are very large.

I like the selection of wines, especially the ones on tap.
author: Carly B.

description: Today me and my friend went to the city for some work so we parked and did what we needed to do. And It was lunch time and we decided to eat around there because we already had our car parked and didn't want to go far where we would have to take the car out and then look for parking in the city, which can be insane. So we decide to walk around, my friend was craving pasta so we decide to look for Italian resturant. And we came a cross this place because they had a menu outside and we saw that they had pasta so we decide to go in. And it looked really nice and fancy and they had a really nice seating and the bar looked great it was really nicely decorated resturant very morden kind of a place. So the waiter takes us to the table and hands us the menu and gives us a minute to look at it and we are trying to figure out what we want then he comes back and says you need to order fast of this menu but then he says if you are going to take longer then you order from this menu which made no sense because the same things were on that menu that he gave us. So we said ok we will look at this one and then he comes back minute later and says are you ready to order. We ask him for advice on what to get and it felt as if he was in a hurry to take our order so he can go back to whatever he was doing because it was not busy at all there was only one other table that was being used and there was nobody at the bar so i don't know why he was in a hurry. So we ordered orrecbitt I think that's how you spell it and we also got anchovy brueatta which we thought it would be couple bread with tomato and anchovy and he comes up with on tiny bread which cost 13 dollars and had anchovy Sauce with olives on top and it was hard to eat. And the pasta that we got had a really bad after taste the only thing good that we had there was the lemonade. It was the worst mistake we made going there I wish we never went in there because we only took two bites of the food and paid 27 dollars for two bites. And our waiter provided the worst service ever because, I feel that he should have the food knowledge and try to help us figure out what we would like instead he was jus in a hurry to take our order and leave. The restaurant and name of the items are very fancy I just hoped that the service would be that fancy too. I would never go there again not even on accident. This place is only one time kinda restaurant  for me. We could have just gone to Olive Garden and got pasta that would have  tasted better and had great service.
author: Poonam M.

description: This place was really good. Had the bruschetta and fettuccine with chicken. The service was good, food was good. Really can't go wrong here.
author: Toan D.

description:
This is the BEST casual Italian restaurant! We're a bit biased because we've been going here regularly since they opened. Being regulars consistently for 4 years should tell you something about a restaurant. Barbacco's food is delicious, as are the wines - our faves:  meatballs (yes, raisins in meatballs are delish!), chicken thighs, polenta, brussel sprouts, any of the bruschette and the salumi with fried dough- yum!  Everything is tasty on the menu, but we are creatures of habit and generally order the same 5 items... And, in Italian, it is pronounced "bru-sketta" not "bru-shetta".

For the tourist, please let the staff guide you on the wine. They will steer you in the absolute right direction! Everyone who works there are genuine and lovely peeps. You will be treated very well. Umberto, Nick, Miguel, Becky, Adelino, Estephany, Michael, Kevcin, Alex, Hugo, Gio, Lucy, all of the staff are wonderful! 

The restaurant is more for adults (great for dates - sit at the counter - or with a group of friends). It is intimate and casaul at the same time. I can't say it is "good for kids" type of restaurant. Kids 10 and up would be more appropriate. Be sure to make reservations or call ahead for the wait time if you want to be more spontaneous.

If you are looking for massive bowls of pasta with bread on the side, this classy enoteca is not your place. Please go to Olive Garden for that! 

Buon appetito!
author: T L.

description:
This place is almost too good to be true! Amazing food, great service, nice ambiance, and very low prices. I'm a huge fan of Perbacco, and Barbacco is the next best thing. Just quicker and cheaper. It does get a little crowded around lunch time, so try to go earlier than noon or around 1ish and you should be good. I love the communal tables they have too! Makes for an interesting dinner and conversation.

The sandwiches are delicous! I also love the strawberry and duck salad, but I believe that is seasonal. Which makes me crave it more! Just a really great restarant to check out if you are looking to try something new. You'll definitely love your visit!
author: Heather E.

description:
Okay, let's go: 

Premise: Went there for dinner on a weeknight 6 months ago.  Writing this review now because it takes 6 months to clear the crappy taste out of my mouth and for me to devote 5 mins of my valuable time to comment on this sorry restaurant.

Reception: My friend and I were directly looked over by the host because we looked "minority like" or "not hip enough for a Thursday night".  After awhile, the host finally acknowledge that we exist, the first thing out of his sorry mouth was "what are you guys doing here?"  =.= Unbelievable...

Service: Wine list on an iPad?!!  3 words come to mind: pretentious, gimmicky, desperate.  And it was not even a big wine list!!!  (If you are so lazy that you can't even train your wait staff to talk about wines, what attention are you going to pay to the cooking of my food.)
  
Food: 4 pieces of sliced bologna and olives for $9.  Not seasoned, just sliced and laid out like OOOO.  A deli can do better!!!  Lamb was salty and one dimensional.  Lunch size portions with dinner time prices. 

Conclusion: I'm paying to feed the Chef's or the Owner's ego.  Whoever you are, you're not that good, mate.  

I don't know why people give this place a 4 or 5 star rating.  Are we so devoid of good italian restaurants in SF that we have to go to this place??? C'mon.
author: James D.

description: Very good decor but I wish they did more with their entrees. It's pretty plain at this point.
author: Dan M.

description:
I heard about Perbacco first then Barbacco... so I figured Barbacco is where guys can take off their CLIP-ON TIES and roll up their sleeves  and the Ladies can bring out their FLATS stored in their car (dont choo deny it!), when they're feeling a little bit casual lol!

This place looks cool! Barbacco, you got my heart pumping on your iPad drinks menu teehee! But that could just be me, I love toys and gadgets! Their wine list is impressive. Too bad I dont drink anymore! The vibe is very energetic and lively. 

We cancelled our reservation last minute .. only to take it back again 5 mins before the allotted time. They were gracious enough to take us back in. Thank you!

The service was awesome. They staff are nice and friendly (hmm ok except for 1 server who didnt smile AT ALL! But our server is really sweet!). They were all very attentive. We always have clean utensils and plates and our glasses were always full. 

Must try -- Stuffed Risotto Mushroom, Duck liver pate bruschette, squid and Lasagna Bolognese.
author: RED C.

description: The fried polenta and the marinated shrimp were flavorless and the chicken under a brick was dry.  The corn rigatoni was undercooked but the corn saute under it was delicious.
author: Amin S.

description: Rude, impersonal and dismissive bartender. I live in San Francisco and was here for dinner with a client and was embarassed by this guy's service, which seemed more east coast than west coast.  What a let down for an otherwise nice restaurant; decent food. Im going to be gracious and not describe him or give his name, but suggest to the management they check out their bartending staff-maybe more supervision?  This guy was acting like we were there for him, not the other way around; seemed entitled, pushy and abrupt with customers and decidedly unfriendly. I will give this place a miss next time. There are plenty of places to get a great drink and apetizers in SF and some warmth. Barbacco, Im doing you a favor by giving this feedback- take action. People eventually just stop coming. It is San Francisco after all.
author: Mischa M.

description:
Following a tour of the ultra-posh art galleries, this was a lovely end to a great afternoon. Barbacco has a great ambiance & atmosphere through & through... from the bouncy bar stool seats, iPad menus & calm lighting/earthy tone to the restaurant, you'll feel very relaxed dining on some of the various 'inizio' (to start with, according to the glossary their menu had) & main dishes. Of course with tasty food & spirits, you'll find a crowd... this night was no exception; which had us sharing our table with a very pleasant couple (our 4 to their 2, full table). Although, we were there for a wkend dinner, it looks to be a good place during the week for lunch - long bar & a smattering of tv's playing sports.

Food - [Canneroni Pasta, Bruschette x2 - 1.Cured Sardine 2.Asian Pear]
Menu items were described as being easy to share, especially the left side of the menu... my group took advantage of that to sample everything we had. The canneroni Pasta was an excellently flavored, mild spicy 'small ear' pasta... complimented with shredded lamb made for an excellent balance of flavor & texture. I was disappointed with the bruschette begets - thin, hard & dry... they just didn't support what they were serving well - good thing I cut the pieces, b/c it would crumbled to pieces. The asian bear was overpowered by the gorgonzola cheese; the cured sardine was perfectly balance with it's pesto sauce & potato slices.

Other notable mentions: 
-Paccheri, Rustic Pork Ragu - great & savory taste - could use a little spice.
-Lasagna Bolognes - Just like mom makes.

Drink - [Birra Moretti La Rossa, now aka Formula Rossa] 
Their sported quite a selection of wines, spirits, mixed cocktails & beer... ultimately, things were too pricy considering the full day of food I had... fortunately enough, I came upon the La Rossa double malt beer. Amber colored with a light hoppy taste, it was the perfect compliment to the meal... 7% didn't give me any buzz, but it was more flavorful than expected.

The staff were great... our waiter, knowledgable, patient & had a great mastery of the menu (the paper & iPad menus) in terms of answering questions & helping to recommend great items - I appreciate shit like that, haha. While it was out of the ordinary to share a table... especially with the grandeur of the place... as mentioned above, there was a great couple next to us - it was great form that we informed of that before being seated.

Thanks Nandiya A for you insistence on having us do something different  ^,^
author: Brenton C.

description: Great place, very lively atleast during the lunch time. Had the soup of the day which was really good. Good place to go for team lunches.
author: Ashok L.

description: While the service was truly outstanding, we were not at all impressed by the food. We had a pasta dish each, a couple of appetizers, and the fig cake, and while they were quality dishes, we probably won't be going back, given other options in the neighborhood.
author: Olivier L.

description:
I'm a sucker for anything duck: peking duck, foie gras, confit, even braised...  So when I saw they had duck liver with balsamic onions... my heart melted right away. What an interesting concept to serve it in a glass jar! Although the pate is cooked thoroughly, it does not have the smooth texture like foie gras, but tasty nonetheless. 

Here's a wise tip for a date- the bustling atmosphere makes it less awkward for those planning their first date at Barbacco.  Their wine selection is excellent... did I mention they also have an Ipad to help you with your selection? Bonus points for being technologically savy. I'll be back soon enough. =)
author: Alexander H.

description: My boyfriend and I decided to do date night in the Financial District at Barbacco before going deep into SOMA for another event.  Barbacco seemed like a good place for something that wasn't going to be through the roof expensive, and the reviews seemed to be reasonable.  The 7x7 must-eat list for 2012 had just been released, so I was determined to try the salumi plates (the 7x7 list says to try it at Perbacco, but really...is there THAT big of a difference?).  We tried the smaller Chef's selection of salumi platter, and it was absolutely delicious!  For the mains, I had the flat iron steak tagliata / grilled treviso and it was great!  The grilled treviso, in my opinion, was better than the steak.  My boyfriend got the Orecchiette, and I think he thought it was decent (but nothing to really write home about).  For dessert, I had a cappuccino, but we passed on the sweets.  We sat around a finished the bottle of wine we ordered via the iPad at the beginning of dinner and headed on over to our next event afterwards.  I wasn't thrilled that we got seated at the bar and would have preferred a table, but it wasn't going to be something I was going to make a big deal over.  The food was good, service was good, and the overall ambiance was fun too.  I do love Perbacco's pork chop, and firmly believe it's one of the best things I've had in SF, so if I'm going to come back, I'd prefer to go back to Perbacco.  That being said, another casual date night at Barbacco would be welcome too!
author: Lisa I.

description: Why 5 stars?  Because I have had dinner here countless times while doing Biz in SF and it always delivers for me. I stick to the squid or octopus apps and a pasta main and always leave happy.  Great price points as well
author: T M.

description:
We stopped in last night on a whim.  Had intended to go to its big-brother (sister?) restaurant next door - Perbacco, but our eye was drawn to Barbacco's menu posted outside - not to mention the hip little iPad-driven wine menus that have been well documented elsewhere and need nary a mention from me.  Other than to say (you knew I couldn't resist, didn't you?) that the guy who invented these Smart Cellar devices was one smart feller.  I expect we'll all see many more such things on an increasingly regular basis.

But back to Barbacco.  I held little hope of getting a seat, as the people in line just in front of us turned and walked away.  But we took the seats at the bar that had not been to their liking, and enjoyed the engaging and knowledgeable wait staff, whose name I forget, but whom we knew from her days at the Ferry Plaza Wine Merchant.  She was a font of knowledge on their wines and even poured us scant tastes to make sure we wanted the wine we'd settled on - in short, the very sort of person which we love to have as a wait staff.

The wines were pricey, but very nicely selected and recommended.  The list, despite the impressive technology behind its presentation, is not that long, and could easily have been presented in print form.  But I would have missed the ability to search, sort, and drill down that the Smart Cellar provided, and hey, they're just fun and engaging!  I almost bumped this rating up to five stars just because this tool earns an additional star - This rating is really a 4.5-star rating (just use your imagination).

The Food
Interesting, creative and well executed!  The fried Brussels Sprouts are so good we brought them home (in their fully recyclable brown cardboard container) and they were the inspiration for this already long posting.  If you're tired of my writing (in which case you likely stopped reading long ago), blame the sprouts from Brussels.

The hits were the Bruschetta ($3 per one-slice serving) - we chose three out of a list of 7 or 8, the pea and mint (yes!), the mushrooms (oh yeah), and the duck liver (meh).  We also found the lasagna to be among the best we've tried - not heavy, but rich and satisfying. 

Our bill was $100 before tip, with $45-$50 of that being wine.
author: Dave C.

description:
Barbacco, the darling little sister of Perbacco, shines in its own right.

In the heart of the Financial District, Barbacco Eno Trattoria - yet another entry in the wine bar trend sweeping San Francsico - gives city dwellers yet another reason to journey downtown at night.  Offering a relaxed, but sophisticated atmosphere, Barbacco features delicious dishes and wonderful wines from all over Italy.

The menu is arranged in a way that helps diners navigate the wide variety - more than 50 selections - of large and small plates.  Divided into sections, such as piccolino (small nibbles), salumi fatto a mani (housemade cured meats), latte stagionato (cheese), inizio (appetizers), and others, the extensive listing invites diners to taste little bites from all over Italy as they walk through their meal.

The melt-in-your-mouth arancini (fried risotto balls coated with breadcrumbs) are the perfect way to ease in to a meal.  Rich and flavorful, the rotolo (rolled pasta filled with chard and ricotta with sage-brown butter) was almost too filling.  Sautéed to slight crispness, the Brussels sprouts were the perfect foil to the creaminess of the polenta.  However, accompanied by rucola (arugula) and parmigiano reggiano, the carpaccio lacked intensity of flavor.

Service is top-notch:  the servers were attentive and knowledgeable about both the food and myriad selections of wine.  They were easily able to recommend selections from the more than 100 wines - most offered by the 3 ounce taste, 6 ounce glass, quarto (1/4 bottle), mezzo (1/2 bottle), or full bottle - that perfectly complemented the food.

With excellent food, a great wine selection, detail-oriented and personal servers, Barbacco is off to a good start.
author: CJ G.

description: In the heart of FiDi. Amazing Italian tapas. I am def not a pasta fan but i enjoyed the pork ragu paccheri pasta. Love the interiors - brick walls.
author: Sherry W.

description: Three people ordered lasagna and was lukewarm at best.  Appetizers were served at the same with the entree. Bad service at best, there are too many restaurants in SF, this was the first and last time I'll be back.
author: Jeannie T.

description:
I wasn't planning on going here and in fact, I didn't even know it existed.  However, when I was in another place and they were backed up, Opentable.com showed this as an alternative.  Great choice!

Our server and wine sommelier were amazing and fun.  A must try is the fried (in duck fat) brussel sprouts.  Yum.  Yum.  All the plates can be shared, which is what we did.  We ate and kept eating and devoured a gorgeous bottle of white wine (that I think was an orange wine).  Again with the Yum!

The other interesting thing I thought was you could hear the chatter of everyone BUT, you couldn't hear what they were talking about, just your own conversation.  Me like.

Also, not expensive.  I give it two thumbs up, a smiley  face and gold star!
author: Ryan B.

description:
We headed here after a saturday afternoon of shopping in Union Square.  Funky casual atmosphere. Good when you want an interesting scene but not the swanky price tag. We sat at the bar counter and had a friendly wait staff. 

Drinks:
Anchor steam summer ale

Eats: 
Assorted cheese and salami plate
Pork ragu
Brussels sprouts
Spinach lasagna
author: Samantha A.

description: Service was excellent. Food was good. We got sat at a table with complainers I'm not a huge fan of being sat at tables with strangers but we knew that going there guess it depends who you're sat with. I was disappointed with their lack of domestic beer- only because I don't want to pay $8 for a beer I won't like. I ended up with a glass of wine that was as much as my dinner it was the house Malbec. And it was GOOD!
author: Sarah S.

description:
holy cow this place is so good!!!!! meatballs, cannelini bean bruscetta, mussels, and humbolt fog cheese. 

really nice service, loved sitting at bar, great wine menu, modern/classic hybrid.

everything was tasty - and well-seasoned. Like perfect actually.

This is a definite winner and I'm coming back!!

Great spot for out of town guests and people who love NYC...
author: Andrew K.

description:
Reservation at. 5 pm.  Was handed the lunch menu- strike. 1
Ordered the meatballs and I almost choked with the spices  - extremely hot with no warning on the menu- strike 2
A couple of waiters show some concern and ask what I would like to eat instead as I continue to cough and I am unable to swallow - I choose the Endive salad and they choose to charge me for it- strike 3
We ordered dessert - a lousy pound cake with some fig spread in the center - strike 4
Uncaring staff and questionable food.
Plenty of other restaurants in town offering great menus and service.  Will not return for sure.
author: Vilma A.

description: Polpette, the best meatball ever, and their lasagna is incredible. I'm drooling just thinking about it! The tables are communal so not a great place for a romantic dinner but great for groups. Everything I've tried has been excellent. I love this place.
author: Reza E.

description: simple affordable menu, great parings, nice atmosphere. perfect place to eat. everything was delicious
author: Mmm M.

description:
I've landed, last minute, here a couple times now for dinner. The initial impression is that they are trying just a bit too much to accomplish something modern, casual, and city-esque. The 6-top bar height tables are seated to max out (party of 2 and party of 4 together) and the seats are quite uncomfortable. I suggest grabbing a "bar" seat or a regular table near the back. 

This is a BEER & WINE only establishment. The bev menu is presented on an iPad, with limited details and a less then stellar presentation. To be proud of your wine list would suggest giving additional details when there is no limit to menu length - yet they don't. The servers feed you wine details, though I don't think they actually know what they are talking about. Use your own best judgement. 

The service itself is quite good. Friendly, young folks. The salumi plate is a good starter if you're in a group. I've had the mushroom risotto, lamb/mint/pea pasta, and the halibut special. All were fabulous. 

The setting isn't great - the bev list is questionable, but I haven't had bad service or a bad meal yet. I'm sure to return assuming there isn't a wait for a seat.
author: Mel H.

description:
So. Painfully. SLOW. 
We had a reservation for 1pm and still had to wait 20 minutes to be seated. And every course took them way too long to bring out.

The food is mostly good, with some unique plates. The portions can be a bit small though.

Yum:
- Mint Lemonade: Amazing! And very fresh.
- Celery root salad: I've never had a salad quite like this. Interesting and tasty.
- Cheeses, especially the sheep's milk cheese with bush honey and the parmesan-like one (a platter of 3 cheeses is the best deal, and just 1-2 may not be enough to share with a group)
- Pork Ragu: I just sampled a bite of the pasta, which is this delightful chewy texture that I LOVE. I can't comment on the pork though.
- Spiced Pear Cake: so moist and delicious

Meh:
- Foccacia: Lame that they charge you $1 for 3 pieces when bread is usually free. It's just standard foccacia, nothing special.
- Chocolate Nemesis Cake: I had been hoping for an indulgent, orgasmic Death by Chocolate dessert. It definitely fell short of expectations.
author: Amy X.

description:
Really nice atmosphere, 
started off strong with creamy burrata cheese& perfect side dishes- cauliflower and brussel sprouts, but the main dishes-salmon and mussel pasta were so salty, i thought maybe the chef mistakenly poured the salt all over our entree..
But fortuntely the dessert- housemade gelatos- made up a bit with its creamy sweetness..
author: jiwon evelyn k.

description:
I've been here more than a handful of times so I confidently will vouch for this joint - the more casual, and MUCH more affordable (surprisingly affordable, maybe even cheap for what the establishment looks like, actually - A+) younger sibling of its' fine-dining, pricier older sister, Perbacco, which is just a few doors down. While not a completely rock solid four stars, Barbacco has proven itself to be, at the very least, a sometimes wavering, but mostly a legit four star contemporary Italian establishment. Good for a comfortable first date in the city, a catch-up with a friend, or just an after work bite.

The restaurant encompasses a modern/trendy feel with a somewhat communal atmosphere, what with the long tables, a long bar set-up with seats, and the majority of their plates being conducive to a shared, family-style experience. 

Recommended:
- Fried brussel sprouts: A MUST! An addicting plate of crispy, deliciously sweet and savory red wine vinaigrette doused brussel sprouts. Perfect for sharing. 
- Bruschetta: They had a decent variety. Truffled lardo (shaved fat, basically . . . mm, fat, delicious), duck liver pate, pear and gorgonzola are all especially delicious.
- Mushroom risotto: half shelled, which I don't come across very often, but is flavored perfectly and tastes earthier than your usual risotto because of the chewy shells 
- Lasagna: cheesy, meaty, layered with house made spinach pasta. Delicious and recommended for lasagna fans.
- Orecchiette: "little ears" that come with fennel sausage, a hearty portion of sauteed kale mixed into it and delicious Italian cheeses. One of my favorites, when made right (which unfortunately it hasn't been sometimes)
- Gelato: Butterscotch crunch - tasty and not overwhelmingly sweet at all
- Espresso panna cotta: Both dense and surprisingly light. Delicious.  

A notable quirk they possess here are the iPad drink menus at every table. Only . . .  they're SO incredibly inefficient and unnecessary. They fail more than they display the drink options, and they don't even allow you to order from them. (Maybe expand it's purpose, Barbacco? Have pictures of the specials, food, desserts, etc).  Also, the paper menu is incredibly unorganized. They clear up what certain Italian food categories (piccoline: small starter snacks, dal grano: pasta based dishes, etc) mean on the BACK . . . why?! I'm sure the wait staff has experienced the result of this poor printing choice more than enough by having to explain what could easily have been figured out on our own if it weren't for the poor menu organization. 

Anyway, aside from those few minor gripes, the food has been mostly consistently delicious, innovative, and while not every item on the menu hits it out of the park, nothing I've tried has ever not hit at least slightly above average. Combine that factor with the super reasonable prices, and I'm yours. 

My newest reliable go-to joint in the FiDi, hands down. :)
author: Betty W.

description:
A great place for sharing and family style.

We started with the suppli (mushroom risotto croquettes filled with truffled mozzarella) the two bruschette (crushed sweet peas + cannellini beans). The suppli is pretty heavy, and the size of a hush puppy. Good amount to share between two for appetizer.

For entree, we split the rigatoncini (summer squash + chili mint + parmigiano reggiano) and brussels sprouts fried in duck fat. Pasta was average, and the brussels sprouts were so full of flavor (helloooooo, duck fat in my mouth) though it was slightly on the salty side.

I was pretty happy with my meal. Didn't get to try their yummy cocktails, but this means I'll be back. A perfect place for catching up with friends!
author: Annie L.

description:
It's shocking how some folks can Yelp a restaurant before it even opens to the public... wish I had those kind of hookups!  Came here at the beginning of the lunch service on the opening day.  Was impressed by the level of detail put into every single dish in terms of ingredient complexity and letting the customer know about most of those ingredients on the menu.  The vibe is power-lunch-lite -- great food priced above take out, but not an expense account buster.

Crushed Cannelini Beans Bruschette: Smooth and subdued except for a mild kick from fresh onions, this bruschette is a good contrast when paired with more potent ones.  

Duck Liver Pate Bruschette: First bite was accidentally only the pate which had that overpowering liver taste.  Subsequent bites included the onions in balsamic vinegar which worked perfectly to complement the pate.  A must for folks that get bored by charcuterie with only mustard and cornichons. 

Whipped Salt Cod Bruschette: Like a little salt cod patty with a chapeau of pillowy mashed potatoes.  I'm normally hesitant to get salt cod because it can taste so fishy, but this is apparently made in house and tastes a lot fresher (for salt cod).

Butternut Squash Passato  Soup: Probably the most disappointing item I tasted.  Too salty and watery.  Perhaps even too much butter.  I was hoping for a richer butternut squash experience.

Zuppa di Pesce: The small size is much smaller than the small butternut squash soup.  Lots of great herbs floating about this thin tomato broth.  Only appeared to be fish filet and no shellfish treats.  Really like the concept of being served with a crostini which had a very thick aioli sauce spread on... classier garlic bread!

Slow Roasted Shoulder Porchetta Sandwich: Finally I can stop harping about how no one does porchetta better than the humble Roli Roti.  This was more tender and more flavorful by far!  Apparently they bring in a whole pig for all their pork dishes.  They could have been more liberal with the crunchy skin segments from their personal pig though.  The chewy roll was a good vehicle for absorbing all the juice (i.e. grease).  The grape topping was nice, but I could have been happy with just the meat!  The pickled veggies (carrots, celery, cauliflower, peppers) on the side tasted like pure white vinegar... keep them marinating a bit longer please.

Polpette: It's nice to have over sized meatballs that crumble apart with a fork instead of insisting on a knife.  If you can slow braise meatballs, they must have done so!  The pine nuts were a good surprise inside the ball.  The greens (chard?) was sadly boring.  The tomato chunks had a fresh texture, but could have used more spice.  

Vanilla-Huckleberry Gelato: Second worst thing I tried on the menu.  Allegedly vanilla gelato with huckleberry jam.  The huckleberries were so dry I swear they were huckleraisins.  The vanilla gelato base was dense instead of smooth and creamy.

Limonata: Not from the can or bottle, just another word for fresh lemonade.  Perfect for my taste -- sour enough to make you appreciate as an adult, but not so sour it makes you whince.
author: Adam B.

description:
Even though we came to Barbacco to partake of the NPA (http://www.yelp.com/biz/natural-process-alliance-tasting-room-santa-rosa) 2011 wine releases, I left loving Barbacco for its food.

Charming wine director Mauro eased us into the evening by offering us glasses of the NPA Pinot Gris when he saw my date futilely searching the proffered iPad drinks menu for a martini--wine and beer only are served here. That was the perfect solution, as the wines were our primary focus for the evening. The food, if good, would only heighten the experience. But it turned out that both food and wine were equal partners in the evening's successes--and excesses.

With five or so offerings in each section (salumi, cheeses, bruschette, pastas, secondi, and sides) it was hard to make a decision. Fortunately, visiting NPA wine expert Hardy offered up his recommendations and suggested wine pairings.

The sausage-stuffed deep-fried olives and the nduja partnered perfectly with our Pinot Gris, as promised. At the risk of offending the Boccalone gods, I think I preferred this version of the spreadable salami. Maybe it was the perfectly charred, olive-oil brushed crostini that accompanied it, but the spread here seemed more meatily mellow yet flavorful, with a hint of a peppery kick.

The orecchiette with fennel sausage and the suddenly ubiquitous cavolo nero kale was even better than my more traditional sausage and broccoli rabe favorite. The little pasta ears were filled with a pesto-like rendition of the kale that was very hard to stop eating. This paired well with the NPA red blend (too many varietals to remember), as did my braised chicken thighs with almonds and castelvetrano olives and my date's lamb stew. 

Just as Hardy had said, the saltiness of the fried Brussels sprouts with capers and anchovies was tamed by the Pinot Gris.

I may have found a favorite Italian trattoria at last! Portions and food were better than at SPQR. And even though we stuffed ourselves last night (including the flourless chocolate cake to go--don't judge), I can't wait to return to try the rest of the menu. 

You have to love a place that serves NPA wines and has special NPA wine nights--and that has a dessert called chocolate nemesis. Death by chocolate never sounded (or tasted) better.
author: Julie K.

description:
Food: 5/5 - Pasta is extremely fresh, with a great authentic homemade taste. The celery root salad is a little too drenched for my taste, but the beet salad and brussels sprouts are both outstanding. The ragu is simple, but one of the best I've had in SF. The lasagna was extremely well done as well. 

Service: 4/5 - Since it's a more casual/small place, you may end up waiting a bit for service. And it's certainly not a fine dining type of wait staff, but they are friendly enough.

Ambiance: 4/5 - The entire space is long and narrow, and a good amount of the seating is at the bar - but that's just how this place was intended to be. Even so, having sat at both a table for lunch and bar for dinner, it's always a fun and lively place - not too loud and certainly fun and not stuffy. 

Value: 5/5 - With pastas at no more than $13, and small salads and sides from $5-10, this is a really solid meal that can be under $20 base if you have a simple salad+pasta. Even for a work lunch, I'd definitely pay $10-13 for a great pasta, compared to so many other spots that are near $10+ for a sandwich.
author: Kevin T.

description: I came here to try the braised chicken thigh in roasted peppers and a lot of other good stuff. My sister brought me here and I enjoyed every bite of my dinner.
author: Krystal S.

description:
Hip Trattoria With Good Food At A Great Price.

The ambiance is sleek, urban and inviting. The marble bar stretched from the store front to the kitchen and paired elegantly with its brick wall on the opposite side of the dining area. The staff was helpful, well informed and kind. Our server, married our meal with a great bottle of Alameda wine.

For starters we ordered the Jar of roasted mushrooms trifoalti which was layered with herb truffled mascarpone served with Crostini. This was by far is my favorite dish here. The mushrooms were succlently roasted and paired well with the creamy, lightly rich mascarpone that orchestrated a sweet symphony to my pallet.

The Brussels sprouts fried in duck fat with capers, anchovies and red wine vinaigrette was surprisingly delightful; a concoction of ingredients I would have never imagined.

For dinner I safely ordered the Lasagna Bolognese with spinach pasta and balsamella sauce. It was just ok; there was too much cheese for my taste.

Overall this is a nice place to eat. I would definitely come back for the Jars.
author: Rochelle P.

description:
good not great. the best way to describe this restaurant is by quoting the bartender/waiter in relation to the food i ordered. i asked him if the brussel sprouts were good and he said "oh yes, they are probably one of the most popular things on the menu." 

they weren't good. soggy with no real flavor.

i sent them back and ordered another side which wasn't good either. the pasta i ordered was good but nothing great. this restaurant is not a place i would text my wife about or go with friends if I were in town.

if you read this, do yourself a favor and go to a real italian restaurant.
author: Dan B.

description:
Revisited and still loved the wine list. Really interesting wines from all over the world, and very easy to try plenty with 3 or 6 oz pours.

The salumi plate was just okay, we liked the spicy one called piccante the best.

The crudo was really fresh and surprisingly REALLY spicy with the serranos. We loved it but if you don't like spicy, I wouldn't advise this dish.

The cured anchovy with egg bruschetta was outstanding, perfect balance of flavors.

The pork ragu with (large tube) pasta was just okay, on the bland side and the pork was tough.

The flank steak with poached egg and asparagus was perfectly cooked, great dish, and awesome for leftovers the next day.

You select wines via IPad, which is pretty cool.
author: Derrick V.

description:
YES! this weekend must have been a good one for food on me.

what a discovery.. i had such an awesome experience here tonight. i loved the ambiance, service and mostly food. also it was delightfully weird to see a menu that had nothing over 20 dollars. therefore, i assumed that the portion would be small, WRONG, the portion was ridiculously huge and dishes were very tasty. i enjoyed Perbacco greatly but this place actually managed to blow me away with their food.

the whole ipad thingy was a little bit confusing to me but i could certainly appreciate the high-tech aspect of it!

this would be my to-go place. yum!
author: Sung C.

description:
I was confused when I first heard about Barbacco. I had been to PERbacco -  which was right next door (and delicious, I might add) - but BARbacco was off my radar. I thought it literally was a bar, not the delicious restaurant that deserves ample accolades. 

I liked it even better than Perbacco. Its trendy with it's iPad drink menus, thorough with its extensive menu, and the service is the best I've had in a long time. The man that served us was literally smiling ear-to-ear the entire time, SO helpful and friendly. 

The chicken thighs were divine and the garlic, cooked to perfection. The polpette was also delicious although I wished it were a little softer. The bruschette was a great way to start out the meal (my favorite was the crushed sweet peas). 

Fellas, are you looking for a great new date spot that'll impress but not break the bank? Barbacco will treat you, your date AND your wallet kindly.
author: Julia N.

description: Food price and restaurant are good. I ordered the fish but it's very salty. You may need to suggest them putting less salt in your food before the order. I had the mandarin orange gelato and it's just okay.
author: Luk C.

description:
I had a really fun time at Barbacco. Yes, the iPad wine list is cute (and it was fun to check out everyone's labels), but what made it for me was the service and the quality of the food. The sommelier and our waiter (unfortunately I didn't make the effort to get either of their names) were both kind and extremely helpful. The sommelier even brought my mom and I a complimentary sample of a funky wine that he thought we might enjoy - and he was right! 

As for food, the risotto croquettes sounded amazing but were not the best I have had - they were a little lacking in flavor. However, the celery root salad MORE than made up for that. It was amazing and unlike anything I had tried before; each flavor and texture (apple, walnut, gorgonzola, celery root) was perfectly balanced with the next. I wish I could have gotten the recipe. I also tried the Toma Trifulera cheese, which was paired with Christmas bush honey. It was a new cheese to me and I really loved it - it is always nice to see something unique on a cheese list. My mom and her friend loved the 'njuda spread and the meatballs.

I would love to return to try more small plates!
author: Laura Z.

description:
A friend took me here a few weeks back. He raved about the lasagna, so I got the lasagna and there definitely wasn't any of that "hmm, after all that hype this wasn't really as good as I expected." It was excellent. Probably best I've had.

We also started with the bruschetta. They're super small so get several if you've got more than a couple people. We had the 
house cured lardo / rosemary / frisee and the asparagus / ricotta / meyer lemon / tarragon. I liked them both - pretty different flavors than I'm used to on bruschetta, but in a good way. I liked the options, not just your typical walnut pesto or fig/Brie or classic tomato basil. 

Cool atmosphere; I'd certainly describe it as trendy. We went on a Tuesday night and it was packed with the financial district types. It's a communal table style joint too, so you're rubbing elbows with the other parties next to you. Not too bad though. Pretty loud, so don't expect anything intimate.
