I guess I'd give this place more around 4.5 stars if possible, but I'll round down because table space really was tight and I'm picky about 5 star ratings.

Service was good, nothing bad to say about that really. Beer and wine selection seemed pretty good, though I just had an IPA. The server also claimed to be a sommelier, so if I had wanted wine I probably would have asked his opinion because most of it wasn't stuff I'd heard of.
author: Michelle L.

description:
I've been here a few times, most previous is after being traumetized by the SF protests...sorry but protests are public with bunch of tourists (with kids) around...nude people walking back and forth is not appetizing or tasteful and doesn't put a point across.

Well, lunch time, you definitely need a reservation.  I've come here with a reservation but last minute someone tagged along... (large mistake), because seating is limited, counters and tables may be shared, you definitely need to make reservation and stick with it.

The iPad menus are cool (ish)...although I don't find them particularly useful, although gives the feeling of trying to be hip and with the times.

Service is very good and friendly, regardless if you sit at the "bar" or at a table.  

If you aren't particularly hungry get the spreadable salumi (can't remember the exact name) and the brussel sprouts, absolultely delicious, and cheats since its cooked in duck fat.
author: Omar L.

description:
Love this place.  Always a stop when I'm in SFO.  Great wines (ordered from iPad.  Fun to play around with)
Great apps as well. 
pork ragu pasta was delicious.  I enjoyed the white bean crostini as well as the arinchini

It gets crowded but don't worry. Perbacco's little bro is always a good time.
author: I C U.

description:
Very fine ital small plates. brucchetta, soup, pork pasta, were all stand outs I would order again if the rest of the menu wasnt so tempting

Great server who knew the world wine menus, but a few were a bit too raw and actually turned my stomach

Very fair prices - order small and add as you go

Only real draw back are the huge TV -which undercut the otherwise classy intimate atmosphere - especially when they are dialed in to Food TV - could anything be lamer?
author: Rick N.

description:
Showed up at the restaurant on a Wednesday at 6:30 pm with 4 hungry, tired people and no reservation. No table was available but they were exceptionally accommodating and called next door to their bar and found a place for us to sit for drinks and appetizers. Before we ordered, a table opened at the restaurant so we went back  to have a lovely meal with great drinks.

Our teenagers ordered lemonade with mint and strawberry lemonade. Both refreshing and not too sweet.  We had wine - chose several glasses and each was good.

We made special requests for the entrees for the kids and they were more than accommodating. The gluten free corn pasta was perfect - "toothy" without being underdone or overdone. Smokey bacon, ricotta and spinach created a sublime, ever changing flavor on your tongue. I'm having leftovers for breakfast!

The swordfish pasta was perfectly executed - swordfish cooked perfectly, complimented by a sauce that was a little spicy and paired perfectly with the fish.

The staff bent over backwards to be sure we were taken care of. From the hostess to the server to the staff setting the tables, every one made sure we had everything we needed. No request was too excessive, no work they did was begrudgingly. 

I wish all restaurants had this level of customer service!
author: Casey D.

description:
Got here at around 8:20 for our 8:30 reservations and the place was still bustling! Ordering our drinks via iPad was a really nice touch and kept us occupied until our table was ready.

The ambience was lovely: dark wood accented by intimate lighting. I could see this being a cute date restaurant. 

Dinner Menu for 2 Foodies: duck liver pate, fried brussels sprouts, lasagna, and duck pork ragu. The duck liver pate was nicely rich, but it was a pretty small portion. The fried brussels sprouts were really good at first, but the more we ate, the more we found it pretty salty and had to pair it with some complimentary bread. The lasagna and duck pork ragu were the stars of the night. Even though it was a pretty carb-heavy night, we couldn't stop eating until everything (except the sprouts) were finished. 

The price wasn't bad either. I appreciate that the ambience and menu are different than the usual Italian dining experience. Definitely will be coming back!

On the negative: Because it was so busy and there really aren't a lot of tables, our party of 2 was forced to share a large table, adjacent to another party of 4. This made for tough casual conversation because we had to speak over the already loud crowd. However, the table sharing did add to the lively happy hour ambience.
author: Linna L.

description:
I don't do this very often, but I am RETRACTING my previous review.

Why? Because, after posting this review and writing to the restaurant, both the owner AND the manager emailed me, apologized profusely for my bad experience *and* invited me to return for lunch on the house. 

As it happened, I had a lunch meeting with a client, so I brought her here as she had mentioned she wanted to try it. We had the limonata (mine classic, hers mint), and the following:

Local squid alla piastra: deliciously soft squid, lovely combination of flavors in the sauce, and *just* the right amount of chili. 

Duck liver pate: my client didn't like it (she thought it was too rich and too much pate) but I ate all mine. Yes, it was definitely rich, but I loved the way the acidity from the balsamic caramelized onion cut the richness of the duck liver pate. 

Brussel sprouts: whoever invented this dish is a GENIUS. Absolutely outstandingly delicious. I could eat just a plate of it for dinner and be happy!

Sicilian meatballs: very, very nicely done. Dense, meatballs, but not heavy, and the sauce was delicious. 

And to top it all off, a scoop of the strawberry gelato, which was light, sweet and reminded me that it was summer. 

I was happy to pay for my lunch partner, but was told by the server (who was superbly efficient, friendly, and fun!) that *both* our lunches were on the house. 

AND we were in an out in just under an hour. 

Thank you, Maria and Umberto, for making a believer out of me. I'll definitely be back!
author: Mi M.

description:
Came with an old boss to Barbacco for dinner this past Wednesday night.  I am glad we had made a reservation because it was totally packed even at 7:30 which I feel is a little later than most people in downtown would be eating (people go home early; this ain't Manhattan).  

The menu is really hard to read ... I will blame this on a combination of the font, the spacing, the fact that they chose to eschew capitalization, and the fact that like 90% of the words are in Italian.  I ended up getting the beef & we also ordered a focaccia appetizer and the nemesis chocolate cake.  

Service was attentive perhaps in large part due to the fact that we sat at the bar.  Atmosphere was super crowded and loud -- it's not that any one party was particularly rowdy, but they pack people in here like a can of sardines.  

I enjoyed the food (in particular the focaccia and the nemesis cake) and good service, but have to detract 2 stars for the atmosphere / how hard it was to have a conversation despite sitting literally inches away from my dining companion.  Very dimly lit as well -- I would be wary to bring my parents here because they have trouble reading in the dark.

The number of good, 2-dollar-sign sit-down dinner places in FiDi is pretty limited, but I'll probably branch out and try somewhere else next time I get an evening meal in the area.  I may end up back here eventually, but I can't help but feel it's worth exploring other options.
author: Molly B.

description:
It was a very good co-worker's last work day - we came here post beers to fuel.

First off - I had never been to a restaurant that you ordered partially via iPad. Classy? Maybe just a LITTLE cheesy.

The food selection seemed more Italian/Upper Gourmet fusion - not anything quite "authentic". Portions are small - best to play it like tapas where the table orders a bunch of stuff and everyone picks at it.

I really liked the 3 prosciutto plate, and the toast with fresh cheese and tomato.

Wine selection was fabulous - we ran through two bottles for 5 people.

Some descriptors: Decent menu variety, nice location to the office, modern decor, a bit loud, a place to go maybe once or twice.
author: Pamela R.

description: Love this place! Everything was spectacular from the service to the food to the wine pairing! I would recommend this place for a date night :) Get the spaghetti with meatballs, yum yum!!!
author: Michelle W.

description: I had dinner my first night in town and was floored. First of all, the hostess and servers were so friendly and helpful! I had a billion questions and they were so patient. The food was unreal....I had the Brussels and they were so amazing. Crispy, and fried in duck fat. I could have had them for dinner. I also had the albacore tuna...so good. I loved every bite of this meal! Check them out! Only drawback....they were closed on Sunday for lunch when I tried to go back.:(
author: Caroline K.

description: Lost it's luster. The shared tables are gone, the quality of food and service has fallen (note, the restaurant wasn't busy at all). Save you dollars for so much better elsewhere in SF. We have been here many times since they opened. Sad to see the lack of interest in keeping this place at its best. Won't be back.
author: Teeky P.

description:
I'm always at a loss when I have a good dining experience and a dinner companion doesn't.  So, in order to be fair, I want to state up front that on the merits of my meal Barbacco deserves four stars.

The wine list is pretty brief, but seems well curated. I had a lovely glass of dolcetto that stood up to all of my menu selections well.  One of my friends had an outstanding Sangiovese that also worked well with everything and was nice on its own. On our side of the table, we started things off with some nduja (spicy spreadable salami) and a roasted mushroom spread that consisted of chopped mushrooms layered with truffled marscapone. Both starters came in little pots with crostini. Both were rich, satisfying and delicious. I would order either again in a heartbeat. The crostini to spread ratio was a bit off, but the kitchen happily supplied more. On the other side of the table, they opted to try the suppli (risotto cakes stuffed with truffled mozarella) and crostone with burrata and roasted beets. I only had a morsel of each, but both of them were solid choices. For a main, I had the farrotto (farro cooked risotto style) with roasted mushrooms and chesse. It had a wonderful balance of flavors and was particularly soothing for a rainy evening. The potion seemed never ending and I opted to take half of it home. It made a terrific lunch the next day. One of my friends had the flat iron steak (it was on the rare side, which I personally love) and another had the braised chicken thighs. They both seemed really happy with their options. I thought the steak and its accompanying mushrooms were yummy. But something went off kilter when it came to the paccheti (pork ragu). There wasn't much pork in evidence and my friend didn't like the pasta they chose for the dish or the red sauce. I didn't actually try it, but it did seem kind of lackluster. Things got back on track with dessert. The espresso panna cotta had a textbook-perfect texture (so creamy!) and a nice flavor. 

The service was excellent and I really liked the atmosphere. One thing to note, having the wine list on an ipad seemed kind of silly. The list isn't nearly long enough to remotely justify it.
author: Nicole M.

description:
It was a friday and I'd had a tough week and I wanted a good glass of wine and some carbs, but I didn't feel like hanging out with anyone. So I decided to take myself out on a solo-date to Barbacco. Dining alone on a friday night as a woman in her 30's at a fidi bar, I thought I might get treated like a crazy cat lady. But the Barbacco staff were all class acts and took great care of me. I was immediately granted a seat at the bar where I watched the basketball game with a lovely glass of montepulciano d'abruzzo and a hot slab of lasagna. I emerged from dinner feeling like I'd just indluged in a five-star spa -- totally refreshed and satisfied, attitude successfully adjusted.

Sidenote: their panforte is the best I've had.
author: maggie g.

description:
A friend took me to Barbacco for a casual lunch.

I'm glad we made reservations - a lunch in the Financial District during the holiday season means competing with everyone else's year-end celebration. We arrived on time and were seated within 10 minutes at the bar. The decor was pleasant enough, though not particularly memorable. Our bar seating was kind of cramped but not enough to be totally uncomfortable.

I had a glass of Italian red wine recommended by the bartender/waiter. I forgot to ask the name, but it was a lovely $10 glass. My friend had to return to work, so she abstained.

For our main dish, we both ordered the meatballs with wilted greens. She got a side order of fried polenta which was *amazing*. The flavors went well together - there were three medium-large meatballs, well cooked inside and browned on the outside, just shy of being caramelized. The greens were excellent, and the small amount of pan sauce was great. Combined with a bite of polenta stick, the dish was heavenly.

We skipped dessert and got out of the restaurant for less than $60 (including tax and tip). Not exactly a cheap lunch on the go, but I'd recommend this location for a casual lunch with working professional friends.
author: Karen C.

description:
Porchetta Sandwich is all I need to say after my first of many trips to come. 

I'm a loyal Perbacco fan and finallllly made my way to Barbacco this week to eat up some delish Porchetta. 

What you'll love about this place is the quality food and service - your one and only complaint may just be that fact that you'll have speak louder than usual with your dining companion as this place can get a bit rowdy when it comes to noise levels - but then again, I guess everyone is just having a great time and screaming O's while stuffing their face with the porchetta and the rest of the menu. That's why I'm not docking any stars.

I didn't get a chance to try the pastas but I will definitely be going back to try the rest of the menu. I love their soup selection as well and non-alcoholic beverage options for the lunch hour.

Make a reservations to save yourself a wait - and enjoy! Great for biz lunches or a Stage 1 date where you need some background noise - just in case. Cheers!
author: Jessica C.

description:
Great food and service. 
The menu has decent amount of options.. 
We were 7 so i had a chance to try many things! ( lucky i know! ) 

Coming back again!
author: Lana A.

description:
This is my new favorite restaurant.  First of all.... the most expensive thing on the menu is $19.  Very affordable.   We started with lots of antipasto.  Yummy toasted bread and cheese with artichokes, tapenades, olives, chick pea salad, an awesome beat salad, grilled octopus, bruschetta with pate and pruchetto.  ALL FABULOUS!  I could have made a meal of these alone!... but.. we ate more..... The Spaghetti and Mussels was perfectly cooked pasta with a light olive oil sauce with very tasty black mussels and salami on top... We also had the Beef Cheeks... served on a bed of polenta was delicious... and would be even better on a chilly day.... The major stand out.... the Brussels Sprouts!!!!  They are fried on duck fat, then finished on top of the stove with lemon zest and course salt.. UNREAL!  Craveable!!... Finished up with home made Raspberry Gelato, and a Berry Shortcake.
Everything was FLAWLESS!!!!!  Excellent service, too!  Can't wait to go back to this fabulous place!!
author: Bryan M.

description: Mixed experience.  Food was excellent, albeit portions are small.  Server was very pleasant.  Not so good: server recommended a wine without mentioning that it was quite expensive.  $84 for two small carafes.
author: Charles E.

description:
2.25.2011
9:00 PM (walk-in)
$118

Risotto croquette
broccoli bruchetta
liver pate bruchetta
brussel sprouts
penne pasta

Ambiance: B
Food:  A-
Drink:  B+
Value:  B+
Service:  A-

Overall: A-

note:  service from the waitress was fantastic but the kitchen was too backed up to get food out efficiently.  Still, will def be back.
author: William R.

description: This place is fine, but I wouldn't go out of my way to come, or suggest it to friends. Most of the food tastes fine and the staff is knowledgeable and friendly. But my mouth wasn't particularly excited or happy after eating. I wasn't too impressed. The best part that I would come for is dessert-the ice creams are generous and delicious!
author: Deb B.

description:
I came here with my co-workers and manager to celebrate a great performing month so we decided to order up a storm! 

We got:

- brussel sprouts (fried in duck fat!)
- duck liver pate
- humbolt fog 
- salumi (chef's selection)
- cheese plate
- paccheri (pork ragu) 
- lasagna bolognese
- canneromi (i think?)
- sangria
- panna cotta

Wow, I loved it all. I'd have to say that my faves were the brussel sprouts and salumi. I'm usually not a fan of cured meats but this definitely changed me. Everything was so tasty! I also have a low tolerance for alcohol too but the sangria was sooooo good - straight up juice! 

The service was exceptional and the overall ambiance here was very nice and relaxing after a long day. For 5 people, the bill came out to be less than $200, which is reasonable considering all the things we ordered! 

I definitely want to come back :)
author: V L.

description: Barbacco is a solid option for dinner in the financial district.  The food isn't as mind-blowing as I'd expected, but there were a couple of standouts, particularly the burrata and the steak.  The portions on the pasta dish were a big oversized in my opinion.
author: Hailey C.

description:
Thank you, Yelpers, for telling me to order the Brussels sprouts at Barbacco.  I would not have done it independently and they were so.freaking.good.  Wow.  It is amazing what a little duck fat and red wine vinegar will do for these much-maligned spouts.

Other dishes at Barbacco were similarly impressive.  My personal favorites were the cannellini bean bruschetta and the spiced pear cake.  To die for.  My husband was practically licking the bowl after finishing his bean minestra-- he loved it.  We also enjoyed the paccheri pasta with pork ragu, the gorgonzola pear bruschetta (a little heavy on the gorgonzola, but perfect when half of the cheese was removed) and the braised chicken thighs served on polenta.  I really like the small plates concept here.  The portions aren't so small as to be ridiculous, like so many other places that experiment with Tapas, and it allowed us to try many more offerings.  Two of us split eight dishes, total, and I had a glass of wine.  Total at the end of the evening, with tip, was $80.  Not bad for such a variety of food, and really good food at that.

Service was good.  We had a reservation, and had to wait maybe 5 minutes when we arrived because the restaurant was packed even at an early hour.  No biggie.  We were shown to a spot at the counter.  It's a little awkward to have to turn around to talk to your server and a little squishy in the restaurant in general, but again, not a biggie.  Our server was friendly, gave great input on the various dishes, and kept our time-frame in mind so that we were able to leave in time to catch a movie down the street.  We did enjoy ordering our drinks via iPad.  How cool would it be if the whole menu could be presented that way?

Overall, a great experience.  We would definitely return.
author: Erin L.

description:
took a date here. nice date vibe and we got two seats that were not shared, but mostly seating in this restaurant is communal tables. 

food was pretty good. brussels sprouts were good but a little too vinegary for my taste. portion size of the croquette was kind of small. farrotto (farro risotto) was EXCELLENT. the cornish game hen was alright, kind of flavorless. 

i don't know if i'll be back.
author: Siva M.

description:
This place is great, the ascolane (Fried Olives stuffed with pork) is great, it's hard to just eat one! Also they make their own salumi which is amazing as well. Get the "angry mussels" they are wonderful, make sure to soak up the juices with their bread yum!

Every table has an iPad with the wine and beer list which is kind of fun to go though with your guests.
author: Kyle H.

description:
This is the sister restaurant to Perbacco.  I was excited to try this casual and cheaper version of the aforementioned.  Many a Yelper declared this to be Perbacco without the price tag.  I wouldn't say Perbacco has the best food, but there are some real gems there.

Barbacco is a bit like an Italian tapas place.  The bar seating area that reminds me a bit of a sushi bar.  The action happens here.  They have several ipads resting here on stands.  I immediately grabbed one to check out the goods.

Ipad placement here is pure gimmick.  The Ipad is completely app free, and instead contains a limited cocktail menu with a selection of wine, specialty drinks, and beer.  The specialty drinks features a selection of three bellini.  Technically, bellini is wine.  I look around and notice that they do not have a full liquor license.  Perhaps, remove this option from the menu?

I would recommend unlocking the Ipad and allowing customers to surf the web or check email, in case they are waiting for someone or on a really awkward date.  What a waste of an Ipad!

The menu here looks delicious, and hard to decide what to eat!  We tried a number of shared plates including a selection of cheeses and two orders of flat iron steak.

I found the fare simpler, and less delicate than Perbacco.  The quality of the ingredients is perhaps not as select, however, this is a nice atmosphere for a flavorful meal with friends at a nice price.
author: apple r.

description: The food was good, nothing really stood out.  I thought the wine and beer list could have had a little more variety.  The server/bartender didn't put in an order, but we ended up being beyond full by what was brought out that we didn't mention it.  The hazelnut gelato was delicious, but the seasonal burnt orange was off - it didn't taste even remotely like orange.
author: A L.

description:
Nice combination of elegant dining atmosphere and tasty food! 

We had the following, I would highly recommend it all! 
- Arancini risotto croquettes filled with short rib and mozarella. honestly, I dont even remember what this was like... probably wasn't great or bad.
- Duck Liver Pate / balsamic onion marmellata - MMM pate! 
- Lasagna Bolognese - I normally don't like lasagna because I feel like its some cheap italian dinner that my mom can prepare. BUT this lasagna was pretty delicious... right up there with the likes of the lasagna from cafe claude...
- orecciette - the little ears pasta. I dont know if its the way the pasta is small little chewy bits...but i find it really fun to eat =) 
- Meatballs - I like balls. esp if they are meaty. the seasoning was a little off. 
- Brussel Sprouts - they are fried and make them taste a lot better than your normal cooked sprouts. I kind of got sick of it after a few though.

On a side note... i wanted to try the 'nduja, but they only had the lamb, and AMY L thinks lamb is TOO GAMEY so we didn't get it.. =p (but .. um how do you run out of something like that on a SATURDAY early on in the night?) MEH! 

Finally, the cornerstone of this establishment... the drink menu on ipads. HELLA IPADS! Frankly, its a little unnecessary, but it does add to the 'elegant dining experience' mentioned above. Fun to browse through, but uhhh i dont know much about wine... (also, i kept freezing the 2 ipads we were brought. oops) I tried their sangria which was tasty!
author: Tim B.

description: First off, this place has very good food and is very consistent.  I've been here numerous times - lunch and dinner - and getting the same level of quality sounds simple but so hard to find.  At lunch time, the noise level is high so bring your shouting voice!  The meatballs are my favorite, and all the salads are very good.  While you can certainly enjoy this place as a solo diner, this place is best for 2 for more.  That way you can order a variety of dishes and split them.  Add a good bottle of wine and you are set.  Enjoy....
author: Robert H.

description: Had their Mushroom risotto and it was excellent...great ambiance and nice place for weekday lunch in financial district.
author: Cherry J.

description: I made a reservation using OpenTable for 1 at 7 PM and arrived about 6:50 PM and was immediately seated at the counter (huge points here). The SF Giants game was on TV and I was promptly asked what kind of water I wanted. I ended up ordering wine which cost more than my dinner. The wine seems a little pricey compared to the food prices but I was okay with it. I ended up ordering the Chitarra since everyone from Yelp raved about it. It was very tasty. I'd come back again for sure. Not sure I'd order wine again but the food prices were very reasonable for what you got. Great atmosphere and location in the FD.
author: Greg S.

description:
Alright, so now its been a couple of weeks.months and I tried everything on the menu...

Some stuff maybe bland while others have a punch...
Anything with Sardines, olives, pork, tomato base foods, are all savory while everything else (brussel sprouts, polenta with mushrooms, salad, etc) is super duper bland, no fireworks in your mouth. 

So if you go here and you want flavor, go for the gusto products with anchovies, etc...

Thats all folks :)
author: Q A.

description:
This is the "ugly" sister of the more chichi Perbacco. It's definitely much less formal and stuffy than it's evil big sis. My friends and I ended up ordering quite a few plates to share since the menu is designed to be that way.

We had the following:
- Stuffed Rissotto Mushroom (YUM)
- Toasted almonds (as expected)
- Marinated Olives (meh, I've had better)
- Mix of Salumi (nothing I recall that was drool worthy)
- Lasagna Bolognese (definitely a MUST HAVE; it was fresh and tasty!)
- Mussels (tender and not over cooked)
- Bruschetta (asparagus, mushroom & Duck Pate) the mushroom and Duck pate were lovely; asparagus had no taste
- Squid (tender and tasty with a nice spicy kick to it!)

Our server was very sweet without being pushy despite the restaurant filling up...we never had to ask for our waters to be refilled nor were we ever left waiting. The dishes came out steadily and we were always provided new plates and utensils.

I'll give the stuffier sister restaurant, Perbacco a try based on the tasty plates I had at Barbacco!
author: Soozie H.

description:
We came here instead of Perbacco because we were looking for something a little more casual, and definitely cheaper since it was the last dinner of a long vacation.  I think we made an awesome choice! The atmosphere was really fun, and we didn't have any food that I didn't like.  If I lived in San Francisco, this would definitely be a place that I would go to after work for happy hour and apps.

My favorite part of the meal was the Short Rib and Mozzarella Arancini, but I really enjoyed the Polpette and Parmesan Polenta that I had as my entree.  We also had the Mozzarella di Bufala with Asparagus and Fried Capers, which was really tasty.  My boyfriend wasn't a huge fan of the Lasagna, but that might have been because of the spinach noodles.

We also loved the iPad wine menus, but it would have been cooler if you could order straight from them.  Overall, I really enjoyed Barbacco.  The only negative thing that I might call out is that even though we had reservations, we were seated at the bar which was slightly uncomfortable.
author: Jessica G.

description: Met with some friends to celebrate our 15 year graduation from University. Although the food was delicious, the wait staff should be more attentive to details. Our order for a sparkling water was a still water. We had to rearrange our plates to match what we each ordered, and we had to request steak knives.
author: Kelvin M.

description:
Barbacco was a random dinner spot for me and an out-of-town friend. I'm new to the Bay Area and although I work in the financial district, I don't know all the best places to eat. So, duh, I turned to Yelp to help me figure it out! 

What Yelpers said was that it was reasonably priced, has good food, and it was close to wear we were randomly standing on Market Street (my out-of-towner wearing a dress and thin cardigan was freezing to death, so close proximinty food was needed). 

And you Yelpers were right! A ten minute walk and my friend I were there. The atmosphere is rustic and warm and it's a cool technological touch with being able to read a menu and order from an iPad. Not sure if it's necessary but it's kind of a fun feature. 

The food was pretty delicious. I don't remember how to say what I ate but it was a penne-like pasta cooked well with a light olive oil, garlic-y dressing over it with tomatoes and cheese. Very light, but filling. My friend had a pork pasta dish which was also hard to pronounce, but was pretty tasty too (or as Fergie would say T-A-S-T-E-Y). Had good pork flavor, but not too overwhelming. My favorite part though was the addition of free sparkling and/or flat water. I do love me some non-alcoholic bubbly. 

Service was prompt, nice, and really got the dinner moving at a good pace that seemed efficient, which was perfect since we were in a bit of a rush. The guy next to us was too and he got out pretty quick. 

Not a complaint for me, but I can see a gripe being having to sit close to strangers on the bench and bar seating they have. I liked it, but I can see how some people might not be a fan. 

A gripe of my own though, and really it's a pet peeve so take this with a grain of salt, but my promised wait time wasn't really held true. We were told 25 minutes, but it ended up being more like 35. Not a huge deal, an extra ten minutes, but it made us feel just that more rushed to get out since we had to be at SFO to pick up another friend. But the hostess was very plesant, so that made the wait not seem so bad.

All in all, not a bad experience. Dinner was probably about 30 bucks for the two of us, sans drinks or appetizers (because we're both poor recent college grads). .
author: Patrick W.

description:
The younger, funkier sister of Perbacco is just as delicious.  I had been told by many people you have to have the brussel sprouts, so why not a whole lunch.  

We started with the celery root salad.  The celery root was tender while the celery and apple were crispy.  There was the right amount of gorgonzola and toasted walnuts.  I followed that with a faro risotto.  There was the creaminess of the risotto while still having the heartiness of the faro.  Delish.  

The brussel sprouts are worth having.  They are fried in duck fat and topped with capers, anchovies and a red wine vinaigrette.  The vinaigrette cuts the fat and gives them a little kick.  I did end up with a big bite of anchovy which was not so nice, but I doubt that happens often.

I could not pass us torrone gelato to finish the meal and I was not disappointed.
author: Megan P.

description:
Highly Recommended dishes:
Flat Iron Steak Tagliata - order this one rare!
Braised Chicken Thighs - super tender and delicious.
'nduja - it's almost like a salami pate that you spread on a crostini
Bruschette - duck liver pate...good stuff!

Recommended dishes:
Brushchette - peperonata / ricotta cheese / basil
Fried Brussel Sprouts - I'm typically not a fan of brussel sprouts but these were pretty good....although that's probably because the red wine vinaigrette hid the flavor of the brussel sprouts. This is a decent dish but the fried brussel sprouts at Marlowe are much better.

Skip these dishes:
Pesce Crudo - Hamachi served with radish. The radish did nothing for this dish and the flavors really did not go well together. Not worth $10 for three pieces of fish. Probably the worst dish of the night.
Risotto Croquettes - Nothing special here. Not worth $3 each.

Definitely make reservations as there always seemed to be a line for seats...although, most people seemed to get a table fairly quickly.
author: Lester W.

description: Enjoyed dinner here last night with a few friends. The bad......we had reservations at 8pm, but the place was so packed we had to wait almost 30 minutes. The food & service was excellent though and totally made our wait worth it. While we waited they quickly brought drinks out to us. When finally seated, they brought a couple complimentary appetizers (olives & cherry tomatoes) and a nice surprise at the end, they comped out desserts too. We choose to order a few meals and share family style. Enjoyed the beef stew, steak & lasagna all delicious and well prepared, some of the best flavors I've had in Italian dishes. The Brussels sprouts and the meatballs were our first course and were absolutely amazing! The pine nuts in the meatballs gave a unique texture, which we all that was fantastic. The desserts were excellent, we had 3 different ones, one was s cake with gigs (YUM), roasted strawberry gelato and a panna cota. Overall a fantastic meal with exceptional service and care. Very apologetic for our wait, but they took great care to make up for it without us even mentioning it! I can appreciate a company that goes out of their way like this, great job!
author: Jeanette R.

description:
OMG- this place was so so good. I went on a Friday night with my dear girlfriend and we had so much fun! First of all, our waiter was totally adorable. He gave us great service and recommended some really amazing wine with our meal. We ordered two types of bruschette: 1) roasted pears, balsamic, Gorgonzola truffled lardo- so good! 2) duck liver pate / balsamic onion marmellata- excellent pate! had a really beautiful salad, and then shared the pork ragu, which was easily the most delicious pasta dish I've had this year. In addition to the divine dinner, the restaurant is beautiful with a modern, rustic, elegant feel. I especially loved the iPad menu's which I've never seen in LA. I'm sure those will start showing up soon in my neck of the woods. For now, Barbacco is another San Francisco gem I look forward to visiting next time I'm in the city. 
Ambiance: A 
Price: $$$$
Food: A+ 
Cocktails: A+ (fantastic wine list) 
recommend for dates, special occasion, or evening out with friends. 
LOVED IT!
author: Andrea L.

description:
Meh explains it pretty well. The concierge recommended this place so we went with a handful of people in our party and made our reservation. We were seated promptly. The place was full, service was rather slow but we had an iPad to look at to keep us entertained (bar menu selection) . 

We asked for the recommendations from the menu and ordered a few things the staff suggested. The Brussels were overcooked, much more cabbage tasting and the bread for the bruschetta was burned on some and the toppings were meh. 

The lasagna was alright, but nobody finished their dishes. The squid was nice and tiny looking and the pasta dish with mushrooms had a mix of uncooked with cooked textures leaving a full bowl. Maybe this was an off night for the place so take the review as you will.

Just meh. Probably the worse dinner I've had in SF, however I get spoiled when I go out so my standards may be higher. 

The atmosphere was good and the sangria was excellent.
author: Nicholas R.

description: Everything here is wonderful! Bruschetta meat platter tasty and Brussels sprouts and cauliflower roasted was to die for!  Had the poached tuna salad which was great I like the bite size greens but the tuna had a few scales on it! Hahaha that's fresh! Lol overall love the ambience cool dining chairs and glass water carafes! Will definitely be back!
author: Dana D.

description: One of my favorite Italian restaurants in the City. The lasagna is incredible, all of the bruschette are delicious, the wine selection is fantastic, and the service is great. A little to loud to feel intimate, but still a great date spot.
author: Ari S.

description: Nice place, with great service, although the portions are a bit small. My friend was still hungry after dinner. The calamari dish was very good, but the duck fat brussel sprouts were a bit too rich. There was a very good wine selection.I definitely wouldn't mind checking it out again sometime.
author: Ojas V.

description: Awesome place, staff was very attentive and what I love is that we had only a few members of the staff keeping tabs on us which is refreshing. Nothing more annoying than having a different face at your table every five minuets asking if everything is okay. The staff was poised and polished. Lovely wine selection.  Try the duck liver pate (bruschette) or prosciutti!
author: Shawn C.

description:
Totally solid with some serious hits, and a few misses.

Hits: 

Chocolate nemesis cake.  5 bucks for a huge piece of flourless cake with chocolate sauce, nibs, and whip cream that two people can share?  Yes, please.

Also - solid risotto with farro.  I know farro risotto is the "in" thing now, but for 11 bucks, and a huge bowl of it, I'm not complaining

And - good mozzarella & asparagus starter, and fried brussel sprouts.  Mmm.

Good, solid service.  Cheery, yet not overly-friendly.

Misses:

Side of polenta.  Ugh - if you like clumpy, watery, bland polenta, then you'd like it.  Not my thing.

Bruschetta - they were cool, but the duck liver was really minerally for my taste.  I prefer a bit more creaminess.  The chickpea one was bland.  I just thought I'd skip them next time.

Atmosphere if you're NOT in the financial world: basically, we felt like we were the poorest people there on a Friday after work. I think if you were into "downtown" though, it's right up your alley.


All in all, I thought it was solid food for good prices.  They have wines for $10/glass which is nice BUT it's listed on ipads.  I'm old-school, and it honestly takes me more time to scroll through menus and back again, then to open a piece of paper and look at all the wines at once.  That's just me though, we can't all live in the dark ages I suppose.

I'd go back if I had a bigger group and wanted some lower-priced small plates to share without sacrificing quality!
author: Annie F.

description:
Is it as good as it's big brother next door?  (Perbacco)  No.  Is it worthy of your casual evening out?  Definitely.

- Ambiance -
A fancy casual establishment with a modern lounge feel.  The iPad wine list is a bit of a useless novelty.  It seemed like most tables in the place were six-seaters, so if you're in a party of 2, 3, or 4, plan on having neighbors sharing the table with you.  Also, the angle of the table (30 or 35 degrees) means that the person sitting on the acute side next to the wall is going to have fun repeatedly banging their left elbow.

- Food - 
Everyone at my table complained of saltiness in their pastas except for me.  I thought my Lasagna was very well prepared, though a bit small.  For appetizers, go with the chef's salumi selection.  The duck liver bruchette was also a winner.  The brussels sprouts are flavorful, delightfully seared, and prepared with much less butter and/or oil than seems to be en vogue these days... a plus in my book.

- Beverages -
I realize that there are only so many liquor licenses to be given out in San Francisco, but I was surprised that a place like this did not have a full bar.  Barbacco is definitely going for the lounge vibe, and with your beverage choices limited to wine and beer, it seems that they're missing a key element.  The bar/counter space is so vast and devoid of bottles, it looks like they're just waiting for a license to come through.  There were four of us, and we ordered the sangria pitcher.  The rest of my party enjoyed it well enough -- I found it to be hugely lacking.  It didn't taste like $6-per-glass/$36-per-pitcher sangria.  Little to no genuine fruit flavor.  I felt like I was drinking wine mixed with Koolaid.  Their wine list *is* extensive, and I wish we'd spent more time looking at that than being lured by the sangria.

- Value -
Our price per person, before gratuity and including drinks, came to $48.  We're a hungry lot, and ordered more than most folks might, as we were being adventurous with the menu.  Everyone left satisfied, if not quite impressed.  Still, you can get a perfectly decent fancy lounge meal there for less, just don't expect a hearty portion.

- Service -
Our waiter seemed a bit clueless.  He repeatedly tried to take our plates away at each course when we clearly weren't finished.  I guess he was attentive, though he continued to refill our sangria glasses from the pitcher after we'd asked him not to.  Perhaps he just didn't hear us.

To sum it up:  Quite good, though not great.  Hence only three stars.  Avoid the sangria.  Eat the brussels sprouts, they're good for you.
author: Walter P.

description: Great place to meet up with friends for a casual dinner, since it's pretty easy to grab a table. Cool vibe and the iPad wine menu adds some fun. Pork ragu was tasty, other dishes good too (not the best ever). Note--many of the tables are communal.
author: Abby H.

description: This place is incredible. The food was delicious, served by impeccable waiters, and the ambiance was great. I still frequently crave their risotto - it's some of the best I've ever had. I will definitely be adding this to my "revisit" list during my next trip to San Francisco.
author: Kristen S.

description: Just to say, I LOVE the food, the wine is normally just right. And when it isn't, they bring you a different glass, no problems. Why the one star?  The host/manager dude with the beard was essentially harassing us because one member of our party was running late, and apparently he's supposed to be a pro and no matter what he thinks, I really don't want to be lectured on how you have a 1.5 hour turnover times for the tables. I also didn't care for how he essentially threw the wine glasses down on the table and had a super sense of rush - not who I'd want at my restaurant hosting. I'm not sure when I'll be back with so many other choices. Amazing how one person's attitude can ruin a night.
author: brad m.

description:
Went here for a Saturday night dinner. I always thought Financial would be quite on weekends, but the restaurants near on California were filled. I made a reservation a few days before, which was nice but unnecessary.

The menu was expansive. SO many choices. I went with just one other person and wish I could have tried many more items. I over ordered as always, so was full by the time the more main courses came. The homemade salami's were great. I would recommend the bread to start, a few bruchettes, and one entree to share. Not too expensive unless you add a bottle of their very extensive and intimidating wine list. I am not well versed in wine culture, so getting an iPad with categories by country and state was just another layer of confusion. But if you are into that, will be great.

Last thing, having a TV near the seats we had threw me off. I know it is a lunch place too, but for dinner felt strange. Was a little distracted from my date with the Final Four on. I would go again.
author: CJ B.

description: My visit was a bit of a disaster but it ended on a high note. I'm a vegan. I made sure the waiter knew this. He kindly suggested a couple of pasta options. I went with the gluten-free corn dish without cheese. Guess what happened? Even though meat is not even listed for this dish, it had crumbles upon crumbles of sausage throughout the dish. Return! I guess the cook didn't clean the saute pan well enough or something. It was a happy mistake though. If you don't have a gluten allergy, go with the kale pesto dish. It is one of my favorite dishes now. It takes a while to cook so it was inconvenient in my circumstance, but if they get it right the first time, it's not so bad. As for the gluten dish, i found it a bit dry and boring. And yes, they comped my meal so I didn't pay for it.
author: Shannon D.

description: My co-workers love this place so I've gone 3 or 4 times but I just don't. The bologna lasagna is really good but the rest of their pasta options were pretty mediocre.
author: Jordan S.

description: Just a really cool spot for a business meeting with a client or a business partner. A cool spot for dates too as long as your girl is proper lol! Great environment in FD.
author: Sunny s.

description:
Summary - Great "foodie" value!  Solid 4 starts
Started with pork stuff green olives, small portion was perfect.
Our rucola and radicchio parmigaino reggaino salad had perfectly balanced favors and was very natural (aka not over dressed).  The large was too much for two, split the small next time.
Wow, the lasagna bolognese was our favorite, with great flavors but don't expect any tomato/red sauce in this dish, it's all meat and cheese, but you do get a little white sauce to offset the rich, dense serving.
I liked the braised chicken thighs better than my partner, but order that if you love dark meat (duh) and delicate flavors (it's not very strong).
Probably the only downside is that you will likely sit at a shared/communal table, so be prepared to hear what they are taking about and they will hear your conversation.  Next time, I will have a party of six so I can fill the table.
author: Jas S.

description:
An unplanned trip took us to this restaurant and no regrets here.

Restaurant is in the Financial District so customers are dressy to casual. The restaurant modern in decor.

An iPad is available for perusing the wine selection.

Tried the Duck Pate Bruschetta - the pate was very creamy and delicious with no bitter notes. The caramelized balsamic onions goes so well with the pate.

Paccheri, or Park Ragu was very hearthy. The pork consistency is similar to pulled prok, the sauce it was in was amazing.

Mikey tried Lasagna Bolognese - spinach pasta. This was comfort food confirmed on the very first bite. Much better than my Paccheri. Definitely ordering this one next time I'll be in the area.
author: Roger F.

description:
Barbacco [insert sign for greater than as Yelp won't let me] Perbacco! I've tried both places and thought Perbacco was fine, but Barbacco could easily become a favorite! Easy setting, great service, and fun reasonably priced menu of home-cooking" tasting Italian.

Service was fantastic, we went next door for a cocktail (as we learned Barbacco is only wine/beer) as we waited for our table and hostess was so kind as to personally come next door to grab us when it became ready.  Our server was also super sweet and attentive.

Everything on the menu sounded great, and I learned they dedicate a portion of their menu to a different region of Italy each month so there's always new things to try.  We ordered:
--Bruschette ($3/ea) -- you can pick any -- we had the pear & prosciutto and chicken liver pate ones -- both were fantastic.  I love that the bread was piping hot. 
--Brussel sprouts ($5) -- good but VERY fried.  Highly recommended by other yelpers and the staff.  I will admit I'm a bit of a Brussels sprouts connoisseur though, so I've had better
--Pork ragu parmigiano reggiano ($13) -- great juicy and satisfying.  Fresh pasta, fresh tomatoes, tender pork.  Had a very "home cooked" taste which we loved.  
--Flat iron steak tagliata with cherry tomatoes ($18) -- good steak with lots of cherry tomatoes.  Again, simple dish with good ingredients, yums.
--Panna Cotta ($5) -- standard panna cotta, but i did note how affortable their whole dessert menu was.  They had biscotti's for 50 cents!  I appreciate that, you know?

One compliant would have to be the price of beers and wines, including a $6 PBR.  My fiance and I had a giggle reading their description of the cheap staple "easy drinking, smooth, light with hints of malt and hops." Oh you fancy, huh.
author: Kendra W.

description: No idea how this place has so many 4 star ratings. The decor is the only thing this place has going for it. Super crowded and noisy. We had to wait almost 30 minutes to get our appetizers and another 20 minutes for main course. The pasta portion was very small with very poor taste.
author: Michael P.

description:
The brussel sprouts fried in duck fat are AMAZING!!!!!!!!!!!  Got the porchetta sandwich to compete with the roli roti truck - I think roli roti has better meat, but barbacco wins points for caramelized onions (there may be some balsamic vinegar in there, yum!) and roasted grapes.  The sweetness perfectly compliments the juicy, salty pork and asiago cheese.

Good place for an up-scale sandwich if you need a porchetta fix and can't wait until Thurs (and in a line with 50 other hungry people).
author: Judy L.

description:
Lovely, lovely place to go for a intimate date.   The food was exquisite.  Our waiter was super helpful and told us what is exceptional and what is your standard fare.  My boyfriend really really loved the fried olives.  I am not such a crazy olive myself, so I can't judge.  I loved the paccheri with pork rustic ragu.  This is saying a lot.  I don't really eat that much meat.  AND I don't like tomato sauce.  People were psyched about the brussels sprouts, so we got some.  It was way too salty for me because of the anchovies though...

Ohmygoodness.  The chocolate cake.  Or rather.  The chocolate truffle that was shaped like a slice of cake.  Ridiculously incredible.  Flourless chocolate "cake" (so there is no flour to dilute the chocolate) was the perfect way to end the meal.  The butterscotch gelato was pretty fantastic too.

And the price is totally reasonable to boot!
author: Sandy C.

description:
Came in for a late lunch on Friday and generally had a good experience. The place is nice and a fun, busy lunch atmosphere.  We sat at the counter which was fine. The food was solid- I had the porchetta sandwich which was great. Good ratio of bread to meat to vegetables and came with some pickled carrots and arugula salad on the side. 

I'd have to give three stars because the food wasn't amazing and the service was less than stellar. It was hard to get our servers attention even though he kept walking right past us.
author: Lisa C.

description:
If there be one place I could eat regularly (and not feel compelled to gorge myself) it would be Barbacco. A casual but cosmopolitan feel, this little sister of Perbacco wins the day. Only one small problem: we ALWAYS order too much. The menu of small snacks and portions is far too tempting to order any less. 

The ascalone (fried olives stuffed with pork) are a non-negotiable, especially for a salt lover such as myself. Crispy, with a slightly vinegary bite, these are treats to behold. Small order is plenty for two. 

'ndjua is a spicy, spreadable salami that has salt, smokiness and spice. The texture is meaty and thick. Also a must try. 

Have tried a couple of the bruschettes and I could take or, more likely, leave these. Nothing has impressed. They used to have one made with baccala, which was a bit fishy and not that great an addition. Also, the bread portion of the bruschette is filling, so you should consider this when ordering.

As for pasta- order the 1/2 portion for 2, lest you get overwhelmed. The paccheri (pork ragu and parmigiano reggiano) is a winner. It is indeed rustic, pasta perfectly al dente, pork tender and parmigiano sharp. 

The brussels sprouts (fried with a red wine reduction) are delectable and balance the saltiness of the other courses. 

Wine list on an iPad, which is cool. Plus, service is almost always spot on. Two people can dine and drink (note no hard liquor) here for around $80 including a 20% tip for the very fine staff. One of the best in the City. Cheers.
author: Jenni D.

description: The ipads are so cool! The appetizers are very interesting.  I liked the duck liver and brussel sprouts.  Service staff is pretty friendly.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
Duck salad was amazing!  Pastas were average.
The counter and communal seating wasn't good. I don't typically mind sharing space, but it really is crammed and uncomfortable.
iPad concept is not so hot.  I LOVE my iPad, but the organization of the information on the iPad at Barbacco was difficult to process.
Overall: Liked it, but didn't love it.
author: A A.

description: Ate there about a month ago, with a group of 8. Good service, good food. Despite the positive reviews on Yelp, am not a big fan of the brussel sprouts. Rest was yummy though!
author: Aim M.

description:
And review #200 goes to what is now one of my favoritest spots in SF. My friend had been to Barbacco and told me all about it, and I had to go.

Cool enough ambiance, good service, amazing food and wine, and it's not cheap but not overpriced either. The iPad wine list thing was cool but not really more helpful than a printed wine list. I guess it made it a little more fun to order wine.

We ordered the fried olives stuffed with pork, which were fucking AWESOME! I love fried olives, and stuff olives, and I'd had fried olives stuffed with cheese but never with pork. This was amazing, I highly recommend it. I also recommend the focaccia, because it's only $1 and it's pretty much perfect. It's a little crunchy but not annoyingly so on the outside, soft on the inside, and they brush it with olive oil. So good!

Also got 3 types of bruschette - duck liver pate/balsamic onion marmalade and two other types I can't remember. All three were delicious, and I like that they offered some pretty creative takes on bruschetta.

Rounding out the order were meatballs and fried brussel sprouts. And again, both were incredible.

We also had two bottles of wine, both of which were very good and pretty reasonably priced for this kind of restaurant. The staff were helpful in selecting bottles and we got nicely buzzed and plenty full.

I think we ended up spending $76 each, which for an awesome meal with two bottles of wine ain't so bad. We may have ordered some other food that I forgot about (thanks to the two bottles of wine).

Will definitely be back at some point.
author: Joseph N.

description:
3.5 stars. 

The pasta itself is delicious but taste wise, I think Barbacco is just "good." It has a really cozy atmosphere that I like, but I find the menu too heavy with tomato sauce. If you're really into the tomato, you'll probably like this place. Some popular items like the brussels sprouts and meatballs are overhyped IMO--the sprouts are typically too burnt (as in BLACK) and the meatballs are just meatballs in tomato sauce.

The lamb and pork ragus are my favorite here.
author: Nicole L.

description: I visited Barcacco for the first time after the manager at Perbacco told me how good the restaurant was. He told me that the restaurant had won several awards and even had one of the most popular dishes featured on the newspaper. Since I love Italian food I decided to give it a try. Prices are reasonable, I dare to say that are quite good given the quality of the food. I sat at the bar for a quick lunch and I could see the restaurant getting packed in less than 15 minutes. By 12 pm there was no room left and people were waiting to get a table. I had assorted olives for appetizer and for main course I had the Orechiette with sausage, pesto and kale and it was good, rustic, flavorful. The size of the dish was quite generous so I had no room for dessert. Service was not the best and I felt rushed. I had probably stayed longer to get some coffee and maybe a glass of wine after my lunch but I felt I was a nuisance.  I wonder if the reason is that they needed the seats for other guests that were waiting outside. I'll be back, probably after the rush hour so that I am treated in a better way because the food at Barbacco deserves another chance.
author: Danny G.

description:
Came here for lunch and it was a good meal. Prices are definitely reasonable for being in the FiDi for lunch. They have take out too! 

The reason I gave it three stars was because I didn't have anything that I feel the need to come back for. 

We started off with the bruschette with cherry tomatoes. Good but not great. 

Had the hearts of romaine salad with anchiovy dressing. Delish! The salad was really fresh and it was dressed nicely. 

Tried the roasted lamb shoulder sandwich. It was really good. The lamb was cooked nicely and actually crunchy which was pretty surprising. But it was a sandwich that didn't impress me that much. 

Although I do want to go back to try about their pastas and their famous meatballs... so maybe I'll give it more stars next time around, but for now, it's just A-OK.
author: Jeannie L.

description:
I was disappointed.
I went on a busy Friday. OMG did you say busy?
I had reservation for 9. I think we (and 15 other people) got seated 30 minutes later.
They provide you with fancy Ipads to go over their wine menu. Oh la la sounds awesome. Unfortunately you cannot order from them so ... you still have to catch the attention of a waiter and believe his promise that you'll get your drink shortly (you won't). Warning they do not have a full bar.

The atmosphere was good. Lively, nice decor, young crowd. You want to have fun.
The food was good, not amazing but above average I'd say.

If the service was better, it'd definitely be a 4 star.
It could potentially be a date spot if you can be seated at a 2 person table and if you don't have to wait foreveeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeee .... eeeeeer.
author: Marc L.

description:
The pork sandwich and pasta dishes are excellent here.  BUT, the best thing on the menu (for my money) is the fried polenta appetizer.  Buttery and crispy goodness.  

The only thing that keeps this place from being five stars in my book is that it gets quite crowded during lunch.  It's in the FiDi, so that's no fault of the restaurant itself but  it still detracts from the experience.   All of the staff were professional and friendly.  I hope to try their upscale sister restaurant some day.
author: Mike D.

description:
As the daughter of an Italian-born mother who was a wonderful cook, I'm often disappointed with the fare offered by Italian restaurants in the U.S.  Barbacco proved to be an unexpected and delicious surprise.  There re several menu items nodding to the southernmost part of Italy and my Mom's birthplace, Calabria, that included 'nduja, a spicy sausage inspired by the French andouille.  Try the calamari stuffed with 'nduja for a sassy version of surf and turf.  Babacco's Paccheri dish - large pasta tubes dressed with a tender pork shoulder ragu - is one of the best dishes I've had in a long while, even considering all my trips back to the homeland.  

The lunch menu prices are reasonable, especially given the food quality.  I've spent $10- 12 for a salad made by the many gourmet, organic to-go restaurants south of Market, and for the same price or maybe a couple dollars more I can get a hot, soul-comforting dish that will satisfy me through the early evening.  If you don't have time to sit down for lunch, Barbacco offers a great take-out menu.  Me?  I'm heading back for the Paccheri...
author: Allegra C.

description:
Ok. I want to like the food here. It's close to work, pretty swank, nice staff and the menu has things that sound enticing.

However, I have been here three times now, and each time the dish I had was incredibly, unnecessarily, off-puttingly, adverse-adverbially fatty. And, as my Freshman year English teacher (who moonlighted as a romance novelist) taught me, THREE TREES MAKE A ROW. This is a Barbacco motif. And it's kinda nast.

It might be because butter was a verboten item in my Dipsea running A-type (jew fro donning) father's house, but this little rant is coming from someone who secretly enjoys the fact that food vendors put in too much butter, cheese, oil, what have you.


And despite my being a fan of food items entitled "Butter-Brezel," the 3 dishes I've had at Barbacco just scream compensatory. As in,"we are unsure about the flavors standing on their own, so let's douse these shrimps in mayo, and call it aoli!" Or, "no one will like our brussel sprouts unless they're in a puddle of oil!"

In other words, this is a case of Epicurean Inadequacy. And like Sue Sylvester, there's nothing I dislike more than inadequacy.
Especially when it's in my mouth.


That's what she said. (oh!)


In all earnestness, for a place with the point of purchase fixings of fine midday dining, I am disappointed. Quit trying to make me like you with fat, Barbacco.  It's cheap and unbecoming. Let the dishes namesakes' do the job, and you'll do great, because everything else is all there--including Ipads and arugula!
author: Gladie H.

description: Barbacco provides pretty good food at a reasonable price point (which is kind of asking for a lot in this area). Nothing really stands out, but it is good. I did like the brussel sprouts quite a bit. Overall, not a bad place to grab a bite with a friend, but not really a place that I would be excited to go to again. The beer menu offered lots of interesting, local brews so there is that.
author: Wendy S.

description: The food was good and there are some unique menu items. The communal seating works for the atmosphere of the place, and the prices are very reasonable. Our server was attentive and friendly. I recommend the brussel sprouts appetizer and while I only had a salad (which was good but it's hard to be floored by salad, damn you [healthy lifestyle choice]!), my friends raved about the sandwiches they had ordered. I will be back!
author: Nikki P.

description:
Holy Hannah!  This place is GOOD. Lunch with a friend... they sat us and the sun was hitting my ey, so they moved us, which was a good idea.

Service was great. Hostess very accomodating, waiter was on the spot. 

Ipad for the drink list. First time or me, kinda dug it.

Atmosphere was urban, happening, tre cool.

Had the Butcher's salad and... love me do. Nice n flavorful salames, chees, peppers... Couldn't have been tastier... Friend had mozzarelli de buffalo... looked delish and he absorbed it swiftly.

Me had the Paccheri w/rustic pork ragu (which I learned means country pig sauce)... wonderful. Friend had mushroom risotto... looked fabulous. He gave me a taste and I would get that next time. The Flava, y'all! The folks at the next table were jealous ogf the risotto, they told us afterwards. The aroma of their broccoli rabe and fried brussell sprouts were wafting over and I was this close t ordering a plate of that my damn self.

Just great.
author: Tom M.

description:
I came here after work with some of my coworkers to grab a glass of wine and some food. I didn't get a chance to try the food because I was actually going somewhere after this so I only had a glass of wine. I took a star away because I can only rate this place by service and the wine.  I took away a star because the hostess hesitated in  seating us, but our sever was very helpful. 

Another thing that I really like was how we were able to order a 3oz. glass of wine, perfect for me since I was in a hurry can couldn't stay long.

I'm sure I will give it an extra star the next time I go.
author: Angela T.

description:
Barbacco, do you have some sort of contract with Apple? Does Steve Jobs frequent the restaurant? Do you want me to frown every time I come in here because you have all the iPads and I don't have a single iPad? Can I buy one off you? 

Well, like other people mentioned already, that's the first thing I noticed - the iPad drink menu but a paper food menu? Anyway, I came prepared and knew exactly what I wanted when I sat down at my shared counter height table. 

I ordered meat, meat, meat and meat. Not even intentionally but it just popped out. Salumi platter, duck liver pate, meatballs and pork sandwich. Wow. Call me a meatatarian. Our server was really fabulous and attentive and of course said we ordered all the good stuff. Our glasses were always full too. 

On to the meat: first dish was the duck liver pate - phenomenal. The bread underneath was okay - a little hard, but oh I probably could have licked the plate.  Second dish - Salumi platter.  Eh.  I don't think I'll be eating it for a really long time.  Whatever made me think I would like a whole salumi platter when I don't even like a salami sandwich?  Who knows.  I would not get it again.  

Main dishes - meatballs - three large meatballs on top of veggies and stuffed with delicious raisins inside.  Yum.  Slow-roasted pork shoulder porchetta sandwich - well definitely not what I expected.  I thought it was good but it was all pork belly fat.  Just call it a pork belly sandwich please.  I felt really fat after eating it.  A tip - if you get the pork sandwich, eat it before other things.  The meatball was so flavorful that I couldn't taste the sandwich after I had the meatball.  

Finally, the best part - dessert.  I had to ask the friendly waiter what torrone was because if I were smart I would have known.  Pistachio gelato and orange zest.  Wow.  I love pistachio gelato for some reason and this one was really good.  Perfect flavor with actual pistachio nuts crushed around it.  The perfect bite - pistachio and once it's done, you taste the orange - just a hint, not too much.  They got that right. 

Steve Jobs, er Barbacco, you get four stars because you had me at pate and ending on a gelato high.
author: Stacey C.

description:
This is a good option in FiDi but recently this place has become iPad nation.

Check-in with the hostess and get an iPad while you wait to determine wine choices.  Nice, but unnecessary since I still have to talk to the wait staff to order anything.  We also start to wonder how many of these iPads have disappeared from the restaurant?

We sit down at the bar to enjoy dinner and the first thing they do is drop another iPad in our laps.  Instructions - Look over the wine selection and let us know what you want.  Again, this is helpful but it still requires talking to someone and it is a bit impersonal.  It would really be slick if you could notify wait staff via the iPad that you are ready to order and someone would come by.

It takes forever to order anything at the bar now since they only have one bartender and one support person to help 16+ people.  I think they outsourced their bar staff to purchase all the iPads.

The food is great as usual but they need to figure out how to integrate iPads into the dining experience.  It seems like someone told them if they just have iPads people will come but they forgot to mention that people don't like to wait 20 minutes to order.

We enjoyed the food and wine but they need to get this worked out.
author: James B.

description:
I highly recommend Barbacco....Its a great way to upscale your DAAM date (dinner and a movie).  Why go to Fuzio after the Embarcadero Cinema, when Barbacco is just a block away!?

The small plates are consistently delicious and very reasonably priced.  We've been a couple of times now and the service was excellent both times.  Especially fun to experiment with the bruschetta sampler.  Best yet was the whipped sweet pea bruschetta!  I'm hoping that comes back again this summer.

I'm not particularly a fan of the i-pad wine list gimmick or the TV on the wall.  Other than that, the design (Cass Calder Smith) is hip and modern.  New York Style modern with slick fittings and a very long dining counter.
author: Jason M.

description:
Wow! What an incredible experience.
I went to Barbacco with some friends for dinner last night and was blown away by both the service and food.
We tried the pear + prosciutto bruschetta (nice sized pieces of rustic, toasted bread with slices of pear, covered with prosciutto), the Orecchiete pasta (yummy, though a little too kale-like for me), and Chitarra pasta with meatballs (NOMMM!)
What really made the experience memorable was the service. I made a reservation for 8p, but the table before us was delaying their exit. The hostess graciously offered us almonds while we waited (slightly spicy, salty amazing), and let me try a few wines before deciding on two half glasses of some fancy spicy red Italian wines (loved that I could have both for the price of one!)
Our waiter was incredibly knowledgeable about everything on the menu and knew exactly how to help me order (I get order fright). He was attentive, friendly, and seemed to truly enjoy serving us.
We will certainly be back. Hopefully next time I'll have enough room to try their desserts!
author: Gloria C.

description:
Kudos to Barbacco for being open until 3pm for lunch. Most places close by 2-2:30 and I was desperate for a location to eat with my friend in town I hadn't seen in 8 years! We slipped in at 2:55 pm and quickly ordered from the lunch menu:

-Lasagna: YUM YUM
-Brussel sprouts: YUM YUM
-Sicilian meat balls: YUM
-Squid: OK
-Potato leek soup: Good
-Nus: Good

The wine and beer selections were great! All the food had a spice to it and was delicious.

Would come back to try the dinner menu!

Food + drinks for 3 = $57.
author: Jeanne C.

description:
I liked it. We came for dinner last night and I dug the vibe. It's casual, trendy, and in a great location for after-work drinks/dinner in the Financial District. 

What we ate:
* lasagna Bolognese - spinach pasta / meat ragu / balsamella sauce
* bruschette - roasted peach / basil / prosciutto di parma
* daily fish special - petrole sole / squash / cherry tomatoes
* wine - Cantine Barbera-2009 Nero d'Avola, Sicili

We enjoyed them all, but my favorite was definitely the petrole sole: sooo delicious, very light, seasoned perfectly, and paired well with healthy veggies!

The cool stuff:
* The drink menu and daily specials are viewed on an iPad. Very appealing to Bay Area geeks.
* The menu has a lot of options, perfect for someone wanting to sample a variety of foods.
* There are 6 different kinds of bruschette. I just thought that was really cool.
* Food prices are affordable - most items are under $15. 
* Awesome location downtown - right on California St.

The uncool stuff:
* Drink prices are on the higher end. Our wine could be found elsewhere for almost half.
* The chef behind the bar wiped her nose and then immediately touched the food. ugh.

Even though that last part grossed me out, it can be easily corrected, so I will overlook it and still come back. Everything else about the experience was definitely worth the visit.
author: Cherry M.

description:
One of the rare occasions where bad service unfortunately overcomes good food.  After reading the good Yelp reviews, a friend and I decided to make a reservation at Barbacco for her birthday dinner.

The service at first was very attentive, but it became somewhat oppressive after we ordered.  People tried to bus our plates, with significant amounts of food on them, basically every 3-5 minutes.  The hostesses would stare at our table, talk with our waiter while staring at our table, and then he would just happen to pop over (in between the bussing attempts) to try to clear our plates or ask if we had plans later.  

The food (which is great) might have outweighed all of the bad service if it were not my friend's birthday.  When we first arrived, we mentioned her birthday to our waiter and he very graciously offered us each a free glass of wine.  But by the end of the night, we were left feeling fairly offended by all of the not-so-subtle interruptions, instead of enjoying her birthday dinner.  

Two final notes: first, I waitressed for years, at different types of restaurants with different clientele - I understand that it's natural to want to turn over as many tables as possible, both for the restaurant and the staff.  But it's also important for people to leave a restaurant wanting to come back/recommend it to their friends.   Second, I generally only leave a Yelp review for a restaurant  when they have done such an amazing job that I feel compelled to share their awesomeness with the world.  But the bad service here left me so dismayed (admittedly perhaps because I was expecting care-free birthday celebrations) that I have now spent entirely too much time writing this review.  bah.
author: Jessica O.

description:
Italian food is great especially when it's fresh! We decided to bring our friend who was visiting from SD to this restaurant and she loved it! The mushroom risotto (with farro) is especially amazing! I ordered the Lasagna Bolognese which was great if you're the mood for lasagna. My other friend ordered the Meat Ragu/balsamella sauce which also look great and pretty.

They have an assortment of different bruschette which are pretty good as well! 

The menu is pretty focused and gets updated to reflect the ingredients that are in season. Overall whatever you decide to order that reflects your personal taste will be satisfying to the taste buds!
author: Christina M.

description:
Nice wine selection, great location (near my office!!), the service rocks.  May a res, or they may be a short wait.

I love the pork sandwich and mozzarrella salad for lu
author: Michael J.

description:
Barbacco is so good! The dates stuffed with bacon in a red
Sauce was seriously bomb diggity. I cant stop thinking about
It! The service was outstanding. Love this place
author: Noelle R.

description: Nice restaurant in financial district for a quick dinner. I came here with the bf and was promptly seated. We got the Brussels sprouts, spicy meatballs chittara, and the pork ragu. Everything was tasty, but pretty salty. The Brussels sprouts were crispy, but tasted like they were soaked in vbalsamic vinaigrette salad dressing. Not necessarily a bad thing, but after eating 6-7 pieces I was kind of over it. The pasta had great texture and the meatballs were really good. I def would recommend the chittara. Overall, good first experience.
author: Jackie M.

description:
I definitely wasn't having a good night.  Until I set foot in Barbacco.  

After a disastrous haircut (Thanks, Ringolevio!) I wasn't in the best of mood and was considering heading home and trying to figure out a Plan B as it relates to the haircut.  The only thing that stopped me from going was a dinner date with a globetrottin-girl friend with whom I have not been spending quality time with.  

At her suggestion, we went to Barbacco.  I love the wine selection and I have to admit (grudgingly) that while I find the whole iPad thing quite tacky, it allows the sorting and searching of my favorite wines.  I settled for a crisp pinot gris and my girl friend, a sweet riesling. 

We were seated at the bar (good: we get to chat with our lovely server.  bad: a lack of personal space) and after mulling over the chilled wine for a short while, we started perusing the menu. 

It sure was an array of tongue twister.  We relied on our server's recommendation and were shortly presented with an array of food:
1) Bruchette with ricotta, basil, caramelized onion and tomatoes:  
2) Paccheri  parmigiano reggiano  - rustic pork ragu and parmesan cheese
3) Farrotto / farro risotto with mushroom
4) Patate in padella (literal translation: potato casseroles) - pan roasted fingerling potatoes with nduja (spicy Calabrese sausage) bits and caramelized onion
5) fennel-rubbed pork ribs with shaved fennel salad and roasted lemon

I certainly appreciated the smaller serving - it allowed us to sample different kinds of dishes.  

Verdict: I would come back and order the exact same dishes (finally! Potatoes that can give Los Gatos Cafe's breakfast potatoes the run for their money!), with the exception of the pork ribs which were a tad salty. We definitely ordered one dish too many, for the two of us - we took some of the food home - but, everything else was nothing short of phenomenal and, according to the server, the two of us managed to do a respectable job. 

As I was driving home I realized that the night hasn't really turned out to be a total bust.  Now if only I didn't have to think about my botched hair job.
author: Ange L.

description:
This has got to be one of my top 10 places in SF because the food is enjoyable and unique; the staff is friendly; the decor is clean and most of all the prices are reasonable!

Unique ingredients and combinations.
Portions are not Americanized.
Yummy.
author: Cathy U.

description: Wonderful service and food! A fantastic preparation of handmade Italian dishes. I was pleasantly surprised at the robust taste and quality. The gelato was mind blowing!!!! I wanted to order two more.
author: Joe L.

description:
I have been here a number of times and it's always enjoyable. The service is excellent whether you sit at the bar or at a table. Most recently, my dining companion and I had: 
- Deep fried olives stuffed with pork: So delicious. It's well composed and fun to eat. 
- Salumi platter with fruit: Four different kinds of salumi with bread sticks and crostini and pickles carrots and cauliflower. The fruit were peaches with just a hit of pepper. Yummy. 
- Oreccheti special with spinash and sausage. Delicious. 
- Pasta with lamb and mint. My dining companion raved about this. 

We also had a quarto of my favorite sparkling wine, which I can only find here: Donati Il Mio Malvasio. It's like beer and wine had a baby. My dining companion got the NPA flight, which he likes. I had a glass of another red wine, which I also enjoyed. 

The blond woman who works the bar is by far one of the top servers I've ever had at a restaurant. She remembers me and knows what I like. EVEN BETTER, when I walked out of the restaurant without my bag of leftovers, she ran down the block to give it to me. 

Now THAT'S service.
author: Anne M.

description: Farrotto was very plain and flavourless but wine and cheese was really nice and good service.
author: Simon H.

description: Place is a great lunch spot for the $$. Lots to chose from and everything is cooked to perfection. The meatballs are my favorite.
author: Samantha W.

description:
Overall great food!  We had a bunch of little plates and they were all amazing.  The bruschetta with peach was yummy, the burata was different but loved it!  The fried risotto was pretty darn good as well.  

The main dishes, lasagne and the other pasta dish with lamb I think was hearty and satisfying, but not the best that I've had.  

The brussel sprouts I actually wasn't impressed with, and the fried polenta was ok as well.  

Anyhow, it was a cute restaurant with new gadgets that adds to its appeal.  The iPads probably could've been utilized more, as more than drink menus, etc, but it was still neat enough to be a plus to the restaurant.  

Definitely would head back!
author: Tiffany H.

description:
I've been here a bunch of times and it's always delicious. 

MUST order (to share):
1) 'nduja (just ask for more crostini if you run out)
2) brussels sprouts

Note: the pasta dishes are prepared al dente -- which I love!

Definitely one of my favorite (nicer) lunch time spots in the FiDi!
author: Priscilla T.

description: Date night with Hubby.  We sat at the bar.  The iPad wine menu was a little distracting though and not that easy to navigate.
