The Sommelier was very nice and gave us recommendations of what wines we should drink according to our food and our preferences.  The food was just as good as Perbacco if not better.  I will be back :)
author: Jennifer H.

description:
LOVE Barbacco...reasonably priced.  Good place for lunch or a night out. Conveniently located.  

Most importantly, unpretentious on the atmosphere but uncompromising on the food.  

Favorite item:  "little ears"
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
Pure deliciousness! The food is just bursting with flavor and quality.  The list of things we tried:
Liver pate, squid, Pesce Crudo plate, Brussel sprouts

Each bite was more delicious than the last. 

The service was amazing! from the host, to the lovely guys that served us wine and food...affable, efficient, professional, with a smile and a sense of humor. 

I would have liked a few more CA wine options but it is an Italian place after all...I was able to taste a few before settling on a Nero D'avola which was lovely and carried me through my whole meal perfectly.

The price is just right for what you get: great food, great service, great wine...I will be back soon.
author: Nilu r.

description:
LOOOOOOOOOOOVE this place!  Eat here all the time.

The menu is always yummy & changes with what's in season.  Price point is just right.  Lovely wine list.  I don't know how, but they have the best chocolate chip cookies I have ever, ever had in my life.

I won't bore everyone with the details, but the management bent waaaay over backwards to accommodate an odd request for my group.... these guys are just awesome and really care about their work and their guests. 

counting the days til the summer menu with heirloom tomatoes.....
author: Renee B.

description:
We had a reservation on a Friday at 7:30 pm and were seated promptly.  However, we got an odd table facing the entrance, but the glass barrier did a good job of protecting us from the cold every time the door opened.

The food is fantastic!  I love the idea of being able to share and sample small plates.  The menu is a little bit hard to decipher, but they have a glossary on the back.

We loved the cheeses and and duck liver pate bruschette.  I'm not a big fan of lasagna, but their lasagna bolognese was outstanding!  Nothing we ordered disappointed us.

Service was a little slow and our waitress could've been friendlier, but Barbacco still gets 5 stars because the food was nothing short of amazing.  The space is small, modern and lively.  I suggest making a reservation.  We saw a party of four without one wait an hour before being seated.
author: K V.

description:
Hey! This place is pretty dang good, and not a bad deal for such a classy environment! 

I'll be honest, they tricked me into eating Pesto by having a menu that was pretty tough to 1) focus on and 2) understand. But I didn't even mind eating the pesto - it was paired with some great pasta, sausage and cheese! 

I also recommend you buy the bread. It's only $1 and well worth it! 

What would make this place even more spectacular? The ability to view the menu on their iPad app. I know their wine list is uber long and the iPad helps customers gauge the selection, but I was so unfamiliar with their menu that I would have really enjoyed seeing photos and descriptions off paper!
author: Andrew C.

description:
Was here with some fabulous ladies and I have never in my life been "shushed" by the staff. Wow. If I wanted treatment like this, I would have stayed at my parents place. Never going to a FiDi venue.  Sticking to the Mission. No wonder they have all the hot spots. 

________________________________
author: Hana K.

description: The food was absolutely fantastic.  The dishes were tasty and creative and I just couldn't get enough (we shared a few different dishes).  The wine recommendations were perfect.  Overall, we very were pleased with the service and the venue.
author: Alyssa L.

description: Came here for lunch with a friend and good thing we made a reservation because it was already packed, even though we got there before noon. We shared the salumi platter, which was excellent. I liked the breadsticks and pickled veggies that came with the meat. Next, I had the oricchette and he had the pork ragu pasta. I loved my pasta, which was plentiful and cooked just right with greens, a bit of sausage and lots of olive oil and pecorino on top. His pasta was a little hard and not that special - just a red sauce with shredded pork. He admitted that it was disappointing. To finish, we shared an affogato, which isn't on the menu but the staff accommodated our request. A little pricey, but I think the quality is there. I definitely left full and happy!
author: Bella L.

description:
When I get a feeling for Italian food, I come here.

The menu is extensive and in Italian, so ask a lot of questions or you might end up with something you won't enjoy.

That said:

The pate with crostini has always been delicious.

Last time I went they were stuffing squid with their 'nduja, which was basically heaven on Earth in my mouth.

The iPad concept might not be fully realized, but it's neat nonetheless.
author: Shawn C.

description:
Easily the best Italian food in the city, together with sister restaurant Perbacco. Great wine list, albeit a bit pricey. They have the best arancini you can get anywhere, the spinach lasagna was also the best you can get for the price and portion (which was huge). My favorite dish was the Milanese which is a breaded pork cutlet with caper and lemon butter served with arugula salad with parmesan shavings. It was a big portion and absolutely delicious! 
Atmosphere is Financial District meets NYC, but the servers are so friendly and casual that it ends up being a warm and relaxing spot.
author: Chris D.

description:
Ah, the salty sister of Perbacco. Having had dinner and lunch here, 90% the 12+ dishes I've tried have been doused in salt! Funny, since I'm the girl who's not afraid to ask for a salt grinder at a fine restaurant.  

Aside from being overly salty, the flavors are pretty complex and powerful.  For lunch, I love ordering a spread of small dishes- it's like creating your own mini buffet.  Like Barbacco, pretty big wine list.  However, I'd go to Perbacco to create my mini buffet over Barbacco any day.
author: Hannah W.

description:
Very nice, from start to finish. 

Efficient, attentive service, even at the height of a very busy weekday lunch hour.

Terrific food. I had the brussels sprouts (fried in duck fat, mmm mmm mmm, with capers, anchovy and red wine vinaigrette. Not your grandmother's brussels sprouts. Well, not MY grandmother's anyway) and the paccheri (a rustic pork ragu) and a limonata. My dining companion had soup and lasagne.

Very reasonable prices, especially for generous portions of well prepared food from a menu that was out of the ordinary. Total for 2 people, including tax, tip and health care surcharge was about 51 dollars.

Also: Attractive setting. Comfortable seating at the bar. Normally, being so short (think Bernadette on "Big Bang Theory"), I would prefer a communal table over bar seating because I practically have to get out a step-stool to clamber up on the stool, only to have my legs dangle as though I were a 6-year-old at an ice cream parlor -- but in this instance, I could tell from the photos on the restaurant website and on Yelp that the bar seating was slightly lower to the ground than you often encounter -- so it was a comfortable height, and you also didn't feel jammed in next to other diners or feel as though you were looking up a chef's nostrils. Whoever planned and designed the layout of the restaurant did a great job, both in terms of attractiveness and functionality.
author: Paula M.

description:
I can tell this is going to be my new Beretta.

And that's definitely a good thing!  Great cheese and meat selection, and the rest of the menu looked fresh and delicious as well.  We only had light apps and wine, however I am looking forward to going back.

I like the less stuffy atmosphere than Perbacco, and the prices are friendlier as well.  The atmosphere of the restaurant is chic yet laid back.  Also, you know the restaurant is going to be cool when they have iPad wine menus.  Ha.

Now if only they were open till 1am!!

Cheers!
author: Genevieve M.

description: Great experience there! So delicious, good and rapid service, nice decor, no wait for a table on a Tuesday at 7pm (I would assume it would be different on a weekend). The dishes satisfied my taste for Italian, but they were original at the same time. They serve their food "family style". We shared the beets starter (my favorite, served on bread with super delicious melting cheese and aragula) and the asparagus starters. I had the some lamb ragu with tomato sauce served on long pasta (my favorite entrée), and we also had really good orecchiette. No room left for dessert; the portions were generous. Very reasonably priced; about 30$ per person (including tips, but no alcohol). Well worth it! I totally recommend this place :)
author: Marie H V.

description:
The Nduja (spreadable salami) was bestowed to this restaurant by some higher being, it is absolutely incredible, I could live on it. Additionally, the Lardo which is thinly sliced nearly translucent fat draped over a crostini and dressed in truffle oil is now one of my favorite dishes in the city.

Go here with people who love food, the salumi is all cured in-house, the wine list is on an ipad, its just a great and easy time.
author: Jordan Reis C.

description:
This review is for the GELATO ONLY! 

I got the mairn lemon, which tastes like it's been sitting in a cardboard box for too long with an off lemon flavor. Despite the friendly and nonjudgmental staff (because I look like all sorts of awkward since I'm traveling) and nice decor, I can't say that I like this gelato all too much. The texture is not there. However, the gelato is a lovely little package shaped like a perfect ball and it's ability to not melt is awesome.
author: Kah L.

description:
My boss and I went there today for a quick lunch. We arrived at 11:40a, no reservations but we were lucky to get a spot at the counter/bar area. 

The bar lady was really nice and attentive. The entire lunch experience was nice and quick. We ordered an appetizer, which was a cold cut plate with bread. Not bad but wasn't crazy about it either. Then I ordered the lasagna and my boss ordered the mushroom risotto. 

My lasagna was OK, not bad and didn't scream for me to love it. I think my boss enjoyed his risotto, he didn't complain. What we did like a lot was the side order of the brussels sprouts. That was delicious! 

I liked the food, but again, nothing so crazy that I loved it. I would definitely recommend this place for a work lunch and make a reservation before heading there.
author: Julie L.

description:
The seating arrangement at Barbacco is interesting. All of the tables are "communal", and so even though my date and I had reservations, we opted for the bar seating so we could have more privacy. Service here is excellent and the waitress that helped us was very informative with explaining the menu. 

The special menu items of the night were a hamachi crudo and a white bass for the fish entree, both of which we ordered and loved. The hamachi crudo melted in your mouth but wasn't heavy even with such a fatty fish and the olive oil. I got the sense that they were taking the best components of the fish and enhancing those flavors, which presented hamachi in a whole new light for me. The olives added that briny sea salt flavor without being in your face, complimenting the fish perfectly, and the blistered tomatoes added a delicate sweetness to a buttery texture. (It helps that I'm partial to hamachi, probably)
The white bass came out and for a minute I was afraid they had overcooked the fish. To my surprise, it was super juicy and seasoned perfectly. I loved that you could really just taste the simplicity of the ingredients in the dish all working together.
We also ordered the mushroom risotto croquette, which was really quite tasty, but I could probably have done without that. 
Lastly we ordered the cavatell pasta made with sausage, prosciutto, and mushrooms. You can really tell the pasta was very fresh and hand-made and cooked perfectly al-dente. The sauce had a nice kick to it and the sausage and prosciutto added a nice smoky depth of flavor. 

Everything was delicious and my date and I thoroughly enjoyed our meal. We will definitely be coming back to try some other specialties.
author: Grace C.

description:
It's the World Cup!!  USA, USA, USA!!  Its that time of the year where we country(wo)men gather in pubs from sea to shining sea to celebrate a pastime sport we don't follow, have never really cared about, and gives us the opportunity to brag about that semester we spent abroad in a country that DOES care about it.  

USA! USA! USA!

What this means for me is that I can show up to the office 30 minutes late and my boss, an alumni of the Wake Forest soccer team, is not in the office from 11-2pm.  I've taken the liberty of trying out some new lunch spots.  

Very, very impressed with Barbacco.  I've dined at neighboring Perbacco and I enjoy the relaxed, snazzy, modern atmosphere of this new sister restaurant.  We enjoyed the Duck Confit salad and the summer squash fondo bruschette.  The spinach duck confit was absolutely superb, with cherries mixed in for awesome flavor.  We easily split the large between 4 people.  The bruschette was unreal too, mainly because the squash was spiced and stewed.  Totally different and extremely savory.  

We all ordered pasta dishes, and I went with the rotolo pasta:  eggplant, ricotta cheese and tomato basil wrapped in round pasta. The combination was zesty and satisfying.  My companions went with the lasagna and the pork ragu.  

I would recommend this Barbacco to anyone looking for a special occasion lunch or even a quick bite, as they have a take out bar readily available.  Pop in here especially if your office's "summer hours" leaves you with some time on your hands :)
author: Kerry D.

description:
I had the opportunity to hang @ Barbacco the other night for happy hour. While I don't drink, the ambiance of this tratorria was divine. The company...even better. 

The great impression started with the i-pad menus...nice. Some of the food choices were new to me but I really enjoyed them--fried olives stuffed with pork, smoked salumi plate, ciccioli cheese with arugula, eggplant bruchette and best of all--spinach lasagne. 

Unfortunately, one huge star deduction for our waiter, Christopher---a rude and condescending downer to the entire experience. Everyone working here was so pleasant, so, he stood out like a thorn on a beautiful rose.  Fortunately, we giggled over it and didn't let it ruin the evening. 

I look forward to visiting again and more of the lasagna next time, no doubt.
author: Virgo M.

description:
Maybe it's because I am a HUGE fan of Perbacco. 

Maybe it's because my expectations were too high.

Maybe it's because I know the value of a full bar.

Maybe it's because the bartenders weren't as friendly as one would like.

Maybe it was because the moon was 3/4 full and I had a bad hair day.

Whatever the reason may have been, this place just didn't knock my socks off! Because of my undeniable love for Perbacco I really wanted Barbacco to make all my hopes and dreams come true.

Forgive me for thinking that an establishment called BARbacco (key word being BAR) would serve booze; so you can imagine my horror upon ordering a Beefeater and Tonic after a rather hectic day and having to settle for sparkling wine. Oy!

We ordered:

1. focaccia / fresh herbs and sea salt: Yummy bread. Fresh, flavorful, delightfully light and soft.

2. duck liver pate / balsamic roasted cherries: This pate was VERY heavy. The pate was a very thick spread and I ended up scraping a lot of it off so that I could better enjoy the flavor without being completely overwhelmed. It was a bit over the top.

3. polpette - Sicilian meatballs with raisins and pine nuts / braised chard tomato sugo: The meatballs were really tasty. Flavorful, decent portion size, great spices used for flavor.

4. fresh summer peas: I LOVE peas, but this dish was covered with a certain spice/herb that totally ruined it for me. It was very cilantro like, but I don't think it was cilantro. The herb was way too heavy handed for my tastes.

Overall I think a bit less exuberance when it comes to adding flavor would do Barbacco well. They use fresh ingredients and I would love the flavor of the actual foods to come through without being overwhelmed by the heavy handed added spices and herbs.

I definitely think I will give Barbacco another chance before abandoning it completely.

Come on Barbacco...I REALLY want to love you, honest!
author: Becky M.

description:
Great wine. Love the iPads. Awesome food. 

Minus one star for the ambiance though. It feels... sterile. And set up like a long diner. I didn't get to feel cozy with my pals sipping good wine and eating good food.
author: Evie D.

description:
They had me at the word: iPad. 

No, seriously! The fact that their drink/wine menu is on an iPad is the awesomest thing ever! Ok ok... So the only reason it's awesome is because it speaks to the Apple fanboy in me; but you have to admit that a place with iPads on the table is not only different, but it can probably only happen in San Francisco (for now).

Oh yeah: the food was awesome, too.
author: Kurt C.

description: Sat at the bar. Congenial bartenders, fast service. (We were in a hurry to get to a concert up the street at Grace Cathedral on Nob Hill- the cable car stop is just outside the door. ) Had a pate and a salad and a delicious Manhattan. Hit the spot!
author: Paula H.

description:
A big group of very good girlfriends found ourselves ambling around downtown with a nice buzz and no reservations so as we walked, we called to see how busy the restaurant was. We were told to come in and waited 10 minutes, at most, before a table was cleared for us. While waiting, we had some fun checking out their wine list on ipads! 

The long tables are made for 8 and we had 9 with us to start. The (manager? owner?) came over and was completely gracious and accommodating (as well as perfectly stylish!) offering several solutions from splitting our table, to spilling into Perbacco next door as space cleared up. She decided to help us in a very unorthodox way by adding an extra seat behind our table. This isn't especially easy to do in a place that maximizes it's space to the Nth degree. The TVs were a little imposing on the ambiance... I would have thought, if I'd actually been here on a date. I suppose they need to keep the world cup playing for the suits coming in on their lunches and happy hours, but maybe they should just be turned off for dinner.

We shared a whole bunch of  bruschettas, cheeses and small plates. I was happy that on the whole, they seemed fresher and less greasy than at many other places that serve the same types of dishes.
Here is a run down of my favorites:
- The little fried fish were much lighter and more delicate in flavor and texture than I had imagined- so delicious!
- Fried brussels sprouts were separated into paper thin flaky leaves, burnt tender crispy and seasoned well.
- The stuffed pasta with eggplant and ricotta portion was huge and had a bright, fresh taste.

I can see why this place gets rave reviews for plates AND service. Not once were we made to feel that we were imposing or ignored, (even though we were large in number, and we're a polite bunch but we can get a little raucous after a couple cocktails,) the food was perfectly paced and cleared, and our needs were very nearly anticipated. Perfection!
author: Nomi G.

description:
The iPad wine list and bar stools made me very wary of this restaurant, but I can't say no to Blackboard Eats when it's 2 blocks from my office.  iPad's aside, I couldn't reach the footrest on the stool (I'm not that short) and while the communal tables were somewhat separated by menu stands, I still learned a lot about the inner workings of Angela and Beth's office.

Risotto croquette just a pork ragu inside a ball of fried risotto.  Good drunk food but not exciting flavors.

The bigeye tuna tartar was fresh, with clean olive oil and a jalapeno chimichurri.  But it was extremely small and undersalted, until I found the garnish of salt around the rim of the plate and not on the food.

The squid was almost as tender as pasta and fresh tasting.  The tomato sauce it was in was extremely sour, and the vinaigrette brussel sprouts out at the same time made it 10 times more sour.  While both were good for the first few bites, as the main portion of our meal, the squid wasn't satisfying.

The bruschetta were satisfying.  We tried 3: the sardines, truffled lardo, and duck pate.  The sardines were rich, not too salty.  At a reasonable price for the small, flavorful bites of well-matched food, the bruschetta are the only thing I would return for.

Especially because after half a carafe of sangria that tasted like fancy fruit punch, I felt nothing but weighed down.
author: Laura S.

description:
It's true what they say about the brussel sprouts.  They were the break-out star of the entire meal.  WOWSA.

Meatballs ruled. Polenta side was great. My tablemates loved the pasta w/lamb ragout and the lasagna.  

Halibut special was tasty but delivered tepid.  Olives stuffed with pork were interesting, but not sure I would get again.  Don't waste your time on cheese plate and almonds - there are much more interesting starters to try.  

I"m pro-ipad winelist.  We had a great time with tastings and tried some very cool white!? wines - highly recommend tasting for something really different.  It's just a taste.  We tried the "grandaddy" Radikon 2004 - liked that over some of the other ones.  It's orange.  Really.  Other nice Italian reds, we liked the Grifola Montepulciano.  

I'd go again.  Soon.
author: amy b.

description:
Came here with the
Hubby last month for drinks and apps. Sat at bar, great atmosphere and very
Flavorful food. Heard the brussell sprouts were to die for, they are a must. Fresh pasta bolognese was yummy and perfect portion size.
author: Jennifer O.

description:
Awesome food!
My boyfriend got the salumi plate and couldn't stop talking about how great it was.
I ordered the Farro Risotto which was beyond amazing. 

Complimentary Sparkling Water and great service! The bartender was super sweet & helpful!
author: Ash R.

description:
Yum!  What an outstanding pre-theater dinner treat.  I've enjoyed few meals lately as much as this one.  First the wine...they have a nice, extensive list with lots of options by the glass.  I like that.  The wine lists are on ipads, which I have to say I find cheesy.  I think I would almost invariably prefer an old-fashioned printed list, especially since it's not that long.  Makes comparisons harder actually.  Nonetheless, I had an excellent Vinera Massi Barberra.

We started with some lovely tasty arancini and a great assortment of bruschetta...the Lonza with roasted grapes was both subtle and mouth-watering.  I could have eaten a whole plate of these.  Sadly, for the main course, they were out of the farro, which is a grain that I love that's hard to find.  Instead we had the orechiette and polpette meatballs.  Both dishes came out very well.  A highlight was the side of brussel sprouts...lots of flavors going on, but it works in the end...with a really lovely crunch texture.  I wish I could make brussel sprouts like that.  Sam M. comes close with his brussel sprouts pizza.

Desserts are actually reasonably priced.  Let me repeat that...DESSERTS ARE REASONABLY PRICED!  So many restaurants think that you'd like to pay $10 for a creme brulee...nope, not here.  The delectable Expresso Panna Cotta is $5 and a lovely butterscotch ice cream is only $2/scoop.  I'd bet if more restaurants had this pricing scheme they'd sell a lot more desserts.

Service was attentive, friendly, and non-intrusive.  The atmosphere was nice, and despite being a small place, the sound level was very modest.  I really liked not having to shoot at my fellow dinner.

Cheers!
author: Ian P.

description:
I went to Barbacco for a business lunch. It was a pretty lively crowd for lunch, so I asked the hostess for a more intimate seating and she obliged.
The decor was contemporary chic, and the use of the ipad was an interesting touch, but we didn't even look at the drink menu.

Food was really tasty, but service was a bit slow, even when we lingered after the lunch crowd. My companion never got the iced tea he ordered, and the menu said that the heirloom tomato salad came with bread, but it didn't?

I'd like to come back here with friends and really sample the menu. It also makes me curious to go to Perbacco
author: Marina K.

description: Despite a 30 minute wait at 730, the food and service made up for it!  The spicy meatballs with brussel sprouts cooked in duck fat (sounds bad, but excellent!), and my lasagna was perfect, small portion, but perfect, coupled with the calamari side...everything was excellent!
author: R J.

description:
After coming here for dinner recently and not being able to order everything I wanted to get (my dining companion held me back), I came back for Round 2 with someone who gives me free reign to order anything and everything I want. Yes, my mommy's awesome :)
 
True to form, I did exactly that. (I love that their menu is printed on their placemats--makes ordering more food so much more convenient!) I avoided repeating the dishes I got last time in order to cover more of the menu, except for 3 items since they were so damn tasty! We got: *takes a deep breath*
 
*BRUSCHETTE (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Wd5ho0_FKk9n7uV8pSCYIg?select=4jy-AJsdOqcmxsW-aoWlkQ):
- CURED SARDINES (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Wd5ho0_FKk9n7uV8pSCYIg?select=xKoxhJJSBtsau4t7oWbZkA): Repeat #1. The sardines had the perfect amount of acidity and the radish provided a nice crunch.
- PEPERONATA (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Wd5ho0_FKk9n7uV8pSCYIg?select=gz8qyEmvt4O05GyTX3bcIQ): Loved the roasted peppers with the creamy ricotta.
- LONZA (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Wd5ho0_FKk9n7uV8pSCYIg?select=O-7zHizqDHFYdg-xSMWZ_g): The roasted grapes were juicy and sweet but completely overwhelmed the flavour of the very thin slice of lonza. It was also hard to eat since the grapes kept falling off =( 
- DUCK LIVER PATE (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Wd5ho0_FKk9n7uV8pSCYIg?select=w35LgziJ7S9h1sivjssrCA): Repeat #2. I loved this so much I ordered 2 so I wouldn't have to share! The rich and flavourful pate is perfectly balanced with the acidity, sweetness, and crunch of the balsamic onion jam.
- CHERRY TOMATOES (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Wd5ho0_FKk9n7uV8pSCYIg?select=WZDyC6K-vqfPs0XCkkjbGA): The tomatoes were sweet but there wasn't enough basil. 
*ZUPPA DI PESCE (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Wd5ho0_FKk9n7uV8pSCYIg?select=owMFdQt-IUc0B84ZlieBpg): Fisherman's soup indeed! This hearty tomato-based soup was loaded with halibut and wasn't too acidic. Loved it!
*ONION & POTATO PASSATO [soup of the day] (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Wd5ho0_FKk9n7uV8pSCYIg?select=2fiwzItzEnhwXW_KuPKSbw): This thick and flavourful purée of onions and potatoes also had a touch of acid that added some brightness. Also loved the crunchy croutons!
*TOMATO & BREAD SOUP (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Wd5ho0_FKk9n7uV8pSCYIg?select=dUpCvze4ryxV3MSBpPlY1A): Was not a fan of the really soggy bread or how acidic it was.
*PAN ROASTED POTATOES (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Wd5ho0_FKk9n7uV8pSCYIg?select=npAs3X90Xjn-9HQomTPe1A): Repeat #3. Perfectly cooked potatoes flavoured with aromatic 'nduja and caramelized onions. Both my taste buds and olfactory receptors were in heaven =)
*FRIED BRUSSEL SPROUTS (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Wd5ho0_FKk9n7uV8pSCYIg?select=L_4I1LEpJWcOOvXvYdjrFQ): Very nicely browned brussel sprouts that weren't bitter at all. Also LOVED the vinaigrette with it. I just wish they weren't so greasy...
*FARROTTO (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Wd5ho0_FKk9n7uV8pSCYIg?select=jEaUPNGsNhJeP2vTA5UcnA): The farro gave this dish more texture--and fiber for a happy digestive system!--than it would have with traditional arborio rice. Great flavours from all the mushrooms and parmigiano reggiano cheese too.
*ORECCHIETTE (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Wd5ho0_FKk9n7uV8pSCYIg?select=V3eXNCB72krwUpurCh3V8w): A little bland and underseasoned. The fennel sausage was delicious but there wasn't enough of it.
*GELATO - torrone & butterscotch-chocolate crunch (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Wd5ho0_FKk9n7uV8pSCYIg?select=oafnws0fwlaNvhe8fJGQ8g): Bland! I could taste the orange zest in the torrone but not the pistachio. The chocolate crunch in the other one was nice but the butterscotch flavour was really weak.
*CHOCOLATE NEMESIS CAKE (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Wd5ho0_FKk9n7uV8pSCYIg?select=ZTOZ6wkVDRMtKISCUxi8tQ): This dense mousse-like cake is the nemesis of waistlines everywhere--way too rich and sweet. Not a fan.
*BAKED APPLE (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Wd5ho0_FKk9n7uV8pSCYIg?select=nu6JAib69Xqbbou-dVsEUg): Meh. The sauce was too sweet and grainy with undissolved sugar crystals. The amaretti filling was bland too.

In summary, I'd come back for the savoury stuff. The desserts just weren't up to par.
author: Steph L.

description: Excellent wine and food. Gets crowded so get there early. Brussel sprouts fried in duck fat are unnaturally good.
author: Eric W.

description: Brussels sprouts fried in duck fat! Well, I would imagine anything fried in duck fat would be delicious, so it's no surprise this item ended up in the Yelp highlights.
author: Vivian D.

description: First off, the service here is nothing short of unbelievable.  When my wife and I had lunch here, the staff was so accommodating and friendly it was enough to bring us back.  We ordered the focaccia and olives as appetizers and they were outstanding.  I had the risotto and my wife had the chicken salad sandwich.  Both were awesome.  I went back later that evening to pick up something to go and the staff remembered my name.  WOW!  I will be back.
author: Peter M.

description:
Visited Barbacco last night with 2 co-workers for drinks and a light bite. 
Busy after work atmosphere that was loud, full of energy but we could still hear each other without a problem. Perfect for a co-worker gathering. 

Everyone at the restaurant was friendly and checked in with us often making sure we didn't need anything. The iPad was a cool feature but I enjoyed asking the sommelier questions. She even poured me a little taste of one thing I wanted to try without a fee. Glad I tried it; I didn't like it and ordered something else. No snobbery involved. 

We ordered the Brussels Sprouts and they live up to the hype. They are fantastic. We shared one order between 3 girls and had plenty but not too much of this leafy green which can be gaseous. 

I ordered the Tuna Bruschetta was alright but a bit bland. The meatballs (3 in an order) were also good but nothing amazing. 

I enjoyed my time at Barbacco and plan to go back when I have time to try some of the larger dishes. They looked great as they passed my table. 

I will also go back because of the service and the staff. Cheers to them. They really do a great job at a busy, popular place.
author: Janell H.

description:
After a day of strip-clubbing, drinking, and avoiding work at all costs, we found ourselves at Barbacco. They have an outstanding wine list with excellent choices at all price points and equally outstanding service. Our server was high on integrity, offering strong opinions and great advice about some Sicilian wines (my homeland!) that we ended up *loving*. Our arancini were better than my aunt Beppa's (don't tell her I said that) and the marinated olives were literally a bucket of olives and served 4 people with room to spare. Crispy on the outside, melt-in-your-mouth on the inside focaccia had me saying bye-bye to Atkins as soon as it hit the table. At around $60 for 4 people, we all left happy and ready to get on with the night. Great deal, great wine, great service, and great snacks. Score.

Love this place. Go here. You will thank me.
author: Autumn K.

description:
Sat nite we were in the city for the weekend-this place was reccomended by a friend of ours...Wow! the food was very affordable and super good!
I loved the polpette and the risotto- the charcuterie was great as well- we had some croquettes and well as the padron peppars....all that plus a good bottle of wine-93 bucks without tip. 
worth every penny and we look forward to visiting again
author: CecilHillcrest W.

description:
I ate here with my friend on my recent trip to San Francisco. All in all we had a good meal. It wasn't crazy fantastic but it was good. 

The one thing that turned me off was that we had reservations yet had to wait 20 minutes to get a table. Can't imagine how long we'd wait if we just walked in.  

We had the olive appetizer, the meatballs, the brussel sprouts, and the fried polenta. Everything was really good. I normally don't like brussel sprouts but these were pretty damn good! And the meatballs were excellent. I also had their mint lemonade - YUM! 

The place was SUPER busy so we had to sit at the bar. Normally this would be ok, but it was really hard to eat at the bar (not much room for all the shared plates). 

Overall: Really good but make a reservation - it gets crazy busy! I would recommend this place but at the same time I've been to better places. 

p.s. They don't have paper menu's - the server will hand you an iPad to go over the menu. WICKED!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Kristina B.

description: Nice little place and one of the few open late in this area. The Brussel sprouts fried in duck fat were excellent. Price was a bargain and service was top notch.
author: James L.

description:
So, I think the difference between a superb restaurant and an okay/good restaurant is that when you eat at a superb restaurant it's not just eating, it's an experience.  

I had take-out for lunch here today because I was tired of the same ol' same ol' lunch experience in the fidi. Can I just tell you that I did the right thing! So what my lunch was $16, I was in heaven! & that's only six dollars more than the standard $10 for mediocre fare....anyways, so I ordered the radicchio and arugula / lemon and olive oil / shaved parmigiano salad & it was delicious. What a starter! I knew that it was love at that moment & that my entree would not be a disappointment! 
& oh my gosh it was not! for my entree i had the farrotto-farro"risotto" / roasted mushrooms / parmigiano; SO GOOD! the flavors just melt in your mouth and are truly dynamic. 

The restaurant itself gives off a little bit of a pretentious vibe, but I just brushed that off. Get ready for some DELICIOUS food!
author: Jenna K.

description:
Very weak/overrated.  

The stuffed pepper appetizer was pretty good, but everything else was pretty forgettable.  

My main concern was how flat and bland the lasagna tasted.  

I actually added a star because of the option for delivery, but i won't order here again.
author: eshwar k.

description:
Barbacco is a cool spot in the Financial District. They have iPads on every table that have the menu and wine list, also a bunch of contact information of random people.... which was a little strange. The food was very good, plus our server was great. We had a vegan situation and the server gave great recommendations on which dishes could still be delicious without cheese. The food was very flavorful and fresh in good sized portions. 
Not my favorite place in the City but I would definitely go back.
author: K Z.

description:
Overall, great food! I tried the Burata, Lasagna & Mushroom Risotto! All delicious, and the price very reasonable. Great wine selection!
Service was great.
Will definetly go back.
author: Sepas K.

description:
I like some of the choices on the menu like the orecchiete with fennel sausage and what I think was rapini. I felt the salads were not that good or well dressed-- they should work on that because I usually only eat salad these days.
Oh, and the service was so-so... I didn't feel like he cared whether I enjoyed the meal and brought the check before we were done eating.
author: Jessica O.

description:
Wow - where do I begin? This place was rockin' on a Thursday night!
Hostess: Fabulous attitude
Food for two:
fried olives
cheese (gorgonzola & cow girl creamery red hawk)
arancini
bruschette
orecchiette
braised chicken thighs
fried Brussels sprouts
Every bite was out of this world, so many flavors!
Service: Excellent
Atmosphere: extremely lively, chic decor
Restrooms: I want a Dyson air blade! lol
Definitely get a reservation, the word is OUT!!
author: Stephanie T.

description:
Although I wish there was a more extensive selection of food - the offerings I tried were great. As advertised, Barbacco is a very wine-centered environment, and it is truly something you would find in San Francisco, with their wine menus accessible on iPads. The setting is fun, and lively. The food came out quick, hot, and well-prepared. Althought they do offer take-out, I would strongly encourage dining in. It is pricier, but the quality is comparable to the price.

I liked their small portion sizes, and the little nibblings certainly filled us up. Favorites of mine would be the fried brussel sprouts, the local squid alla piastr (very well-seasoned), the farroto (farro risotto - interesting take on risotto), and of course, the beet salad. Restaurants would be remiss to not have that on their menu these days. 

The manager Adelino was very hospitable, and gave us such the delightful experience, that we will certainly return for a weekday happy hour, or future dinner outing. Reservations had been made, but since we were a larger party during the famed dinner hour, we had to incur a slight bit of a wait. We felt a bit slighted at first, since some of our party had already arrived and had begun drinking, but like so many institutions in the city that have sister restaurants next door to each other, they did offer to come retrieve us from next door at Perbacco, when our table was ready. We elected to stay and ponder over their unlimited wine offerings, and wine flights (several of which that were very well-priced). Our server was very busy, but made sure that we could sample our bottles before ordering an entire one. 

We especially loved that even though we were not celebrating a special occasion, they made our dinner a memorable one. In my experience, the restaurants that are cognizant of special occasions (in this case, an overdue sorority sister reunion) without us deliberating specifying, are those with the most well-trained staff, that are in tune with diners' wants, can best gauge their food interests, and can pick up on occasions. We appreciate the sampling of desserts! Will come back for the butter scotch-chocolate crunch gelato and chocolate nemesis cake!
author: Tammy H.

description:
Wine selection - fab
Spritz?!?!?!? YES. I haven't had a spritz since I was in Italia and this just hit the spot!!! It was refreshing and delicious, I'd be back just for one more of those!

But, onto the food. The focaccia was good, the polpette were delish and the bruschette were tasty. I wish we had ordered some of the pastas, but was ok to skip for the super yummy Steak Tagliata. Cooked perfectly to my specifications and the asparagus and the poached egg were great sides.

I really enjoyed this spot. The restaurant is gorgeous and the atmosphere is perfetto!!!! Si mangia bene! Love.
author: Francesca F.

description:
Delicious! 

Such a fun place to go to with good friends, but a little on the pricier side if you have a husband who eats like a monster. We came here to celebrate his birthday this past weekend and were seated right away. It helped that we had made reservations for 5:45pm. 

Fun, pish posh environment, but a little awkward if you have to share a table with another set of guests. We were a party of 4 and the table we sat at seated 6, so they told us to keep the 2 end seats open for another party of 2. I felt bad for the 2 guys who sat down next to us because we were laughing and being totally rowdy next to them. 

My favorite dish here was definitely the rustic pork ragu. It was absolutely delicious! The rest of the dishes that we shared together were also really good, but I gotta say that the menu was super hard to read. It had to do with a combination of the layout being difficult and the dish titles being totally foreign. We literally just closed our eyes and pointed at random things to order, lol.
author: Kimberly B.

description:
I was here for my first "power lunch". Okay, it wasn't really a power lunch but it was still work related! We had reservations for 1pm and were seated right about at 1. The placemat menus are a good idea, as is the iPad wine list! I was scared to touch that thing, so I admired it in its stand. We ordered a trio of bruschetta, duck pate, sardine, and tomato. A little too oily for my taste. I know it's olive oil, the "good fat", but still too heavy. They really lay it on thick with the duck pate, if it's your thing, go to town! I ordered the porchetta for an entree. The pork in the porchetta was cooked good. I'm not a die-hard fan of the Roli Roti truck like some people out there but I'll admit, I liked Roli Roti's porchetta a little bit better. I should add that my tastebuds are compromised because I have a cold but I know sucky & yummy food when I eat it.

Service was prompt and polite.
author: Tatiana D.

description:
Solid Italian fare -- had the pork ragu as recommended by the waitress. Flavorful and delicious (though slightly too al dente for my tastes). Fried brussels sprouts were amazing, and the pear ricotta cake really hit the spot too. 

There was a 40-minute wait on a Wednesday at 7, so make reservations if you can. Hostess was really sweet, but waitress seemed annoyed to be serving us all night.
author: Resa W.

description:
Man this place gets packed during lunch! Had an 11:30am reservation here, and it was a full house by 11:45. Note here: Make reservations!

The food here was pretty solid, ordered the focaccia, a sardine crostini, the farro risotto with mushroom, and the polpeti. 

Let me also say, having an ipad at the table, while cool to browse the wine list, is really clumsy and useless as the food actually starts hitting the table.

The food itself was like I said solid, nothing that blew me out of the water, but well executed. The sardine crostini was some local sardines and some egg salad, a good start. The risotto was delicious, creamy with a touch of mushroom and some parmesean. It was a little liquidy for my tastes, and still a shade al-dente, or toothsome as some like to put it.

The polpete. Underwhelming and the reason for this four star review as opposed to five. It's just meatballs. Nothing too special, not a lot of red sauce, some braised kale underneath. Well cooked but nothing to set it apart from the meatballs I might make during the weekend to go with spaghetti if you catch my drift.

All in all, I'd come here again as it was well priced for lunch ($30 with tip included), but please don't get the polpete here even if they tell you they're famous for it.
author: David H.

description:
Barbacco, I love you. Barbacco's sister's restaurant, Perbacco, has a special place in my heart - as it's the place I went the night I got engaged. The menu there is a little pricey to go on a regular basis, so I was counting down the minutes until the opening of Barbacco. Within the first two months it opened, my fiancé and I went about four times - having the same waiter each time and...always ordering the Barbera. 

If you like cheese, please run (not walk) to get the burratta. There are  no words. Creamy, cheap and so good. I've never had arancini before coming here, but I can't step foot in the restaurant without ordering the small fried balls filled  with risotto, cheese and pork. I tried last time to  not order it, but halfway through the meal felt the urge to order it. My fiancé and I shared three of the bruchette  - the caponata, summer squash and crushed spring peas. The summer squash was my favorite by far. I  also recently had the tomato  soup which was not amazing - tasted like pasta sauce. A good pasta sauce...but still pasta sauce.

So why am I giving this place only 4 stars? Last  time I was there sitting at the counter, the chef in front of us preparing the cheese plates and desert was eating constantly off of things she was preparing - very gross. Needless to say, we didn't order desert  or a cheese plate...but I still love this place.
author: Ashley L.

description: I love this restaurant everything is amazing. I love the large wine selection and the bruschetta is yummy. Don't forget to order a latte and biscotti. So delicious.
author: Gabby G.

description:
This is a good place to have a drink and food on a weekend evening if you don't want to pop out of your pants and have your date bitch about how they feel fat.   Don't over order... the portions are reasonable.

We got out of here for 45$ with drinks.  Not bad.  I'd come here again if I were in the area. 

It looks like an old converted Denny's to tell you the truth.  Diner style.
author: D. T.

description: LOVE this place! They give each table an ipad to order drinks on and the ambience is very nice, so beautifully designed and sleek. Seating is a little weird because you share tables with a seat in between, not so intimate. The brussel sprouts are delish though and the chicken pate was really unique. The wine selection is great and the waiters are very knowledgeable. They also have a movie on in the background, this great Italian film which was fun.
author: Anthea L.

description: This is one of our favorite places in the FiDi area.  The ambiance is great, they take reservations, they seat you on time (we went on a week day), their food is super yummy.  You get to order a few different wines if you want to do tastings, and it's a little cheaper than if you were order a full glass of wine.  We ordered their butter squash pasta, the mussels to share, and the parpadelli pasta with ragu.  I would say everything was very flavorful, especially mussels, their broth was to die for.  My Bf said he would just come back for that dish.  They have bread you can order for $1 a pc, which kinda sucks, because I'm a bread lover, so when the Mgr came to ask if we wanted bread to eat with our broth from finishing our mussels dish, we said yes, and the charge was added to our bill.  This place is definitely a date night spot.
author: Amy A.

description:
This place is pretty great. Made a reservation a few weeks in advance for a Friday night (had the blackboard eats coupon). We were seated right away and immediately began playing around with the wine list iPad-style. Pretty awesome. 

Atmosphere is really cool and waitress was super nice, but the place is REALLY loud. Was sitting across from my boyfriend and honestly had to yell to have a conversation. There are small communal tables so we sat next to a group of girls (presumably on a girls' night out) who may or may not have had too much to drink. This could likely happen to you: be forewarned. 

Anyway, we ordered the arancini balls (risotto croquettes) and bruschette with tomatoes and cheese (both super delicious and fresh). Also got a pasta dish with tomatoes and mozzarella- not amazing but good. 

The blackboard eats deal required us to order $30 of food/drinks per person, which we didn't, so the waitress told us and we got some stuff to go. SO nice of her-  the bill came to $61- and we left with some more arancini balls and deliciously rich flourless chocolate cake.
author: Cristina P.

description:
Oh, god. So good! 

Radishes with salt and butter.
Finocchiona salumi.
Quick braised squid -- so tender! -- with tomato, chili and spicy pan grattato.
Chocolate nemesis cake. 

Great service.
author: Todd H.

description:
Came here with a friend a little before they were closing up for lunch. 

For starters, we picked a trio of bruschette that consisted of the house cured sardines, duck liver pate, and smoked lonza which none disappointed. We also had the great tasting soup of the day which was cream asparagus and truffle oil. Wish we got a bowl instead of a cup. 

With such a great start we were excited for what was to come next. We ordered the slow roasted shoulder porchetta and the orecchiette pasta with sausage. To our surprise, both dishes were bland and boring. Very disappointed for what we thought would be the stars. 

To end the meal, we decided on the butterscotch chocolate crunch gelato. I'm not much of a dessert fan but this was awesome. 

Being that the restaurant was clearing up for the closing of lunch, we felt a little uneasy being one of the last customers. Our server reassured us that we were of no inconvenience. This really made us feel welcomed. The price and quality of service you get at Barbacco feels like you're definitely getting the better end of the stick.
author: Eric L.

description:
Beet salad and risotto balls were amazing.  Pork ragu was okay -- a little bland.  Risotta was good.  Steak was not prepared as ordered -- came out medrare rather than medium.

Service was pretty good.  Took awhile for the server to come by at first, but once he did, was smooth sailing.  Water was refilled constantly and received all our food in a timely manner.  We poured all our own wine, but I generally prefer that.

Was not digging sitting at the same table as 2 random strangers.  Weird.
author: Latef X.

description: Rarely do I find myself kept going to a restaurant and bringing friends with me 3x in the same week, Barbacco was the exception.  They never fail to disappoint with the yummy food selection which are all meant to be shared, attentive staff and a great overall vibe.  My family enjoyed Perbacco so much but couldn't get in so we tried next door and lucked out w/ a table.  I actually like casual mood of Barbacco more but they both are equally great options with solid menus.  Can't go wrong!!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Favorite restaurant in SF at the moment!

During your wait, the hostess provides you with an iPad with their wine list for you to peruse. The waiter was truthful and helpful with his recommendations and the food was AMAZING.

We had:
- pork spread (don't remember what it was called on the menu) with baguette slices (5 stars; never had anything like it), 
- fried brussel sprouts (4 stars; a little overdone for me but the seasoning was prime)
- tuna with capers on baguette thing (4.5 stars; also forgot what it was called)
- the chicken (5 stars; perfectly tender and comes with yummy, flavorful bok choy-esque veggies)
- the lasagna (4 stars; too much cheese, not enough spinach).

Loved.
author: Lilian W.

description:
Look..I love pasta but what the F is up with this citys' inability to produce good Italian places. I'm not saying we don't have any, I'm saying, for how easy it is to make pasta taste good, I really haven't seen as many great Italian restaurants as I'd expect. I say that because that's the only reason I can fathom this place getting 4 stars. With that said the brussels sprouts are awesome. Other than that the paccheri is decent but nothing to write home about. Ambiance is nice, typical white and steel, high end SF look. 

In all there's nothing particularly notable about this place but it isn't bad either. If you're looking for a nice place in the financial to grab a bite after work try this place out, but don't go out of your way to come here.
author: Shreya C.

description:
Best restaurant of this trip by far. I wish there was something like this in NH. 

I stared with small Rucola salad. Very fresh and perfect amount of dressing.  I then order the slow roasted lamb orecchiette with braised char and chili with a nice glass of Fenocchio Barbera.  Simply awesome.   Decided to order one more course. A nice humbly fog with dried cherries poached in wine.  

The menu is a little hard to figure out at first, but having the wine menu on on iPad was an interesting touch. It would be nice if the rest of the menu was also on the iPad and you could read wine recommendations for each item on the menu.  

The Waitress was very friendly and helpful.   I will definitely be back.
author: Mike E.

description:
You can't really go wrong with Italian food but for $75 and the ambiance, you'd think you'd get food with a little 'je ne sais quoi'. Instead this place was meh.

We went for a celebratory meal (instead of Slanted Door, which would of given that UMPH we were looking for). Our server was creepy and lacked personality.

Our food was mediocre etc etc etc.  I don't really recommend this place, its just a gimmick.
author: emme n.

description:
Barbacco... I heart you! 

I love this casual outpost of Perbacco (located right next door) for the following reasons:

1) WINE: depending how "thirsty" you are, you can order wine by 1/2 glass, full glass, carafe or bottle - GENIUS! 
2) FOOD: excellent salumi plate, amazing Sicilian meatballs, succulent braised calamari, delicious bruschetta and expertly poached pasta with brown butter! Everything is scrumptious!  
3) SERVICE: attentive and welcoming waitstaff
4) ATMOSPHERE: relaxed, comfortable and vibrant setting

Barbacco... you have the key to my heart!
author: Alice W.

description: This place is truly a great spot for lingering over your food. Time and again (I think I've been here three times now?), Barbacco has never failed to disappoint.  The ingredients are fresh, the servers knowledgeable, and the presentation, very nice.  Great for a date night, bringing parents to from out of town, or for trying a bunch of new foods with a group.  The wine list is on an Ipad, which is a nice touch.  My favorite dishes are the meatballs, the brussel sprouts sauteed in duck fat, and the salumi.  Don't worry, there are healthier options, too, like fish and salads. ;)
author: Nina B.

description:
I'm really torn about this review.  Barbacco deserves 3.5 awesome stars in my book, but I have to round it down to 3.  I really hate to put a damper on the stellar reviews, but the restaurant did not live up to its hype. 

i think everything is just too damn salty..

WE HAD:
ARANCINI: the taste is definitely there, but the texture is just a tad bit dry.  The whole croquette pretty much fell apart into multiple pieces after I stuck my fork in.  also, the dish really (and i mean REALLY) lacked any sort of mozzarella.  overall, still yummy.

BRUSHETTE: duck liver pate/balsamic onion marmellata- this was delicious!!! everything, from the taste to texture, was on par.  my dinner buddy n i agreed that this is the definite winner of the night. lonza/roasted grape/saba- mehh.. i like the concept behind this little bruschette, but it really was nothing special, a little too hard to eat, and can easily be duped at home.  roasted mushrooms/garlic/parsley- this was yummy, but the burnt (i meant to say charred black) baguette that accompanied the mushrooms really threw this whole dish off.

ORECCHIETTE: this was voted the worst dish of the night.  i felt like i was eating a spinach salad, not pasta.  the ratio of spinach to orecchiette was like 3:1.  I get that this is supposed to be a "light" dish.  However, it was salty, but at the same time, lacked any depth of flavor.  We ended up packing this to go, and we kept pushing the to go bag back and forth cuz neither one of us wanted to bring this home.  Definite miss for our table.

FLAT IRON STEAK TAGLIATA: this dish was really yummy!  The steak was cooked to a perfect medium rare, and it was really tender and flavorful.  The king trumpet mushrooms were cooked to perfection, and the cipollini onions complemented the steak quite nicely.  However, my friend and I both agreed that it is just a little teeny bit salty.  Other than that, we loved this dish!

FRIED BRUSSELS SPROUTS: you know how chefs always tell us novice cooks that we should only add things to enhance the flavor of the star ingredient?  Well, the rule apparently did not adhere to this dish. I barely tasted the brussels sprouts itself because the dish was doushed with the red wine vinaigrette.  However, I do like how they were roasted in the oven.  Thumbs up to the texture.  Overall, it was a only A-OK.

ESPRESSO PANA COTTA: lovely end to our meal.  I really liked this dish.  I really tasted the flavors of the espresso, and it was not overly sweet.  yum!

OTHER PROS: I made reservations today at 4:30pm, and although they were extremely busy, the hostess managed to squeeze me in.  :)  We were originally supposed to sit at the communal tables, but the lovely host seated us at the bar (par request).  The service wasn't the greatest because it was an extremely busy night, but the waiter did make a point to check up on us every once in awhile.. kudos to you, mr. waiter! Also, I really like the idea of using ipads for the wine menu.  :)

I definitely want to try this restaurant again, only because you fellow yelpers gave this place such great reviews.  Maybe the chef mistakenly added the salt in place of pepper? *baffled*
author: S L.

description:
Barbacco has been on my list for quite some time and I'm glad I finally tried it. I'm a big fan of Perbacco so it was only fitting that I become a fan of Barbacco as well. I love that they have the IPAD for ordering drinks (although a bit wasteful since that is all it does). The wine list was amazing (containing a variety of reds/whites, regions, and vintages -- something for everyone on any budget) and the food was superb. There were 5 of us and we had a taste of everything. Everyone in my party was raving about the brussel sprouts (we had 2 orders of this!) and the mussels (so fresh and plump). However, the pasta dishes were underwhelming and weren't thoroughly cooked. I do like my pasta al dente, but not like this -- as if almost uncooked. 

Another to add to my *favorites* list. :)
author: J T.

description:
I'm a big fan of Barbacco and have been there for lunch and dinner multiple times. I like dinner more because they have a wider selection of food. It's Italian style tapas and definitely meant to be shared family style. Let me discuss my favorite dishes.

I do like the arancinis and how can you really go wrong with fried risotto croquettes filled with a little bit of short ribs and cheese. At $3/croquette, I don't always order them, but would recommend it if it's your first visit there.

Definitely try the bruschette! They have seasonal varieties and I like the classic tomato version (not always in season) and the duck liver pate with caramelized balsamic onions on top. The different combinations of bruschette are unique and go well together. Not really a big fan of the lardo (didn't really think it had a ton of taste).

They were out of the lasagna so we ordered the paccheri pasta with pork ragu. The pasta is big tube pastas (imagine giant rigatoni, not as big as manicotti). At first, I was thrown off by how the pasta was thicker and so the texture was not what I was expecting. The sauce won me over though and we didn't have problems polishing off that dish.

The flat iron steak is a winner. I think that might be my go-to "need to order this every time I come here" dish. It was cooked perfectly (they ask you how you like your meat cooked) and sliced into strips with you. It's seasoned so well with salt but not too salty. The mushrooms and little pearl onions are delicious too.

The quick braised squid is also cooked very well. It's not tough or rubbery and comes in a casserole dish with a yummy tomato sauce. I'm also a fan of the fried brussel sprouts. Trust me, you've never had brussel sprouts like this before. They don't have a normal brussel sprouts taste, but you can taste the vinegar.

The only thing I have ordered here and not liked is the mushroom risotto. Funny how the fried risotto croquettes are so delicious but pass on the entree. It lacked flavor and just wasn't very good... the mushrooms were good but not the actual risotto.

Service is excellent and the wine selection is vast (plus it's on iPads). The seating is either at the bar counter or on tandem tables (also high seats). Not the most comfortable seating but it's a fun, lively atmosphere!
author: Jackie T.

description:
Wow!  5-stars.  Really?  Whats the deal?

Almost everything we ate was incredibly delicious.  We ordered the braised squid 3 times and it was all done serially.  After we had the first time, we ordered it again, and then ordered it again after that.  So good that we ordered some focaccia on the side to sop-up all the sauce.

The wine selection is great and the staff is very helpful.  They even use an iPAD to organize their wine cellar (not that this has anything to do with the review).

Why the 5-stars?  Cause the prices are not outrageous and the food was great.  I think I'd could come back here for dinner at least 6-7 times in a row before I would say, "hmmm, maybe I should consider something else."  

Just good and as good as Perbacco.  Just cheaper.  

Can't wait to come back.
author: Mark K.

description: Nice place to grab a bite to eat in the financial district.  Can't comment on the wine list, but you can order it all via iPAD:  gimmicky.  Good food and good attentive service is always what makes or breaks a place for me.  I would recommend the mushroom jar over any of the bruschetta (while good, I just preferred the mushroom jar).
author: Hann A.

description:
Forget Perbacco! Why not just come to Barbacco?! Well...unless you're trying to look really fancy and impress, Barbacco serves just as delicious italian deliciouness for half the price. 

Thanks to clients, I had the opportunity to try both within 2 weeks so it was easy to do a side-to-side comparison, and Barbacco wins.

The service is unpretenscious and feels way less stuffy.

The food's great too: I ordered the Orechiatte pasta, which was positively devine! Flavorful with tons of leftover for the next day. 

The squid appetizer was rustic and awesome, and the fried brussel sprouts were wonderful!

The sandwiches and salads looked great, too.

All in all, a definitely recommendation for FiDi lunch!
author: Gail N.

description:
I have been to Barbacco twice.
Their bruschette are a hit-or-miss... but their Pinot Grigio on tap (yes!), pesce crudo and lasagna are delicious.
What I truly fell in love with though, was the savory bread pudding: golden crust on the outside and melt-in-your mouth inside, with the bread having been soaked in rich lamb stock. Everything I was hoping for and then some.
author: Laure b.

description: This place makes you wanna eat your veggies! My husband has been a frequent patron here and was anxious for me to try it. We sat at the bar on a Tuesday night and enjoyed a lovely meal. The waiter was very helpful and attentive, but not overly so. We split a half bottle of the Bacchus pinot and enjoyed the complimentary mineral water, which i learned is made in house. We started with the roasted carrots and the mushroom brushette. Carrots were tasty and had a fantastic herb yogurt sauce. Hubby loved the brushette. We split the tagliata and the fresh fish, which was some sort of cod. The tagliata (strip steak) was prepared perfectly at medium rare and served over arugula. The fish was surrounded by beans and had a lovely light sauce. We also split the brussel sprouts which were close to burnt but surprisingly delicious! The total tab was around $100.00 plus tip which isn't bad for a such quality. Will return!!
author: Mary B.

description:
I'd describe this place as italian tapas. Small plates to share, all very tasty. The place is a bit pricey, but well worth it. With wine, and food, look to spend $35-$45 per person. Here are some of the really good dishes we had.

Tripe in tomato sauce
Fried Risotto Ball
Pear Gorgonzola Bruchette
Angry Mussels
Fried Brussel Sprouts

Also cool, good wine selection, which can choose from an iPad. Service was very good, friendly, and attentive.
author: Eddy N.

description:
Located right next door to Perbacco, Barbacco is like the younger enthusiastic sibling trying to break away from the shadow of its older wiser counterpart. As a result you get a hip and trendy Italian Trattoria that's a bit more laid back serving up food that's just as good but at a friendlier price point. Definitely a great place to take your clients if you want them to be at ease and not appear to be too pretentious.  

The wine menu: It was larger than the food menu and had a good selection of wines listed by region. Unlike most restaurants, the Barbacco wine menu has 3oz pours -- perfect for those who are indecisive at heart. In addition, there was a hearty list of wines by the glass. Most restaurants give you a few choice selections and the rest of the wine menu consists of the bottles. 

The dinner menu: Though consisting of only 2 pages, the selections are pretty solid. I like the idea of listing the salumi plates separately--another great option for the indecisive. My guest and I ordered 2 salumi dishes. The duck mortadella, with its perfect texture and taste, blew me away...so much so that I have forgotten what the other salumi plate was. For our second course, we had the squid and mussels. The mussels were very fresh and the sauce was so well balanced I could have drunk it as a soup. The main course consisted of the ribs, carpaccio, pork ragu, and a side of brussels sprouts. Out of the three, the carpaccio was the best. What makes a good carpaccio plate perfect is not only how thin the meat is cut nor how fresh it is. A perfect carpaccio plate sits on top of a bed of arugula and is sprinkled with just the right amount of salt. 

People often say of the younger sibling that they can go either way--they can become so spoiled rotten that they make nothing of themselves and just live in other people's shadow, or they try so hard to be seen as an individual that they break the mold and become someone great. I believe the latter will be true of Barbacco.
author: Sue L.

description:
This place is terrific. We ate here a year ago after the Chinese New Year Treasure Hunt and enjoyed it so much we went back this year. 

The food is terrific with some interesting items you don't typically see. The bruschettas are really good and the Angry Mussels were perfectly cooked. The service was friendly and generally timely.

The really amazing thing is the value. I was pleasantly surprised  when the bill came. I would recommend Barbacco to anyone looking for good food in S.F.
author: Stuart M.

description: great for a power lunch. cozy atmosphere with enough but not too much noise. Food is somehwat adventuours for your average business type but very San Francisco in it's quality and presentation.
author: Jim M.

description:
We arrived early to our reservation and ordered a bottle of wine while we waited for our table.  Their wine list is stored on iPads which make everyone want to look through the list.  If only you could order directly from the ipad, now that would be cool!

After being seated we got our first order in immediately due to dying hunger.  The bruschetta came out quickly and was all quite delicious.  I recommend ordering at least one order per person at the table as they are individual pieces, nothing wrong with that but good to know.

A note on the restaurant itself: this is a gorgeous spot and clearly a lot of thought went in to the decor.  It could get a little noisy though and depending on your party size and availability of seats, you may be seated communally.  

We all ordered a main and a couple more apps.  For me the most notable item of the night was the "fried Brussels sprouts / capers / anchovy
shallot-red wine vinaigrette".  You MUST order this if you dine here.  The rest is up to you, all 4 of our mains were delicious.

Our waiter was very attentive and helpful all night, he kept our evening moving and in all this was the perfect ending to a great Friday.
author: Shaun T.

description:
4.5 stars

For new comers who doesn't know Italian, the dinner menu could be intimidating.  There were five of us and we had no idea what to order.  Maybe this place can update their menu and photo-rize it.  The restaurant link on yelp is wrong, so you have to google their website.  Their pdf dinner menu is exactly what it's like.....which is a bunch of words.

Anyways, let's get to the food, which is really awesome.

Appetizers *The entire left page is appetizers*

Arancini - Croquettes filled with pork and mozzarella.  I wish I ordered this.  I don't remember how I forget.  

Coppa - 4 slices of salumi for $6......not worth it in my book.  But to all his own.  I wouldn't try anything under the Salumi section next time.

Burrata - Grilled filone *bread* with some amazing mozzarella and ruola *herbs*.  Everyone enjoyed this dish so much we almost ordered second.  The cheese was simply amazing.  This is a must try.

Bruschette - 3 for $8...
Duck Liver Pate - yuck.....almost didn't want to eat it.  I was expecting something similar to Goose liver but I was so wrong.  I had duck liver before and whatever they did to it made it horrible.  

Truffle Lardo - a bit salty but it's good.  It's truffle oil on pork slices.

Crushed peas and artichokes - ymmy and healthy.  Good stuff.

House Cured Sardine - I shoulda try this one.  Next time.

Entree
Spinch Lasagna - Possible the best lasagna I had in life.  The chessiness and overall flavor and saltiness was perfect.  Top layer cheese was crusty and melty.  So freaking good.  Can't really distinguish the spinach flavor tho.  Totally worth it for $12.

Polpette - Sicilian Meatballs.  Another awesome dish.  Almost every table has an order of this.  The meatball has raisins and pinenuts for flavor.  The tomato sugo was perfect for the meatball.  3 big ones for $12 bucks.  

Fennel Rubbed Pork Ribs with fennel salad.  5 pork ribs with very flavorful crust from the rubs.  It's cooked properly and taste great with the fennel salad.  Yum

Milanese - Fried Pork cutlet.  This is the most ordinary entree of the night.  I was not as amazed as the other three.  The size of the culet was plenty though.  So it makes up for it hahaha.  But we only ordered this because we were looking for 1 more dish and they ran out of duck.

Sides

Patate in padella - Roasted potato with caramelized onion.  This is a dish that's so awesome and so cheap we ordered 2.  The sweetness of the onion and whatever salt on the potato made it almost perfect.

Deserts
Gelato - Spiced chocolate with a hint of cinnamon was the best in my opinion.  Second was the butterscotch choco crunch.  And third was the torrone.  Torrone is a nutty candy bar that they cracked and put it into the ice cream.  Not my type of nutty ice cream.  Just get all three and share with the table.  They are $2 each so it's not expensive at all.

Sorberto - strawberry flavor.  It's alrite.  I like gelato.

This place is 2 blocks from bart and has plenty of street parking after the meter stops.  So I would love to come here again for dinner.  Probably not lunch tho since I don't like to bus.

The ambiance here is perfect for date.  Crowd is not loud at all and the lighting is low and gentle.  Dress to impress but not mandatory.
Don't come here to chow down.  This is a place to hold a conversation and enjoy the company and the atmosphere.

Once again, 4.5 stars.
author: Ricky N.

description:
After driving down to the city (3 hours) and working all day, I was trying to get out of the city to drive back, but hit gridlock traffic at Market St.  After sitting there for 15 minutes, I said f-this, I need a drink and maybe some food while I let it clear up. So I pulled over and walked over to Barbacco. I had been here once before, but it was a power lunch with a client, so I hadn't really paid too much attention.  I remembered that they had a nice bar where a single guy could sit and eat and catch a game. This was the case, as I was promptly seated at this nice bar, and got great, attentive service right away.  Wine, food, and atmosphere were all relaxing and wonderful, just what I needed.  I walked out feeling way better than when I came in, and promised myself I'd be back.  Bravo, Barbacco.

p.s. I don't really get the iPads, they don't really do much (only show the drinks menus)...more of a novelty really. I guess maybe they wanted that buzz out on the street, i.e. "have you been to that place with iPads for menus?"  Meh...
author: Joe S.

description:
I love this place. They are well priced and the service is great. I have been here a few times for dinner and lunch and have enjoyed it each time. The small plates are great to share and I haven't found anything I don't like!

They also do their wine list on an IPAD (fun, fun)...now to take it to the next level and let other patrons write reviews, waitstaff put their recommendations...the sky is the limit!
author: Alisa S.

description:
Overrated.

We had a 8:45 dinner reservation on Saturday night, and when we arrived, the place was packed. I was a bit put off by the fact that the hostess said we would have to wait 10 minutes for our table, but okay. However....15 minutes later, we asked when we can expect to be seated, and she told us it would be another 20 minutes. Suspiciously, when we indicated that we were not likely to stay and wait for a table if it was going to be that long (basically a full 30 minutes after our reservation time), she was able to find us a table in the next 2 minutes. I honestly do not like places where I feel like you have to throw a fit to get a table when you already have a reservation. Totally shady. Minus 1 star.

We ordered the following:
-buffalo mozzarella and beet salad
-lasagna
-squid
-fried brussel sprouts 

The mozzarella and beet salad was lovely, the squid was okay and the lasagna was pretty good. I love brussel sprouts and I was so excited to see all the rave reviews about them on yelp. But I found them to be totally overfried and salty. Like, they need to figure out how to blot the oil out of the leaves or something because they were pretty inedible. The anchovies were not complementary either, unfortunately. 

We ended the night with the pear ricotta cake, which was light, but not particularly amazing. If I hadn't just eaten there last night, I probably wouldn't have even remembered to mention it. 

Overall, the food was a solid 3, and quite reasonably priced. The service was fine for what we were paying for. I wouldn't be opposed to returning, but I probably won't go out of my way to go back.
author: Nora G.

description:
I've been here a couple of times and had the same thing both times - farro risotto (there aren't many options for vegetarians and their menu doesn't change often).  Both times the food has been good.  

On my most recent visit, we went for lunch without a reservation.  We were told it would be 20 minutes.  We decided to wait.  30 minutes later, we asked one of the hostesses how much longer it would be.  Her response was, "I'm not the one who told you 20 minutes, so don't get mad at me." Huh?  No one was mad.  No one even acted upset.  It was so annoying that she responded that way.  Afterward, they sat us at a table that had been open the entire 30 minutes we were waiting.
author: Renee D.

description:
Came here for lunch with colleagues with a reservation.  By noon time, people were waiting out the door.  The place is kind of minimalist-contemporary?  Service was friendly and efficient.

We had the following, family style:
- fried brussel sprouts - yummy with a strong balsamic vinegar flavor
- celery/celery root salad with apples and gorgonzola - too much gorgonzola flavor for my taste but otherwise refreshing
- canerroni pasta with lamb sugo - very bitter, not good
- polpette, pork meatballs - good flavor, not dry
- braised chicken thighs - okay, moist chicken

For the portion size, it's a little bit expensive but the food tasted good overall, except for the pasta.  

A lot of San Francisco restaurants seem very pretentious to me, this feels a little bit that way too.
author: Annie C.

description:
Have been meaning to go here since it opened, so last night we stopped in around 7:30 pm on a Tuesday night.  We walked in and the place was buzzing and great smells were coming from the kitchen area!  We grabbed a seat at the lovely long counter and looked over the comprehensive menu and wine list.  With a few suggestions from our great server, we ordered the following:

Fried olives stuffed with pork (does it get more SF than that?)
Fried brussel sprouts
Roasted beet salad
Bruschetta
Grilled squid with chili tomato sauce

Everything was amazing and paired well with a mezzo of nice italian red.  All the wines are available by the glass, mini-glass, quarter bottle (quarto), half bottle (mezzo) or full-bottle.  I wish there were a few more inexpensive options on the wine list (quarter bottles start at $15) but other than that, can't complain.  Decor is cute, sleek and stylish with counter seating overlooking the prep area, communal tables at the front, and cozy two-tops along the side.

Finished off the meal with some panafuerta (like fruitcake) and a large serving of pannacotta with lemon curd.  Both good but the small savory plates were definitely the highlight of the evening.  I'll be back...
author: Jaimie M.

description:
Working around the corner from this place I've had a chance to work my way through their wine and food menus.  The food is mostly excellent, although there are a few dishes that I think they need to fix.

Hits: the various bruschettas, lasagna, tuna sandwhich, the pasta dishes, tomato soup.

One dish I think they just have all wrong is the fried polenta.  It's just a few sticks of fried polenta on a plate - they seriously need some kind of dipping sauce, probably a remoulade of some sort.

The noise level is very loud.

They use iPads to present the wine menu, which is a bit gimicky.  I'd rather just talk to my bar tender about what he's got that I might like.  Nothing substitutes for a knowledgeable bar tender, and they are happy to give you free tastes.

Service has always been excellent.
author: David L.

description:
Went here for a nice night out and had an excellent meal. We tried practically everything: 
lasagna Bolognese - really good!
"angry mussels" - YUM (except we got them not-so-angry because we don't eat pork)
braised chicken thighs - so juicy!
Brussels sprouts fried in duck fat - TRY THEM YUM!
focaccia - so fluffy and nicely salted
suppli - risotto balls with cheese (my mouth waters just thinking about them)

dessert:
olive oil cake - moist with a nice light flavor
chocolate nemesis cake - do I even need to elaborate???

It was all very reasonably priced, and everything was delicious. I highly recommend!
author: Erin P.

description:
I came back with co-workers for a farewell lunch and we were really happy with our decision to eat at Barbacco.

I got the porchetta sandwich, which is delicious as porchetta can get.  I like that the porchetta here is cut thicker than at Roli Roti, so I could really taste the natural flavor of the pork.  I do wish it came with more crispy skin like RR.  The combo of roasted grapes, red onion, asiago cheese and balsalmic reduction was also delicious and well-balance.  I probably could have eaten just half of it, but it was so good I ate the whole thing (off to the gym I go....).
