My co-workers ordered a variety of plates including the farrotto (which I still highly recommend) and the orecchiette (popular and well-received).  I split a dish of the 'nduja potatoes which are heavenly, though a bit rich, and some other people split the brussel sprouts.  

My co-workers agreed: the Le Colonial brussel sprouts are still better, though Barbacco's are very good.

This is a great place with reasonably priced, well-executed and delicious Italian.  I highly highly recommend it!
author: Naoko M.

description:
Wow! I've been waiting a long time to try Barbacco.  I don't know why I didn't do it sooner. I am such a huge fan now!!

Their salad is simple and yummy! Definitely increased my appetite.  I had their tube pasta and their sauce was delicious. I also tried my friend's shoulder pork sandwich! That was delicious!!! 

And this place is nice, comfortable and affordable for a FiDi lunch! Most entrees are around $10-12.  I mean it's arond the same price if you go Fuzio.  I am definitely coming back here to try their other items!
author: AhLin C.

description:
You'll rave about Barbacco if you share my appreciation for:

- Fine design. The space is warm, modern and inviting, with a palatable buzz from the business professional lunch crowd.

- Tasty, generously sized sandwiches (the chicken with apple slices) and inventive apps (whipped cod)

- Friendly and attentive servers who can articulate the menu with ease and confidence

You'll feel less enthusiastic about Barbacco if share my disdain for:

- Way, way too much oil and butter. Even the chicken sandwich, which was made to order with no fancy cheese sauce that I couldn't pronounce (much like the rest of the menu), was soaking in some artery clogging substance. Same with the simple side salad.

- Not enough private tables available, as they were all reserved even though most sat unused. There are communal tables, and fortunately my dining companion and I were able to take the end of one for some private conversation. But were it been busier we'd have been out of luck.
author: Jason B.

description: Top notch! Impressive wine selection and coupled with the treats in the jar, make this a fantastic early spot for a light meal and several glasses of wine.
author: Dev A.

description: Prompt service but all items had cream and butter which I'm allergic to. I had their bruschetta and was disappointed ... The bread was burnt and the pate was dried up and bland.
author: Benny C.

description:
Absolutely incredible from start to finish!!

The ambiance when we first walked in was exactly what we were looking for during our one night visit to San Fran. It was a Monday night at 8 and every table was full, which is always a good sign. We luckily had reservations and were greeted by a wonderfully friendly hostess, who let us know it would be a few minutes and pointed to an empty space at the counter where we could have a glass of wine and wait. For a place that doesn't actually have a bar, this was a nice option.
Once we were seated we instantly ordered the brussel sprouts, not because I knew that they were basically known for them, but because they are my go-to and I order them everywhere I go. We also ordered a bottle of a California Sauvignon Blanc, cause "when in Rome". The brussel sprouts come out and it happens...I taste one of the most amazing things I've ever tried!! (Reminder: Brussel sprouts are kind of my thing) They had the perfect amount of seasoning and flavor. You know sometimes you order them and the flavor is good, but you bite into it and your mouth is filled with an over-the-top flavor that messes with palate?? Well these didn't do that...they were perfect in every way.

We then decided to stick with a couple apps for the time being....we tried the:
- Seasonal fruit salad with arugula and whipped ricotta cheese - Wow!! These flavor combos were well thought out and fresh as fresh can be! Excellent light start for any meal.
~ Bruchetta on toast with goat cheese? (don't quote me on that) - Perfect crunch and perfect flavor balance

After chatting it up with the two gentlemen beside us, we got friendly enough to offer bites of our competing appetizers....so we also tried..

-Sicilian Meatballs - Delicious and so tender! But not falling apart tender...held together in the best way tender.
-Spreadable salami of some sort - this was very interesting, but actually very tasty. It was basically just a sausage without the casing...but a very delicious sausage.

At this point we were stuffed to the brim, but we had to try the pasta dishes we had ordered before filling ourselves with all the amazing apps (which we didn't regret one bit). We ordered the  orecchiette pasta "little ears" with fennel sausage and Farrotto risotto dish. 
- The Orecchiette had perfectly cooked al dente pasta with crumbled sausage...it was absolutely delicious.
- The Farrotto was unlike any risotto dish I've ever had, in the best way possible. It was rich, dense, and fabulous.

As you can probably tell, I am a huge fan of Barbacco now...and will not come into the bay area again without visiting! 

From the service to the ambiance to the food...you really can't ask for more.
author: Lacey Y.

description:
An absolutely excellent lunch experience in the Financial District!
A potential candidate for one of my best spot in San Francisco.

(Please note that this review is only about their sandwiches)

Lunch with a friend. Since we tasted each-others I was able to try both their roasted lamb sandwich (with broccoli rabe  and roasted tomato) as well as their slow roasted shoulder porchetta sandwich (with grapes, red onions and asiago cheese). 

First thing I had to say: don't look on the picture on yelp as they are far from being accurate to what you really get on your plate (probably due to the lighting condition where those pictures were taken). 
Those sandwiches were simply amazing and each of the bite you get instantly melts in your month. The second sandwich is less meaty that the first one but both are still very flavorful.

Sorry, those sandwiches are not for vegetarian unfortunately :-/

I will definitely go back to Barbacco place to try more during the week!

On a side note, they will bring you an Ipad on your table but this is only to browse (and probably buy) your beverages.
author: Cedric L.

description:
Had a late night dinner here after work with a buddy of mine and we asked the server to bring whatever she thought would be good.  From the best of my memory, here's what we had:

3 kinds of crustinis ...
Aspargus and buratta
Meatballs
Lasagne

After we got over the place smelling like a fish tank when we walked in, the food was very good.  I would definitely go back.
author: Rod C.

description: This is a great, bustling little restaurant in the heart of  FiDi - great spot to meet after work for some nosh & wine or full dinner. Its very energetic, so don't plan to have deep conversation here, but I loved the shared table concept & loved being seated at the bar, with our reservation. They have so many tasty small plates, I had a hard time deciding where to start - but finally picked the risotto croquettes & the fried olives - phenom! I'd have to say my flat -iron steak, although tasty, was a bit chewy, but I ordered in medium but maybe should have gone med-well for the cut. But despite, that we will be back!
author: Jen S.

description: Very classy and sociable ambiance here. Great place to relax and enjoy a good conversation with friends for dinner.  I had the special seasonal(?) dish of swordfish homemade spaghetti - very unique and delicious. Service was great. I would go again. :)
author: Ann V.

description:
My coworker and I decided to treat ourselves to a nice holiday lunch before our vacations and out of several restaurants in the area chose Barbacco. 

The atmosphere and the service were fine. Unfortunately, we were not able to have wine, as we were heading back to work afterwards.  I actually did enjoy the items that I ordered - meatballs and the brussels sprouts fried in duck fat, they both were delish.  

My coworkers' meal, however, was not a great experience. She is a vegetarian and ordered butternut squash pasta and cauliflower with cheese as a side dish. The pasta was ok, just nothing to write home about. However, trying to stay decently healthy during the holidays, she wanted a nice side of veggies to compliment her pasta. We expected cauliflower with a little bit of cheese on top. What she got was a little bit of cauliflower swimming in some awful creamy sauce. It didn't even taste like cheese.  It was gross and really heavy, with tons of butter in it. So much so, that the cauliflower was barely noticeable.  Hey, if we want cheese, we can get a cheese plate.  If we want a yummy yet heavy side, we could get fries, or something to that effect. But we did want a healthy veggie side, which this was definitely not, but you wouldn't guess that from the description.  She had a couple of bites and left it alone. However, we didn't even order dessert that we planned on getting because she felt gross after eating a bit of that dish.  Considering that she picked up the bill for the lunch that she didn't enjoy very much, I did feel bad for choosing Barbacco over Perbacco for this outing.

My suggestion to the restaurant is to leave veggies as veggies for those of us who like at least some healthy alternatives for our meal.  The brussels sprouts were an excellent example of that - still the veggies that i love with delicious flavor added by duck fat that was not overbearing.  

With so many great choices in FiDi, we are not tempted to come back.
author: Marina S.

description:
I'm a huge Perbacco fan, and was excited they opened a smaller venue two doors down with similar dishes at around half the price (i probably shouldn't tell you that...). What i found when i got there, was the most attentive, friendly, non intrusive service i have had anywhere in the city in a looong time where i wasn't a regular. 

- Wine selection and service - A+++ tastes of anything you'd like to make sure you are happy before you order either a glass or a bottle. 

- Fisherman's stew (chipino) was phenomenal.
- Charcuterie platter (same quality and size for half the price?Thanks!)
- Oso Bucco (decadent)
- Ribollita (a fried stew that looked amazing at the next table)
- Chocolate Decadence (divine)

We laughed and dined. which is what a makes for a great experience. 

More to come...

BTW: Valet service thank god since it was 5:15 and there is nowhere to park downtown if you drive in.
author: Adam X.

description:
Let's be frank, I'm on a diet - so when I eat out, the food better be worth my calories! Since I'm still thinking about last night's amazing dinner, Barbacco's food was DEFINITELY worth every single calorie.

My friend made reservations for 7:15, we were a tad late, and they called him to check up on us! They are serious about their reservations, just come on time. 

Although we were seated at the bar area (not so good sometimes for a party of 3), it was just fine. The decor was classy, perfect for a hump day dinner + wine. But the decor isn't what I'm still thinking about.

We ordered a bottle of Cabernet for $43, not bad at all. Here's what I loved in the order of preference.

1: Butterscotch Gelato ($2, are you kidding!? SO CHEAP)
One of my friends has the BIGGEST sweet tooth I know, and he has declared it his favorite ice cream. He even wanted to buy a quart to go! (Unfortunately they don't sell it to go). The flavor was spot on, not overwhelmingly sweet, just like I like it.

2: Duck Pate Bruschetta ($3 or $8/3)
Delish!! They might give you a ton of pate, but it's so good. Balanced with a balsamic reduction and an onion jam on toasted bread. MUST HAVE!

3: Fried Brussels Sprouts ($4)
To those kids who used to feed their brussels sprouts to their dogs, fear no more! Fried Brussels Sprouts are here!! Any hint of nutrition is taken out once these babies are fried - but who cares, this ish is the bomb! Definitely not what I expected when I ordered it, but it was an awesome surprise.

4: Spinach Lasagna ($12)
Vegetarians be warned, this is not your average spinach lasagna, it's actually pork+veal ragu beautifully layered between a spinach pasta with a light cream sauce. This was just what I needed for some good Italian lovin' and highly recommended.

I don't give out 5 stars loosely, but this place is worth recommending!!
author: Shelly L.

description:
Came here for lunch with a friend.  You must make reservations, even for a casual lunch -- otherwise, you will wait!  She's organized, so we did not wait.  ;)  

If they have the artichoke soup, you must get it!  O m g.  It's really divine.  It has that sweet aftertaste that you have from real artichokes.  

The butcher's salad is good but nothing special, so I'd skip it next time.  Of the bruschette, we tried the duck liver pate (good), local sardines (a little tart for me), and something else that I don't remember.  

The orecchiette are also delicious, and the portion is really big.  We ended up bagging most of it after the soup, bruchette, and salad...I can't wait to come back and try more the menu!
author: Olivia L.

description: Great food, service and ambience. Our server was very friendly and knowledgable of the menu items. The food was very flavorful. The Nduja  stuffed dates in spicy tomato sauce was wonderful though quite rich but worth it for the combination of sweet, spicy and savory flavors. Paired with a nice montepulciano d'abruzzo wine, to complete the meal.
author: Hari J.

description: eh... My first experience here was great. We got suppli, risotto, and bubbly water. It was delicious and felt very unpretentious. Another time, I cam on the fly and met a friend here. They were busier and sort of rude about me not having a reservation. It was fine, I ended up going somewhere else. I think I remembered why I like places where you order at the counter.
author: Julia D.

description: Apparently this place is the fashionably less-expensive option to its next door neighbor, however, I was less-than impressed. My party (of 2) were seated at the bar (TO EAT) right near the kitchen. The portions were less than satisfying and over-priced. The only cool thing that would have been memorable was that you get to order from an iPad except everything we chose on the menu was out of stock. I would have been sympathetic if they were a start-up operation but Barbacco's had time to adjust... they didn't, so this is what they get. If you plan to eat in the financial district, go somewhere else!
author: Devin W.

description: I really like this place! The appetizers are great - I remember the calamari, burrata and brussels sprouts being excellent. And wonderful Italian wines by the glass.  This is a terrific place to come for an after work dinner because it's 1) Tasty, 2) Pretty easy to get a last minute reservation and 3) Easy to park on the street.
author: Missy S.

description: what a great place! atmosphere is great, the prices are reasonable and food great. Loved the brussel sprouts and all pasta and meatballs are great also. The spreadable salumi is aaawesome! They used to have a great wine called Poco a Poco Wine but no longer :-(
author: Ilya Movshovich M.

description:
I came here with a friend for a girl date.  I had tried Perbacco a couple of years ago and was curious about Barbacco.  Meeting up with my buddy gave me a great excuse. 

Service was good but the noise level was a little crazy as the night wore on.  We had dinner at 6pm-ish and left around 8pm.  No big deal, it was prime happy hour time.   They're using iPads for the drinks menu, which I thought was awesome but it got in the way when we got our waters and plates.  Maybe they'll put the entire menu on it someday.  Anyways, we had some great dishes:

marinated olives
salumi with fennel seed and fennel pollen (i forget the exact italian name; it was a cured meat)
duck sausage with polenta and arugula plus caramelized onions
pork ragu
sliced heirloom tomatoes
berry tart
chamomile citrus tea (mighty leaf brand)

I liked the tapas style dishes, makes it different from Perbacco.  All the dishes were awesome, especially the pork ragu and duck sausage.  The berry tart was eh...nothing special, wasn't horrible, wasn't spectacular.  I'd like to try the gelato next time.  

Great place and a "cheaper" alternative to Perbacco.
author: DJ P.

description:
Barbacco is a great place for a cozy business lunch down in the fidi.  
The standouts were the rotolo: basically a sheet of pasta wrapped around some ricotta topped with asparagus and meyer lemon zest.  Sounds simple and it is simply delicious.  The salumi platter was well executed. I liked the sardine bruschetta - nice and briny.  The lasagna was deceptively small  but rich - a little too rich for lunch.  Avoid the fisherman soup - it tasted like canned chunky tomato soup and I couldn't find seafood anywhere.  It looks like Barbacco may give Tadich a run for its money.
author: Monica L.

description: I love this place. it is a great date night place. The food is great, the atmosphere is great and the wine list is wide. Excellent choice for a great date. Now I just need to find more people to take me here or save up to go there.
author: Amy E.

description:
Our dinner at Barbacco started a bit shaky...we had 6:30pm reservations and were not seated until 7:10pm. I was surprised that restaurant management could have so poorly mis-managed seatings and reservations so early. At around 7:05pm, the manager came over to everyone waiting and offered to lay out some food while we wait. "unfortunately" we were seated pretty soon thereafter. We were disappointed that ever after sitting, we were not comped any wine, or app... now that's the bad news. 

Good news is, the food was delicious and we had a warm and friendly waiter. We started with the bruschette: chicken liver pate, bean and duck, and peach with prosciutto. The clams was probably our favorite dish...super flavorful, light, and delicious broth. The brussel sprouts, as everyone had mentioned, was delicious. Our least favorite dish was the pork ragu over pasta. Perhaps if they used a different kind of pasta, like a papardelle or tagliatelle would have been a better choice. 

Unfortunately we were way too stuffed to try any of the desserts, hopefully next time! Overall was pretty impressed with the caliber of the food, all at a very very reasonable price. By the time we left, we had forgotten about the 40minute wait we had, even with reservations :)
author: Jane T.

description:
So I actually prefer this place to its big sister next door.  I agree with the reviews that say Perbacco is over hyped.  It's not terrible it's just not amazing.  

Little sister Barbacco is awesome.  I especially liked the salumi platter which was thoughtfully customized by our server so I could have a healthy serving of 'nduja. 

We ate quite a bit of yummy food, drank a Barbera wine flight and had a big slice of chocolate nemesis cake for a very reasonable amount of money.  

Seating is kind of tight and it's noisy in a fun way.  Mirror on the wall behind me reflected the baseball game being shown on the tv above the bar which made my date happy, he got to watch the Giants while pretending to be very interested in everything I was saying!
author: Poppy C.

description:
Been to Barbacco twice in the past week and I am very, very impressed with both the service and the food.  

The front of house staff does a wonderful job juggling reservations, walk ins, and drink orders.  While there isn't a bar for people to hang out at while they wait for their table, there is a small alcove near the door that works just fine.  Both times I've been, the hostess and General Manager have been very accomodative about bringing a glass of wine or beer to us while we wait.  I was impressed with Maria's recommendation for a 2007 Mancini Sangiovese - so impressed that I ended up buying 6 bottles from the distributor the next day.  Great recommendation.  

Food has been excellent both times.  The highlights:

- Farm Eggs
- Beet Salad
- Bruschetta (Many kinds, but the duck liver pate with balsamico/onion jam is UNBELIEVABLE.  It's one of the best things I've eaten in SF - a must have). 
- Seared tuna
- Rigolo with rustic pork

I will say that a few dishes, particularly the farm eggs, have been oversalted, but not dramatically so.  We also sent our tuna back as it was overseared, but they replaced it promptly and apologized, so no harm, no foul there.  

My wife and I dined there last night and had a salad, a bruschetta order (3 for $8), the farm eggs, two entrees, a dessert and 3 glasses of wine.  We got out of there for under $100, which we both thought was a steal given the quality of the meal and the service.  

Highly recommended!
author: Kent E.

description:
Never disappointed.  The pulled pork ragu is a must try for everyone, simple and delicious.  Fried polenta is sinful.  Just think Italian tapas when you come here.  The portions are not huge but pack real flavor.  

This is a great place to go with a group of people.  Order a bunch of dishes and let everyone have a taste.  

Price is incredibly reasonable for what you are getting.
author: Mike E.

description:
I ordered soup and salad to go. The Butternut Squash Soup is ALL butter and salt. The Beet Salad has good flavor / components but there is not enough salad and way too much dressing. Meh, indeed! I will wait to try Barbacco again after they work out the new restaurant kinks.

Oh! And for $12, it wouldn't hurt to throw in a slice of bread. Who eats soup and salad without bread?
author: Valerie N.

description: Service outstanding.  Sat at the bar.  Great food and the atmosphere was perfect.  Great for conversation.  Solid wine menu and dessert menu. Had the maccheroni alla chitarra.   Perfect size portions .
author: Alissa P.

description:
How is this possible? Right next door, owned by same people, shares the name "...bacco", yet Barbacco is great, and Perbacco is meh~

I've been to Perbacco a few times and never been impressed. Food was almost always disappointing. The atmosphere is generic financial district.

Barbacco's warm brick wall cheered me up instantly. Everything I had was plate licking good. Service was quick. It's great that you can make a reservation for a place that allows take-out and is reasonably priced.

Minus one star for being super loud with cramped seating.
author: Su K.

description:
Barbacco is like a beautiful woman that is far out of your league: Yes, you will pay a premium for her company, but you just can't believe you're so goddamn lucky to have the privilege.

I went at lunchtime and had the Octopus and Sardine sandwich, which came with a beautiful salad of vinegary, multicolored carrots and the best bread I've ever been served in a restaurant. My friend and I split the brussel sprouts, which were crispy and flavorful and oh my god so good.

If you're feeling adventurous, you may want to give their "White?!" section of the wine list a workout - I did and don't regret a single sip.

We were there for nearly two hours at the bar, eating and drinking our way through the afternoon, and the service was perfectly attentive and gave us our space at the same time.

This place might not be for everyone, but that's ok. More for me.
author: Jess F.

description:
Barbacco is in the heart of the Financial District and is just as busy as all the other places. If you are looking for a place with space and comfort, I wouldn't choose here. The seating arrangement makes one feel very, "squished". The person to my left kept bumping into me the entire meal. 

I will say that the service was friendly, polite, and quick. The food was good. Nothing out of this world, but quality taste for the price. Menu prices are reasonable and they have a great selection of small plates and entrees.
author: Holly F.

description:
The reason this place only gets a four star is the fact that we waited 30 minutes despite having a reservation on a Friday night.  Granted, 10 people walked out because the wait was too long, but I got a little upset when a reservation at the same time as ours got seated before us and we were there before them!

However, despite the wait and crazy amount of people, the Italian tapas menu was well priced and very delicious. First off, they use ipads for their drink menu which was really cool at first especially when trying to figure out what wine you want. However, it got distracting during the meal... not sure if I was a fan or if it was too much.  I did like how they described the wines so you can choose one you wanted to try.

We were seated on the counter which was fine and right next to the prepping station.  We ordered four dishes and everything was delicious. The first item was a deep fried dough ball filled with risotto, mozzarella and short ribs. Yummy.  We had a duck pate bruchetta with caramelized onions, which was perfectly done, both sweet and savory at the same time. Our next dish was tripe cooked in a sweet tomato red sauce over a crispy bread.  It was pleasantly sweet and not overly done.  And finally, crazy mussels, cooked in a spicy red broth, a really great dish that completed our meal. We had the espresso panna cotta for dessert which tasted fantastic with the speak easy porter.

For five dishes plus drinks the tab was swallowable. It's definitely a hip new place worth the visit for an innovative way to have Italian food to share.
author: SF Diner A.

description:
So after watching Top Chef last Wednesday night, I immediately began craving some pasta (thanks to Italian food battles!). We were heading to the mission to celebrate some great friends, but were unable to score a table at any of the places in that area. So, we turned to Open Table who informed us that there were available reservations for Barbacco! 

What a night it turned out to be! Despite almost dying in the Yellow van cab gunning it down Bush Street, I highly recommend Barbacco for a fun and delicious night out! 

We started with the bruschette which is 3 for $8. We tried the duck liver pate, broccoli rabe and the (surprisingly delicious) squash and cranberry. 

We followed up the bruschette with two pasta dishes - the pork ragu and the orecchiette with broccoli rabe and anchovies. Both dishes were good, but the pork ragu really stood out to me. It was fantastic! 

Sadly, we were trying to restrain ourselves from ordering everything on the menu, so I cannot speak to the desserts or some of the other entrees. However, it just gives us another excuse to head back for date night part 2!
author: Landon W.

description:
The food at Barbacco is good because it shares a kitchen with Perbacco.  I had pasta with bolognese sauce, which was very savoury. My partner had the orecchiette with broccoli rabe and anchovies (but we could barely taste the anchovy so that was a bit of a miss). Food prices are quite low: we had 2 starters and two pastas, in total $30. 

The wine list is confusing and misleading. 

There are 5 choices: 3oz, 6oz, Quarto, Mezzo and Full Bottle. The Quarto (Italian for 1/4) means, at least to me, 1/4 bottle. The Mezzo (Italian for 1/2) means 1/2 bottle to me. 

However, our waitress explained that Quarto is a glass of wine. So in my head it would be 187.5 ml (which is 1/4 of 750 ml). Sounds about right for a glass. But you pay more than 1/4 of the wine bottle price. I never got around to finding out if the amount they pour into a glass is exactly 187.5 ml because I gave up. Too exhausting.

I feel this restaurant is trying to rip us off on wine by creating these 5 categories where 1/4 may or may not be equal to 1/4 in volume, but the price is more than 1/4 the price of the bottle. 

As such it is expensive: $15-$19 per "quarto" or glass of pretty average Italian wines. When I was in Rome last September, I paid 3.50 EUR for a carafe of very good (house) wine. In Barcelona, you go to a good tapas bar or restaurant, they pour you a sizable glass of excellent wine and it rarely ever cost me more than 8 EUR. 

So we ended up just eating, no wine, bill came to $30, which is an excellent deal. 

Barbacco is very noisy. The ceilings are low so the effect is quite claustrophobic. 

We ate at Credo two weeks ago, a few blocks away at Pine and Montgomery and that was much, much better. Better service, large tables not clapped together so closely, not a big ripoff on wine, chef came out to greet the guests, much more civilized for dinner. 

OK Barbacco is a BAR first and foremost . . . I forgot. A Bar that happens to serve food. So it has a loud bar atmosphere.
author: Esme V.

description: DO NOT ORDER TAKEOUT!!! WARNING!!! Called the take out number and an automated message directed me to another number. Called that number - waited 3 minutes for the automated message to go through options and finally selected the take out option which instructed me to go online. Went online, went through the process of adding a number of items in my shopping cart (10 minutes), went to pay and the system wouldn't process the order stating I had to update my shipping address (another 15 minutes). For the life of me, selected every option with no success. Call the number again, pressed 0, got through to a real human being who asked me to hold. 10 minutes later.... I gave up. A real shame because I had just been raving to so many people about this place after going their for lunch yesterday and felt like a real goose not being able to close the loop.
author: Maria S.

description:
Me and the girlfriend went here for dinner last weekend and it was quite alright. The food was great, but I personally was not a fan of the seating arrangement, and we had to get moved twice because they kept giving us gnarly locations: once right by the end of the bar, and another time on a shared table with some guys who were talking really loudly. 

This isnt the place for a romantic evening, but its probally a good place for a social meal with a few friends or co-workers.
author: Tim P.

description:
Thank you to the kind SF Yelpers that recommended this place, i really liked it!

I walked into Barbacco without looking at the menu, sat at the bar and thought, "i have no idea what to order".  The waiter made some recommendations and everything was great except for the soup.

Food:  
1.  Arancini - risotto croquettes filled with braised pork, mozzarella and peas.  This was so good, you have to try it!!  The exterior of the croquette was crispy and the filling was delicious!  I would've ordered another one if i wasn't full.
2.  Bruschette - cannelini beans / rosemary / radicchio
                            caponata / spicy ricotta
                            duck liver pate / balsamico / onion jam
-the cannelini beans were my least favorite, probably because i don't like beans.  But they're all very tasty.
3.  I had the soup of the day...can't remember the name.  But it was some creamy veggie soup.  I didn't like it because the garlic taste was too strong.

The decor & ambiance is nice, relaxed and comfortable.  I would recommend Barbacco for groups so that you can order different dishes to share, order some wine and hang out.

The service ended up to be great.  I was thisclose to walking out as I sat at the bar and waited for about 10 minutes before the server came by.  But once he came by, he was attentive, friendly and made those great recommendations.
author: Terry C.

description:
"Little ears" pasta- delicious!

I had eaten there a while ago and ordered several appetizers. I forgot what they were called but my experience there was very filling! Good lunch spot!
author: Jennifer D.

description: Get the chitarra. The ingredients sound a bit strange but together everything is delicious. The noodles must be made in house as the consistency is perfect. I also ate the burrata and polenta, both very tasty. I had my first and last meal in SF here. I will be back.
author: Justine C.

description:
So happy this place moved into my building. Great prices, but wasn't as taken with the food that was attached to the lower (than Perbacco's) prices. The brussels sprouts were a nice surprise though! The penne wasn't so wonderful. Not bad. But not fantastic.

Trying it again next week, and this time eating in-restaurant. Will update after.
author: Natasha M.

description:
My boyfriend doesn't like mushrooms. My boyfriend was fighting me for chanterelles that came with the asparagus at Barbacco. Really, these statements are contradictory but they are the best way to describe last night's long-awaited dinner date.

I've been wanting to check out Barbacco since reading about it in a tantalizing article on Urban Daddy. Finally, nearly five months later, we made a reservation. Note on the reservation: I was slow getting ready so we were a half hour late, but the bf called in and the restaurant said that was not a problem: when we arrived, we were seated immediately and our seats had a 'reserved' card on them. Major points there.

But ok, the FOOD!!! Simply amazing. I want to come back and try the other items on the menu we didn't get to. What we did get to, however, was the salumi, the flatiron steak, mushroom risotto, 3 types of bruschettes (eggplant, spring pea and artichoke), asparagus, and two types of gelato. The plates are small but mighty; we definitely weren't hungry. Minus the bottle of Riesling I insisted on getting (and they have like 8 different Rieslings!), dinner would have been around $50. TOTAL WIN RIGHT THERE.

A note on the staff and environment as well: the staff is really friendly and accommodating (back to our late arrival) and even though the restaurant is shared tables (we sat at the bar), you don't feel like you're in everyone's business. Special shoutout to our server, Gretchen: you were great and your recommendations left both of us VERY happy and anxious to come back again.
author: Emilia S.

description:
The menu is extensive and everything looked so good that my friend and I ordered way too much food. We ordered so much food, the elderly man at the next table felt the need to exclaim (and loudly), "How can you girls eat so much?!" We would have been embarrassed if we weren't so distracted by the deliciousness on our plates. 

The fried brussels sprouts are heaven on a plate. I could eat a whole meal of these brussels sprouts. I can't stop thinking about them. 

The best mussels in a spicy chili sauce. I was really tempted to drink the broth after we'd devoured all the mussels and toast. 

The farro risotto was rich and flavorful. The meatballs out of this world. The asparagus was really good, but the most subtle of everything we ordered. 

I also love that they offer several different wine pouring options: 3 oz, 6 oz, or 8.5 oz. I can never have more than one glass in a setting, so I loved that I could try a couple of different wines without getting blotto. 

Just one question for the owners - why the huge sports bar-style TVs over the bar?! Seemed completely incongruous and distracting. It's a much more elegant restaurant than that. Yes, the bar extends the length of the restaurant and I understand that they're the downmarket cousin of Perbacoo, but that doesn't mean they need to cheapen themselves with those TVs. I didn't get it.
author: Caitlin L.

description:
I made a reservation for 1:30 on a Friday afternoon. The hostess wouldn't seat me until my other party arrived. Not a big deal, but I noticed that she didn't treat all patrons the same. Another party in which only 2 of the 4 people showed up - was seated before us (even though they arrived after me). 

After my friend arrived, the hostess said that she would seat me shortly. We waited another 15 minutes. We were only seated after I asked her what was the point of the reservation. A few minutes later, we were seated along the long counter. 

The ipad drink menu is cool, but silly since the food menu is the placemat. The server brought a jug of water, but never brought any more water after we finished it. Service sucks! For the $, go next door to Perbacco.
author: Bruges L.

description:
This place rocks! Thankfully, the person I went with was smart enough to make a reservation because the place is completely full during the week at lunch apparently. 

Very trendy decor in all aspects, including iPads to order drinks! At lunch I had the pork sandwich and it was phenomenal. It didn't leave me feeling disgustingly full, but rather content with my selection. We also ordered a side of the brussel sprouts, which I was told was the hottest side dish. We were a little apprehensive at first, but the waiter finally convinced us we wouldn't be sorry. And we certainly were not! They were delicious. I'm definitely going back for seconds.
author: Ricardo M.

description:
Enjoyed a lovely lunch that left me yearning to come back for more. I had the gnocchi, and they were surprisingly light.  The sauce was delicious and everything tasted fresh.  
We were too full to get dessert and the server surprised us with a complementary little cup of some ridiculously yummy cream with fig and honey. Oh dear! What a climatic end!
author: Mrs. G.

description: Barbacco is one of those places that I never intend to end up at but am always glad I did. It's right by Tadich Grill which gets a lot more attention, but don't let Barbacco's unassuming front and (usually) lack of a long wait fool you. They have an excellent selection of wines by the glass or different size bottles, a varied menu of delicious salads, pastas, appetizers, sides and entrees and great service. I very highly recommend the Brussels sprouts fried in duck fat  - yes, it's as lush and lovely as it sounds - and polpette (Italian meatballs). Barbacco is certainly a great place to drop in for some wine and small plates or a full meal and I should try to remember not to forget it.
author: Kristina A.

description: I really loved this place. The food was amazing and service was pretty fast. I had the braised chicken thigh /creamy polenta which was amazing! The fudge swirled hazelnut was better than what I was expecting. I would highly recommend eating here.
author: Raza D.

description: Just as tasty as its parent, Perbacco, but faster and more friendly on the wallet.  Overall, the dishes are flavorful without being excessively seasoned.  I recommend the braised chicken thighs with fennel and garlic confit, and the orecchiette with sausage and broccoli rabe -- both are delicious and generously portioned.  Given the high-quality food, I was impressed that we got in and out of here in under an hour (with a reservation).
author: Chris T.

description:
Had a lovely evening with my friend at Barbacco.  I have to admit that I often find these downtown places kinda snooty, kinda meat-markety...especially on a weekday night.  But I was pleasantly surprised by a very enjoyable crowd and delightful service.  Will definitely be back - and try Perbacco as well!

We ordered 5 tasty plates - all of which were delish!  In particular, I liked the duck sausage with yummy caramelized onions, and the salumi with fennel seed.  The marinated olives were also tasty, but I found it a tad odd that they were terribly wrinkly...oh well, goes down the same, and I love olives!

We finished the meal with a berry tart.  I liked that the custard and/or shell had a yummy almond flavor, and the berries were fresh.  The main minus is that the stems for the strawberries were still on?  Found that odd.

Totally a delicious (and decently affordable) meal with some great company.  Can't ask for more!  :)

Oh - and you can view (and possibly order?) drinks via iPad.  Super cool!

The place was pretty busy on a Tuesday night...definitely recommend reservations.
author: Fontane L.

description:
Impressive and affordable food and wine!  

Salumi plate (substantial)
Burrata with arugula (too salty)
Duck liver and balsamic and onion marmaletta bruschetta (yum!)
Spicy tripe Neapolitana and the porchetta sandwich (good, but I've had better)

Impeccable service (ingenius portable, electronic order-taking doohickys)
Cool modern diner-like layout  (WARNING: be careful not to walk into your reflection when passing the mirrored wall on the way to the bathroom!)
author: jane d.

description: Great food, fun atmosphere. We flew in from Austin and stayed at the Galleria Park Hotel. We thought about Perbacco, but then I saw Barbacco and was as intrigued AND we were able to get in with a last minute reservation. We sat at the bar and had great wine and food. Definitely get the brussel sprouts fried in duck fat - OMG. and the suppli to snack on. The fried olives were pretty kick ass too. I enjoyed the paccheri for my main course, but wasn't blown away. The dude got the beef stew and LOVED it.
author: Meg R.

description:
Went in for a lunch with a friend who was in town - TIP: make sure you have a reservation during the weekday lunch rush. We did, and were seated immediately and had fun playing with the iPad that featured the drink menu.

Overall, good experience.The food was excellent. We both got the duck liver bruschette to start, which was on the small side, but an good starter for a quick lunch. In the future, I'd like to come back with friends and check out the different bruschettes. 

For my main, I got the paccheri pork ragu. Honestly, a little too oily for my liking. Other than that, it had good flavor and came in a sizable portion - I ended up taking it home. 

Only downside was the fact that it was lunch rush and thus, crowded and loud. But what else can you expect in downtown San Francisco, right?
author: Aimee S.

description:
I'm a pretty big fan of this place - it's a great casual restaurant with a relatively fun menu. i came here with a couple coworkers and we split a bunch of appetizers. the fried polenta was very good, and i don't even like polenta that much! 

it's a good sit down restaurant where you can still be casual but have great food. the prices are good for a fidi restaurant, and if you ever need a place to bring some friends just a casual get together, this is the place to be!
author: A Y.

description:
When it comes to food variety is really the spice of life. Having a 'small plate" setup, my wife and I got to try quite a few scrumptious dishes. 

Burratta - always a treat and their portion is much larger than other restaurants. 

Fennel spare ribs - good but the least fave of the dishes we tried but still ok.

Fried brussel spouts - very tasty 

The Meatballs - velvety and probably my second favorite dish

Chef's Selection Salumi - The star of a great meal. A variety within the variety of dishes we ordered. 5 distinct house cured meats and spreads that all had their own textures and flavors. I recommend this dish to all.
author: Johnny J.

description:
Coworkers and I came here for lunch.  Food was good but not impressive.  I was pleased because their portions are spot on.

Our server was really cool and very easy going.

Also, the nduja was not good at all.  Supposedly it's a spreadable sausage, but in all honesty it tasted like pureed spam.  Fancy name, but tasted cheap.  Not a fan.

At least we ended our meal with some yummy dessert.  I highly recommend their butterscotch gelato!
author: Jen G.

description:
quite nice. recommended. casual enough environment to feel relaxed, while swank enough to feel like you are "out for an evening". well spaced tables and good lighting, coupled with friendly, helpful servers and a solidly executed menu of tasty italian delights with a sardinian slant. dining companion and i enjoyed a duo sampling of the bruschetta (roasted pear / prosciutto di parma & marinated cherry tomatoes / basil / garlic) that got the salivary glands going strong, paired two pasta dishes (gnocco fritto - savory and decadent  - loved it, plus orecchiette - "little ears" / cavolo nero fennel sausage / pecorino cheese, delicious with a bright and satisfying tang) along with a side of brussels sprouts - near blackened without any char or burnt aftertaste - recommend, with a satisfying medium bodied  Italian red grifola- montepulciano, 2008 thoughtfully suggested by our server with a sample before ordering.

terrific evening. delicious meal. understated, unconsciously elegant atmosphere conducive to conversation and savoring sardinian fare. do go.
author: wendella a.

description:
Tucked in between Front and Battery Street next to it's big sister Perbacco, Barbacco has an elegant and active dining scene. My husband and I sat at the "counter" and were handed our iPad that contained all the information you could possibly want to know about their drink selections. 

We decided on a bottle of the Verge 2007 Syrah, from Dry Creek Valley. It was a perfect match to the lovely meat sauces and cheese plate we had next. For our cheese plate we chose the gorgonzola with chestnut honey and the lonzo (pork loin soaked in red wine). The pungent yet creamy gorgonzola very much complimented the sweetness of the honey and the salty warm flavor of the pork. 

For our main entrees I had the spinach lasagna with a bolognese ragu balsamella sauce, the ultimate definition of a comforting pasta dish without being ridiculously heavy, perhaps it was the spinach lasagna noodles that lightened it. My husband had the polpette:  Sicilian meatballs with raisins and pine nuts, and braised chard with a tomato sugo. I definitely appreciate the Sicilian style meatball, the sweetness of the dried fruit and the ground nuts whether pine nuts or pecans add such wonderful layers of flavor.

We finished our meal with the chocolate nemisis cake, I have to admit I believe ordered purely for its name. It was not a nemisis at all really, rather a good friend, especially paired with the last bits of the Syrah we ordered. 

Next time we go, I hope we indulge in more of the cheeses and meats, as they have such a impressive array of choices.
author: Rachel O.

description:
Wow, this really is like a little Perbacco.  Came here during lunch and was immediately awestruck at the iPads they used as drink menus.  If first impressions are everything, then I was blown away.

With that said, we ordered the salumi platter as appetizer and I had the orecchiette.  This was pretty much a seemingly light pasta dish with kale, sausage, garlic, and cheese.  

The cold cuts were pretty good.  I can't say that all the selections were the best I've ever had (Salumi in Seattle still takes the cake), but some of them were pretty damn good, especially the cubed meat (no clue what it was).

The pasta was light and delicate tasting at first, but the sheer volume of it got me stuffed by the end of lunch.  I also tried the pork ragu and that was nothing short of amazing.
author: Jeff N.

description:
Such a wonderful meal!  We didn't have reservations but they squeezed us in at the counter, which was surprisingly comfortable (the husband wants me to add here that he enjoyed sliding his silverware around on the placemats in between courses, but then, he's easily entertained).  I am not usually a fan of bar stools (I'm short, okay), but these were only a little bit taller than regular chairs and had a well-placed footrest bar, good padding, and a decent back, so I actually quite liked them.  Plus there are hooks underneath the counter for hanging your purse, which is a nice touch, and it's fun to watch the staff assemble some of the dishes in right front of you.

Our waitress was an absolute delight, attentive and informative and friendly and fun without being obtrusive.

I had a strawberry-lavender lemonade, which could've been more lavender-y, but was still delicious (and also a goodly amount -- sometimes when you order specialty drinks it feels like you barely get three sips in and it's gone; that is not the case here, I'm pleased to report).  We started with the suppli, which had a nicely distinct wild mushroom flavor and were yummy but probably would've been even yummier with marinara (which is possibly non-traditional?  I have no idea.  But it's how our favorite Italian place in Austin serves them).  The pastas were a highlight for me -- I got the orecchiette with sausage and my husband got the paccheri with pork ragu and they were both exceptional.  My favorite pasta dishes are the ones that seem simple but are full of flavor and perfectly balanced.  Both of the dishes we had hit that mark and hit it _hard_.  So freaking good!  The sides were also excellent (we got the brussels sprouts fried in duck fat, because how could we not, and the fried polenta), as were the desserts.  I loved my almond cake with its little dab of milk chocolate ganache, quenelle of vanilla cream, and generous pile of deliciously tart-sweet marinated cherries and crunchy toffee bits.  And my husband's chocolate nemesis cake was rich dark flourless chocolate goodness, creamy and sinful.

So, to recap:
Service: Perfection
Food: Ranging from very good to spectacular, and more the latter than the former
Value: Very high

I could imagine paying more elsewhere for every single part of that meal, and in some cases a lot more.  Given the quality of the food and the overall pleasure of the experience (and especially when compared to the other food options in the area), I would say that Barbacco qualifies as a true bargain.
author: Jen C.

description:
The food here is truly delicious (let me say that again: delicious!) and I like the atmosphere too. 
The reason I am not giving this place the review the chefs deserve is because of the service.
The last time I was there I stayed for longer than normal (great conversation!) and was asked to leave so the table could be given to the next reservation, despite the fact we were ordering more food and more drinks - I think this speaks poorly to how they are organized. 
They also give you grief if a person in your party is late. 
I think a restaurant of this caliber needs to be better organized to deal with situations that happen frequently in this kind of business. There is no greater pleasure than be having such a good time that you end up sitting at your table for more than two hours - it's a compliment to the place and the food. Who kicks out a customer having a good time?
author: D Z.

description: This is a good place to share bites and bottles of wine. I love their fried brussels sprouts and polpette, they are excellent together. Excellent. Try it.
author: Laxme G.

description: Good italian restaurant. I ordered paccheri with rustic pork ragu sauce and I was impressed. I came back to the next day and order the same thing... Some people may say pasta is a bit tough, but this is the real Italian way of cooking pasta, al dente.
author: Machiruda Y.

description:
My initial review of this place was 4* Especially when it first opened.  However - after my third time eating here I have to say service, quality and consistency have failed big time.  

The positive: There was a gentleman host there showing people around, he was great

Very negative: The wait staff, we had a female who poured water on the table and ended up in my co-workers purse, she wasn't very knowledgeable about the "meat" dishes and finally it took her 3 times asking her about our foccacio bread for it to finally arrive.

Noise Level is noisy, and they do try an pack you in like Sardines (ie. you are elbow to elbow with others).  

In my option: Best thing on the menu - fried brussel sprouts (its their side).
author: Rebecca W B.

description: The whole "order drinks on the iPad" thing is kind of cool, but food here is average and overpriced for what it is.
author: Romita J.

description:
I would actually give this place 3.5 stars, but I'll be nice and round it up. I came here last month for a nice little holiday dinner with some of my girlfriends. At first we were really intrigued by the way they had the menu. We got to the restaurant and immediately looked for the iPad to order. To our disappointment, only drinks were on the menu on the iPad and we couldn't even put our order in from the iPad! Minus 1 star! There wasn't much else we could do with the iPad.... BOO!

We ended up ordering quite a few dishes. We started off with the Risotto Croquettes (pretty good), along with the 'nduja ( like salame pate), pesce crudo (raw fish, similar to sashimi) and duck liver pate bruschette as appetizer. I actually really liked the salame pate, because there was a hint of spice and they gave a good portion. The duck was an entirely different story! This dish was very strong and a bit game-y, which none of us liked.

We shared our entrees, which included the Orecchiette (little ears pasta), Farrotto (risotto with mushrooms) and i think the lamb. All the entrees were very good and we especially enjoyed the Orecchiette. 

We did actually stay for a good 2.5 hours but they eventually kicked us out nicely, since there were some other people waiting.
author: Cheryl C.

description:
YUMMMMM YUMMMMM

If it's possible to have a foodgasm than this place will do it for you.

I've had lunch here once and dinner here once. It's the same menu. .. I think. Or maybe I just ordered the same thing because it was just so tasty.

MMM meatballs. The first time I ate here with my girlfriend we picked apart that meatball and tried to figure out what all was in it so we could go home and replicate. We failed. So I dragged my husband there. He did a little better (it's the Italian in him) at deconstructing the meatball. He still hasn't made them for me but he thinks he knows the elements. I will say that the second time  the meatballs were more salty than the first. 

The salumi plate is amazing, says Mr Kelly. I, found most of it amazing and I even tried the head cheese, but there are just some things I can't get over and head cheese is one of them.

This place is perfect for the lunch time financial dist. crowd. But word to the wise, get there early, like when they open or you'll be standing on the sidewalk waiting for a table. Also note the tables are crammed together! I prefer to sit and eat at the bar. Bonus here is it's closer to the wine.

Note too that this is not inexpensive. Again, if you omit the booze then your bill will be much cheaper.

Speaking of booze. they have these really handy ipad wine lists. You can click through all of their wines by location, price, type etc.. I even found an organic white wine from Sicily (my favorite Italian location). 

-1 star because of the inconsistent food quality of my beloved meatballs
author: Kelly C.

description: Love this place! 3 blocks from home and I could not be happier bout that! Wine list is small, but solid! The Brussel sprouts are amazing. The meatballs are really good too! Salumi selection is Bataliesque! The paccari pasta dish is one of my favs with this great pork ragu. The atmosphere is great, love to sit at the bar counter late! Enjoy!
author: glenn w.

description:
Went to Barbacco for the first time today with colleagues on a last minute decision. Well, as you can tell by the star rating, I'm esctatic that we decided on it. The place was absolutely bustling but we got there at 11:30 and beat much of the rush. As the place filled up I must say that the service did not really lag all that much. There were a few times our server rushed away before actually finishing with us but it wasn't done in a negative way and we were attended to promptly.

The food was quite good - I had the pork meatballs with chard, raisins and pine nuts and others got the paccheri in the pasta section. I loved the meatballs but I didn't hear any amorous eruptions from the paccheri section. But no snorts of utter disdain either so I must deduce that they were fine.

There was also one who ordered the chicken salad sandwich and no complaints on that front, either.

So, all in all, it is worth a repeat trip and the bill was actually below expectation so you can take that to the bank!

The 5 star rating is influenced heavily by value, service and experience above expectations. If I return for dinner, it would likely fall to 4 but as of now, I'm quite happy :)
author: Mark K.

description:
i almost never go out to eat italian food because for the most part i feel like i can make all the pasta dishes at home

with the bruchette, i had a hit and a few misses... 

duck liver pate - i love duck liver and they give you a pretty generous spread of it of too!
cured sardines - i normally like sardines but i did nottt like this one. it was way too fishy for me
house cured lardo - aside from the slices of peaches, this tasted like i was eating nothing but bread and FAT!

but aside from the two bruchette i did not like, it was still a good dinner because i loved the restaurant's atmosphere, the two pasta dishes (the maccheroni alla chitarra with pork ragu and orecchiette with broccoli rabe and fennel sausage ) i tried were really good, and prices are pretty fair.
author: Katherine C.

description: Just had a great lunch here - they're serving a lamb sandwich right now that is awesome.  Also had their leek soup that was very tasty.  Good, fast, friendly service.  You may get a shared table - makes for awkward business lunches - but really good food.  Sister restaurant to Perbacco.
author: Ketan D.

description:
Holy Jesus.

This place is amazing.  The sangria tasted like heaven.  The brussel sprouts were divine.  The meatballs were more than tasty.

The price is reasonable for the excellent quality.  

It was kind of funky to share a table with two other couples, but we were all in such a good mood from the delicious food it was fun to chat about how yummy everything was with them.

I wouldn't recommend the bruschetta because it was the only thing i thought was too expensive for what you get.

A++++++++++++++ WOULD EAT AGAIN
author: Light Bulb J.

description:
Parking is hard to find there, but you can always pay for it when you park at the Embarcadero building. No one validates though. We tried asking. 

Barbacco is right next to Perbacco, which is another place I have been meaning to try. 

Barbacco is nicely decorated, but affordably priced. 

There is a good selection of starters, like bruschettes (my favs being the smoked lonza and duck liver pate) and entrees (gotta try the pork meatballs! Nicely seasoned and tender. Not dry at all). 

I had the orichette pasta with fennel sausage. It was okay, but needed a sprinkling of salt, which luckily they had at the table. 

I loved my dad's pork ragu. It had huge pasta rolls, like rigatoni without the ridges, Tender shredded pieces of pork in a simple tomato sauce and parm cheese. 

My mom's braised chicken thighs were great as well. Very flavorful, and again, not dry. i loved the addition of the marcona almonds. It added a different level of texture and flavor to the dish. 

My sister had the fisherman's stew, which tasted ok, kinda fishy. 

I wanted to try the cheese selections, especially the gorgonzola and chestnut honey,, but sadly, no room! 

Forgot to mention we had the fried brussel sprouts! Soooo goood! 

I will definitely go back!
author: Rachel N.

description:
Phenomenal! The wine selection (and the wine selection process) is really frickin' cool (Try the Peter Paul Pinot Noir, I think you'll love it). 

And the meal was fantastic; the menu is a bit of a pain to read, but once you get it down.. well, just about everything is good because they go after fresh and quality ingredients and you can really taste it.

Lastly - awesome service. The entire time we were there, we felt really welcome, and never rushed. 

Bonus: Lots of street parking nearby.
author: Ryan D.

description:
I've been here twice - that's saying a lot for a casual/fancier place in San Francisco. Sometimes there are so many options in this city, I become paralyzed with fear. Yes, it is a strange conundrum indeed.

This place is kind of a really down to earth place disguised in slight, trendy pretension. Order the mushroom risotto, brussel sprouts drenched in red wine vinegar and oven blasted/roasted. The little ear pasta with kale was devine as well.

We paired the brussel sprouts with a Thirsty Bear Ale - the darker, slightly bitter tasting beer was a great match for the deep, earthy flavor of the oven-roasted brussel sprouts. 

Big groups or with a date, it's a really great place. You can also browse their wine and drinks selection from an iPad. Altho I wish it did more, it's still cool that you can fiddle with an iPad at dinner!
author: Tian L.

description:
My friend really liked Perbacco but I never got into it, so when we tried to think of a place to get together for dinner after work, Barbacco seemed to be a good choice to try.  I was surprised at how difficult it is to book a table on a weeknight.  We ended up with no choice but a 5 o'clock reservation. 

Beware: because the dinner reservation is so early and Barbacco shares the same valet as Perbacco, the valet may not even be there at 5.  My friend was frantically getting confused not knowing where to park when the valet guy was just showing up for work and hadn't had a chance to bring out his podium yet.  

The place is nice. Modern and sleek.  Most of the tables have semi-high chairs and seat six people.  So if you are a party of four, you are sitting with two random strangers.  I find this to be very prevalent in SF's new restaurants now.  Is it a way to save space?  perhaps. 

The menu has a bunch of choices, all meant to be shared.  For starters, we had the croquettes and the bruschettes.  The croquettes with risotto were good, but not mind blowing like France's chickpea fritters.  Perhaps unfair to compare, but that's what came to mind when I was thinking about something starchy and fried.  

As for the bruschettes, I had the cannellini bean one.  The extra raw onions on top really ruined the subtle taste of the beans.  Again, maybe unfair to compare, but in my mind I was ready to drool over something that resembles the fava bean bruschettes from Beretta, and when it comes out less delicious, I get disappointed.  

My friends who had the duck liver bruschettes couldn't stop raving about them.  In fact, they liked it so much that when it came time to order desserts, they order a duck liver bruschette.  The other bruschettes they tried, asparagus, and sardines, were decent but didn't get much comment like the duck liver one. 

For entree, I got the rigatoni pasta with ricotta cheese and asparagus and meyer lemon and mint.  Yes, the ingredients sound, unusual.  But they work extremely well together.  Texture of the pasta is perfect, the ricotta cheese is so light and blends so well with the other subtle flavors of lemon and mint.  Very good dish.  Pretty much what bumped this place to a four star from a three star restaurant. 

Two friends had the steak, which were too salty according to them.  And unlike pasta which comes in a what I considered as entree size portion, the steaks didn't come with sides.  so if you are the kind that expects the meat entree to be surrounded by some sort of starch or veggies, then order something extra. 

One friend ordered the rotolo pasta and it was alright. 

For dessert we had the Cowgirl creamery red hawk cheese (a tiny piece) and the special, the cookie-n-cream cup of ice cream.  Ice cream was delicious, and only $2!

For some reason, our tab still added up to about $150 for four people.  The low prices of the dishes do add up when you order a bunch (plus wine).

Overall, I can think of other places I recently visited that stood out more than Barbacco, but it does have its highlights and it's quite good for a post-work get together in downtown.
author: Candice B.

description:
Hate to say it, but I was underwhelmed by the food. Went for lunch and had the pork ragu pasta. Well, it was basically an acceptable pork stew with big rings of pasta. Nothing to complain about but it tasted like something you'd have at Grandma's house.

To start, I had what sounded like it would be a pasta e fagioli soup but was not quite. My stomach is now blowing up like a balloon from all the beans in this soup, and it didn't really taste that great. Plus, it was tepid, not hot when served.

And the service was really bad. It was an extremely busy lunch hour, but the friendly-enough waitress basically ignored us. The meal took surely an hour longer than it should have because the service was so negligent.

So, I won't be back.
author: Mister K.

description:
I had the roasted lamb sanwich and the fisherman's soup for today. The lamb sandwich was off the hook. The soup was okay,3 stars.  The service was okay too. It was maybe because we sat near the take out/pick-up corner.  We refilled our own water. Not a big deal. 

On a previous occasion, I had the mushroom risotto. It was delicious. Service was prompt and friendly. 

Can't say anything about dinner but this place is a solid place for lunch.  But come early like 11:45a or earlier for seating because it can fill up quick.
author: alex c.

description:
Dazzling. Wine menu on iPads, awesome. Food, adventurous and tasty. Service was amazing... low key and hip!

Will return.

Updated review: I left before ordering last time because cigarette smoke was wafting in from somewhere. disgusting!
author: Jennifer L.

description: Yummmmm....great place for wine connoisseurs! On a girl's trip to San Fran, we stopped by on a whim and definitely enjoyed ourselves. My friend and I shared a bottle of champagne and I ordered the spinach lasagna. YUM! Great place for wonderful food and drinks. The tables were shared with other guests so maybe not the best place if you want a more intimate or quiet dinner.
author: Whitney L.

description:
I recently ate at barbacco for the second time, and I think it's time to drop a little four star review.  Last time, I had a tasty pasta with roasted pork and fresh shaved parm.  Simple fare, created with a short list of well sourced ingredients, delivering balanced flavors.  My colleague and I both liked it.  Today, I returned for lunch again and was pleased.  I had a great sandwich consisting of shrimp, sweet chili, greens and aioli.  The bread was fresh and tasty and the sandwich came with a nice little salad.  We tacked on a side of roasted brussel sprouts and they were nicely browned and carmelized.  Yum.  

Bonus points for having an iPad based wine list.  I don't drink wine, but for a newer place catering to a crowd that surely appreciates technology, I think it's a nice touch.  This wouldn't work if they were going for Michelin stars, but for a reasonably priced sit down lunch in the financial district, it was a nice touch.  Keep up the good work Barbacco.
author: Chad K.

description: I've been here a few times and Barbacco continues to be one of my favorite spots for a delicious, yet low-key meal.  Perfect for a dinner date or after work get-together.  Great service, good wine and fantastic rustic Italian food.  I love the ambiance - communal tables, modern, yet home-y.  House made orecchiette, olive oil poached tuna, and asparagus pesto bruschetta - yum.  And I'm not normally a dessert person, but the lemon olive oil cake with creme fraiche and strawberries is to die for!  Save room and give yourself time for a leisurely meal.
author: Megan C.

description:
I had high expectations cause I like Perbacco.

However, Barbacco seems like the ghetto Perbacco.  This is speaking in food terms.  I guess I can say the service, vibe and wine were not that bad.

Our waitress was graceful and happy, always a plus.  We tried mostly her recommendations.  Started with the chef's selection meat plate, small one.  In general, the selection was very bland.  Flavors were fairly similar and yeah, meh.  Didn't care for it.  Cheap and very generous portion, thus, pretty boring and low quality.

Next, Burrata cheese.  Wow, what a disappointment.  I am not a cheese expert, but I know Burrata is best when it's served within 24 hours, and you end up with a nice buttery, rich mozzarella flavor.  This one was very past due.  So bitter and harsh on the palate.  Also, I really didn't get the extra salty arugula salad on the side.  Extra punishment.  Anyways...

Spinach Lasagna, hmmm.  I could have liked it if I didn't know it was lasagna.  Once I saw the nice crusty layers I got excited, but the flavor was down the hill.  I understand spinach is delicate and all, but I mean the sauce was nonexistent.  

So sorry barbacco.  I will try it again I am sure.  Not for a while though.

One other funny thing was the service stuff getting hypnotized in front of the big tvs watching baseball games.  haha.  :)  they are having fun.

yeah, i don't know.  I have to say: best Italian food is still in the Mission District.
author: Ziya A.

description: The duck liver pate and brussels sprouts were some of the best side dishes I've had. Great atmosphere too.
author: Tom W.

description:
Alice Feiring referred me to this place. My guru for natural wine. I went with 3 friends, one of who owns the Tuscan Wine School in Italy.  

Greeted by a lovely friendly woman, who seated us right away. Warm inviting and comfy.

Digital wine list on ipads, which I loved, my friends struggled with it for some reason. Im a digital gal.

Started with bubbles. La Grange Tiphaine, from Loire. I liked it
Red Domaine Sainte Eugenie, was delicious and I also tried the Brunello Sangiovese which was really fruity, full and wonderful. My friend also loved it. 

Food, well we tried many different things:

boho bel / saffron honey 6   this was good 

pesce crudo - marinated, raw fish
seasonal accompaniments 10   my least fav of everything, but still good

bruschette with sardines, my friends did truffled lardo and went crazy for it. I loved the sardines.

fried Brussels sprouts / capers / anchovy
red wine vinaigrette 4   mmmmm devine

quick braised local squid / tomato / chili
garlic / spicy pan grattato 8  yummy

roasted squash / pan grattato / pecorino
pumpkin seeds / balsamic 4 I adore squash and this was really yummy.

farrotto - farro "risotto" / roasted mushrooms
parmigiano reggiano 11  this was my main, and I totally loved it, perfect blend.

polpette - Sicilian meatballs with raisins and
pine nuts / braised chard / tomato sugo 12 
I dont eat beef or chicken, there were a couple of other meaty things, that my friends loved. 

Most of the dishes are small plates to be shared, some plates are larger, ie the meatballs and risotto. 

I like that their wine list has many by the glass options and also by the half glass if you want to try many things, which I often like to do, and still be able to drive.  I loved that he showed me the bottle and gave me a taste before I committed to the glass.  Most wine bars will offer this.

Barbacco has a nice vibe, and spacious interior.

 I have a bit of critique of our server. He seemed to lack sophistication in how he spoke to us, and his description of the menus, and was at times interruptive. He was attentive though.  Our ipad wine list vanished before we had finished our meal and we had to ask for it to come back, so we could order more wine. I also felt as we had a late reservation 9pm, and towards the end of our evening,  I felt the service kinda lacked.  I am still loving this place.  We will be back and excited to try more of the wines. Quite lovely
author: Madrone H.

description: Service was excellent.  Food was medicore.  Restaurant was loud. The only dish I'd recommend would be the appetizer dish that stuck out - burrata cheese on grilled crostone / blistered cherry tomatoes / basil.   We ordered sandwiches and there was a side of salad with some marinated veggies, which I didn't think complimented the dish.  Their lemon drink was quite sour and delicious.  Their butterscotch gelato -chocolate crunch was good but if the chocolate crunch overpowered the dish.  I wished the restaurant was setup with the skylight but only hallway to the bathroom had the best lighting.
author: pengrin ..

description:
Perbacco's little sister has done good!  Service at the bar was excellent, very attentive and prompt.  Food was reasonably priced and done well.  I loved the celery root salad and the rotolo pasta.  Actually I ADORED the rotolo.  Get it.  You won't be sad.  (I'm just sad that I don't have it in front of me right now.)

I thought the sardines were good, but nothing out of the ordinary.  Ditto with the two bruschette (note that these are $3 a piece).  My friend was a little put out by the fact that our plates were changed between each course, but that didn't bother me.
author: She-Ra ..

description:
I am a big fan of Perbacco, having been many times - I enjoyed my first visit to Barbacco.
I know it is more casual but we were a bit dissapointed to have a bar seat.  However, it was fun as we watched a prep chef do his magic.
We had a sicilian wine which was fantastic.  The cheese and salumi plate was pretty good, though not the best.  The beet salad was excellent.  The meatballs were excellent.  The brussel sprouts were amazing.
All pretty reasonably priced, and a nice environment.  I will return again.
The ipad wine list is cool, but is it necessary?  The list is like 30-40 wines.  I could see this helping at a place with a huge list.
author: Mike A.

description:
The food and wine here is fantastic. LOVED the bruschettas and the fried brussel sprouts. The service was also friendly. They have communal tables as well as a bar.

The only bummer is that it's a bit on the pricey side, which just means I can't come here all the time...
author: Tamara M.

description: Everything we ordered was SO GOOD. The vibe is upbeat, loud, and not pretentious or annoying at all. Definitely need to go back next time I'm in SF!
author: Azita R.

description:
Finally had a chance to try Barbacco. I went for lunch. We had a reservation, which was good, because it gets super busy with the FiDi lunch crowd. 

We started by sharing three bruschetta. We honestly wanted to try all 6 or 7 of them, but settled on three because they had a 3 for $8 deal. We had the duck liver pate with cherries, fresh peas with pecorino and the fresh tomatoes. All were excellent except the peas could have used extra pecorino in them. Wish I could have had them with wine but it was a weekday lunch so none this time!

For my main I had the sardine and squid sandwich - yummmm. Really soft ciabatta roll filled with freshly sauteed baby squid - oh so tender - and grilled local sardines. It had a light lemony sauce on it and a light olive spread. My friend had the pasta with pork ragu. It looked awesome and so I might get it to go tonight for dinner. :)

Needless to say, I am looking forward to going back. Did I mention the prices are super reasonable for such great food - and portions were generous.
author: Miki C.

description:
This is a great place to dine!  Casual, great atmosphere, friendly staff, and AWESOME food & wine.

My friends and I went on a Monday evening, with reserv. @ 8:30pm.  I knocked off 1 star because even with the reserv., we had to wait 'til past 9pm to be seated.  Yeah, it was THAT crowded.

But upon seating, my friend ordered us a round of prosecco, and that's when the fun times really began.  The waiter/owner was SOO nice, always smiling, as if we were his first table of the day, and not his last.  We ordered a whole bunch of small plates, and EVERY single one of them was great.  

My Absolute Favorite?  FENNEL RUBBED PORK RIBS.  A close second?  LASAGNA BOLOGNESE.  A not-too-distant third?  FRIED BRUSSEL SPROUTS.  A nice accompaniment to the not-too-distant third? ze MEATBALLS.

I would come back in a heartbeat, except for the fact that i will prolly lose many heartbeats if i eat here too often.  The friendly server/waiter/owner (they're all dressed so nicely, i couldn't tell them apart) gave away the secret to why my favorite dish was soo good:  it's fried in pork fat.  Yep, the pork rib was fried in its own fat.  No wonder it was so stinkin' good.

If you're here with a group of 9, here's the suggested menu:
Bruschetta w/:
Duck Liver Pate (never though i'd like it, but it was actually really good)
Olive Oil Crushed Spring Peas (nice, refreshing bite)
Marinated summer Tomatoes (my favorite of the Bruschetta)

Salumi Plate:  Chef's suggestion (bologne never tasted soo good)

Polpette (a.k.a, ze MEATBALLS; i think you get 3 per dish)

Fried Brussel Sprouts (wouldn't be surprised if it was fried in pork fat)

Lasgna (it will beat your grandma's recipe)

Rustic Pork Ragu (the only dish i may skip next time...)

Pork Ribs (an order comes w/3 ribs)

Dessert:  Farmer's Market Fruit (we had roasted Peach w/Vanilla Bean Ice Cream drizzled with Honey); i experience a bit of heaven the moment i took the first bite...

Great food, great friends, it's a perfect combination for a memorable time that makes you go: "remember that time when we went to Barbacco..."
author: Laura C.

description:
They took everything we liked about dining at the bar in Perbacco and turned it into it's own restaurant! Only less crowded, less wait and SIGNIFICANTLY LESS EXPENSIVE. The menu (which if you don't speak Italian requires a decoder, or just talk to your waitress) is full of livelier yet just as delicious and high quality dishes for every taste. The meal feels less heavy and the atmosphere less haughty. The wine list is superb, with options of different intermediate carafe sizes to fit your table size and penchant for alcohol. The beer selection offers a range of quality local drafts on tap to try.

Not only would I consider this a great afterwork spot to share with friends but it seemed like a lot of successful dates were going down - perhaps due in part to the reasonable prices. 

I will definitely go back to have the Tuna or try the interestingly named "Angry Mussels" that looked good at the table next doors. The true mark of a good restaurant is if you see other people enjoying themselves and I got that sense here.

(They lose a star for the CRYPTIC menu.)
author: Little P.

description:
I'm always hesitant on swanky looking restaurants because many times, the food can't stand up to the fashionable decor.  Barbacco did not have this problem.  My friend and I went there for a long lunch and we really enjoyed ourselves.

The duck liver pate bruschette had the perfect amount of pate, paired with sweet carmelized onions to cut the bitterness of the pate.  The shoulder porchetta sandwich and the orriechette were also delicious.  The pasta was not evenly cooked so some pieces were harder than others, but I'm willing to let this slide because it was so flavorful.  My favorite part of the meal were the fried brussel sprouts.  Clearly, anybody that says they don't like brussel sprouts haven't tried these - they were SO GOOD.  

Barbacco is one of my new favorite restaurants, I can't wait to go back and try everything else on the menu.
author: Carmen L.

description:
Went here for a little date night with the hubby before going to the movies - loved  it! Made an early reservation and were seated right away. Everyone we dealt with that night was very friendly & our waiter was especially great.

All the small foods/left side of the menu were great for sharing and tasting. We tried 3 different bruschettes (I liked 2 of them) & the 'nduja, which was great (another yelper described it as a salami pate that you spread on crostini - perfect description!). I wanted to try a salad & bread & cheese too, but we decided to move onto the entree at this point.

Entrees: I had the "little ears" pasta which came with black kale, fennel sausage, garlic & pecorino cheese - yum! This dish was great. I was appropriately full at the end. Husband had the braised chicken thighs and he loved them (I had a bite - very tender). Food is all reasonably priced.
