Wine (which is listed on the iPad) is offered in 5 different sizes: bottle, Mezzo (about 3 glasses), Quarto (1.5 glasses), 6 oz. & 3 oz. We ended up splitting 2 quartos of different wines. It was nice because we were forced to drink a whole bottle and we could sample different wines. All the wine was pricey though, so it makes up for the reasonable food.

Dessert menu didn't have anything that I was dying to have, not to mention I was stuffed, but there's always next time...
author: Nancy B.

description:
I had been once for lunch, and it was good but not that memorable (except the duck liver pate bruschetta, which was delicious).  My husband and I went the other night for dinner, using our Blackboard Eats discount.  The hostess was very friendly during our short wait and handed me the newest trend in wine lists - an iPad with all of their wines listed.  I knew it was a gimmick, but it was still fun to play with.  And true to the NY Times article, I did end up ordering more than I would have otherwise.

When we got seated, I was a little disappointed because the previous diner's dirty napkin was still in my seat, but that was pretty much the only down side to the service.  (Except that it was insanely loud in there so it was hard to hear the server and vice versa).

The food was great overall.  We ordered the duck liver pate bruschetta (how could I not?), the roasted pear bruschetta, the oriechette, the polpette and the brussel sprouts.  Everything was great (although the polpette was my least favorite) and more than enough for the both of us.

No desserts - we were stuffed.
author: B. Y.

description: THis place is great.  Everything we've ordered the two times we've been there has been pretty amazing.
author: Michael E.

description:
Pretty swanky tapas/wine bar. Came here after happy hour on a Thursday and mistakenly walked into Perbacco at first (two doors away). Irrelevant to this review, but a funny detail. 

Our reservations for two were a great idea considering the dinner crowd on a Thursday night. The iPad menus were entertaining. 

Had the risotto croquettes (7/10), duck liver pate bruschette (8/10), orecchiette pasta (6.5/10), the meatballs (7/10), and the fried Brussels sprouts (9/10) accompanied by a red wine which name I can't remember nor could I pronounce (the friend that is a girl chose it). 

Definitely worth a return visit.
author: Joe A.

description:
Great big slabs of noodles in tomato sauce and melt-in-your-mouth pork. All is good with my paccheri pork ragu. We had a selection of 3 bruschette, caponata,  summer squash fondo and spring peas, all were super.

While the interior is trendy, the food is honest and authentic. They don't try to overdo Italian food like most places do. Just simple flavors that come from fresh ingredients. If you're looking for fancy and pretentious fusion, go somewhere else. 

Service is excellent and prices are very reasonable especially if you consider the location. It's a bit small as we had to sit at the bar but this is a minor quibble. A great find.
author: Norman S.

description: A place to be professional, hip and sexy with italian food.   I asked what was the most well known thing and it was meatballs with polenta.    I'm good with meatballs but usually I'm not a fan of polenta.  This meal was AWESOME.   Love it, would come back again!
author: Albert W.

description:
Very good food and service. I applaud the hostesses for not letting these two blond bimbettes try and swipe a spot at the bar out from under us, even after one of the bimbettes sat down and got a bit belligerent when they told her to get up. After bimbette one joined bimbette two standing behind me, they bitched and moaned, but then eventually left. Good riddance. 

Anyway, the rest of the service was fantastic. Our waitress was very knowledgeable about the menu. She gave us good suggestions and was attentive without hovering. 

The food was quite good and very, very cheap. Din-din for two (w/o booze) was $40, including tip. Loved the duck liver bruschette with a balsamic reduction.  The bruschette pieces are HUGE.  You really can split one btw two people.  The sardines was yummy and tangy.  And the best dish of all was the rotolo pasta, served like a jellyroll filled with chard and ricotta, baked then pan fried in sage-brown butter.  Oh my god, this was fantastic!

One thing I did not like was the constant changing of share plates and silverware between each dish.  Not only was it annoying and broke up the dinner conversation, it doesnt seem very environmentally friendly.  How much water and dish soap are they going through?  I hope they discontinue this practice.  

Anyway, I definitely will be back for the good food and service!
author: brewgirl b.

description:
Honestly Barbacco probably deserves a higher rating than this.  It's my fault for going when I was still 19 and couldn't partake in any of the wine.  

What was good: the risotto cr- (can't remember the name.  It was like a little ball of browned polenta).   The choice of still vs sparkling water was nice too.

What was eh: roommate's duck sausage.  It was really too sweet and needed more of the delicious arugula salad with which it came.
My meatballs were very good but too salty.

What was nauseating: the duck liver pate crostini.  Maybe I'm just not refined enough, but we both valiantly tried to eat as much of it as we could for the sake of the cherries... and ended up pushing the plate away as far as it would go because we could smell it, and it was making us want to throw up.  I grew up on chicken gizzards and beef heart, but for some reason just couldn't stomach that duck liver pate.

The prices are barely affordable for petite students (poor but small-stomached).
author: Katarina M.

description:
Arrived here around 6:30 on Wednesday night and had a 45 minute wait to get counter seating for 2.  The entrance was packed, and it would've been difficult to squeeze one more person in there.  The front door staff seemed overwhelmed.

We had the Sicilian meatballs, a tiny wedge of cheese will almonds & honey, and the chef's salumi plate with 2 glasses of the barbera.  It was 60 or 70 bucks total.  You don't a whole lot of food for that, but what you get is surprisingly filling.
author: Gopal R.

description:
Met a friend for lunch during the work week at 1:30pm - the place was still packed and even with a reservation we had to wait a little bit.   The wait for us wasn't bad at all, but I felt bad for anyone without a reservation.  I wouldn't wait in line for a late lunch here: the food is good, but not amaaazzzinng.

My friend and I split 3 of the bruschette: 2 of the cannelini beans and 1 asparagus lemon zest.  The rosemary in the beans bruschette was definitely strong...so if you like rosemary, you might want to try that.  I thought the asparagus and lemon zest one was pretty good.

I had a pasta dish that was really good (sorry! I can't remember what it was called...) and my friend had polenta.

Overall the food was good, but I definitely wouldn't wait in line to grab lunch here during the work week.
author: Alvina W.

description:
Wow, what a treat. We arrived an hour early for our reservations because we were done with the DeYoung and ordered a bottle of wine. We finished the wine right before our reservation and they seated us right about the same time. Awesome!

We ordered another bottle of 08 Nero d'avolo because it was a great price point and tasty. We also ordered 4 bruschette: truffled lardo, duck liver pate, marinated summer tomatoes, and peperonata. Omg, all were off the hook. 

I then ordered the polpette- sicilian meatballs.. omg.. to die for! so good! i got to try shaun's risotto (good), gary's milanese (tasty w/the capers), and kevin's paccheri, pork ragu (soo delish!). 

I can't wait to go back! Everything was on point, friendly service, and fun atmosphere (we got a quiet table :))

YUM!

ps- forgot about the brussels sprouts, get them!
author: Art A.

description:
Went here with my  boyfriend on our first official date.  Because at the time he was new to the Bay area it was left to me to find some where for us to dine.  I read about how great the food here was-with a laid back vibe and  good prices I figured this would be a nice place to try out.  

Barbacco made our first date not only relaxing but a great place for us to visit many times over.  We were about 30 minutes late but with a few calls prior to our arrival they held our table.  When we arrived the restaurant was packed yet it was still comfortable.  Our waiter was  friendly and helpful with their menu selection.  He recommended a fantastic Italian Tempranillo that even my non wine enthusiastic boyfriend enjoyed.  He recommended a few dishes which after he described told him bring them out for us.  HIs recommendations were fantastic as they all had their own distinct flavors.  No two plates tasted alike.  My favorite of the night was the duck liver bruschetta.  I sigh just thinking about it.  We plan on going back to have it again and MAYBE to try some new dishes--or maybe to have the same meal.  :)
author: Beverly R.

description:
What is there not to like about this place? Notable aspects: reasonable prices, delicious food, cozy ambience, and cute waiters!

Reasonable prices- I spent less than $20 to share an entree, two apps, and a dessert with a friend. Almost unheard of in the financial district.

Delicious food- All the food was pretty high quality. It's kind of tapas style and the plates are not that big. I had:
-Brussel sprouts: very well done brussel sprouts, with balsamic vinegar. It's quite nice if a little salty for me.
-Pork ragu- al dente, fresh fat pasta tubes. They were soft but a little chewy at the same time. I love this kind of pasta... it's a cross between the sheet pasta of lasagna and other more chewy types of pasta like penne. The pork ragu had some mint in it, which brought out the flavors.
-Risotto croquette- MMMM!! My favorite of the night. Cheesy risotto, breaded and fried. 
-Olive oil cake with cherries- I think I only read this description halfway. Olive oil cake sounds delicious to me- it was basically a fatty cake that tasted like delicious olive oil goodness. Like a butter cake, but without the butter! But I actually don't like cherries that much, which made the dish slightly less enjoyable

Cozy ambience- You get an Ipad to peruse drink options. They have Iron Chef playing on flat screen TVs. We were seated at the bar with a HUGE pig leg in front of us. I adore the place settings and decor; it's dark and intimate inside, but also trendy and a fun place worthy of happy hour.

Cute waiters- my waiter had a killer smile, which he used frequently. Enough said.
author: Cathy S.

description:
Was recommended this place from a coworker who is known for his excellent taste in food and wine. My expectations were set high and I was ready to be impressed! 

Decided to take my boyfriend here during my lunch break, so I made reservations for 1:30. It was very busy when we walked in, and the hostess seemed very aloof and disengaged. We were not sat for almost 20 minutes past our reservation. Normally I am less irritated by this, because things happen and it may not be the hostess/host fault. However, this hostess was not reassuring at all or helpful, and appeared as if she was listening to little voices inside her head instead of the questions we and other patrons were asking. 

Finally sat down, our server was nice but nothing special. I was dissapointed with the lack of vegetarian options, but ordered the raddichio and fennel panini. It was good, but again, nothing special, nothing that I could not recreate at home. Same went for my boyfriends grilled Lamb sandwich. He did comment that the meat was cooked perfectly, yet the sandwich lacked condiments/texture, making it a bit dry and bland. 

The one thing (at least he) was impressed with was the N'dja, the famous spreadable salami. I don't eat meat, but he said it was incredible, full of spice and flavor that never got old. 

All in all, it was a mediocre experience, do not plan on going back any time soon. Too many other places in SF that have stolen my heart!
author: Kate V.

description: Perhaps my memory of the Cannellini Bean Bruschetta was a tad cushioned by my wine intake - or, it's possible that last time it was actually better.  One of my favorite things about it: the HEAT, was lacking.  Too, I had oversold it to my husband, so I don't think he was amazed by it either.  Maybe it was just that day.  But the service is always great - and even though it wasn't what I remembered, the bruschetta was still delicious.
author: Emily Y.

description:
My third visit was this Friday, Aug 28, and I can say that some things are consistently executed really well, and others can be improved. The consistently great items are: 

- Brushetta, all the varieties are good, and we really like the pate
- Salads
- Some of the pastas
- House made cured meats
- Aranchi

Items that are inconsistent are:
- Lasagna, the meat sauce was so salty we couldn't finish it
- Ratatouja, was really olive oily so it tasted more like condiment rather than a side dish
author: Karrot L.

description:
Great vibe and space here. Sandwiches for lunch are fantastic and the tomato soup I had was one of the best I have ever had. 

Great lunch selection, pretty reasonable prices, great location, great ambiance. Solid 4 star lunch place.
author: Ravi A.

description:
My friend suggested this place as we both work in the city.  The restaurant is located very close to where I used to work, and adjacent to one of the Charles Schwab branches (200 California St.).  :)

I have to say our server was a little bit weird and somehow I felt he wasn't very comfortable interacting with customers (just my personal opinion), but he managed to make some good suggestions of the dishes nonetheless.

I enjoyed their arancini (risotto croquettes filled with braised pork, mozzarella and peas), bruschette (I liked the duck liver pate especially), and flat iron steak very much.  Portion is about right for the price we paid.  Overall a pleasant dining experience and the location is situated pretty much in the heart of the financial district, so not much complain to arrange a dine out night within walking distance after work.
author: Vicky H.

description:
As fans of Perbacco we tried Barbacco for lunch and loved it.  Two of the staff helped us with wine selection as my husband and I have very different tastes. They found something we both really enjoyed. 

We also both loved our meals. I had a the risotto with mushrooms & hubby had the pasta bolognese. Both were incredible.  Pasta cooked perfectly al dente and sauces just delicious.

Definitely a place we will visit often.
author: lisa m.

description:
I cannot rave enough about this place.  I just finished my second spectacular meal there. I have been raving to a friend about it for a month and was worried that it would not live up to my memory of my first amazing meal, but indeed it did.  Not only is the food amazing, delicious, beautiful, but it is extremely reasonable.

We had a glass of wine each, focaccia, olives, the chef's salumi plate, pork ragu and a dessert each.  The total???? $56!! AMAZING!  The service was excellent, she interacted with us, but was not intrusive.  

The Chef's plate is amazing and not to be missed.  The pork ragu was delicate, yet hearty.  The peach sorbet was the best I have ever had.

Love this place!!!
author: Amy J.

description:
The pros:
-less stuffy than Perbacco but still maintains the elegance in the decor
-fantastic wine list - especially the 3oz short pours!
-decent sized portions for the money
-good for sharing food

The cons:
-Neighborhood.  Heading to FiDi for dinner is really only enjoyable if there's another reason to be in the neighborhood
-Wait staff did not seem to value their wine knowledge and seemed rather aloof when asked about the different wines by the glass.  A big disappointment given the list was extensive and intimidating
-Closing time.  We were seated at 9PM on a Saturday and we were the last table to leave at around 1030PM.  For an Italian meal on a Saturday night, it felt like we were at a children-themed restaurant like Red Robin where the wait staff was not used to working at 1030PM on a Saturday night.

What we ordered:
- arancini (very good, everyone liked it at our table)
- roasted beets, gorgonzola, almonds, vinaigrette (very good as well)
- fried brussels spouts, capers, anchovy, vinaigrette (was not served piping hot and the combination of the flavors ended up too bitter vs desired vinegar taste)
- flat iron steak, rucola, reggiano.  we both ordered this and agreed it was perfect.  cooked exactly as we ordered and the minimal flavors really worked together to create the perfect steak.  great portion size
- chocolate nemesis cake.  nothing mind-blowing but a deliciously rich chocolate cake to end the meal.

Would go again - if only for the ambiance and exciting wine list
author: Gracie L.

description: I used to get food here on a weekly basis, but the service is so atrocious, I will not be returning.  My firm also used to get catering from here, but that won't be happening again either.  The food is never ready when it should be and the delays have caused too many problems for me to list.  The worst part is the unapologetic staff who just shrug and offer no sympathy or compensation for their mistakes.  I have tried to deal exclusively with Pandora, but that has not helped at all.  The sad part is, the restaurant is never busy when I arrive, so they're basically too busy doing nothing to take care of business and get my food ready.
author: Otto D.

description:
Dim lighting, wine menus on ipads, family style seating, nice wait staff, excellent food. 

Everything was quite perfect the moment we walked in the door. The bar was busy with people eating and drinking. Once we sat, our waiter was super nice. Recommended a fabulous red wine which I wish I could remember. Our food was fantastic.

The seating is family style so if you are trying to get to know someone on an intimate level, you may want to pass on this place and save it for a later date (if you make it that far ;)  However, it's very casual in an elegant sort of way. Lots of different types of people which lead to the wonderfully cool atmosphere of Barbacco.

The wine menu is all on ipads which they give to each group. It's a cool idea but I found myself getting lost going back and forth and forgetting that I was there to enjoy the company I was with!  Given that the technology was there, I wish they had a tiny description of each wine.

They have a great menu. Dishes are available in a variety of sizes which you can share.  Contemporary Italian in a really nice, simple, yet delicious way.  Nothing was muddled or over seasoned. Everything tasted fresh and clean.

My experience here was great. I'd go back in a heartbeat.  Just for the meatballs. And the beets.  I love beets. :)
author: Kirsten S.

description: Barbacco is the kind of restaurant you always hope to find when you visit a new city... creative menu, good wine, nice ambiance and good service.  The salads were fresh and inspired.  My husband had the endive, gorgonzola, and walnuts and I had the arugula with parmesan.... both outstanding.  I choose the Sicilian meatball pasta dish and was transported straight to Italy.  It was delicious and like nothing I have ever tasted before.  The prices were reasonable and the portions filling.  We definitely will be back!
author: Mary J.

description:
Came here on a weekday evening for dinner. The food was generally delicious -- the meatballs and brussels sprouts in particular were wonderful. Salumi plate was unimpressive, though (Boccalone is much better). 

This place has a bizarre drinks list. They only serve wine and beer, and don't have many by-the-glass options; my friend tried a honey ale and I tried a sparkling red wine out of curiosity (both at the bartender's suggestion) and they were both awful. 

Also, I really don't mind communal or bar seating, but the bar chairs are so tightly packed that you can barely eat without hitting another person. Overall I would come here just for food (takeout maybe?) but the rest of the experience was sub-par.
author: Alexa F.

description: Terrific service, great food, wines and cocktails!   I am a fan.  We ordered a little bit of everything -- and while I wish for more selections of lighter less sweet desserts -- the entire staff was very professional  and a great experience -- we'll be back!
author: T S.

description:
Three times for lunch - always felt it was too greasy.  I tried the grilled shrimp sandwich today, hoping it was the 'clean' option.  But both sides of the bread were coated with oil, and the shrimp was tossed in mayo.  
I wish there were healthy options for this chic place.
author: Leah B.

description: This is just want we needed in the Financial district!  We have high end... and we have low end.. but we do not have much in the middle.  Barbacco offers a bit higher end food at very reasonable prices.  It is a little more then the average lunch I go to... but not by much.  It is a good treat place when you are looking for something better then average, but you do not want to drop too much cash.
author: John F.

description: My first time here, met a couple of girlfriends after work. We ordered small plates first to go with our champagne, the prosciutto and the brussel sprouts fried in duck fat and vinaigrette were my absolute favorite! I was a bit disappointed to find out that the seafood (tuna on the menu that night) was cooked ahi style. I was hoping for something grilled drizzled with flavorful sauce or something. Nonetheless, the service was awesome, our waiter new the menu well and made great recommendations. Decided to order the steak and chicken for dinner. The steak they normally cook medium rare or rare only, had to tell our waiter to cook it medium. The chicken was on the dry side but tasty. Next time I will try one of their pasta dishes, I heard they are delish as well. Would have given it 3/12 to 4 stars but again, seafood selection was pretty weak and portions are on the light side. I do would like to give 5 stars to our waiter though!
author: Joy E.

description: Hit or miss. The soup of the day was like green mucus. It came with 3 pieces of asparagus and the rest was just broth. The chicken sandwich was good but did not compare to the pork shoulder sandwich that I got last time. The service was incredibly slow today and the place was packed so it was hard to hear during our business lunch. Plus we had to share a table. Not really sure this will be a good go-to lunch place anymore.
author: Debbie C.

description: Truffle ball and lasagna. Brussels and pork ragu
author: Jenny B.

description:
+
Good vibe, menu and wine (pairing options). 
Staff knowledgeable on the wine list. 
Valet parking very courteous and convenient. 

-
Food is ho-hum.

Fine place to meet up, but if you're a foodie, this is a convenient, decently priced "meh".
author: Jules H.

description:
As I perused the large lunch menu, my eyes kept returning to the fried brussels sprouts. Thoughts of the beautifully executed fried brussels sprouts at SPQR helped me decide that I needed to try Barbacco's version. My dining partner turned her nose up at the thought of the sprouts, which is just as well because they were plate-licking delicious and reminiscent of the famed version at SPQR. 

The seating situation leaves a little to be desired. Lunchtime diners were packed in elbow to elbow, giving me flashbacks of that horrendous evening at A16 when we were practically sitting on top of our neighbors. 

If you're considering Barbacco for a first date, look for another spot.
author: Lee H.

description: Surprised there aren't more reviews given the crowds that have discovered this place...seems like the perfect 2010 restaurant.  I was never that thrilled with Perbacco, but this offshoot thrilled me for lunch.  Wanted to order everything on the menu, but settled for the soft polenta with mushroom ragu, shared the roasted cauliflour with my host, and he had a bowl of minestrone soup.  Granted, would have need more food if we were starving, but a perfect, healthy, delicious lunch at a great price.
author: Robin W.

description: Great place! Ambiance is nice and the you order drinks on an iPad.  Cool idea.  Pasta was very good.  Cooked well and the lamb in it was very tasty.  Salumi Platter was good too, maybe a little fatty but thats why you order it in a way.  Drinks are reasonably priced and you can order wine in many sizes - also a great idea.  Fun place and a must ;)
author: Jordan S.

description: Outstanding. We were looking for a light dinner and were referred here. The food was outstanding as was our server Kevin. The brussel sprouts were the best we have ever had  - good enough that we has a second order and skipped desert.
author: Hal F.

description: I came here for lunch with a reservation. We were seated promptly and the selection of vegetarian dishes were good. They did forget our focaccia bread but i'll forgive them since the food was delish!
author: Vanessa J.

description: Great little Financial District spot.  Loved the chicken thighs, polenta logs, salads, Brussels sprouts, topped by great and friendly service.  One downer, please lose the table I Pad -- pretentious and unnecessary and only encourages the use of electronics in a restaurant setting.
author: Charna G.

description: Went there on Friday night to meet up with couple of girlfriends. I'm not a drinker, but seems like they got a pretty good list of Wine, and beer. They use iPad as the menu (Fancy!). We ordered some small plates to share. I can't recall what they are since I'm not the one who ordered them. But I did order my own dessert and that was the Baked persimmons. I think this is seasonal so they might not have it all the time.
author: Lovetoeat A.

description: We traveled from Los Angeles, CA and absolutely loved it.  The food was delicious and the staff was friendly.  We ate the lasagna and the meat family style.  Definitely will go back if I go to SF.  Must try their ginger lemonade.
author: Maritza C.

description:
I walked in to get a quick bite, expected straightforward Italian cuisine.  It was much more.  Blending the fresh ingredients of CA farms and infusing classic northern Italian cuisine, the food was sublime.  I had an amazing salad of fresh buffala mozzarella with sauted golden and red beets.  And I rarely eat beets.  This was an amazing dish.  I then enjoyed an entree of duck sausage with grilled potenta.  Hearty, flavorful, filling, and very rich.  It also included sauted red onions which was a nice touch to cut some of the richness of the duck.  

Ordered the wine on an iPad as well, which was fun.  A bit gimmicky, but fun anyway.  

Prices were not unreasonable.  For what I had, I say the prices were downright cheap.  With another appetizer, this could have been easily a meal for two to share.  And, you would have gotten out of the there for less than $50 for two.  Not bad.    Highly recommend this place.
author: Christopher C.

description: Best flank steak ever!  And the brussel sprouts were awesome as well. Attentive service, nice atmosphere.  Will definitely return!
author: Linda C.

description: Barbacco is just what you would expect from the younger hipper sister of Perbacco.  The crowd is a mix of business and pleasure.  Everything we tried on the menu was pretty good.  I especially liked the olive oil cake for dessert.  It made quite an impression on our entire table even though they had originally insisted they didn't want any dessert they were all persuaded to try it, then all dug in.  There was only one miss with the "angry" mussels.  Mussels in my opinion, like oysters, need to be just the right size.  Too small and they seem shriveled and paltry.   Too big though and they are a mouthful, chewy and kinda gross to eat.  These mussels were too big.  A bit much.  Other than that no complaints about the salumi, olive oil tuna, heirloom tomatoes, polepette or brussel sprouts.  The wine was also delish though it was odd to have an iPad at every table for the wine list/explanation.  I don't associate the constant beaming of information with a pleasant evening of dining.  It made it feel as I should be doing something other than paying attention to my tablemates.  It's also very loud in the restaurant.  So don't go with anyone you don't want to get close with or discuss anything you wouldn't want your neighbors to hear.
author: Jean K.

description: Wow. Obviously families (as small as they are - 3) are not welcome here for lunch on weekdays. We came in at 12 looking for a short lunch in the city. Busy but no line. "sorry I don't have any table, it'll be at least 45mn". "What about we sit at the bar, the 3 chairs there". "Hmm, sorry we have a lot of reservations" (waiting for us to leave). Ok, we got the message and it really wasn't subtle. I'll make sure to also take my business diners elsewhere. NB: don't assume all kids don't know how to sit and stay still while eating.
author: D L.

description: We went there on 12/22/2012 for a dinner after spending a day in the wine country.  We had a 6:30 pm reservation but because of the SF traffic we were almost 45 minutes late.  After we arrived at the restaurant we checked in with the hostess and let her know we were late for our reservation because of the weather (raining) and traffic.  She can't be more nice and understanding (sorry, can't remember her name).  She said she will put our name down and will sit our party of 5 as soon as the next table opened up.   The food was very good and service was attentive.  After dinner my daughter want some "ugly cookies" from Perbacco .  The manager was very accommodating, he went over next door and order those cookies for us.  That is SERVICE.  We will definitely go back when we are back to the Bay area to visit our daughter again.
author: Chuck T.

description:
Randomly went to Barbacco today, I had never heard of it and ran a search on Yelp for "Italian food financial district."  Barbacco came up so I made a reservation . . . glad I did!  I had the lasagne (homeade sausage--to die for) and fried brussel sprouts--both were incredible!  The wine list was decent, but not outstanding (thus, the 4 stars).  

The prices are very affordable!  I recommend that you try it:)
author: Dionne M.

description:
Coming to Barbacco was a series of question marks. I'd heard of Perbacco but of this place, I knew nothing of the food, experience, service, drinks...well, anything.

I left blown away.

My dinner date and I came here and had a series of small dishes that were phenomenal.

Ribolitta - a bread pan-fried in olive oil. dude.
Arancini - risotto croquettes that were perfectly cooked
three of the bruschette: whipped salt cod, anchovy/celery/egg, and broccoli rabe... the first two were salty and light, the last covered in cheese. Wow.
Rotolo: rolled pasta filled with chard and ricotta and sage-brown butter. Rich, hot, and sooooo satisfying.
Polpette: Sicilian meatballs with raisins, pinenuts, braised chard and tomato sugo...this aint your mama's meatballs

and to finish we had panforte by napa cakes (sticky cake with hazelnuts covered in a light powdered sugar) and a spiced chocolate gelato and meyer lemon sorbetto. Both evaporated on the tongue but left behind wispy trails of flavor long after the gelato was gone.

Service was phenomenal too. The guys serving us was polite, attentive, and recommended a great french wine to pair.

This place has amazing food and despite the noise would make a great date place. My dinner date can back me up there. ;-)
author: Aaron F.

description: Totally agree with the 4 star average. Better-than-average food, better-than-average service, nice environment, all good. Nothing hit me as "OMG WOW!" but thats not a bad thing, it was totally B+ all around.
author: Jacob M.

description: Chicken was a little dry, carrots and beets overcooked, but at this price point the food was pretty good. If I'm in the area I would go again.
author: Projectshave L.

description:
I'm over this place.

I'll give you that it is a bustling somewhat hip downtown spot, but I've never been there when I didnt have to wait for ages - and have always had a reservation yet typically waited for half an hour from our booking time. Last time I was there the same clueless hostess asked me three times if I'd been helped while I waited for my table.

The service is generally mediocre - and the food and ambience are not so special that you feel you want to wait. The table set-up - set diagionally into the walls - perhaps so that they can get more seating capacity into the room - is bizarre, and means that you are offset from your dining companion and occasionally sitting closer to your neighbour stranger than the person you've come to dine with.

Maybe OK if you've never been there but there aren't enough positives in this place to make me want to go back after 3 or 4 visits.
author: Reg D.

description:
these are a few of my favorite things:

sicilian meatballs - so juicy and tender and tasty. with pine nuts and white raisins. resting on a bed of sweet swiss chard and homemade tomato sugo. it's one of the bigger portions - three giant balls. ooooh yeahhh.

arancini - fried risotto, mozzarella, and short rib balls. the best $3 i've ever spent.

pork ragu - shredded braised ribs in a sweet, sweet sauce, with large tubes of al dente (seriously al dente) pasta. party in your mouth. 

fried brussel sprouts - sauteed in duck fat, but the richness is cut so well with the red wine vinegar sauce. eat your greens!

bar seating and ipad drink menus - oh-so-2011.

all for under $70! what's not to heart? 

(save your stomach and skip out on the bruschette - they're filling, but there are so many better things to fill your tummy with on the menu!)
author: Diana L.

description: Chose this restaurant based on Yelp ratings and had a great experience. Ordered the cold mixed veggies as appetizer, pasta with braised pork for main, and lemon olive oil cake for dessert. Wine menu was not that large but was able to find something our group ended up enjoying (wine list is on the iPad but had to place order with the waiter). Overall a very good experience, nice atmosphere, good food & service, and definitely fair priced that won't break the bank for a good meal.
author: Kent W.

description: Inexpensive, fucking amazing food. Expensive, decent wine.
author: Sam S.

description:
Mmmm delicious! I've been here twice, once for wine, once for wine + food, and it was awesome both times. Everything we ate was delicious, and the wine list is amazing. The wine comes in multiple sizes, so you can taste everything, or have a nice hefty glass of your fav.

Breathing nicely: really helpful waitstaff, delicious food, great wine list
Corked: Busy - get there early or make reservations, seats are a bit cozy, totally unnecessary tv behind the bar
author: Sarah K.

description:
I love this place! The food is absolutely amazing and the wine list is exquisite!! I love how modern this place is and how you can share dishes with your friends. 

looking forward to coming back!
author: Audrey T.

description: I would never normally judge a book by its cover, nor a restaurant by its takeout. However, if you can win me over on a single dish that's traveled down the street and around the corner to save me from midnight starvation during a long night at work, you get five stars. Barbacco's Farrotto (farro "risotto"  with roasted mushrooms and parmigiano reggiano) may now be my favorite menu item in all of SF. Try it - you won't be sorry.
author: Brittany M.

description:
This place has quickly turned into my fiancé and my favorite restaurant in the city!  The menu is a really fun and different mix of small plates to share.  Everything we have tried so far is really amazing but definitely recommend these:

 - Arancini - small fried balls of risotto, cheese, pork.  Insanely good and addicting. 
 - Burratta - if you are a mozzarella lover like us you have to try this.  
 - Spinach Lasagna - my server told me this is the best lasagna he has ever had....I couldn't agree more.  
 - Tagliata Steak - simple but amazing.  Perfectly cooked and seasoned thinly sliced steak.
 - Polpette - delicious meatballs served with only sauce so make sure you order some foccacia with it to soak it all up.
author: Dan L.

description:
A casual but nicer place to have lunch in the FiDi that's reasonably priced.  Came in with a couple co-workers in a collective effort to not eat lunch in front of our computers while answering e-mails.  It was busy enough so that we had to wait about 10 minutes for a table, but they did offer some iced teas on the house which was nice.

Shared dishes so I had half of the Caponata and half of the Poached Chicken.  The Chicken won.  I thought I would like the Caponata just because it sounded amazing (eggplant, mozzarella, pine nuts, raisins and basil...right?), but the Chicken was just better.  I'm thinking it was the dolcelatte, which I found out is a type of cheese.  A sweet, creamy, delicious cheese with higher than normal fat content, even for cheese.  Definitely would explain the superiority of the chicken sandwich.  Cheese just makes things better.  Which reminds me I will have to come back to try the buratta.  Yum.
author: K P.

description:
I went to Barbacco for supper and wine with a few good friends.  We enjoyed the wine list on the iPad!

We decided to split everything and started with an heirloom tomato salad, bruschetta and the beet/mozzarella salad.  They were all good, but the beets/fresh mozzarella were by far my favorite.  We then had the meatballs, squid and pork ragu pasta.  I'm not normally a meatball fan, but these were very tender and yummy.  The squid was in a spicy sauce.  

We sat at a high table that sat 6 ... so we had 3 others at the table and that party turned over midway through our meal.  Both were very friendly, but it would have been difficult if the groups had been rude or even unfriendly.  You can't have much of a private conversation here, and it's rather loud.  

But, it was great for a girlfriends' night out and I will definitely go back!
author: Debby C.

description: Shrimp sandwich - the best sandwich i've had in a while! Juicy shrimp and squid, nicely toasted bread. Definitely coming back.
author: Shirley W.

description: Great environment to eat and have a glass of wine. Food portions were a little on the smaller size, but good overall!
author: Donnie W.

description:
Luba R. dragged me back here for lunch last week and I gotta say I was more impressed this time around.  The chicken sandwich was surprisingly good (and decent portion size) and the chardonnay we had was just what I needed before going back to work.  The service was also better this time around.

Looks like Barbacco is going to be put into the lunch rotation.
author: Toby C.

description: A great place to hang out with friends.  Dishes are like tapas.  Meatballs and pasta is awesome!!!!
author: JAN I.

description: One word: brussels sprouts.  OK, that's 2 words, and really it's brussels sprouts rendered in duck fat -- OMG!  One of the best things ever!  The caesar salad was also yummy, as was the foccaccia bread, as was my pasta with a pork ragu sauce.  But it's the brussels sprouts I dream about...
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Tip: Grab a reservation early on in the evening and order the duck conserva and rustic pork ragu. This will easily be filling for two. 

Environment: It gets crowded and moderately noisy.

We ordered the suppli (basically a fried mushroom risotto ball) appetizer and sliced pear cake dessert which weren't anything special. The pear "cake" is better described as a moist "muffin." 

Despite the items above, this is my newest favorite place in the city when I crave duck or freshly made pasta. Also, I've been to Perbacco and I like Barbacco better. Strange that some people are reviewing for Perbacco on this page.

Anyway, the duck conserva is cooked well, topped over the spinach and mild balsamic dressing. The rustic pork ragu sauce is as others have described, hearty and filling but light in taste. The real kicker is the freshly  made pasta which they recently changed to maccheroni alla chitarra. It has a thicker texture and a slightly stronger, more prominent taste than your store bought pastas (love it!). I think I was told that the Chef slaves away in the back, feeding the dough through guitar strings. :) I'd go back just for these dishes alone. Anyway, this restaurant inspired me to make my own pasta -- so thanks for pushing me to buy 22lbs of '00 superfine farina flour! :D
author: L C.

description: This place was excellent for food, staff, and wine list. . You should go !
author: Bob R.

description:
Two words: 'nudja nera

F'ing amazing.
author: Michael A.

description:
I'm not sure why but I didn't want to like you when you opened.  However, I've made my way in a few times now and I'm quite impressed.  Your competition around the corner at "Credo" should take lessons from you.

Service was prompt and professional.  Food was imaginative, prepared properly, and well seasoned.  Prices are fair and portions are more than adequate.  

If I had to complain about anything it would be the shared table thing- So I just sit at the bar.  

Enough said.  Try it.  You'll like it.  Just save me a seat a the bar.
author: Spidermonkey J.

description: Ok, who likes iPads?  Now who would like their dinner menu to be an iPad?  ME.  One of the cool things about this place; aside from the casual and well appointed atmosphere and AWESOME Italian dishes.  A girlfriend of mine (who is local to downtown SF) took me here and I'm grateful.  We did apps, entrees, desert and wine.  And there's not real criticisms I can put down here.  It's easy to walk to, affordable, great staff, and great food.  I'll be back.  I think I stole that line from someone.
author: Patrick M.

description: Barbacco is a GREAT DEAL (surprisingly). They have their Wine list on iPads which adds to an ultra chic, modern, upscale ambiance.  The sister to Perbacco seems to cater to a bunch of Financial District SEMI-affluent attorneys and bankers whom think their poop don't stink...but other than that, I had a great experience. Food is amazing, esp the deep-fried Brussels for a Friday lunchtime indulgence. Our waiter was very knowledgeable and super nice.  The reason for four instead of five: The hosts could improve in their customer service....remember folks...smile - its infectious!  A great welcome sets the tone for the entire experience. PS: be sure to make a reservation well in advance if going during the lunch rush...or you will be standing around with those aforementioned up-ities for some time and that is oh no fun. Unless you are looking to marry rich.  ;)
author: Michael K.

description: I've been there a few times. It's a wonderful place. Great service. Great atmosphere. Make sure and make a reservation. Food is wonderful and so is the wine collection. Parking is bad but it is in FiDi so it's easier to Bart or walk.
author: Rob L.

description: My go to place for out of towners.  The food is always above average and the service is excellent. I am not giving it a five because it isn't my number one Italian restaurant but it is definitely number 2 on my list!
author: Molly M.

description:
I've only done take out, but I do take out very often here. The food is delicious and VERY reasonably priced. The staff is friendly and helpful. I've never had a problem with my order. The menu changes every now and then (sometimes for the worse -- I miss the roasted pear salad and cannolicchi with albacore!), but the variety is nice and it keeps the menu seasonal.

I often go next door to Perbacco (sister restaurant) and I don't think the quality of the food is that different, but Barbacco considerably less expensive. However, the atmosphere at Perbacco is a little nicer if you're dining in.
author: Rob C.

description:
Barabacco is the perfect choice for those of us who are tired of paying Taddich Grill prices, yet don't want to eat Financial District fast food for lunch.  

We did have to wait about 10 minutes for a seat at the bar, but the meal was well-worth the wait.  

For starters, we split the 'NDUJA, which is their housemade Calabrian salami on crostini. Order the smaller portion--is spreadable, delicious, and huge, and you WILL eat the entire thing.  

We also had the DUCK LIVER PATE, which was so good I scraped every bit from my plate, and could have eaten about 4 more orders.

For entrees, I had the seared sardines and squid sandwich, and I believe my husband had the pork meatballs.  My sandwich was good, but the sardines were so huge that they probably could have used some de-boning.  My husband liked the meatballs, but I can only assume that what we had as appetizers was so extraordinary that the entrees were not quite up to par.  

That said, I will return again and again but will probably stick to the appetizers.
author: Hannah A.

description: minus stars for extreme loudness even first thing in the evening - yelling across the table is no fun - tables are spaced so closely together that the servers have to pass food and drinks over diners' heads - bathroom is dark beyond being atmospheric - food was pretty good (not great)
author: Nancy M.

description: Great atmosphere and excellent service. I made a reservation online and upon my arrival I was seated immediately. I ordered the apple/celery salad and it was excellent. Highly recommend this spot for a lunch meeting in Financial District.
author: NewTo S.

description:
I've only been there for lunch...and it's reasonably priced for Fidi lunch although the service can be slow.   Hmmm....here are the memorables:

- Brussel Sprouts - we get this all the time
- Lamb Sandwich - very good and tender
- Pork Shoulder sandwich - good as well
- Meatball - very good 

There are others...but I have forgotten.  Oh, make a reservation...otherwise you may be waiting for awhile.
author: Sim T.

description: I made a reservation here for 7:30 and we we're seated at that time. My friend and I came a little early and so they had us browse on their ipad selection of wines. They seemed to have a healthy selection so it took us a while to look at it. When we got seated the server Stephanie greeted us and was very very helpful with suggestions! The feel was very modern and gave off a great retro vibe. We ordered a couple of bruschette for appitizers and they were just absolutely delicious! The food was delicious and the wine she suggested to pair with my food was great. Everything about this restaurant was perfect from the decor to the service. Great job to the hostess too who was very busy but kept a level head!
author: Ezequiel R.

description: I've been going to Barbacco for years and it is one of my favorite restaurants in SF, especially for a nice lunch. N'duja, duck conserva salad, piastra seared squid, polpette and brussell sprouts. I love them all. Wonderful staff and wonderful orange wines. Thank you.
author: Loubna M.

description:
DEE-LISH-US! We tried a little bit of everything:
Arancini, ascolane, beet salad, polenta, brussel sprouts & panino.
YUM all around. My most favorite thing were the brussels sprouts. PLEASE ORDER THESE. They are SO GOOD!

For dessert, a scoop of spiced chocolate & butter scotch-chocolate crunch gelato. YUM!

Our server, Franco was wonderful - super knowledgeable, funny, and had great rec's!

I can't wait to go back!
author: Isabel M. L.

description:
A solid four stars.

My party of three had the following:

-Arancini "risotto croquettes" (mm... not really a fan. wasn't that impressed)
-Brussel Sprouts (delicious and I don't even LIKE brussell sprouts)
-Duck liver pate / balsamic onion marmellata (spreadable heaven on a piece of toast)
-Lasagna Bolognese (probs my favorite entree that we ordered)
-Orecchiette "little ears" (kind of fun to eat)
-Meatballs (really peppery, imo)

For the most part, everything was really tasty. Although i didn't really like the arancini as much as everything else, they were nevertheless very tasty.

A bit disappointed that they were out of the 'nduja--a spreadable pork house cured salame--but honestly, I came on a Saturday night for dinner at 6pm, how could they be out? I've heard really good things about the salame so was tres disappointed I didn't get to try it.

I was also a bit puzzled about the function of the iPad. You can't order from it or anything but you can look up all the alcoholic drinks and get information on it. Seemed like overkill for what they're using the iPad for.

Yeah, definitely a solid 4 stars.
author: Amy L.

description: Besides the great wines by the glass I was very disappointed with lunch here. The pork sandwich was very uninspired and the fisherman's stew was more like tomato soup with potatoes and a small amount of 'white fish". The service was just mediocre. Next.
author: Raymond L V.

description: Barbacco is a great place to have dinner with friends.  Their rigatonici dish with asparagus is amazing!  They also have very creative bruschetta that is definitely worth trying.
author: Jessica B.

description:
Came here on Friday night and we sat at the bar area. Our waitress was super nice and friendly and she was the best part of the meal. 

We ordered a few things:
- Bruschetta (3 kinds: anchovy, beans, peach): A few were recommended by our waitress. They were all great. I think they were my favorite item.
- Duck Pate: I didn't realize how this came as an entire dish (vs. one piece like the bruschetta). Anyway, it was so rich and in some ways its like adding more bruschetta (in addition to the previous order) so it was too much and it is so rich, you can only eat a little - at least that's how I felt. I wish they would make this a choice for the 3 bruschetta options.
- Pork Ragu pasta: It's okay. Not mind-blowing. 
- Brussel Sprouts: Some of it is too charred. Upon initial serving, it was just okay. Then I had some pasta on my plate, and then the brussels mixed with some of my pasta, a few minutes passed, I ate some brussels and they were so much tastier! Either the flavor settled or some ragu got on it. Either way - it got tastier.

We opted to skip dessert and go elsewhere. Overall, it was a fun meal, but I think I'd be more inclined to try another place before coming back. But our waitress was the nicest. She bumps it up to 4 stars.
author: Veronica H.

description: I love this place for a quick meal and a drink. Their food is quite nice for the price, though I kind of noticed that the portion was reduced recently. Local squid dish is my favorite.
author: Esther L.

description: Delicious pasta and yummy wine for a girl's night. Trendy, hip and I like the iPad idea to make your wine selection. The tapas style menu gives you the option to pick several dishes to share and taste. My favorite was the burrata cheese / spring vegetable salad with herb vinaigrette. The dish was fresh and light with so many flavors in one bite. Great service and be sure to make a reservation!
author: Lisa C.

description: love Barbacco! if you can get past the intense noisiness of the place, you'll have a good time. the seating is very communal and casual, though by the looks of it you might think differently. lots of yuppy looking people of the Fidi crowd come here after work to grab a bite and some wine. overall, it's still a pretty chill spot. the food is really very good. i particularly enjoyed the orecchiette and the burrata.
author: Regina C.

description:
Came here in april for my bday lunch with  my co-worker.
We shared the Radichio salad and the Rotolo pasta filled with asparagus and ricotta cheese. Was yummy and light. Thoroughly enjoyed the casual dining experience ..

Have to come back and try their other specialties. They also have a great wine selection .

Server was very attentive and did a great job.
author: Veee W.

description:
Finished up a get together at the Bently Reserve a little late and needed a place to fit and feed 7 people around 9 last night.  Popped up Yelp and this was right around the corner.  Great reviews so we figured we'd check it out.

Came in and the wait staff started working on putting a table together for us.  Pretty spiffy decor and the iPad for booze/wine was interesting. Our waiter(s) came over and explained the menu.  We went with a house selection of bruschetta and the breaded and fried risotto for appetizers.  Much better than what we expected!  Everyone ordered or split an entree and they were good sized.  The risotto was tasty and my milanesa was quite tasty.  The only downside was the price for the 3 meat balls was a little much.  

Great service and great food.  Can't argue with 4/5 stars.
author: Jeff W.

description: Great location and nice atmosphere, but mediocre food with limited and uninspired menu. I had the olive oil poached tuna salad which was flavorless and greasy. My Arnold Palmer  was 90% lemonade and had to be sent back. Don't go here if you are looking for great food.
author: Chris H.

description:
As promised, here is my review of Barbacco.

Now let me preface this review by saying that I hope I'll be able to give Barbacco at least four stars after my next visit, or even five (like its big brother, Perbacco).  

I went here on Friday, four days after it opened.  I came with some friends from work, and we were prepared to dine in or take out, depending on the availability of a table.  Because the wait was estimated at 20 minutes, we decided to take out.  

I reviewed the menu.  It all looks delicious, and I'm sure it is, but I'm on this new year's resolution diet, so I had to be choosy.  I chose the fisherman's stew.  I asked the lady at the cash register what the difference was between a small and a large.  She indicated that the difference was between a tall pint-sized container filled partway and a tall pint-sized container filled to the top.  I decided to go with a large, because I was hungry and fisherman's stew is generally a low-cal kind of item.  It was $9 vs. $6, and I was feeling well-off.

Well, my food came (it took a bit long, maybe 10 minutes, but heck, the place is brand new) and I was surprised by how light and not soup-like the bag looked.  When I got back to my office, I had a maybe 5" by 5" container filled maybe an inch to an inch and a half with soup.

I've gotta say, either they need to reevaluate what they call a "large" soup, or they screwed up my order. 

At least the stew was super-duper tasty.  I enjoyed every last morsel.

I will be back.
author: Sarah S.

description: 3.5 stars, rounding down.  Nothing really noteworthy.  Nothing bad, nothing great.  Go if you like/want pasta.  Meat dishes are bland.
author: V G.

description:
The easiest reviews to write are the best and worst. Barbacco is in the best category. Their brussels sprouts are to die for. The shrimp panini is delicious. A great place to go for lunch. The price is reasonable, and the service is good. They even have a frequent buyer card if you do lunches to go, which I often do. It's a bit loud if you eat there, but that didn't bother me because I was busy eating those delicious brussels sprouts.

I like that they change their menu, but why do they have to get rid of my favorite items. Each time I find a substitute, they will eventually get rid of it. No more shrimp panini, BLT, or meatballs. Good thing they still have the brussels sprouts.
author: Lisa F.

description:
Came here for a very nice lunch today. Service was very smooth, particularly considering it was day 2 of the "hard" open. Ambiance is open and modern, and as another reviewer said, a very nice casual interpretation of the big sister Perbacco's set up.

I started with a burrata appetizer that came with arugula and some nice griddled toasts. The burrata was very fresh, and reminded me of the real stuff in Italy -- definitely the best I've had in the states since I came back, and like a few others on the menu, the app came in 2 sizes (6 dollars and 12 dollars) -- the smaller size was perfect/generous for one.

As my main, I went for the polpette which came with pine nuts, sultana raisins, some chard, all in a tomato sugo. Very flavorful, and at 12 dollars not an altogether bad deal.

Also at the table were the ribollita (looked great, more modern interpretation), a nice beef stew, and a stuffed pasta. All three of us were out the door for 60 dollars with tip, including 2 appetizers, 3 entrees, and 1 drink. All in all, I think a great addition to the fidi lunch drudgery, and a really nice, more affordable way to get the perbacco experience -- i'm looking forward to sampling the takeout and sandwiches.
author: Sophie S.

description:
Cute little place that filled up almost as soon as the clock hit 11:30. I stood outside waiting for a friend (we had reservations) but it was truly impressive to see how quickly the people flowed in as soon as the place opened up.

Due to being so busy, the service was a tad slow but friendly. He made good recommendations and answered all our questions and seemed knowledgeable about the menu.

Food itself was very good and I was even happier when the bill came out. Shocked, almost, at all the food plus drinks plus dessert plus coffee we consumed. Dishes are on the small side but it was nice so we were able to order a variety of dishes to try out.
author: Amy C.

description: Used the YELP system to make reservations, and they worked! We were newbies...so we sat for a while before the waitress could explain the system and menu 'extras' to us. We did 2 wine tastings (1 each) and found the iPad helpful. Food was great! We tried the brussel sprouts and they were good. The chicken was awesome! I enjoyed the smaller proportions because it is truly the size we should keep ourselves to if we are at all conscious about the # of calories we eat. Perfect for us. We will go back in the future. (visiting SF at the time)
author: Karen G.

description: I came back for a weekday dinner this time.  While the food was as great as before, the noise level in the restaurant was so high that it was impossible to carry on a normal conversation without shouting.  It's still a good choice if your a party of two and sit at the bar or go in a group of six so that you can fill up a communal table.
author: Wei K.

description:
As a greasy-spoon and dive-bar fan, I was a bit intimidated by Barbacco's style, but they won me over:

     1.)   all staff were genuine and friendly and didn't sneer at my somewhat-shabby-for-FiDi-clothes (would it be rude to note the servers were HAWT?)
     2.)   I didn't immediately see a lot of vegetarian options, but the server (K Gibson, says my receipt) recommended a bunch in a concise-but-still-yummy-sounding way
     3.)   reasonable prices for such tasty food (I had pasta), including local microbrews
     4.)   servers were both quick and did their own dishes - a nice touch
     5.)   the place was full for Wednesday happy hour, but stools at the bar were comfortable and clean
     6.)   usually happy hour is a lot of dudes (I'm female), but there were a lot of women there

Overall, the service and food were excellent at very reasonable prices for the area.
author: Raina M.

description: This place is great!  I was looking for a place close to our hotel for dinner.  After searching on yelp, I decided to make a reservation here.  So glad I did!  The food was great and the wine was alright.  We had 2 flights of Italian wine.  For dinner we had 3 bruscetta (laurdo, sardine and asian pear)  All were really good and very flavorful.  We also had the mussels (big and juicy goodness), brussel sprouts fried in duck fat (SO SO delish!), meatballs (giant and tasty) and fried polenta (it was ok).  We were so full!!  It didn't seem like a lot of food but it was!  iPad wine menu is cool.  Will definitely come back here again.
author: Eegnam A.

description: We sat at the bar and had an amazing glad of wine and the lasagna for lunch. Fresh spinach pasta sheets and amazing bolognese sauce. Creamy cheese melted on top. It was to die for, and I probably would've licked the plate if it wasn't such a faux pas! Would definitely recommend it. One of our best meals in San Francisco.
author: Rachel F.

description: I wrote my first review after going to the restaurant for lunch with a group of friends, we got sandwiches and apps and it was a very pleasant experience...this update comes after two times that my office got catering from Barbacco, I think from the dinner menu...all the food was very good but with one very important drawback...everything was DROWNING in oil (both times)...the farrotto and the lasagne had way too much cheese with made it very oily, the roasted veggies were drenched in oil, and even the foccacia bread was saturated with oil. I do have to say that the chicken that comes with castelventrano olives, toasted almonds, roasted garlic and some type of bok choy looking green is a very good (and non-oily) dish.
author: Yevi A.

description: Great lunch spot if you work in the FiDi. I've tried the risotto, brussels sprouts and lasagna on separate occasions. The food has been delicious every time.
author: ND S.

description:
Was prepared to have a nice meal, but turned into a really great experience.  I'm a tough grader otherwise would be 5 stars.

Expectations for the atmosphere were low, since I thought this would be super casual and noisy.  It actually is casual, but in a very sophisticated European way.  Was very impressed with the interior and the noise level had energy without being deafening.   Service was very personable and efficient. 

Food also exceeded expectations in the same way.  Was expecting simple but good and got casual but sophisticated, complex and exciting.  

Everything was great, in particular the salumi and cheese plates, pastas and meat courses.  Highly recommended.  And by the way very reasonably priced.
author: Robert G.

description: I have yet to really find a great Italian restaurant in SF. If any of you have recommendations please let me know. Let me begin by saying that the atmosphere and ambiance in the restaurant was great. The hostesses were sweet. I would have to say that the sommelier made my evening. She knew we were waiting to get a table and came over to greet us with almonds and a wine list on a ipad. She took the time (even though the restaurant was busy) to discuss wine recommendations with us. I would have to say that the waiter was worst part. He forgot to serve us water and when we asked it took him 30mins to get us some. Oddly he served the people next to us some water right away. When we asked him for dinner recommendations he encouraged us to order dishes that all tasted the same. Lastly, it took him 20 mins to process our bill.
author: M W.

description: Everything was yummy, especially the Orrechiette, but everything was SUPER SALTY.  I am super bloated right now, and wearing a red shift dress makes me look like Cool-Aid..... OH YEAAAAAAAA
author: Ivy S.

description:
Enjoyed a belated birthday lunch with 2 other friends this past  Monday. The more casual sister restaurant to Perbacco, this venue is similar in layout and has a very attractive modern interior.  I had accidentally made my Open Table reservation at Perbacco, but the hostess was kind enough to both cancel my reservation next door and accommodate us within a few minutes at a very nice table along the east wall.  

Overall we had a very relaxed and enjoyable experience.  We ordered three creative soft drinks (pomegranate spritz, limonata, and watermelon limonata) and enjoyed all three.  Then we shared the polpette - pork meat balls with raisins and pine nuts and braised chard.  This was a great starter with three large meatballs and the sauce was delicious.  Two of us ordered the Paccheri pasta (rustic pork ragu / parmigiano reggiano) which again was very generous wonderfully prepared.  My friend ordered the chicken salad sandwich (poached chicken / golden raisins / walnuts red onion / celery / rucola).  Again her sandwich was very generous so she ate half and had the rest packaged to go.  

A minor glitch in the otherwise professional and cheerful service was that our coffee/latte order at the end of lunch was delayed due to some problem with the coffee machine.   The server was very apologetic and offered to comp us espresso (just the coffee machine was having problems) but due to time constraints we had to ask for the check to go.  All in all, a great place for a casual business lunch or to catch up with friends.  Not as fancy as Perbacco, but the same high quality ingredients and execution and a lot easier on the wallet as well.  Also, they have a dedicated "to-go" menu for workers who need to get back to the office.
author: Charles D.

description:
Verdict not out - first lunch. 4th Yelp. I think this place has been open for only 5 days. 

Nice modern remodel (a more casual reincarnation of Perbacco), I would say this is a sit down lunch spot, rather then to go. I decided to get my lunch to go today. So no review on the service yet. 

I am eating (as I'm yelping) the Poached chicken breast/dolce latte/apple and chicory salad, served warm on a soft roll. Tasty, original, on the small side considering it was $10.00 - Overpriced in my opinion. The sandwich came with a small side of marinated vegetables - cauliflower, pickles, onion, red bell pepper and carrot,--inedible, too strong on the vinegar. 

Sandwich to go with can of diet coke and bag of kettle chips - $15.33. Pretty steep (all main lunch entrees are $9-12)  but their menu seems original, and I'm a fan of Perbacco -- so I'll go back and check it out a couple more times.
author: Colleen B.

description:
Came here today with a few friends so I was able to try a few things on the menu. Everything was so good! Sat at the bar where the service was great.. I can't wait to come back to try more!

- Slow roasted shoulder porchetta sando: Pork was so tender with just the right amount of fat. I'm drooling just thinking about it..
- Soft polenta: Creamy and not too cheesy. So good. If it were up to me, I'd ask them to go light on the olive oil next time, but it didn't stop me from eating it all.
- Ribollita (pan fried Tuscan bean and kale soup): A hearty soup, really thick, with beans and pasta. Goes well with a sando!
- Roasted beets salad: Nice and light, with citrus.
- Roasted mushrooms salad: I'm bummed that I didn't get to try the polenta croutons, but what I did eat was delicious!
- Rotolo: OMG, so good. I thought it'd be super sweet because of the brown butter, but it wasn't at all. It was described to us as like a lasagna, which it kind of was, but better! I actually liked this better than the pork sando.

Servers were very knowledgeable and very patient. (We were there for awhile..)
author: Vera H.

description:
The food and wine are pretty good here, but I had two complaints:  

1. The iPad wine list is kind of annoying -- it is a fun gimmick, but impractical for perusing the list.  

2.  The brussel sprouts are cooked in duck fat, yet there is no mention of any meat ingredients on the menu.  As a vegetarian, I was very disappointed to learn this (while eating the brussel sprouts, gross!), especially since this was one of the few veggie options.  

Ew.
author: Abby and Brent s.

description: Ordered burrata, bruschetta, artichokes, Brussels sprouts, and risotto. Overall food was all very mediocre. Don't expect hearty Italian. Much more like, over priced bland Italian. Service was also terrible. Ambiance is nice, hence the 3 stars. Will not be coming back.
author: Anitha R.

description:
I would give Barbacco 5 stars for their burrata alone, if not for the fact that everything I sampled off the menu was amazing.  This kitchen could do no wrong!  

The small plates shined... try the anchovy bruschette for something different.  For dessert, try the chocolate nemesis cake.
author: Graham M.

description: Literally the best spinach and mushroom risotto I've ever had. Not a lot of vegetarian friendly options but what they did have, they did extremely well. Good food but WAY too noisy. I went here with my coworkers for lunch and I felt like such an jerk but I couldn't hear a word anyone was saying.
author: Amanda M.

description: I have to make a comment about the dessert. I had the butterscotch chocolate crunch ice cream. OMG..hands down, very very good! So good, if it hadn't been for the fact that I had to get back to the office, I would have ordered another one. I'm still craving it the next day (today)!
author: J. S.

description:
We 3 had the following:
Suppli: This was amazing but I think it could have used a little more flavor.  It was slightly on the bland side.  The cheesed oozed when we cut the darn thing into 3.  It's just one piece.  Just fyi.
Duck Liver Fegatini - The carmelized onions paired so well with the pate and crustinis.  My favorite dish. 
Olive oil poached tuna bruchette - The tuna was amazing. If you don't like fish don't order this because it definitely has a strong fishy taste.  But it was so good with the olive oil.  
Farro Risotto - Ok, fried risotto stuffed mushroom.  It lacked some flavor. But overall, lightly crusted and light crunchy taste.
Lasagna Bolognese - holy moly.  Yum.  Lots of cheese and different colored presentation.  Visually pleasing to the eye and just as yummy to my tummy.  
Polpette - These meatballs were perfectly cooked considering their massive size.  Came in a plate of 3 with spinach in a tomato sauce.  The center was also cooked well.
Flat iron steak tagliata - the steak was sliced in smaller pieces and juicy, warm.  Served on a bed of green leaf veggies.  The large sliced chunks of onion was delicious.
Fried Polenta - Also a little on the bland side.  I swear I was sippin on on a Bellini prior to when the food arrived.  Not sure why most of the food was bland to me.  I guess I could have grabbed the salt and sprinkled some on there.  

Service: we had 3 different servers helping us and the final person was kind enough to split the bill into 2 separate receipts.

Great place, gets packed quick, make reservations.  Most tables are communal.
author: Hanna Y.

description: Fun, trendy, comfortable and lots of excellent small plates to choose from.   Seating at the bar is very comfortable.  Had the burrata, bruschetta, meatballs and cod - all delicious.
author: Dom P.

description:
- poor quality of food
- OK prices
- servers a bit creepy
- decent wine
- so so atmosphere
author: Nick S.

description: Had an excellent meal here. Just visiting town, but chose Barbacco because it was highly rated and we could walk there. It sure did not disappoint! The complimentary still or sparkling water was a nice touch. The soup of the day (creamed artichoke soup) was excellent - perhaps a bit on the cool side. The lasagne was fabulous. Good service, and well worth the price. Even if we're only in town for a few days, I think I'll return.
author: Waldemar K.

description: Barbacco has an immaculate  wine selection. There are ipads propped all over the restaurant so you can explore your options. Everything that I have had there is amazing from Ossu Bucco to risotto rice cakes and beet salad. It's the perfect place to unwind with a co-worker after work or meet up with your sweetheart for nice evening together.
author: Leslie L.

description:
I've eaten at Perbacco several times, but just went to Barbacco for this first time and it was just as good. We had a 12:45 res on a Friday and got there right at time, it took a few minutes to get seated as there like 5 other tables for our same time that were all there as well. We sat at the counter area and got drinks immediately, but took our waiter at least 10 minutes to get back to us to take our order. From there though, everything was quick and we were still out of there by 1:45.

We ordered the tuna salad to start - I'm not really a tuna salad kind of person, but this was excellent - not mayonaissy. Then we ordered the white bean brushetta and the pork crudo - a bit salty, very rich, but good to split. Then I had the orchiette 'chili' which was excellent. My friend had the fried polenta and the meatballs which she said were really good. The only thing is, I was so thirsty the rest of the day. The 'chili' must have had a lot of salt in it.

We had a great lunch though and I look forward to going back to try more stuff off the menu.
author: Lauren M.

description:
Lunch and Dinner here is always a great choice for a delicious, classy-yet-budget-friendly dining experience.

Lunch can be a little cramped; they seat parties together at long tables near the front. The service is quick enough for your lunch hour, but for dinner it may feel a little fast-paced.

I have enjoyed everything they serve, but it is impossible to make a visit without ordering Brussels sprouts.

The wine list is substantial and decently priced.

The wait staff is knowledgeable and excited about the food, and always friendly.  (Well, we showed up 30 minutes late for a reservation and the hostess made us wait another 25 when there were vacant tables... But her job isn't easy and I totally respect her cunning lesson in manners; Don't mess with the gatekeeper)

For the quality, the variety, and the cost, this place is a staple of my Financial District food options.
author: Matt R.

description:
My goodness that was one darn tasty meal. Still thinking about it so time to review:
Scene: Cool, low ceiling, modern -- feels like some cool NYC place only the in crowd knows about. You will be seated at a communal table or at the bar, so be prepared for that.
Bar: Not a full liquor license. Lotta Italian wines. I'm not a big Italian wine guy so hard to say if it's the real deal or not
Service: we sat at the bar and had the full attention of one of the guys back there. Excellent service.
Menu: Great selection and the majority of items looked very tempting.
Food:
Fried olives with shortribs: They get crazy points just for attempting this. Everything should be stuffed with shortribs and fried.
Fried risotto ball w truffled mozzarella: good but same as you find elsewhere
Minestra soup: Interesting. Highly seasoned, lotta veggies, lotta pesto. Good thing we shared one bowl because it was too intensely seasoned to have a whole serving yourself.
Salad of green beans, potato, ricotta: Oh. my. dear. God. How could something this simple taste so amazingly amazing? It was just perfect in every way. Winner of the night.
Brussels sprouts in duck fat: Not going to waste time describing. You know it's just damn good. Nice vinegary tang also.
Sweet/sour stuffed peppers: Yummy - perhaps a bit overseasoned. Very typically Sicilian flavors.
Farro risotto with mushrooms: Maybe the most mushroomy dish ever. Super delicious. Large serving too. (Major leftovers. mmmmm.) Top notch.
Lamb Chops Sicilian style: Fine, but nothing special. A bit too much rosemary, a little too salty. You've had better chops elsewhere.
Desserts: Gelato and an almond cake. Fine but their pastry program isn't going to win any awards.
Wines: Good but like I said, it's hard for me to appreciate some of those old-world varieties so I thought the wines were just so-so.
Value: Surprisingly good -- two diners stuffed to the gills, 5 glasses of wine, $120 total plus tip. Really hard to complain given the quality of the food.
I will definitely come back here. This is 4.5 stars rounded down because of the lamb.
author: Al M.

description: I've eaten here a few times and I like that the menu gets tweaked often so you won't get bored with any of their take out sandwiches.  One thing I wish you could get for take is their Squid stuffed with nduja (which is essentially spicy salami paste).  The flavor of that thing was so intense and delicious, I want one right now.  Their pork shoulder sandwiches are great too.  The one I had with the roasted peaches and arugala was quite good.  It is a little on the expensive side but hey, it's FiDi, if you want cheap, go around the corner to mcdonalds.
author: Scott G.

description:
This place is fantastic!  The service was prompt, the food - absolutely delicious, and the staff are simply wonderful.  I am not easily impressed when it comes to restaurants, but this one was a hit, no question.

The seating may bother some, but being a European who enjoys going out alone from time to time, I can see the value in it.  This is not a big deal in Europe, but I know it's a huge deal here as people tend to enjoy their tight circles lol.

What I will say about the food is, if you are looking for salad with no dressing, hoity toity Californian cuisine with no butter or seasoning, or can't appreciate food from other cultures and are afraid of spices, then this place is not for you.  This is not your typical spaghetti-maccaroni-linguine-pizza Italian restaurant.  This is authentic homey Italian cuisine, and you can't beat the great prices and EXCELLENT wine selection.  We have places like this all over Europe, and I can't say enough how happy I am to have one here!

I also have to hand it to the owner, Humberto.  Wow, how impressed can you be with someone who's pulled off 2 restaurants right next door to each other... He's incredibly professional and a joy to chat with.  Congrats!
author: N J.

description: Polpette is off the hook good. Good wines. The iPad winelist is a gimmick. At least leave it on the table and put angry birds on there. A little loud but good atmosphere. In three words, I like it.
author: Chris M.

description: Tried the duck liver, tried brussel sprouts and a few other unmemorable items. Will not be back.
author: Cindy W.

description: Great food, excellent service, loved the cozy and friendly vibe and large flat-screen TVs without the typical sports-bar feeling and crowd.  A much-needed addition to the scene on this area.  A+.
author: Christin A.

description: We stumbled upon this place by chance, and I am so glad we did. The food was creative and delicious, the service was outstanding and the wine service and wines were some of the best I have ever experienced. I can't really comment on the environment since we were enjoying ourselves so much over the food and wine...and I think that's a good thing. Really enjoyed the entire experience.
author: Carrie A.

description:
The iPad thing would be so much cooler if one could place their order from it.  I mean, I was doing shit like that from pizza joints in Tokyo last summer 'cept the iPads were replaced with flat screen, touchpad consoles.  As techy as we can be in SF, we're no Tokyo, so I shall snap out of my funk now.

Barbacco is an excellent play for lunch.  The restaurant fills up quickly, so come before noon.  Better yet, make a reservation.  The best deals are undoubtedly the pasta bowls.  I could have easily gotten two meals out of a lunch portion of the farrotto (farro risotto with mushrooms and plentiful parmesan) for $11. 

I picked up the tab for three of us (we all had pasta), including a beer, a lemonade, and a shared appetizer (bruschetta - yum!) and after tax/tip, my total was around $60.  On the way out, I snagged a catering menu.  Next in-office lunch meeting?  Barbacco it is.  And they will even deliver!
author: Lindsay M.
