description: I always enjoy Barbacco for a nice sit-down lunch near my office that isn't too stuffy or fancy. The food is good (I like their crostinis), although the last two times I've been there the fish has been over-salted. Atmosphere is bustling and reasonably hip.
author: M U.

description:
Nice, contemporary vibe but totally welcoming 3 adults, 1 child and a 7 week old infant.  My dining companions (a family of 4) and I were too exhausted to choose from the menu so we asked for our waiter to bring food.    After providing a simple plate of rigatoni for the child, he brought multiple courses of Pasta, Salumi, Bruschetta, rollatini, exceedingly fresh mozzarella and sweet cheese...and a meat spread that was phenomenal

  I couldn't tell you want any of it was, but it was all excellent.  My next trip downtown I'll try this restaurant again.
author: Dan W.

description:
Went here for dinner last Friday night and loved it. We walked in at 8pm during the height of the dinner rush with no reservation and only had to wait 20 minutes for a seat. 

We got the smoked Calabrian salami for an appetizer. It was a spreadable salami that came with warm bread and had just the right amount of spice to it. The salami went amazing with the Sangiovese we ordered. We didn't even have to ask for more bread to savor the last few servings of salami we had left. The server brought more fresh, warm bread right over. 

We split two entrees: 1) the meatballs and 2) mushroom risotto. Both portions were large enough to satisfy two people. I thought I was full until I heard there was a vanilla gelato for dessert with strawberries soaked in an orange liquor. Even though we were one of the last tables to shut down the restaurant, the server didn't rush us at all. We were shocked how reasonable the menu prices were, and the service made the experience that much more valuable. Without a doubt, I'll be back in the future.
author: J M.

description:
As long time fans of Perbacco, we were very much looking forward to our first visit to Barbacco. 

It's quite different from the big brother, but still very delicious. Since Perbacco no longer offers mortadella, it was great to find it here. There were only 4-5 pasta dishes, none as inventive as those found at at Perbacco. We had the steak and meatballs, with a side of fried brussel spouts. These were the best brussel spouts EVER and I normally hate this vegetable.

Many wines were offered by 3oz glass, 6 oz glass, a quarter, a mezzo, and then a bottle. It was fun to make our our wine tasting flight.

We enjoyed our meal immensely, and then ducked next door for our usual panna cotta and ugly cookies dessert. Will definitely be back -- maybe even tonite! :)
author: Judy D.

description:
it is such an amazing dining experience. 

took M out for a date night (whee!) at barbacco, somewhere i've been wanting to try quite possibly since it opened up. 

the ipad wine list is quite unnecessary, and the tilted table was screaming "we try hard to appear mod". but our judgement soon changed. 

ordered the following: 

spreadable salamei: 
it was just like sliced salumi, but ground up in paste form. perfectly salty, spicy, and amazing on the olive oil toasted bread. it will keep coming up but that bread sure is a winner. 

bruschetta: 
summer tomato was so fresh and amazing. our safeway-tomato numbed palettes were awoken startled, but ever so pleasantly. 

and now: the duck liver patte bruschetta. to be really considered patte needs i believe at least 75 - 80% duck or goose liver. and it was exactly that. the basalmic roasted cherries on top was the perfect touch. i could feast on that alone. 

angry mussels: 
lump, juicy mussels in tasty hot  chorizo broth. again, the olive oil baked bread is the perfect way to spoon all the broth right up. by now all the dishes are heavy and salty, but that is when that glass of that 2005 cotes du rhone (full body, cherry) was just the perfect compliment without losing its stage to the dishes. 

paccheri and pork ragu: 
the only reason why italian is never my most favorite cuisine because of its earthiness. my palette is one for the brighter flavors. this dish suffers the earthiness a little, and the paccheri is a one minute before al dente. BUT - nothing but a couple drops of lemon juice can't fix :) magic touch and it was beautiful. 

meatballs!:
flavorful, but not my fav. 

fried brussels sprouts: 
i don't quite understand this city's craze with fried brussels sprouts. dissatisfied at spqr i decided to give it another try. ehhhhh. there is nothing crispy about it. the vinegar is slightly overpowering. though: it's not bad the day after chopped up and mixed with pasta. woot. 

half way through our meatballs, M caught a small, 2mm rock in his mouth. he was fine, but i alerted the waitstaff of it, so they can let the kitchen now. minutes later, the store manager came to apologize, and offered complimentary dessert. 

we thought it was going to be a piece of cake: they came out with a fruit tart, two gelatto, and a piece of flowerless chocolate cake to PERFECTION. 

"wow, you really want us to come back!" said M. and that.. we just might :)
author: Fiona S.

description:
Ah, the nuovo aperitivo bar!  Adesso is more straightforward, but yes, we need something with more SF style and CA taste to promote the ongoing unification of Italian and NorCal sensibilities. Perhaps this means a daily passeggiata around Lake Merritt in the near future. We'll see. I'm working on it.

After realizing that the Union Square scene was hopelessly out of control (mobbed by blue-extremitied midwesterners and haughty Frenchmen), I moved two BART stops east to follow up on this place. At 6:30 I hit the edge of the Saturday crush, and was relegated to the last seat at the bar at the back. Eh, no offense taken--I'd rather watch the staff work, anyway, since the bar crowd seemed well-grouped and unlikely to create a communal experience. 

I was immediately impressed by the iPad set up in front of my spot. Wow, it's happened. Interactive menus! Ah, it's just the wine list, but hey, what a cool idea. Sadly, the software was crap and spoiled the experience. It was a bit like a bad website modeled on Windows(tm) wizards, with unintuitive one-way navigation (hint: if you are in the bottle list and want wines by the glass, go "home" and start a new search) and not much more info than a large paper "wine list." I would think that a digital volume would sort by flavors, styles, etc., rather than just replicate a wine binder. In the end, I went back to the old standby--asking the server for recommendations based on flavors, textures, and smells.

But they can still do that.

Once I turned off the iPad (button at the top), found the paper food menu, and engaged the server, things got good, and maybe even great. The server was cool, knowledgeable, and helpful. I was able to pick out two great selections by the glass, and both delivered. The food selection was just divine. I skipped the cheese courses, secondi, and salume samplers (although they looked great) and selected a first course of ascolane (stuffed fried olives), a second course of mixed bruschetta (sardine, duck pate, and lardo), and a third course of pasta, a tasty paccheri with a mild, fresh pork ragu. The flavors were true upscale Cal-Ital, but light on the Cal, with the necessary freshness not compromising the richness of a traditional cuisine. The bruschetta sampler, at $8 for 3 slices, was an exceptional dish and an exceptional value, blending powerful flavors in large quantities. No mini-crostini here. The pasta dish was just right in volume, balancing richness with a chewy pasta and more tomato texture than you get in some of the Bay Area gastropub sugos (often heavy on pork fat and wine reductions).

The prices were the real surprise--in both directions.  6oz pours (which looked a lot like standard 5oz pours) often ran in the $12-$16 range, although the wine selection was indeed extraordinary. The food, however, was quite affordable for the quality, with ~$5 snacks, $8 bruschetta samplers, and pastas in the low teens. Even the secondi stayed close to or below $20.  You can really go crazy for under $30 here, counting only the food.
author: Matt R.

description: I had the chicken thighs w brocolli rhab and polenta. It was delicious. I tasted my coworkers lasagna and it was awesome. Great place for lunch. =)
author: Genaro R.

description:
We had dinner at Barbacco after I had been waiting for ages to try both it and the neighboring Perbacco.

Actually, we started out with drinks and a plate of cheeses and meats at the neighboring Perbacco.  That part was good, if a bit pricey for what you get.

Barbacco has a similarly sleek, trendy, urban interior, though not quite as formal as Perbacco.  We were seated in the middle of what felt like a communal seating arrangement, though we had our own iPad at our table area.  The full menu and wine list is on each iPad, sort of like a high-tech electronic menu.

The food portions were predictably a bit petite, though not egregiously so.  I though it was a bit spendy for what you get, though the flavors were pretty tasty.  Be careful with the wine list; you can spend a lot of money on just wine here, and it seems that the sky is the limit on what you can spend on a bottle of the good stuff.

Overall, I can say that I've been there, though it would take a dinner on an expense account with clients to make me go back.
author: Dave N.

description: Barbacco is one of my favorite restaurants amongst those in San Francisco and New York. At their price point, their dishes are classy, flavorful, and overall a fantastic value. Like others have said, their pastas are unique, the service quite good (for their price point), and those duck fat fried brussel sprouts - there's nothing like 'em. If I were to compare Barbacco to Mario Batali's Otto based on price point, Barbacco wins by a long shot for their menu variety and food quality. Within SF, slightly higher priced Italian restaurants Cotogna and SPQR don't deliver more on service or food to justify their higher prices. Barbacco's wine list is also fun to explore. It can get extremely loud though in the restaurant during busy periods, but I find that to be a minor nuisance considering that most restaurants in SF or NYC have tables so close together that you're bound to hear your neighbor's conversations anyhow.
author: SiliconValleyShoeGirl L.

description: ACTUAL *TRUE* ITALIANS work here, and they are SOOOO nice. Great customer service. Barbacco had me at crouton. Croutons are AMAZING. Oh yeah, pasta purrty good too.
author: Rebecca S.

description: If you can get past the wine list being on an ipad you'll have an enjoyable meal.  I can see the benefits of the ipad and i'm not against technology, it's just indulgent. They have a tv that shows local sports, it does not feel like a sports bar and I approve! The servers were very nice. Oh did  you want to know about the food? There is a lot to choose from, vegitarian friendly, and the quality is good. There are no surprises on the menu. So of course you will see burratta...beets...asapargus...But again it is good quality food. I would definitely go back.
author: Anna R.

description: Quick update to mention that, if you're waiting for a table and looking for a stronger sip than a glass of wine, the Barbacco staff is more than happy to send you next door to Perbacco for a stiff drink and give you a holler when your table is ready.
author: Amanda F.

description: I visited here for the first time for a quick lunch. Even I had read that the Little Ear pasta is bit salty, I still went ahead to order it. The picture looked too good, and when I asked the waiter if it maybe salty, he could convince me that it is inevitable to be a little salty because it is cooked with sausage. The waiter is super nice and attentive. So I thought I should be fine. But the pasta is beyond salty... I almost told the waiter but being shy I did not feel comfortable. Perhaps before, they saw the previous feedback and asked the chefs already, perhaps the chef assumed the sausage is to blame- but, think about it, they really need to change this. I regret I did not just send back the dish, because now I'd hesitate to go again. If I did tell them straight forward, I am sure they would have done something, then I would go very often - they have a super cool decoration and layout, reasonably priced, perfect for many occasions, right in middle of finance district. I really hope they can do something- then I will go again and take same dish.
author: Fort Z.

description: Great date spot - we shared an assortment of small plates and everything was delicious!  It's a bit pretentious that the menu needs a glossary... but if you can overlook that, the food is great.
author: Carrie V.

description: Hands down the best Italian food I have ever had! The dishes are unique and unlike anything I have had. The brussel sprouts cooked in duck fat are - without exaggerating - as good as anything I have ever eaten. My favorite dish appears to be seasonal - the lentils with pomegranate seeds. The meatballs are unbelievably good and have raisins and bits of nuts I believe. My wife and I go here every time we are in SF and will continue to go back as long as the food stays at this level. The decor is modern and ipads are used for the wine menu. The seating is either at private two person tables, sort of shared tables (which are left with spaces in the middle to avoid crowding) or along the kitchen area. I can't recommend this restaurant enough - a must try!!!!
author: Christopher C.

description:
Great food and great service. The atmosphere is really nice here. This is the sister restaurant to the more expensive Perbacco (which is right next door). 

You have to make reservations here though since it's so popular. Highly recommend the fried brussel sprouts. I sometimes get it to go because I crave it.
author: Linda J.

description:
I've been wanting to try Perbacco and Barbacco since it's been open and Barbacco has not let me down.  We did family style lunch and order the following.

Squid:  Excellent
Mushroom & Pate Bruschetta:  Vergy Good
Asparagus salad:  Excellent and refreshing
Beets salad:  Verg good
Meatballs:  a little undercooked but flavor was good
Lamb sandwich:  Excellent
Risotto:  Excellent

I would definitely go back real soon.
author: Mary L.

description: Eric made my night! this guy is seriously the best server i've ever had. Wish i was single so I could run my fingers through his hair.
author: RYU r.

description: Great food, good prices and highly knowledgable staff!!
author: Eric S.

description: We went here for dinner because it was close to the hotel and it was the best meal we had in San francisco! The service was outstanding as well, which we had not experienced in the city. It was very small and intimate, a typical wine bar vibe.... But the food really sets it apart from the rest! The lasagna and meatballs are a must!!!
author: Kristen B.

description: While I will be needing to learn Italian before my next visit, I was impressed with the food.  I had the lasagna, because that's what I could pronounce, and it was amazing.  I'd certainly go here again.
author: Michael G.

description:
I am a loyal customer of the 'baccos restaurants...  anniversaries, birthdays, business, friends... been there over 10x (6 and 4) so it is not easy for me to write a bad review given all the good times I have had... but all good things pass... ;(

I still think there is hope for perbacco and WILL go back (I only hope the vary the menu some!)... but NOT for Barabacco...  why?  Service.... and food that was mediorce (2.5 stars)

Service that was awful (.5 stars).  I am not comparing the service expectations to Perbacco, but to dining in general.... read on...



Highlights of poor service:
* Unkempt waiters (I like my waiters to look neat and clean)
* Busbuys with stains on there shirts (yuck)
* Snooty manager that was anything buy helpful
* Hostess that did nothing to explain the ipad menu (or even say good evening!)
* Drink orders not taken
* Wrong wine brought
* Food not explained when brought to the table
* Waiter that did nothing to highlight the dishes we had questions about
* Bus people that bumped into us and took drinks before they were 100% complete (sorry, but every drip of good wine should be consumed)
* Water left empty.
* Fly in my wifes wine
* Long waits for visit from our waiter.

Food:
*Meatballs overmixed (wonderful flavor though)
* Overcooked tuna
* Overcooked pasta
* EXCELLENT arancia


I want to feel important, cared for and served with grace, dignity and a feeling that I am the most important diner in the restaurant--and I will tip accordingly.


Overall, I left the restaurant feeling bad.  Feeling like I was being served by a girlfriend that was going to break up with me at the end of the meal.

Perhaps it was that we were a bit late (we called and ended up 20 mins late) to the almost empty restaurant.

So, so long Barbacco... we had some good times.
author: Max L.

description: The food is great, the physical setting is crowded, loud and uncomfortable. We had reservations and were seated at the counter? Sorry but that just sucks. If you're looking for a place to linger over your food and relax while you eat, this is not the place.
author: Tom A.

description: Trendy, yummy & reasonably priced but don't expect bread. It's not the usual Italian setup but the waiter was great, seating was comfy & the atmosphere was pleasant.
author: Buster C.

description:
The first time I visited the meal was incredible.   Soup and pasta were simple and incredible.   Atmosphere was fun--sitting at the long bar, perusing the iPad wine list, chatting with folks around me.   The sausage and orecchietti were fantastic.     

Visited last week and actually ended up leaving before being served.  The menu was needlessly complicated and strange.   I know that true foodies are always looking for the next great random combination of foods but I feel like I was in a completely different universe all of a sudden.   I would only go back by checking the menu in advance and if I felt particularly adventurous.   What a shame....
author: Scott W.

description: I've only been here for cocktails, which we found to be delicious, very well prepared, and done much flourish.  This is a great place for cocktails after a long day at work.
author: Brian M.

description: Went here for a work dinner and had a really good time. The restaurant is very sleek and modern and has a good vibe. It would be a good date spot downtown after work. There's a good selection of small plates and cheeses. We enjoyed a cheese that had a hint of truffle oil and it was amazing. The mushroom risotto was really good too. The one downside is that some tables are communal and they don't tell you that they might seat someone at your table until after you've already ordered. I would definitely go back.
author: Gina C.

description: I came in here for dinner with a girlfriend a few weeks ago, and having dined at Perbacco a few times, knew I was in for a treat.  Our waiter (behind the bar) was a complete douche and a low talker to boot, but the food was so good it didn't even matter.  Do not miss the burrata or the duck fat fried brussels sprouts.  Heaven.
author: Sarah S.

description: Not as good as the big brother Perbacco. It is meant to be the more casual restaurant but, even thought the dishes are understood to be less elaborated and more casual, unfortunately, they are also way lower in quality. Too bad :(
author: Luca R.

description:
I just tried this place today and I have to say it's very good.

The restaurant is busy during lunch, I made a reservation, and even then we got seated about 10 minutes afterwards b/c the place was packed.

Here's what was had:

the salmon bruchetta - very good smoked salmon flavor
the lamb bruchetta - was spicy and good

The house squid - spicy sauce, very tender squid, done right!
The mushroom rissotto - I think they use puffed quinoa or barlea for the rissotto.  It made for a great chewy consistency.  Very good mushroom flavor and creamy.  This was definitely a winner!

I'd definitely go back b/c there was another pasta I wanted to try.
author: Lillian M.

description: A business associate and I went and loved the dinner. we ordered about 8 different apps to share. Portions were small but with enough of them we left very satisfied. We were very disappointed with the wine selection. only about 7 calif reds, 6-7 calif whites and the same for every other category from around the world. Otherwise, very satisfied.
author: Andy L.

description: This is my absolute favorite restaurant in the city. The food is always outstanding, and the service is always friendly and accommodating. Each server that I've had has been extremely knowledgable and have made great recommendations. The polpette and bacon wrapped dates are OUTSTANDING!
author: Tricia S.

description: I don't normally find myself in the Financial District... however I now have a reason to make it a new destination. YUM! Tapas, main course, sangria, service, all top notch! Barbacco you are a gem!
author: Courtney H.

description:
been here a few times now and must say i really like this place.  the food is consistently good, never been disappointed with any of the dishes, and the prices are reasonable.  i love the wine menu!

arancini - delicious!!  i ordered a 2nd one b/c i was just not satisfied with 1, i could've had 5 of these and called it dinner!
salumi nduja nera - very good but you get a big bowl of this stuff and i would've been good with just one crostini, so would recommend only if you're with a big party and not just 2 people
duck liver pate bruschette - it was too rich for me (i had just a small bite), but if you like pate, then you'll love this
truffled lardo bruschette - you must get this, but just one piece will do
lasagna bolognese w/spinach pasta, meat ragu - delicious, the highlight of the night
pork ribs - it was good but must admit the other dishes were far more interesting.  it was, however, nice to have a meaty plate to contrast the carb dishes
will definitely come back here as a regular as it's not disappointed thus far!
author: Nana S.

description: I used to work at a really amazing award winning Italian restaurant, and some of the offerings here are comparable to the food we had ... except this place dishes them out for half the price.  This place is AMAZING, and I, a lover of sandwiches and hand held food, can't find a better place to spend my money every time I go into the city for a meeting.  There are some things though, that can definitely ... be better, as in they really sucked, so now I just stick with the sandwiches and salads, which I know are good.
author: Biqi C.

description:
i went here with a group of friends for dinner recently.. of course, half of them don't know how to be on time so my friend and i (who got there "early") ordered an appetizer: suppli (mushroom risotto balls with mozzarella cheese and truffle oil inside) which were delicious, but at $4/ea, i'd say it's a little much. 

for my entree, i got the flat iron steak tagliata with roasted asparagus, 
poached egg, and pangrattato-- it was really good, but i was still hungry after. 

which is why i ate some of my friend's meal too, which is also worth mentioning: the canneroni pasta with roasted lamb sugo,
artichokes, favas, mint and chili-- the lamb was so tender, it just melts in your mouth. also the portion size for this was bigger and more filling overall with this entree 

this place has nice atmosphere, but it's kinda dim and kinda loud. also, make reservations, there's not too much seating and the place fills up pretty quick after 5 pm on a weekday.
author: Muzna N.

description: Barbacco is the sister restaurant of Perbacco, but is more focused on smaller tapa style dishes with an Italian flair. I ordered the popular pork ragu. I could tell the pasta noodles were handmade and had a nice thick texture. Portions were quite small but decent pricing. Boyfriend had the halibut, which was dry but had a nice pea sauce.
author: Angela M.

description:
There are no happy hour specials at Barbacco, but they don't need any given how reasonably priced their menu and wine offerings are.  I arrived shortly after 7:30pm and was met with a crush of people at the door, clamouring for seating at the dimly lit, modern restaurant.  They took my name, I took a wine menu.  5 minutes later, a tasting portion of Washington red wine in hand, I was perusing the dinner menu.  My dinner date arrived shortly thereafter.  She ordered a glass of wine as well, and thank goodness we both had something to drink because it was at least 50 minutes before we were seated.  That's what you get when you walk in at 7:40pm on a Thursday evening without reservations.

Finally, as the last drop of wine hit our tongues, we were seated.  Foursquare told us "Mary the Mayor of Barbacco" was at the restaurant.  Curious, we asked the server if she happened to know who this Mary was.  No clue.  As we were deliberating on what to order, we both couldn't help but look over at the ladies seated to my left.  Whatever they were having looked delicious.  Catching our coy exchange of glances, the friendly blonde seated next to me recommended a few dishes we had to try - grilled asparagus with chanterelles & ricotta salata , the amazing burrata cheese, the duck liver pate with balsamico & onion jam and the fried brussel sprouts.  After exchanging another knowing glance, we turned to the blonde and asked if her name happened to be Mary.  No, it wasn't =)  We never did find out who the Mayor of Barbacco was.  Perhaps another time.

After much waffling, we ordered to share the asparagus, 3 bruschette (caponata with spicy ricotta, smoked lonza with marinated tuscan kale, duck liver pate with balsamico & onion jam), quick braised squid and the fried brussel sprouts.

Can I just say we were really impressed??

6 spears of olive-oil brushed, grilled asparagus with glossy black chanterelle mushrooms and crumbled ricotta salata were delivered to our table.  The asparagus were cooked through to perfection so they were juicy and tender without being wilted, slightly smoky and sweet tasting.  The earthiness from the mushrooms and saltiness of the ricotta salata perfectly offset the asparagus.  The brushette were delicious too, though we were slightly disappointed with the smoked lonza.  Lonza is a cured salumi, much like proscuitto in taste.  The lightly dressed kale paired with the lonza was simple, but not spectacular.  Compared to the other bruschette, it was plain vanilla.  The caponata with spicy ricotta was delicious.  Grilled, vinegar-dressed eggplant dressed with a little bit of sweet, rich sundried tomato on which sat a creamy dollop of mildly spicy ricotta cheese.  Delicious!  I also loved the duck liver pate.  The richness of the pate was played up by the balsamico & onion jam, a delightful pairing of sweet, rich and savory.  I'd order that again in a heartbeat.

A platter of fried brussel sprouts was set on the table, succeeded by the quick braised squid.  Can you possibly go wrong with fried brussel sprouts?  Not when you throw in smashed capers, anchovies & a punchy red wine vinaigrette.  Order it.  You won't be disappointed.  Seafood lovers should order the squid.  Four curls of soft squid came nestled in a rich, chunky tomato sauce, with two slices of grilled baguette bread.  I spooned every last bit of the chunky tomato sauce onto the bread, and into my mouth.

A great place to wind down on a weeknight, with a good glass of wine in hand, and to nosh on tasty Italian small plates.  I'll be back again!
author: Janet L.

description: Update:  Barbacco continues to deliver.  Meatballs continue to be favorites of everyone who goes.  It is casual so if you are going out for business it should be with someone you know well and who likes to share food.  Bruschetta is excellent.
author: Rachel E.

description:
If i could give half stars this place would be a 3.5. Went here a couple of weeks ago, and had an early meal. Let's break it down:

1) Decor/Ambiance

Pretty cool spot. Great location, very nice looks to the place, and definitely like the way the tables were arranged. It definitely invites you to relax and hang out with your party. The iPad wine list was an interesting touch, and I think they could probably extend the use of that to even more interesting uses (e.g. pics of the food, where they source ingredients, etc.)

2) Service

The service was good overall. Polite, accommodating, if a little slow. Considering we ate there pretty early was hoping that they would have been more attentive. However, all in all it was a good experience

3) Food

Food was hit and miss. Some dishes were awesome, while some were very mediocre:

- Bruschette - I had a trio. The cured local anchovy, egg and lemon aioli was so-so. It felt like I was eating anchovy out of a can on egg salad. The asparagus with meyer lemon aioli was great. Very fresh and tasty. The duck liver pate with balsamic onion marmellata was awesome. Great flavours and textures.

- Lasagna Bolognese - pretty average. This could have and should have been more flavourful. Hearty for sure, but if you are going to go for the heavy calories, then getting a good flavour should accompany that.

- Local squid alla piastra - decent and very spicy. 

- Braised chicken thighs with olives, escarole and almonds - this was pretty good. Nice flavours, and textures. I wished they would have taken off the chicken skin on the thighs though. I usually love skin, but the texture did not work with it on in the dish.

- Grilled sardine special - this was excellent. Pickled first and then grilled. Simple, clean flavours.

The wine is available in various sizes which was a great touch. 

All in all, a decent night out at Perbaccos little sibling restaurant (they have separate kitchens but share the pastry/dessert dept).
author: Maz S.

description: Food is excellent.  iPad wine and beer menu a bit overkill, but good try
author: Amelia C.

description:
2nd visit. Very pleasant feel to the room. Sat at the bar and dove into the ipad winelist. Great variety of wines from different countries, but not overwhelming.
I enjoyed that you could see the label and get lots of info about a wine before ordering. Wife and I chose a few and asked the bartender Kevin for his thoughts. He gave good descriptions af all four choices and let us taste a splash of the ones we chose before ordering a glass. 
Nice menu of plates large and small. Had excellent bruschetta including a very nice one with cannellni beans and one with fresh sardine.
Great nice-casual spot with excellent service.
author: Chris E.

description: Nice ambiance, decent value.  Food is interesting but not my style - tends toward heavy, meaty.  Many bar seats, though more of a dining bar than drinking bar.
author: Glenn S.

description:
I went here with a Blackboard Eats 30% off coupon (if you haven't joined, you are missing out) and made a reservation about two weeks in advance. When we got there, even though we had a reservation, we were seated about 35 minutes later -- and while we got an apology, they should have sent over a free appetizer. It was just sooo busy, which is good for the restaurant, but you should always try to honor reservations. 

The wine list is on iPads, which is cool, although I wish the waiters gave you more guidance.

The food was pretty good, but the plates are small-ish, so order some pastas and risottos if you want to walk out full. The pork ragu and farro risotto were wonderful. The friend brussel sprouts were also insanely good.
author: Michelle K.

description:
LOVE THIS PLACE. The food here is to dieeee for. I went last night with a group of sorority sisters and I am so impressed. They let us taste wine for daysss and we ended up with 2 bottles (granted...what kind of wine? I have no idea). Anyways, this place has a great atmosphere and the wine is great, but the food is AMAZING. We ordered the foccacia, the angry mussels, and the brussels sprouts. I know you are probably thinking that I'm crazy (because who likes brussels sprouts?) but they are life changing. I think they are fried in duck fat and laced with vinegar. Really the best food ever. And the angry mussels are delicious as well. 

I think my favorite part was the manager, Adelino (sorry if I spelled your name wrong). He was so nice and so helpful, and ended up bringing us free dessert. The butterscotch ice cream (I think it's ice cream, maybe it's gelato).....so good! :)

I am definitely coming back here :) PS their wine menu is on an ipad. cool.
author: Margaret L.

description: My crostini and Tuscan stew was delicious.  Brussel sprouts were fine, but not a must have.   Well designed space and a personable, helpful wait person
author: Colette H.

description: This seems to be a fast food version of Perbacco that is faster and cheaper. Although I want my lunches to be more casual, I still would like to get quality when I am still paying restaurant prices. I got to go from here and the food was decent. The meatballs were hearty and tasty but a little dry. Although very fresh, the pasta was slightly undercooked and chewy. Very convenient but quality may be hit or miss.
author: Ed L.

description: Been here several times now for lunch and for dinner. It is always packed. The food & service are all great. I love their mushroom risotto, butternut squash pasta and soups. The Brussels sprouts fried in duck fat are a must for the table!
author: Julie Z.

description: This is another one of those places that totally impressed me the first time around but left me mildly disappointed when I went back a second time.  In particular, the ndjula or whatever, their signature salumi dish, was completely lacking the second time.  The first time I got it, it was mind blowing.  Smoky, balanced, melt in your mouth.  The second time, it seemed salty and had a weird, congealed consistency.  I kept on eating it, hoping it would get better, but it just didn't.  oh well.  I don't think I'll go back a third time.
author: Ash T.

description: Delicious brussels sprouts!!! The menu here had too many exciting things too choose from, and everything was delicious. I like the i-pad wine menus, the busy atmosphere and the snazzily-dressed people patronizing the place. We sat at the bar and had great service.
author: Dina G.

description:
probably one of the longest bar table i have ever seen.

the more casual side of perbacco, this place only has a soft bar with beer and wine.  though with all of the wine choices and flight option, it's fun to sample a few.  our server was really knowledgeable so i just told him what i liked and got what i wanted!

i wish that i could yelp the food but we were jumping next door to perbacco for dinner in one of their private rooms.

more to follow when i get to update the review.
author: Anh V.

description: The service was great, but I'll give three stars for the food. I wasn't blown away by the food and I wasn't dissatisfied by any means - just thought it was okay. Started with the citrus/fennel salad (good) and had the minestra soup (good, but came out semi warm - I prefer soups to be hot). My friends enjoyed the lamb, polenta, steak, etc, but no one really said they loved it either.
author: Chihee K.

description: Great food, excellent service. Not to crowded for a small place. The squid and chicken dishes were very good.  Groups of 6 would be ideal.
author: John w.

description: Great downtown place - nice setting, solid food, and good service.  Nice companion to Perbacco.
author: Eric C.

description:
Husband and I were in San Francisco for labor day weekend to get away, and on Friday night we were going to see a Comedy show at the Punchline. We were thinking about going to the Tadich, but after reviewing my fellow Yelpers, we decided we didn't want to chance paying too much money for mediocre food. This place looked good, so we decided to give it a try...

I called for reservations, and after being placed on hold for a few minutes, I was told that the ONLY reservation they had was at 8:45, and I wanted 8. So I said thank you and hung up, while my husband placed the reservation on opentable.com... for 8 o' clock.

Atmosphere: Young and hip modern style. Since it's in the Financial District, it seemed that a lot of young hipster professionals go here after work. They pass out their wine list on iPads, and distribute them to you while you're waiting for your table. The seating is communal, which I didn't like because the embryo that I sat next to decided his life goal was to see how many times he could elbow me before I glared at his parents. 

First impression: The hostess seemed friendly, and genuinely happy to see us. She looked on her iPad to find our reservation, and although we were booked for a table, it was the counter that was available. We decided to wait and see what opened up. 

So we sat: We were stuck on the end of a table. While we were waiting for our waitress the Manager decided to come over and discuss the wine list. My husband knows a lot about wine, and I have learned a lot, so we like wine, however THIS is where the fun begins...
The Manager/ pretend Sommelier proceeded to talk to my husband about the wine. This wouldn't have been a problem, except that he completely IGNORED me. Not even eye contact. Not that I am a burn-your-bra kind of feminist, but you don't completely ignore the wife, ESPECIALLY if WE are interested in buying a bottle! My husband picked a bottle, and the manager went on his merry way. He came back and asked JUST my husband if we would like appetizers. He said yes and ordered the Bruschetta. Then he asked my husband if I would like anything. Again, ignoring me. My husband then told him, "I don't speak for my wife." Only THEN did the manager decide I was important enough for him. 

So food: 
Appetizer: Typical tomato basil Bruschetta. I ordered the peach and balsamic vinegar bruschetta. Both were delicious. 

Dinner: Husband ordered the Flank steak. He said that it was a little chewy but flavorful. I had the Pork ragu, and it was delicious. 

Dessert: Husband had the Lemon Pannacotta and I had the chocolate gelato. Both delicious. 

I would honestly give the food itself at least 4 stars, but with the wait, and the RUDE manager, it brought the rating down. 

I would go again, and give it another shot, as the food was flavorful, but the manager needs to understand that this is not a world where men order for women anymore, and in San Francisco no less!
author: Genna M.

description:
I went to Barbacco for lunch today with a group of co-workers.  We showed up at 11:30am to an empty restaurant, and within 20 minutes the place was hoppin'.  

The look and feel of the place is great.  I love the long bar leading to a mirror that creates the illusion that it goes through to the next block.  

The service was good.  No complaints.

As for the food, they start you off with a crostini with a salami spread of some sort.  It was very rich, but I like freebies so it was a good start.

I had the lasagna, which came highly recommended from a few of the staff,  with a side of the brussel sprouts cooked in duck fat.  When my order came, the lasagna looked like it had just been thrown on the plate.  The presentation made me think of diner food.  As for the taste, the pasta was made fresh with fresh meat sauce, but for some reason it didn't really wow me.  I thought to myself, "I should've ordered the porcetta," but my colleague said it ended up being a little dry and needed a sauce or something.  The brussel sprouts were good.

Overall, it was an average lunch.  It was good, but it definitely didn't exceed expectations.
author: Justin H.

description:
bruschetta: squash/cranberries, chickories/asiago, and pear/gorgonzola - decent, a little bit oily
pork ragu - not impressed
fried brussel sprouts - very salty and fishy
gelato: chocolate/marshmallow, vanilla/pistacchio - not bad

all in all, a bit overhyped. also, i don't like knowing that i'm helping to pay for $600 ipad wine menus.
author: Debbie Chiou S.

description: Yummy! Between everyone in my table, I probably tasted about 10 dishes (entrees and appetizers), and everything I tasted was amazingly good. Very reasonable pricing for the quality of food. Highly recommended. Good service.
author: Nick B.

description:
Pretty good place for an informal business lunch. There can be a wait for seating though, even if you make reservations.

If I had to sum it up in one word: "Trendy"...but in a good way! honestly!
author: BetheBrit Z.

description: This was my first time here and it was fantastic. The service was great, we weren't disappointed with any of the dishes we had. The pork stuffed, fried olives were unreal! The bruschetta was delicious and the fried brussels sprouts were outstanding. We had a nice spot at the bar and our server explained the dishes to us without any attitude. He recommended the order for our plates and we could not have agreed more with the order!  All in all me and my wife loved this place and will definitely be back to try out some of their larger plates!
author: Ruben M.

description: Lively atmosphere and delicious food.  Clams with pasta had just the right amount of subtle heat, and the menu had so many appealing choices that it was hard to decide.  I will definitely return on future travels to SF.
author: John S.

description: Great place for happy hour...the atmosphere was very intimate. We only tried the appetizers and had a few drinks but all of the small cheese appetizers were delicious. I would come again here!
author: Shikha M.

description: The unparalleled service I have come to expect from Perbacco is evident at their casual trattoria, Barbacco. The food is creative, yet straightforward, allowing seasonal ingredients to state their case of freshness and flavor. The Brussels sprouts with anchovy and capers were remarkable, the salumi divine, the pastas a cause for celebration. Umberto Gibin is one of San Francisco's most remarkable restaurateurs.
author: Jon W.

description: Barbacco is a beautiful Italian restaurant where you can order your favorite selection of drinks using a fancy iPad on the table. If you're working in the Financial District it could be a good place to have some drinks and some light dessert, but the main dishes were a little disappointing for me after I've got really high expectations based on the above average stylish interior. If you'd like to have a conversation with your partner, make sure to avoid rush hours to be able to hear the conversation over the table. Their wines are nice, the atmosphere is great, however the food could be improved, but probably that's not the primary reason why you're heading here in the first case.
author: Tamas K.

description: I am down with this place - great food, fun atmosphere, waiters who know their wine, and the best brussel sprouts ever. Nuff said.
author: Zig Z.

description:
very, very good!!
slow service, but really good food, great wine choices, knowledgeable wait staff. really nice! and super reasonable prices, almost too cheap for what you're getting, especially in this neighborhood! i was really impressed! 
will definitely be back!! and soon!!
author: Ilovelife Z.

description: Stumbled across this place  and glad we stopped in.  The place very high-tech, they use Ipads as menus! Food and service is awesome!  Must trip their bruscette and meatballs! super yummy!
author: Mia P.

description:
wine menu via ipad, pretty swanky.

the food was decent here. there's not much more to say about that. 

we did get a reservation rather quickly and on short notice.
author: Ameer N.

description:
have always felt that perbacco was for grown-ups. suit-wearing, greying-at-the-temples men and polished, lipstick-wearing women. everything was always well prepared, beautifully presented, great service, etc, but it lacked something....some sort of vitality. 

it's prolly why they opened up barbacco right next door. it's younger, a little sexier, and way more fun. :) just like a slick little italian spot should be. 

i ate here last week with for a birthday celebration. we shared a handful of the small plates and one order of the orrechiette with broccoli rabe and anchovies which was large enough to be an entree. everything we ordered was delish. the brussel sprouts were a major hit, as was the polenta with wild mushrooms. we also loved the arancini, which were pleasantly large. also, it's worth getting the pork stuffed fried olives--just because you can.

the two desserts were both stand-outs. most of the ladies loved the blood orange bar, which tasted just like a creamsicle. but two of us were floored by the flourless chocolate cake. so rich, so velvety. so going right to our asses. sigh. 

we shared two bottles of really lovely (and reasonably priced) cote du rhone. and speaking of reasonably priced it was just under $50 for each of us, and we even paid for the birthday girl's meal. um, yeah. the older folk can have perbacco. i'm eating here.
author: rachel p.

description: Just going to go with the 5 star tonight after a really nice, delicious and well served meal. Our server, Karen, was all over it all at the right time and all with the right suggestions. Our pairings were right and her suggestions of the pairing was perfect. She offered wine selections and they too were terrific. She and her manager, Adalino, brought our selections, checked in appropriately and were never intrusive. This is a spot that I really like for so many reasons and tonight was just another perfect night at Barbacco. Check out the brussel sprouts and get wine suggestions based on what you pick-they know what they are doing! Can't wait to go back.
author: Dr F.

description: Starting off with crostini of house cured anchovies, ricotta and a spinach sauce, I knew I was in the presence of greatness. The warm spinach salad w/duck confit and cherries and onion balsamic dressing ($8) might be the best foodie bargain in the city. The lasagna w/homemade spinach noodles was fabulous. Service was impeccable. A really nice surprise for a first visit. Will definitely go back!
author: joan g.

description: Went here for the first time and felt it has a nice ambiance, nice service and good food.  The only thing I did not care for is the communal seating, but I guess given the narrowness of the restaurant, the owner has to do it.  Otherwise, I recommend the lasagna and the brussel sprouts.
author: Tina K.

description:
"MI SCOOZI, MI SCOOZI"    (a la the crazy italian guy in the train car in Euro Trip)

literally, that's exactly what our waiter sounded like...too funny

but this restaurant is seriously yummy

must haves: ***PORK RIBS...ROTOLO...VEAL MILANESE...ARANCINI***

not so much on the salt cod bruschetta (waaaay salty) or orcchiette

dinner for 5 (no dessert, 2 glasses of wine) = $115

service was excellent....rolled in at 9:45 pm (closes at 10 pm on website) but sat us no problem! and did not rush our meal in the least
author: Sarah S.

description:
Small plates that were heavenly tasting. We ordered the chef's selection of salumi and the plate had a really great variety and quality of meat for the price. The calamari was also very tasty, and the brussel sprouts were delicious. We also ordered the bittersweet and torrone gelatos which were fantastic. 
The only inconvenience was the seating- we were seated so close to the next table we actually ended up having a conversation with them. Not sure if I'd like that kind of familiarity with others again, but, nonetheless, a great restaurant and a great value for the variety of small plates.
author: Elena A.

description: Absolutely delicious!!!!! We ordered the Brussel Sprouts (YUM!), RIsotta (delish), Lasagna (Yum!), Salumi Platter (so-so), Fried Polenta (pretty good). The service was great as well! We had a very patient server that let us try a couple different glasses of wine to make sure we found the one we liked before we ordered. I'm coming back again!!!!!!
author: Kwixxy S.

description:
More of a 4.5 star from me!

I came here multiple times for lunch during the work week and it has always been packed. I would suggest making reservations ahead of time which I have always done.

The atmosphere is great for a casual (and business) lunch dining. 5 star for service and atmosphere. 4 star for food.

I highly recommend the lamb sandwich which I have gotten the majority of the times I was here. Also good on the menu are there meatballs. I would say the salad orders are on par with salads you would get elsewhere around the area.

Overall, great place to eat lunch with coworkers and/or friends on a weekday! I would highly recommend.
author: Linda Y.

description:
The vibe is great, and the place really cool and interesting. Also, compared to the closeby restaurant (Perbacco), it's much more informal and casual, which does help. 

I do really like some of the choices they have in their selective menu (which is not too comprehensive). In particular, I think the Finocchiona salami in the appetizers menu is really delicious, and probably quite impossible to find anywhere else. All pastas are good, both as for sauce and texture. Again, maybe the small choice is the only real limitation. 

The reason why I don't give more than three stars, despite being very happy with the food, is their wine list. Maybe it's because of the i-pads, but I really find their list EXTREMELY too overpriced. Of course, I expect wine to be overpriced in this kind of place. But the prices they charge are really too mcuh for what you get. I still remember paying $45 bucks for a Sicilian rosé wine which was probably worth no more than $5. Also, we once got a German white which was more than $50 and again  worth about one tenth. 

Still I enjoy having a bite here every now and then.
author: france d.

description:
So good they'll make you fall in love with brussel sprouts!

Perhaps the best restaurant I've found in downtown SF. You can tell that some time and care went into creating their dishes as they're packed with flavor. The prices aren't bad considering the portions, and even better yet the portions are a *sensible* portion (a rarity to find in this day and age where so many restaurants have traded flavor and craftmanship for sheer bulk). The pork ragu was delicious and the brussel sprouts, fried in duck fat, were out of this world!

(Granted you could probably fry aluminum siding in duck fat and it would still be delicious, but these were nicely done)

Get here early - this place fills up quick!
author: Ann H.

description:
My expectations were much too high before dining here tonight.  The Yelp reviews all seemed very good and high. My daughter raved about the meatballs and the Bruschetta.  The only one I liked was the Duck Liver Bruschetta. The Sardine was too fishy for me, the Lonza was pretty good. The Buratta Cheese appetizer was tasty but too much salt on the arugula.

When the entrees came out,  I had to ask my waitress/server for clean entree plates to replace the smaller dirty appetizer plates.  I thought that was a little strange that she didn't instinctively want to replace them.  Then the Meatball dish was not velvety soft to cut but rather tough to cut and only lukewarm at best! So I had to send it back which the waiter profusely apologized and returned with a new, hotter portion. But by that time we had almost finished eating the Pork Ragu with Pasta entree. I would not get both those entrees together again as they were both tomato-based. The meatballs were good but too spicy for me.  

Perhaps I was hoping for the delightful Perbacco experience I had earlier this year. The Pork Sugo at Perbacco was divine and maybe I was hoping to have as comparable a "foodie" experience as that. 

Our Barbacco waiter was really attentive and helpful with explanations and suggestions. Dessert was the highlight of the evening. The Peach Sorbetto, Torrone Gelato and Espresso Panna Cotta were all delicious. 

I would sooner return to Perbacco than Barbacco. I wish we had tried the radishes since my daughter said it was delicious the last time she ate there. Ambiance was pleasant.
author: Flo H.

description: Been to this place 4x now and this 5th visit was so far the best. Service was beyond superior. Went to dinner here last week and the waiter that served us was patient and highly knowledgeable about the menu. He was kind enough to change out our bottle of wine after we noticed it was somewhat flat. The food was incredible but the dessert after our meal was even better. We ordered the chocolate nemesis cake and it was so rich and utterly delicious!! Can't wait for another lunch or dinner here... Definitely going to order light to make room for dessert!
author: Tiffany B.

description: I've been to Barbacco for dinner twice and lunch once. Overall, it's a below average to average dining experience. The first couple of times I went, the tables were right on top of each other, but I recently went for lunch, and the table arrangement completely changed. It's now 6 top tables that are for sharing. Kind of awkward when you're having a conversation, and someone from another party is sitting right next to you. The service at dinner has been average...nothing special. However, my service at lunch was horrible. We waited a long time to order and to get our drinks. The party sitting next to us was seated at the exact same time, and they had their food before we even had our drinks. When my food came, it was actually the wrong order. The server never came back to check on us, and then gave us the wrong check (which was actually double the amount of ours) when we were trying to close out. The food is actually very good, and it's the one reason I didn't give this place one star. I don't think I'll be heading back anytime soon. So many restaurants in the downtown area where I can get better food and service for the money.
author: Amanda R.

description: very very nice place, great food, love the fact that they use ipad menus :)  loved the meatballs and the brussel sprouts, very yummy, will be back!
author: Karin A.

description: As a vegetarian I wasn't fond of their food. I ordered some broccoli bruschetta, croquette, & the cauliflower. I had the apple crostada for dessert. A bit overpriced as well. The service however was fantastic.
author: L P.

description:
I am a fan of Perbacco and naturally I wanted to try Barbacco. I came here last night w/my husband and overall we were very happy with our experience there. We were a bit early so the hostess asked if we wanted to drink something first while waiting at the bar. I had the Lambrusco which was quite delicious. We were seated right on time and our server was extremely nice, attentive, and helpful. We ordered the following:

Nduja - The salumi was fantastic! I liked how it had a nice kick to it.
Bruschette (Cannelini beans, anchovy, & duck liver pate) - The cannelini beans had this mashed potato like texture and it was quite delightful. The anchovy & duck liver was very good.

Braised pork ribs - so tender & juicy but the flavor was a bit mundane for me but overall still good.

Flatiron steak - cooked medium rare and it tasted like medium rare so bravo to that!

Unfortunately the dessert selection seemed boring so we passed. Overall, great service, great food (although I wish they would spruce up their desserts), and very reasonable prices.
author: Xuyen H.

description: The food was very good, just the right portion size for lunch. We got there right when it opened and the host seemed a little flustered but the wait wasn't too long. I got the tuna salad and lentil soup, perfect lunch combo.
author: Samantha S.

description: I don't really like this place but if you have not been its worth a try. The food is only ok. Atmosphere is really nice. Went twice but not going anymore till I hear the food is doing better. I need fresher food for these prices.
author: John Y.

description: After one visit to this restaurant I am definitely a fan and hope to return soon! The food is of excellent quality, the service is great, the ambience of the restaurant is modern/hip, and, to top it all off, the prices are pretty reasonable. Just for reference, Barbacco and Perbacco are sister restaurants right next to each other. But don't make the mistake of going to Michael Mina which is also right next to Parbacco. I made this mistake and got through my first glass of wine before I realized it and experienced extreme sticker shock, as well as some snooty attitude. After the way I was treated at Michael Mina, I was pleasantly surprised by the hospitality when I walked in the door at Barbacco. Despite being extremely busy, I was greeted with a friendly smile and an apology for a possible 30 minute wait. Luckily the manager, noticed a spot at the bar and offered to seat me right away. I definitely felt I was appreciated as a customer. This friendliness continued with the extremely affable bartender who made me feel welcome and offered good suggestions on menu choices. I was dead set on ordering 4 or more courses because everything looked so good. The bartender, though, suggested that 2-3 items would be enough. She was right, and I appreciated her honesty. For my first course I ordered 3 bruschetta (sardine with potatoes and salsa verde, lardo with rosemary, and pear with gorgonzola and honey). The sardine bruschetta was a nice combination of brinyness with tartness, and my favorite of the 3. For my second course I had the pasta with rustic pork ragu. The combination of slow braised/tender pork with tomato sauce was new to me, and highly enjoyable. The pasta itself was cooked perfectly aldente. The portion size was not particularly large, but somehow I was pretty full at the end of the second course. For desert I had a duo of pear cake and butterscotch gelato with chocolate crunch. The pear cake was moist and not overly sweet. It was a good accompaniment to the butterscotch gelato, which was decadently rich and sweet. The gelato was amazing--possible the best I have ever had here in the US or in Italy. Barbacco probably could make a lot of money selling just the gelato. So, in summary, I really enjoyed my dinner at Barbacco and you will too.
author: Eugene C.

description: Definitely my go to places downtown.  The prices are reasonable and the food is great.  I love their orecchiette, I wish I could replicate this at home!  The Rucola salas is also fantastic.  All in this place is great and has reasonable prices .  My only complaint if I had one is that it is a little noisey due to the brick walls.  I would recommend reservation and have gotten a little tud from the hostess if I don't have one even with tables open and finally getting sat.  Strange but I will go with it for that yummy pasta.
author: Karen C.

description: This place is solid.  I've only been here once, but the first impression was good.  The service was average (a tiny bit slow and they got one of my drink orders wrong), but the food was all delicious.  The only downside was location (not really a fan of financial district- not easy to get to) and it was a bit noisy. We did family style (about 8 items), and everything we tried was tasty and hit the spot.  The best part was that the prices aren't insane and its perfect for tapa's/family style dinner with friends. I definitely would try again.
author: Sun M.

description: This has become my go to spot in the financial district.  Well priced small plates of flavorful ingredient-forward Italian food.  Skip the mains.  Try everything else.  I could eat my way through the whole menu.
author: Andrew L.

description:
the atmosphere was hip, the ipad wine menus were hip, the menu was hip, the service was hip.

the food was just okay.  we loved the mozzarella/roasted beets/heirloom tomato salad!  the rest ranged from fine to bad.  the red hawk cheese with almonds was good, but cowgirl creamery can take credit for that, not barbacco. the other salad we ordered (i forget exactly, but it was with lettuce) was tasty, but nothing special. the farro "risotto" with mushrooms and parmigiano was also tasty, but lacked a layer of flavor.  (i couldn't help but compare this dish to a similar one at range that was much better).  

the real reason for just two stars here, though, is the quick braised local squid dish.  my dining companions and i often order grilled calimari/squid dishes at restaurants and usually love them.  this dish, however, was really nasty.  the squid was thick and chewy.  we couldn't eat it --  i was pretty shocked at how gnarly it was.

glad we had a blackboard eats coupon for this meal.  won't be back. and  you didn't win me over with your ipad:customer ratio, but nice try.
author: micaela r.

description: Wonderful food, fair price, perfect portions.  Had the brussels sprouts, house made salami, a variety of bruschette, ribolita, lasagna, apple salad and risotto balls.  All really amazing and I eat a lot of great food!  I would give this five stars if it weren't for the horribly uncomfortable seats.  They were ridiculously uncomfortable.  We actually left without dessert, so we could go sit somewhere more comfortable.
author: Robyn J.

description: LOVED the Brussel Sprouts!!!  This place was so delicious.  Small plates, sweet waitress, good wines.  And omg the BRUSSEL SPROUTS!  They are a side for $4 and you'd have to look it up for the exact description because any attempt of mine won't be sufficient.  Basically - seared so they are crispy.  And the vinaigrette that it's cooked in gives it a punch of a unique flavor.  mmMm do it, do it.  And trust me.
author: Alias A.

description: I've eaten here a few times, both for lunch and for dinner. I've had the lasagna bolognese, which seemed a bit small at first, but was actually very filling, the maccheroni alla chitarra, which I thought was pretty tasty, the fried polenta, also tasty, and the mushroom risotto. The prices are pretty reasonable for the FiDi, and it sometimes gets busier than its big sister, Perbacco, at lunch, so you may need a reservation. I could get into the flavors, but I should get back to work.
author: B Y.

description: Great, fun restaurant near the Embarcadero theater. We come here to escape Fuzio and the other chains during the week of the New Italian Cinema Events film festival. Great food, great service.
author: Craig W.

description: Awesome atmosophere....awesome food. Buratta cheese was delish.  First stop in San Fran and very pleased.
author: Alyssa C.

description: Very important: the bathroom smells like gummy bears.
author: Melanie C.

description: Great location, very busy and noisy place.  portions are small. stuffed squid was great, but salad was just "OK."
author: Yoko O.

description: Great ambience great food great wine. Easy parking too!
author: Carlos R.

description: Barbacco offered a great pre-ballet dinner experience. A good selection on their standard menu and some interesting specials on offer that the waitstaff was happy to explain to us. I had the maccheroni with lamb shoulder ragu - delicious but more than I could eat on my own so keep in mind sharing with your dining companion! My friend, a vegetarian, was satisfied with the minestrone and cauliflower side dish and we shared the fried mozzarella for the appetizer. With a glass of prosecco each, the bill matched the quality and quantity of food we expected out of this experience. Barbacco will be a new go-to for dinner downtown.
author: Katrina S.

description: Good variety, lots of nice flavors, and you get to view the wine list from an iPad! The crowd is mixed; fidi/tourists/locals. It's a little loud in the joint, but a very lively atomosphere. The bathrooms are modern and clean. A little hard to catch a cab after dinner. Looking forward to going back.
author: B K.

description: Really good food, cozy ambiance.  Great place if you're downtown.
author: Rebecca S.

description: Amazingly good food--even better than the somewhat overrated Perbacco next door. Everything came perfectly prepared, in appropriate portions and decent prices. The service was really superb, with smiles, eye contact, attention, quips and quiet exactly when you need each. The only thing that keeps me from high-fiving this place is imagination. I was looking for delectables like rabbit, goat, smoked fish, pheasant, kumquats, turnips or parsnips, any of which could confidently and successfully be integrated into Cal-Ital menu like this. Maybe next visit I'll be dazzled. And there will be a next time, soon.
author: Denny S.

description:
Barbacco did a nice job of dinner tonight. Here's my take. 
Food: we had sliced steak with mushrooms and cipollinis, dry rubbed pork ribs with fennel-parsley salad, and. and a side of brussel sprouts, fried with small caper berries and anchovies. The dishes were nicely proportioned and very flavorful.  My favorite delight was actually the brussel sprouts... deliciously hearty, tangy, and salty all at the same time. The ribs were very tender inside, had a nice dry crust outside, and the spice rub was tasty (note for personal preference: this is a dry rib, not sauced).  The steak came rare, as a nod to their authenticity... American medium rare is medium or medium well in Italy. A tiny bit more on the cooking would have broken down the tissues enough for less stringiness, but the meat was tender and had nice grain. Sauce on it was richly flavored and smooth. Overall, food deserved a solid 4/5. The brussel sprouts deserved a 4.5 stars. 
Now, atmosphere: modern and stylish. Not super warm, but not coldly industrial either. They had a nice mix of warm brown tones and metals, and a nice arrangement of a dinner service bar right next to adjoining tables. It's a lively atmosphere. The Yankees and Rangers were showing on the big screen which made for a few points of focus though I often don't like sports on TV during dinner; maybe this is special. 
Service: Very friendly hostess and a courteous, efficient waiter. No complaints. Only oddity; they used Ipads as their Wine list... I think to the common technophile this might be kind of cool and hip. I felt it was a bit excessive; something a little in your face about it. I'm weighing the environmental impact of all those Ipads vs printing wine menus... maybe it's a wash... I'm sure they thought about it. Regardless of impact, I have to say it probably helps them order drinks faster. 
So overall, I thought Barbacco was good and deserves a stop-in. Oh, the bill was quite reasonable too.
author: Harry K.

description: For the price this place is 5 star. We spent about $100 for appetizers, wine, sides, entrees, and dessert. This is not bad considering some of the higher priced restaurants in the area. The food was great. You must try the brussel sprouts cooked in duck fat and the flourless chocolate cake. Simply delicious!
author: Jason M.

description: Went with friends to "test the food."  Loved the concept -- everybody sits at the bar.  Food was O-kay.  Still a nice place to dine with a different approach.
author: Heather R.

description:
I came up north to have a rendevous with my lovely roomates before we wouldn't be able to meet up again.  We were originally going to eat at Tadich Grill but the wait was ridiculous.  Luckily Iris recognized this place and recommended it.
and... I'm glad she did.  The waiters were very friendly and helped us order.  At this restaurant, you tend to order a bunch of small appetizers and share it family style.  This way you get to try a variety of their foods and get the most of your buck.
The arachini (deep fried risotto ball) was definitely new to me.  It was creamy inside and very interesting.  The salami spread had a very distinct salami taste and smell and was good, but make sure you don't eat it all yourself, it may be a bit heavy.  We also got bruschetta 3 ways.  The duck liver pate w/ balsamic roasted cherry was a bit weird, even though I do love pate.  lonza with peaches was very fresh and the sardines had a nice balance of pungent fish and light vegies.  The fried brussel sprouts were amazing!  We also had paccheri and penne pasta, but they seemed typical to us.  The small finger-foods were the best parts of the meal.
The only reason I give it 4 stars and not 5 is simply because of it's high pricing.
author: Calvin T.

description: The Perbacco team hit the ground running with this casual diner-style eatery opening next door on Monday.  The selection and execution of food is fantastic and incredibly original. For the 200,000 or so people who work in the Financial District, the take-out component is a gift from the gods.  The restaurant is hip, crisp, comfortable and charming - exposed brick, stainless steel and black marble.   Congratulations Stefan and Umberto, we will be enjoying this for years to come.
author: Jacklyn A.

description: great atmosphere for a small bite in the financial district. had the beet salad which was good and perfect size. then had the lasanga and delicious. love homemade pasta. brussell sprouts was what people talked about. it was ehhh...our dish was a bit chard and the salt was not distributed evenly. the place only has bar tables and tables that are shared, so be prepared to be friendly with strangers.
author: Kerry T.

description:
Great food; worth the price of admission for the risotto croquettes alone.
Minus one star for the passive aggressive hostess.  Umm, we have a reservation, why would we want to sit at the bar, and by the entry/exit bar door to boot?  Nice try.
author: Alex M.

description: Second visit to Barbacco: superb, efficient service, tight/elegant design, and a reasonably priced menu of superb southern Italian staples. Yesterday I tried a bruschetta with fresh/cured sardines ($3)--fantastic, and my friend had a beautiful fennel salad. Many great sandwiches and plates to choose from, most in $10 range--hard to choose, I went with the pork ragu pasta and my friend had the lasagna.  Both were superbly done, served in beautiful hot plates.  With such simple dishes it's the ingredients and the preparation that become so important--the folks @ Barbacco have it down...will be back soon.
author: Jack G.

description: Loud, energetic and vibrant! If this is not the ambience you want then do not come here.  Came with my friend as the last dinner we would have in SF before heading home to LA. Tables are communal but it was fun because we were paired with a group that ordered almost exactly what we ate.  Not to miss are the meatballs, beet salad, brussel sprouts and steak dishes.  Corkage is $20.
author: A A.

description: I was just in for lunch today and it was quite good.  It is true what they say about the liver pate bruschetta...soo good! The other highlights were the gelato and the wine (pricey but very, very good).  And any time I get to use an iPad I am a happy camper.
author: Elizabeth K.

description: Loved this place. Homemade pasta was excellent.
author: Joshua S.

description:
I took my friend out to dinner here a couple of weeks ago. First off, I was greeted warmly by the hostess and taken to my table, a lady came by later and took my drink order, I had the Thirsty Bear Watermelon wheat which was delicious. Our handsome and extremely polite waiter Christopher came by later and explained the specials of the day, we had the salami and tallegio cheese as recommended, bruschetta with duck liver pate and caramelized onion marmalade, the braised squid with tomato and the orechiette with fennel sausage and the roasted brussel sprouts. The squid and the bruschetta with duck liver pate were the stars, everything else was just okay. None of the flavors really stood out, dessert was especially weak, some sort of apple baked in a crust, the apple was crunchy, flavorless and quite unpleasant, thank goodness for the ice cream on the side. 

The ipads are a very cool touch, but I'm a bit baffled why the wine list is on the ipad and the food on a paper menu, why not have the entire menu on the ipad, seems a bit gimmicky too. The  wine isn't going to taste any better just because it's listed on an electronic screen.

Overall, a good experience, nice ambiance, well lit restaurant and warm service, many thanks to our waiter Christopher. Maybe I'll give it another try and order some different dishes.
author: Chris H.

description: The best brussel sprouts ever!!! Every place I go that has them on the menu I order them but they never come close to competing with Barbacco's brussel sprouts. Delicious cauliflower side as well as amazing meatballs! Cool vibe and very reasonably priced.
author: Sasha G.

description: A+ for location and never requiring reservations; C+/B- for food and service, which is inconsistently good. Loud and trendy-looking with ipads for ordering drinks and a long, open bar that spans almost the whole restaurant. Perfect for a quick weekday lunch or dinner if you are downtown. Reminds me that there is a serious need for similar restaurants in the now-almost-trashy immediate area.
author: Mary C.

description: I am rarely effusive about restaurants, but this one deserves it.  The food and wine were tops.  But the staff makes this place the success that it is.  On the two recent occasions that we ate here, we sat at the bar and at a table.  It didn't matter which, because the service was outstanding in both places.  The servers could not be more helpful.  They explained things on the wine list and offered us tastes to help us choose.  They have a unique and interesting food  menu and again, their explanations were very helpful to us.  I cannot praise this place or its staff enough.  It shows that a properly trained staff can make a big difference in a restaurant.  Of course, the food has to be what brings people back, and it certainly brought us back - twice in the 3 days that we were in town.
author: Ron W.

description: Enjoyed an evening out with some business associates at Barbacco. The service was very good! Food was excellent, our selection from salumi fatto a mano was very good and made on premises, however I have had better, pasta paccheri / rustic pork ragu parmigiano reggiano was outstanding, and polpette - Sicilian meatballs were also superb. Wine list was extensive with a selection of Italian wines. Expensive but very good. The place was hopping and loud. I have met the owners before at the their restaurant next door, and always very nice. My first visit to Barbacco and was a lot of fun! I'll be back!
author: Gerry C.

description: Having had a fantastic dinner at Perbacco, I had high hopes and expectations for this place. However, not only did we have to wait half an hour after our reservation to be seated, the food was more than disappointing. For that price point, you'd expect the pasta to taste slightly better what you can make from dried noodle and a jar of sauce, but it didn't. eh.. The brushetta was okay, but I won't be going back just to have bruchetta when I could go next door to have a real meal.
author: tessie n.

description:
wow, loved this place! this was a "blackboard eats" find (check that out if you haven't already) and we were so glad to stumble upon it. 

we were walk-ins with a 30-45 minute wait which actually only lasted 20. the hostess was super chill with the crowd accumulating at the door and even brought us the wine we ordered off the iPad (too cool). 

the menu was fun and ingredients interesting. we ordered mortadella, cesar type salad, padron peppers (my favorite), tomato soup, fried brussels sprouts, polpette (giant meatballs-so good!) and the baked apple with mascarpone. the food was excellently prepared and presented, 5 stars for the food.

our server was very patient (let us order in intervals), attentive and calm in the bustling high energy atmosphere, 5 stars for the wait staff.

why 4 stars?it was a bit too loud for me, but then again, i'm a bit sensitive to loud shrill voices. with that said we still enjoyed our meal and experience and will definitely go back soon....
author: peanut h.

description: This place is super fun.   Casual vibe for great bar bites and/or entree options to suit your mood.  Service is superb.  Best place to unwind with a strawberry bellini after a rough day in the FiDi.
author: K W.

description: I ate here about a week ago with a bunch of work associates. I was the one who selected the restaurants based on Yelp review! No pressure. We sat at one of the tall bar tables towards the front. I immediately liked this place this minute I walked through the door as it had a cool, NY kind of vibe. There is a huge, long bar with lots of seating that is great for people like myself who often like to grab a quick bite to eat and glass of wine. The wine list was amazing and our waiter was very knowledgeable and helpful making recommendations, all of which we loved. The red from Campagnia was amazing!! The menu is great as there is something for everyone and the small plate format is fun for a group as you can try lots of things. We ate a lot and loved everything except for a bruschetta dish that had lardo. I had to leave before dessert but heard it was a crowd pleaser again. I think this is my new favorite restaurant in the FiDi and I would highly recommend it whether you are dining alone, with a friend or a group!
author: Emily C.

description: OK, Barbacco is definitely easier on the wallet than Perbacco, and they do manage to serve stellar food. I loved the meatballs and the bruchettas. Although I thought the gorgonzola was a bit salty, the beet salad was good too. And they do have an excellent wine selection along with a full bar. If you decide to sit at the bar, I do recommend sitting closer to the entrance. It seems a bit confined towards the middle of the restaurant. Also, they could have a friendlier host/hostess. I politely asked her to move us from the mid section of the bar and although it only disrupted her for no more than 1 minute, she was clearly annoyed...not a very good first impression of a restaurant. But our server was excellent, so it made up for the bad treatment by the oh-so-important hostess on the pedestal.
author: Aya C.

description: Is it wrong to prefer this to Perbacco?  It's bustling but doesn't seem as loud.  The food is really good but doesn't have the whiff of pretension.  I don't love ordering wine via a computer monitor, but what the heck.  I would like to request that all restaurants stop slathering on the oil and salt.
author: Laura H.

description: Went for lunch. Everything was perfect. The attentive service, the wine, the food: bruschette wuth broccoli rabb and credenza cheese, the best foccacia I have ever tasted (order it, people, it is a buck), and wild mushroom faratto. YUM.
author: Ashley H.

description:
This rating is based on the value of Barbacco.  It is hard to find the quality of food for the money anywhere else in San Francisco.  My friend and I enjoyed dinner here last week and paid a fraction of the price of what we would pay for comparable restaurants in the city.  
Though the menu is weighted toward Italian dishes, I had no problem finding gluten free options.  This is not a pizza and pasta type of restaurant- the menu options are plenty and diverse, as are the wine choices (which are presented on ipads, which I found a bit unusual).
I will happily return to try other items on the menu, but I will say that their grilled steak and trumpet mushrooms, and the lamb stew were both delicious entrees.
author: joel b.

description:
