Me and a friend had a delicious dinner here on a very busy Friday night.

The highlights from the menu were the fried risotto-beef-mozz croquettes and the flat-iron, the latter of which was incredible. Just, worthy of death to eat. The focaccia and the pesto pasta were solidly good, and their wine list was extensive.

All in all, an excellent meal for a good price (60 for 2 appetizers, 2 meals and 2 glasses of wine) - but get a reservation, especially if you're eating later, because they are BUZZING all night.
author: SC M.

description:
The hype on this place doesn't match the experience. The food was edible but was very uneven and either void of real flavor or overdone with one taste. I went to dinner with a group of 5, all pretty excited to try this place. We started with 3 types of bruschette. The peperonata/ricotta cheese was extremely bland, just no flavor and we weren't sure if it was supposed to be served warm or cold since the cheese was both, depending on the bite. The fennel/coppa was horribly bitter, I think it might have been missing an ingredient to offset this? Finally, the pear gorgonzola was a crowd pleaser and everyone enjoyed it, this one was a winner. 

Then the salads came. I had the radicchio, which looked delicious but the dressing was entirely vinegar and was so tart it hurt your mouth, I barely touched it. A couple of people had the fennel/fuji apple/gorgonzola salad, the fennel really acting as the lettuce, which ended up being an odd taste and one diner said she felt like she was eating rabbit food. Lastly, one diner had the hearts of romaine salad and it was void of any real seasoning/taste. 

Finally, the main courses came and these saved the experience. I had the Lasagna bolognese and it was delicious, no complaints on the seasoning here! A fellow diner did comment the presentation looked like a lean cuisine on a white plate, but the taste made up for it. A couple of folks had the orrechiette with fennel sausage (what is up with all the fennel? someone has a fennel obsession at this place!!) and it was tasty, but one diner seemed to have so much kale it was more like a kale bowl with pasta instead of the other way around. She moved a lot of the kale out and overall enjoyed it. Finally, another diner had the mushroom farro risotto, which is a more earthy taste than the usual risotto made with aborio rice. It was a thumbs up but you must like a strong mushroom taste, it's a very earthy dish combined with the farro. 

The atmosphere is so-so. One diner felt like they were in a cafeteria. It's a little cold but if the food was better I wouldn't mind. The service was decent. To sum it up, I'd give the appetizers & salads we had 2 stars, and the main entrees 3-4 stars, for a total rating of 3 stars.
author: Kerry T.

description: Service was outstanding.  To the Server: How can you grin so much and be so enthusiastic?  The noise in this place gave me a headache.  I guess the longer you sit and talk; the more you get into adding to the noise and the noise doesn't bother you so much.  The high chairs are weird for someone short.  They're not good for the back.  That is why this place is so chic.  You'll be asked what kind of water you want.  I guess when you are in the high end, you get to choose the bubbly or non-bubbly (all complimentary).  We tried the three brushchettes:  asparagus, tuna, and sardines.  Sardines won by a landslide.  It had more taste. Loved the glossary section on the menu.  It makes it easy on the server not to have to translate.  Dal grano:  Pasta.  I had the mezzi rigatoni/asparagus/mint preserved meyer lemon/ricotta-loved it.  Al Denti.  Just right.  The slight meyer lemon added to the taste.  Ricotta was smooth.  I had a side order of fried Brussels sprouts-yummy, but a bit over fried.  The capers and the shallot-red wine vinaigrette added a subtle taste.  I'm such a sour person. The chocolate nemesis cake was amazingly dense.  Reminds me of a flourless cake.
author: Helen L.

description:
Really good wine...good enough to make me forgive them for not bringing me my boxed leftover risotto (which was yum!). Also, they get bonus geek points for using iPads for their wine list.

One big distraction - my friend and I were sitting near the door (which at times had a fishbowl effect, particularly when a woman came right up to the glass and watched me take a bite of said delish risotto. Um, yeah, lady, I can see you too...) Anyway, they have double doors and for whatever reason had only the left side one unlocked. Literally everyone coming into the place tried the right side first. Going out, everyone tried the (locked) left side - even the hostess! Maybe next time they should unlock both, or go with the overwhelming majority and at least unlock the other side.
author: D R.

description: Had dinner here with some friends on Friday.  The food was outstanding.  I LOVED the bruschetta and and my orechiette.  Service was exceptional.  And prices were quite good.
author: Kevin M.

description:
Dinner tonight with the boyfriend and friend. Solid food and overall experience. Definitely worth a try and not too pricey for a nice night out. Although you should know it is tapas style and some seating is communal. 

Atmosphere - casual, upscale, modern, busy but not too loud.

Service - a little inconsistent, but overall very nice and attentive staff.

Food -

Duck Sausage: very flavorful 
Flat Iron Steak: simple and good crowd pleaser
Sicilian meat balls:solid, but not special to me.
pesco crudo: great components of halibut, radish, fennel but needed some acid.
brussel sprouts: tangy and cooked in duck fat. amazing.

$125 plus tip for 3 people and a couple drinks.
author: Sarah G.

description: I would have to say I like this place more than Perbacco.  Not only is the food excellent, but the atmosphere is more relaxed.  They have great appetizers.  I highly recommend the brussel sprouts even if you dislike them.  They make it delicious and we ended up ordering a second dish!  The tuna sandwich was also extremely tasty.  A bit pricey though, so I only go there for special occasions.
author: S L.

description: There may be many fish in the sea, but some of the tastiest ones end up on the sardine and squid sandwich at Barbacco.  I seriously may need to start walking on the other side of the street to avoid the siren song of that sandwich.  While Barbacco, the noisier sibling to nearby Perbacco gets crowded, especially at lunch, this place is well worth it.  The food is great, and like Perbacco, so is the service.  Their wine list is also very good.  Barbacco is a welcome addition to the block, and hopefully will stick around.
author: Aaron S.

description: My co-worker and I went to Barbacco for lunch.  I was having one of those rare days where I didn't want any carbs (shocking, I know).  So I had the pork meat balls with raisins and pine nuts.  Great choice!  The meatballs are surprisingly spicy, but not un-doable if you don't like a little heat with your food and the tomato sugo goes perfectly with the meat balls. The worst part of the experience was talking ourselves out of a glass of wine because we had to go back to work...
author: Chrissy B.

description: I've been here three times already and plan to go again next week.  The small plates allow you to try many dishes.  I loved the 'nduja nera and the fried brussel sprouts.  The watermelon salad was innovative and refreshing.  Definitely a must try!
author: Gail W.

description:
Not all that it's cracked up to be.

I like the wine menu on the IPAD, but what about pairing information? Many places that emphasize wine (like this place) provide pairing suggestions with the food. Not here. Every wine I asked about was "great!" or "good choice!" or "that'll go great with the food!"

Ordered the beet salad. It was good, nothing great. And it came with these large chunks of blue cheese. I love blue cheese, but these cubes of cheese were kind of lame. So I ordered some bread, that came out cold (not room temperatute, COLD,like they just hauled it out of the refrigerator).

The pasta with squid was OK, nice flavor, but pretty small portion.

The steak came pre-cut, resting on some tired greens and curling up along the edges--it looked like it had been cut 20 minutes ago.

The pork chops were salty and dry.

I guess if you just wanted a glass of wine and a snack it's OK, but lower your expectations.
author: Mike M.

description: Went for lunch and had a nice duck ragu pasta dish. Great flavor and a perfect portion size for a mid day meal. The service was good with a trio of servers minding the table. Didn't get the iPad at the table, cool gimmick but not much function as there wasn't much you could do with it. Overall, great lunch spot.
author: Dan A.

description: Absolutely love going here for lunch. Go for lunch almost every trip to SFO. It's that rare mix of excellent fare, good prices, and a menu with a lot of variety. That "fancy, gourmet lunch" that fits in the time you have for lunch, and at a reasonable price.
author: Josh B.

description: Worth fighting lunch hour Financial District traffic in a rain storm and paying $15 for the parking garage. Will come back many MANY times.
author: Colby S.

description: This is not an Italian restaurant, this is an American restaurant with Italian fusion. If you are craving Italian food this is not the place.
author: Sean B.

description: Barbacco transports you from downtown SF to the wonderful wine bars or Italy or Spain. Extremely authentic shared small plates shine with flavor. A parade of duck liver pate, pasta, carpaccio and salumi danced in front of our bar seats, bedazzled with glasses of chenin blanc and permeated with the happy buzz of a packed venue. My only slight quibbles were that service was at times slow, and having TVs seemed odd for such an otherwise lovely spot. The food is such high quality though, and it's so nice to have a casual Perbacco sibling, you'll be willing to overlook the little things.
author: Shoshana D.

description: To quote Modern Family's Sophia Vergaro's character playing charades: (One word) "Meat Balls!" ;) I loooove this place. Truly delicious Italian food & attentive, no-nonsense (read: no pretentious upsell bullshit) service with intuitive recommendations. Ask for Gretchen who remembered our faces (after only 1 visit at least a month prior) & after a heartfelt request, even convinced the kitchen to prepare a favorite dish slightly differently. GET the meatballs- the fresh tomatoes, pine nuts, savory flavor- OMG!  Beats out A16 hands down, baby.
author: Jamie R.

description: LOVE this place. Everything was good. We had a party of 8 and had the luxury to order a number of different plates. The fried brussel sprouts and salami spread were among my favorites. While the seating for a party of 8 was a bit tight, the great atmosphere and food made up for it. I highly recommend this place.
author: Joanne H.

description: Brussel sprouts fried in duck fat?  Yes please.  Reservations are definitely recommended since the place is pretty small.  I usually don't like small plates but this place has so many dishes that are either salted, cured, or fried that are just too irresistible.  Great wine list and reasonable prices compared to similar offerings in the city.
author: Liz W.

description:
Fun atmosphere, bustling waitstaff, and interesting food. If you're tired of your neighborhood Italian place, go to Barbacco. It's definitely more appealing than Perbacco.

I like the upscale bar feeling. Looks like it would be good to go with four people and sit at one of the tables pushed together. We were at the bar, wedged in with a nice guy who offered me a taste of his brussel sprouts when they arrived. Only at the bar can perfect strangers talk casually about the food they've ordered. In a white tablecloth restaurant, it would just be weird.

The only downside to the seating was cricks in our neck from trying to look at each other and our waiter. 

Our waiter was knowledgeable about wine and suggested we try tastings of what he recommended. The many servers who brought us food were fast and friendly. 
 
The iPad wine list gimmick is cute, but made me wonder why they don't put the food on the iPad as well and jettison their paper menus entirely.

Food highlights:
Their piccante (spicy salumi) is excellent. The cool part is that the meat slicer is right in front of the bar, so you can watch the kitchen staff at work.

The meatballs were very good with the polenta, which has great texture. 

We particularly enjoyed the brussel sprouts. Get 'em.

The meatballs themselves seem variable--some reports have them very light, ours were heavy enough to sink a battleship. However, the flavors were great. All pork with golden raisins and pine nuts is hard to beat, then there's the chard in the broth. Yum. 

Duck pate crostini was interesting, although I wouldn't get it a second time.

Do not get the Arancini. We shared a couple bites of one and my boyfriend commented, "Some stores sells these frozen." It was overcooked rice with a fried exterior and a glob of cheese in the middle. 

I'll go back to Barbacco, but not for awhile.
author: Simone E.

description:
As you have read. The wine list is on a IPad. The feature I like about it. Is that it has quite a bit of info on which bottle of wine you're looking at. For the people complaining about food pairing and not getting service on someone telling you. It helps to read. It also helps to know just the basic info on varietals of grapes. Stop being a pussy. You can ask as well. 
Though it's a somewhat casual place and I looked like a lumber jack when I walked in. I didn't feel judged. Everyone else was dressed significantly more appropriate then I was. Dinner here was kinda last minute. 
I found their staff to be very accommodating and resourceful. Food was on point. I even ate something (don't remember) I'm not a big fan on. But I know when it's executed well. And that just so happen to be the case here. 
Our server. A cool blonde haired girl. Was great to bullshit with. Gave us space to eat, but checked up on us enough to where I wasn't annoyed by someone. She recommended this dessert wine that was a perfect ending to my evening! 
Overall great time. The space is beautiful. Bathroom was clean. staff was great. Food was great. It also helps to be in the company of good friends here. Everything is just that much better.
author: Deejay K.

description:
This is a very cute bar rendition of Perbacco. The wine list is amazing. It's huge!! Thank goodness for recommendations from our waiter. He picked a perfect wine for me based on my simple description for a white. We ordered a bunch of small dishes; cheeses (each drizzled with its own specially dressing/sauce), salumi with breadsticks, the roasted beet salad (very well made with fine touches of pistacio and fennel), the brussel sprouts (which were a little too crispy and a little too salty), the risotto balls (crispy on the outside and warm and gooey on the inside), the broiled calamari (perfectly done!!!), and finishing with the roasted strawberries and gelato (very unique and baked fresh daily!). Everything looked so good, we kept ordering. We will definitely be back soon. 
The only drawback is that it's slightly noisy in there. There are people standing / sitting, so it's relatively crowded and overwhelming, but very... San Francisco!
author: Kathleen T.

description: I've been here for dinner a few times and it never let me down, so I decided to try it for a business lunch.  Lunch at Barbacco is the best deal in SF.  Great choices at below reasonable prices.  I had the pork shoulder sandwich.  Huge portion, amazing flavors and came with a side salad.  All for a little more than $10.  Also had the fish soup for $6.  Nice size portion of perfectly selected and cooked fish.
author: Ric S.

description:
NUMMY! 

Fall menu is something pretty special and homey; I highly recommend!
I like that Barbacco is casual. In the FiDi everyone has their noses in the air and is wearing a suit. At Barbacco you can just sort of show up and have a nice meal, it's casual, and it's reasonably priced.

Don't miss: fried brussel sprouts, the roasted squash, or the beet salad. Worth skipping: the seafood soup... nothing special (not 'bad", just not "Damn, yum")

Both the butterscotch & chocolate / marshmallow gelato are like little bits of heaven. Goodness they're tasty! 

Another big ol +++++ = the service. They're attentive, and sweet (also rarities for FiDi)
I say again "Nummy"!
author: Lori L.

description: This is my fiancee and my favorite date spot. Barbacco is as good as ever. Great place for trying lots of things on the menu. The duck liver pate bruschette is a must order as are the brussel sprouts, no matter how they prepare them. The pastas were even better this time than anytime before!
author: Josh M.

description: We had a 5:30 reservation and they were super nice in changing it to 7, but when we got there, we ended waiting like 10 minutes for our table. Ordered wine while waiting in the crowded hostess area. Wine list is extensive.  We got seated before the wine came.  It was definitely crowded but the waitstaff was attentive and friendly.  We shared some bruscettas--there are a variety to choose from. And, they were great--we had duck liver, asparagus and sardines.  Though a little hard to share--they were spectacular. entrees were flat iron steak (perfectly medium rare!) and pork ragu. Pasta was fresh and fantastic.  I will be back.
author: Elizabeth H.

description: Same amazing quality of food as next door at Perbaco, but more laid back environment.  A great spot for quick, casual dinner at a communal table.  Also a great place to explore wines with their iPad wine app & many wines by the glass & half bottle
author: Johnna M.

description: Wow what a surprise, just talking a walk on California Street this Friday and happened to sit down to a beautiful lunch. To my suprise it was the first day the place was open. The service was fantastic and the food was mouth watering. Another BRAVO for the restarant is from the owner of Perbacco. Now I will have to take my family and clients here now for a great dinning experience.
author: P C.

description: Came here w/ a friend. Had the Duck Confit Salad - quite yummy. If your under 40, you should be able to hear your friend's conversation. If you are over that, you may be hearing other ppl's conversations. If you have 4 ppl or more - you get your own table. If you have less - its the bar or you share..
author: Johnson H.

description: Couldn't wait for a table at Tadish so we ventured into this place...decor was nice and modern. Food was just so-so..well it just isn't my style I guess. The artichokes lacked flavor and needed a kick..of something...My sandwich was on a nice roll but it lacked cheese, (only one slice) and there really wasn't much of the meat (salami potato's were drenched in olive oil making them a little too greasy and the bacon was a bit too salty...Like I said, the food was ok, not great but I just don't know if I would go back there again...well maybe can't give up on this place just yet...
author: Michael M.

description: I love this place for lunch.  You get really fast service service at the bar which is important when you're on your work lunch break.  The porchetta sandwich with peaches is awesome! It's light, but filling.   The pasta with pork ragu is tasty and it's a perfect size for lunch (you don't feel like you have a food baby afterwards).
author: Shannon C.

description: Nice decor, friendly host! This was my first time eating here. I've eaten in the sister restaurant Perbacco numerous times. I initially thought that the ipad was slick as I assumed you could place your lunch order and drink using it. Why else would it be there? To my surprise, you're just able to browse the drinks menu but you still have to place your order with the server? I thought that was odd, not to mention useless. I ordered the tuna salad and because I'm allergic to olives, I asked to take them out. I got a tuna salad without onions but with loads of olives. I was taking a client to lunch so didn't want to make a big deal out of it so just picked at the salad. If only I could have ordered through the ipad!! To give the restaurant credit, the brussel sprouts are absolutely delicious and the squash bruschetta and the pear bruschetta are really tasty. I wish I'd gotten a couple more. I thought my server was a bit rough around the edges. That typically wouldn't bother me but it was just annoying to come out of there hungry! I'll give the place another shot though because the food was good.
author: Clare C.

description: great place for lunch if you are in the financial district. it was busy but i didn't feel crowded. the taste of food and presentation are up to the standard of a nice restaurant. while it's a little pricy for everyday lunch, it's definitely reasonable for the quality. there're quite a few items on the menu that i look forward to trying next time i meet people for lunch in that area.
author: Claire J.

description:
The place is LOUD!!  We had dinner there last night.  The food was a little bit overly-salty, and the service was slow.  However, it tasted good and was very reasonably priced.  I particularly liked the bruschetta. 

I would give it more stars for the food and pricing, but it is LOUD!  We had to scream to each other to talk the whole night.
author: Adam P.

description: While the food and the service were fine, the hostess asked our table to leave so that she could seat another guest. We had ordered a full meal, a bottle of wine and several glasses of wine. This was the first time this has ever happened to me and we were appalled. Barbacco is clearly more focused on turning tables than providing guests with a good dining experience and pleasant atmosphere. I would suggest supporting restaurants that cultivate the exceptional food culture that this city has and not places that show such blatant disrespect to patrons.
author: Analisa S.

description:
We didn't know what to expect.  I had heard about Perbaco but didn't really know anything about Barbacco.  We had been walking around the city and were dressed very casually.  Would we get an attitude when we walked in?  Would we even be able to get a table without reserves on a Sat night??

We were warmly greeted and seated at the long bar right away.  The waitress/bartender was quite friendly as she brought us our IPAD drink menu.  Hubby was duly impressed.  This is actually the first time I've seen technology being used like this in the restaurant industry and I have to say - it was very cool!  You could look up all kinds of info about the wines (if you're so inclined).

Wine comes in 4 sizes - 3 oz, 6 oz, quattro (1 1/2 glass) and mettro (I think this is about a 1/2 bottle).

Their menu has many, many options of yummy sounding dishes. Lots of small, sharing plates.  We tried 3 different bruschettes (all of which were yummy - tomato, spring pea and summer squash).  Then we got the pork ragu and the mushroom farrotta.  Desserts looked good too but we were too full.

Space is nice - sleek, not too loud.  Service was excellent - very attentive and friendly.

Will definitely go back!
author: L F.

description: pretty good fare, but not a fan of the wine selection.  we had the tripe and it was good, but salty.  the aranchinos w/short ribs were good, but the crostinis were ok.  i think i'd rather spend my time at perbacco.
author: Scott C.

description: Not impressed. After sitting down for 3 minutes, a waitress spilled balsamic vinaigrette all down the front of my white sweater. Not a great start, but it was downhill from there. The waitress flailed, didn't hardly do anything, and brought me a cloth soaked in hot water. If you know anything about getting stains out, hot sets stains, cold removes stains. Then after a while the manager came over and I requested vinegar to get out the stain. They brought it, and the manager offered to pay for my dry cleaning bill. The worst part was that at the end, the manager disappeared not giving me any info. on how to get reimbursed for my dry cleaning, didn't comp anything from my bill, and gave us complimentary brussel sprouts after she asked and I said I didn't like them. Needless to say, I'm not going back.
author: Lisa I.

description: I have been coming here for several years for lunch and I find the food, service and atmosphere consistently excellent. Well prepared and imaginative dishes, very fresh ingredients and a pleasant dining experience (yes, even at High Noon Lunch) make this one a winner. Be sure to try the brussels sprouts rendered in duck fat; unbelievably delicious even if you generally don't care for the things.
author: John K.

description: Had lunch and was very impressed.  Sublime polenta, 'nduja was delicious, sort of like BBQ pate.  And it wasn't even that expensive by FiDi standards.
author: Ken-ichi U.

description: Nice place.  Service was ok(if only we didn't feel rushed because apparently the table we were given was reserved shortly after us)  Food was good although my dinner companions were able to finish their entrees before I got my veal cutlet......but it was delicious.  My girlfriend loved her Ritolo.    I'd definitely go back.
author: i a.

description:
I would give it a zero star if I could for this horrible experience.
I've been to many many restaurants and this has never happen to me and my friends before.

My friend and I ate there on 6/18/10 nite.
We were chatting and chatting and enjoying each others' company and one of the hostess came by and ask us to leave.

The reason was they needed the table for another group.

When I voiced my disappointment as we were leaving, another girl told us that the group waiting was the chef's friends.

Horrible and unacceptable!



I emailed  the manager that nite, Friday, 6/18/10 and haven't hear anything back.
author: Dave K.

description: So they get a 3.  I think that the people are awesome, atmosphere is perfect and the food is amazing!!  However, 2 times now I have made reservations for 12:30 PM and not been seated until a little after 1:00 PM.  Both were client meetings and both times either my client or I were on a tight schedule.  They really need to get it together if they are going to do great at this place.
author: Brianna R.

description: My friend and love to try new places for our standard one night a week dinner date. We wanted to try out Barbacco because the prices were pretty good, plus we like to be really classy and go eat at fancy places like grown-ups. I was excited because is was busy which I believe is a testament to how good a place is. I loved that they had iPads at the bar, although I was less excited when I found out they serve no real purpose except to tell you about their drinks. I t would have been awesome if you could order with them! Anyways, We had a couple kinds of bruschetta; the pear and Gorgonzola one was to die for, and I ended up recreating shortly after; and a regular tomato and basil one which was also delicious. We ended up ordering focaccia bread (it was $1) and was very disappointed. First of all, it was cheap so I wasn't expecting the best bread ever, but it's an ITALIAN restaurant, focaccia bread should be at least decent. This wasn't. It tasted like a crappy donut from some hole in the wall that only has day old donuts. We complained (and by that I mean my friend went Israeli on their asses, Her words, not mine!) and they took it off our bill. Overall, the food was good but they get dinged for a few things; 1) the crappy focaccia; 2) they were pouring sample glasses of wine on the counter above where we were eating and spilled a couple on our food and us; 3) they kinda forgot about us and our drinks, I understand you're busy, but we did tell you what we wanted and you forgot to punch it in and then you claimed we didn't tell you what we wanted. Yea, okay. Haven't you heard of the customer is ALWAYS right? Always.
author: Sheila N.

description: Real Italian cuisine! Loved it! And service is excellent
author: Roland F.

description: Just finished an excellent lunch at Barbacco today.  There was a line for tables, but I got a single seat at the bar with no wait.  The service was cheerful and helpful and made sure I was situated allright after a tight squeeze into the barstool.  The seared squid and sardine sadwich ($11) was fantastic, as was the fisherman's soup ($6).  The sardines were the right blend of mild and sour, and the rich tomato-basil broth of the soup was tangy and flavorful.  Both the sandwich and soup were served piping hot.  A great Friday treat.
author: Seth G.

description: I came here last night with a friend.  I made reservations on Opentable, so we had no problem getting a seat at the very crowded eatery.  I mean, this place was poppin' off!  After my experience I could see why.  The wait staff was extremely friendly, knowledgable and attentive despite the amount of people in the restaurant.  The food was well prepared and came out pretty fast, which was nice because we were very hungry!  We split the hamachi, which I didn't care for at all!  It was very fishy tasting, but I am not much of a fish eater so it was my own ordering mistake...my friend enjoyed it!  I had the arancini with short rib--delicious!  For our main dish my friend had the fish special, which was halibut, and I had the mushroom risotto.  The halibut was wonderful, seasoned nicely and cooked perfectly.  My mushroom risotto was hands down the best thing we had all night.  It was rich and creamy, but not too heavy.  The mushrooms were so yummy also!  I will definitely be back!
author: Veronica F.

description:
Okay, so I've gone to this restaurant 3 times since they've opened and LOVED IT every time.  I have tried almost everything on the menu (all the desserts too).  Some of my favs are the home made salami sandwich, the mussels, sardines, the butcher's salad and of course their HOME MADE gelato.  I really like the pistachio.  The service is very good and all the staff is very courteous and friendly.  The owner is a delight as well.  
Overall 5 stars for Barbacco and I will be going there again for sure.
author: Evelina A.

description: I'd been to Perbacco before and loved it, so I was curious to try its sister restaurant next store. Barbacco is more casual in ambiance, but the food is also excellent. My friend and I shared the duck salad for starters-it isn't often that you fall in love with a salad, but this one was amazing! Rich pieces of duck paired with onions, grilled peaches, and a light vinaigrette over baby spinach and frisee-divine. For my main course, I had the pork ragu pasta and my friend has the polpette. I was a bit underwhelmed with the pasta, but the polpette were standout. We also shared a side of Brussels sprouts-a bit overdone to my taste. For dessert, we each tried a scoop of gelato-the toffee was excellent, the torrone very refreshing. They have quite a large selection of wines by the glass and a very knowledgeable and attentive staff. Compared to Perbacco, the food is less consistently executed, but for the very reasonable price, it's definitely worth a trip.
author: Ashley T.

description: The lasana here is great.  It is a great place to go for a nice lunch in the financial district.  I've heard good things about it for dinner as well but have never planned ahead enough to get a decent dinner reservation time.
author: K L.

description: I couldn't get past the offensive smell of whatever they were cooking.  Sorry.
author: S W.

description: Barbacco is sometimes a five and sometimes a one, so I think that a three star is a good average.  The first time I ate here I had a farro risotto, great brussels sprouts and a good beet dish.  Desserts were great, ate at the counter and found it a true deal.  Last night we sat at a table (four of us) and it was less great.  Our bruschetta of fresh sardines were very good.  The brussels sprouts were either bathed in an over-reduced balsamic sauce or the salt vat spilled all over them and they were really, really salty (did I mention they were salty?).  One person at the table had the meat balls and similarly, the salt cellar tipped into that dish.  Two of us had the maccharoni with pork ragu, which had no more than one tablespoon of pork in the dish.  Either it was a miniature pig or the pork flew away.  Please, charge me more but if you say pork, be sure I don't have to go on a treasure hunt to find it!  Gelato was good, not great.  Probably my biggest complaint was that they served the wrong dish to people at our table at least twice and also brought out three out of four of the dishes for a course, leaving one person sitting there.  Not a big deal, but not ideal either.  I'd go back, I think, as I like the idea of smaller plates and lots of choices, but I hope by that time they figure out their over-salting issue.
author: Susan L.

description: Loved this restaurant! Great food! Had Lasagna for main meal and Brussels sprouts for appetizer. It was delicious. I like the location, the restaurant looks trendy, great service and surprisingly, it isnt too expensive. I definitely recommend this restaurant!
author: Mel G.

description: Hype, hype, hype!  Was in SF for a wedding.  Barbacco was recommended.  Had brussel sprouts, rigatoni with ragout, liver pate, and some other stuff.  The brussel sprouts were freaking scorched beyond edible.  Not what I'm used to, which is cooked, but not demolished to looking like charcoal briquets.  Also, no flavor.  The rigatoni was bad too.  Dry and no flavor.  Should have put some more olive oil in there.  The pate was average too, nothing special.  The only reason I'm giving this 2 stars is because the service was very attentive.  I've had much better pasta, including Osteria Mozzeria in LA.
author: Daniel H.

description: Everything we ordered here was fantastic.  There were so many waiters you never had to try to hunt yours down.   We made a dinner out of small plates and it was a perfect date night.
author: Allison H.

description: I like the small touches here. Napkins that are thick cloth rather than some picnic-paper embarrassments, silverware with satisfying heft, leaving the water jug, rounding off the bill so I don't have to carry 95 cents worth of change, a TV that is on but silent.  My roasted eggplant & mozzarella sandwich came warm and could not have been better. It is clear someone put a lot of money and thought into this place and it shows immediately.
author: George S.

description: We celebrated our friend's birthday luncheon here and this was our first visit.  We all enjoyed the cannelini bean bruschette and the Madigan Chardonnay.  The rigatoni with asparagus was delicious and the zuppa de pesce was good but we felt there could have been more bits of seafood in it.  The cotechino was tasty but as my friend spooned some of the bean salad into her mouth, she bit into a stone!  In all the excitement, the stone fell out of her hand and under the table and we couldn't retrieve it.  Luckily, she didn't break a tooth.  We told our server of what just went down.  He apologized but didn't comp our desserts or apps (perhaps because we couldn't produce the evidence)!  Despite that incident, we would come back to Barbacco again.
author: Michelle E.

description:
Made a visit on Wednesday night for dinner.  Luckily, gal pal made a reservation.  Folks were waiting outside and when I walked in, there was an even larger crowd.  

I'm not restaurant critic.  Quite frankly, I like food.  I love to cook and I love to eat.  

I liked the look of the place, it was comfortable.  

The food was fabulous.  

Started with the arancini.  Fried food, need I say more?  Honestly, this was a recommendation of the server, Christopher, and the couple sitting next to us.  

Along with this, the duck liver pate.  I'll have to say, the first time I had pate was the 1st time I visited Paris and that was in 2004 and I found in Paris I liked pate but it was mixed with cheese (but like I said, that was in Paris).  I think if you are a pate lover, I suggest this, however, I felt it was missing something... 

Next was the burrata.  This was fabulous.  When thinking about it, had this been mixed with the pate, it would have made the pate much better.  By itself it was very good.  

Angry mussels.  At first I couldn't figure out why angry??  Once I picked up some of the broth I realized, they had a slight kick of spice.  Ahhh, I like spice.  

Then the rotolo.  Mmmmm...  

To finish, gelato!!!  Pistachio and Butterscotch chocolate crunch.  

Luckily, this friend and I don't mind sharing food.  

We paired it with a French Syrah.  I know French, why French when dining on Italian food.  What can I say, I like French wines.  

We thought the service was fabulous.  But we only get together for dinner every 2 or 3 months so we always end up chatting and enjoying our wine.  

I've already told 5 people about this place and plan on telling others.
author: Christine A.

description: Food was fresh and the service was good!  I don't like how you can only make reservations online.   I had a salad which was a little bland and pork sandwich which was amazing.  With sparking water and tip my total was only $16.  Which is not bad for the Financial District.
author: Matthew F.

description: Nice lunch, portion, cost, etc.  I actually enjoy this restaurant better than Perbacco.  Great vibe and extensive menu.  I'd definitely try this again.
author: Nick S.

description: food was way below average, however service was good---would not go to this restaurant again.
author: Pete K.

description: WOW! I went here with the girls and was BLOWN AWAY! We had all three of the Bruscetta (delicious!), the brussel sprouts which were divine! and a hole much more little yummy plates of goodness! I HIGHLY recommend stopping in!
author: K L.

description: This place is fantastic.  The food is great, the space is great and the service is perfect.  I wish I could eat here every day.  Everything is so good, but you got to try the Porchetta Sandwich (not sure I spelled that right) and the brussel sprouts
author: Trevor S.

description: really really good taste.  there isn't a duck liver pate i met that i didn't like, or a bubbling pile of cheesy lasagna for that matter.  as a person who avoids human interaction with strangers as much as possible, the ipad sommelier was a welcome companion.  my opinion of after-work options in the financial district has marginally moved toward the better.
author: Stephanie L.

description: Loved the orecchiette with lamb, and the Brussels sprouts fried in duck fat were totally addictive. The fennel salad that accompanied the skate special was delicious, although the skate itself was the only low point, with a mushy texture as if it had been frozen, sadly. The 3 oz tasting pours let us sample several interesting wines from their extensive list. We're not big on ordering desserts, so the thin slices of panforte they offer for a mere $1 were perfect for us. Will definitely be back.
author: Karen S.

description: Had dinner reservations through opentable for 3 people at 7:15 on a Monday. The restaurant was lively and nearly full, even on a Monday night. We were sat at a communal table (6 total) near the front. Clean, modern, and casual (compared to Perbacco). Love the iPad for drinks menu, but wish we could've ordered our wine and drinks using it, and had hoped for some helpful descriptions (perfect use for something like this). Server was very helpful and cheerful. Ordered salumi chef selection, aruncini (with shortrib filling), tripe in tomato sauce, brussel sprouts, mushroom risotto, orecchiette, and rustic pork ragu. We loved everything!! Pasta cooked perfectly al dente, tender tripe, and all great, traditional Italian flavors. We will definitely be back for more. The menu has so much to choose from! Plus, the bill averaged out to be only less than $40 per person including wine and tax/tip, which I thought was well worth it.
author: Rob L.

description: came here with my family for dinner.  we had reservations and were seated right away.  the food was okay and something about this place was just off.  to start on the food, the meatball was a bit on the salty side.   we asked for lemons for the water and it didnt come until after asking a third time.  the waiter kept on forgetting.  focaccia bread was ok.  it didnt seem to have a lot of flavor except a lot of oil.  the decor is nice but i think they're trying too hard to modernize Italian food and losing a lot of traditional Italian flavors.  the mushroom risotto was well cooked and very mushroomy! the lasagna was tender and good, but the meats overpower the tomato and cheese. also, i couldnt stand the stupid iPad drink menus!  every table had an ipad that displayed their drink menu.  only one person could read at a time and it just didnt make sense.  you couldnt order drinks with but only view what they had to offer.  save some money and print it on paper.  overall the food was ok but i felt like their whole menu/food/environment concept is confused.  i didnt feel or taste any italian which disappointed me.  i may be back but there are certainly a lot of other places to try first....
author: ben c.

description: Excellent vegetarian options! My favorite was the farro risotto with the mushrooms.
author: Meg P.

description: Really great. Nice veggie options. Looking forward to going back.
author: tim b.

description: food was good, service was the worst. In fact, the service was so poor it really made the overall experience deserve a one star.  moreover, my husband (did not dine with us) phoned ahead to buy us a round of drinks as a special treat.  of course, the host and the waiter brought the drinks, but never said anything about the gift from my husband.  And they overcharged my husband!  My husband wrote an email and called/left a message at the restaurant to inquire about the overcharge and the fact that they messed up.  It has been a week -- no return call or email.   There are too many other great restos in SF to put up with this kind of schlocky service.  I'll be taking my business elsewhere.
author: D H.

description: Salumi plate! Omg I am still trying to remember which is which. And great entrees with nice wine. It made our girls night out perfect. The only drawback is its iPad. I love that thing, but not as a menu.
author: Joanne X.

description: Two thumbs up for this place, seriously.  I had been to Perbacco before, and was very impressed, so I definitely went in with high expectations--all of which were met.  The atmosphere was great....busy and high energy, but not too crowded.  Our server was sweet, attentive (but not overly so) and very knowledgeable about the menu and wine list.  All of her recommendations were great--we ordered the pork ragu, flank steak and the 'egg' dish (almost like a veggie sausage scramble with two over-easy eggs on top....SO DELISH).   We also got a scoop of their chocolate, butterscotch crunch gelatto, which was the perfect finishing touch to our meal.  To top it all off, the prices were VERY reasonable (I'm talking $5-$10 a plate for the majority of the dishes).  I would go back here in a heartbeat and would highly recommend it to anyone looking for a fun, after work (or anytime, really) spot with great, affordable food, and a lively atmosphere.
author: Liz L.

description: love this place terrific food, the wine is magnifico & service superior- went 3x last month!
author: Maribeth G.

description: Considering how much I love Perbacco, I was destined to like this place. And I did. The iPads are a bit too gimmicky (and really don't add any value), especially since it's limited to the wine and drink list. Loved almost everything we ordered, especially the lasagna -- except the squid dish (wayyyyy too salty). Great ambiance, good service and chatty but knowledgeable bar staff. Thumbs up.
author: Lemon S.

description: I came here with lunch with some coworkers.  Unfortunately we got here right after the first round of people got seated so we had to sit at a communal table with a table of two.  The tables are a bit close together so it was a little tough trying to tune them out.  The food was so good though so once it came out it was well worth it!  We tried the meatballs, the pasta with pork ragu, the porchetta sandwich, the cauliflower, the brussel sprouts and the three bruschetta sampler.  Everything was pretty hearty and good.  Portions were a decent size but you aren't going to leave completely stuffed.  My favorite bruschetta type was the pate.  Loved it!!  My pasta was delish and very similar to the pasta ragu at Perbacco.  Also cauliflower side had bacon or pancetta which really amped up the flavor and the brussel sprouts were the best I've ever had!  Finally, I like how they don't try to push bottled water on you.  It's just not pretentious like that.  Instead they filter both flat and sparkling water in house and give you the choice.  You can get away with spending about $15 here for lunch if you just get an entrée which isn't cheap but given that you are in the financial district, is not outrageous by any means.  Solid quick lunch place to have a special meal but make sure to come early.  Obviously it's not as upscale as Perbacco which is also awesome but well worth it for the price point.
author: Susan L.

description: atmosphere is classy, tasteful and well-executed. delicious tapas-style portions for sharing with a table and very well-presented dishes. excellent place for lunch in the financial district.
author: Torrpedo T.

description: Delicious food and excellent service.   I had lunch here last week and was impressed.   The duck liver pate on bruschette was creamy and rich.  The brussel sprouts in duck fat were crispy and flavorful.  Great rustic pork ragu - nicely balanced sauce and meat.
author: workingstiff f.

description: Wow what a great meal! My man and I had mo trouble gettingin on a Saturday night at 8pm and the restaurant was only 60% full. We sat at the bar, which was nice and modern like the rest of the decor. The most modern aspect were the iPad drink menus, which was a nice touch but since you couldn't actually order your drink on the iPad, it seemed like an excessive accessory. But back to the point, the food was all excellent! We had the potato soup of the day, bruschetta (3 pieces for $8: sardines, roasted pear & gorgonzola, and the roasted pepper & ricotta), the sicilian meatballs and the Farro risotto with mushrooms (the pasta serving were very generous! Enough to share for 2). Everything was perfectly cooked and seasoned... and for dessert we got their gelato (made in-house): one scoop for a mere $2 makes it a good option if you want a sweet finish to your meal without over stuffing yourself...they had some tempting flavors ( chocolate-marshmallow, torrone, sorbetto) but we got the caramel-chocolate chunk which was really good (lots of chocolate!) All that plus a glass of wine and a beer was a surprisingly low $65 with tax and tip. I'd definitely go back!
author: Grace M.

description: What a great lunch spot. The price is amazingly low for FiDi. Food is delicious. Meatballs are a tad too salty for me so you might want to eat it with a side dish. Pork Sandwich is delicious. The meat is so tender. it melts in your mouth. Brussel Sprouts is a must. If only all greens can taste like this. I wouldn't mind being a vegetarian.
author: Lynn W.

description: I had reservations at Barbacco (8-FEB-11) for  2, but arrived with 4. I asked the hostess if she could squeeze in 2 more people on my reservation and she said probably not, but I can get all of you in, but the wait will be 45 minutes to 1 hour.  Three of us squeezed into a "table", really just a ledge by the hostess desk and ordered some wine and a few appetizers while we waited for our 4th person, hoping that the hostess would find something for us.  Even though the spot we were in was more for 2 people, the hostess and the waiter were very accommodating. The hostess was exceptional and really tried to get all of us in, she was so pleasant considering we were being a bit of pain.  I always appreciate anyone who goes out of their way to make the customer happy.  I'll be back :-)
author: Sandra P.

description: Came with a couple friends the other night and was seriously impressed.  We tried all sorts of things on the menu, the lasagna was amazing and the chicken thighs were cooked perfectly and in a wonderfully tasty sauce.  We also tried some of the cheeses and bruschetta's and were not disappointed.  The only reason it doesn't get 5 stars is that they don't serve cocktails and I was not that excited about their beer list.
author: Ibbi A.

description: great italian fare in the financial district.  i've only come here for work lunches but it's never disappointed.  burrata cheese, brussel sprouts, and porchetta sandwich are some faves.
author: Helen T.

description: Came here for a birthday dinner with a group of 7 girls.  We had reservations on a Saturday night but we still had to wait another 20-30 minutes to be seated.  They give you an IPAD so you can order drinks from which was pretty cool.  We had a pitcher of sangria while waiting for our table.  The sangria was really good!  A little light and sweeter than other places I've had it.  Food was for the most part pretty good.  Most of the plates are little tapas style plates so sharing with 6 other girls you might need to order doubles.  We had the ribs which was okay.  The duck liver was excellent - nice and moussey with some cherries on top.  Good balance.  The pork ragu was good.  We had some kind of salami that didnt come in a tube but was more like a paste you put on bread but was good.  The fried pork cutlet was okay. The spinach lasagna was excellent.   We each ordered a plate and I would say i wasn't stuffed but was just okay.  Would probably order a little more since the plates were on the small side.
author: Ha T.

description: Delicious...what a great find in the financial district!  Definitely get an order of the meatballs - the best I've ever had.  The beet salad and bruschetta (we tried the fresh pea & mushroom) were also great.  Only thing that was overrated were the brussel sprouts.  Excellent service & good wine menu.
author: Anne D.

description: Have been there twice for dinner since they opened.  LOVE it!  Can't wait to go again.  It's food for sharing, which not everyone is into.  I love to be able to try different things. Everything we've had has been outstanding.  Plus the staff is super knowledgeable about the wines. Now they have their drink menus on iPads - how chic!
author: Kris H.

description:
What can I say.. I am impressed.  
I don't go downtown to eat much anymore (at least, not for dinner), and wasn't sure what to expect.  My first impression of the place was being handed an ipad with the beer/wine list on it while we waited for our table.  Cool, except when I realized you can't actually order drinks from it.  Then it became a pretty paperweight.  Don't really get that.
Aside from that, the food was way more than I expected.  Incredible plates, and so reasonable too... $5-$16 a dish?!  Unheard of for the quality you get.  We ate a lot, and I apologize, but food coma prevents me from remembering everything we had.  A couple of things that stand out in my mind were the brussels sprouts, and the meatballs..  I was a little apprehensive about getting the meatballs because I'm not much of a raisin guy, but I have to admit, it added a nice depth to the dish.  Yum!  Will go back again and again.
author: tom s.

description: What a fun, vivacious evening had by all! The cuisine, service and ambience were perfect! We had two six tops and shared a wide variety of tasty items. Here are a few that we all loved: Burrata Cheese, Rucola, Grilled Filone, Olive Oil; Radicchio, Rucola, Lemon And Olive Oil, Shaved Parmigiano; a wonderful Salumi selection; Shared all of the bruschetta: House Cured Local Sardines, Radish, Salsa Verde, Duck Liver Pate, Balsamico, Onion Marmellata, House Cured Lonza, Fava Greens, Garlic, Chili and broccolini special --- to name a few; the Farrotto farro "risotto", roasted mushrooms, parmigiano reggiano (OMGoodness!!!, amazing, my favorite!!!!), Polpette pork meat balls with raisins and pine nuts braised chard, tomato sugo (YUMMY, even a non-meat eater had to try it at our table and LOVED it), Orecchiette with bitter greens was yummy; Quick Braised Squid tomato, chili, garlic, spicy pan grattato very good; Sole special was delicious; Old school lasagna; Fried Brussels Sprouts capers, anchovy, shallot-red wine vinaigrette - WOWZIERS! In fair balance, the only item that did not make the "cut" with our group was the Nduja housemade spicy calabrian salame, crostini. The strong pork flavor was overwhelming and just did not hit the mark as with all the other items. We finished with the cheese plate with four decadent cheeses, espresso's and cappuccino's.  Thank you Barbacco, we will definitely be back soon and hope to bring new folks to enjoy your wonderful place!
author: georgie g.

description: I was never a big Perbacco fan--lacked soul, or something--but this new offshoot is a different story.  I liked the sleek, sophisticated decor, and the servers who were all wearing the same shirt, a sure tipoff that you're in the financial district, not the Mission; my server and wine consultant was Gretchen, a real delight.  They have quite an extensive menu, all reasonably priced, and a good assortment of Italian wines.  I tried the calamari, served with a spicy tomato sauce, which was superb, followed by the meatballs (good, but not life changing) and the roasted cauliflower.  Definitely will be back for further samplings.
author: David T.

description: Really, really like this restaurant.  Everything I've tried is delicious and the best part is how affordable it is.  It is perfect to grab dinner after work.
author: Liz D.

description: I'd come here for every meal, every day, if my arteries would allow it.  I easily made reservations for my friend and I to have dinner here last Friday via OpenTable (oddly, the website says they don't take reservations for less than 6 people....good thing I don't pay attention to such things).  The place is very clean, open floorplan, but not obnoxiously noisy.  Our service was excellent, my friend and I never were in need of the basics such as water or bread, and the dishes came out at a nice place (not too quick to feel like we were being rushed out, but also not so slow).  We actually just had the appetizers, as Barbacco makes it's own salumi.  It was all delicious, especially the spreadable nduja (get two of those - don't make the same mistake I did).  My friend and I definitely plan on coming back, and experiencing the dishes, which I have no doubt will be delicious.  I love Barbacco, definitely coming back here as much as I can.
author: Ria D.

description: One of my colleagues took me there for lunch a couple of weeks ago.  The ipad was a little too 'cool' for me. It would have been easier to look through a single page wine list.  I had the Polpette and the fried Brussel sprouts.  Both of which I thought were outstanding.  For dessert I had the fruit tart that I thought was good.   The wait staff was very friendly.
author: Pramod J.

description: My positive expereince started out when I called to make a reservation. The person who answered the phone was very friendly and polite. Upon arriving, I immediate liked the ambiance -- super fun and modern. The food was fantastic - we ordered a wide variety of options. Favorites were the arancini, the burrata cheese on grilled crostone (so good we had to order seconds, the brussel sprouts, and patate in padella. I didn't love the olive oil crushed spring peas bruschetta, but my friend enjoyed it. Not so good were the seared padrone peppers / sea salt / basil -- just a little bit blah... our server was phenomenal -- she was cheerful and attentive and really made the evening fun. Can't wait to go back soon!
author: rachel s.

description: Went there again with a buddy and tis time we had the farro rissotto, the bruschetta and the pate. All very good. Wine service was outstanding in terms of explaining what's what and giving us a taste before we bought. Why aren't more restaurants in the bay area this customer focused?
author: Jay K.

description: Great, reasonably priced food paired with yummy wines and great service makes Barbacco one of my new "go to" places in SF.  Satisfying, tasty food + good wine pairings for about $100 for two people = worth a return trip or three.
author: Amy A.

description: First time there last week.  Everything was pretty good.  Need to go back for Round 2 before I can give it more stars.  Good news first.  They have a really good beer with a hint of watermelon.  Sounds sweet, but it was really slight and refreshing.  Def going back for happy hour beers.  Appetizers were great, had the grilled peppers and a few other things.  Wasn't a big fan of the salami because we thought it would be sliced meat and bread, it was "served warm" and mashed like a pate or spread.  Tasted really good on the toasted bread, but I prefer my meats cold and sliced.  Still good though.  Only complaint I have was the disappointing lasagna.  It was spinach pasta noodles, but you could barely even see (or taste) the pasta because there was way too much cheese.  I love baked cheese, but this was overwhelming.  That's the only reason I wouldn't give it 4 stars. And I do wish there were a few more pasta dishes, there were only four.   But I'm definitely going back to try more little plates and to give the entrees another shot.
author: Eli G.

description: Pate with cherries very good as is the farro risotto and chekcen thighs.  A little hard to hear and the table seating is shared, which I dislike but it is a bit of a bar scene at lunch so if you are looking for this it is a find. They keep an ipad on table for wine but you can't order from it you can just mark your faves.
author: colleen o.

description:
first time at barbacco


so far the best impression and experience! didn't make a reservation so my friend and I got one of the tables far in the back of the restaurant.. surprised I was when are "table" was in the back counter not what I expected, but I understand that for the time that we came in the place was busy! so we agree taking the counter, after all of being a busy night the attention and service was great we did enjoy watching the pantry guy making delicious salad and desserts! we try the pate brusquette and the lardo! witch it sounded at little weird when the server describe what lardo was "cured pork back fat with rosemary and salt" ......... it was amazing! good stuff! than had the the burrata crostone quite good, angry mussels and and farroto good dishes! wine recommendations and food went great! also the pantry guy felt that we were looking too much at what he was doing and kindly he gave us information about the dishes he prepare and made us feel comfortable.
 another thing... be careful with the mirror when you go to the bathroom!

great food 
great wines
tables mmm ok... i accept that is a small restaurant for how busy it gets
atmosphere fun! and a little bit loud, but have to remind that is a casual restaurant.
service was great!
price range- great! for the quality of food and and service!

 i will come back for lardo brus and the killers angry mussels!!!

cheers!

 I know theres too many greats! but this is what this place has great things. :-D
author: Leo P.

description: I went with the idea in my head that the menu looked like OTTO in New York so though they are a country apart and obviously different owners, I foolishly hoped for the same impeccable service, food and ambience at Barbacco I have had on my visits to OTTO.  Bouncing back and forth between bites on small plates and sips of several tasting pours of wine is one of me and my husband's favorite things to do together.  Instead of a relaxed evening at BarBacco, we found big TVs, mediocre food, and since were sat at the bar in front of the Garde Manger, we not only got the pleasure of watching her unload pre-packaged frozen meat products (tartare or 'Nduja?) we also "got" to watch her close up shop, scrub everything down, etc. Bad, Barbacco!
author: christi f.

description:
I haven't been to very many restaurants in the fi-di since I moved to SF and had been hearing the buzz about this place. I stopped in for dinner with a friend last Thursday and it was already packed at 5:30 with the after-work crowd so I was relieved we had made a reservation. 

The server was very friendly and patient, as it took us a while to make decisions, being slightly overwhelmed by their extensive menu. We started off with some wine and a variety of small bites while we pondered the menu. The ascolane (fried olives stuffed w/ pork) were delish and I would also recommend the 'nduja (spicy smoked salame served w/ grilled crostino)..the flavor was powerful and perfectly spicy yumm. The mortadella literally melts in your mouth-another worthy choice.
Instead of ordering full entree dishes we decided to keep sampling the small plates so we ordered 3 bruschettes, my favorite being the brocolli rabe/chili...it was simple yet exploding with flavor.
Lastly if you like brussel sprouts then this is the place! they're lightly friend and oh-so-yummy! 
I will definitely be returning soon, not only because it made for an enjoyable and very satisfying evening, but also because we didn't even have enough room to try any of the pastas or main dishes. I have no regrets since everything we had was amazing but I can only imagine how delicious the rest of the menu is..next time you're in the mood for unique Italian-influenced tasty bites (or a full meal) make a reservation or just stop by if you don't mind waiting....after all there is a full bar and impressive wine selection to keep you occupied while you wait :)
author: Alison W.

description: I was there for lunch and it was very busy. We had share a table with other lunchers. The place is very high end and the food was great and tasted authentic Italian. ( I had their Martadella sandwitch). I think they bake the bread there or it's brought in fresh daily. you need a reservation for lunch or you'll miss your afternoon appointment.
author: Bess T.

description: i tried this place out the other day. the food was divine. i stuffed my face! the truffle marscapone OMG... i almost licked the jar. not even joking.
author: Lola r.

description: San Franciscans! Haven't you ever been to Italy?? Barbacco is another SF hype job with a trendy interior and an attitude. Ordered the pesce crudo, small but tasty. Bread you have to "order" i.e. pay for separately. Settled on focaccia which came hard, dry, cold and (excuse me for saying it) stale. When we complained we were told they don't serve stale bread. Oops, our mistake. The"farotto" and the pork ragu were so overcooked that you could have gummed them to death without "dente". The pork ribs were over salted and, except for the salt, tasteless. We are Italian and I asked the snooty manager if she was, knowing she wasn't. "What!" she said "I have to be Italian to work here? Well, no, but it would help if she knew what good Italian food is. We are ashamed that San Franciscans classify that place as Italian. Per bacco loosely translates as "for heaven's sake". Bar bacco  translates as "don't bother".
author: Shelley S.

description: Being that we really like Perbacco, we wanted to give Barbacco a try. The menu is less expensive than Perbacco and the restaurant has a more casual feel which I think it is a great idea during these tough times! First off, the menu is extensive - similar to Perbacco. We had a tough time trying to pick what we wanted to try! We settled on the marinated sardines and a radicchio salad to start. My boyfriend definitely picked a winner with the sardines. I don't even like sardines and thought they were delicious. The salad was your usual salad but I was trying to be good since I chose the meatballs for my main. Now it was my boyfriend's turn to have a bit of food envy. He ordered the pork short ribs which were good, but the meatballs were unbelievably tasty! I normally would not order meatballs, but I had read a very good review on them, so I encourage others to try them too. I doubt you will be disappointed! We also ordered a side of the cauliflower which was good but not the best I have had. SPQR I would say has the best when they have them. We were too full for dessert but had one of their cheeses which was a nice end to the meal. They only serve beer and wine at this restaurant so be prepared if for any reason you are craving a cocktail. We had one beer, an ice tea and 2 coffee drinks and the total bill came to under $70 without tip. Definitely recommend trying this restaurant and we will be back to try more of the menu!
author: M S.
